HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies After the Swiss Say Their Franc Is Overvalued

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied yesterday, bolstered by a selloff in the Swiss franc, which tumbled after Swiss officials said the currency was overvalued.
The dollar was also helped by selling of pounds by traders to lock in profits and by renewed optimism on the prospects for Europe's planned single currency, a development that weakened the German mark. 
 In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5178 marks from 1.5109 on Wednesday and to 114.05 yen from 113.94. The pound, which surged on Wednesday after a rise in British interest rates, fell yesterday to $1.6280 from $1.6337.
The Swiss franc is one of the most stable currencies. But it began to weaken after finance officials reiterated their view that the franc was overvalued despite a reduction of interest rates last month to the lowest levels in nearly 20 years.
The high cost of the Swiss franc is hurting Switzerland's economy by making its exports more expensive. But low interest rates in Switzerland have failed to reduce the currency's attraction for global investors seeking a haven for their money.
Switzerland's Finance Minister, Kaspar Villiger, said after a conference in Zurich that the franc was likely to fall. The Swiss central bank's chief economist, Georg Rich, in an interview in the weekly Swiss newspaper Handels Zeitung, said the franc's strength was contributing to Switzerland's economic weakness. Traders bought marks and dollars in response, bolstering them relative to the Swiss franc. In New York, the dollar surged to 1.2680 Swiss francs, up from 1.2541 on Thursday.
"We just rocketed higher," said Ben Strauss, a trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer & Company. "We had a continuation of the jawboning from central bank ministers in Switzerland that the Swiss franc is overvalued."
Andrew Hodge, a currency strategist at Bank Brussels Lambert in New York, said the Swiss franc was also undermined by rumors that the Swiss would ease their tight bank secrecy. Recent revelations about Swiss bank collaboration with the Nazis in World War II have focused attention on Switzerland's confidential banking practices.
In other trading, a strengthening Mexican peso closed at a level of 7.93 to the dollar yesterday, a day after passing the eight-to-the-dollar level for the first time since the Mexican economic crisis began in late 1994.

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
What Reagan Left Behind: More Than Some Jokes

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
The Reagan Presidency, still able to provoke arguments among politicians and historians, comes under scrutiny in "The Reagan Legacy" on "Discovery Journal." Sunday's opening hour focuses on what has come to be known as Reaganomics; Monday brings back the Strategic Defense Initiative, a k a Star Wars. Both have figured in the Presidential campaign now reaching its climax or anticlimax, and both, by this incisive account, sprang full-blown from Mr. Reagan's philosophy and personality.
Relying largely on eminences in the Reagan White House, "Balancing Act" on Sunday tells of how candidate Reagan's promise of a balanced budget gave way to President Reagan's determination to cut taxes and build up the nation's military. 
 Particularly sharp attention is given to the deals with which the Administration bought the votes of conservative Democrats for a big tax cut. Donald Regan, then Secretary of the Treasury, says: "You would accuse these Congressmen of being too narrow in their prejudices and say, 'Look, we're looking at the common good,' and they would say, 'Yes, but we weren't elected by the common good, we were elected by our constituencies.' " The result was billions of dollars in sweeteners for oil and natural-gas producers, sugar and peanut growers, real-estate interests and like groups.
Former Treasury Department officials tell of trying, to little avail, to protect the budget. Supply-side economics and heavy military spending ("Whatever Cappy wants Cappy gets," says one of them, referring to Caspar W. Weinberger, the Reagan Secretary of Defense) brought short-term prosperity and an enormous deficit that continues to weigh on the nation.
"Star Wars," on Monday, is an equally sharp account of how Mr. Reagan's abhorrence of nuclear weapons led to the Pentagon's spending billions on a scientifically dubious search for a weapon that could destroy space missiles in flight. Russian officials' recollections of the impact of the idea on the Kremlin, where it was seen as a destabilizing threat, are fascinating.
This report leaves us with the possibility that a notion that many even in the Pentagon considered wacky helped bring about Soviet-American detente. Speaking of Mr. Reagan's Moscow visit to Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1988, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, then the Soviet Ambassador to the United States, says: "He began as a No. 1 enemy and he ended, if I may put it this way, as No. 1 friend from the capitalist world."
Produced by the team that gave us the exemplary "Yugoslavia: Death of a Nation," and narrated by Garrick Utley, "The Reagan Legacy" attests that Ronald Reagan was not just a practiced television communicator and remarkably popular figure. For better and for worse, his simple but big ideas changed the course of American politics and world history.
 
'Why Can't I Be President?'
PBS, tonight at 10
(Channel 13 in New York)
If it's more obscure figures than Mr. Reagan you're after and more improbable causes than Star Wars, here they are: the environmentalist who wants to ban computers on the ground that they cause cancer; the evangelist who would assign the National Guard to shut down abortion clinics; an anti-plaque campaigner; a fellow who is alerting the rest of us to the danger that U.F.O.'s pose to shopping malls; the former nun who wants marijuana legalized, and others. Better catch them; this may be their first and last appearance in prime time.

HEADLINE: Japan Premier Did Too Well in Election to Form Solid Coalition

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Despite a resounding victory for his party in national elections, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is having difficulty forming a new governing coalition, raising the likelihood that Japan's next government will be fragile and indecisive.
Political experts say it now looks likely that Mr. Hashimoto's Liberal Democratic Party will not be able to put together a coalition that will give it a comfortable majority in the lower house of Parliament. 
 Instead, the Liberal Democrats might run a minority government, controlling the Cabinet but being forced to cooperate with other parties on a case-by-case basis to enact legislation. That could slow passage of laws to deregulate the economy or streamline Japan's bureaucracy.
"You're looking at the prospect of gridlock," said John Neuffer, a political analyst here. But he said the new government would not be in danger.
The Liberal Democratic Party took a step toward a minority government today when it agreed with its two partners in the current ruling coalition to cooperate on some policy issues, such as proposing a bill to reduce the number of ministries and agencies over five years.
The two parties, the Social Democrats and the New Party Sakigake, made it clear that they would not remain in a coalition with the Liberal Democrats and would not cooperate on all issues. The Social Democrats, for instance, are calling for a reduction in the number of United States marines stationed in Okinawa while the Liberal Democrats want to maintain current troop levels.
Mr. Hashimoto may attract enough independents and defectors from other parties to scrape together a majority by next Thursday, when the lower house of Parliament will meet in a special session to elect the new Prime Minister. It is certain to be him, even if his party does not have an absolute majority by then.
It was not supposed to turn out this way. The Oct. 20 election was seen as a resounding victory for the Liberal Democrats, who ruled Japan for most of the period since World War II until falling from power after voter disgust over corruption in 1993.
The Liberal Democrats won 239 seats in the 500-seat lower house, up from the 211 seats it held before. It would be relatively easy, it was thought, for the party to cobble together a majority and continue its conservative policies.
The problem, however, was that the L.D.P. won so many seats that it has scared away potential partners, which fear being dominated in a coalition. "Ironically, because the L.D.P. won a few seats too many, this government is turning out to be a weaker government," said Shigenori Okazaki, a political analyst for SBC Warburg Japan, a securities firm.
The Socialists were decimated in the last election, winning only 15 seats, down from the 30 they held before. Party officials say its longtime supporters deserted the party at the polls because it had abandoned its principles by entering into the coalition with the Liberal Democrats. The new Socialist leader, Takako Doi, has thus vowed to stay out of the coalition this time.
Mr. Hashimoto was also snubbed by the new Democratic Party, which won 52 seats.
Mr. Hashimoto will be able to count on the cooperation of a handful of independents. There have also been some defectors from the New Frontier Party, the largest opposition party, who could eventually join the Liberal Democrats.
Many members of the New Frontier Party are dissatisfied with the heavy-handed leadership of its chief, Ichiro Ozawa. The party seems to be in danger of disintegrating but Mr. Ozawa, a wily politician, has so far managed to hold it together.

HEADLINE: Stocks Climb as Investors See Low Inflation

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The stock market rose yesterday, paced by consumer-product makers like Procter & Gamble and Clorox, after falling commodity prices and a series of economic reports reinforced investors' perception of a slow-growth, low-inflation economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 36.15 points, to 6,029.38, its biggest jump in two weeks. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 4.37 points, to 705.27, while the Nasdaq composite index jumped 15.28 points, to 1,221.51. A total of 1,485 issues advanced on the Big Board, while 974 declined. Trading was heavier than usual, with 488.5 million shares changing hands. 
 Investors turned to consumer issues because those companies typically offer the most dependable earnings in a slowing economy.
The Government said 23,000 Americans filed first-time claims for unemployment benefits last week, more than the 15,000 expected. A separate Government report showed that consumer spending rose an unexpectedly small one-tenth of 1 percent.
Today, the Labor Department is scheduled to release its monthly report on the unemployment rate and the change in nonfarm payrolls for October. Reports that showed surprisingly strong job growth rattled the stock and bond markets earlier this year.
"People believe that this economy is slowing in a way that has the market thrilled," said John Hammerschmidt, a fund manager at Turner Investment Partners, which has $2.5 billion in assets. "Between rates and the economic numbers, it paints a great picture for the consumer stocks."
Among household-goods stocks, Procter & Gamble jumped 1 1/4, to 99; Clorox rose 2 1/4, to 108 7/8, and Colgate-Palmolive gained 1 1/2, to 92 1/8.
"With slow growth and no perceptible inflation, there is some fear corporate profits could slow, which helps the consumer stocks," said James Miller, a fund manager at Bartlett Capital with $2.4 billion in assets.
Among bank stocks, BankAmerica rose 1 to 91 1/2, Citicorp gained 1, to 99, and First Chicago NBD jumped 1 3/8, to 51.
Makers of computers and semiconductors gained after the Semiconductor Industry Association, an industry group, predicted fourth-quarter sales would rise, ending a nine-month slide.
I.B.M. rose 2 5/8, to 129; Intel climbed 3 1/8, to 109 7/8, and Novellus Systems gained 2 1/4, to 41 1/4.
Oil companies slumped as the price of oil fell. Texaco slipped 1 3/8, to 101 5/8; Chevron fell 1/2, to 65 3/4, and Mobil dropped 1 1/4, to 116 3/4.
Campbell Soup shares fell 3, to 80, after John T. Dorrance 3d, a relative of the founder, sold nine million shares in a single trade for $720 million. Campbell said it was the biggest trade of its shares ever.
Netscape Communications lost 1 7/8, to 44 1/4, after the company said it would sell five million shares in an additional stock sale.
Pharmacia & Upjohn dropped 1 3/4, to 36, after the company reported third-quarter net income before charges was unchanged from last year, in line with reduced profit forecasts.
Odwalla shares tumbled 6 1/4, to 12 1/8, after the company recalled its apple juice products following an outbreak of E. coli infections in Washington State linked to the company's juices.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Lowest Rate Since April On Long Bond

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond fell yesterday to its lowest level since April 1 after fresh data suggested that the economy was continuing to slow, with no sign of inflation.
The new numbers included a report that showed surprisingly high unemployment claims, easing market fears of wage pressures from a tight labor market. Traders said the broad-based buying ahead of today's more significant report on payrolls for October was also aided by a big drop in commodity prices. 
 The price of the 30-year bond increased 26/32 of a point, to 10114/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.64 percent from 6.70 percent. The 30-year bond is the benchmark by which many interest rates are set.
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said that the market was heading into the employment report close to the high end of the most recent trading range. But even if the report shows strong job growth in October, which normally would alarm the bond market, buyers eventually will surface, he said.
"Traders think that Friday could help define the next couple of months for the bond market," he said. "However, when you consider that investors still have cash to put to work and that inflation has made no signs of emerging from its long hibernation, even a bearish employment report could eventually take the market down to levels where these willing buyers reside."
Some of the early price gains were pared after a report showed strong manufacturing conditions in the Chicago region, because investors viewed that report as a signal that growth could rebound, causing inflation to accelerate. Economists had expected a drop.
Bonds initially gained on the Labor Department's weekly report of initial jobless claims for the period that ended on Oct. 26, as first-time claims rose by a larger-than-expected figure, 23,000, to a seasonally adjusted 342,000. Some traders had been expecting the figure to rise by 15,000.
The market extended gains on a weaker-than-expected rise in September consumer spending of one-tenth of 1 percent, down from a gain of half of 1 percent the previous month. Personal income rose six-tenths of 1 percent, largely a result of higher wages, as it had in August.
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a research analysis firm, said: "Although the increase in spending has trailed income through much of the past year, this does not mean that spending will accelerate. There have been many periods in the past when income growth has been healthy while spending has lagged. We expect spending growth to remain sluggish in the next several months as consumers strive to reduce debt burdens." He predicted that this would keep total economic growth moderate for the next six to nine months and would keep the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates.
The last time the central bank adjusted the Federal funds rate, the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans, was on Jan. 31, when the rate was lowered a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.25 percent.
The Chicago purchasing managers' index of factory activity rose to an unexpectedly high 56.9 points in October from 56.3 in September. Market participants had expected the overall number to drop to 53.0, and the rise led to a small decline in bond prices. However, the prices-paid component fell to 50.7 from 59.3 in September, and the employment component eased slightly, to 48.8 from 50.8 in September. Those drops, indicating that inflation remains in check, left the bullish tone to the bond market largely intact.
Also released yesterday was the Conference Board's help-wanted index, a gauge of the amount of employment advertising in newspapers, which rose to 84 points for September from 81 for August.
Taken together, the reports did little to alter the perception that economic growth is decelerating.
Market participants are waiting to see whether today's employment report will give them more indications of slowing growth. Economists expect it to show that the economy gained 203,000 jobs last month, slightly below the 205,000 average monthly gain so far this year.
In when-issued trading yesterday, investors paid a premium price, as the three-year Treasury note was being offered at a price to yield 5.90 percent, a drop of 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from the previous day. The reopened 10-year note was priced to yield 6.40 percent, down 7 basis points. And the 30-year bond had a drop of 6 basis points, to 6.65 percent.

HEADLINE: How Conrail Became A Hot Ticket;
Global Trade, High Tech Lift Railroad 'Basket Case'

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J.

 BODY:
Derided as "a basket of basket cases" when the Government created it from the ruins of six bankrupt railroads two decades ago, today Conrail Inc. is a corporate jewel at the heart of the biggest railroad merger battle ever. Conrail has worked hard to modernize, but a visit to Port Elizabeth underscores that the railroad itself is only part of this Cinderella story.
Day after day, Conrail freight trains bring hundreds of truck-size containers filled with products for export to a mammoth dock on Newark Bay here. Unloading is so rapid that some containers are on ships on their way out to the Atlantic within hours. And each day, a similar mountain of containers recently plucked by cranes from ships arriving from Europe, Asia, Africa and Latin America, ride Conrail trains back into the American heartland, filled with clothing, beer, electronics, toys and other goods. 
 Express Rail, as the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey calls the transfer service, handles only a small part of the cargo here at the East Coast's busiest port. It also is just a sliver of Conrail's multi-billion-dollar operations.
But Express Rail did not exist at all six years ago. Its rapid growth is a product of railroad deregulation, new technology and shifting patterns of world trade -- the same factors that have made Conrail an increasingly valuable piece of the nation's freight transportation system.
The dollar value of Conrail's near monopoly on freight transport over tracks that run as far west as Chicago and as far south as Maryland is not settled. Conrail's preferred merger partner is CSX, the giant rail and shipping company based in Richmond that recently offered more than $8 billion in cash and stock. Norfolk Southern, which is both wooing and suing to win Conrail away from CSX, has offered $9 billion.
Conrail, formally known as the Consolidated Rail Corporation, was created by the Government in a multibillion-dollar bailout of the bankrupt Penn Central and other Northeastern railroads two decades ago. The Chessie System merged with the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad to form CSX.
The contest for Conrail comes on the heels of the Union Pacific Railroad's $5.4 billion marriage to the Southern Pacific, itself a response to the merger of the Burlington Northern and Santa Fe railroads in 1995. The deals are defended as necessary to increase efficiency and profits, but, as Express Rail shows, railroads have not relied on consolidation alone.
"The railroads have snuck up on people," said J. Ganson Evans, a Conrail marketing executive who courts customers for Express Rail and other Conrail terminals near the port that also handle container traffic. "People are surprised at what we are doing today."
What Conrail and other lines are doing is slowing, and in some cases reversing, a decades-long loss of business to the trucking industry. While the public perception is that railroads are crumbling because passenger service is notoriously bad compared with other countries, freight shippers say the American rail network is the best and most efficient in the world.
Railroads' share of freight traffic, measured by tonnage and distance carried, rose to 40.6 percent last year, from 36.4 percent in 1985, according to Mercer Management, a transportation consulting firm based in Lexington, Mass.
The recovery has its roots in deregulation of the industry in 1980, four years after the Government began pouring billions into the dying Penn Central and five other lines to replace dilapidated track and rolling stock. Deregulation allowed railroads to drop costly branch lines that generated little traffic, and to quickly add new services to make better use of main lines like those Conrail uses to move goods from here to Chicago, Detroit and other inland hubs. It also freed them to rapidly change prices to meet competition from the far more flexible and reliable truckers.
"The key is, unlike anywhere else in the world, you have the opportunity to have truly commercial railroads," said William Rennicke, a rail specialist at Mercer Management. "Our productivity is 2 or 3 times greater than in Western Europe and 10 or 20 times that in other parts of the world."
Express Rail is just one of many new services contributing to the freight railroads' slow but unmistakable renaissance. In the West, 110-car trains ferry a single valuable product, low-sulfur coal, from the Powder River basin of Wyoming to distant power plants.
On the East Coast, CSX transports a million gallons of Tropicana orange juice from Bradenton, Fla., to Philadelphia three times a week on 65-car trains that it turns over to Conrail for a last leg to Kearny, N.J.
Many services like Express Rail -- called intermodal because they use two or more modes of transportation -- exploit the huge cost advantage that railroads have over long distance trucking by carrying truck trailers that can be attached to cabs near their final destination and containers that can go on either ships or trucks.
"Intermodal has been growing because railroads continue to bring their costs down and improve the reliability of their service," said Donald Schneider, president of Schneider National Inc. The Green Bay, Wis., trucking giant has seen its intermodal business with railroads grow 30 percent a year.
Huge productivity gains have come from relatively straightforward improvements like raising road overpasses and enlarging tunnels enough to stack containers two high. As the improvements were completed, it became cheaper and faster to land goods pouring out of booming factories in Japan and Korea at West Coast ports and ship them across the country by rail than to ship them to the East Coast via the Panama Canal.
Conrail spent $64 million on such improvements in Pennsylvania alone to create an eastbound container route south of its main line across New York. West Coast container services then could reach terminals around Harrisburg, the Port of Philadelphia, and, with a handoff to the Norfolk Southern in Hagerstown, Md., cities further south.
The rail bridge from California grew at the expense of East Coast ports like the Port of New York and New Jersey. But now, with manufacturing moving to Southeast Asia, the same improvements to the rail network are making it attractive to ship containerized goods from there to New York via the Suez Canal and then into the Midwest by rail.
The benefits of increased global trade have been enhanced by investments in a variety of new technologies. Conrail and others are buying a new generation of locomotives powerful enough to do the work of two of their predecessors. Computerized dispatch centers control traffic more efficiently; satellites are used to pinpoint and repair breakdowns more quickly.
The railroads' economic revival cost 270,000 railroad employees their jobs from 1980 to 1995, about 60 percent of the total. Conrail's work force was cut to 23,500 from 96,000.
On the other hand, the railroads' comeback has revived locomotive and rail car manufacturing, saved shippers billions of dollars a year, stimulated world trade and influenced many domestic activities in ways the average citizen might not realize, like allowing utilities to meet clean air regulations by switching to low-sulfur Western coal instead of installing expensive scrubbers. Rail revenue, meanwhile, rose to $32.28 billion last year, from $28.26 billion in 1980. Operating profits doubled to $2.86 billion.
"The railroads, which were laid out a century ago to serve passengers, have finally found their niche serving commerce," said Robert Voltman, director of policy for the National Industrial Transportation League, a Washington-based trade group of manufacturers and other major shippers. "They are now in a battle to expand that niche."
The battle is tough because many customers are moving targets that are easier for truckers to hit. Railroads typically figure they are on schedule if they pick up and deliver within 24 hours of when they are expected, a big improvement from the days when the window was several days at least. But truckers generally show up within 15 minutes of the time they promise. That is a huge advantage in the just-in-time era, when manufacturers do not want materials until they are ready to process them, and retailers do not want products delivered before they are needed on the shelves.
"We use rail shipping from plants to our own warehouses, but our customers are now specifying what time of day we have to deliver," said Thomas Weikart, director of global logistics for Owens Corning, which spends about $380 million a year shipping Fiberglas insulation and other goods. "Intermodal is getting very reliable, but if I have to go 500 miles and it has to be there tomorrow, I still use trucks. I'll pay a 5 percent to 10 percent premium to get them."
The biggest problem for the railroads may be overcoming their reputation for indifference, even arrogance, in dealing with many customers. Until deregulation, they paid little attention to selling themselves.
Conrail, by virtue of its monopoly position, has generally received lower marks than most lines on that score, but those working with it say the situation has improved. Port Authority executives, for instance, say they had to lobby hard to convince Conrail that Express Rail would bring new business to both of them. But once Conrail made the commitment, it became a responsive partner, they say.
Big customers with a choice of carriers naturally see the biggest improvements. Transportation executives at the Ford Motor Company say Norfolk Southern participated in designing a new vehicle distribution system that is expected to cut inventory costs.
The railroad is setting up new yards where Ford will send vehicles from several factories, allowing trains to be filled and dispatched to dealers more quickly. And both Norfolk Southern and CSX have asked to be included in planning new methods for handling incoming components to Ford plants.
"They recognize they have to be more than just movers of goods," said Wade Deal, director of supply chain management for Ford. "Their share of our business could grow substantially."
But many more customers say railroads are still run by people who care more about convenient operations than customers. And retailing experts agree.
"I still haven't seen the rail industry come up with clever service ideas," said Robert Sabath, a retailing expert in Mercer Management's Chicago office. "It's been their customers pushing them. They used to be one on a one-to-10 scale of customer service. Now they are a 3."
Wall Street, although nervous about whether Norfolk Southern or CSX will end up overpaying for Conrail, has generally been pleased. Rising profits and the prospect of still more mergers as Conrail and its rivals jockey for leverage with customers have lifted rail stocks more than 12 percent in the last year.
But with just four railroads controlling 95 percent of interstate rail traffic once Conrail is married off, customers and other participants in the transportation system are increasingly anxious. Many fear price increases or service cuts. Even those anticipating improvements, like the Port of New York and New Jersey, worry that the railroads' efforts to be more competitive could shift business away from them, just as new shipping routes shifted cargo away from it before.
"What seems to be a modest improvement in the price or service a railroad offers to a particular destination can have a huge impact on where cargo goes," said Joseph Curnyn, the facility supervisor at the Port Authority's New Jersey marine terminal.

HEADLINE: With Insurers' Payment, Exxon Says Valdez Case Is Ended

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Seven years after the Exxon Valdez supertanker ran aground off Alaska, spilling oil in one of the worst environmental disasters ever, the Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it was closing the books on attempts to recover its costs from scores of insurance companies, with a final settlement installment of $480 million.
The agreement, reached yesterday in discussions in the United States and Britain, brought Exxon's total recovery to $780 million. Company officials said the disaster had cost Exxon $2.5 billion before the insurance recovery. 
 Lee R. Raymond, the company's chairman, said it was "pleased that these claims have been resolved."
William Pitt, a spokesman in the United States for Lloyd's of London, which had provided the largest share of insurance on the supertanker, said his company was "glad a settlement has been reached."
Eugene Anderson, a New York lawyer whose firm is a leader in representing big corporations and individuals against insurance companies, said the settlement reflected a growing trend in the insurance industry.
"The insurance companies initially deny virtually all large claims," Mr. Anderson said, "because in the end there is usually a compromise and they end up paying much less than the amount of the claim."
In addition, he said, by delaying payment, the insurers are able to continue investing the disputed money, earning profit on the funds at risk. "They pay lawyers much less each year in these cases than they earn in interest," he said.
Mr. Anderson estimated that the $780 million paid by Equitas, a company recently established to pay previous claims against Lloyd's, and by more than 250 other insurers, was half what Exxon had initially requested. Neither Exxon nor Lloyd's would disclose the size of the original claim.
Mr. Pitt said that "claims on this scale do sometimes lead to differences of opinion over the coverage that was available."
But he said "it is a very small fraction of total claims in which you have litigation of this kind."
One contention of the insurance companies has been that they should not have been held liable because the ship's captain, Joseph J. Hazelwood, had a history of alcohol abuse. Mr. Hazelwood has been acquitted of charges of operating the tanker while drunk.
Mr. Pitt said the claim in the Exxon Valdez disaster had been one of the largest on the books of Lloyd's as it struggled through several years of heavy losses in the late 1980's and early 90's.
Lloyd's officials said the venerable international insurance organization had been near financial collapse in September, when investors, regulators and a series of courts agreed that it could form a new company, Equitas, to take responsibility for Lloyd's liabilities for 1992 and earlier.
The disputed claims began moving toward conclusion in January with a partial settlement of $300 million.
In June, a jury in a state court in Texas, where Exxon has its headquarters, awarded the oil company $250 million, and a judge increased the amount to $410 million to cover Exxon's legal expenses and what he calculated to have been the interest that would have accumulated since the start of the case.
The agreement reached yesterday encompassed the Texas judgment, and, with an increase in the amount due from the insurers of $70 million, brought an end to two cases pending in New York and headed off yet another suit that Exxon had said it was considering bringing against the insurance companies in Texas.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE THIRD PARTY;
Perot, on the Stump, Goes on the Attack

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31

 BODY:
As the 1996 campaign draws to a close, the nation is seeing another side of Ross Perot.
Four years ago, his enemy was George Bush, and his weapons were charts, graphs and homespun lectures on the economy that were broadcast from television studios. 
 At first this year, he tried the same tactics, but could not dig himself out of single digits in the polls. So now, he has switched strategies.
In the last week, the Reform Party candidate has embraced an old-fashioned kind of politicking by barnstorming across the country and trying to energize students and other young voters.
He has also more broadly attacked President Clinton, attacking his character. And with recent disclosures about questionable foreign contributions to the Democratic Party, Mr. Perot has been able to freshen his speeches with talk about campaign finance, his signature cause.
The new approach may be working. For the first time in this campaign, he has climbed out of the single digits in some polls and has shown an upward movement in the major, daily tracking polls.
Although the numbers by no means put him in a position to overtake the other candidates, they suggest that he may be connecting with more voters.
Here at the University of Pennsylvania, Mr. Perot attacked Mr. Clinton and the Democrats on the issue of campaign finance.
"If you will give a $100,000 to the Democrats, you can spend the night in the Lincoln Bedroom," Mr. Perot said. "That offends me to my soul because working people -- plumbers, electricians, people working the third shift -- pay the full cost of the White House with their taxes. And if I am your President, you will have my word, we will put a sign all across Washington -- 'Not for sale at any price.' "
Saying that Mr. Clinton sent an aircraft carrier group to protect Taiwan after that country's ruling party offered the Democrats $15 million, Mr. Perot said here: "Do you want a President who puts the lives of the armed forces at risk and manipulates foreign policy in exchange for $15 million in political contributions? If you do, don't vote for me on Nov. 5 because hell will freeze over before I do that."
 Mr. Perot has also found a new voice with attacks on Mr. Clinton's character, a standard campaign technique that Mr. Perot, a critic of partisan-politics-as-usual, has long criticized.
For example, in his speeches here and in Blacksburg, Va., at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University on Monday, he posed sarcastic, rhetorical questions about Mr. Clinton's lack of a military record.
"If you were wounded on the battlefield, you're lying out there in no man's land, you only got three survivors in your platoon and they are the three candidates for President, who do you think is going to come out there and drag you back to safety?" Mr. Perot, who served in the Navy, asked his audience here.
Applauding and laughing, the students roared, "Ross!"
Trying to remind his audience of Mr. Clinton's past marital problems and accusations that he was a womanizer, Mr. Perot continued: "Here's one for all of the dads in the audience. Which of the three candidates would you be very comfortable having your daughter work for?" The crowd responded with more applause and laughter.
Mr. Perot then brandished a copy of an editorial in The New York Times last Sunday that endorsed Mr. Clinton but urged him to pledge not to pardon anyone convicted in prosecutions arising from Whitewater matters or fund raising for the 1996 campaign, among other things, and to cooperate with any investigations into these matters.
"Read this editorial," he said. "They are basically asking this man to have a character and integrity change in midlife."
The 1996 Perot campaign not only sounds different than it did four years ago; it also looks different.
Barred from the televised Presidential debates last month and unable to buy as much prime television time as he has wanted for 30-minute infomericals, Mr. Perot is campaigning more in public this time, making two personal appearances on many days since mid-October. He plans to continue that pace until Friday.
Four years ago, he largely ran his campaign from television studios, relying on his appearances in the Presidential debates and on his 12 infomercials between Oct. 17 and Election Day to reach voters. During the same time span, he made only seven public appearances.
"Keep in mind, in '92 we were doing more studio time," said Sharon Holman, press secretary for Mr. Perot and the Reform Party.
In a speech at the National Press Club in Washington last week, Mr. Perot acknowledged he had been forced to abandon the television studio he prefers for the traditional stump. "We've been pretty well frozen out this time around," he said, "but every now and then a blind hog finds an acre."
Most of Mr. Perot's rallies and speeches in recent weeks have been before college groups that have invited him to speak. These audiences have mostly been friendly and curious.
Mr. Perot's advisers say he is getting more support because of the perception that a vote for Mr. Dole could be a wasted vote in the event of a Clinton landslide.
They say this perception could lead some voters to give Mr. Perot and the Reform Party another look.

ROSS PEROT

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Munich in Washington

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
America at election time: two Chamberlains and not a Churchill in sight.
On Sept. 29, 1938, in Munich, Neville Chamberlain abandoned the 14 million people of Czechoslovakia to the German Nazis. It took the lives of tens of millions of Europeans and Americans to pay for that appeasement -- and the leadership of Winston Churchill, alone at first, then with Franklin D. Roosevelt. 
 More than a half-century later, in Washington on May 28, 1993, President Clinton abandoned the people of China and Tibet, 1.2 billion souls, to Communist mercy, in direct betrayal of his own official promise to do America's peaceful best to ease the bitterness of their oppression.
Bob Dole does not attempt Churchill's role. It probably never crossed his mind. Mr. Dole, as Senate majority leader and still, has supported Mr. Clinton's major appeasement step of surrendering any economic pressure for human rights in China. They had the same motivation: to please the U.S. lobby doing business with China.
From that day in May when Mr. Clinton publicly and without apparent shame canceled his own promise to use tariff pressure for human liberties, there was no doubt what would happen.
The incarceration and torture meted out to dissidents in China increased. So did China's military strength and influence abroad.
In the past couple of weeks certain things were reported by the press that give a hint of the depth and width of the iceberg that has formed beneath the appeasement policy, and of the costs yet to be paid by the victims, and Americans.
Jeff Gerth and David Sanger of the Washington bureau of The New York Times reported that the Chinese had illegally used part of an airplane order from McDonnell Douglas to build a factory producing missiles. Bill Gertz of The Washington Times reported that China was selling nuclear technology to the Pakistanis -- again. China was discovered selling more missiles to Iran. Robert S. Greenberger of The Wall Street Journal found Chinese agents roving the U.S. snapping up defense-related equipment at bargain prices.
Shock, shock: China uses profits from American trade to build up its armed forces. Why not? Most foreign trade with China is with companies owned by the armed forces, and the gentlemen running for President know it. The U.S. has become not so much the Communists' trading partner as their quartermaster.
Then on Wednesday, Beijing showed its contempt for the U.S. by sentencing the dissident Wang Dan to 11 more years in prison -- its answer to a request by Mr. Clinton that it free this man, innocent of any crime but expressing his opinion.
At least the Communists are true to their own principles and system. Repression is the Government's bloodstream. Tens of millions have sweated their lives away in slave-labor camps. Thousands of political prisoners are still incarcerated.
It is difficult to grasp what the Communists mean by prison, but important to try: years of fiendish torture, living in excrement, shackled to boards, beatings, starvation, slave labor and slow death. Is that China-made sweater still cozy? (Please put up with the pain of reading "Anthems of Defeat" (Asia Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York 10017).
Now the U.S. is sending Secretary of State Christopher to Beijing. Ho boy, that should frighten them. But I have a suggestion for him.
Harry Wu, that great man who suffered 19 years in Chinese prisons, keeps risking his life sneaking back to them -- to help the world remember. He writes of one slave factory in "Troublemaker," a fine, quietly terrifying new book, written with George Vecsey. It is a pipe plant. Its 2,000 workers sit at machinery with heads shaven and in prison uniforms.
Mr. Christopher can easily take a side trip there. It is at 1551 Beidi Road, right in the middle of Shanghai. It will be the most useful thing he can do in China; the prisoners may get a little extra rice that day.
At least Chamberlain could say Britain had no chance against Nazi power. All our two can say is that it is more profitable to appease Communist China with trade and security-risk deals than to stand up, without risking an American life, for decency for its captives -- maybe less time on the shackle boards.

HEADLINE: More Growth, a Recession, Or a 'Growth Recession'?

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
On Wednesday it was the Government tally showing that the nation's growth rate fell by more than half over the summer. Today, figures showed that consumer spending barely budged in September, rising less than inflation. And the General Motors strike swelled first-time claims for jobless benefits, while the United States Chamber of Commerce said its index of business confidence skidded to the lowest level since February.
The question posed by the economic data is no longer whether the economy is slowing from last spring's breakneck pace. Now it is, "How slow will it get?" 
 While many analysts say that the economy is likely to pick up momentum again, a growing minority of analysts contend that growth may slow so much that unemployment will rise significantly. Some worry that the economy next year could even slip into a recession. Others speak of what they call a "growth recession," a sustained period in which the economy keeps expanding but at a slow pace.
Today's data showed that consumer spending rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the weakest since a drop of five-tenths of 1 percent in June. The Commerce Department also reported that personal income rose a modest six-tenths of 1 percent.
The degree of slowdown seen in such reports is of immediate political consequence. Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, disparaged Wednesday's report of a 2.2 percent third-quarter growth rate by saying, "If this is a recovery, I can hardly wait for the recession."
In fact, the economy has been expanding without interruption for more than five and a half years. How long that continues will not become clear until well after next week's election, and the pace of next year's economy will depend on decisions by millions of consumers and businesses.
The mainstream view is that prospects are good, with the latest quarter reflecting merely a consumer "breather." The buildup of unsold goods reported on Wednesday, most analysts say, is nothing to worry about. They say the economy will perk up again because the job market appears strong and consumers are enjoying a modest rise in spendable income that is likely to show up at retailers this Christmas.
Still, excessive inventories have traditionally been one of the three chief causes of business downturns -- the others being higher interest rates and such external shocks as disrupted oil supplies. So the minority predicting paltry growth or recession should not be lightly dismissed.
Geoffrey H. Moore, the respected business-cycle researcher, last week announced that his newly refined forecasting system had produced its first signal of a "growth recession." By the turn of the year, he expects the economic expansion to be below its long-term trend of 2.5 percent.
Dr. Moore, director of the Economic Cycle Research Institute in New York, cautioned that he was making only a preliminary warning, though an aide asserted that Dr. Moore correctly predicted in February 1990 that subpar growth then would deteriorate into the full-blown, though brief, recession that began that July.
A recent Dun & Bradstreet survey of 3,000 business executives found a general "wait and see" stance, with those in small business least sanguine. "Small businesses can be very sensitive to early changes in the economy," noted Joseph W. Duncan, the company's chief economic adviser. "Their new pessimism may be an early sign that conditions will soften in the first half of 1997."
In the same vein, economists at UBS Securities are telling clients that consumer spending "continues to sputter" and that both housing and exports will contribute only slightly, if at all, to growth in coming months.
"Expansions do not necessarily die of old age, but they become feeble," the bank's analysts say, predicting that the Fed will have to cut short-term interest rates next year because of "below trend growth."
History also shows that recessions have a way of popping up in the years after Presidential elections. Half the 10 postwar downturns, occurred at such times -- in 1953, 1957, 1969, 1973 and 1981, according to the National Bureau of Economic Research.
And history also shows that despite the intense scrutiny that every indicator now gets, recessions can still arrive with little notice. In the summer of 1990, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said he saw no sign of a downturn even though the National Bureau later determined that it had already started. Because it takes time to evaluate economic data thoroughly, the researchers did not declare the recession under way until the spring of 1991, about the time it ended.
Indeed, in raising the specter of recession this week, Mr. Dole seemed to reflect Republican chagrin about a small but seemingly fiendish lack of congruence in the business and electoral cycles.
President George Bush, most analysts believe, lost his 1992 re-election bid in large part because most people thought the economy was doing poorly. But it was actually growing at a brisk 3 percent pace in the third quarter of that year and boomed at a robust 4.3 percent rate in the three-month period that included Election Day. President Clinton, by contrast, is getting credit for a strong economy when growth in the pre-election quarter was not only below that under President Bush but weakening.

HEADLINE: William Rosenwald Dies; Benefactor to Many Was 93

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
William Rosenwald, who gave and raised millions of dollars in a life dominated by philanthropy that saved tens of thousands of lives and bettered countless others through education and the arts, died yesterday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 93.
Mr. Rosenwald carried on a commitment to charity established by his father, Julius, a chairman and builder of Sears, Roebuck & Company, and was one of the three signatories to the agreement that founded a nationwide United Jewish Appeal in 1939. 
 A private investor, Mr. Rosenwald had business interests at various times in enterprises that included the American Securities Corporation, an investment bank; Western Union International, and Ametek, a maker of precision instruments and small electric motors, like those used in vacuum cleaners. He was nevertheless best known for his tireless philanthropic dedication.
"I spend half my time in philanthropic work, half at business, half with my family and half at personal affairs," he said once with his characteristic good humor.
Besides his longtime work with the United Jewish Appeal, Mr. Rosenwald served for four decades on the board of the Tuskegee Institute and for many years on the board of the New York Philharmonic.
Long before many others realized the threat posed to European Jews by the Nazis, Mr. Rosenwald was busy working to save as many people as he could from the impending Holocaust.
In the mid-1930's, he led a family effort to rescue relatives in Europe, and by 1948, the endeavor had succeeded in bringing 300 of them to the United States and had assumed responsibility for another 300 still in Europe. Not only did the Rosenwalds bring their kin to America; they also provided them with homes and found them jobs.
But Mr. Rosenwald's experiences in Europe gave him first-hand exposure to the plight of Jews in Nazi Germany and in other countries where anti-Semitism was flourishing.
In a 1935 interview, Mr. Rosenwald said: "There is the thought in my mind -- and that I would like to get across to the Jews of America -- that to the extent that the Jews as a whole help their suffering brethren, we will fortify the Jews of all countries against anti-Semitic onslaughts."
As a result, he was unremitting in his efforts to raise money to address the needs of Jews in distress.
In 1939, when he became the organizer and first president of the National Refugee Service, later a part of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, he had already been working for three years to resettle refugees in communities outside New York City.
And when the state of Israel was founded in 1948, Mr. Rosenwald was in the forefront of efforts to support the immigration of thousands of European refugees to the Jewish homeland.
"The time has come for rededication on a scale that will measure up to the historic moment that our generation has been privileged to witness," he said.
Mr. Rosenwald served the United Jewish Appeal as one of its three national chairmen from 1942 to 1946, when he began the first campaign that raised more than $100 million; and he headed the organization's campaigns in 1955, 1956 and 1957.
He encouraged the combined campaign of the U.J.A.-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York and served as the campaign organization's first president for three years beginning in 1974.
For 50 years he was a member of the executive committee of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, and he held various posts with organizations like the Council of Jewish Federations and the American Jewish Committee.
Mr. Rosenwald, one of the five children of Julius Rosenwald and the former Augusta Nusbaum, was born in Chicago in 1903. He earned a bachelor of science degree at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1924, studied liberal arts at Harvard University for a year, then attended the London School of Economics.
Beginning in 1928, he went to work for Sears, Roebuck in various posts, including as a director from 1934 to 1938.
In 1935, he began his career as a private investor.
His many awards and honors included doctorates from Hebrew University and Tuskegee Institute.
Mr. Rosenwald was married three times. His first marriage, to Renee Scharf in 1928, ended in divorce in 1935. In 1938, he married Mary Kurtz, who died in 1985, and last year, he married Ruth G. Israels, who survives him.
Mr. Rosenwald is also survived by three daughters, Nina Rosenwald, Elizabeth R. Varet and Alice R. Sigelman, all of Manhattan; a stepson, Michael J. Israel of Manhattan; five grandchildren, and two step-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: POLITICAL MEMO;
For Dole, Plenty of Movement but Momentum Remains Elusive

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31

 BODY:
As with families, so, it seems, with campaigns.
Certainly, Bob Dole's campaign is unhappy in its own distinctive way. It is unhappy in a way that somehow combines weary resignation with caustic defiance and then adds a certain antic spontaneity. It is unhappy in a way that is sad and funny at the same time. 
 Since last weekend, the Dole campaign has been in an odd state of leisurely frenzy, bouncing from one jury-rigged appearance to the next, changing its plans almost on an hourly basis and keeping bankers' hours. Remarkably, for a down-and-out campaign in the countdown week, it has not been staging more than a handful of events each day, and on Tuesday it traveled 3,000 miles to touch down only once -- for a rally in a poorly lit ballroom in the Denver convention center.
On Wednesday, Mr. Dole's campaign schedule did not begin until early afternoon and consisted of just two events. At the first stop, in Clarksville, Tenn., Mr. Dole stepped on his one prepared sound-bite of the day, a warning about the upcoming "Clinton recession." At the second stop, here in New Orleans, he remembered to issue the warning, but then got sidetracked again.
"It's not a great economy," he told a rally at the Pontchartrain Center here. "Everyone who understands Economics 101 -- I didn't do too well, come to think of it, but I understand it better now."
By nature a stoic, Mr. Dole remains at least publicly upbeat, even as his aides have forsaken the immense effort it would take to spin all this as a strategy.
At the start of each day, Mr. Dole sounds the theme that every day is a new day. Yet by the end of the day it seems that each day has actually been a lot like the last day.
There has been a hastily put together speech. There has been a hastily put together rally. There have been aspersions on the Democratic Party's fund-raising techniques: "I wouldn't be surprised to see them holding fund raisers in homeless shelters." There have been exhortations to ignore the polls: "You are the polls!" And there have been attacks on the press: "A lot of people in the media who don't understand the economy very well report on it," Mr. Dole told the audience in Clarksville.
But there has not been, as Mr. Dole's erstwhile rival and current ally, George Bush, so memorably put it, the "big mo."
Momentum is a quality that has always eluded Mr. Dole in his national campaigns, and now, in his fourth and quite probably final national race, the former Senator from Kansas seems genuinely perplexed by the race's dynamic. Despite the many allegations of impropriety that have been leveled against President Clinton, Mr. Dole seems unable to make much headway against him. In an interview the other day on CNN, Mr. Dole was asked why he thought this was the case.
"I'm baffled," he replied in a tone of real bewilderment. "I'm really baffled. It seems to me -- and I'm not trying to be judgmental -- but if the American people really care and they're really concerned about who's in charge, something ought to get their attention sooner or later."
As he waits for something to catch voters' attention -- "sooner or later" -- Mr. Dole seems disinclined to alter or even examine his own campaign style, which remains as dependably changeless as the polls.
With an occasional exception, like the speech he gave in San Diego on Monday on affirmative action, Mr. Dole is still, for example, blithely ignoring the remarks his campaign has prepared for his delivery.
Although he calls himself "a plain-spoken man," Mr. Dole is also still issuing many of his denunciations of Mr. Clinton in the kind of shorthand that only political insiders could be expected to understand. For example, he mentions a Democratic campaign donor, Yogesh Gandhi, who gave more than $300,000 to the party while reportedly owing back taxes, but never exactly articulates the principle involved in his criticism.
"He gave the President an award," Mr. Dole said on Tuesday in Irvine, Calif., referring to Mr. Gandhi. "It turned out to be a phony."
"Those are the details," he went on. "Fact is, he had the $300,000."
Mr. Dole can be similarly cryptic when explaining the centerpiece of his own campaign: his 15 percent tax cut plan. "Revenues are going to grow by about 20 percent over the next six years and the President wants to spend all that," Mr. Dole said, also in Irvine. "We want to spend about 14 percent of it and give the other 6 percent back to the American people."
How this 6 percent would translate into 15 percent, Mr. Dole left unexplained. Still, he concluded his defense of his plan by noting, "It's not rocket science."
There comes a time in every lagging campaign when the candidate realizes that, barring some act of Providence, he is not going to win. For former President Bush, that time occurred on a train trip through Wisconsin the Saturday before the 1992 election when, after surveying the latest polls, he seemed to visibly deflate.
Just what Mr. Dole is thinking in the curtained-off area at the front of his campaign plane, Citizen's Ship, is, of course, something that only he and perhaps a few close advisers know. Sometimes he seems almost liberated by his situation, as he did here on Wednesday evening, offering up wisecracks with an enthusiasm bordering on abandon.
"Don't let Halloween scare you," he said. "Let four more years of Clinton -- think about that. That'll keep you awake. That'll curdle your milk, as we used to say in Kansas."
Yet just the night before, when he had insisted on traveling across the country to sleep in his own bed, it seemed to signal some kind of emotional exhaustion, a need for solace from a man who has spent much of his adult life running for national office, but has never seemed fully to embrace the color and the chaos of the passing American scene. And on occasion the loneliness of the enterprise that has absorbed him for so long comes through.
"I have been around long enough to know it is going to be the candidate's fault," he told Candy Crowley of CNN when she asked the other day about his staff. "If I lose, the rest of them are going to be home free, but it will be the candidate's fault. And I am prepared to accept that."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
In His Own Words

 BODY:

BOB DOLE
 
Discussing the Medicare Trust Fund and President Clinton's television advertisements yesterday in Tampa:
"I call it irresponsible. The White House should not be in the business of distorting the truth and scaring senior citizens. I listen to some of these horror stories, sometimes I think Dick Morris has been replaced by Stephen King. These Medicare or Medi-scare tactics are intended to attack my campaign. They are winding up hurting every senior in America, because when you're alone and you see something on television, or you hear it on the radio, or you read it in the newspaper, you're inclined to believe it. Nobody to talk to. 
 "The President is ignoring the problems. He has ignored the problems. His political games are not just misleading. They are dangerous. Because they divert us from the real job -- and that is getting the economy back on track. . . .
"Every day we have another reason to wonder how low will this White House go. How low will this White House go? Is there any trust it will not violate?
"Let me say one thing: I will never play politics with Medicare, because too much is at stake. Seniors don't want scare tactics. They want straight talk. Straight talk."

HEADLINE: Compromise In G.M. Strike Still Elusive

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Negotiators from the United Automobile Workers union and the General Motors Corporation held marathon talks today aimed at settling the third big strike this year against the company, but a compromise remained elusive.
The latest round of talks began on Wednesday at 10 A.M. and continued without interruption through Wednesday night and today. The auto industry has a tradition of settling strikes after negotiating sessions lasting as long as 60 hours, a sign that a deal could come in the next several days. 
 "The negotiators are focusing on resolving the remaining issues and have been talking through the night and day," said Gerald E. Holmes, a G.M. spokesman.
Most of the G.M. and U.A.W. officials went home to rest at about 6 P.M. today, after 32 hours of talks, said Charles Licari, a G.M. spokesman. Talks continued on a few subjects, with full negotiations scheduled to resume on Friday morning.
As officials here tried to work out an arrangement addressing the U.A.W.'s demand for greater job security and G.M.'s insistence on lower labor costs, the effects of the latest strike continued to widen. G.M. notified 4,000 workers today at an assembly plant in Moraine, Ohio, that they would be temporarily laid off as of Friday. The latest strike had deprived the factory of the parts needed to continue assembling the GMC Jimmy, Chevrolet Blazer and Oldsmobile Bravada sport utility vehicles.
The ripple of local strikes is part of a strategy by the U.A.W. to put more pressure on the auto maker. G.M.'s labor contract with the union expired on Sunday night, leaving the workers free to stage strikes without notice.
On Tuesday evening, U.A.W. workers walked out at G.M.'s most profitable assembly plant and one of its most important truck parts factories. The 4,800-employee assembly plant, located in Janesville, Wis., makes Chevrolet and GMC Suburban full-size sport utility vehicles. Auto analysts estimate that G.M. makes up to $12,000 in profit on each of these vehicles.
The walkout at the 2,600-employee truck parts factory, which is in Indianapolis, has crippled G.M.'s ability to manufacture roofs and hoods for all of its pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, including the Moraine factory. G.M. also closed a 2,250-employee pickup truck factory in Fort Wayne, Ind., on Wednesday night for lack of parts.
U.A.W. officials said that a 2,500-employee assembly plant in Linden, N.J., could close by Monday if the strike was not resolved soon. Five other G.M. truck assembly plants rely on parts from Indianapolis. They are in Pontiac, Mich.; Flint, Mich.; Shreveport, La.; Silao, Mexico, and Oshawa, Ontario.
Senior officials from both sides were participating in the negotiations here. Richard Shoemaker, the U.A.W.'s vice president for G.M. issues, and Gerald A. Knechtel, G.M.'s vice president of personnel, stayed at the table through the night and were still here this evening. Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, has been in and out of the talks while being host of a quarterly meeting of the U.A.W.'s board.
A union local at a crucial parts factory in Kokomo, Ind., also threatened to go on strike today, which could force G.M. to shut its car factories as well as its truck factories if the strike lasts long. But while G.M.'s truck models are highly profitable, most of its car models lose money. A strike that closes car factories could cost the U.A.W. heavily, particularly if states denied unemployment benefits to any laid-off workers and the union wound up paying them strike benefits instead.
Auto analysts have estimated that if all of G.M.'s truck factories close because of the strike, G.M. would lose $50 million a day in after-tax profits.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BOOM IN PROFITS FOR CORPORATIONS NOW APPEARS OVER

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The great boom in corporate earnings, which helped propel the market and buoyed the economy for more than four years, seems to be over. What analysts are arguing over now is how much more slowly earnings will grow.
While not all companies have reported yet, enough have released results to indicate that the third quarter should have the weakest gains in operating earnings in about four and a half years, according to several Wall Street estimates. That would mean that for the year, earnings growth is likely to be the smallest since profits actually fell in 1991. 
 Weaker earnings are certainly not good news for the stock market in general. But slower growth does not necessarily mean that stocks are going to perform poorly. That is because simply exceeding what investors had expected, as apparently happened this quarter, can support stocks even if the pace of growth slackens. This year's gains in the stock market make that abundantly clear: the Dow Jones industrial average has risen 17.8 percent through yesterday and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index is up 14.5 percent.
But with the broader market indexes near record levels and the value of stocks already relatively high, weak earnings growth next year could worry investors and undermine the stock market's performance. And with earnings forecasts for 1997 all over the lot -- from flat to up 10 percent -- the debate continues on whether the stock market can continue to move higher for yet another year.
The reasons for the earnings slowdown from the 15 to 18 percent average rate from 1992 through 1995 run the gamut. They range from an inability to raise prices and the slowing productivity of workers to the moderating pace of growth in the economy and the fact that a lot of the corporate cost-cutting and downsizing that helped earnings in recent years has now been done.
In the third quarter, the decline in earnings for technology stocks like Motorola, and a drop at basic industries, including International Paper, Phelps Dodge and Temple-Inland, all served as anchors that put a drag on earnings growth.
The positive push came from energy companies, including Exxon, Chevron and Texaco, which were helped by the spurt in oil prices, and from consumer companies, like the auto makers, that prosper when the economy is growing. Mobil bucked the energy tide, reporting a 10 percent drop in earnings.
Banks, investment firms and insurance companies also contributed to the growth but gave much less of a boost than in recent quarters.
Microsoft and Intel, whose earnings jumped, went against the grain in the technology sector.
There are also indications that average companies are no longer the profit generators they had been, leaving it up to the largest, best- known concerns to keep the growth going.
Thomas McManus, an investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, noted that over all there was a rise in the total earnings per share of the companies in the S.& P. 500 that have already reported when their results are weighted in favor of the bigger companies. But looking at the simple average of all the companies, earnings per share are down a bit.
"What we are seeing," he argued, "is the transition of the market to an environment where it is tougher and tougher for the average company to increase its earnings. I think a bull market is a market which enables the average company to gain in price."
Richard B. Hoey, chief economist and the manager of portfolios worth $2.3 billion at the Dreyfus Corporation, said the shift to "a narrower pattern of earnings gains" had already made him move toward "higher quality stocks" that have "strong revenue growth."
Wall Street analysts agree that the huge gains in earnings that helped propel the longest bull market in history are over for this economic cycle.
"We had been expecting this notable inflection point in earnings," said Abby Joseph Cohen, market strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. But that is all that they agree on.
The exact growth figures for the quarter are still being debated on Wall Street, in part because many retailers work on a third quarter ending with October, and have yet to report.
In addition, the measures of the same earnings season can vary because analysts differ in how they treat the special write-offs that companies take for everything from accounting changes to employee layoffs. That is why they come up with such different readings for what they call operating earnings.
Because of these differences, the estimates for growth in the third quarter compared with the third quarter of 1995 range from 8 percent at Goldman, Sachs to a barely perceptible one-tenth of one percent at Paine Webber.
For the year, the estimates run from 3 percent at Paine Webber to just under 10 percent at Goldman.
So the answer to whether or not this was a good quarter and what is in store for 1997 depends on whom you talk to.
"If you see that the profit decline is in large part due to technology profits being down that is a concern because people see technology leading the market," said Melissa R. Brown, director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities.
Bruce Steinberg, the manager of macroeconomic analysis at Merrill Lynch, said that the third quarter was showing the "weakest earnings performance in four years."
Don't tell that to Ms. Cohen at Goldman, though. Third-quarter earnings are "good, not great," she countered. More importantly, she added, "the quality of earnings is good because there is no inflation behind them."
Eric Miller, the chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that one reason why slowing growth had not pulled the market lower was that third-quarter earnings "came in a little better than expected."
And Thomas Doerflinger, an investment strategist at Paine Webber, is forecasting a rebound in earnings next year despite his belief that earnings last quarter were flat. "Earnings are re-accelerating again," he said.
Mr. Doerflinger forecasts a rise of 8.6 percent in earnings next year; Ms. Cohen sees about 10 percent growth and says confidently that the year-to-year gain in earnings "is not going to end soon." But Mr. Steinberg is forecasting only 2.5 percent, while Mr. Miller is expecting earnings to be unchanged.
There are several factors that could make the positive forecasts for 1997 slower and the slow ones worse. One is the strength of the dollar. If it rose significantly, profits that American companies make abroad would suffer when recorded in dollars.
And then there is the assumption that economies outside the United States, especially in Europe and Asia, will rebound, letting consumers there buy more goods from the United States. "The international economy is important because we are running out of domestic steam," Mr. Miller said.
The other important factor is interest rates. A rise in rates might crimp earnings of companies. But more important, higher interest rates, by giving investors a more attractive alternative to stocks, would make the stock market less appealing.
"Given the outlook of modest growth and low inflation, we expect bond yields to move lower during the next three to six months," Mr. Steinberg wrote recently. "That could buoy the equity market despite diminished earnings momentum. But bond-market setbacks would likely take a significant toll."

HEADLINE: Undertow for the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By Matthew Miller; Matthew Miller, a senior editor at The New Republic, writes often about politics and economic policy.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Just as California's Proposition 13 in 1978 ushered in the anti-tax wave Republicans have ridden to this day, the state's backlash against immigration and affirmative action was supposed to energize enough "angry white men" to bury Democrats for a decade. But these so-called wedge issues are not helping Republican Congressional candidates here. In fact, they're laying the groundwork for erosion of the Republican base in the nation's pivotal electoral state.
Blame Pete Wilson and Newt Gingrich. Republican strategists misread the meaning of Mr. Wilson's come-from-behind romp over Kathleen Brown in the 1994 race for Governor. Yes, Mr. Wilson's disciplined campaign, tied to Proposition 187's call for ending government benefits to illegal immigrants, was effective. But lost amid the excitement was the fact that Ms. Brown's own weaknesses were more decisive. 
 Nonetheless, Republicans apparently thought all they needed in 1996 was another wedge issue like Proposition 187 to help their candidates. Thus their use of the California Civil Rights Initiative, which would bar state and local governments from using quotas or preferences based on race, ethnicity and sex.
But the Republicans have been outflanked. President Clinton's moves to address legitimate concerns about immigration have inoculated Democrats down the ballot. Mr. Clinton's campaign ads here boast of border patrols and surveillance beefed up on his watch. The Immigration and Naturalization Service has just announced record numbers of deportations from the state.
On affirmative action, Mr. Clinton's "mend it, don't end it" straddle has helped out Democratic candidates on the stump. And though polls suggest that the initiative, Proposition 209, will pass, for Republican candidates there's no percentage in being tied to it. A new Field Poll here shows that opposition to the civil rights initiative has risen by nine percentage points since Bob Dole and the G.O.P. embraced it.
It turns out that affirmative action doesn't resonate with voters the way immigration does. Since 1990, a third of Californians have routinely told pollsters that immigration is a big problem, especially in the southern part of the state. "People see immigration as an issue every day in their lives as they drive around," said Representative Henry Waxman, a Los Angeles Democrat. "It's an issue that's brought out emotion in people."
Affirmative action, involving state procurement and agency jobs, has a narrower impact. Bill Carrick, senior adviser to the Clinton campaign here, says that of 25 statewide surveys he's seen, not one has turned up a significant percentage of voters who are seriously concerned about quotas or set-asides. A G.O.P. analyst, Tony Quinn, acknowledged that state Republican candidates aren't using Proposition 209 as an issue because "nobody is interested in it."
The Republicans' wedge strategy has another problem: It drives away educated female swing voters. Women have benefited from affirmative action, and the proposal also evokes the "meanness" they may already associate with Newt Gingrich's party. So while Republican candidates support the measure, few say much about it. Last week, Mr. Waxman's Republican challenger, Paul Stepanek, even endorsed Mr. Clinton.
Despite efforts by individual candidates to soft-pedal the initiative, last-minute advertising in favor of it will aim at shoring up support among the "angry white men." But for Mr. Dole and the Republicans, hopes of a bailout by these voters looks a lot like California dreamin'.

HEADLINE: For $8.6 Million, Christie's Sells a Rare Korean Dragon

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
A rare Korean dragon jar from the 17th century, cracked down one side, was sold on Thursday night for $8.6 million at Christie's in New York. The price was the highest ever paid at auction for an Asian art object. The names of the seller and the buyer, who bid by telephone, were not disclosed.
The jar is boldly emblazoned with a fierce, three-clawed dragon, a brown-black iron oxide monster depicted as chasing the pearl of wisdom around the baluster-shaped jar. At nearly 19 inches, it is the tallest known of this type of ceramic vessel.
TXT>
 "Forget about it being cracked," said Leighton Longhi, a New York dealer in Asian art. "That piece has everything going for it. It has enormous size, beautiful proportions and great painting. The dragon is a boldly drawn image in iron oxide, not the more usual blue and white. This was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity."
The previous record price for Asian art was $6.1 million, for a Tang horse sold in 1989 at Sotheby's in London.
Sebastian Izzard, the head of Christie's department of Korean and Japanese art, said he had not known that the dragon jar existed until it was shown to him in 1995. "It had been in storage probably for 50 years," he said. "It is the largest version known of a type produced in the Choson Dynasty in the early 17th century. The four or five others are all in museums."
Even so, he made a conservative estimate, at $400,000 to $600,000, because the jar had a crack running down the side and a firing crack in the base.
Similar but much smaller pieces are in the National Museum of Korea in Seoul as well as in two other museums in South Korea, the Victoria and Albert Museum in London and the Ataka Collection in Osaka, Japan.
"Korean industrialists and museums have bought virtually all the important pieces of Korean art sold recently," Mr. Longhi said. "This one most likely is also going back to Korea."
Prices for Korean art began to increase rapidly in the late 1980's, as the economy in South Korea improved. The pace quickened in 1992 when Korean ceramics from the Ataka Collection in Japan were exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And prices have continued to rise since the Metropolitan announced a year ago that its Arts of Korea Galleries would open in late 1997.
