HEADLINE: A Robust Pace Of Job Growth, With Inflation Under Control

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
In the latest of a string of pre-election reports showing the economy on a slow but steady track, Government figures indicated today that the number of American jobs once again grew at a robust pace in October while wages posed no threat of faster inflation.
Unemployment remained at the low rate of 5.2 percent for the second consecutive month, and employers added 210,000 new jobs last month after payrolls had shrunk by 35,000 in September, the Labor Department said. 
 The Clinton Administration exulted over an economy in which the jobless rate has now descended basically to the lowest levels since 1974 and which has grown every quarter without interruption since the spring of 1991.
"No other sitting President since Lyndon Johnson has had a better economy to run on," Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, contended. Responding to the suggestion by Mr. Clinton's Republican rival that a recession looms just over the horizon, he added, "This is most certainly not a doleful economy."
President Clinton, campaigning in Santa Barbara, Calif., said the figures rebutted Bob Dole's attacks on the Administration's economic record.
"It is time for my opponent and those on the other side to stop all this doom-and-gloom talk about America," Mr. Clinton said. "In spite of what he wants you to think, when it comes to the economy, the sky is not falling."
Christina Martin, a spokeswoman for Mr. Dole, responded by noting that a relatively high number of people had been out of work more than six months and that hourly earnings did not grow last month. "Most importantly," she added, economic anxiety "is most evident in the number of individuals who have to work at more than one job to make ends meet."
On Wall Street, where the bond market rallied sharply this week on expectation of continued low inflation, the jobs report came across as old news. Bond prices fell slightly and the stock market dipped as well, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 7.45 points, to 6,021.93.
Private analysts generally agree that the economy has held up remarkably well, particularly for the sixth year of an expansion, a time when inflation normally would have begun to heat up. But they tended to minimize the credit that could be properly claimed by the Administration.
"This is about as good as it gets," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities in New York. He pointed to the economy's slowing from a rapid pace in the spring and said it was now running "within the tolerable speed limits" that imply little upward drift in inflation.
The gain of 210,000 in employer payrolls, considered the best single barometer of the labor market, was a rebound from the surprising September decline of 35,000 that prompted some thoughts that the economy might be slowing too much.
While the October increase was in line with those prevailing so far this year, the deceleration dragged the gain for the latest three months down to a monthly average of 152,000 from an average of 283,000 for May, June and July.
Business services showed almost no job growth for the second consecutive month but retail trade added 62,000 jobs. That reflected a strong start in seasonal hiring by department stores, said Katharine G. Abraham, Commissioner of Labor Statistics.
Factory jobs edged up a negligible 6,000 after a September skid of 59,000 while a drop of 40,000 in government jobs was mainly a statistical aberration caused by a trend to earlier school reopenings.
Economists who scrutinized today's report for any impact from the 50-cent rise in the minimum wage that took effect Oct. 1 found little sign of change other than a 1.1 percent jump, to $8.11 from $8.02, in the average earnings of those working in retail trade.
The effect on overall earnings -- unchanged at $11.91 an hour after two hefty increases -- was "not more than a cent or two," Commissioner Abraham said.
Officials said that one factor in the 24-minute decline in the length of the private-sector workweek was the Canadian auto workers strike against General Motors, which shut down some production in the United States.
The department's survey of households, on which the unemployment rate is based, showed 259,000 more people with jobs, just enough, given a 234,000 expansion of the labor force, to keep the unemployment rate from rising.
But there were the usual geographical disparities, with the jobless rate inching up two-tenths in the Northeast and South, to 5.4 percent and 5.2 percent, respectively, while it eased that amount, to 4.3 percent, in the Midwest. The West's rate was 6.3 percent for the third consecutive month.
The 5.2 percent national jobless rate compares with 7.3 percent four years ago on the eve of the last Presidential election. But the Dole campaign focused today on different comparisons.
Ms. Martin, the campaign spokeswoman, cited the fact that 17.4 percent of those who were jobless in October had been out of work more than six months, a higher rate than in previous expansions. The average length of unemployment was 40 percent higher, she said, than in the 1980's.
The number of people holding two or more jobs last month was 8,369,000, or 5 percent more than in October 1995. Of those employed, 6.5 percent held multiple jobs last month, compared with 6.3 percent a year ago.
Some lesser economic gauges published today tended to point in the same direction as the employment report -- slackened but continued growth with little inflation.
The nation's purchasing managers put their monthly index covering industrial activity at 50.2, down from 51.7 in September, as the new-orders and commodity-price components sagged while production and supplier deliveries edged up and export orders kept up a robust pace.
The Index of Leading Indicators, a forecasting tool now compiled by the Conference Board, edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the skimpiest of eight consecutive advances.
Coincident indicators, those that move at the same time as the overall economy, rose two-tenths of 1 percent for the third month after three increases that averaged twice that much.
And factory orders jumped 2.7 percent in September, the biggest advance in two years.
"This is another set of numbers that is an incumbent politician's dream," Robert Dederick, chief economic consultant for the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, told The Associated Press. "We have comfortable growth but not so rapid as to trigger inflation concerns."

HEADLINE: J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka Dies at 90; Modernized Nation He Led for 11 Years

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
J. R. Jayewardene, a former President of Sri Lanka who modernized and reshaped the country politically and was later criticized for his handling of ethnic tensions at its most critical moments, died yesterday in Colombo. He was 90.
Junius Richard Jayewardene -- who was always known as J. R. -- was the last of a generation of leaders who came of age politically before his island nation, then known as Ceylon, achieved independence in 1948.
When he became Prime Minister in 1977 and President the next year as a result of a rewriting of the Constitution, Mr. Jayewardene began to dismantle the socialist economic system. "The early years of his administration were wonderful years," said Howard Wriggins, who was American Ambassador in Colombo, the capital, from 1977 to 1980. "The whole economy turned around."
"He did remarkable things for Sri Lanka," said Mr. Wriggins, who is now retired and the co-author with a Sri Lankan historian, Kingsley de Silva, of a book on the former President, titled "J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka: A Political Biography."
"On economic policy, he was one of the early ones to move toward the free market in a country that had been locked into the socialist myth," Mr. Wriggins said. "If they had moved 10 years earlier, Sri Lanka might have been one of the export successes."
But Sri Lanka, known for its high rates of literacy and education and strong democratic and judicial institutions, fell prey to ethnic divisions. In 1983 a group of Sinhalese Sri Lankan soldiers were killed in an ambush, and tensions rose to an explosive level. In the crucial early moments when the country's Sinhalese-speaking, largely Buddhist majority took revenge on the ethnic Tamil, largely Hindu minority, Mr. Jayewardene, a Sinhalese Buddhist, inexplicably withdrew from sight and did nothing to stop the violence.
Gangs of thugs who, witnesses said, were led by members of the President's United National Party, went on a rampage against Tamils in Colombo, killing many and destroying their homes and businesses. In the civil war that still continues, more than 47,000 people have died -- Buddhists, Hindus, Christians and Muslims.
To compound the country's problems, in 1987 Mr. Jayewardene invited India to send troops to disarm the Tamil rebels. That action set off an extremely violent reaction among radical Sinhalese nationalists in the south of the country, who -- like the President himself -- blamed India for having earlier armed and trained the Tamils.
A Sinhalese nationalist in a presidential honor guard tried to club India's Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, with a rifle, when he came to Colombo to sign the agreement. In towns and villages, thousands died in the terrorism that followed, at least some of it Government-inspired or officially condoned, especially during the administration of Mr. Jayewardene's successor, President Ranasinghe Premadasa, who was also Sinhalese.
After stepping down from the presidency in 1988, Mr. Jayewardene withdrew from public life. In an interview then, he defended his record by comparing it with previous administrations led by Solomon W. R. D. Bandaranaike and then by his widow, Sirimavo Bandaranaike. He seemed oblivious to the violence and instability around him.
"We have a free press; the previous Government nationalized the press," declared Mr. Jayewardene, who said he had modeled his otherwise authoritarian presidency in part on Charles de Gaulle's France. "Political parties can operate freely. This is the essence of democracy: Freedom to vote and freedom to elect a president."
Mr. Jayewardene grew up in a privileged, English-speaking family in Colombo, and was looked after by a British nanny during an age when Sri Lanka's hallmarks were an old-fashioned civility and a formality that are all but gone.
He was a bookish intellectual and Buddhist who was able to detach himself from the world around him -- too much so, his critics say. All his life, even when he was traveling abroad, he wore the traditional Sri Lankan simple white sarong and long white shirt.
When he retired, Mr. Jayewardene said he had great faith in the country's power to survive -- even while bombs were killing hundreds of innocent people and bodies were being strewn across the verdant landscape of the island the ancient Arab traders called Serendip. A burgeoning tourist industry was shattered, and the freed economy was collapsing as reports of terrorism, curfews and rights violations circled the globe.
"Sri Lanka withstood several coups and assassinations and attempts to overthrow democracy," he said serenely. "In the midst of all that, it seems to be quite strong."
Mr. Jayewardene is survived by his wife, Elina, and a son, Ravi.

HEADLINE: Germany's Retailers Beckon Warily to Customers

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: HOFHEIM, Germany, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The shopkeepers in this 500-year-old village tried hard to look happy today, as they marked the first day in German history that stores will be allowed to stay open on weekdays past 6:30 P.M.
Promptly at 6:30 P.M., they handed out chocolate coins in gold foil, each one stamped with a clock face with the hand pointing to 7:30. To rebut the common complaint that German stores treat customers as nuisances, the merchants here came up with 1,200 bright yellow umbrellas to lend to customers as they walked between stores in a drizzle. 
 But below the surface, few store owners tried to conceal their angst and misgivings.
"This will add to our labor costs, but people won't have any more money than they did before," grumbled Wolfgang Waller, a local optician. "So why should they start spending more at our stores?"
After years of heated political debate, a new German law took effect today that, ever so slightly, tries to warm up one of the most consumer-unfriendly countries in the West.
But change comes slowly in Germany. Even now, stores will not be able to stay open later than 8 P.M. on weekdays and 4 P.M. on Saturdays. And Sundays remain entirely off-limits.
Beyond that, many retailers say that even this modest change is too much. While big department stores and shopping malls eagerly began extending their hours today, small shopkeepers who still make up the backbone of German retailing tended to balk.
In Hofheim, as in almost every town and village, local merchants have banded together and carefully tried to judge how late they needed to stay open to avoid losing customers. In Hofheim, shopkeepers decided that stores should close no later than 7:30 P.M. on weekdays and 2 P.M. on Saturdays. The "mittagspause," or lunch break, was left to each store's judgment.
For shopkeepers and store clerks, longer hours mean nothing more than higher costs without new revenues. It means getting home later for dinner and perhaps even having to give up the hallowed midday rest that stretches between 12:30 and 2.
Many owners of small stores are also convinced that the longer store hours will only hasten the rise of American-style shopping malls and big-city retail districts in cities like Frankfurt and Munich. At risk, they fear, are the picturesque village shopping districts where stores are nestled in gingerbread buildings on pedestrian-only cobblestone streets.
Recent surveys here indicate that about 70 percent of stores plan to extend their hours at least somewhat. In big cities and shopping malls, stores are generally staying open as long as permissible and are hoping for an increase in sales.
"This is very important for us," said Werner Heger, the manager of Peek & Cloppenburg, a big department store at the Main Taunus Zentrum shopping mall outside Frankfurt. "We are salespeople, so we want the opportunity to be able to sell things."
German consumers are more than ready for a change. The restrictive shopping hours were manageable for traditional families in which the wife stayed home and did her shopping on weekday mornings.
But for single people who work and for families in which both parents work, ordinary shopping has become stressful.
"I don't understand why Germany is so rigid," said Sabine Ruby, a human resources executive at a technology company who lives in the town of Walluf, about an hour's drive from Frankfurt. "The only time I can shop is on Saturday mornings. I have to get up early and leave by 8:30 because if I get to the store at 10 A.M. I may not be able to find a parking place."
Indeed, supermarkets on Saturdays can be so crowded and pressured that many people consider it the height of bad form to bring children along, for fear they will get in the path of other frenzied customers.
That pressure is only getting worse. The number of families with two working parents has climbed by one-third since the mid-1980's, and accounts for 46 percent of all households with children, according to the German Ministry of Economics.
Many traditional German store owners feel trapped in a quandary. In Hofheim, not far from Frankfurt, merchants say they are already losing business to the Main Taunus Zentrum mall as well as to the downtown retail district in Frankfurt.
The problem, they say, is that keeping stores open later may do nothing at all to keep customers and could simply lead to higher costs.
Despite widespread grumbling about rigid shopping laws, many people enjoy the fringe benefit of short store hours: guaranteed free time in the evenings, on Saturday afternoons and on Sundays.
"I think the longer hours are a good thing, but I personally don't think I will use them," Petra Schwarm, a housewife, said as she waited for the stores to open today at Main Taunus Zentrum. "I don't have to go to a job and I can go shopping while the children are in school."
The shopkeepers in towns like Hofheim are edgily waiting to see what happens. If the customers don't start showing up in the evenings, they say, they won't keep the stores open late.
"For this to work, the consumers have to come," Mr. Waller said. "They must."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
In His Own Words

 BODY:

ROBERT G. TORRICELLI
 
Speaking to students at Kittatinny Regional High School in Hampton Township, Sussex County, he addressed the risks of overdevelopment:
"Where I lived in Bergen County as a small boy, there were communities of open pasture land, forests, streams and lakes. During my life I have seen much of that land consumed by suburban sprawl, and with it went the deterioration in the quality of the water and the air. We lost the quality of life that brought us to those communities to begin with. That's not to say that we don't want economic development. But there is a difference between economic growth and endless suburban sprawl."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
In Nobody's Whistlestop, N.J., if Anyone Cares, a Few Votes for Bruce Willis

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: PENNS GROVE, N.J., Oct. 30

 BODY:
Once again, the politicians looking for votes were close by, just not close enough.
President Clinton was spending the afternoon in Philadelphia, just a half-hour's drive to the northeast. A few days before, Hillary Rodham Clinton was in Cherry Hill, which is even closer. On Friday, the Senate candidate Robert G. Torricelli was stumping in Vineland, which is right next door, in Cumberland County. Yet none of the politicos had bothered to put Salem County on their itineraries. 
 Donna Stout and Fred Fitch did not mind. Standing on empty, forlorn Main Street in the middle of a beautiful day, they were busy wondering: when is Bruce Willis coming back?
"I think he was here three weeks ago," said Ms. Stout, who publishes a local shopper.
"No, I heard he was around a few days ago," said Mr. Fitch, who runs Dollar Daze Inc., a new discount store on Main and Broad Streets. "In fact," he said hopefully, "I heard he's still around."
More than any politician, the star of the "Die Hard" movies, a hometown boy made good, is the talk of Penns Grove, what with his plans to invest $50 million into redeveloping the Delaware River waterfront. The excitement of what everyone calls the Bruce Willis Project has even captured the rest of Salem County, always hungry for good economic news. As for the biggest political campaign in the country, it seems far away, almost an abstraction.
In Salem County, residents have no campaign promises to sort through, no stump speeches to compare with negative ads. Which has probably made the election easier. Of two dozen county residents interviewed in Penns Grove and the City of Salem, all said they had decided whom to vote for, even if they remain skeptical about the ability of government to make a real difference in their lives.
Not once have the contenders for Senate or the Presidency come courting in these parts. But that is typical. Salem County, where baseball fans tend to root for the Phillies and just about everyone makes the trip over the Delaware Memorial Bridge to shop in Wilmington, has long been overlooked by politicians courting the New Jersey Vote.
Three things have worked against it: it is poor, underpopulated, remote. Its urban centers, Penns Grove and the City of Salem, are on the list of the state's "most distressed municipalities." And it is the least densely populated county in New Jersey, with 65,000 residents spread over 350 square miles, mostly farmland. It has not received a visit from a sitting President since Richard M. Nixon stopped by once on the way to somewhere else.
At 23, Dorothy Wright is one of the optimists. A cashier at a liquor store in downtown Salem, she is hopeful that times will get better here for her 7-year-old son and 4-year-old daughter. "I registered to vote for the first time just recently," she said, as her children helped her fold their clothes in the Laundromat. "I want to keep Clinton in office. I'd rather stay with what I know already."
Salem, she said, needs help. But she is not relying on the politicians. She thinks the residents should help themselves. "This is a community that needs people to care about it," she said. "I hear people say their children aren't learning. I tell them if their kids aren't learning, they need to go to their schools and find out why, things like that."
The City of Salem (population 6,800) is deceiving. With its broad, handsome streets and quaint national historic district, it looks like the quintessential middle-class American village. It is easy to overlook the empty stores, the shabbier houses, the men of working age sitting on stoops or standing in front of a bar. The city (like Penns Grove) has a 14.3 percent unemployment rate. More than 33 percent of its residents live below the poverty line. The future of its largest employer, Anchor Glass factory, with 350 jobs, is uncertain. It may be sold and closed.
In the middle of the day, in the middle of the week, Coranna Pierce was having a yard sale at her downtown apartment. She was selling her living room, her magazines, her tiny porcelain animals, which she arranged in a row on her window sill. "There are no jobs here," she said. "I'm moving to Norwich, Conn., to stay with my sister." Her children, who go to school in Penns Grove, are not happy. "Times have been better," she said.
She plans to skip the Senate election ("too negative") and vote for Ross Perot for President. "I voted for him last time," she said. "He wants to run the country like a business, the way it should be run. We need to put people here to work."
Many people here said the same thing, though most everyone in the City of Salem also said they planned to vote for Mr. Clinton. (George Bush beat Mr. Clinton in Salem County in 1992, but barely: by 301 votes.) Charlotte Morrison, of Carneys Point, which is next to Penns Grove, said she planned to vote for Mr. Clinton even though she will vote for Republicans in the local and statewide races, as she always does.
"I'm voting for Clinton because he's more for the poor and I'm right near poverty myself," she said, almost cheerfully. She was having her hair permed at the Penns Grove Foodrite Plaza, after a long day of work at a shoe factory: "I've been up since 4 this morning, started work at 6. I put in a lot of hours to stay in place, to make the bills."
Such is the way of life in Salem County. The largest employers are the Dupont Chamber Works plant, with 2,200 jobs, and Public Service Electric and Gas, which owns the Salem nuclear plants, with 2,300 jobs. Except for those who work on one of the 752 farms, a plant job is the only way to make decent money.
For most residents, the answer to better times is the same answer that worked once before: private business. Marlene and George Morris, who run Morris's Takeout in Penns Grove, remember how things were when the DuPont factory opened years ago. "People moved here to work at Dupont and made their living," Mrs. Morris said. "And now we have Bruce Willis, another rich person coming here to spend a lot of money to resurrect Penns Grove."
They will vote Republican on Tuesday. "I always vote Republican,' Mrs. Morris said, "even though the city votes Democratic. I'm a die-hard. Get it? Bruce Willis? 'Die Hard?' "
Rob Bowen of Penns Grove gets it, though he is voting for Mr. Perot. "I think Dole is too old to be even thinking about running and I think Ross has some good ideas," said Mr. Bowen, who supports two children with a job at a Texaco station. He blames politicians for the county's sad state.
"Anything that North Jersey wants, it gets," Mr. Bowen said. "Anything that South Jersey wants, we have to wait for." Yet Mr. Bowen seems firmly convinced, like so many others here, that times in Salem County are going to get better, much better, in the near future.
How so? The answer came quickly. "Bruce," he said with a wide smile. "Bruce."

HEADLINE: Bonds Drop Despite Reports Of Slower Economic Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities slipped yesterday, as economic reports showed the pace of growth in jobs and manufacturing slowing but not enough to ease investors' concern that inflation could rebound later this year.
The 30-year bond fell 16/32 to a price of 10030/32 to yield 6.68 percent, up from 6.64 percent on Thursday. 
 Initially the market gained after the Government said the economy added 210,000 jobs last month, after losing 35,000 in September. Yesterday's gain was in line with expectations. Traders noted, however, that the jobs gain left concern that the economy would bounce back if consumers went deeper into their wallets and purses in the holiday season.
Trading was heavy, with talk of foreign central banks taking profits after Thursday's advance. And with interest rates down as much as they have been over the last week, there was also talk of investors in mortgage-backed securities shifting into Treasury securities because of the potential that the mortgages backing these securities could be paid down in advance.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, said the jobs number along with the other string of reports released this week initially made bond traders the most "bullish individuals in America." However, as the day progressed, he got the impression that many investors were beginning to wonder if economic news could get even better next week, especially as the quarterly refunding issues go on the auction block, increasing the supply of securities available. Investors may also have realized yesterday that with very little data on tap next week, pushing yields lower would prove difficult.
In when-issued trading, the three-year note that will be auctioned on Tuesday was offered at a price to yield 5.93 percent; the 10-year note on Wednesday was offered at a price to yield 6.38 percent, and the 30-year bond on Thursday at a price to yield 6.64 percent.
Mr. Chan said yesterday's report of a 2.7 percent rise in factory orders for September after a decline of 2.1 percent in August was no surprise. The overall gains in orders were largely a result of the surge in aircraft orders that was reported last week in durable-goods orders.
The National Association of Purchasing Management also released a report; it was similar to the previous day's Chicago purchasing management report, which showed a rise in the production component but no corresponding improvement in the orders components. "Let's face it," Mr. Chan said, "increasing production without a corresponding rise in new orders does not imply sustainability." The association's October index fell to 50.2 from 51.7.
Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc., said yesterday's data told him that the economy was doing fine, that employment was not too robust, and that leading indicators met expectations except for the disappointing national purchasing management report. Therefore, he said, it was a mystery to him that the bond market did not react more favorably. "There may be something subliminal here, and that is that the market could be already focusing on Tuesday's" election, he said.
"Growth is slow and inflation benign," Mr. Guild said, "and it is increasingly likely that on Nov. 13 the Fed will do nothing." He said the Consumer Price Index was "a mixed bag because it is overstated by as much as five-tenths to 2 percent."
Mr. Guild said energy costs would be a key and that in August and September the energy components were grossly understated. Energy in August declined six-tenths of 1 percent, and it was unchanged in September, "very much in severe conflict with the price of oil," he said. "If you believe those data, I have three bridges I'd like to sell you. But if by chance the Federal Open Market Committee perceives that inflation is climbing because of energy costs and other things, they'd have to make a preemptive strike with at least a quarter-point rate increase. They won't do half, although that would be marvelous."

HEADLINE: Mexico City Journal;
The Day of the Ghouls vs. the Day of the Dead

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1

 BODY:
As dusk fell and shadows began to creep, the streets were suddenly filled with unearthly creatures, running in packs.
There were ghouls, skeletons, devils, vampire princesses and corpses returned from the dead. Even Death himself appeared, dressed in a gray hooded cassock and carrying not exactly a scythe but a cardboard machete. 
 It was Halloween, but not in any American town. On Thursday night children in droves in the capital and Mexico's other big cities donned spooky costumes and went house to house asking for candy. A distinctly American version of Halloween, with jack-o'-lanterns, candy corn, Batman and Morticia, is rapidly catching on in Mexico, a country with its own powerful traditions for celebrating the Day of the Dead.
The American Halloween and the colorful rituals taking place in cemeteries throughout Mexico today, All Saints' Day, and on Saturday, All Souls' Day, have the same roots, at least in part. In the ninth century the Christian church declared All Saints' Day, in effect recognizing the pagan festivals celebrating the harvest and honoring the dead. Just as European settlers brought the tradition to the United States, the Spanish spread it in Mexico.
But in this country the European practice melded with the beliefs of the Aztecs and other indigenous peoples for whom Death was an intimate and enthralling spiritual being. Modern Mexicans observe the Day of the Dead by decorating graves and communing with deceased loved ones in rites that mourn the survivors' loss but also celebrate the continuing closeness of the living and the dead.
By contrast, Halloween, on the eve of All Saints' Day of All Hallows, is the night of Death's dark side, when monsters and bloodsuckers and the souls that found no rest run free.
In Mexico, the custom is catching on mainly because it's fun.
"It's pure candy!" said Erica Jasmin Sanchez, a 6-year-old scarlet devil with horns and a pointed tail who was carrying a skull full of cookies and caramels.
Children in big groups flock through the capital's well-to-do neighborhoods, lining up in crowds to receive treats from whoever will open their front door. In Mexico City, since everyone is disguised in a costume, Halloween is a once-a-year opportunity for poor children to go begging for treats at the homes of the rich without being chased away by security guards.
"Give me my Halloween!" they cry, using the English term. Sometimes the "trick" part of the routine is maintained as well, with children carrying markers or paint to write vengeful graffiti on the houses where no goodies are given.
The horticultural ancestors of the big orange pumpkin that Americans carve with scary faces were Mexican. Nowadays Mexico grows squashes in hundreds of colors and shapes, but not many pumpkins, so to meet Halloween demand they must be imported from the United States. Many Mexicans choose plastic pumpkins instead.
Mexico's turn to Halloween began two decades ago and boomed as the country's economic and political opening produced an explosion of trade and travel across the border with the United States. Like many United States cultural exports, Halloween in Mexico is a major marketing event.
A Wal-Mart superstore in a northern suburb of Mexico City set aside floor space for a mock graveyard where costumes and candies are displayed above half-open coffins inhabited by blood-spattered mummies.
"Let me explain this as a Mexican," said Alvaro Alonso, the deputy store manager. "This is really new for us. It is not one of our fiestas. But Halloween is a concept that is definitely growing."
Wal-Mart's Halloween sales have increased for the last three years despite a deep recession in Mexico.
But Mr. Alonso said the trend was controversial among Mexican consumers. Wal-Mart's suggestion box was filled today with comments from customers demanding to know why the salespeople were dressed up like witches in a store in the center of Mexico.
"Halloween is costumes and candy," said Mariana Villareal, a top buyer at the store. "The Day of the Dead is more a matter of the heart."
Some intellectuals agree that Halloween is an offense against Mexican nationalism.
"This is cultural pollution," the Mexican novelist Homero Aridjis said. "In these hard times I call upon Mexicans to leave aside all those Anglo-Saxon witches and ghosts and keep their money to buy bread and flowers to honor their dead."
But the gleeful children in the streets on Thursday night were not concerned about the national origins of the game.
"This comes from the United States, but we can take culture from wherever we want," said Guillermo Morales, a 15-year-old phantom.
Some Mexican children had decided that Halloween was already theirs.
"I like it because it is a tradition of the Mexicans," said the white-eyed, black-lipped Adriana Alicia Garcia, 12. "We go out every year and ask for candies to fill up our skulls."
To judge from the crowds thronging cemeteries here today, Mexicans are adding a Halloween tradition without abandoning the older one. Many parents who accompanied their children on Thursday night said they would be out today making altars and adorning graves.
At the Dolores cemetery, there were reminders of the deep emotions engaged by the Day of the Dead. A young mother, Lucia Mena de Acevedo, wove a blanket of red roses to lay on the tomb of her daughter Mireya, who died of liver disease last year when she was 7. Siblings and cousins sat by quietly.
"We want her to know that we will always keep the flowers fresh for her," Mrs. Acevedo said, fighting tears. She let her two other children go out on Thursday night to ask for candy, to let them feel that life is moving on after their sister's death.
"But we are in Mexico," Mrs. Acevedo said. "We don't call it Halloween."

HEADLINE: Mergers Continue Record Pace, but One Alliance Falters;
MCI Deal Would Speed Pace of Current Mergers

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Every day seems to bring yet another announcement of a multibillion-dollar merger and acquisition deal, and with almost two months left in the year, British Telecommunications' pending $22 billion acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation would propel 1996 well beyond last year's record.
A deal for MCI, once it has been formally announced, would bring the total volume of merger deals to $537 billion, up from $518 billion in all of 1995 and well ahead of $341.9 billion in deals during 1994, according to the Securities Data Company. More than a trillion dollars worth of deals were struck in 1995 and 1996. 
 Those numbers dwarf the high-water mark of the previous decade, $353 billion in 1988. In the recession, merger activity declined precipitously, falling to $137.2 billion in 1991. But a resurgent stock market and a looser regulatory environment revived merger activity in recent years.
"In the last three years, the velocity of the expansion of the merger market has been astonishing," said Arthur Fleischer, a partner at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, a mergers and acquisitions law firm in New York. Nothing suggests that this trend will cease any time soon. Scale, location, financial capacity and the ability to compete globally help make it a very aggressive acquisition marketplace. It is also clearly stimulated by the availability of capital and the level of stock prices."
The fast pace of merger activity is nowhere more evident than in the media and telecommunications industries, where deregulation and international competition have removed both commercial and territorial barriers. The possible British Telecom-MCI deal follows by months the announcement of the Bell Atlantic Corporation's $21.3 billion acquisition of Nynex Corporation. Earlier this year, SBC Communications bid $16.5 billion for the Pacific Telesis Group; World-Com Inc. announced the purchase of MFS Communications Company in a stock swap valued at $13.6 billion, and the Hughes Electronics Corporation moved to acquire Panamsat Corporation for $3 billion.
But about 60 percent of the activity is taking place among mature industries and companies -- in such fields as retailing, banking and health care -- driven together in a search for strength and lower costs because they are unable to increase profits through price or production increases.
Sears, Roebuck & Company has announced it intends to buy the Orchard Supply Hardware Stores Corporation for $308 million, while Staples Inc. has an agreement to acquire its larger rival, Office Depot Inc., in a $3.36 billion deal. More recently, the Rite Aid Corporation announced an agreement to acquire Thrifty Payless Holdings Inc., in a $1.4 billion stock deal. The move would create the dominant drugstore chain on the East and West Coasts, even as Rite Aid sheds hundreds of stores in the Southeast, where it runs a distant fourth to its competition.
Safeway Inc., the supermarket chain, was also seeking to become a market leader on the West Coast when it announced plans to buy the Vons Companies, a leading chain in Southern California, for $1.6 billion.
Although many consumers fear that the merger trend will lead to layoffs, higher prices and less competition, bankers, lawyers and corporate executives contend that the tidal wave of mergers and acquisitions enables the combining companies to cut administrative expenses and redundant services and to pass along the savings.
"All this is leading to massive consolidation, making American business as strong as ever, and leading to lower prices for consumers," the investment banker Peter Solomon said.
Amid the surge of multibillion-dollar deals, Merrill Lynch & Company moved into first place in handling transactions after years of running behind Goldman, Sachs & Company and Morgan Stanley. According to Securities Data, Merrill Lynch has advised on deals valued at a total of $145.3 billion so far this year, compared with $127.7 billion for Morgan Stanley and $92 billion for Goldman, Sachs. At the same time, J. P. Morgan, a relatively recent entry to the merger field in the United States, has climbed into seventh position.
The explosion of merger deals has witnessed the resurrection of Bruce Wasserstein, the financier who heads Wasserstein Perella & Company. The once highflying deal maker, who urged corporate executives to dare to be great during the 1980's by undertaking huge takeover battles and assuming comparable debt, became a symbol of the excess of the era. His firm drifted out of the standings as colleagues defected.
But Mr. Wasserstein and his firm have made a comeback, albeit as a gentler, less public deal maker, ranking 11th this year among merger advisers, up from 20th in 1992. He is currently advising Aetna Life and Casualty Company on its $8.8 billion bid to purchase U.S. Healthcare Inc. and form the nation's largest medical benefits company; he is also advising Diamond Shamrock on its friendly $1 billion acquisition of the Ultramar Corporation, which would create the third-largest independent oil refining and marketing company.

HEADLINE: A Plunge From Hoop Dream to Nightmare

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ with VINCENT M. MALLOZZI 

 BODY:
Richie Adams sat in the stands at Madison Square Garden two weeks ago with the bill of his baseball cap pulled low over his face, his eyes darting back and forth as the New York Knicks and his buddy Larry Johnson scrambled across the court.
He wasn't hiding from his fans that day, the people who might have remembered him as a star basketball center, a jaw-dropping leaper with tireless legs who played for Jerry Tarkanian and the University of Nevada-Las Vegas during the early 1980's. Instead, Mr. Adams said, he was ducking drug-running killers who were tailing him around town, accusing him of murdering a teen-age girl. 
 "I'm on the run," Mr. Adams, who admits using cocaine and hanging out with neighborhood gangsters, said after the game. "I can't go home because drug dealers there want to kill me."
Six days later, Mr. Adams, 33, was arrested and charged in the killing of Norma Rodriguez, a 14-year-old girl who was found dead on Oct. 15 in the Melrose section of the Bronx, one floor below Mr. Adams's mother's apartment. She had been bludgeoned to death near the elevator. A bloody Adidas sneaker, size 13 1/2, was found just outside the building.
Mr. Adams turned himself in Oct. 23 and pleaded not guilty to murder the next day. Family and friends of Ms. Rodriguez, who lived across the street, said Mr. Adams had been stalking her.
Mr. Adams's tumble from pro prospect to suspect in a gruesome killing was slow and incremental and, to his coaches and teammates, heart-breaking. Mr. Adams, they say, did not miss just one opportunity to play with the Johnsons and Jordans of the N.B.A. He missed a string of them.
There was an offer from the Washington Bullets, international league contracts, a casino job in Las Vegas, and the pleas and affection of his U.N.L.V. coach, Mr. Tarkanian.
"Everybody in Las Vegas loved him, but every time he went back to New York he got in trouble," said his coach, Mr. Tarkanian, holding back tears. "We tried real hard to get him not to go back to New York."
New York, though, was Mr. Adams's haven. On the streets of Harlem and the South Bronx, he understood instinctively what to say and when to say it. It didn't matter that he couldn't read or write well.
What mattered was his prowess on the court, and in the end, the steady supply of cocaine and easy adulation it brought him, friends say. Despite the streetwise veneer, Mr. Adams was also a man more malleable than tough, a willing follower who never considered taking a lead position off the court.
"When he was around good people, he did the right thing," said Danny Tarkanian, the coach's son and Mr. Adams's friend and former teammate. "When he was around the wrong crowd, he messed up."
On the hardwood, Mr. Adams seemed to float above it all. He was gifted, a 6-foot-9-inch player who was nimble on his feet and rebounded with confidence and precision.
In New York City, his size and agility turned him into one of the most sought-after summer tournament players. The Animal, people called him. In Las Vegas, his talent made him a celebrity.
 
Player of the Year, Two Years in a Row
In each of his last two seasons at U.N.L.V., in which the Runnin' Rebels finished with a combined record of 57-10, he was the conference player of the year. He finished his college career with 1,168 points and 623 rebounds. Some say that in his prime, Mr. Adams could have outrebounded Dennis Rodman.
In 1985, he made the ultimate leap, becoming a fourth-round draft pick for the Washington Bullets. The day after the draft he was arrested for stealing a car in the Bronx. It was the beginning of his free fall.
"Richie was a great player," said Mr. Tarkanian, who was ultimately forced out of U.N.L.V. amid controversy and a feud with the university president. He is now head coach at California State University at Fresno.
"What made him such a special person," Mr. Tarkanian said, "is that despite his greatness, he was never cocky or self-assuming. He never boasted about the things he accomplished on the basketball court.
"He was one of the quickest jumpers I have ever seen. He was like a pogo stick, he was so quick off of his feet, and he could jump just as high the second time as he did the first, and just as high the third time as he had jumped the second."
Mr. Adams was at his best from 1981 to 1984, while he was at U.N.L.V. He warmed to his teammates quickly and worked hard on the court. Toward the end of his career there, he was always the first to volunteer to speak to elementary-school children about staying off drugs and graduating from high school, advice Mr. Adams never took to heart.
At one Rebel party honoring the players' parents, Mr. Adams brought seven local children as his guests. During his off time, he took children no taller than his kneecaps to the 7-Eleven for Slurpees.
"He loved talking to the kids," said Paul Brozovich, a former teammate. "And the kids really loved him."
But Mr. Adams, who had not yet learned to read or write at 14, could not shake off the lure of New York City's streets. At times, he so missed hanging out with his "get-high" buddies in New York that he isolated himself from the team. Coaches and teammates thought he was manic-depressive. Mr. Adams was convinced he just needed to go home, and he did that, when his grandmother died, taking a year off in 1982 before returning to play for the next two seasons.
That year, Mr. Adams ambled around his gritty neighborhood in high style, a star admired even by rich drug dealers. It was a feeling he had always coveted, one he first tasted in 1978 as a hotshot player on the top-ranked Benjamin Franklin High School team in East Harlem, teammates said.
"He never wanted to leave his neighborhood," said a Franklin High School teammate and lifelong friend, Gary Springer, who now lives in North Carolina. "He was just a street kid like the rest of us."
From an early age, Mr. Adams had a penchant for trouble. The people around him chalked it up to poor upbringing, simple-mindedness and dangerous friendships, but they held out hope that his talent would prevail. At school, he was a truant with a reputation for using drugs and stealing, said Stan Dinner, a former basketball coach for Franklin High, now closed, who recruited Mr. Adams.
"Every now and then, he would shock you by doing something stupid," Mr. Dinner said. "He would get caught stealing apples from the cafeteria when all he had to do was ask for them."
Mr. Dinner recalls picking up the phone in his office one afternoon and hearing a police officer tell him Mr. Adams was in custody. "Richie had stolen my car," Mr. Dinner said. "He went on a joy ride. Of course, I dropped the charges."
At home, after he left U.N.L.V. and squandered his shot at the N.B.A. by being arrested, Mr. Adams sought refuge on the asphalt playground courts of Holcombe Rucker Memorial Park in Harlem, where the city's best players face off every summer in a brash and brazen display of skill.
Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Wilt Chamberlain and Stephon Marbury were among the best who made it. Many more did not, like Joe Hammond, dubbed the Destroyer; Herman (the Helicopter) Knowings, and Earl Manigault, called the Goat, who dunked a ball backward 36 times in a row to win a $60 bet.
The Rucker League summer tournaments, which have no official sponsors, also earned a reputation for bending the rules, and sometimes the law, former players and coaches say. High stakes gambling on games, under-the-table payments to players and team sponsorship by drug dealers are not uncommon. It is no secret that the best players are paid well for these ultracompetitive tournaments. Victory at Rucker Park is a matter of honor to drug dealers.
"There is definitely a drug element in the Rucker League, and a few teams are run by drug dealers who are looking for their own fame," said James Ryan, who has coached Mr. Adams in summer tournaments since he was a teen-ager. "They love saying, 'I have Richie Adams on my team.' "
 
$1,000 a Game, Spent on Drugs
Mr. Adams found he could make a comfortable living playing in local tournaments.
"A lot of basketball teams I play for in different tournaments are run by drug dealers who pay me to play for them," he said after a recent Knicks game. The dealers, he said, often dropped him off at home at the Andrew Jackson Houses in a gleaming Mercedes-Benz or Lexus. He had a steady paycheck and his ego was being stroked. He was needed on the court.
"In his prime, Richie made a ton of money playing in the summer leagues," said Lenzell Vaughn, who played with Mr. Adams in tournaments and was known as the Predator on the court. "People would do anything to have him play for them. They would buy him clothes, sneakers and even food, if he was hungry."
But Mr. Adams, who Mr. Ryan said was probably making $1,000 a game during his best years, spent most of his money on drugs, especially cocaine, friends said. Even after he fathered two children with different women, he kept draining his wallet to get high, they said. Not even the drug dealers approved, Mr. Ryan said.
"Of course it was drug money he was being paid, but no one told him to buy drugs with it," Mr. Ryan said. "Heck, if these dealers wanted to see Richie get high, they would have paid him in drugs, not cash, because that would have been a lot cheaper. Believe me, no drug dealer, especially the ones who bet big money on some of those games, would want to see one of their players show up high."
When his money ran out, Mr. Adams turned to crime. Between 1988 and 1989, he was convicted three times. He snatched two purses and held up a woman at an automated teller machine, placing a gun to her jaw. In April 1989, Mr. Adams was sent to an upstate prison, where he played ball behind barbed wire as shotgun-toting guards watched.
Through it all, his teammates and coaches tried to help him see past the easy money. Mr. Tarkanian sent him airline tickets to Las Vegas. Mr. Adams cashed them in. He lined up a job for Mr. Adams at a casino, a route many former U.N.L.V. players take when they graduate, but Mr. Adams ignored the offer.
After Mr. Adams was sent to prison, Mr. Tarkanian and his son, Danny, tried unsuccessfully to get the Governor of Nevada to permit him to enter a work-release program in Las Vegas. Teammates and friends encouraged him to play basketball abroad, and he did, briefly, in Argentina, but New York never failed to tug him home.
"Playing in those summer tournaments in Harlem," said Mr. Dinner, Mr. Adams's former high school coach who now owns a restaurant, "Richie was a legend here in New York, and that's one of the reasons why he always wanted to go back. It was a safe, comfortable place for him."
When he got out of prison in April 1994, Mr. Adams returned to his mother's apartment in the Bronx. People in the neighborhood pulled for him once again.
"There was a lot of love out here for him, but he just went back to it," said James Howard, who grew up in the same projects and remembers when Mr. Adams came home.
Eventually, it became common knowledge in his building at 3050 Park Avenue that little had changed. Mr. Adams still used drugs, friends said. He was still unemployed.
But one thing was different: his game. No longer a young man with a marquee name, Mr. Adams was paid considerably less for his time on the court. Fewer games came his way. Neighbors said he again turned to stealing to finance his habit, sometimes in his own building. The crimes were not reported, they said, because residents were afraid.
"People stayed clear of him," Mr. Howard said. "He was a smooth operator. He never stayed long here."
His basketball buddies also noticed that he had taken another downward turn. "I was aware that Richie had drug problems," Mr. Vaughn said. "He'd show up before games and say, 'I'm so tired.' He was real dragging and his eyes looked so droopy. I knew right there he was getting high."
Mr. Dinner remembers Mr. Adams coming into his restaurant last year. "He looked horrible," Mr. Dinner said. "His hair was matted and his clothes did not look fresh. I gave him an order of chicken wings and a bottle of beer. He said, 'Coach, can you spot me a few bucks?' "
Still, the people who know him best said they are astonished that Mr. Adams, a man never seen fighting, not even after taking an intentional elbow to the face on the court, could have committed murder. Most said they never heard him mention Norma Rodriguez, the girl he is charged with killing. As for the size 13 1/2 sneaker found nearby, Mr. Adams says he wears a size 15.
"I don't know if Richie did this," Mr. Dinner added, "but anything is possible. Drugs do strange things to people, and Richie is a very strong guy. What a shame. What a waste. Here's a guy who really had a chance to go places."

HEADLINE: 'President McKinley's Paper' Evolves, and So Do Its Political Endorsements

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE: Editorial History

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 1

 BODY:
In 177 years, Canton's newspaper, The Repository, had never endorsed a Democrat for President. "President McKinley's paper," they called it, and it really was, owned by his wife's family. In the 1896 Presidential election, run from the front porch of the McKinley home here, special editions of The Repository featuring the daily speeches of William McKinley were printed each evening and sent round America by train.
Far into the modern era, it continued a Republican paper editorially and in news columns. For four decades, through the 1970's, The Repository was run by Clayton G. Horn, a legendary Ohio editor and rabid Republican, who once banned his reporters from using the name of Canton's Democratic Mayor in the paper, who rewrote the editorial on the Kent State killings in 1970 to be more supportive of the National Guard and had such a close relationship with James Rhodes, the Republican Governor of Ohio, that he could call and say, "Jim? Clayt! I want you in my office tomorrow at noon!" And the Governor would be there. 
 Then, in 1992, The Repository endorsed Bill Clinton. "You could feel the earth tremble," said Michael Hanke, The Repository's current editor. A former publisher of the paper, John Siam, a Republican, who presided over the endorsements of Presidents Reagan and Bush in the 1980's before retiring in 1990, put it this way: "I felt like throwing up when I read it." W. R. Timken Jr., the fourth-generation Timken to run the steel and bearing company here, said, "I thought they were nuts."
That the paper of McKinley, Rhodes and the Ohio National Guard would endorse Bill Clinton, says a lot about how much small-town newspapering and politics have changed in America in the last decades and about the kind of Democrat Mr. Clinton is. The 1992 endorsement was the final, most public step in a slow transformation that began 25 years earlier when the Thomson chain bought The Repository.
The Repository's editorial board met Monday, Oct. 21, at 10 A.M. to decide the paper's 1996 Presidential endorsement. Attending were James Smith, 37, the publisher, who came here in January 1995, from Thomson's corporate headquarters in Stamford, Conn.; Mr. Hanke, 47, the editor for 16 years now; Bill Hopper, 60, the editorial page editor, and David Kaminski, 44, the managing editor. As is true at all 85 Thomson newspapers, the local publisher has the final word on endorsements. Mr. Smith would later say, he came in, "looking for a reason to endorse Dole."
They agreed that the economy and character were the big issues, and that they needed to decide, as Mr. Hanke said, whether President Clinton had "fulfilled our wishes" from the paper's 1992 endorsement.
"Character isn't just about the womanizer or the guy involved in Whitewater," began Mr. Hopper. "If you broaden it out, you see a man willing to take some tough decisions, take some risks."
As for Mr. Dole's political character, Mr. Hopper said: "I was terribly disappointed. The Dole I expected was not the Dole running for President. He immediately changed positions." Mr. Hopper mentioned the 15 percent tax-cut proposal and the selection of Jack Kemp, whose supply side views were at odds with Mr. Dole's ideas. "So I don't think it's a clear-cut decision. The character issue is not all a minus for Clinton."
"I'm frightened," said Mr. Kaminski, "that we will be embarrassed as a newspaper if we endorse Clinton and have a huge scandal break out." He said Mr. Hopper's idea to factor in Mr. Clinton's political character for taking on groups like the gun lobby, could be "the way out of this problem."
"To maintain our integrity," said Mr. Hopper, "the editorial would have to raise the possibility that something may blow up."
The publisher looked uneasy. "A newspaper's choice in making an editorial endorsement should be on a higher plane," Mr. Smith said.
Today under Mr. Hanke, The Repository, with a daily circulation of 62,000, is a fairer, better quality newspaper than it was 25 years ago, (named the best paper of its size in Ohio the last two years.) Indeed, Mr. Hanke is so guarded about his politics in this place where secrets don't keep, he registers as an independent.
On the other hand, The Repository is also a far less influential paper than it was in the 1950's, 1960's, and 1970's, when its cigar-chomping, profanity-spewing, tyrannical Republican editor teamed up with Canton's business elite to bring two state colleges and a medical school to this region, move two highways to more convenient spots, and snag the Pro Football Hall of Fame for Ohio's ninth-largest city.
In those days under Clayton Horn, there was no editorial board meeting to decide a Presidential endorsement. "Clayt wrote the editorial and handed it to me," said Mr. Hopper, the editorial page editor here for 28 years. "And we printed it."
In the 1960's, Mr. Horn was No. 1 on a list of the 10 most influential people in Stark County. The Football Hall of Fame is in Canton thanks to Mr. Horn. Germane Swanson, a sportswriter, had the original idea. "Clayt was into bowling at the time and he said, 'That's a 12-strike idea! Let's go for it!' " recalled Mr. Swanson. Mr. Horn brought together William Umstattd, The Timken Company president and Paul Brown of the Cleveland Browns, who in the 1930's had coached one of Stark's great high school football powers, Massillon.
Mr. Umstattd lined up business leaders. Mr. Brown handled the National Football League. And Mr. Horn took care of publicity. On Dec. 9, 1959, the campaign began with a story in The Repository headlined, "Pro Football Needs Hall of Fame and Logical Site Is Here." In two years it was.
Mr. Hanke, the current editor, was a cub reporter in the early 1970's covering a regional board meeting about bringing a state medical school to nearby Rootstown. Mr. Horn and the Akron Beacon-Journal editor, Ben Maidenburg, were both on the board and the only ones talking at the meeting, according to Mr. Hanke. "Maidenburg and Horn said, 'You do this, you do this, I'll call Jim,' " (Governor Rhodes). "I'll call Vern," (Vern Riffe, Speaker of the Ohio House at the time). "And that was it."
The Repository in those days was the flagship of the Brush-Moore newspapers, a small chain that included a half-dozen small-town Ohio papers. Mr. Horn wrote editorials and wired them to the other papers which were under orders to print them. In an interview with The Repository in 1993, shortly before he died, Mr. Horn explained his philosophy. "This was a Republican newspaper and you didn't forget that," he said, bragging that one year 22 of 23 endorsements were Republicans. "And 22 won!" he said.
In the 1950's Canton was a wide-open town, with a red light district. "Clayt wanted it cleaned up, so he had Stanley Cmich run for Mayor," recalled Mr. Swanson. Mr. Cmich, a Republican, of course, served 20 years and was widely respected.
But there was another side to Mr. Horn, that would not be acceptable in newsrooms today. In the 1950's he banned the name of the Democratic Mayor, Charles Babcock, from the paper, referring to him as "a city official."
Mr. Hanke says as a young reporter, Mr. Horn spiked one of his stories that made the Republican Mayor look wrong on a revenue-sharing issue. Mr. Hopper's editorial on the four students killed at Kent State was also spiked. It was replaced by Mr. Horn's own editorial that was supportive of the National Guard, which was sent to the campus by Mr. Horn's political ally and friend, Governor Rhodes, to keep order at a university where Mr. Horn was a member of the board.
"Has anyone read anything that makes the tax-cut plan close to viable?" asked Mr. Smith, the publisher.
"No and I've looked," said Mr. Hanke.
Mr. Kaminski had a question for the publisher. "Let me ask you. Do you feel, as the operator of our business, that this administration has been a problem? Is it difficult to do business under Clinton?"
"The answer," said Mr. Smith, "is in the results and the truth of it is, it's not. The last couple of years have been better than the early 90's. A lot of folks I talk to are supporting Dole, but will say on the side, 'I can take a couple of more years like the last couple.' Just look at the companies here. Hoover's doing O.K., thank you. Diebold's making big profits, Timken's doing all sorts of expansion."
"We're looking at another record quarter for Timken," said Mr. Kaminski, adding that Ed Semmler, the business editor, "was pitching it" for page 1 at the morning news meeting.
In 1980, a new publisher, Mr. Siam, was brought in by the Thomson chain. He picked as his editor Mr. Hanke, a Canton native and Notre Dame graduate, who was only 30 at the time but had worked almost every job on the paper. Mr. Siam was impressed by Mr. Hanke's intellect, his sense of fairness and his feelings for Canton. Indeed, in the 16 years since, Mr. Hanke had many chances to climb the Thomson corporate ladder, but chose to stay. He is the kind of editor who issues as few orders as possible. On primary night last March, he was at the board of elections with his political reporters, helping them download results from their computers.
"I'm one of the luckiest guys you'll meet," said Mr. Hanke, the son of a union construction worker. "I'm editor of my hometown newspaper." His goal was to make The Repository the best paper of its size in Ohio. "I thought it would take just a few years," he said.
Shortly after taking over, Mr. Siam and Mr. Hanke recall being asked by some Republican Party leaders to lunch at Bender's, the favorite downtown political hangout. "We went upstairs and sat down," said Mr. Hanke, "They wanted a political contribution to the Republicans. I was steamed, but Siam didn't say anything for a while. We had a few drinks, then Siam said, 'I'm sorry, we don't do that.' Afterwards we were walking back to the paper and I said, 'I can't believe that.' And he said, 'Mike it's their job to ask, it's my job to say no.' "
For the first time candidates were invited to come in and make their case on why they should be endorsed -- both Republicans and Democrats. Mr. Hanke wrote Editor & Publisher, the industry's trade publication, and had the paper's affliation switched from "Republican" to "Independent."
In 1996 the paper has endorsed a few more Democrats than Republicans for office; in 1994, more Republicans.
The entire editorial staff is only 65 people, including clerks and secretaries, so each new hire has been precious. There were many who had given years of service and couldn't be let go, but couldn't adapt to a modern newspaper, either.
"I'd move people aside who couldn't do the job and let them keep their titles," said Mr. Hanke, "then I'd put in more talented people with lesser titles to do the job."
They went hunting for young, aggressive reporters. At a suburban meeting one night, Mr. Hanke found the paper's star projects reporter, M. L. Schultze, who worked for a radio station at the time. She was hammering questions at an official during a break while the rest of the press was out having a smoke. For the first time, they sought out talented minority reporters like Charita Goshay, a journalism school graduate who was designing department store windows when the city editor, Rick Senften, found her.
Five years ago The Repository finally cracked the Associated Press awards, finishing third in its category. Three years ago, it was second, and the last two years, first. "It was always my goal," said Mr. Hanke. "It just took so much longer than I thought."
Mr. Hopper said, "I'd say he's earned another four years."
"Dole on the whole has given us nothing to vote for," said Mr. Hanke.
"If he had," said Mr. Kaminiski, "the paper would endorse him."
"If he hadn't said that goofy 15 percent," said the publisher.
"I think of Clinton as a student of history," said Mr. Hanke, "I think he's interested in how he'll be viewed down the road. Because of that I think he'll try very hard to do" things that "will have significant impact in this term."
"Mr. Publisher," Mr. Hanke added, "you have the veto power."
"We have serious concerns about this man," said Mr. Smith, "his lack of character, the integrity of the White House and his appointments. Right?" Mr. Smith wanted the editorial to make some comment on "the political system that gives us candidates we can't get excited about." There was an awkward quiet.
"Maybe it's a subject of other pieces," said Mr. Hanke, and Mr. Hopper said, "You endorse somebody, you endorse them warts and all."
"It's pretty damn sad," said the publisher. "The pre-campaign Dole, we would have endorsed. Ah. . . . geeze."
For all The Repository has improved, there is something that has been lost in communities like Stark with the passing of the Clayton Horns. Mr. Horn was the catalyst for a ruling elite that made things happen. Today, there is a power vacuum in mid-sized Ohio cities like Canton and Dayton and Springfield that is obvious from driving downtown and seeing so many vacant buildings on the main streets.
"Clayt would have done something about those problems," said Mr. Hopper. "He was absolutely fearless in pursuing things for this community."
Today, the newspaper's community causes are safer, like helping fight illiteracy. The Repository's influence comes through its news pages, like its investigative pieces by Ms. Schultze of corruption in local Head Start programs.
Mr. Hanke says, "I hear people say, 'Don't blame Mike, he can't tell his reporters what to do the way Clayt would.' The implication is I don't have the authority. The truth is, I believe an editor's job is to provide an environment so journalists are free to do their jobs."
Mr. Horn, on the other hand, tried to control things to the very end. Two years before he died, he mailed in his advance obituary. "I wrote it myself," he told Mr. Hanke, "because I wanted to get it right, damnit."
"The newspaper will catch hell for this," said Mr. Kaminski.
"Well, Clinton and the Democrats are a hell of a lot more liberal than we are on most issues, right?" said Mr. Smith.
"The Democrats aren't as liberal as they used to be," said Mr. Hanke, "and we're not a Republican paper. I don't think we have been in several years. We're independent people who tend to take the conservative side."
"I'll write a draft," said Mr. Hopper, "and we'll all take a crack at it?"
"Write her up," said Mr. Smith.
Last Sunday, The Plain-Dealer in Democratic Cleveland to the north, endorsed Mr. Clinton and The Dispatch in Republican Columbus to the west, chose Mr. Dole, while the paper of McKinley, Mr. Hanke and Mr. Smith swung Democrat this time.
 
Living midway between Democratic Cleveland and Republican Columbus, the citizens of Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County have a history of voting for the winning Presidential candidate. This is the 34th article in a yearlong series that seeks to explore the forces shaping the political debate at the grass roots. (Previous articles are available to computer users on The New York Times on the Web, at http://www.nytimes.com/specials/canton.)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: RACES FOR GOVERNOR;
A Democrat Is Struggling in a Democratic Haven, West Virginia

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: MARTINSBURG, W.Va., Oct. 28

 BODY:
Charlotte Pritt, the Democratic nominee for governor here, likes to brag of the close relationship she forged with President Clinton during a brief ride on Air Force One a few months ago.
If she is elected and calls the White House to request help for West Virginia, Ms. Pritt assures voters, Mr. Clinton's response will be, "How much, and when do you need it?" 
 Right now it is Ms. Pritt, a former teacher and state senator, who needs Mr. Clinton's help in what is shaping up as the nation's tightest governor's race. Tagged by her Republican opponent as too liberal even for heavily Democratic West Virginia and dogged by feuds with members of her own party, she has seen an early lead disappear and now trails former Gov. Cecil H. Underwood in the race to succeed Gov. Gaston Caperton, a Democrat who has served two terms and is barred by state law from seeking a third.
Mr. Clinton has no plans to do what would help Ms. Pritt most: campaign in West Virginia for her in the race's closing days. Still, Ms. Pritt links herself to Mr. Clinton at every chance, and her best hope is that a wide margin of victory here for the President and other Democrats, including Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, will bring her the votes she needs.
But West Virginia -- one of 11 states electing a governor this year and among the 7 with Democratic incumbents -- ranks, along with Indiana, as one of the best hopes for Republicans to gain a governor's mansion.
The latest statewide poll, conducted Oct. 17-18 by the Mason-Dixon Research polling organization among 822 registered voters who said they were likely to vote, showed Mr. Underwood leading by 48 percent to 43 percent. The poll had a sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
For Mr. Underwood, the race is a chance for a remarkable political resurrection. Elected governor in 1956 at age 34, he was the youngest chief executive in the state's history. Under the state's Constitution at the time, he was barred from seeking a second term in 1960 but ran and lost two later races for governor, in 1964 and 1976.
He will turn 74 on Election Day, and if he wins, he will be West Virginia's oldest governor.
Mr. Underwood has been campaigning as a moderate who can build on the progress that the state -- long ravaged by the decline of coal mining and other industries -- has made in recent years in attracting new industry and reducing unemployment. A former college president who has been active in luring technology companies to West Virginia, he has emphasized reducing regulations on business, cutting state spending and improving education.
He has also raised questions about whether Ms. Pritt, a coal miner's daughter from the heavily unionized southern part of the state, is too beholden to labor and other special interests and would scare away industries considering moving to or expanding in the state.
Ms. Pritt, who is 47, has taken some pro-labor positions, saying she would make state employees eligible for collective bargaining and promising to increase the amount of money that corporations have to pay into the workers' compensation fund.
She argues that her working-class background makes her particularly sensitive to the concerns of working families, and her platform includes a promise of universal access to health care by the end of her second term. Yet she has increased her efforts to moderate her image, portraying herself as a friend of small business and a member of the National Rifle Association.
"When people say business is going to leave because of Charlotte Pritt, well, they don't have a lick of common sense, as my Momma used to say," she said. "I'll be the hardest fighter to keep the good-paying jobs that West Virginia's ever seen."
Although she retains a strong base in the state's southern coal-mining district, she is having a tougher time with moderate Democratic swing voters elsewhere, particularly here in the northeastern panhandle.
She also suffering from a rift she caused in the party establishment. Four years ago, after losing in the Democratic primary to Mr. Caperton, she ran a write-in campaign in the general election that failed but left him furious with her. Still angry, Mr. Caperton has given her only the most tepid support.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

MCI Shares Soar on News Of British Telecom Talks
MCI stock rose 20.4 percent in extremely heavy volume as word leaked out that the company was negotiating a merger with British Telecom. The stock was the most active and the largest percentage gainer, rising $5.125 to $30.25. American depository receipts for British Telecom fell $2.125, to $55.50. 
 MCI's rise came on a lackluster day in the market, as traders worried about the election and about the potential for lower corporate profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.45 to 6,021.93. [Page 41.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities slipped, as economic reports showed the pace of growth in jobs and manufacturing slowing but not enough to ease investors' concern that inflation could rebound later this year. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.68 percent, up from 6.64 percent Thursday. [41.]
 
G.M. Sales Decline 7.9 Percent; Reich Calls for Strike Settlement
General Motors reported a 7.9 percent decline in vehicle sales last month from a year earlier, even as Chrysler, Honda and Toyota all announced their highest October sales ever. G.M.'s car sales were off 24 percent, but sales of pickup trucks, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles rose 22.1 percent. G.M. executives and U.A.W. leaders continued contract talks, as Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich called for a settlement of the union's three-day strike. [39.]
 
Detroit Seeks Slower Air Bags
The Big Three auto makers asked Federal authorities for permission begin using air bags that inflate more slowly to reduce the risk of neck-injury deaths among children and short adults from rapidly inflating air bags. [1.]
 
High Court Accepts Asbestos Cases
Agreeing to confront the litigation crisis caused by huge numbers of lawsuits over exposure to asbestos, the Supreme Court accepted two cases that will help define how the Federal courts treat the legal claims of people who have been exposed to toxic substances but have not yet become ill. [8.]
 
Longer Hours for German Shops
German retailers tried hard to look happy as the nation's stores were allowed to begin staying open past 6:30 P.M. on weekdays -- but never on Sunday. Privately, however, many small shopkeepers grumbled that longer hours would raise labor costs without increasing sales -- and even give rise to American-style malls. With more families having two wage-earners, consumers have demanded longer shopping hours. [3.]
 
Viacom's Earnings Advance
Viacom said that its operating profits rose 31.7 percent in the third quarter, based on the strength of results from its MTV Networks, Paramount studios and Blockbuster video stores. With a one-time $1.3 billion gain from the sale of its cable systems, net income was $1.4 billion, or $3.82 a share, up from $93.8 million, or 21 cents a share. [38.]
 
Corn and Soybean Futures Fall
Corn and soybean futures prices fell as ideal weather was forecast for this weekend, allowing farmers to harvest bumper crops. Crude oil futures fell to a two-month low, as rising heating oil inventories signaled an end to last month's rally. [40.]
 
Dollar Falls Against Yen and Mark
The dollar fell after Lloyd M. Bentsen, a former Treasury Secretary, said further gains would hurt American competitiveness. The dollar was quoted in New York at 113.31 yen, down from 114.05 late Thursday, and at 1.5145 marks, down from 1.5178. [40.]
 
New York Allows Mace Sales
The sale of Chemical Mace and other self-defense sprays became legal in New York State, and at least one store in Manhattan reported heavy sales. But there was no sign of a widespread stampede. [27.]
