HEADLINE: Standing by His Man In Role After Role;
Mickey Kantor, Gutsy Campaigner, Has Smoothed Clinton's Path

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: ASHTABULA, Ohio, Oct. 29

 BODY:
It is midday at the sprawling Pinney Dock, and halfway through a tour of the piles of coal and iron ore moving off the waterfront on Lake Erie, Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor is already spewing the endless statistics that he repeats nonstop from one Congressional district to the next.
Told that companies in this northeastern corner of Ohio are badly in need of better trained recruits, he goes into a familiar patter. "We've created 2.6 million new jobs a year -- higher than job growth under President Reagan, and, as you know, much higher than under President Bush" -- and tells local newspaper and television reporters that the Republican incumbent in the district has obstructed every effort in Washington to improve worker training. 
 Spotting raw materials headed for nearby auto plants, Mr. Kantor cites "the 900,000 people now directly employed in the autos and auto-parts sector, the highest figure since the 1960's," and then, barely pausing for breath, races through a review of Ohio's export surge: "Twenty-two billion dollars! Up from just $15 billion when this President took office!"
Even the Democratic candidate Mr. Kantor has come to endorse, Thomas J. Coyne, who is Mayor of a nearby town, seems a bit stunned by the numerical blitz. He tells Mr. Kantor that it's too bad he missed the local pig roast the previous weekend. "On Tuesday we'll roast something else," Mr. Kantor shoots back.
If the Clinton Administration has run a perpetual campaign for the last four years, no one has pursued the strategy with more vigor than Mickey Kantor. First as United States trade representative, and since last spring as Commerce Secretary, following the death of Ronald H. Brown, he has fine-tuned the ancient Washington art of using trade accords to benefit the political fortunes of the President. Expansive and insistent, by turns charming and combative, he has talked for four years about the need to open markets. But his critics, who are particularly plentiful in Canada, Mexico, Japan and China, make a strong case that he is never shy about turning to protectionism if that is the best way to mollify a key constituency or defuse anger against the Administration in a key electoral battleground.
This is, after all, a man who keeps two telephones on his desk, one for official business and the other a private line, which he pays for himself, for endless political strategizing. "I once saw him talking on both at the same time," one of his former aides and admirers recalled recently. "And that's the real Mickey: total fusion."
He has kept the flow of low-priced Mexican tomatoes to Florida in check, using the threat of trade sanctions against Mexico to quiet the complaints of growers in a state that until a few months ago Mr. Clinton appeared to have little chance of winning. The growers are still unlikely to support Mr. Clinton, but they have not organized against him.
Late last year, he moved to suspend a provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement that would have allowed Mexican trucks to rove through Texas and California. His argument: Inspections show many of the trucks are unsafe, and many are laden with hidden caches of drugs. But the delay, which continues, in letting them into the country had a convenient side benefit for truckers in two of the most electoral-vote-rich states in the country.
Long before most Americans were focused on the 1996 campaign, Mr. Kantor, working from the trade representative's building across from the White House, was overseeing deals on wheat and softwood lumber that quieted discontent in the Midwest and Northwest, even though the solution in both cases imposed quotas that amounted to highly managed trade.
And Mr. Kantor's most high-profile trade battle -- a bruising dust-up with Japan over autos and auto parts that consumed him during the first half of 1995 -- has had a not entirely coincidental payoff. It helped win back the support of labor leaders who were outraged at him after he pushed through the Administration's two biggest free-trade deals, Nafta and the worldwide trade accord that established a new and powerful world trade organization.
"Nafta's come and gone," George Becker, the international president of the United Steelworkers of America, said while campaigning in Pennsylvania with Mr. Kantor. "We've come to understand each other."
Mr. Kantor insists that in each of these cases good trade policy came before good politics. He committed himself to solving the tomato problem, he notes, years before anyone could know that President Clinton had a shot at winning Florida. He said it would have been "foolishness" to allow unsafe trucks in to the country. And "there was no politics in the auto deal," he said, which arose from "a clear vision that the inability to get cars and car parts into Japan was a symbol of our past failures" in trade policy.
"To be successful at this you need to be political without being partisan," he concluded. "But are there incidental political benefits in opening markets and creating jobs? You bet there are."
Mr. Kantor's political skills have been taxed this last week. As he campaigned, his department was enmeshed in the controversy over John Huang, the Asian-American who held a midlevel job in the Commerce Department until last December, when he moved to the Democratic National Committee as its chief fund-raiser in the Asian-American community. Several of those contributions now appear to have been illegal, and Commerce has been beseiged with demands from Congress and the media for a full accounting of Mr. Huang's actions at Commerce, particularly his apparently limited role in policy making.
Mr. Huang was gone from Commerce before Mr. Kantor arrived. Still, the Commerce Secretary has found himself in the uncomfortable position of handing over documents that have kept the story alive -- to the annoyance of White House officials who have been trying to contain the damage. Moving through Ohio and Pennsylvania the other day while keeping up with the disclosures by phone, it was clear he was unhappy.
In Mr. Clinton's economic war room, while Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has played the role of the quiet, unflappable master strategist who has watched the charts and kept the troops from wandering away from the message of deficit-cutting, Mr. Kantor has been the fiery tactician. When he showed up in Geneva to negotiate the car accord with Japan, he brought along a bamboo sword used in kendo, a highly ritualized form of Japanese fencing, and presented it to Ryutaro Hashimoto, then the trade minister, now Japan's Prime Minister.
Mr. Kantor's detractors say he has often sliced and diced reality in advancing the Administration's cause.
Robert Lighthizer, trade adviser to the Dole campaign, recently called Mr. Kantor's record "a terribly failed policy" that has left the country with economic anxiety.
"The merchandise trade deficit last year was the worst in history, and this year it will be worse yet -- and twice what it was when the President came to power in 1993," Mr. Lighthizer said. "We've seen a loss of manufacturing jobs and stagnant wages."
Moreover, he said, "our trading partners are treating us like patsies," singling out China as particularly successful in avoiding real penalties for its trade practices. But Bob Dole has made only scant reference to trade in the campaign; a speech on the subject he was said to be preparing never materialized.
Mr. Kantor, who ran Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign, shrugs off the partisan attacks. "It is critical that we build confidence among the American public that we are going to stand by them and make sure that our competitors play by the same rules that we have to play by," he said during his trip to Ohio and Pennsylvania. "That is in my head all the time. And if that helps the President, well there's no shame in that."
Most trade experts agree that Mr. Kantor has racked up a considerable number of accomplishments; the auto deal with Japan has been more successful than American executives expected, even though Tokyo has opened only a fraction of the American car dealerships Mr. Kantor said it would.
Mr. Kantor's defenders point out that the Commerce Department and the trade representative's office have frequently been occupied by political loyalists. Robert S.Strauss, a former Democratic Party chairman, was President Jimmy Carter's trade representative, and William E. Brock, a former Republican chairman, was President Ronald Reagan's. Hanging outside Mr. Kantor's door at the Commerce Department is a portrait of one of his predecessors, Harry L. Hopkins, who was Franklin D. Roosevelt's closest confidante and who, like Mr. Kantor, was charged with both placating the business community and neutralizing it as a potent political opposition.
The parallel is not lost on Mr. Kantor. Everywhere he goes campaigning these days -- Detroit, Phoenix, Seattle, Miami and Newark -- he points out that if Mr. Clinton is elected to a second term on Tuesday, he will be the first Democrat to pull off the feat since F.D.R.
"You have to conclude that Kantor has been enormously skillful at measuring the climate," said I. M. Destler, a University of Maryland trade expert who has just finished a study of the workings of the National Economic Council, an institution the Clinton Administration invented to move economic issues to center stage in the White House. "The first two years were all about market openings, and he closed big deals. And the next two were about political holding actions," strategic retrenchments to make sure that neither workers nor corporate chiefs felt that the Administration was sacrificing them to some ideal of free trade.
"I'm not a free trader," Mr. Kantor happily admitted at a breakfast with reporters in Washington a few weeks ago. "A lot of our agreements have been regulated trade agreements. The goal is to nurture American workers and industry. It is not to adhere to some kind of strict ideology. That would be the height of foolishness."
It is still unclear what role Mr. Clinton's loyalist might play if Mr. Clinton wins a second term. It is unlikely to be at Commerce, a job Mr. Kantor resisted when the President was looking to quickly fill the post after Mr. Brown's death. Mr. Kantor's associates say he agreed only to fill out the term.
When Mr. Kantor relaxes after a long day of stumping for Democratic candidates, he concedes that running the Commerce Department, a lumbering barge of 36,000 employees, is too managerial for his temperament. He clearly misses the informal collegiality of the trade representative's office, which has a staff of 200 and is among the more efficient corners of the Federal Government.
"As the trade representative, I could delve into the middle of every issue and either get the base hit or not," he said recently. "At Commerce, you can't do that. I've had to learn to control my need to dive into every detail. It's the difference between being a manager and a player."
Now the question is whether Mr. Kantor will be a manager or a player in a second term, should Mr. Clinton win. There is talk of Attorney General and of White House chief of staff, a job Mr. Kantor desired four years ago. Now a bit calmer, and more familiar with the chaos of the White House, he seems torn about his next move and could end up once again practicing law.
"I'm totally focused on Nov. 5," he said. "On Nov. 6, I'll worry about what's next."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE RUNNING MATE;
On Stump, Gore Shows a New Touch in Connecting With Crowds

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore, whose boxy shoulders and predilection for polysyllabic earnestness have often made him seem like a kind of uptight Mr. Rogers, looks relaxed these days. No, really.
Mr. Gore is loping through a fast-paced but low-pressure campaign sweep in the last days before the election, mainly intended to help local Congressional candidates. 
 By all appearances, he is having a ball -- whether jabbing at the Republican-controlled Congress, working the pep-rally crowds that his advance teams assemble on college campuses or kidding with reporters on the Vice-Presidential plane.
But it is also a side of the Vice President that most people have not seen. In his previous campaigns, for Vice President in 1992 or for President in 1988, his speeches were more often noted for their awkwardness, or for diffidence. In his debate last month with the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, Jack Kemp, Mr. Gore was soft-spoken and polite.
Speaking today at an outdoor rally at Faneuil Hall in Boston, Mr. Gore shouted and punched his fist into the gray sky, railing against the Republicans in Congress.
"They march in lockstep," he told the crowd. "They don't vary. They all hold hands, and they jump off the cliff together,"
He jokes about things he always has, like his supposedly stiff demeanor, and about things he often has not, including the notion of one day being President himself. To judge by the audience, the jokes are hitting home.
At an outdoor speech on a Galveston, Tex., pier on Thursday, Mr. Gore at one point gestured to the seal of the Vice Presidency that adorns the front of his podium.
"If you look at that seal and close your left eye and hold your head just right, it says, 'President of the United States,' " Mr. Gore said. The partisan crowd of more than 1,000 roared approval. "It gives me a thrill every time I do it," Mr. Gore added.
Several forces explain the Vice President's newfound loose limbs: the Democrats are leading in the polls by comfortable margins, and Mr. Gore is drawing substantial crowds with many who have come to see him in particular. At most stops, at least one or two signs or a shout from the audience suggest a Gore Presidential bid in 2000.
But campaign aides offer an additional explanation. They say Mr. Gore's final campaigning week is revealing how much he has learned at Mr. Clinton's side over the last four years.
"These two men are great students of each other," said Robert Squier, the Clinton-Gore campaign's media consultant, who was traveling with the Vice President this week. "One of the things that Gore draws from Clinton is an understanding of how important connecting is in politics, not just speaking to them, but connecting."
But Mr. Squier said the Clinton influence is subtle, as in its effect on Mr. Gore's timing.
When the Vice President tells a joke or makes a point, Mr. Squier said, there is often now a half-beat pause that was absent four years ago, or even before this campaign. The pause, to Mr. Squier's media-conscious eye, shows a new confidence Mr. Gore has in himself.
"He makes the audience come to him," Mr. Squier said.
But along with that relaxed posture, and in many ways in contrast to it, is a tightly controlled campaign that longtime Gore watchers say is far more scripted than some of his past campaigns.
Mr. Gore's relaxed style sometimes seems like a role he is playing while the old Al Gore stands at attention somewhere beneath.
At the New Zion Baptist Church in Louisville, Ky., for a packed service last Sunday afternoon, Mr. Gore began, as he often does, with a patter of parody about his own stiffness.
Within 15 minutes, most of the people who heard those jokes were shaking their heads at the contradiction because Mr. Gore was shouting with the hoarse growl of a bluesman.
Much as the gospel choir had just done before his speech, he modulated his voice down into the lower registers, keeping it at a monotone until the tension rose, then broke out, whooping a message of civic involvement, couched in the language of the prophet Ezekiel.
"Every time someone is suffering or persecuted, let there be another standing with them -- let it be you, let it be me!" Mr. Gore shouted. The congregation began responding, echoing Mr. Gore's phrases and affirming them, as they just had with their pastor.
"He was preaching," said one trustee, Aaron Carter.
But then, like a switch, the growl and the fire were shut off. "On this occasion, thank you for the opportunity to be in your church," Mr. Gore said quietly in conclusion, reverting to form.
Sometimes the old Al Gore seems itching for a comeback. In Albuquerque, N.M., on Tuesday night, for example, he began his speech at the University of New Mexico with a rhapsody about the value of technology research.
The boredom level rose among the high school marching bands invited to perform.s.
But then the arm-waving, gravel-voiced Preacher Gore returned with a tirade against the Republican challenger Bob Dole's proposal to eliminate the Department of Energy that finances much of the New Mexican research economy.
The students were back, waving and cheering.

HEADLINE: Auto Makers Seek to Reduce the Danger of Air Bags' Impact

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Chrysler, Ford and General Motors have asked the Federal safety authorities for emergency permission to switch to air bags that inflate more slowly, seeking to reduce the risk of neck-injury deaths among infants, children and short adults when air bags inflate at up to 200 miles an hour.
The auto makers said today they would begin installing such bags within months in cars sold in Canada, where no Government permission is needed. They also said they would work harder to teach adults to keep children in the back seat. 
 Since 1990 about 30 children, including infants, have died when they were struck by passenger-side airbags, which are only now coming into common use. Safety officials say the number of such deaths is likely to rise rapidly unless something is done, because passenger-side airbags are nearly universal on new cars now.
But the officials stressed that about 1,100 lives had been saved by air bags since they came into wider use. The auto makers said that they had no research on how much the slower air bags would cut the casualty rate, but that they thought slowing the inflation speed of bags by 25 percent would help. They said the bags would probably not reduce the safety factor for average-sized adults, for whom they were designed.
The slower air bags would be very similar to the ones used today, but with less of the explosive propellant that inflates them. They are not expected to cost any more than the current ones. Switching over will take some time but the first ones could be on the road in Canada in a few months, said Andrew H. Card Jr., the president of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, who represented the companies.
The auto makers cannot use them in the United States until the standard is changed by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. An agency spokesman, Tim Hurd, said the companies' petition would be answered "soon," but he would not elaborate.
Mr. Card, who was Transportation Secretary in the Bush Administration, said he had approved the air bag rules now in force. They are based on protecting a 165-pound man of median height who is not wearing a seatbelt and who is in a frontal collision at 30 miles an hour.
At the time Mr. Card approved the regulations -- on Dec. 14, 1992, he recalled today -- only about 15 percent of front-seat passengers were using belts, but now the number is about 67 percent. In Canada it is 90 to 95 percent, he said.
An air bag that opens 25 percent more slowly would provide the same level of protection to belted occupants, Mr. Card said. In a study of "real-world crashes" of unbelted occupants, the depowered air bags would have been sufficient, he said.
"We're saying the crash test for the unbelted dummy does not best reflect what's happening in the real world," Mr. Card said.
According to safety engineers, the current air bags can injure babies in infant seats that keep them too close to the dashboard, or children who are wearing the lap belts but slip the shoulder belts behind them. The airbags may hit some short adults too hard and too high.
"The injury that smaller-statured individuals seem to die of mimics a hanging," Mr. Card said. "Basically it's a broken neck."
He said the three auto companies would write to the owners of all 22 million vehicles with passenger-side air bags and remind them not to seat children or infants in the front, and would put additional warning labels in new cars, beyond the ones already used, which are often tucked away on the sun visors or in a part of the passenger compartment visible only when the passenger door is open.
Mr. Card said today that the auto makers' education campaign would teach people "how to sit in the car, how to buckle up, and how to respect an air bag." The National Transportation Safety Board recently called for better labels and an education campaign, and predicted a sharp increase in the number of children killed by air bags as they became standard on the passenger side.
In the long term, safety experts want "smart" air bags that would sense the stature of the person in the passenger seat and vary their speed of inflation. But "it's not likely that a breakthrough technology will be on the market until well into the turn of the century," Mr. Card said, because of the need for testing.
Ricardo Martinez, who heads the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said in a statement that he applauded the industry for sending letters to the owners of vehicles with passenger-side air bags. And a spokesman at the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, Stephen L. Oesch, said, "We are very supportive of the action they've taken today."
In high-speed crashes that kill the driver or passenger, said Mr. Oesch of the insurance institute, the problem is not the air bag -- it is that the crash crushes the structure of the vehicle. The auto makers, he said, should be allowed "more design freedom" to develop bags to work well with people big and small.
Joan Claybrook, a former Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the president of Public Citizen, a watchdog group founded by Ralph Nader, also applauded the auto makers' decision to send letters but said the long-term solution was smart airbags, "including two-stage deployment with slower deployment at lower speeds."
"This needs to be put into production as soon as possible," she said.

HEADLINE: Contract Settlement Averts Wider Strike At General Motors

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Saturday, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union announced an agreement early this morning on a new three-year labor contract, averting a national strike against the world's largest auto maker and likely bringing to an end the greatest labor unrest in the American automobile industry since 1970.
Negotiators did not settle a three-day strike by two local unions, but a resolution of those walkouts seems likely very soon. 
 The deal, which is subject to a ratification vote by 215,000 G.M. workers, bears a strong resemblance to contracts that the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation have already signed with the U.A.W. The contracts are intended to make the Detroit auto makers' stop the long shrinkage of their work forces while still letting them reduce their labor costs and compete more effectively with non-union factories that Japanese and European auto makers have built in the South.
Each auto maker agreed to keep overall employment close to current levels, although with a few escape clauses, such as in case of recession. The employment guarantees slightly reduce the incentive for auto makers to rely on outside suppliers, since they will have to pay their workers anyway.
The union even gave the auto makers an incentive to hire more workers, by allowing them to pay somewhat lower wages in any auto parts industries they may enter. Ford has already begun a broad review of what parts can now be manufactured in-house to make use of the lower wages.
But the auto makers, notably G.M. and Ford, gained a little more flexibility this autumn to sell a handful of unprofitable auto parts factories. And while the union won wage increases that will exceed the inflation rate by a couple percentage points a year, it was not as aggressive in demanding pay increases as it has been in some previous labor contracts negotiated during prosperous times in the auto industry.
Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, announced the new labor contract at about 2 A.M., saying: "We have it. We're happy about it."
The Canadian Automobile Workers, a separate union, has already reached deals with Chrysler and G.M. and is trying to reach an agreement with Ford by next Monday. A short strike there cannot be ruled out, but few industry experts expect a prolonged walkout.
So while there may still be a few isolated walkouts at G.M. factories in the months' ahead, today's agreement seems likely to end months of conflict that pitted a more militant American labor movement against the nation's biggest companies in a struggle over corporate downsizing and outsourcing. G.M. is the nation's biggest company in terms of sales, while Ford is the second largest and Chrysler is the ninth largest.
G.M.'s sprawling empire of assembly plants and auto parts factories, which produce a little over 1 percent of the nation's economic output, has suffered three massive strikes this year. A 17-day strike last March at two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, forced G.M. to close most of its North American assembly plants and temporarily lay off 177,000 workers.
A three-week strike by G.M.'s Canadian workers that ended on Oct. 23 also produced heavy layoffs, as severe shortages of auto parts idled many American factories. G.M. said today that 19,000 of its American workers still have not been able to return to their jobs because of the lingering effects of that strike.
The latest strike, and potentially the most costly of all, began on Tuesday evening when 7,500 U.A.W. workers walked out at G.M.'s most profitable assembly plant and at one of its most important truck parts factory. Because G.M.'s truck factories have been running at full speed and have scant supplies of spare parts, the latest strike quickly affected other operations. G.M. closed four highly profitable assembly plants that make pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, and idled another 11,000 workers. Outside companies that make parts for G.M. also began temporarily laying off thousands of workers.
Auto analysts put G.M. combined losses from these strikes at about $1.3 billion in foregone after-tax profits. By comparison, only 46 publicly traded American companies earned more than $1.3 billion in all of 1995, a year of record corporate profits. The strikes have also cost the Federal Government as much as $600 million in taxes that G.M. would have paid on these profits.
G.M. may recoup half its losses by asking workers to put in a lot of overtime in the months ahead, Wall Street experts said.
Tonight's settlement came after Labor Secretary Robert E. Reich had publicly urged both sides today to strike an agreement. Mr. Reich said that Labor Department officials had tried to "make sure that all parties know that there is a national interest at stake, that we hope and encourage them to reach a settlement."
But it was unclear that Mr. Reich's efforts had affected the timing of tonight's deal. Labor Department officials also told union leaders and company executives that Federal mediators were available if needed. But both sides' negotiators declined the offer, following an auto industry tradition in which union and company officials have prefered for decades to deal with each other with no outsiders present.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Shaving Fares On the Shuttle

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
LAST summer, I spent a lot of time trying to find a cheap shuttle trip to Boston, a daunting task because the advertised shuttle fares represent perhaps the highest per-mile rate in the country, a result of the predominance of business travelers in the Northeast corridor. But I knew there were weekend discounts and I had a couple of coupons. There was also the possibility of an airline senior coupon book that could mean a cheaper fare if I needed to take the trip more than once in a year.
My experience indicates it is worthwhile to shop for a shuttle ticket and, most particularly, to avoid going to the airport ticketless, because the walk-up fare is the highest. There is some irony in that, because when the shuttle began more than 30 years ago, the point was that travelers could go at any hour and pay a standard fare. 
 The gimmick was, and in the East still is, that one passenger in line for a flight can theoretically end up on an otherwise empty new plane if the preceding one is full; as long as there are passengers -- meaning more than one these days -- the airlines roll out the planes. Delta reports having put on as many as 22 extra sections in a day. The shuttles run by six airlines in the busy corridor between San Francisco and Los Angeles do not do this: a traveler waits until the next scheduled departure.
For the Boston-New York-Washington shuttles, as this article went to press, both Delta and USAir were advertising one-way weekday fares of $173 each way between New York and Boston or New York and Washington. (All fares cited exclude a $3 airport departure charge.) This fare reflects an increase that went into effect at the end of August when the 10 percent Federal tax resumed.
Amtrak offers no stable benchmark, since it is now adapting its fares to demand. However, if one plans ahead of time, the cheapest ticket on a conventional train from New York to Washington is $60 one way. The best price on a weekday Metroliner is $106 and on a weekend Metroliner, $88. The cheapest New York-Boston fare is $43.
 
 
 
Saving Money but Not Time
 Train trips are longer: three hours on the Metroliner between New York and Washington; at least 20 minutes more on conventional trains. The New York-Boston run takes at least four and a half hours. Where you arrive also affects travel time: Penn Station, Union Station and South Station are all downtown and on subway systems; getting out of the airports takes longer.
All the flights take roughly an hour. Delta leaves on the half-hour from the Marine Terminal at La Guardia, Logan Airport in Boston and National in Washington, starting at 6:30 A.M. weekdays (6:45 from Washington because of a noise curfew). The last flights are at 9:30 P.M. weekdays, except those from New York to Washington, which end at 9. Weekend schedules start an hour later and end an hour earlier.
USAir's flights leave on the hour from the USAir terminal at La Guardia, Logan and National. They start on weekdays at 6:30 A.M. from New York and Boston, with the next flights at 7 A.M. The last Boston-New York and New York-Boston departures are 10 P.M. The Washington starting hour is 7 A.M. and the last flight from there is at 9 P.M.
Delta bought the Pan American Shuttle in 1991. The Eastern Air Lines Shuttle, which began it all in 1961, became the Trump Shuttle; its operation was taken over by USAir in 1992 although the USAir Shuttle company is separate from USAir.
My fun began with a free booklet called NY96 Funpass, published by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority with the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, which expired Aug. 31; a new version is planned for next year. I learned that with the fancy Metropass in this booklet one could purchase a Delta Shuttle ticket for travel all day Saturday or Sunday at $80 the round trip. I called the 800 number and the agents eventually found the data, which doomed the project: The trip must begin in Washington or Boston. The agent explained that the idea was to bring people into New York City, not send them away.
Another coupon booklet, called Manhattan Today, leads off with a page for the USAir Shuttle. This coupon allows discount travel at slower weekday periods: flights at 11 A.M., noon, 1 and 2 P.M. and 9 and 10 P.M. The coupon in the current booklet, valid until Jan. 31, offers a fare of $77 each way, $154 for the required round-trip purchase. If you add the $5 cost of the booklet, for a total of $159, and use the ticket going in only one direction, you can still beat the $173 regular fare. On a round trip, it's a winner: $159 vs. $346. It's worth noting that this coupon says "standby only," meaning that USAir will not roll out a new plane for you.
The $5 Manhattan Today booklet, which contains restaurant and store coupons for New York as well as the USAir coupon, can be ordered by phone with a credit card at (800) 685-6760. The booklet is published every four months; the current booklet covers Oct. 1 to Jan. 31. The people at the USAir information number, (800) 428-4322, seemed confused about it, but Terry V. Hallcom, chairman of the USAir Shuttle, said the coupon was intended simply to be taken to the airport.

 
 
Weekend Fares
 Setting aside coupons, I examined weekend shuttle fares. This is a thicket.
Delta and USAir both have an "off peak" weekend walkup fare of $79 one way, excluding airport charges, no round-trip purchase required. It is valid all day Saturday, and on Sunday until 2:30 P.M. on Delta and until 3 P.M. on USAir.
Both airlines have another one-way weekend fare, currently $51, which requires purchase three days in advance. It is valid all day Saturday and until 11:30 A.M. Sunday on Delta and noon on USAir. This fare went up a notch at the end of summer, but on Delta the traveler may now take along one child 12 or younger free.
Delta and USAir also have two restricted advance-purchase fares that require a round-trip purchase. The 14-day advance purchase costs $144 round trip and requires a Saturday-night stay. The seven-day advance purchase costs $176 round trip, with no Saturday-night stay required. These tickets are valid in the slow midday hours, after 7 P.M. Monday to Friday and all day Saturday or Sunday.
In addition, both companies have coupon booklets providing discounts for travelers aged 12 to 24 or those over 62. A book of four coupons, each valid for a shuttle flight, costs $227, or about $57 a flight; a book of eight costs $418, or about $52 a flight.

 
 
Few Solo Flights
 Do Delta and the USAir Shuttle still roll out a vast empty plane for a passenger who cannot get aboard the chosen flight? Very seldom, Mr. Hallcom said. It makes better economic sense, he said, to put angry USAir passengers into a cab to Delta and let them take a flight leaving in half an hour.
And my Boston trip? The shuttle flight I took cost yet another amount -- $115 one way, known as an "unpublished" fare, meaning it was negotiated with Delta by the travel agent for my employer. And that is another issue.

HEADLINE: Airline Dining, No Soup to No Nuts

BYLINE: By RALPH SCHOENSTEIN; RALPH SCHOENSTEIN's latest book is "Superman and Son" (Rutgers).

 BODY:
DIETING ALOFT was already rampant in late 1995 when American Airlines discovered that it could save $100,000 a year by removing one olive from each salad it served to its passengers. But this was just the tip of the iceberg lettuce, for other airlines have gone far beyond merely deregulating salad: they have been canceling whole meals in the hope that passengers have eaten in the terminal.
Last summer the Air Transport Association revealed that this country's airlines now were spending only $4.45 on meals per passenger, $1.15 less than they had spent in 1992, and the decrease is accelerating. Is the next step frequent-fasting miles? 
 Considering blood sugar a frill, United Airlines now serves just a beverage on flights up to 889 miles, unless the flight is during a traditional mealtime, and many longer trips are broken into two legs, neither of which qualifies for a meal. It is now possible to travel for 12 hours and feel that you are preparing to take monastic vows.
There is, of course, a sunnier way to look at no pie in the sky.
"Airline food has always been awful," said Peter Bauer of Miami, president of Youngone America sportswear company, "and now it's gotten both worse and less."
Does not less of worse produce a happy double negative for America's travelers?
For many, yes, but alas not for me: I have always loved airline food, a confession that belongs on a talk show about eating disorders. Some small genetic flaw in me -- the scientific name is bad taste -- has left me unable to discriminate between food that is served in Paris and food that is served in Federal prisons.
Many years ago in a mess hall at Fort Dix, I was actually heard to say, "This food is pretty good," a comment that my comrades felt was an attempt at a discharge for insanity. When I left the Army, I replaced the mess hall with railroad and airline food; a grand sweep of transportational tastelessness was calling to me.
Often I was lured to Philadelphia by the custards at the 30th Street Station, for my favorite dish has always been food that is either intentionally custard or drifting that way. And on airlines flying domestic routes, I used to find myself sitting with my wife and one or two of my daughters when a flight attendant brought us dishes that defied identification.
"Pass everything that isn't green to Dad," my wife would say, and I received a cornucopia of potential food.
Now, however, like millions of other travelers, I have to buy my own imitation food in the terminal instead of having the airline serve it to me.
To airline analysts, it was inevitable that passengers would become stratospheric Oliver Twists.
"After losing more than $13 billion from 1990 to 1994, the industry was desperate to cut costs," said David Swierenga, the Air Transport Association's chief economist. And Lee Howard, president of Airline Economics International, a consulting firm in Georgia, said, "The big airlines all learned from Southwest, which never made a pretext of serving anything but peanuts or cookies."
"The peanuts!" said Caroline Feller, who flies more than 100,000 miles every year to set up reading programs in libraries around the world. "It couldn't have been hard for the airlines to remove the taste from meat, but peanuts must've been a real challenge. You know, I once actually mailed a whole meal back to an airline."
"At the junk mail rate, I presume," I said. "But Caroline, it's still a very mixed situation -- for people with taste, that is; I'm not talking about myself. I mean, it is a blessing when your intake of cardboard goes down. Wasn't it Aristotle who said, 'Less is more'? "
"Aristotle never flew American from Miami to Dallas," she said, "when even first class has no meal. And then I switch planes in Dallas and miss the evening service."
"The evening service," I replied, "should be a prayer for all passengers who forget to eat in the terminal."
"The only way to beat it is to fly first class to Asia. Then you get the caviar and pressed duck. The hunger project operates only in the United States."
If Caroline wants to upgrade nuts, she should fly Continental, where a woman named Miss Loberto (she wanted the rest of her name kept confidential) told me, "We've recently gone back to our original peanuts. The original Coke, too."
"Any original things I can slice?" I asked her.
"We're always considering changes in our food service."
At most airlines today, a change in the food service means ending it.
"The public asked us to eliminate the food," said Cindy Reeds in customer relations at Delta. "About a year and a half ago, we took a survey of a thousand passengers -- all types of people -- and they said they wanted lower fares, so we got rid of the meals."
"Lindbergh would have admired their toughness," I said. "He ate only half a sandwich on a whole Paris flight -- and it wasn't served."
The flying public, however, seems to be of two minds, for another woman at Continental told me, "So many people have been calling to say, 'You're not feeding us.' But they do love their fares. And recently we did start using fresh bread."
"Instead of stale?" I said.
"No, frozen. The taste wasn't too good."
"Even in boom times before deregulation," said Mr. Howard, "when the only competition was in amenities, airline food was often poor. USAir, for example, always served very little."
"So it's been an easy transition," I said "to serve even less."
"They're down to raisins and Ry-Krisp. The bargain-hunting public is controlling this thing. Business people on expense accounts will still want to eat, but they'll have to look hard for the food."
"Somewhere outside the plane."
 THE great jettisoning of food has led to delicious -- you'll pardon the word -- irony: on the Internet, American Airlines is now offering a cookbook of the meals it is trying not to serve. The airline's hope seems to be that passengers will eat these meals at home and then fly, reversing the usual sequence and using the plane just for digestion.
But no cookbook can distract a traveler from the fact that United States airlines, which, says the Air Transport Association, saved $368 million last year by cutting meals, are soaring to new levels of competitive deprivation.
"Passengers used to have a choice of three or four hot meals, but now they're lucky to get a roll with a slice of ham or turkey" on shorter trips, I was told by one flight attendant at United.
What might the future of flying be?
Perhaps one day, I will go out to JFK for a flight to Los Angeles that will cost $14.95 or 10 subway tokens, if I buy my ticket at least a half-hour before takeoff. When I enter the plane I find no flight attendants, for passengers voted to get rid of them. They voted to get rid of the copilot too and replace him with something from the Sharper Image.
At cruising altitude I walk to the rear of the plane, where the pilot is slapping a candy vending machine.
"There's just no maintenance on these things," he says. "Maintenance was such a nice frill."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
In Mexico, Bargains As the Peso Slides On

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
TWO years ago, one peso was worth 30 American cents. Today it is the equivalent of about 13 cents. As a result, Mexico has become a moveable feast of bargains. Hotels, taxis, restaurants, movies, picnic food, handicrafts and many other vacation accouterments now cost far less than in the United States.
"I had no idea the values would be so dramatic," said Vincent Davis, an engineering student from California who came south this year planning to travel for three months and stayed for six because rambling around Mexico has turned out to be so cheap. 
 The devaluation of the Mexican peso, which began with a crash in December 1994, has continued as an intermittent slide, most recently by losing 3 percent of its value against the dollar last month. Inflation has raised consumer prices here during 1995 and 1996 by about 75 percent, making daily life for the average Mexican worker painfully austere. But for travelers paying in dollars, the effects of the advantageous exchange rate have far outstripped inflation.
"Hotels are a real bargain now," said H. H. Felsted, the editor of a travel newsletter, Mexican Meandering, published in Austin, Tex. Last month he and his wife traveled to San Antonio, where they stayed in a Holiday Inn for $89 a night. In contrast, they later went to the northern Mexico city of Monterrey, where they stayed in the Hotel Rio, a tidy, modern establishment with a swimming pool. There the Felsteds paid a weekend rate of $45 a night, although the Hotel Rio's rates rise to $57 on weeknights.
Prices of some luxury hotels are also lower now than two years ago, even though most have always priced their rooms in dollars. A standard room at the Hotel Camino Real in Mexico City's Polanco district cost $180 before the 1994 devaluation. Today the same room goes for $160.
Other luxury hotels have not cut their rates. And when the high season begins on Dec. 21, many hotels will hike prices by 50 to 100 percent. In January 1995, a standard room in the luxurious Ritz-Carlton in Cancun cost $245. Today it costs $295, and in high season (through mid-April), it will cost $443.
Food prices in Mexico will seem extremely reasonable to Americans. A meal in most restaurants costs $10 or less. A sumptuous feast for two, beginning with Herradura tequila and continuing with Chilean wine and chicken mole at the Asador Vasco, on a balcony overlooking the colonial square in Oaxaca, can be had for $35.
Ground transportation is also a bargain. Two years ago a taxi ride from the international airport to downtown Mexico City cost $16. Today it has dropped to $8.50. The Mexico City subway, with stops at the airport, the Museum of Anthropology and dozens of other attractions, costs one peso, or 13 cents, for an unlimited ride. That is up from 40 centavos, or 8 cents, a year ago.
Flights in Mexico, tied to fuel and to international aircraft-leasing costs, have grown costlier. Round-trip air fare between Mexico City and Guadalajara on Mexicana Airlines, $180 before the 1994 devaluation, now costs $197. But for intercity travel, Mexico's first-class buses are cheap and clean.
Air tickets to and from the United States, paid in dollars, fluctuate according to the airline industry's own dynamics, generally having little to do with the Mexican economy. But travel agents and airlines serving Latin America said that excursion tickets purchased weeks in advance have tended to drop in price over the past two years, while regular coach tickets have risen. In November 1994, the round-trip excursion fare from Newark to Mexico City on Continental Airlines was $388, said Marta Rosas, a Continental spokeswoman. Currently the fare is $258, she said.
The favorable exchange rates have attracted record numbers of foreign travelers, said Javier Solis Diego, a spokesman for Mexico's Department of Tourism. Last year more than 20 million tourists traveled to Mexico, up from 17 million in 1994, he said. Underlining the low cost of travel here, however, the 20 million travelers who came in 1995 spent an average of $305 each, down from $370 in 1994. The figures include foreigners who visit Mexico's northern border cities, as long as they stay overnight.
The government projects that 23 million foreign tourists will visit Mexico in 1996, and that 1997 will see a further 15 percent increase, Mr. Solis said.
Runzheimer International, a Wisconsin company that advises American businesses on the costs of executive transfers and travel to foreign cities, has compared the cost of food, clothing and other goods and services in Mexico City with the cost of the same items in American cities. The company estimates that for $80 a traveler in Mexico City can buy goods and services that would cost $118 in New York, said Peter D. Packer, a Runzheimer spokesman.
"Mexico City is now among the least expensive places in the world," Mr. Packer said.

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Steven B. Tanger;
The Outlet Shopping Center as a Growing Retailing Concept

BYLINE: By THOMAS CLAVIN 

 BODY:
AS president and chief executive officer of Tanger Factory Outlet Centers Inc., Steven B. Tanger runs a family business that his grandfather, Moe Tanger, started 78 years ago, and that his father, Stanley Tanger, continued.
The company's mall in Riverhead, one of 27 it owns in 22 states, opened in May 1994 and now has 68 tenants. At 287,000 square feet, the Tanger Outlet Center in Riverhead is the largest on the Island. 
 The company has received approval from Riverhead town for an additional 450,000 square feet of shopping space, and in July the company broke ground for Tanger II. It is estimated that this will bring the total number of shops to close to 200.
The company, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange with a total market capitalization of $400 million, has its headquarters in North Carolina, but Mr. Tanger and his family live part-time in Southampton.
Q. Why was Riverhead chosen as the site of the most recent Tanger Outlet Center?
A. First, we wanted an outlet center on Long Island because of its huge density of population and very high average income. But Long Island is over-retailed, with every form of product distribution already available through WalMart, K-Mart, Caldor and strip malls. What was missing were factory outlets, and we thought we could do well on Long Island if we could select the right site.
Typically, we look for sites on major interstates, and on Long Island that meant we wanted to be on the Long Island Expressway. There wasn't much available to us in Nassau County and western Suffolk. Even if there was, our tenants are manufacturers of brand-name products and their customers are the major department stores. They want to be at least 20 miles away from malls so as not to compete directly with retailers. There were very few choices left once we plugged in that criteria, and we're not speculators.
Q. Initially, were Riverhead officials knowledgeable about and open to a factory outlet center?
A. Yes, for two reasons. When the Calverton base shut down a few years ago, 2500 jobs were lost, so the surrounding population and economy took a hit. Some sort of replacement would be welcome. Second, prior to our finding this site, the town fathers created a factory overlay zone for the central community in anticipation and hope a factory outlet center would develop there. So they were already aware of the economic advantages of our type of development. It was a classic win-win situation for the host community and our company and its shareholders.
Q. After over two years in Riverhead, have economic goals been met?
A.
, In the first full year after expansion, we anticipate generating $8 million in sales tax revenue. Unlike other retail distribution channels, less than 5 percent of our sales come from within five miles of our shopping center. This is the exact opposite of your major box users such as K-Mart, where 95 percent of their business tends to come from a 5- or 10-mile radius. We are drawing people to Riverhead from 50 to 75 miles away, and many of these people have not been to Riverhead before.
In addition, we're working with a local entrepreneur and the town to create a trolley system to link our property to Splish Splash and downtown merchants. We're one of few shopping center developments to allow a transportation system to come onto our property and take our shoppers away to other shops and attractions. We want to extend Main Street out to our center. This is very important because at present we are bringing in excess of three million people to Riverhead.
Q. Though the bottom line is encouraging now, looking back, was developing a center in Riverhead a risk?
A. It was a major risk. When we started to tell people about locating in Riverhead, I was told that I was crazy. They said no one goes past Exit 70 on the L.I.E., and no one goes to Riverhead unless they need driver's license renewed or a building permit.
But we understood that the L.I.E. was becoming literally the Main Street of eastern Suffolk County. We knew of no major retail distribution center east of the Smithaven Mall. We thought that if we were fortunate enough to attract the right customers and the right management group to run the center, we would attract enough people to expand rapidly in the hopes of becoming the regional mall on Long Island, located in Riverhead. And we're on our way.
Q. In addition to the Riverhead site, what is fueling the popularity of factory outlet malls around the United States?
A. People love a true value. They trust brand-name products, and in the 22 states where we operate our channel of distribution, and of course that of other outlet centers, is based upon consumers buying directly from manufacturers. The middle man is cut out. Without the middle-man profit, the consumer should get the very best price on broadest selection of brand-name products. That's why there are now 324 factory outlet centers in the country, and that number is growing.
Q. Is there a threshold, a possibility that the factory outlet concept could soon peak and then decline in popularity?
A. Like evey other channel of distribution, the factory outlet industry going through changes. But we're not talking about a business fad. The outlet store concept has been around for 100 years. Previously, they were called employee stores.
Q. Why have your centers grown to be so large, rivaling and exceeding retail malls?
A. The original outlet centers of 15 years ago were really quite small, 40,000 to 60,000 square feet. Today they average 250,000 square feet. However, of the over 300 factory outlet centers in the country, only 70 are in excess of 200,000 square feet. The large centers are a recent phenomenon, obviously in response to demand or we'd all go broke.
What will happen is the smaller centers may evolve into other types of retailing unless they are in tourist areas where three or four can be clustered. The smaller centers in smaller towns may not be outlet centers in five to 10 years.
Q. What indications do you have that consumer demand will support a larger center?
A. We are strong believers in research driving our decisions. We listen to consumers telling us what they want. The L.I.E. links Riverhead not only to Nassau and Suffolk Counties, but people are coming from as far away as New York City. Once you get past a certain point on the L.I.E., the driving is easy. And when you get off at Exit 73, essentially you're in our parking lot. The experience so far has demonstrated that we have tapped a consumer demand no one else was satisfying.
Q. Putting consumers aside, have you been welcomed by residents of the Riverhead area?
A. It seems so. One reason is we have about 700 employees now, and after expansion we will have around 2,000. That almost makes up for what was lost at Calverton. We may be the biggest employer in Riverhead, and one of biggest in Suffolk County.
Another reason is our economic impact on the local school system, which involves everyone who pays school taxes in addition to the children. Apart from the effect on property taxes, we have a program where we give back to school systems. In January and February, schools collect receipts of products purchased at our center and turn them in, then we donate back to school system, with no strings attached, 10 percent of those receipts. The schools have used this money to install computer labs, gymnasium floors, and other things that couldn't get approved through normal channels in a time-efficient manner.
Q. How do you counter criticism that your Riverhead center is taking business away from local merchants and drawing consumers away from the North and South Forks, which depend on seasonal business to survive?
A. With perhaps a few isolated cases, I don't think that is happening. We are active members of local Chambers of Commerce, and the Southampton Chamber asked me to be its keynote speaker at its annual meeting in September.
We don't sell pharmaceuticals, groceries, automobiles, washing machines and other so-called hard goods, so we don't compete with a lot of merchants in town.
There is some direct competition. In Bridgehampton there is a Gap store and we have a Gap outlet, 30 miles away. Both do very well.
Once the new center is open, we anticipate 10 million visits a year. Next to Niagara Falls, we will be the most visited tourist attraction in the state. Q. Other than doing business, have you got involved with local interests?
A. I've tried, and it's going well. I grew up in North Carolina and that's where my family is based, but we spend as much time as we can in the Southampton and Riverhead area. We've made a lot of friends here and have gotten involved. We've hosted charitable events, one being for Southampton Hospital and another for the Fresh Air Fund. I'm also on the board of overseers of Southampton College and vice-chairman of the Business Committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. My whole family over the years has attempted to be part of the communities where we have outlet centers. In recent years I've probably spent more time here than anywhere outside of North Carolina.
Q. Is being the third generation to run the family business confining or enjoyable?
A. I have been truly blessed to have had the opportunity to work 10 years with my father and grandfather, then the last 25 years with my father, who continues to offer advice based on experience. He spent 35 years working with his father. We know how to separate family affairs from business affairs because we've done it for so long. My father had to do it with his father, and I'm having to do it with my father. I'm proud of the fact that the family business has survived for over 75 years. There are not many of those left.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steven B. Tanger, president and chief operating officer of Tanger Factory Outlet Centers. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: John Wargo;
Pesticides in Food, Children at Risk

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
THE potential danger of toxic chemicals in pesticides has been called an "invisible hazard," but for John Wargo of Westbrook, the evidence of continued contamination and its risks to humans is all too clear.
Nearly a quarter-century after the Federal Government began banning toxic pesticides, Mr. Wargo, an associate professor of forestry, political science and environmental studies at Yale University, argues that the threat posed by pesticide use continues unabated. 
 The message is contained in his new book, "Our Children's Toxic Legacy" (Yale University Press, $30), a volume already being compared to Rachel Carson's 1962 classic "Silent Spring." Mr. Wargo, an unabashed admirer of Ms. Carson, said he is pleased with the comparison, but concerned, too. "It could make me a target," he said.
That may be expected, considering his strong criticisms of both the pesticide industry and Federal regulations which he claims too often underestimate the risks pesticides, especially as residue in the food supply.
One of the book's chapter titles, "Fractured Law, Fractured Science," sums up Mr. Wargo's case.
What little regulatory protection exists, he writes, is driven by the introduction of pesticides on a case-by-case basis, a reactive rather than proactive policy.
Worse, he adds, is the assumption among regulators that a chemical compound is innocent until proven guilty, a mindset that can mean years of use before a dangerous pesticide is banned.
Mr. Wargo recently discussed his book, and his concerns, at lunch in a Thai restaurant near his office in New Haven. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. You argue for a more unified body of regulations. Yet you also point up the wide divergence of views on the threat of pesticide use. So how can you expect consensus?
A. Pesticides are very difficult because they carry great benefits, in health protection as well as crop protection. Yet they carry risks. Pesticides aren't like fat or alcohol, you can't label them in foods. It's a different kind of risk management problem. Unlike other chemicals, pesticides are not unintentionally toxic to some species. They are intentionally toxic, which is why we are using them.
Q. You argue there are many different ways toxins enter the human food chain. What are your biggest concerns?
A. I have to say it's not clear. We still don't know which toxic effect we should be most concerned about. We ought to be concerned about all of them, about licensing these compounds without understanding their effects or how we are exposed to them. Once I understood that, I started thinking about it in terms of experimentation.
Q. That we are experimenting on human beings?
A. Yes. Exactly.
Q. Why do you single out children as a group at risk?
A. In 1985 my graduate students and I started looking at this huge, huge data set put together by the United States Department of Agriculture. We noticed that kids' diets were extremely different from adult diets. Their diversity is so much lower. So any contaminant on any one food they eat would translate into a higher level of exposure. Also, kids take in more of these foods for each unit of body weight, to fuel growth.
Q. Are children's foods any more toxic than adults'?
A. Fruits and vegetables are pretty tough to grow in some parts of the country without fungicides. Fungicides are commonly classified as possible or probable carcinogens in animal studies.
Children's intake of fruit juices and mushed-up vegetables is greater per unit of body weight than adults', so their exposure to any fungicide residue would be higher.
There's also a pretty convincing intuitive argument that because kids' cells are reproducing at a rate faster than adults are, it's probably not a great idea to expose those cells to chemicals that pose a higher cancer risk, cancer being an abnormal reproductive process. During a period of cell growth, you want the most normal conditions to exist.
Q. What are some examples of the Federal Government permitting the use of a dangerous pesticide?
A. There are so many. I think you could go back and look at every chemical that the Environmental Protection Agency banned, and then ask: "Why did it take so long?" It was very common in the 1970's and 1980's for the E.P.A. to have taken 10, 12, even 14 years to review a chemical, waiting for the data to be what they termed "good enough" before prohibiting it from the marketplace.
Q. How does the risk of pesticide exposure compare to other purported cancer risks, i.e. secondary smoke and radiation? Some might say we are being poisoned so many different ways, why get worked up about one more?
A. I would turn it around and say that's a good logic for being vigilant. One out of every four people get cancer in their lifetimes and as many as 45 to 50 percent are unexplained by genetic factors or behaviors such as smoking. Most of the scientists at the National Cancer Institute believe that environmental factors are playing some role. That's a pretty good logic for thinking carefully about which factors are posing the greatest risk.
Q. Don't some naturally occurring materials expose people to carcinogens, too?
A. It's not clear natural compounds are posing a cancer risk at the same level as synthetic compounds. The data are quite poor.
We know aflatoxins, molds common on some grain products, are carcinogenic, so it makes good sense to keep them out of the food supply, and the grain and nut industries are careful about that.
From my perspective, an ideal government would be one that managed the most risky compounds in a way that kept people from being exposed to them regardless of whether they are natural or synthetic.
Q. How do you view those on the other side of the pesticide debate? Are they willfully ignorant, or is it an honest difference of opinion?
A. I always wonder who's paying them, and what their stake is in the regulatory decision.
But getting beyond that, I think it's really two different viewpoints on how we should be managing hazards given the uncertainty in the data. I favor caution, driven by the history of incremental chemical-at-a-time licensing. I think that law has failed us because we've broken up the questions into bits and pieces.
Q. How do you view the recent insecticide sprayings in southeastern Connecticut, to deal with the mosquito-transmitted equine encephalitis virus?
A. The question is whether it's reasonable to spray the landscape with insecticide to try to prevent an epidemic. I think in this case, the answer is a qualified yes -- if we choose an insecticide that has the least level of toxicity to humans. In this case they have chosen one that has a very low level. It is highly toxic to fish, though.
Q. That can't make you happy.
A. We're trading off risks. So what's reasonable? Trading off kids dying of encephalitis for some ecological risks? It seems like a reasonable trade-off, if you meet a couple of conditions. People have to be warned before a spraying. And flying over schools, cars and school buses should clearly be avoided.
Q. You claim that people have been all too willing to trade off economic risks for ecological risks. Isn't this a similar scenario?
A. That's a whole different kind of issue. If you're dealing with increased yields per acre of crops or increased jobs, and trade those off against risk to kids, I say unfair. But if you're trading off risk to kids for risk to kids, then you choose the lower risk.
Q. Do you see any political party as being better able to address the pesticide issue? Or will it require a wholesale rethinking by everyone?
A. We're certainly fortunate to have people like Al Gore and E.P.A. Director Carol Browner, who have very strong concerns for kids' health and made recent efforts to revise pesticide policies. But this country still needs a wake-up call. This Administration is heading in the right direction. But the scale of the problem is being grossly understated.
Q. What do you hope your book will accomplish?
A. My agenda is one of public education so parents and consumers can be more knowledgeable about the risks they face. That knowledge will empower them. The message will get back to industry.
I'm a big fan of public awareness and risk education.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Wargo, a professor at Yale University, argues that "the scale of the problem is being grossly understated." (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
The Master Skeptic Steps Aside

BYLINE: By WARREN BERGER 

 BODY:
ON A RECENT MORNING at his quiet office in the Washington bureau of ABC News, David Brinkley looked and sounded -- as he often does on his Sunday-morning program, "This Week With David Brinkley" -- like a man who had been woken too early. With his heavy-lidded eyes and laconic, halting manner of speaking, which distinguished him when he was a co-host of the groundbreaking "Huntley-Brinkley Report" in the 1950's and 1960's, Mr. Brinkley has always seemed unusually sedate for a television newsman. Now, at the age of 76, he seems more so: his shoulders slouch a bit, his soft-featured face is smaller and more drawn, and his voice, no doubt affected by lung surgery last year, is sometimes weak.
But given an opportunity, Mr. Brinkley can still rail against Washington with considerable vigor. Asked about Tuesday's Presidential election, he quickly launched into an assault on the process of nominating candidates: "It has completely broken down," he said. Later, he groused about Government spending, and characterized Congress as "a fractious, self-centered, arrogant bunch." And he said that he regarded President Clinton -- who has granted him the first post-Election Day interview, on Friday, two days before Mr. Brinkley steps down as host of "This Week" -- as "a classic politician." (That's no praise, coming from Mr. Brinkley.) 
 Though Mr. Brinkley can seem like a bit of a curmudgeon these days, his trademark skepticism and succinct candor have long been appreciated, and will assuredly be missed, by viewers who have been watching him for the last 40 years, first on "Huntley-Brinkley," then as an "NBC Nightly News" anchor with John Chancellor and finally as host of "This Week," which he helped begin in 1981. After next week's program, which will include the interview with the President, Mr. Brinkley will relinquish the role of host to two of the program's longtime panelists, Sam Donaldson and Cokie Roberts. Although he will continue to contribute commentary, the title of the program is expected to become simply "This Week."
With Mr. Brinkley at the helm, the program's blend of political news, commentary and sometimes quarrelsome debate established it as both a ratings leader and a trend setter on Sunday mornings, inspiring a wave of similar pundit chat programs over the years. Tim Russert, the host of NBC's "Meet the Press," which has recently been challenging the ratings supremacy of "This Week," said of his competitor, "David Brinkley redefined Sunday-morning TV."
Almost everyone involved with Sunday-morning television is wondering how its competitive landscape will change after Mr. Brinkley's semiretirement. "I think we can have a successful show without David, but at the same time there's no doubt that we're losing the linchpin," said Mr. Donaldson. "I've always maintained that David Brinkley is the principal draw of the broadcast, because viewers trust him and feel comfortable with him."
The president of ABC News, Roone Arledge, acknowledges that "there is the possibility that we'll lose viewers." But he hopes that he can soften the blow by keeping Mr. Brinkley at least partly involved in the program. "I was determined that we not do what CBS did with Walter Cronkite, which was to have him just suddenly go away," he said.
In any case, Mr. Arledge, who lured Mr. Brinkley away from NBC 15 years ago by offering him the host slot on "This Week," insists that a change in Mr. Brinkley's status was inevitable. Mr. Brinkley had been talking about scaling back his involvement in the program, indicating that he wanted that to happen sometime after the 1996 election. At the same time, Mr. Arledge felt that the program, which was his creation, needed to be "freshened up," he said.
"Everybody has copied our format over the years," he said, "and now we need to take the next step forward."
No doubt adding to the pressure for change has been the rise in the ratings of "Meet the Press." In recent weeks, and for the first time consistently, that program has been drawing more viewers than "This Week." " 'Meet the Press' is now perceived to be the hotter show of the two," said Andrew Tyndall, who reports on the television news business for The Tyndall Report, an industry newsletter.
But Mr. Arledge asserts that the decision to change hosts was not influenced by the ratings pressures. "If we were worried about ratings, we would have tried to keep David here longer," he said. Rather, he said, the move was made in response to Mr. Brinkley's wishes and also grew out of Mr. Arledge's concern about Mr. Brinkley's health. Though Mr. Brinkley returned to the program soon after his operation, he has seemed at times to be moving a step slower than his feisty round-table partners. "David had a serious operation, and while I think he was able to come back, I've noticed an energy level drop-off," Mr. Donaldson said.
Mr. Tyndall said he believed that Mr. Brinkley's on-air performance had clearly fallen off: "He always had that laconic style, but in the last year he has begun to look tired."
ABC News insiders also note that Mr. Brinkley's familiar skepticism has lately sometimes veered toward crankiness. "There's been more of a tendency to say, 'They're all a bunch of crooks on Capitol Hill,' though I don't think he really feels that way," said one person at the network.
For his part, Mr. Brinkley insists that he is feeling quite well these days, his frail appearance notwithstanding. "I probably can't run as fast or lift as much as I used to, but this job requires no heavy lifting," he said.
Of the decision to scale back his role on "This Week," Mr. Brinkley said: "I've done this for a long time and now I want to do something different. That's all." Mr. Brinkley is interested in producing documentaries about history and culture, and ABC News has already signed him up to do a couple.
As for his skepticism about politics, and any crankiness thereof, Mr. Brinkley said: "As long as I've known anything about politics, I've been skeptical. And it has evolved. The more I saw, the more skeptical I became."
As he wrote last year in his best-selling memoir "David Brinkley," he became immersed in politics early in his career, when he left his home state, North Carolina, to take a job as White House correspondent with NBC News. In 1956, he and Chet Huntley began doing their influential nightly news broadcast, which ran for 14 years, with Mr. Brinkley reporting from Washington and Mr. Huntley from New York.
Mr. Brinkley achieved a number of "firsts" during his years at NBC, including writing and serving as host for the first television news magazine, "David Brinkley's Journal," in the 1960's. But some of his finest moments involved the coverage of politics by "The Huntley-Brinkley Report," particularly its live reporting from the party conventions, beginning in 1956.
By 1964, the program's coverage of the Democratic convention drew a remarkable 84 percent share of the viewers. President Clinton has said that the Huntley-Brinkley coverage of the conventions piqued his early interest in politics. "David Brinkley created a whole generation of political junkies," said the ABC News political analyst Jeff Greenfield.
Mr. Brinkley did that in part by bringing a more casual, impressionistic tone to his discussion of politics, as he shared observations and anecdotes, often humorous, with viewers. "He appreciated the human side of politics, and got a chuckle out of it," Mr. Greenfield said. "He treated politics in the manner H. L. Mencken did, as a great spectator sport."
MR. DONALDSON SAID Mr. Brinkley was also "able to cut through the fog and explain the essence of an issue in a way that everybody could understand." And Mr. Brinkley's unusual, low-key manner of speaking also sets him apart from more aggressive commentators. (When Mr. Brinkley speaks, particular words in each sentence are singled out for emphasis; because of this, Mr. Donaldson observed, "David and I can say exactly the same thing, but when he says it, it just sounds more interesting.")
Mr. Brinkley was often dissatisfied with what he saw in Washington, but he remained unfailingly polite. "One of the things that stands out about David is that he's so civil to everyone," said Mr. Arledge. When Mr. Brinkley has chided politicians and government bureaucrats -- as he has done most Sundays on "This Week" -- he has usually done it gently, and wryly.
On one program, Mr. Brinkley reported on large batches of mail that the Postal Service had failed to deliver in Washington, and he speculated that the misplaced mail might have included a letter from President Clinton asking Congress to enact Mr. Clinton's earlier promise to cut taxes for the middle class. "That certainly got lost somewhere," Mr. Brinkley noted.
Though he has waded in Washington politics for 50 years, Mr. Brinkley has tended to distance himself from most politicians. There are no pictures of Presidents on his office walls, though he has known all of them since Roosevelt. Instead, the office is decorated with a few family snapshots and a picture of a mansion that was next door to his boyhood home in Wilmington, N.C., where Mr. Brinkley began his journalism career as a teen-age writer for The Wilmington Morning Star.
Aside from Winston Churchill, whom he admired greatly, Mr. Brinkley seems to have few fond memories of the politicians he has known. He was regarded as an enemy by President Richard M. Nixon, though Mr. Brinkley says he is not sure why. "I think he figured, wrongly, that I was part of the Washington liberal establishment," he said. The Presidential campaign of Senator Barry Goldwater in 1964 also viewed him as a foe, he says. "The Goldwater people were constantly following me into elevators and threatening me with bodily harm," Mr. Brinkley recalled, with a smile.
Mr. Brinkley is not given to nostalgia. Speaking of Huntley, who died in 1974, Mr. Brinkley said: "We weren't really close. He was always in New York, and I was always in Washington."
And Mr. Brinkley explained the enormous success of "The Huntley-Brinkley Report" -- which, according to one 1960's survey, made its anchors more famous than the Beatles -- in this way: "I wrote pretty well, and Huntley looked good and had a great voice."
While many Americans who watched television in the 1950's and 60's fondly recall the way he and Mr. Huntley used to personally bid each other good night on the air, Mr. Brinkley has always thought the famous nightly sign-off, which was the idea of network producers, was "silly and inappropriate."
Not surprising, Mr. Brinkley is expected to do nothing very sentimental next Sunday on his final broadcast as host of "This Week." And though Tuesday's election will probably be the last he covers as full-time network newsman -- he'll provide commentary during the evening -- he seems, like many Americans, a little bored by this particular contest.
"I like surprises, and so far there haven't been many this time," he said, contrasting this election to the one in 1960 that kept Mr. Brinkley and Mr. Huntley on the air awaiting a winner all night and halfway into the following day. "This one seems to be cut and dried," he said. "This is a pretty quiet time in American history, with no wars, no recession, no divisive bloodthirsty issues. That's good, but it doesn't make for very exciting politics."
Regarding the future of "This Week," Mr. Brinkley says he will leave it to Mr. Arledge and others to decide which new directions the program should move in. Mr. Arledge says that the program will probably begin to broaden its focus beyond Washington politics and that various format and personnel changes are still being worked out.
Mr. Brinkley, too, is expected to broaden his focus beyond the Beltway. In addition to producing historical documentaries, he plans to write books (his third, "Everyone Is Entitled to My Opinion," was published last month) and travel with his wife, Susan. And now that he no longer has to be at the ABC News studios every Sunday morning, he also plans to begin sleeping in on weekends. "It's painful rolling out of bed at 5 in the morning on Sundays," he said. "I won't miss it."
