HEADLINE: The Arab Worlds as Seen Through Film Makers' Eyes

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER; Judith Miller, a reporter for The New York Times, is the author of "God has 99 Names: Reporting From a Militant Middle East."

 BODY:
THE TITLE OF THE remarkable film festival now at Lincoln Center is a bit of a misnomer. "The Centennial of Arab Cinema," which features 36 Arab films, all of them subtitled and many never before shown in this country, celebrates the 100th anniversary not of Arab film per se but of Egyptian cinema.
As the films themselves suggest, however, any homage to Arab cinema means paying tribute to Egypt, which made half of the more than 6,000 Arab films produced since 1896, when the first Egyptian film, a short, was shown in Alexandria. 
 Half the festival's films are also Egyptian. But the rest, from seven other Arab nations, prove that while Arab cinema is historically beholden to Egypt, gifted Arab directors have adapted the medium, often brilliantly, to express local concerns.
"The diversity of these films shows that there is no more an 'Arab' cinema than there is an 'Arab' world," said Mouny Berrah, an Algerian sociologist and film critic who lives in Washington. "These films reflect the many different national cultures of the Arabs."
The festival, which opened on Friday and runs through Dec. 5 at the Walter Reade Theater, is ambitious, covering vast historical, social and political ground. It has to be. Most New Yorkers have had little exposure to these works. According to Alia Arasoughly, a Palestinian-born film teacher who, with Richard Pena, program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, organized the event, the festival and two related panel discussions this weekend are the first major effort to present Arab film culture comprehensively in the United States.
Most of the films transcend national, linguistic and religious barriers. Consider Tewfiq Saleh's 1955 film "Darb Al-Mahabil" ("Fool's Alley"), about the chaos wrought by a winning lottery ticket. And their emotional force shows that if Arabs did not invent melodrama, their best directors have deified it as a genre.
The range is broad. There are some three-hanky dramas, but some without the Hollywood endings in which good guys win. There are also zany musicals and outrageously funny comedies, though many of these have an overtone of darkness that underlies the best of the region's artistic products.
For those who know the Middle East, the films evoke a wrenching nostalgia. For those who do not, they begin to explain the region's intense appeal, the hold it retains not only on those who abandon it but on foreigners who, having once tasted Nile waters, return again and again to be delighted and brokenhearted..
"Al-Azimah" ("Determination"), the festival opener (it will be repeated on Tuesday), is also its oldest. The film, made in 1939 and directed by Kamal Salim, reflects Hollywood's influence on classical Egyptian film. This Muhammad-meets-Fatma story, which features passionate kissing (far rarer in Egyptian films today), a rousing neighborhood brawl and, yes, a happy ending, nonetheless marks the beginning of the realist tradition in Egyptian films. One theme is the rigidity of the Egypt's class system and the impact of the country's vast unemployment on the young.
The festival includes several films like this one, works that helped make Egypt the center of Arab film for more than two decades; in fact, Samir Farid, an Egyptian critic, described the prosperous period from 1945 to 1952 as Egypt's golden age. But also featured are several extraordinary films from the second phase of Arab cinema, what Ms. Berrah calls the "liberation" phase, when many films explored concerns related to post-colonial life.
Among the best from this period, from the 1950's through the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, are "Bidayah wa-Nihayah" ("The Beginning and the End"), by Salah Abou Seif, the Egyptian master of realism, which has a superb performance by a young Omar Sharif, and Youssef Chahine's masterpiece, "Bab al-Hadid" ("Cairo Station"). Mr. Chahine both directs this smoldering account of life among the poor inhabitants of Cairo's railroad station and plays a crippled newspaper dealer whose sexual obsession with a lemonade seller leads to tragedy.
ANOTHER MASTERPIECE IS "Al-Ard" ("The Land"), a Chahine film made after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war; the movie ends not with justice, the Hollywood-on-the-Nile happy ending, but with a lynching.
According to Ms. Berrah, a third phase of Arab cinema, one that more openly explores personal subjects like sex, religion, political oppression and the subjugation of women, emerged after 1967. It was after this war that censors, working under discredited Arab governments, temporarily stopped clamping down on caustic originality.
A Tunisian movie, "Halfaouine, Child of the Terraces" (1990), concerns a boy allowed in the women's baths. "Our Heedless War," a 1995 video documentary from Lebanon by Randa Shahal, weaves the death of the director's father with that of Beirut during its 15-year civil war; also from Lebanon is "Hurub Saghirah" ("Little Wars"), a 1982 film by the talented Maroun Baghdadi, who lived in Paris during the 1980's and returned to Beirut in 1993, only to die in an elevator accident.
"Ahlam al-Madinah" ("Dreams of the City"), by Muhammad Malas, one of Syria's most talented directors, portrays a boy coming of age during the politically turbulent 1950's and early 60's. Mr. Malas flouts the politically correct image of the virtuous poor to describe the often emotionally crippling effect, especially on women, of the idealized Arab family's embrace.
The festival does have omissions, like any film by Duraid Lahham, Syria's Woody Allen, and his scriptwriter Muhammad Maghut, whose satirical portraits of Arab life and politics are admired in much of the region. Nevertheless, the series is a welcome counterpoint to the caricatures of Arabs and Arab life so prevalent in American cinema.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Fool's Alley," from Egypt.; "Halfaouine, Child of the Terraces," a 1990 film from Tunisia.; Omar Sharif and Sana' Gamil in "The Beginning and the End," based on the novel by Naguib Mahfouz. (Photographs from the Film Society of Lincoln Center)

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (73%); NILE RIVER (57%);

GEOGRAPHIC: EGYPT; EGYPT (94%); UNITED STATES (91%); PALESTINIAN TERRITORY, OCCUPIED (79%); MIDDLE EAST (79%); NEW YORK, USA (73%); NILE RIVER (57%); 

SUBJECT: MOTION PICTURES FESTIVALS (91%); MOVIE INDUSTRY (90%); ARTS FESTIVALS & EXHIBITIONS (90%); FILM (90%); VISUAL ARTISTS (89%); FILM DIRECTORS (89%); MOVIE REVIEWS (78%); ANNIVERSARIES (72%); SOCIOLOGY (67%); LOTTERIES (62%); THEATER (58%);

HEADLINE: ATLANTIC CITY;
A Master Dealmaker

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
WHAT comes through that door" -- Marty Wood pointed to the front of his pawnshop -- "you just wouldn't believe."
There was the man who came in with a prosthetic right foot. "He asks me how much I can give him for it," Mr. Wood said. "I say: 'Absolutely nothing. We don't take body parts.' " 
 And what about the one who came in with a parrot? "I told him, 'This is a pawnshop, not a pet shop.' He said, 'But what if I can get it to talk?' I said, 'Get out of here!' "
But the most interesting story from Mr. Wood, 61, a second-generation Atlantic City pawnbroker, does not end with a punch line.
"From where I am, things could be better," he said. "I'd rather be in a building that I own instead of paying rent. But aside from writing one more check every month, I have no complaints."
Exactly two years ago this month, Mr. Wood read in newspapers of a plan to build a shopping area, with a supermarket, on land adjacent to his pawnshop. The shopping area would be financed, in part, by the Casino Reinvestment and Development Authority, a state agency. It takes a little more than a penny from every gambling dollar left in Atlantic City and spends it on urban renewal projects and other civic and cultural improvements all over the state.
Mr. Wood thought a supermarket was a stupid idea. "You don't build a supermarket in a neighborhood where nobody wants to live anymore," he said. "You build it where the people are living, up around Connecticut Avenue, where all that new housing is going up."
Along with numerous nightclubs and restaurants, the pawnshop Mr. Wood's father opened on Kentucky Avenue in 1927 was a fixture of the city's mostly black Westside section. Wood's-Money-to-Loan, one of only two licensed pawnshops in the city, has made small cash loans in exchange for jewelry, musical instruments, even suits of clothing, to musicians, entertainers, residents and visitors from as far away as Florida and California.
In November 1994, he received a letter from the development authority informing him that it was using the power of eminent domain to condemn his pawnshop. Mr. Wood would receive compensation of $85 a square foot, roughly $85,000. The authority would also pay moderate business relocation expenses.
The letter further stated that Mr. Wood had until the end of 1994 to vacate his property unless he wanted to join the hundreds of Atlantic City business and property owners fighting the authority in court.
Mr. Wood called his lawyer: his son, Eric Wood. Eric told his father he could not represent him in any legal matter dealing with the authority because his firm represented the authority in other legal matters.
Mr. Wood persisted: "You think they could give me $100,000?"
Eric suggested that Mr. Wood try doing what almost none of the numerous homeowners and businesses displaced by casino-related projects have done: go with the flow. "Think of how much you'd save on legal fees," Eric said.
Mr. Wood accepted the $85,000, pushing back his moving date to the end of January 1995. He found a vacant storefront two blocks south, on Atlantic Avenue. Then he ran up a bill for moving expenses that fell somewhat short of $20,000, including a new security system and 7,800 32-cent stamps, so that each and every customer in his files would know that his business address had changed.
It took Mr. Wood most of a day, with a Brinks armored car and four police officers, to make the move. Then the letters went out. "For two months, we had a dip in business," he said. "It takes some of our customers a while to get the message."
The city's second supermarket opened at Kentucky and Atlantic Avenues this summer. By then, Mr. Wood said, his old customers had found him and brought new customers from the casinos.
Although the pawnbroker's business is not a growth industry, Mr. Wood said: "We have our niche, and we're very comfortable in it. Our business has never been better -- so good, in fact, that I've been able to specialize. We now only loan money on jewelry, musical instruments, cameras, TV's and VCR's. Just the other day, a guy came in with a set of false teeth. I told him to see a dentist."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/East 57th Street;
For Mickey, Bugs and Nike, It's Breakfast at Tiffany's

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
DIRECTLY across 57th Street from the mahagony and marble hush of Tiffany's, heroic size statues of Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck in formal clothing doff their top hats to visitors.
Just to the east of Tiffany's on 57th Street, a five-story sneaker and apparel store, Niketown, opened last week. A few blocks south on Fifth Avenue, Mickey and Minnie Mouse cavort on a marquee. 
 Clearly the neighborhood is changing. The corner of Fifth and 57th Street and a few blocks to the east were once the center of gravity for high-toned, high-priced shopping in New York. Ladies in Chanel suits shopped for accessories in Hermes and for baubles at Van Cleef & Arpels. The carriage trade flourished.
Then the Warner Brothers Studio Store showed up in October 1993 in old bank and office space on the northeast corner of 57th Street and Fifth Avenue. At first it was a fairly modest, three story, 30,000 square foot emporium selling mostly soft goods linked to Bugs, Daffy and Warner's immense collection of still and moving picture cartoon characters.
Tourists and families with children loved it and Studio Store officials began looking upward. When the store reopened recently it had grown to nine stories and 75,000 square feet with a wider variety of merchandise and special floors for interactive games, a cafe and candy store and a 74-seat viewing space for the screening films, including the first computer-generated 3-D cartoon feature, starring Daffy Duck and Marvin the Martian.
Entertainment retailing is taking the area by storm and reactions are mixed. "The comments are all over the lot," said Josh Kuriloff, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield, which represents the Crown Building on the southwest corner of 57th and Fifth. "Some retailers think the street should maintain a Tiffany image, like Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills or Michigan Avenue in Chicago."
"But that is like saying Microsoft does not exist," he added. "Today's world includes technology and entertainment and that's what you have to present."
"It is becoming clear that entertainment and luxury retailing are not mutually exclusive," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty Services. "People who can afford Chanel are also interested in Nike. We have become a less formal society, and retailing has evolved to match that."
Entertainment retailing is a relatively new approach to the business that uses movie characters or sports figures to establish an attractive setting where customers are given something extra while shopping.
"Over the years retail had been heavily overbuilt in this country and you had all the problems with the time-pressed consumer and women in the workforce," said Peter Starrett, the president of Warner Bros. Studio Stores. "Shopping had gone from being a near pastime for many people to a form of drudgery.
"I think entertainment retailing tapped into something that was always there," he added. "We tried to make shopping a happy experience, something more than just a product. People reacted by taking home a part of the environment."
GLITZY as the new stores are, retail specialists in the brokerage community noted that Chanel, the epitome of upscale designer goods, moved a few doors east earlier this year to a completely renovated building where it has a 99-year lease. Louis Vuitton, the French marketer of luxury leather goods, is building a 23-story tower, designed by Christian dePortzamparc, next to Chanel, with plans to use the first two floors for a retail store and the upper floors to house the parent company's offices.
"You are seeing that completely opposite retailers can live harmoniously right next to each other," said Joseph A. Fabrizi, an associate director at Cushman & Wakefield. He said that stores like Warner, Disney and Niketown appeal largely to the tourists that are becoming an increasingly important part of the New York economy, while the older, luxury stores have an established clientele that tends to return over and over again, regardless of changes in the neighborhood.
Many argue that the new stores bring more total traffic to the area, for the benefit of all. "If you only have one type of store in an area, it limits the number of people who walk past your store," said Richard Seligman, a retail broker with the Edward S. Gordon Company. "A store like Warner's attracts huge volumes of people."
Others note that Warner and Niketown are opening in an area with some of the highest rents in the city, which indicates that the retailers are convinced that the economics are favorable and the landlords think their expectations are realistic.
"Space on 57th Street between Fifth and Park Avenues ranges from $400 to $600 a square foot, and you have to do 10 times that in sales to make it all work," said Faith H. Consolo, a senior managing director of Garrick-Aug Associates. She said 57th Street east of Fifth Avenue was traditionally the preserve of higher price retailers while the western stretches of the street were populated by stores that appealed to bargain hunters and, lately, theme restaurants like Planet Hollywood and Motown.
"We tried to bring some of the apparel guys west, but they always refused," Ms. Consolo said. "It was as if they would get a nosebleed west of of Fifth."
But others argue that the two blocks of 57th Street between Fifth and Park are such a prime location that economics is not the only motivation for retailers to establish stores there. "If you are paying $300 a square foot, you can probably justify $150 to $200 on sales," said Mr. Fabrizi. "The last $100 is because you need a flagship in New York. You are showing you are strong enough to establish a presence in this location."
IF the tonier neighbors of Bugs, Mickey and Niketown are upset, they are not making much noise about it. In fact, the Bulgari jewelry store diagonally across 57th Street from Warner's is displaying in its windows, along with more traditional products, the hand-drawn cels used to make cartoon movies.
Some people are positively enthusiastic about the change. An official of Tourneau, which is building a store on 57th Street, on the same block as Tiffany and Niketown, said, "We chose the site because of its eclectic mix of stores.
"A true shopping mecca cannot be a mecca to just one stratum of society," said Anthony J. D'Ambrosio, executive vice president of the watch retailer. He said the new stores, for all their emphasis on cartoon characters that exist only as figments of the imagination, or on the reflected glory of sports heroes, are managed by very sophisticated retailers.
"They have made shopping exciting and entertaining again," said Mr. D'Ambrosio, whose own store is scheduled to open next spring.
Still, some change can be wrenching. When industrialists erected buildings, they carved words like "commerce," "industry," "transportation," "communications" and the appropriate symbols in the granite facade panels flanking their doorways.
At the Warner store, the stone panels have legends like "action" and a carving of Wile E. Coyote chasing the Roadrunner, or "suspense" and a depiction of Batman on some mythical mission.
Mr. Starrett of Warner Bros. said the company did not originally plan to locate on the corner of 57th and Fifth, where he said the rental rates are among the highest in the world. "You would have to go to some parts of Hong Kong or the Ginza in Tokyo to find anything higher," he said.
He said the company wanted to establish a flagship store on Fifth Avenue, somewhere in the 50's. As they explored they found that the building on the northeast corner of the famed intersection had been largely vacant for four years. "At first we were not interested in the whole building, just the retail space," he said.
But as sales boomed, the company took over most of the building, occuping 75,000 of the 85,000 total square feet. The landlord, Daiichi America Real Estate, maintains its offices on the top floors.
Mr. Starrett said the real significance of the entertainment retailers is that they "have helped prove you can do business on 57th Street at less than the designer level."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tiffany's new neighbor, Niketown, left, opened Friday on 57th Street and will be joined next spring by the Tourneau watch store, right. Warner Brothers Studio Store is across 57th from Tiffany's. (Photographs by Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The End for Winsted Hospital

BYLINE: By SUSAN PEARSALL 

 BODY:
AFTER six months of community debate and legal wrangling over the future of financially strapped Winsted Memorial Hospital, the end came quickly. Litchfield Superior Court Judge Richard A. Walsh ordered the hospital closed on Oct. 25, three days after receiving an independent report that showed there was no money to pay employees.
"The financial condition of Win-sted Memorial Hospital is more than precarious," Judge Walsh wrote in his decision. "Indeed, it is nothing less than desperate -- so desperate that there is nowhere to turn." 
 The decision affects 206 full- and part-time employees, who were laid off without receiving severance pay or earned vacation pay. Lawyers for the hospital said they would file for bankruptcy in Federal court under Chapter 7, which requires liquidation of assets to pay off creditors.
The judge based his decision on a report prepared by court-appointed receiver, E. Cortright Phillips of Fairfield, who replaced James E. Sok, former chief executive of the hospital, and testimony in a lawsuit filed by Attorney General Richard Blumenthal to block the closing. Mr. Phillips, now retired, served on the State Commission on Hospitals and Health Care from 1992 to '95 and worked in the banking industry.
"When I got to the financial situation at the end of August, I was shocked," Mr. Phillips testified. Between October 1995 and last August, hospital admissions dropped by 38 percent, causing an operating loss of $3.2 million, according to his report. Preliminary figures indicated the operating loss would reach $3.7 million for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, he said.
While the hospital was licensed for 73 beds, "its average daily in-patient census over the last six months has been less than 10 patients, and the census is declining," Mr. Phillips said in his report.
Earlier this year, Mr. Sok blamed the sudden decline on managed-care providers, which tend to exclude small hospitals that cannot afford steep discounts, and increased competition between Winsted Memorial and Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington, a larger hospital about 25 minutes away.
The judge's decision to close the hospital was a blow to the Community Trust for Winsted Hospital Inc., a group of local residents who had hoped to replace the current board of directors if the judge found they had mismanaged hospital affairs. But he did not.
The decision ends, for now, months of bitter dispute between hospital officials and residents who differed sharply on how to provide medical care in a rapidly changing health care environment.
On April 23, the hospital's directors voted unanimously to approve a "new vision" proposed by hospital administrators that would close in-patient beds and convert the hospital to a residential care center for elderly men and women. Under the plan, the hospital would have remained open for out-patient services until a new, more cost-effective ambulatory-care center and emergency room were built on another site.
Within days, a petition drive to keep the hospital open collected more than 10,000 signatures. The effort was organized by Charlene LaVoie, a community lawyer who works for free for the citizens of Winsted as part of a nonprofit trust established by the consumer advocate Ralph Nader, a Winsted native, and his sister, Claire, who still lives there.
The group maintained the directors should look at small hospitals that have survived, despite similar obstacles, by establishing innovative new programs.
Hospitals officials, backed by most of the medical community, had decided to go ahead with their plan by affiliating with Hartford and Charlotte Hungerford hospitals and closing in-patient beds, when Mr. Blumenthal filed his lawsuit on Sept. 10. It was disclosed in court testimony that Mr. Sok and Daniel Dombal, vice president for financial services, received bonuses totaling $150,000 to promote the plan.
Ben Serafini and his wife, Sue, both worked at Winsted Memorial. He was in housekeeping; she was in admitting and registration. Now both are unemployed.
How does Mr. Serafini feel about the situation? "Sad and disgusted," he replied. "We didn't expect to go out not having anything. We thought there would be something there for the community, even if we didn't have our jobs."
The Serafinis will sign up for unemployment benefits and soon begin looking for new jobs. But first they're taking some time off, "to wind down from all that happened," Mr. Serafini said.
Under the administration's plan, some 100 employees would have kept their jobs when in-patient beds closed.
Perhaps Ms. LaVoie and the community group were too fixed on saving in-patient care at any cost?
"There were no other options," Ms. LaVoie insisted. "A hospital is an institution in this community, not a walk-in clinic. Small hospitals are surviving all over the country, and it could have survived here."
Mr. Sok, the former hospital executive vindicated by the court proceedings, is angry about the bankruptcy. "It's a tragedy the the community and the hospital were blocked from accepting the $9.5 million in financial support that Hartford Hospital and Charlotte Hungerford Hospital were willing to provide to rebuild, retool, renovate and reposition Winsted Memorial Hospital," he said. "Instead, the community lost a century-old institution and the $10.6 million it put into the local economy, because some people were resistant to change."
With the longer drive to a hospital, local officials are concerned volunteer ambulance crews may not be able to take time from work to respond to daytime calls. Paul S. Vayer, the town manager, said he expects to hire a paid medic to solve that problem, but the Winsted Volunteer Ambulance Association will no longer be able to offer free service.
It has been a stressful six months for Douglas Gerard, an internist in Winsted and member of the hospital board of directors. But he has just sold his practice so he can stay in Winsted and concentrate more on patients than business details. However, Dr. Gerard sounded a warning.
"People should pay attention," he said. "This could happen in other places, too."

HEADLINE: Teaching English Around the Dinner Table

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER'S business voice is changing, and one of the reasons is the remarkable growth of minority-owned businesses.
In the last 10 years, the number of Asian-owned companies alone has doubled and a sixfold increase in the number of Hispanic-owned businesses has been recorded, according to the most recent statistics from the county's Office of Economic Opportunity. Charles Gonzalez, president of the Westchester Hispanic Chamber of Commerce in White Plains, estimates that there are at least 2,500 Hispanic business owners in Westchester. 
 But success brings problems. And one that looms large is the language barrier.
"Business people and professionals quickly realize that they need more than survival English in order to be upwardly mobile," observed Beth S. K. Morris, president of Unispeech in White Plains. Ms. Morris, who has a doctorate in speech and hearing sciences, runs a company that specializes in teaching verbal skills to business people who are not native speakers of English.
"As a result of Westchester's ethnic diversity, I have a global client list," said Ms. Morris, who also speaks French and Spanish.
"Many of our county's best and brightest are foreign born," she said. "They have medical degrees or doctorates in engineering and computer science. Some are employers who run mid-sized companies. These are people who already have basic English but they have a need and desire to improve their verbal communication skills.
"They not only want to perfect their diction, grammar and English pronunciation," she added, "but they want to learn English in the vernacular, the lingo, the slang, the special American nuances and subjects that are not found in textbooks. One of my clients, a Hispanic executive who works for an international computer company, wanted to learn how to talk about American football. He kept confusing it with soccer, which of course, goes by the name of football in other countries."
The best way to learn to speak another language, Ms. Morris emphasized, is through conversation. And since conversation takes place most effortlessly around the dinner table, Ms. Morris and a colleague, Lorraine Way, have started a new language program in an environment conducive to conversation, a restaurant.
"It's a realistic setting for conversing," she said. "The participants have dinner together with us at the Exotic Foods Cafe in Ossining, owned by Martha Camacho, a Hispanic businesswoman who serves very tasty food. The group is kept deliberately small in order to give everyone a chance to get into the conversation. In Latin and European cultures, sitting around the table and talking is the normal thing to do, so conversation flows easily."
Ms. Way, a former adjunct professor of Spanish at Pace University, started her business, the Language Way in Ossining, 18 months ago. She is proficient in Spanish and French.
"I help business people, professionals and tourists become verbal in both Spanish and French," she said. "Many of my clients are physicians and health care aids, who work in neighborhoods with large Spanish-speaking populations. It is essential for them to understand and speak Spanish in order to care for their patients."
The ability to speak French, Ms. Way said, is becoming increasingly important for those involved with commerce and business in the international marketplace.
"Even though English is the language of business there are many places in the world where it isn't adequate," Ms. Way said. "I have clients who deal with companies in the French-speaking countries in Africa where, in order to get business, speaking and understanding French is important."
But business is not the only motivation for learning how to speak in another language, Ms. Way said.
"One of my dinner students, Nina Weireter, the daughter of an American father and a Cuban mother, never learned to speak Spanish as a child. She wants to learn it now, to be able to teach her children something about their heritage and because she has a Spanish nanny."
By contrast, Ms. Morris said, most of her students are like Susana Lara, who is improving her English, to get ahead in business.
"Susana is a typical client," Ms. Morris said. "She is from El Salvador, but earned a master's degree in business from an American university so she speaks English on a good level. Although she's doing well professionally -- she's vice president of Sir Speedy, a printing firm in Pleasantville -- she feels she can improve her pronunciation and vocabulary in order to make her sales presentations and her very frequent telephone conversations more effective."
Observing that the telephone exaggerates flaws in diction and pronunciation, Ms. Morris said: "For the foreign born, the telephone is the bane of their existence. One of my clients, an Indian-born journalist, was upset because he was constantly asked to repeat certain words and, too frequently, their meaning was still unclear. Other students find the cold-call strategy, a common business strategy used in the U.S. a nightmare for those not used to American ways. I often base speech sessions around such business problems."
English speakers learning conversational Spanish most often have problems using the correct tense, Ms. Way said. "There are two verbs in Spanish making it extremely confusing, but the wrong tense completely alters the meaning of a conversation, so that is something we always work on."
Both groups meet for eight sessions, from 6:30 to 7:45 P.M. at the restaurant. Ms. Morris's group meets on Tuesdays; Ms. Way's on Thursdays. The cost, including dinner, is $ 20 a session. For information, call 923-7724.
Unispeech also specializes in corporate work. Companies hire Ms. Morris to work with personnel in key company positions who are not native English speakers. They usually are highly trained specialists who need to upgrade their verbal skills," she said. "One of my corporate students is a Mexican nuclear physicist, another is a Chinese computer technician. I see them during business hours in the privacy of their own offices."
Ms. Morris and Ms. Way also provide on-site team language instruction to the employees of organizations and corporations in Westchester.
"Right now, we're working with a major hotel," Ms. Way said. "I will be working with management executives to increase their proficiency in Spanish, and Beth will work on teaching spoken English to the large non-English-speaking staff."

LENGTH: 429 words

HEADLINE: What Drives a Batterer? Issues of Control

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
COMPLAINTS by battered spouses -- women and men -- increased sharply last year, as did deaths caused by domestic partners. In New Jersey, reports of domestic violence increased 22 percent over 1994, to 86,213, in part because the authorities take it more seriously and because more women are seeking help. And 61 adults were killed by domestic violence, compared to 42 in 1994.
Last year, nearly half of all reports of domestic violence in the state led to arrests. And more women -- for a great majority of victims are female -- are filing complaints and seeking other help. 
 But women are actually at highest risk when they seek help. When a woman leaves her abuser, her risk of being injured or murdered increases by 75 percent, the Coalition for Battered Women says.
"He's losing power and control, and that's what it's about," said Barbara Price, executive director of the coalition, a statewide group based in Trenton. The abuser's logic, she says, "If I can't have you, no one will."
Battering has only recently been taken as seriously as child abuse or, for that matter, animal torture. New Jersey passed its first law against battering a spouse only 15 years ago, about a century after cruelty to animals was outlawed. Since then, the coalition, founded in the mid-1970's, has opened shelters for battered women and their children in every county, with 12 to 40 beds. The state covers the cost.
These shelters house women of no means and women who have left $500,000 houses, women with little schooling and with college degrees. "Domestic violence crosses all socio-economic lines," said Carol Vasili, supervisor of the state Office on the Prevention of Violence Against Women. "The only piece connected to economic status is, does the woman have access to any money when she leaves?"
Many woman who safely leave abusive relationships must then find ways to support and care for children alone, since it is often hard to collect child support. Fear of losing the children is a potent reason for remaining in a destructive marriage, for, contrary to popular belief fathers win three-quarters of all custody fights, the coalition says.
Hiding from an abusive spouse also takes a toll. The state Legislature is considering a law that would conceal a battered spouse's address by funneling mail and child-support checks through a government address.
The time a family may stay in a shelter is limited, ranging from two weeks to two months. But shelters do provide a place for battered women to take their children and to get their bearings in safety.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Abused No More

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
THIS is what Debbie Karamanol remembers about her 12-year marriage: Her husband threw hot coffee on her. He broke her hand. He blackened her eyes and blackened her eyes and blackened her eyes. He threw her down the stairs for cooking pork chops too rare. He threw her down the stairs for carrying the baby he wanted aborted.
This is what she knows about her life after marriage: She runs her own business. It grossed $357,000 last year, and she expects to double that this year. She hires women like her, women whose husbands once beat them and who have mustered the courage to leave that life to make it on their own. It is a source of support -- financial and emotional -- for herself, her business partner, Pam Sullivan, and her 12 sales representatives, all who have left abusive husbands. 
 It takes some doing, employing these women. Ms. Karamanol worries about stalkers. She does not list her business in the phone book. She has no sign on the door. Mail is directed to an address in Wayne, although the office is in Hoboken. Ms. Karamanol and Ms. Sullivan are accustomed to dealing with restraining orders and employees who have to take time to go to court hearings. Their business is printing; their mission is helping battered women live on their own.
"This is not just a job," Ms. Karamanol said. "We have a personal stake in it."
Ms. Sullivan concurred: "We go way beyond Avis."
True, the business is still rather dicey. Not long ago, Ms. Sullivan borrowed money to keep the company afloat, using her car as collateral. She lost the car and still can't afford to buy a new one.
But the office, like the business partners, has an air of success. The women share a well-lighted one-room office in downtown Hoboken. On Mondays, when the sales reps meet, they sit on folding chairs pulled from the closet. The shiny desks, the leather chairs, the posters are as stylish as the female partners. On a recent Friday afternoon, Ms. Karamanol, 45, wore a sport jacket, which fit sleekly over her slender frame, and running shoes. Her reddish-brown hair was jaunty, the bangs framing eyes highlighted with shadow and mascara. Ms. Sullivan, also 45, had white-blond hair falling to her shoulders, and pink buffed nails and lips that coordinated with her long pink plaid jacket. Together they looked more like television sitcom stars than veterans of years of anguish hidden within suburban comfort.
Ms. Karamanol named her company after her new life: Independent Graphics. It is a printing brokerage. Its sales reps comb their counties for businesses that want four-color brochures, menus, cards, T-shirts. The orders are sent to the outside printing shops that give good work at a good price.
She learned of these shops only after she left her husband and their suburban house in Wayne. He was, and is, a corporate manager; they lived well. She shopped and prepared fancy recipes and cared for their son, Fredrick, now 18. And she waited, all day, for him to come home. "I was afraid of the garage door opening at night," she said.
He hit her, she said, for any reason or no reason: "You're worthless. You made dinner wrong. You painted the house wrong." She says she'd blame herself. If she were better, she thought, he'd stop.
Why didn't she leave him? This is the question everybody asks. Ms. Karamanol -- educated, obviously competent, from a Wayne family she describes as supportive and prosperous -- could surely have survived on her own. The answer is, she did leave -- all the time. But she always went back.
In the early years, she loved him. Later, she had no place to go and no faith that she could find a job. She was afraid of losing her children; she was afraid of being homeless. "If you're from an affluent area like Wayne, you're not likely to go to a battered women's shelter in the inner city," she said. Not that she would have known where to find one.
Why didn't she seek help? Because, she said, she was ashamed. The beatings were a "deep, dark, dirty secret."
It was worst when she was pregnant with Courtney, now 11. He didn't want the baby. He beat her every night, she said. She was terrified he would make her miscarry or damage the unborn child. It was joy over her unscathed newborn that gave her the energy to escape.
"There was nothing wrong with her head, no retardation," Ms. Karamanol said. "I was so grateful she was healthy. I felt God blessed me."
With no credit, no job experience and no confidence, she took what she could find -- waitressing, mainly. For years she floundered, working three or four or six jobs at a time to make ends meet. An employment agency led her to first substantial full-time job, selling for a printing broker. She promptly signed up the Meadowlands Sports Complex. "I didn't know I had sales ability," she said.
She sold -- successfully, she says -- for a few years. Then the boss called her in. He was replacing her. Sorry, but the new employee was not a divorced housewife, but a man, "a man with real sales experience," he said. Maybe she should try catering or something. The employees certainly enjoyed the homemade cheesecakes and stuffed croissants she was constantly taking to the office.
As Ms. Karamanol tells it, she didn't even force the boss to say the nasty words. "I said, 'I'll leave. Thank you very much for the opportunity. Thank you very much.' "
After a second job in which, she said, the boss would shut the door, tell his secretary to hold all calls and chase her around the desk as in a Playboy cartoon, something snapped. "I got tired of being pushed around," she said. "I wanted some respect."
She took the $66 in her bank account and had business cards printed: Independent Graphics.
"I was stupid," she said.
Ms. Sullivan batted back: "I call it courageous."
From home, Ms. Karamanol called around to see if local companies had printing work. "You're in luck," a bank manager told her. "We have a job right now."
From her first job, she took printers' phone numbers with her. She understood color separation and deadlines. That first job for the bank paid $2,700.
That was two years ago. Day after day, she made calls -- cold calls -- for 10, 12 hours a day. She landed jobs from Riverside Mall, Nickelodeon, Sussex County Senior Services, Representative Rodney Frelinghuysen and non-profit groups, including several battered women's shelters in New Jersey. From the shelters, from displaced homemakers' groups, she obtained names of other women like her, who had left abusive husbands and had children to support but no job experience. She hired a few, paying a 10 to 15 percent commission and health insurance.
INDEPENDENT GRAPHICS outgrew her living room. She needed a business loan, but no one was willing to lend to a divorced woman with no business record. Not the Federal Government's Small Business Administration, nor the state, nor the Passaic County Economic Council. Certainly no private bank -- until, in the process of methodically applying everywhere, she tried West Jersey Community Bank in Fairfield.
This is how Sally Schwartz, a bank vice president, explains the apparently risky $10,000 loan: "You can't lend money with numbers all the time. You can't lend by your heart, but you can lend by your gut. You can't lend money because you feel sorry for them. But my gut feeling was: 'This is going to work. She doesn't have collateral or assets, but this is going to work.' "
Ms. Schwartz took the application to John Van Voorhis, who was then the president of West Jersey Bank, which has since been bought by Sovereign Bank. "I looked at his face and he looked at me," she said, "and he said yes."
Ms. Karamanol has now rented an office, attended seminars to learn about debt equity and financing, and applied for another loan for computers. "Then we can really expand," she said.
However much the company grows, Ms. Karamanol plans for Independent to stick to its mission, to be openly and avowedly a business of and by battered women. This is what sales reps say almost immediately in their pitches. It is printed on fact sheets they stuff into packages to clients. It is the topic they turn over at Monday meetings, exchanging advice when the sales talks are done.
Although she's on her own, Ms. Karamanol still lives with remnants of her marriage. Her former husband makes harassing phone calls several times a day, she said. Because they share custody of the children, she cannot obtain a restraining order. Unlike Ms. Sullivan -- who says, "I'm still the romantic; I still have the hope Mr. Right will come along" -- she has no intention of giving up being single. After all, what for? "Men remarry for companionship," she said firmly. "Women remarry for a paycheck."
It took nearly 20 years for her to realize she can earn her own paycheck. And more than that, she can now to help other women in need earn one, too.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Mid-October Storm Highlights Fire Island Concerns

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
WHILE Fire Island lost no houses during the nor'easter that pounded the New York metropolitan area Oct. 19, its battered beaches lost large chunks of sand in some areas as the churning seas washed over dunes and walkways.
In Seaview, for example, most of the sand that was scraped from the beach this summer to replenish dunes was washed away. 
 Speaking of the dune in front of the oceanfront house that he and his wife, Patricia, own, Keith Fogerty said, "It is 75 percent to 80 percent gone."
Seaview's experience was echoed in the Village of Saltaire. "The storm took away some of the new dunes we built and we lost a substantial amount of sand," said the Mayor, Martin M. Berger, a Manhattan lawyer. Two houses were lost in a storm in 1992, he said.
Narrowing beaches, vanishing dunes and property damage from storms have long been a way of life for this 32-mile-long barrier island that forms the Fire Island National Seashore and stretches from Moriches Inlet to Fire Island Inlet.
The Shinnecock and Moriches Inlets, created by hurricanes in the 30's and stabilized by jetties in the 50's, and the construction of a series of jetties called groins in Westhampton Beach that was started in 1964 but never completed are blamed by residents for stopping the natural flow of sand from east to west, robbing their beaches of sustaining sand.
Each storm brings an increased sense of urgency that a coordinated beach restoration project be undertaken by Federal, state and local agencies before breaches occur. Residents say all the agencies created the problems because they share the costs.
"An overwash would have a disastrous affect on the mainland and would affect the salinity of the Great South Bay," said Mr. Berger, the Saltaire Mayor. "Millions of people and dollars depend on the stability and integrity of Fire Island."
Of the island's 3,700 or so houses, about 50 have been swept away by storms since 1992, with the latest casualty a house in Corneille Estates, west of Ocean Beach, which was lost to the sea in early October.
Many more houses might have been lost to date had not seven of Fire Island's 17 communities, including Seaview and Saltaire, formed erosion control districts to protect their beaches. Residents are paying off the total of $8 million raised since 1993 in bond issues through extra tax levies.
"A lot of projects have been done piecemeal and that doesn't work," said Jane Ekstein, executive director of a nonprofit advocacy group called Save Our Seashore, which was formed in 1993 in response to Fire Island's erosion problems.
Its constituency now extends from Montauk Point to Coney Island, Mrs. Ekstein said, "but Fire Island is our focus because it is one of the most endangered areas, and along with Shinnecock the only place where there hasn't been a project mounted."
HAD local efforts and a $4 million state project at Robert Moses State Park undertaken in 1993 been leveraged with Federal funds, a $40 million project could already have been launched, she pointed out.
Last June, a beach-restoration plan was drafted by the New York district office of the Army Corps of Engineers, the Federal agency in charge of maintaining navigable waterways.
Some environmental issues must still be resolved before the plan, which requires state approval, is sent to the corps' Washington office for policy review.
The plan calls for creating a 270-foot-deep beach and constructing a 15-foot high dune and to maintain the beach at its restored level for 30 years.
The cost is estimated to be $59 million. No work would be done in the federally designated Wilderness Area.
Under a cost-sharing formula, the Federal share would be 65 percent, the state's share 24.5 percent, and the county share, 10.5 percent. Owners of property representing two-thirds of the assessed value on Fire Island voted in favor of a self-taxing district to pay up to half the county share, but not more than $4 million.
The objective of the project, said Joseph R. Vietri, special assistant to the corps' district engineer for strategic planning, is to stabilize the barrier island beach and to protect the mainland, not private property on Fire Island, as some critics claim.
"The bulk of all the benefits would go to the back bay of Long Island, and benefits attributable to homes on Fire Island are incidental to the whole project," he said.
The proposed project would be an interim step until the corps completes a study of the barrier island system between Montauk and Fire Island. The study was originally authorized in 1960 and completed in 1977. But in 1978 the President's Council on Environmental Quality, among other Federal agencies, instructed the corps to do further studies of erosion problems. The so-called reformulation study, which did not begin until 1993, is due to be completed in 2003.
There are concerns that the interim plan would be implemented without a full review of its effects on the environment and fish and wildlife.
The theory of barrier island geology is that these islands are not naturally stable and that they move, said Robert G. Murray, a biologist with the Fish and Wildlife Service, a Federal environmental agency with which the Army Corps of Engineers must coordinate activities. Breaches are not necessarily bad since they allow sand to be transported to the bay to form new wetlands and mudflats, he said.
"There are still a lot of questions and the answers are in the reformulation study," he said. "Yet the Corps of Engineers is on the brink of moving ahead with this project without knowing whether it's the best solution." A state breach contingency plan would also avert any major incursion from occurring, he added.
But others say that it is critically important to protect Fire Island now.
"While protection of endangered species is important, it is not the only resource value on Fire Island that has to be protected," said Gerard Stoddard, president of the Fire Island Association, a homeowners' group.
"Unless Fire Island maintains its geologic integrity, there will be effects not only on the ecology, but also on the economy," said Mr. Stoddard, who also is chairman of the Long Island Coastal Alliance in Manhattan, a coastal policy analysis group. "You are talking about fundamental changes on the entire Great South Bay."
WHILE Mr. Stoddard said that he felt confident that a project will start by 1998, others fear that given budget cutting and the political climate in Washington, the project will only move forward if additional pressure is applied.
About 300 property owners are suing the Army Corps of Engineers and Suffolk County in Federal District Court in Brooklyn seeking more than $200 million in damages for property values lost, they say, because of governmental-agency mistakes.
"We don't believe we can get these governmental agencies to repair years of neglect and mismanagement without the additional pressure of this lawsuit," said Edward Lewis, who owns a house in Fire Island Pines. "What we really want is that they fix the beaches, but if that's not achievable, we'll take the damages."
The case could go to trial as early as March, said John J. O'Connell, a Manhattan lawyer who represents the homeowners.
A settlement in December 1994 in a similar action brought by residents of what is now the Village of West Hampton Dunes resulted in a $32 million beach restoration project that is now under way. Groinfields are being modified and new ways to bypass sand at inlets are being implemented.
"The settlement in West Hampton Dunes coincided with a government task force report on coastal erosion that for the first time admitted what everyone involved already knew -- that much of the South Shore erosion problems were man-made," said Mr. O'Connell, who also represented West Hampton Dunes residents.
"Everyone thought that that settlement marked the beginning of a new era in coastal erosion protection with the various levels of government and property owners working together," he added.
But the euphoria was short-lived, he said, because of concerns over budget cuts in Washington following Republican victories in 1994 and the Clinton Administration's withdrawal in 1995 of support for shore protection projects that were without national significance.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
New Baseball Parks Taking the Field in the State

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
PLANS are advancing in New Jersey for three baseball stadiums and the possibility of a fourth, in Bridgewater, is being explored.
The approved projects -- in Newark, Atlantic City and North Wildwood -- will be home to minor-league or independent teams. If completed as planned in 1998 they will bring to six the number of minor-league stadiums in the state. The others, in Trenton and Frankford Township in Sussex County, opened in 1994 and marked the return of professional baseball, after a 15-year absence, to New Jersey where, some authorities say, the first game between organized teams was played in Hoboken in 1846. 
 Officials of the municipalities involved consider the stadiums not only a way to compete for entertainment dollars, but also to promote commerce, tourism and open and recreational space.
Professional ballparks can help attract "sports-minded people with dollars to spend" to an area and establish it as an entertainment destination, said Jonn T. Kaatz, director of the sports, entertainment and leisure division at the Dallas office of Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm.
The stadiums, which, for the most part, are publicly financed, can also produce such potential "public offshoots" as raising tax revenue and spurring economic growth, Mr. Kaatz added.
Since 1985, 76 minor-league stadiums have been or are being built in the country. Attendance at minor-league games is also on the rise, increasing to over 33 million in each of the last three years from 27 million in 1992, according to the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues in St. Petersburg, Fla., which governs minor league teams nationwide. And that, industry experts say, underscores a move toward affordable, family-oriented entertainment.
But Mr. Kaatz cautioned that ballparks did not constitute a panacea for urban ailments. Challenges such as securing the public funds and addressing concerns over traffic and quality of life, among others, also exist.
To increase the odds for success Mr. Kaatz said such projects should complement other community initiatives.
That is the case for the $13 million project on the Delaware River in Trenton, considered by many to be a success. It comprises a 6,150-seat stadium for the Trenton Thunder, an affiliate of the Detroit Tigers; a riverfront walkway, a picnic area and a boat launch.
The project "has given state workers a reason to stay in the city and outsiders a reason to come," said Mercer County Executive Robert D. Prunetti, noting that it had helped change the perception of Trenton. Attendance was 437,396 this year, the highest among teams in the Eastern League.
It is also spurring other development, Mr. Prunetti said, noting that a nearby vacant factory was being converted to a restaurant/nightclub. He said plans were also advancing to reshape a mile-long stretch of the waterfront for recreation and commercial uses, and to link that area to two others. They are the state capital environs, where new housing is planned, and a former 45-acre industrial area that is being turned into a mix of housing, commerce and cultural and recreational amenities, including a possible minor-league hockey arena.
The idea, said Mr. Prunetti, is "to create a triangle" of economic development that will be a magnet like Baltimore's Inner Harbor.
That same approach is being taken in Newark. After months of delays over environmental and community concerns, city and Essex County officials recently approved financing for a $22 million sports complex to include a 6,000-seat ballpark and a 6,000-seat soccer stadium. It will rise in the Ironbound section on a nine-acre park along the Passaic River recently closed because it was found to be polluted. It will now be cleaned up.
PLANS also call for a replacement park to be built elsewhere in the East Ward. That park will be developed first and with community input to address concerns of neighbors who objected to the stadium project because they felt the new park would not be built or be inferior to the old one.
City and county leaders consider the complex a second anchor to the waterfront's revival and another step in the city's rebirth. The other anchor is the $200 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center, including a 500-seat theater and a 2,750-seat concert hall, which will open downtown next October.
Also in the works is a federally financed riverfront greenway of more than two miles with a public walkway at the water's edge. It will link the Ironbound neighborhood on the east -- with its stadium and myriad multi-ethnic restaurants -- to the Pennsylvania Station area in the middle and the performing-arts center neighborhood on the west.
By linking these attractions together "we are creating reasons for people to enjoy Newark as center of entertainment where they can go for beer and a hotdog or white wine and Verdi," said Thomas Banker. He is executive director of the semi-autonomous Essex County Improvement Authority, which will develop and manage the sports complex.
County Executive James Treffinger called it the use of public money "to ignite new fires of economic growth."
The authority will lease the complex to users, with the ballpark set to become the home of the Newark Bears, whose principal owner is Rick Cerone, the former Yankee catcher and Newark native.
The team is part of the Atlantic League Inc., an independent franchise founded by Frank Boulton and Peter Kirk together with such former major league baseball players as Mr. Cerone and Buddy Harrelson, a former New York Mets manager. Mr. Boulton said he and his partners were bringing their franchise to eight high density areas with, among other things, large corporate populations and a supportive political climate. That is the case in Newark as well as Atlantic City, where the team has not yet been named.
In that oceanside resort 25 city-owned acres at the edge of its old but still operating airport are being turned into a $12 million, 6,000-seat stadium. The Albany Avenue site is some seven blocks from the nearest casino.
The stadium is intended to help establish the city as a family vacation and convention center, not just a gaming town, said Louis Toscano, a senior policy adviser for Mayor James Whelan. "Minor-league baseball is a nice fit," he said.
The project is also moving ahead at a time when some $7 billion in public and private investment is planned or under way. That exceeds the $6 billion invested since the first casino was built in the city in 1978, said Mr. Toscano.
AMONG the other projects are the expansion of existing casino hotels and the construction of new ones that will triple the number of casino hotel rooms to 27,000 by the end of 1999. Beyond that there will a 1,000-room noncasino hotel joined to the state's $268 million convention center, set to open in May. Plans for the existing convention hall call for turning it into a special-events area for concerts and sporting events as well as a family entertainment and retail complex.
In the seaside resort of North Wildwood, public financing is now being completed for a 5,500-seat, $10.5 million ballpark on an 18-acre site edging the Herford Inlet. The site, once a municipal landfill that was closed in the 70's, will be sealed. Construction of the stadium is to start this spring, said Bob Heal, the city administrator, noting that it would be home to an affiliate club of a major league team.
In Bridgewater in Somerset County, local and county officials are considering a proposal for an up-to-7,000-seat, $16 million stadium for an independent or minor league team. It would rise on 25 no longer contaminated acres of a 565-acre Superfund site owned by American Home Products, where 461 acres must still be cleaned.
A committee appointed by the county's Board of Freeholders is expected to make a recommendation next month on whether any publicly financing of such a project is justified, said James B. Ventantonio, the committee chairman.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS;
Bound for Washington? Voters Will Soon Decide

 BODY:

FIRST DISTRICT
Most of Camden County and parts of Burlington and Gloucester counties.
 
INCUMBENT Robert E. Andrews, 39, of Haddon Heights, three-term Congressman. Elected in 1990 to succeed Jim Florio; member of the International Relations Committee and the Economic and Educational Opportunities Committee. Former Camden County freeholder and lawyer.
CHALLENGER Mel Suplee, (R), of Bellmawr; his 57th birthday is today. A retired Federal employee, he now works as a purchasing specialist for Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia. Has unsuccessfully run for mayor of Bellmawr and for state Senate.
THE RACE The incumbent, who has his eye on the New Jersey State House, has little to worry about in this Democratic district. Republicans were forced to come up with a substitute candidate over the summer after the withdrawal of the candidate who had won the primary running unopposed. Crucial issues, according to Mr. Andrews, are protecting Medicare and protecting the environment.
 
SECOND DISTRICT
All of Atlantic, Cape May, Cumberland and Salem counties. Part of Gloucester County and one municipality in Burlington County.
 
INCUMBENT Frank LoBiondo, (R), 50, first-term Congressman from Vineland. Member of the Banking and Financial Services Committee and the Small Business Committee. Member of state Assembly from 1988 to 1994; operations manager for LoBiondo Brothers Motor Express, a family trucking company.
CHALLENGER Ruth Katz, (D), 44, a lawyer from Ventnor. Former counsel to House Subcommittee on Health and the Environment.
THE RACE Although Mr. LoBiondo is favored, Ms. Katz could be within striking distance, according to some independent political publications analyzing congressional races. The district was represented for many years by William J. Hughes, a Democrat. Calling health care a crucial issue, Ms. Katz says her priority would be to control Medicare costs and to promote long-term and nursing-home care. Ms. Katz, who has been endorsed by the New Jersey Environmental Federation, assails the Republican record on the environment, including protection of the New Jersey shore. Mr. LoBiondo, who has had several tough races in his political career, supported the changes in welfare policy approved by Congress and favors Republican measures to balance the budget.
 
THIRD DISTRICT
Parts of Burlington and Camden counties and southern Ocean County.
 
INCUMBENT H. James Saxton, (R), 53, six-term Congressman from Southampton. Member ofe National Security Committee and Resources Committee; vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee. Has worked in real estate and insurance and served in the state Assembly and Senate.
CHALLENGER John Leonardi, (D), 40, of Cherry Hill Township. An Army officer for 14 years, he is now in the Army Reserves. President and chief executive of the Greater New Jersey Regional Multiple Listing Service.
THE RACE This is a decidedly lopsided race, with Mr. Saxton firmly entrenched in a district that has voted Republican for many years. Mr. Leonardi, who was drafted by the Democrats when they could not persuade an experienced politician to run, has almost no campaign money. He does, however, have the backing of the New Jersey Education Association and the National Education Association.
 
FOURTH DISTRICT
Parts of Burlington, Mercer, Monmouth and Ocean counties.
 
INCUMBENT Christopher H. Smith, (R), 43, eight-term Congressman from Washington Township. Member of Veterans' Affairs and International Relations committees.
CHALLENGER Kevin J. Meara, 38, a former Hamilton Township councilman from 1990 to 1994. Marketing representative for P.S.E. & G. Ran unsuccessfully for the state Assembly as an independent in 1991.
THE RACE Mr. Smith has easily won the last several races and seems destined to do so this year, when his opponent has almost no campaign money. Mr. Meara is hoping for a boost from Democrats who want to regain control of Congress.
 
FIFTH DISTRICT
Parts of Bergen, Passaic and Sussex counties and all of Warren County.
 
INCUMBENT Marge S. Roukema, (R), 67; nine-term Congresswoman from Ridgewood, the longest-serving member of the New Jersey delegation. Member of Banking and Financial Services Committee and the Economic and Educational Opportunities Committee.
CHALLENGER Bill Auer, (D), 56, a former electrical engineer who now works in advertising. A resident of Allendale and a former member of the local planning board.
THE RACE In an overwhelmingly Republican district, Mrs. Roukema has repeatedly easily won re-election. She received 74 percent of the vote against Mr. Auer in 1994.
 
SIXTH DISTRICT
Southern and middle Middlesex County and coastal Monmouth County.
 
INCUMBENT Frank J. Pallone Jr., (D), 45, Long Branch. A lawyer specializing in maritime law, he was originally elected to Congress in 1988 to succeed the late James J. Howard. Member of Commerce Committee and Resources Committee.
CHALLENGER Steven J. Corodemus, (R), 44, a lawyer who lives in Atlantic Highlands. Three-term state assemblyman.
THE RACE Although Mr. Pallone is considered the leader, it is a hard-fought campaign. In Congress, Mr. Pallone has specialized in environmental and fishing issues, both important topics for coastal residents. Mr. Corodemus can also claim credit for state environmental legislation, including coastline protection. The candidates follow party lines in their disagreement on Bob Dole's proposed 15 percent tax cut. Mr. Pallone, who initially opposed abortion, now supports a woman's right to have an abortion and Mr. Corodemus opposes it.
 
SEVENTH DISTRICT
Parts of Middlesex, Somerset and Union counties and a bit of Essex County.
 
INCUMBENT Robert D. Franks, (R), 45, a two-term Congressman from New Providence. Member of Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Budget Committee. Former member of state Assembly; former state Republican chairman.
CHALLENGER Lawrence Lerner, (D), 61, a patent lawyer from Warren in Pohatcong Township.
THE RACE Although the Seventh District has been represented by a Republican for nearly 25 years, there are more registered Democrats in its current configuration and Mr. Lerner has put $500,000 of his own money into his first race for public office. Although Mr. Franks won re-election by a healthy 59 percent of the vote two years ago, his predecessor, Matthew Rinaldo, won by 75 percent in his last race Mr. Lerner opposes cuts in Medicare spending, supports tax credits for college costs and opposes cuts in spending for environmental protection. Mr. Franks voted for the recent welfare bill and supports a balanced-budget amendment. He points to the bill signed by President Clinton to dredge the Ports of Newark and Elizabeth as one of his major accomplishments.
 
EIGHTH DISTRICT
Parts of Essex and Passaic counties.
 
INCUMBENT William J. Martini, (R), 49, a one-term Congressman from Clifton and a lawyer. Member of Government Reform and Oversight Committee and Transportation and Infrastructure Committee.
CHALLENGER William Pascrell Jr., (D), 59, Mayor of Paterson since 1990; member of state Assembly since 1988.
THE RACE One of the most hotly contested Congressional contests in the state, if not the nation. Both sides, with help from the national parties, could spend as much as $1 million. The city of Paterson is heavily Democratic, but it is surrounded by Republican-leaning suburbs and Mr. Martini won his first race by the slimmest of margins. Mr. Pascrell has not been shy about noting that Representative Martini has voted with Newt Gingrich more often than other Republican members of the New Jersey delegation, while Mr. Martini, describing Paterson as a deteriorating city, says Mayor Pascrell is at fault.
 
NINTH DISTRICT
Parts of Bergen and Hudson counties. Since 1982, Robert G. Torricelli has been Congressman.
 
DEMOCRAT Steven R. Rothman, 44, of Fair Lawn. Former Mayor of Englewood; Bergen County Surrogate Court Judge.
REPUBLICAN Kathleen A. Donovan, 44, of Lyndhurst. Former member of state Assembly; former chairwoman of Republican State Committee. Former chairwoman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, appointed by Governor Whitman. Bergen County Clerk, 1988 to 1996.
THE RACE One of the most hotly contested, races in the state. One would think that Mr. Torricelli's hold on the district, plus President Clinton lead in the polls, would make this a gimme for the Democrats. But many believe Ms. Donovan has a good chance. She touts herself as a pro-choice, pro-environment, pro-gun-control politician and has won endorsements from groups that normally support Democrats, like the Sierra Club and the National Education Association. Mr. Rothman, who has the backing of many union and consumer groups, describes himself as a fiscally conservative, socially progressive Democrat who will stand up to House Speaker Newt Gingrich.
 
10TH DISTRICT
Includes parts of Newark and Jersey City, plus suburbs in Essex and Union counties.
 
INCUMBENT Donald Payne, (D), 62, four-term member of Congress from Newark. Chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus. Former Essex County freeholder; former Newark Councilman.
CHALLENGER Vanessa Williams, (R), 35, a lawyer from Newark. Former Essex County Superior Court clerk.
THE RACE Mr. Payne is a popular incumbent in a heavily Democratic district. (In 1994, for example, he captured 76 percent of the vote.) Mr. Payne was one of the few Democrats to vote against President Clinton on the welfare bill. His opponent, Ms. Williams, is a political novice and member of a group called Concerned Black Republicans. She supports school choice, a balanced-budget amendment and welfare reform.
 
11TH DISTRICT
Covering all of Morris County and bits of Essex, Passaic, Somerset and Sussex.
 
INCUMBENT Rodney Frelinghuysen, (R), 50, first-term Congressman from Harding Township. Former Morris County freeholder and member of the state Assembly.
CHALLENGER Chris Evangel, (D), 39, a vice president of Moody's Investors Service, who lives in Morris Township. Former member of Jersey City School Board and Jersey City Finance Committee; delegate, 1988 Democratic National Convention
THE RACE Mr. Frelinghuysen, a member of one of New Jersey's most distinguished political families, would seem to have this one clinched: he is well known and won in 1994 with 71 percent of the vote. But Mr. Evangel has been buoyed by the endorsement of The Star-Ledger and is hoping for help from the coattails of President Clinton. Mr. Evangel has tried to link Mr. Frelinghuysen with (surprise, surprise) Speaker Newt Gingrich and accused Mr. Frelinghuysen of not doing enough to stop corporate downsizing in the district. Mr. Frelinghuysen, for his part, is counting on his reputation as a fiscal conservative and social moderate, his long-standing service in the district, plus a bevy of endorsements and from business, police and mental health groups.
 
12TH DISTRICT
All of Hunterdon County and parts of Monmouth, Mercer and Middlesex. Richard A. Zimmer, who has represented the district since 1990, is running for Senate.
 
DEMOCRAT David M. Del Vecchio, 40, the Mayor of Lambertville since 1991. Senior executive for economic development in the state Treasury Department since 1991; former acting executive director of the Essex County Improvement Authority.
REPUBLICAN Mike Pappas, 35, of Rocky Hill. Somerset County Freeholder since 1984. Former Mayor of Franklin Township and former member of Franklin Township Council. Partner in family-owned insurance agency in Somerset.
THE RACE Considered close. Democrats are upbeat because they believe that Mr. Pappas, an anti-abortion conservative who opposes the ban on assault weapons, is too far to the right for the district's moderate Republicans. Mr. Del Vecchio has been promoting himself as a centrist who would cut the capital gains tax and who supports the death penalty. Mr. Pappas has billed himself as an anti-tax crusader and says more responsibility should be shifted to states and towns. One problem for both candidates is that they are relatively unknown.
 
13TH DISTRICT
Includes a chunk of Hudson County with slivers of Essex, Middlesex and Union.
 
INCUMBENT Robert Menendez, (D), 42, two-term Congressman from Union City. Former Mayor of Union City; former member of state Assembly and Senate.
CHALLENGER Carlos Munoz. (R), 50, a West New York resident who works at the Hudson County welfare office. Has run unsuccessfully for state offices for almost 15 years.
THE RACE Mr. Menendez captured 71 percent of the vote in 1994, and Mr. Munoz has no money and no support from the party. Still, the race is drawing attention. That's because Mr. Munoz, a Cuban native who moved to the United States in 1972, may be the first Federal office seeker to campaign entirely in a foreign language. Mr. Munoz reads and write English just fine; it's just the speaking part that is tricky. So during a recent televised debate, Mr. Munoz (actually, Dr. Munoz, because he was a veterinarian in Cuba) sparred in Spanish with Mr. Menendez, who, though fluent in Spanish himself as New Jersey's first Hispanic House member, replied in English.
