SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1286 words

HEADLINE: EARINING IT;
Redress For Broken Nest Eggs

BYLINE: By MARGARET CRANE 

 BODY:
WHEN a worker loses money in a 401(k) or similar retirement plan, is the company or the worker responsible? Generally, the worker is, because he chose where to put his money.
But the issue is being clouded by lawsuits brought by workers at the Unisys Corporation and Color Tile Inc. Last month the Supreme Court sent the Unisys case back to a lower court, which will determine whether the employees or the employer are on the hook for losses suffered by the plan. At issue in this case, and in a similar Federal suit filed in Texas by a Color Tile worker, is whether the investments were prudent choices by the companies. Companies have usually considered themselves exempt from liability as long as they give workers a large menu of investment options. Now they are waiting to find out if that is enough. 
 If the courts find in favor of the employees, workers nationwide might gain new recourse when something goes wrong. Such rulings might encourage companies to offer more investment choices and to disclose more information about those investments.
But at least one benefits expert warns of a possible corporate backlash.
"If employers become so nervous about potential liability, they may become too conservative in making investments or afraid to have defined-contribution plans" like 401(k)'s, said Ian D. Lanoff, a lawyer and former administrator of the Labor Department. "Or they could provide too much information and give employees what look like proxy statements."
The Supreme Court let stand a ruling by the Federal appeals court in Philadelphia that ordered a trial concerning losses in a 401(k) plan at Unisys, the information services company in Blue Bell, Pa. Among the several investment choices in the plan were guaranteed investment contracts issued by the Executive Life Insurance Company of California. The contracts are similar to certificates of deposit, paying an interest rate on the principal invested.
But Executive Life failed in 1991. Though some employees, including Michael Blumenthal, then the chairman of Unisys, transferred their investments out of Executive Life in time, the bankruptcy filing froze about $176 million of the original $213 million invested by Unisys employees.
Under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, the Federal law known as Erisa that regulates pensions and 401(k)-type retirement plans, companies are given broad protection from employee suits about investment returns if the investment choices in the plans are diversified. Because the decision of which investment to select is left with employees, companies have not been held responsible for losses.
But the options must be prudent, and in the Unisys case, the Federal appeals court in Philadelphia found earlier this year that if a company is not, then employees could not be held responsible for losses. Unisys must now prove at trial that its investment options were prudent as well as that it kept employees adequately informed about the investments.
"Companies cannot get away with simply throwing fund choices at employees. There has to be some investigation behind whether an investment is viable," said Shaun O'Brien, a staff lawyer at the Pension Rights Center, a worker-advocacy group in Washington. "One of the issues in the Unisys case is whether, in selecting the GIC's to begin with, the employees should have been informed of the precarious status of Executive Life. There's a certain level of responsibility in picking the funds."
Employees at the Allied Construction Equipment Company in St. Louis last month settled a 1992 suit involving Executive Life contracts of their own, which had made up the majority of their company profit-sharing plan. Thomas E. Held, the president of Allied, contends that the Boatmen's Trust Company, which managed the plan, never told him and his 18 employees of the Executive Life investment. When Executive Life went bust, Allied employees lost about $300,000, almost all the money in their plan.
"We gave Boatmen's the nod to invest," Mr. Held said. "But how could the largest trust company in Missouri take a small company's profit-sharing plan, put it in a single guaranteed investment contract from Executive Life, a company that was heavily invested in junk bonds, and wipe out the savings of people who had worked for Allied for years?"
Boatmen's refused to comment, but in court filings, the company asserted that its Executive Life investment was diversified because the assets of an insurance company are by their nature diversified.
Employees of Color Tile still don't know how much money they lost. Most of their 401(k) is invested in company stock and real estate, but the company, a retailer of home-decorating materials based in Fort Worth, declared bankruptcy in January. That froze the estimated $20 million in the plan and its exact value is unknown.
In June, a Color Tile employee filed a lawsuit in United States District Court in Dallas questioning the prudence of the investments. The suit contends that the administrators and trustee of the plan violated their fiduciary duties under Erisa by not offering a diversified plan. Jeffrey S. Osgood, a lawyer representing the defendants, said there is no validity to the suit's claim.
Under current law, a company cannot have more than 10 percent of its defined-benefit plan, like a traditional pension plan, invested in company stock, but there is no such restriction on 401(k)'s and other defined-contribution plans. So the Color Tile investment itself was not illegal. At issue, however, is whether the investment options that the company's employees were offered constituted a diversified enough portfolio and whether those options were prudent. The trial is expected in the spring.
 Legislation was introduced in Congress last year to extend the 10 percent rule to some 401(k) plans, but the bill stalled. It is expected to be debated again next year.
Dennis R. Coleman, a principal with Kwasha Lipton, an employee benefits consulting firm in Fort Lee, N.J., said that, depending on how the courts rule, the Unisys and Color Tile cases could find that fund administrators are liable for investment performance and require them to keep employees better informed about their investments.
"These cases deal with imprudence and misrepresentation where plan participants were left holding the bag," he said.
Mr. Lanoff, a lawyer with Groom & Nordberg and former administrator of the Labor Department's Erisa program, said he hopes such cases will result in a reasonable balance between providing ample disclosure and clarifying the Erisa provisions.
"This case points out the yin and yang of Erisa," he said. "It was passed to provide protections to employees to prevent certain pension-fund abuses and to provide protections to employers to make them more comfortable in offering pension plans by making them less burdensome."
J. Peter Hynes, a spokesman for Unisys, said the company's 401(k) plan was diversified with six investment options. He also said that at the time, Executive Life had received top credit ratings from Standard & Poor's. "We feel our company did its due diligence," he said.
When those credit ratings changed, Mr. Hynes said employees were notified and, within six months, withdrew about $70 million from the contracts. "The company continues to try to recover pension funds from Executive Life's bankrupt estate," he said.
Mr. Held of Allied would not say how much money his company will recover from Boatmen's, but said that the dispute taught him to pay better attention to his pension. "In the future," he said, "I'll get more information about where my money is going before I'll take anyone's word for it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas E. Held, center, president of Allied Construction Equipment, with John E. Gammon, chief executive, and Stanley W. Novak, treasurer. Employees sued after an insurer that handled most of their profit-sharing plan went bankrupt. (L. G. Patterson for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1368 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Search for Scholarships Can Be a Bitter Lesson

BYLINE: By MARTHA NOLAN McKENZIE 

 BODY:
JESSE SALDANA 3d's dreams of an athletic scholarship to the University of Texas at El Paso crumbled along with his knee during a high school football game in his senior year. Without the money, his parents doubted that they could afford to send him to the school. But then he was reached by a company that guaranteed to find him a scholarship or grant.
All his family had to do was pay a $179 fee. 
 What the Saldanas said they received, after months of waiting, was a list of about 40 sources, consisting mostly of contests, loan programs and scholarships for which the deadline had already passed.
"They didn't give me a name that was worth sitting down and writing a letter to," said Jesse Saldana Jr. of San Antonio, the father of Jesse, who eventually received some local scholarship money and is now a freshman at the university.
The company the Saldanas dealt with, College Assistance Services in Sunrise, Fla., is one of four concerns and two individuals that the Federal Trade Commission filed charges against in several Federal District courts in September, accusing them of defrauding families out of a total of about $10 million. The agency added two more companies to the lawsuits at the end of October. The agency has obtained court orders freezing the assets of all the companies and their owners and forbidding them to use deceptive schemes. The F.T.C. also is seeking permanent injunctions against the companies and restitution for consumers. The agency said two of the companies have responded to the complaint and both have denied wrongdoing.
"It's a fraud of the 90's, and it's growing," said Heather Hippsley, an F.T.C. senior staff lawyer who is working on the cases. "When inflation was high, we saw investment scams with rare coins. With escalating college costs, it's a perfect environment for scholarship scams."
Tuition at public colleges more than tripled since 1980, while household income increased only about 90 percent, the General Accounting Office says. Today, four years at a public university, including tuition, fees and room and board, costs an average of $28,000, versus about $73,000 at a private school, says the College Board, the research group that administers scholastic tests.
That is causing more families to seek aid. Each year a little more than half of all college students get financial aid, according to Jack Joyce, associate director of information and training services at the College Board. But more and more of that aid is in the form of loans and work-study programs. In the last school year, scholarships and grants accounted for 48 percent of the total $50 billion in student aid, down from 42 percent in the 1986-87 school year. And Mr. Joyce said he expected the scholarship portion of the pie to keep shrinking.
According to Mark Kantrowitz, who runs a home page sponsored by the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators on the World Wide Web, an estimated 300,000 people were victimized last year by scholarship search companies.
"I suppose I really wanted to believe help was available," said Helen Ward of Culpeper, Va., who thought the $199 she paid Career Assistance Planning in Atlanta guaranteed a scholarship for her son, Michael Dennis, a sophomore at James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Va. She said it took six months of haggling to get her money back.
The F.T.C. contended in August that the defendants falsely guaranteed scholarships or grants of at least $1,000 for their customers and did not honor offers of refunds. The defendants are College Assistance Services, Career Assistance Planning, Student Assistance Services in Plantation, Fla., Student Aid Inc. in New York, Deco Consulting Services, Unimark Industries, both of Lauderhill, Fla., and two individuals, Christopher Nwaigwe and Udoka Maduka of Washington. College Assistance Planning and Student Aid were also charged with unauthorized credit card and bank account debiting.
"We will show there was no intention to deceive," James Lewis, the lawyer for Student Assistance Services, said. "People paid for what they got, and that was leads on scholarships. As far as we can tell, everyone who complained got their money back."
Alan Jay Braverman, a lawyer for College Assistance Services, said: "I'm not telling you there is not abuse going on -- there is abuse. But my clients did not abuse the system at all. They were trying to run a legitimate business."
Lawyers representing the other defendants declined to comment.
Jodie Bernstein, director of the F.T.C.'s Bureau of Consumer Protection, said that people should be alert for the following claims made by some search companies:
* "We have access to information not available to the general public." But often, the same information can be obtained through libraries and the Internet.
* "We will do the work for you." But often, applicants must fill out their own scholarship and financial aid forms.
* "We can tap into some of the billions of dollars in scholarship money that goes unclaimed each year." But only 3.5 percent of scholarships are unclaimed, totaling in the low millions of dollars, according to Daniel J. Cassidy, president of the National Scholarship Research Service in Santa Rosa, Calif., and author of "The Scholarship Book" (Prentice Hall, 1996, $21.95).
* "We guarantee you a scholarship or your money back." No one can guarantee a scholarship.
"A guarantee is the best tip-off of all," Ms. Bernstein said.
Legitimate scholarship search companies fear that consumers will find them guilty by association because of the F.T.C. action.
"We're all going to take a hit on this," Mr. Cassidy said. "I've already had a customer call me wanting her money back because she read that we were all scams."
Some educators, however, question the usefulness of even the good firms, which typically charge $50 to $200 for lists of scholarships and financial aid providers.
Wayne Huey, director of counseling for Lakeside High School in Atlanta, said, "I think a student using computer data bases, the Internet, reference books in libraries and information from college financial aid offices and high school guidance counselors can find the exact same information at no charge."
 
Information Aids For Financial Aid
 
Here are a few of the many sources of information for obtaining scholarships and other financial aid:

ON LINE
* The Financial Aid Information Page, which is on the World Wide Web (http:// www.finaid.org) is sponsored by the National Association of Financial Aid Administrators. It contains information on scholarships and grants, as well as warnings about fraudulent search firms. The association has another site (http://www.nasfaa.org) that offers consumer scholarship tips.
* The College Board Web site (http:// www.collegeboard.org) contains a database of scholarship sources called Expan Scholarship Search. A similar database is available in many libraries and guidance counselors' offices through a software program called Fund Finder, also from the College Board.
* The Student Loan Marketing Association home page (http://www.salliemae.com) offers information on scholarships, grants and student loans.
* S.R.N. Express (http://www.rams.com/ srn/search.htm) is a free Web version of the data base of the Scholarship Resource Network, a search firm. It focuses on private-sector aid, like academic scholarships.

BOOKS
* "College Costs and Financial Aid Handbook" (College Board, $16). This how-to book includes an outline of major aid programs, a discussion of how financial need is determined and a look at college costs.
* "The Scholarship Book," by Daniel J. Cassidy (Prentice Hall, $21.95). This is a guide to private-sector scholarships, grants and loans.
* "Need a Lift?" published by the American Legion and available by writing Emblem Sales, P.O. Box 1050, Indianapolis, Ind. 46206 ($3). It lists sources of information on careers, scholarships and loans for all students, with an emphasis on children of veterans.
* "Financial Aids for Higher Education" edited by Oreon Keeslar (Brown & Benchmark, $58). It lists more than 3,000 sources of financial aid, with details on eligibility criteria.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1215 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
A Market-Moving Guru Plans to Run Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
FOR three months, Elaine Garzarelli has predicted the United States stock market will fall by 15 to 25 percent. Now, she wants to put your money where her mouth is.
On Oct. 25, Ms. Garzarelli, a market guru with a wide following among both institutional and individual investors, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to start two new mutual funds. The strategy of the Garzarelli Balanced fund and the Garzarelli Affinity Equity fund will be based on her proprietary method of sector analysis, which relies on 14 economic and market statistics to make predictions about stock prices. 
 Rarely in the history of the fund industry has a person whose single utterance can shake the market to its foundations also headed a mutual fund. But Ms. Garzarelli is one of a few Wall Street commentators who has that kind of influence. On July 23, the Dow Jones industrial average undertook a 100-point midday reversal after she suddenly turned bearish, predicting a big market decline.
That prediction has yet to come true -- in fact, the market is some 12 percent above its level at the time of her prediction. Now, the confluence of her roles as market analyst and fund manager raise ticklish issues of potential conflicts of interest, which current and former regulators say could limit her propensity to talk about the market's direction.
This will not be Ms. Garzarelli's first foray into mutual fund management -- although potential investors in the new funds will find no mention of that in the new funds' prospectus. Were they to seek out her record, they would find it mediocre at best.
And while the funds bear her name, Ms. Garzarelli will not be choosing all of the securities in the new funds' portfolios. Instead, after she sets their asset allocations, others will pick the individual securities for each fund's portfolio.
Ms. Garzarelli's fame as a prognosticator relies chiefly on a prediction nine years ago. In the summer of 1987, while she was a quantitative analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers, she told clients that stocks were in for a steep decline.
At about the same time, Shearson started a mutual fund based on Ms. Garzarelli's skills as a sector analyst. When the market crashed in October 1987, the fund was largely in cash. Thus, while the Standard & Poor's 500 index declined by about 23 percent in the last four months of that year, the Sector Analysis fund rose 2.4 percent.
That propitious timing gained Ms. Garzarelli wide fame and a multimillion-dollar annual salary. Two years ago, she struck out on her own, starting Garzarelli Investment Management in Chicago. She recently started a joint venture with Zachs Investment Research to market her research and she began soliciting subscribers for a newsletter, in addition to managing money for wealthy individuals and institutions.
The potential success of the Garzarelli funds will rely on more than simply her asset-allocation skills. In the case of the Balanced fund, individual securities will be chosen by a committee of managers from her investment company. Stocks in the Affinity fund will be chosen by a subadviser, Gregory Lai, a former manager for Pimco Advisors who now heads Affinity Investment Advisers in Newport Beach, Calif.
Both funds will have wide investment flexibility. According to the preliminary prospectus, at least 25 percent of the Balanced fund will be invested in bonds, and at least 65 percent of the Affinity fund will be in equities or equity-related securities, under "normal market conditions."
But while the prospectus states that the funds will seek "risk levels equal to or lower than the general market," they have considerable flexibility. If Ms. Garzarelli's indicators tell her another crash is looming, "each fund may invest up to 100 percent of its assets in short-term, high-quality money market instruments," the prospectus states.
Nearly every other conceivable type of security is open to investment by both funds -- including futures contracts, options, stocks or bonds of foreign companies or governments, currency exchange contracts, even zero-coupon "strips" -- the interest portion of zero-coupon bonds and the type of derivative that wreaked havoc on many bond funds in 1994 when interest rates shot up.
Ms. Garzarelli insists, however, that the funds "are not going to take any big chances." Instead, in an interview from Milan where she was on a business trip, she vowed, "I'd be happy to beat the index by a couple of percentage points."
INVESTORS in the Shearson fund Ms. Garzarelli managed would have been happy had she attained that for them, especially in 1988. That year, the S.& P. 500 rose 16.6 percent, but the Sector Analysis fund fell 13 percent. In subsequent years the fund tracked the market more closely, but the sector fund gained just a little more than half as much as the S.& P. 500 over its seven years. When Ms. Garzarelli left the firm two years ago, the fund was merged into another run by Smith Barney, the successor firm to Shearson.
Investors who read the prospectus for the new Garzarelli funds will find no mention of the manager's previous experience managing a mutual fund. In fact, they might be led to believe that she has no such record. "Neither the Adviser not the Sub-Adviser has any prior experience managing a U.S. registered investment company," the prospectus states, referring to Garzarelli Investment Management and Affinity Investment Advisers.
That is technically true. In any case, Ms. Garzarelli said, the Shearson fund's performance was hurt by high expenses and other factors, including missing a buy signal in 1988 and being limited to buying stocks on the firm's recommended list. For the new funds, total operating expenses are estimated at 1.5 percent for the Affinity fund and 1.25 percent for the Balanced fund, about even with the average domestic stock fund.
When the funds will start accepting investors' money is unclear, although Ms. Garzarelli said her partners hoped it would be soon, in light of her prediction that the stock market will head sharply lower sometime after the election. "What they want to do," she said, "is start it now so we can get all the good performance when the market drops."
It remains to be seen if managing a mutual fund will cramp Ms. Garzarelli's style as a market prognosticator. No one at Garzarelli Investment Management will discuss the prospectus or the firm's specific plans once the funds start up, citing S.E.C. rules against comments that can be construed as marketing funds before they win approval.
Robert Plaze, deputy director of the S.E.C.'s division of investment management, declined to comment on this situation specifically. But in general, he said, "anybody managing money who has the potential to move the market has to be careful not to run afoul of the anti-fraud rules," which prohibit intentional market manipulation.
"There isn't anything that says a manager can't mouth off about what they like" in a particular stock or the market as a whole, said Kathryn McGrath, a former director of the S.E.C.'s mutual fund division who is now a lawyer at Morgan Lewis & Bockius in Washington. "But if you do it with a particular intent and effect of manipulating the market, then you're in trouble."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATBUSH;
Flatbush Ave. Renaissance Brings Hope For Kings

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
It isn't quite a complete turnaround for Flatbush, because even after the neighborhood's Golden Age was over, after the Brooklyn Dodgers left town and the Loew's Kings movie palace closed down, the avenue didn't lose all its allure. Still, by the late 70's, the commercial strip near Flatbush and Church Avenues was clearly in decay: discount shops dominated and scores of shuttered businesses became graffiti-strewn emblems of decline.
But in the last several years, there has been an economic renaissance in the neighborhood, encouraged by a drop in crime and concerted efforts by local merchants, the Flatbush Development Corporation and the city to revive Flatbush. 
 "We have practically no boarded-up businesses," said Jack Katz, executive director of the Flatbush Avenue Business Improvement District, which was founded in 1990 and represents 195 merchants between Parkside Avenue and Cortelyou Road. "We've got people shopping the avenue. It's safer. It's cleaner. We've got the whole package."
But there is a sad twist to Flatbush's economic revival. The Loew's Kings, the gigantic, ornate movie palace built in 1929 that was the magnet for development of the neighborhood in the first place, remains a dormant, deteriorating, memory-filled behemoth.
The theater, which drew masses to its vaudeville shows and feature films, was the catalyst for construction of the mansions that line the streets west of Flatbush Avenue and the businesses that turned the strip into a bustling corridor. Coinciding with a general decline of Flatbush Avenue, the Kings closed in 1978, when the city took it over for nonpayment of taxes, and has remained unused since.
"It's such a magical place," said Bruce Paul Friedman, who grew up in Flatbush and started the organization Save the Kings 10 years ago. "The Kings started Flatbush and it deserves a second chance."
After an unsuccessful attempt to find a developer for the Kings in 1990, the city's Economic Development Corporation, hoping to take advantage of the current commercial upswing in Flatbush, is expected to solicit developers again within the next month.
The bustle of development proceeds around the theater, which is in the heart of the neighborhood on Flatbush near Tilden Avenue. There are signs of growth everywhere, from the construction of a Rite-Aid drugstore on Flatbush and Church to the fresh sand laid down last month for what is soon to be a new municipal parking lot on Tilden Avenue. Blockbuster Video opened on Flatbush six months ago, Dr. Jay's, a sporting goods store, a few months later, and there is a Burger King on the way.
The redevelopment spurt was started two years ago when the Caldor department store replaced the Macy's store on Tilden Avenue. Along with the arrival of other new businesses, apartment buildings have been renovated, Brookdale Hospital Medical Center completed a new primary care center on Flatbush, near Cortelyou Road, in August and major renovations are under way at Erasmus Hall High School.
Also in the works is a $10 million municipal parking lot project financed by the Brooklyn Borough President's office, the city and Sears, which has an adjacent store. The lot, along with a roof garage above Caldor's, will provide 763 free parking spaces for shoppers on Flatbush Avenue, which has long been plagued by traffic jams and scarce parking.
"What happens with development is you almost have a psychic moment where everyone realizes, 'Gee, we could really do this,' " said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "I would say the Flatbush market is anything but flat." SARAH KERSHAW

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Americans Don't Like Treasury Bonds

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Over the last two years, since the last Congressional election, the Treasury bond market has done very well, with the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds falling from 8.16 percent to 6.67 percent.
And over that time period, how much money do you think American investors have put into Treasuries? 
 If you said zero, you overestimated the investment attraction of such bonds. Americans, individuals and institutions combined, have been selling Treasury securities for the last couple of years.
That's why we think the Treasury rally should be named for Blanche duBois, the Tennessee Williams character who averred she had "always depended on the kindness of strangers." For it is foreigners who have put up the cash as our Government sought to finance its budget deficits.
The buyers have been foreign governments, individuals and institutional investors. Some were seeking a good yield. (These days, the payout on a one-year Japanese Government security is almost four-tenths of one percent. At that rate, Japanese investors can double their money in just 174 years. (A similar United States Government obligation pays 5.4 percent.) But in other cases, the buyer was a government simply trying to invest dollars that had been accumulated in efforts to keep the local currency from rising against the greenback.
The result: While at the end of the Bush Administration foreigners owned less than 20 percent of all Treasury bonds not held by United States Government agencies (mainly the Federal Reserve and Social Security), now they own 30 percent.
In the past, when foreign ownership of Treasuries rose, there have been fears about what might happen when foreigners sold. In fact, there have been few periods of net liquidation by foreigners. The only full year in the last 20 when foreigners sold was 1979, when they cut back $24 billion, to $119 billion, and interest rates did rise. Now foreigners own $1 trillion in Treasuries.
That could yet be a concern in this cycle. But it may be that the more interesting fact of the Treasury market is just how uninterested Americans seem to be. From the end of 1994 through last August -- the latest figures available -- Americans cut their investment in Treasury securities by more than $100 billion. During the same period, mutual fund investors alone put more than twice that into United States stock funds -- and also put $15 billion into junk bond funds.
Jim Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, argues that investor aversion to Treasuries reflects a lack of fear. If you don't fear a bear market in stocks, there is no reason to guard against it. If you don't fear a recession or the possibility of defaults, there is no reason to buy Treasuries instead of more risky bonds.
So money that might have gone into Treasuries has gone into riskier assets instead. The interest-rate spreads -- that is, the risk premiums -- for buying corporates rather than Treasuries, or junk bonds rather than investment-grade ones -- are very low. And the smallest rally in Treasuries has been in the safest ones of all, Treasury bills. Over the last two years, as the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds fell by about one and one-half percentage points, the yield on three-month Treasury bills fell by about a quarter of a percent.
The investment attribute least valued today by investors -- and therefore the cheapest to buy -- is safety. Those foreigners who bought Treasuries may be on to something.

HEADLINE: Where the Choice (Yes, a Choice) Lies on Tuesday

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AFTER 10 months of campaigning, after the expenditure of hundreds of millions of dollars, after innumerable witless speeches and enough wretched television commercials to last a lifetime or two, the voters of America are underwhelmed, or so they tell the pollsters. Many of them say it doesn't really matter who is elected President this week.
They are wrong. 
 It may be, as the columnist George Will has suggested, that too much emphasis is placed on the President and his power to shape the nation's destiny. It may be that "such talk encourages what needs to be constantly discouraged -- the hubris of government and its delusions of mastery." And it may be, as many maintain, that Presidential elections are no more than lotteries, because campaign promises are written in sand.
Still, choosing Roosevelt over Hoover changed the whole balance between government and business, and choosing Nixon over McGovern prolonged the national agony in Vietnam, among other things. Practically (although not constitutionally) speaking, Presidents can take the country into war. They can shift dollars from guns to schools. They can lift the nation up or let it down.
This year as in so many others, the candidates have told us that this is one of the most important elections in history. Vote for my opponent, says Bob Dole, and the nation's morality will be sorely endangered. Vote for my opponent, says Bill Clinton, and you will fall off the bridge to the 21st century.
That is so much autumn hyperbole. The country faces no war-or-peace decisions, and no domestic crisis like the Depression is at hand. Moreover, the two major-party candidates are both internationalists, broadly speaking, and both free traders; both believe, to varying degrees, in government's duty to care for the powerless; both have said that the problem of keeping Medicare and Social Security from going broke will probably have to be handed over to a nonpartisan commission.
 
 
 
The Differences
 But President Dole, particularly if supported by a Republican Congress, would scale back affirmative action, probably seeking some national version of California Proposition 209 to prohibit racial and gender preferences in public hiring, contracting and education. He would move no further in reforming health care. He would trim immigration and push to make English the nation's official language. He promises to work for Constitutional amendments mandating a balanced budget and establishing term limits for members of Congress. He vows to cut Federal spending for a range of social programs and increase it for the military.
Unless the Democrats win control of both houses of Congress, which would constitute a considerable surprise, a second-term President Clinton would be constrained in his actions. He might or might not try to extend health insurance, perhaps to cover all the nation's children. He would resist any erosion of abortion rights, such as a ban on late-term procedures. He would cut taxes much less than Mr. Dole and would probably avoid any major overhaul of the tax code.
Mr. Dole has made a major campaign issue out of campaign finance, particularly contributions by foreigners. Mr. Clinton has promised reform. But neither man has committed himself to anything as far-reaching as the bill proposed by Senators John McCain, an Arizona Republican, and Russ Feingold, a Wisconsin Democrat, which would ban political action committees and clamp down on unregulated "soft money" gifts.
Nor, for all the talk about tax cuts and balanced budgets, is it clear how either man would get there. The two men's sharply differing philosophies are evident in the language they choose to explain it.
"I have proposed a program of tax cuts for working families," Mr. Clinton says, "that focus on education and child-rearing and are clearly within our ability to balance the budget so we can continue to keep interest rates down and the economy growing." To which Mr. Dole replies: "I have one big plan, to give you back more of your hard-earned money and more of your freedom, because you can run your own life better than any government bureaucracy ever can or ever will."
The era of big government may be over, but Mr. Clinton wants to use the tax code and Federal spending in one way (call it the way of the semi-reformed liberal), Mr. Dole in quite another (the way of the sometime supply-sider).
It is not easy to judge how the two men might react to trouble abroad. But Mr. Dole has said he would accelerate NATO's expansion. He would probably take a harder line if a post-Yeltsin crisis developed in Russia. And he might be less willing to extend the stay of American troops in Bosnia for a year, a prospect that seems certain in a second Clinton Administration.
Finally, there is the matter of Supreme Court justices. On issues from abortion to term limits to affirmative action, the men and women chosen to replace the jurists who are approaching retirement will exert a powerful influence, and clearly Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton would seek very different sorts of nominees. But history has frustrated Presidential wishes in this area.
For every Clarence Thomas, whose ideological persuasion survives the transition to the Supreme Court, there is an Earl Warren, who surprises. So there is no guarantee that a vote for Bob Dole on Tuesday will shift the court to the right or that a vote for Bill Clinton will keep it where it is today.

LENGTH: 2606 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
When the Best Policy May Be No Policy at All

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
DASHING through the airport, you pass a Mutual of Omaha insurance kiosk. Scenes of T.W.A. Flight 800 flash before your eyes. You already have life insurance, but is it enough? Now you can get $300,000 worth of flight-accident coverage for a mere $6 a trip. You know you're being foolish -- the taxi to the airport was far more dangerous than the flight to Dallas -- but you sign up.
Well, at least you're not alone. Mutual of Omaha sells roughly 150,000 policies in airports every year, and by no means does frivolous insurance stop there. There is a policy to soothe your every worry, whether it is cancer, breaking your ankle before your trip to Asia, or huge veterinary bills if your cat needs surgery. You can insure an adoption, a wedding or child support, or you can buy a policy to make sure your car loan is paid if you die. You can even pay to ease the pain if you can't use your Broadway theater tickets. 
 But while the coverage seems cheap -- a few dollars on your life if your plane crashes, a couple of hundred dollars if you end up in the hospital with cancer -- it can add up quickly. Taken as a whole, such insurance offers consumers little value for their money.
The expenditure would almost always be better put toward making sure you have enough of the insurance you really need: auto, home, life, health and disability. "People have a limited amount of money to spend on insurance," said Glenn Daily, a consultant in Manhattan who advises consumers on life insurance matters. "They should spend it wisely."
To be sure, some of these policies may make sense. If it took you years to save for a trip to China and your favorite aunt is ailing, buying trip-cancellation insurance may be a good idea. Wedding insurance may be worthwhile if you do not want to risk tens of thousands of dollars in deposits, and pet insurance might pay if you are unable to afford four-digit veterinarian bills.
Still, insurance is worthwhile only if it offers coverage that is comprehensive and protects you against a catastrophic financial loss, said J. Robert Hunter, director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America. He advises consumers to avoid policies that offer only a sliver of the protection they need, like insurance for cancer but not for heart disease, or protection against a financially trivial loss, like a missed Broadway show.
Here is a look at nearly a dozen kinds of insurance that consumers may want to avoid.

Flight-Accident Insurance
The chances of dying in a plane crash are extraordinarily slim, but nervous travelers buy it anyway. Sales typically jump as much as 10 percent after a serious accident like the T.W.A. crash, Mutual of Omaha says. People "don't really buy it as a substitute for their life insurance policy," said Holly Richmond, a vice president for the Tele-Trip Company, which sells the insurance for Mutual of Omaha, but for "peace of mind."
Yes, your family will need money if you die -- that's what life insurance is for -- but they will not need an extra $200,000 to $500,000 just because you died in a plane crash rather than from a heart attack. You should avoid any policy that pays more if you die in some sort of gruesome accident, Mr. Daily said. Your family should be well protected no matter how you die.

Rental Car Insurance
The next time you find yourself at a car-rental counter, resist the impulse to take the loss-damage waiver unless you absolutely need it. While not technically insurance, it serves the same purpose, releasing you from liability if the rental car is wrecked or stolen. You can also buy liability insurance in case you are sued by a third party.
Chances are you already have coverage under your own auto policy, and you may automatically receive it from your credit-card company at no extra charge. The coverage from the rental-car agency is "way, way overpriced," Mr. Hunter said. A driver in New Jersey renting from Hertz would pay $15.99 a day for the waiver, or nearly $6,000 a year. The liability insurance adds $3,000 to the tab.
Why would anyone consent to what seems like highway robbery? You might if you do not have auto insurance or if your regular insurer does not cover you. For example, though regulations vary from state to state, State Farm generally does not cover a rental car if you rent it for business, rent it for three weeks or longer, or rent it overseas.
 
Cancer Insurance
If you have health and disability insurance, cancer insurance is probably superfluous. Buying it makes as much sense as buying car insurance that covers the fender but not the windshield, said Bonnie Burns, a health insurance consultant to consumer organizations.
And though a cancer policy may look like health insurance, it does not cover your actual medical bills, paying you only a fixed amount per day, warns Glenn Pomeroy, the Insurance Commissioner for North Dakota. People without other insurance could easily end up staring at huge unpaid bills.
Although insurance companies say these policies pay for related costs like having someone take care of your dogs or putting your family up in a hotel near the hospital, make sure you need the extra coverage. Consumers generally pay out a lot more in premiums than they receive in benefits, which concerns regulators, Mr. Pomeroy said, adding that many policies pay as little as 30 to 40 cents on the dollar. Aflac Inc., the largest supplemental insurance company, says it pays 71 cents in benefits on cancer insurance in the United States, including reserves for future losses, for every $1 of premiums.
A few states, like New Jersey and Connecticut, have outlawed cancer policies.
"For the Medicare population, these policies make no sense whatsoever," Ms. Burns said. And anyone under 65 is "getting a very inefficient benefit for an expensive premium."

Children's Insurance
While fear prompts some people to buy insurance, others are motivated by love. About 30 years ago, Gerber Products decided to sell proud parents more than just baby food -- it would also offer them life insurance for their children.
Forget it. The whole purpose of life insurance is to replace lost income, and with the possible exception of child movie stars, a child's death rarely represents an economic loss.
The pitches for such policies vary, but parents should probably ignore them all. Gerber guarantees that a child will qualify for life insurance as an adult, "regardless of poor health, hazardous job or anything else that could make another company refuse coverage." But this is an incentive that few will ever need, since 96 percent of those who seek life insurance are able to get it, according to the American Council of Life Insurance. And if your child already has a condition that would rule out being insured as an adult, you probably would not get a child's policy either.
Another pitch: that these policies build "cash value," which can be turned over to the child at age 21. But the amount is roughly equal to the premiums paid, with no return on the money. Put the cash in a savings account instead, and you would be earning interest.
Some insurers also sell another kind of policy for children, variable life, which invests some of the money as a way to save for college. But parents are usually better off putting the money in a mutual fund.
 
Consumer Credit Insurance
Another poor value: insurance on your mortgage balance, your car loan or your credit-card balance. "If you have adequate insurance to replace your income, you will be able to replace the income needs for your debts," said Raymond E. Forgue, a professor at the University of Kentucky and president of the American Council on Consumer Interests.
Even if your existing insurance does not cover your debts, the money will be taken out of your assets, so your family is not necessarily on the hook. Only a family member who has co-signed a loan will inherit your debt. You may need more insurance, whether it is to pay off large debts or estate taxes, if your estate consists of a closely held family business or some other illiquid asset, said Frederick Raffety, a financial planner in Rockford, Ill.
Still, if you do want extra coverage, you should probably buy more life or disability insurance. Consumer-credit insurance "is not the cheapest way," said Donna Lee H. Williams, the Delaware Insurance Commissioner. Consumers receive slightly less than 50 cents in benefits for every $1 of premiums they pay for credit life and disability, according to Gary Fagg, an industry consultant.
 
Adoption Insurance
Adoption insurance, introduced by Fireman's Fund Insurance two years ago to protect someone who is adopting if the birth mother changes her mind, might occasionally make sense, but only if you could not afford to try to adopt again.
Be aware, though, that not all of your bills will be covered. While the policy reimburses you for what you paid in living and medical expenses for the birth mother, only 10 percent of the benefit can go to legal fees. And in a handful of states, including New York, you may not be reimbursed for all of your legal fees, if any.
When you add it all up, you may not be risking that much. The birth mother's medical expenses may already be covered by her own insurance, or the adoptive parents may be obliged to pay them only after the adoption is final. Depending on where the birth mother lives, living expenses may also be modest. The insurance "only makes sense when you have a significant amount at risk," said Michael Goldstein, a lawyer in Rye Brook, N.Y., who said the vast majority of his adopting clients were not risking more than $3,000. Since you have to buy at least $5,000 in coverage, and it costs $750, you would end up paying a quarter of your costs in insurance in that case.
 
Child Support Insurance
Covering child support payments if the supporting spouse is thrown out of work, this insurance is also pricey and provides limited coverage. One policy, offered by Cigna Property and Casualty, pays if the supporting spouse is laid off, but not if he or she gets sick or quits a job. And anyone under 25 or over 55 is not eligible to sign up.
What's more, the coverage is good for only four months. That's too short a period to be useful, Jane King, a financial planner in Wellesley, Mass., asserts. If you do not have enough in savings to get you through, she recommends taking out a home-equity loan before the layoff occurs.
The premiums also add up. After three years, you could end up paying in premiums more than 40 percent of your potential benefits -- "awfully expensive unless you're awfully sure you're going to lose your job," Mr. Raffety, the financial planner, said.
 
Wedding Insurance
Since weddings can run into tens of thousands of dollars, Fireman's Fund Insurance offers $2,000 to $20,000 (and sometimes more) in coverage for nonrefundable deposits if the ceremony is postponed or canceled because of the death of a cousin or the arrest of the groom. But if you are not spending a small fortune on the wedding, you may want to say, "I don't."
The likelihood that your plans will change is low. Because a typical wedding is meticulously arranged months in advance, Marcy Blum, a wedding planner in New York, said, "postponements are extremely unusual." And if the lovebirds get cold feet as the big day nears, the policy will not pay.
Even if you do postpone your marriage, you can sometimes get a deposit back if the room can be rebooked and the band can find another gig.
Some of the additional coverage available may also be redundant: the wedding hall or your personal homeowners' insurance might provide personal liability, for example, if your guests trash the banquet hall during the reception.
 
Trip Insurance
Travel-cancellation insurance is worthwhile only if you are planning an expensive trip and you cannot get most of your money back if your plans fall through. Still, there are many travel agents like Richard Nigosian, president of Bond Street Financial in Manhattan, who "strongly recommends" that his clients consider it.
Travelers should also think twice before signing up for the other coverage included in trip-insurance packages. A policy that covers emergency medical evacuations is hardly essential if you are spending two weeks in Atlanta, but if you have Medicare and are traveling overseas, you may need additional medical coverage.
If the main reason you are buying trip-cancellation insurance is that you are worried that your asthma could flare up and prevent you from traveling, the policy needs to cover pre-existing conditions. Many policies do, provided that you sign up within a day or two of booking reservations. And as with wedding insurance, you can forget about getting your money back if you simply change your mind.
 
Pet Insurance
For those worried about mammoth veterinary bills, there is pet insurance. The American Humane Association, the country's oldest animal-protection society, endorses the idea for anyone who is either unwilling or unable to afford care for their pets. "If you have a pet you love, why put it to sleep if you can cure it?" asked Jack L. Stephens, who founded Veterinary Pet Insurance, the Anaheim, Calif., outfit that covers furry friends.
But remember that treatment for most routine ailments is rarely a significant blow to the family finances. While care can run into the thousands of dollars, the average claim paid by Mr. Stephens's company is only $220. Unless you are on a limited budget, it makes more sense to bank those premiums -- $100 or so a year -- and save for any unexpected bills.
What's more, like most other insurance, the pet policies exclude pre-existing conditions. For instance, if your cat has been diagnosed with feline leukemia, it will not be covered until it is considered disease-free for six months.

Broadway Ticket Insurance
Does a missed evening on Broadway constitute a financial catastrophe? Hardly. But that doesn't mean you can't buy insurance to protect you. For $5 a ticket, Theatre Direct Inc., a New York ticket agency, will give you a refund if you can't make it to the show after buying tickets. The catch is that you have to cancel in writing and return the tickets two business days before the show -- no protection against a sudden case of flu or gridlock on the Long Island Expressway.
And a family of four would be out only $320 if, say, they were forced to miss "Cats" -- unfortunate, maybe, but hardly enough to plunge anyone into bankrutpcy. The risk of missing the musical also seems small: only 5 percent of those who have purchased the insurance have returned their tickets since the coverage was first offered earlier this year, said Bruce Amick, the agency's director of operations.
If you really hate the idea of being out all that money, resell the tickets yourself, which is what Theatre Direct does. While Mr. Amick notes that finding someone to buy your "Cats" tickets will be harder than selling orchestra seats for "Rent," it is certainly not impossible. Otherwise, chalk it up to bad luck.
So remember: a little insurance here, a little insurance there, and pretty soon you're out a tidy sum. Take a couple about to be married: they could spend about $200 for wedding insurance, $12 for flight insurance, $165 or so for trip-cancellation insurance, $100 in liability insurance for their rental car, $10 for Broadway ticket insurance, and who knows what else -- a total of about $500. If they are anxious enough to buy all that coverage, they might want to splurge instead on a few sessions with a good therapist.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
How Will Wall St. Vote on the Vote?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
LESS than two weeks ago, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell back below 6,000, there was plenty of talk that the threat of a Democratic takeover of the Republican-controlled Congress -- President Clinton's re-election being taken for granted -- was already sending tremors through the stock market.
But by the end of last week, all that conventional wisdom seemed to be forgotten. Even before the October employment data were released on Friday, the latest economic data -- especially the very moderate third-quarter increase in wages and benefits -- helped push the Dow back over 6,000. More important, the yield on the 30-year bond plunged to 6.64 percent, its lowest since April. 
 So is the election not worrying the market? No. But it is a lot easier for investors to dismiss such political concerns if the more important, fundamental economic forces that move markets over the long term are going in the right direction. That is, until the election results are in. Then, the market will react.
But don't look for a Wall Street consensus: the opinions on what happens after Election Day are sharply divided. In other words, the tips on how to play the election results have their risks.
David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, predicts a Dow decline to 5,800 -- a 3.7 percent drop -- if the Democrats sweep Congress. "It would be hard to make a new high before the end of the year while we waited to see what they would do," he said.
Joseph V. Battipaglia, the chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company, disagrees.
Unless the Democrats unexpectedly win an overwhelming victory in Congress, "there will not be any substantive change in policy," Mr. Battipaglia said. Democrats "are being more conservative and not upsetting the apple cart," he added, which should keep in check the more liberal Democrats who are in line to head some key committees.
He acknowledges that the shock of such a change would send bonds and stocks immediately lower. But a recovery would follow. He said investors would see continued good news on inflation, hear the new Democratic leaders talking centrist themes and see a moderate Cabinet from President Clinton. "Then the market becomes accustomed to that," he said. "It sees that there will not be big changes and gets back to the economic fundamentals."
A Democratic sweep, of course, is only one of several election scenarios -- and not the most probable. The most likely outcome is that the Washington status quo will prevail. If not that, the Republicans may well keep control of either the House or the Senate, probably the Senate.
And then there is always the possibility, though it may seem remote based on current polls, that Bob Dole will pull off an upset.
And where does Wall Street stand? "The market wants a status quo election," Mr. Shulman said. "They view this as the best of all possible worlds."
If the status quo persists -- and that's the expectation among those taking bets in the University of Iowa political futures market -- then it is likely that the economic fundamentals, which ruled last week, will continue to do so. Steady or declining interest rates, a moderate pace of roughly 2.5 percent economic growth and continued low inflation all could help push stock prices higher.
But two other status-quo scenarios could be more troubling.
One is that Mr. Dole may be right in prophesying that the slowdown of the economy in the third quarter is not foreshadowing a soft landing and subsequent rebound but a recession just around the corner. Economic downturns don't help stocks.
The other is the revenge of the Republicans. If they maintain control of Congress, they surely will step up the investigations of the President, throwing in the latest disclosures about campaign contributions from foreigners for good measure. The Justice Department has already taken the first step in deciding whether to ask for the appointment of a special prosecutor, who would be the fifth special prosecutor looking into accusations of wrongdoing on the part of current or former Clinton Administration officials.
How that plays out in the markets is hard to say. If the investigations intensified gridlock between the White House and Congress, little may be done to cut Federal budget deficits or retool the ailing Medicare program. If the investigations begin to look worse for the President, that could also hurt. "Typically, the market does not like weak Presidents," Mr. Shulman said.
And for those who think the past is a guide to the future, there is always the hope that history might repeat itself. The problem is in figuring out whose textbook to trust.
To begin with, in every Presidential election year since 1952, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose in the fourth quarter. With the average increase for Democratic winners at 3.9 percent, that implies the S.& P. index, which closed Friday at 703.76, could move another 1.5 percent, to 714.12.
Kenneth L. Fisher, the chief executive officer of Fisher Investments Inc. in Woodside, Calif., takes a longer view. In nearly every Presidential election since 1928, he found, the S.& P. 500 fell in the first or second year of the new term.
But like most election tips -- beyond remembering to vote -- there is a catch.
There have been three exceptions, starting with Truman. While the S.& P. 500 fell in the fourth quarter after Truman's stunning victory, it climbed in 1949, 1950 and then in 1951 and 1952. Then came Ronald Reagan's second term, which also turned into four up years for the S.& P.
The third? President Clinton, who is gunning for his own four-year run.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Quaker Waking Up to a Snapple Hangover

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
QUAKER OATS may be gearing up to report its biggest loss ever.
The loss, stock analysts and institutional investors say, would be a bookkeeping write-off of $1 billion or more in the current quarter to put a realistic value on the Snapple beverage business that Quaker bought for $1.7 billion in 1994. 
 Such a move would plunge reported earnings for the year deeply into the red. The consensus estimate of 19 stock analysts who follow Quaker is $1.28 a share in profits this year, according to Zacks Investment Research. A $1 billion write-off would amount to well over $7 a share.
Considering the close attention investors have been paying to Snapple's disastrous performance, though, stock analysts see no reason for such a write-off to make a big dent in Quaker's stock, which ended Friday's trading at $35.25 a share.
Facing facts in an accounting sense might be extremely embarrassing for William D. Smithburg, Quaker's embattled chairman, but the write-down would have no impact on cash earnings, on the prospects for reviving Snapple or on Quaker's other businesses. Nor would it address what's really on Wall Street's mind: How soon will Mr. Smithburg do something to live up to his promise to lift Quaker's market value?
Mr. Smithburg has no easy choices. Michael Mauboussin of CS First Boston is the only stock analyst confident enough of swift progress to recommend Quaker shares. He expects some strategic move that will push the stock price up to the low 40's in the next three to six months.
Greg Jackson, an analyst at Yachtman Asset Management in Chicago, a large Quaker shareholder, said, "The truly economical thing would be to sell Snapple and use the loss to offset capital gains on pet foods," referring to the company's 1995 sale of its pet foods business to Heinz in the United States for $725 million and to Dalgety P.L.C. in Europe for $700 million.
Mr. Jackson concedes that it may be hard to get a good price, say $700 million or more, for Snapple. Any purchaser would be hobbled by many of the problems weighing down Quaker, including distribution contracts that prevent Snapple from retreating to the East and West Coasts where its products are most popular.
The global solution would be to sell all of Quaker. The company has long been considered a takeover candidate because it is the smallest major food conglomerate. No rival is interested in all of its businesses, but analysts point out that Philip Morris, for example, might snap up Quaker's food businesses to merge with its Kraft subsidiary if it could line up a quick buyer for the beverages. Analysts estimate the breakup value of Quaker at $45 to $50 a share.
The simplest move might be to sell or spin off Gatorade, which analysts say is worth more than $2 billion. But a sale would saddle the company with a big taxable gain. Moreover, the companies that might be most attracted to Gatorade, Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola, might face antitrust problems if they bought it.
Some analysts say the best course would be to package Snapple with Gatorade, taking Quaker out of beverages altogether. But such an alignment could hurt shareholders by discouraging a buyer from paying top dollar for Gatorade.
There's one good reason why Quaker is cautious about moving hastily. Snapple may be much easier to sell or spin off, with or without Gatorade, if its new management team, led by Michael Schott, can make it even marginally profitable next year. Snapple lost $55 million last year. It is expected to trim that loss this year, but remain deeply in the red. The first returns on whether Mr. Schott has found a path to profitability won't be in until late spring.
The uncertainty is hard for Wall Street to swallow. "It would be close to a buy at its current level if they just had a clear plan for getting rid of Snapple," said Steven Galbraith, who follows the company for Sanford C. Bernstein. He raised Quaker from a sell recommendation to a hold when the stock hit $31 in July.
Quaker said it would not comment on when or whether it would take a write-off on Snapple before it had completed its long-range plans.
Wall Street is not always rational when it comes to writing off good will, the excess amount that an acquiring company pays over the tangible value of the acquired company's buildings, inventory and other physical assets. When Sony took a $2.7 billion write-down on its investment in two Hollywood film studios, Columbia and Tri-Star, its shares plunged 5.6 percent that day. When the Allegiance Corporation, a medical products spinoff of Baxter International, said on Friday that it would take a $550 million charge for good will, its stock rose 6 percent, to $19.875.
Some analysts say a slight stock bounce would be the most logical outcome of a Quaker write-down, since the company would no longer be amortizing the good will over 40 years, an accounting process that reduces earnings by about 12 cents a share each quarter. Without the good will, Quaker's reported earnings per share would rise, and that might encourage buying by technical traders, who follow numbers without looking at what's behind them.
But impatient investors could penalize the company for failing to take more drastic steps. On Oct. 24, Quaker's shares fell $1.75, to $34.625, in heavy trading when the company announced third-quarter earnings that exceeded Wall Street's expectations. A stellar performance by Gatorade and the cereal business was not enough to offset disappointment that Mr. Smithburg did not announce plans to dispose of Snapple.
"He's bought about as much time as he can," said John McMillin, who follows food companies for Prudential Securities.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATBUSH -- CINEMA;
The Kings of Flatbush

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
As the neighborhood around the Loew's Kings undergoes a development renaissance, the city is attempting to sell the theater. The city's Economic Development Corp. is expected to invite developers to make new proposals for the property within the next month or so. SARAH KERSHAW
 
Structure -- Once known as the "crown jewel of Brooklyn," the 78,200-square-foot theater, with 3,692 seats, is the third largest performing space in the city. Its decor is an unusual hodgepodge of Art Deco, Baroque and Renaissance, and its enormous lobby, where theatergoers would play canasta and mah-jongg while they waited for performances to begin, features giant walnut columns, sweeping staircases, gilded ceilings, marble fountains and two huge Art Deco chandeliers.
 
Heyday -- On Sept. 7, 1929, the Kings, the flagship of the Loew's chain, opened its doors. The theater hosted some of the biggest performers of the day, who appeared to promote their films. Among them were Bob Hope, Milton Berle, Jimmy Durante, Eddie Cantor, Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, Cab Calloway, the Nicholas Brothers (above), Bette Davis, Joan Crawford and Marlon Brando.
 
Decline -- Despite decreasing attendance, the Kings stayed open through 1978, when the city took over the theater for nonpayment of taxes.
 
Rescue attempts -- The city solicited developers in 1990, restricting use to a theater format, but a proposal to turn it into a multiplex theater never materialized. Meanwhile, the structure fell into disrepair, and between 1987 and 1992 the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, allocated $1.5 million to renovate the roof and other structures and repair the theater's plumbing. Rough estimates put the cost of restoring the theater -- for any use -- at about $10 million.
 
Future -- Unlike the city's 1990 solicitations to develop the theater, uses of the space will not be restricted in new proposals. Although some other old movie palaces in the city are protected with landmark status, the Kings is not, which means developers could tear it down.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1236 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Voting by the Numbers
Here's the familiar image: the American voter, heading for the polls, takes a hard look at the economy and then makes a choice. Now it might be overly kind to suggest that the American voter takes a hard look at anything except whatever ball is at that moment being passed, hit or dribbled on the tube. But assume, for the moment, the validity of the vote-your-pocketbook theory. Where did things stand last week as the Government bestowed its final pre-election statistics on a data-weary public? The picture's a bit fuzzy. Unemployment held steady at a relatively low 5.2 percent, and the monthly growth in payroll jobs was a healthy 210,000. But wages, which you'd think would flourish with such numbers, showed their slowest rise in a year -- 0.6 percent in the third quarter. Consumer spending stalled in September, and the overall economy slowed to a 2.2 percent growth rate for the quarter, prompting Bob Dole to cry that the sky was surely about to fall. If he's right and the economy does sink into recession, it will -- if Bill Clinton wins -- be a cruel joke on Republicans. For Mr. Clinton won four years ago just as, unknown to voters, the economy under George Bush was stirring to life; and this time, if a recession does lurk, it would be awfully tough to persuade voters of it now. The election aside (if that's possible), what do these conflicting numbers add up to? One theory: an odd hybrid known as a "growth recession" -- growth, yes, but nothing to get excited about in the voting booth.
 
STOCK MARKET
Let the Sun Shine In
They'll try anything to keep this stock market rally going. Now everyone knows that people feel gloomier when deprived of sunshine, but last week -- just as we were sent hurtling toward a bleak December with the end of daylight saving time -- the New York Stock Exchange proposed an expansion that would create a trading floor flooded with natural light. And sunnier traders would have to mean sunnier stock prices, right? The exchange, desperately in need of more space, proposed a trading floor floating above Broad Street, with a pedestrian passage below. Above would be an eight-story, glass-enclosed atrium, allowing traders to look straight up to the sky. They may still be in the dark a lot, though, for some crazy ideas are floating around about 16-hour, or even 20-hour, trading days.
 
WATER ECONOMICS
Restoring a River
The West makes such convoluted deals with its water -- swapping it, selling it, damming it up, sending it vast distances to create incongruously lush desert lawns -- that it's a wonder the stuff doesn't all evaporate in its travels. Now the weighty economics of water has taken yet another twist. Loans through the Clean Water Act are used mainly to treat water to get it up to Federal standards. But last week a deal was reached that for the first time will use such loans to restore a river -- the Truckee River, which runs through Reno. Hundreds of Western rivers, one expert said, are "garbaged up, dammed up or dried up." But this one will be restored by buying farmers' rights to the water, bringing -- in this spot, at least -- the whole water game full circle.
 
SUPERSTORES
Nike, Nike and More Nike
What is Nike trying to be, anyway -- the Microsoft of sneakers? It already has 37 percent of the world's sports-shoe market, and it has so many athletes in its pocket that when you see one endorsing a shoe, you assume the shoe will have that ubiquitous slash. Yes, faint murmurs are heard from, say, New Balance (2 percent of the market), that it has wide shoes, American-made shoes. But Nike makes the big noise, and that noise got even louder last week when it opened Nike Town on East 57th Street in Manhattan -- 5 floors, 5,000 products, 66,520 feet of sales space, a multimedia studio showing, naturally, films about Nike, you name it. But one shopper passing by on this ritzy stretch off Fifth Avenue had simply this to say: "no class."
 
 
 
SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA
So There Are Mountains
Sorry, but it's good news/bad news time again. Southern Californians can actually see their mountains a bit more often these days (they're only about 10,000 feet high), for the air is the cleanest it's been in 40 years. When the "smog season" ended on Thursday (what a depressing season to have!), there had been just 7 severe smog alerts, down from 121 in the gasping year of 1977. Credit goes to reduced auto emissions and a reformulated gasoline in use since June. The new gas alone, the State Air Resources Board said, had the same effect as taking 3.5 million cars off the road. So that's the good news. The bad news: On 87 days this year, Southern California's air -- under Federal standards -- was still unhealthy.
 
PHILANTHROPY
A Tale of Two Numbers
It's funny how numbers, concrete as they are, tell only the tip of a story. Here are two sums in the news last week: $14.5 million and $15 million. Roughly the same, but what different facts lie behind them! The $14.5 million tells a long, rich, painful tale: it was the sum raised in Vienna at a Christie's auction of a bounty of art stolen by Nazis -- Old Master paintings, tapestries, porcelains, you name it -- with most of the proceeds going to Holocaust victims. The $15 million, in stark contrast, was what Bill Gates gave to Harvard, for computer and engineering programs. That was, though, the equivalent of an average person digging into a pocket for a few pennies. Mr. Gates is worth about 1,000 times that, though -- more than $15 billion -- and he's been criticized -- most publically by Ted Turner -- for giving away so little. But "I just started a family," he said; he'll focus on philanthropy later. For now, it'll be only pennies from Microsoft.
 
JOB SECURITY
Miserable on Broadway
The hot topic of job security popped up in an unusual place last week. It wasn't a downsizing exactly, more like a resizing. You don't normally think of actors as having I.B.M.-type lifetime careers (the old I.B.M., that is), but then you get these shows that just never end, like "Cats" or "Les Miserables," and you find actors getting mortgages instead of waiting on tables. Shows can get stale, though, and you can't let "long-run-itis" turn a musical into "Madame Tussaud's," said John Caird, co-director of "Les Miz." His solution, unheard of on Broadway: replace the cast. On March 12, for the show's 10th anniversary (it's outlived many a high-tech startup), the new cast will appear. And some new actors can get mortgages.
 
CAR LEASING
Zero, Give or Take $1,000
Some ads you can take with a grain of salt. It's "the best," they blare, but you know in your heart of hearts that hyperbole might have crept in. But "zero down" on a car lease? Sounds pretty precise, doesn't it? It turns out, though, that when Mazda says "zero down" (or, to be fair, "a penny down"), it neglected a $450 "acquisition fee" and other little matters. The total, to drive out the door, is actually more like $1,000. In response, 14 states have filed suit against Mazda, accusing it of unfair labor practices. Of course, as a Minnesota official put it, such fine-print sleight of hand "isn't limited to Mazda" -- but its ads were "especially egregious." Of course, in car-leasing roulette -- a game played by 25 percent of new-car drivers -- it's easy to be confused about just what kind of deal you're getting.
