HEADLINE: The World;
Why China Has No Ears For American Demands

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
IN the last four years, America has remained right where it began in its efforts to change China.
As a candidate in 1992, Bill Clinton set his sights on making China's rulers -- dictators, he called them -- agree to stop spreading missile and nuclear technology to unstable parts of the world. 
 As a Southern governor who had campaigned for civil rights in America, he also was appalled at the harsh treatment of China's pro-democracy dissidents.
As President, Mr. Clinton asked why China's markets were closed to American firms while the American market was saturated with Chinese goods, which seemed to be one reason China was so rapidly becoming an economic power to be reckoned with.
 
 
 
I've Been Here Before
 Now, at the end of his first term and perhaps the beginning of a second, Mr. Clinton finds himself in a familiar place, in part because China's rulers are consumed by their own internal politics and remain an inflexible lot to deal with. Mr. Clinton did not help his case last year by getting into the middle of the mainland's reunification courtship of Taiwan with a visitor's visa for Taiwan's President and the recriminations that followed.
But the larger problem has not been the momentary miscalculations; China's leaders have come to believe that intransigence is rewarded when dealing with Washington; that a well timed fit of indignation to an American Secretary of State or a noisy military exercise can change policy in the White House. What a contrast to the 1970's, when Chinese leaders courted American approval because they considered the American relationship the key to China's modernization.
Today, the same "dictators" rule, only they seem stronger because they have spent four years standing up to what they call "American power politics" and "pressure tactics" and "interference."
After flirting with a more tolerant attitude toward free speech when Beijing wanted to host the 2000 Olympics, they have imprisoned dozens of dissidents whose only crime was to raise their voices. The latest example, last week, was the 11-year sentence for Wang Dan, a leader of the Tiananmen Square demonstrations of 1989.
In 1996, as in 1992, the Chinese Politburo refuses to discuss whether it supplied the design for Pakistan's nuclear bomb, as American intelligence believes China did, and whether it will provide continuing help to Pakistan and Iran as they pursue their arms buildups.
And, after considering a new stage of bold economic reforms in 1993, the Politburo feared they would lead to worker unrest and so China's moribund state factories remain protected by a fortress of trade barriers longer than the Great Wall.
If current realities did not count in politics, it would be easy to imagine America in recent decades as one of China's greatest friends and benefactors, helping with technology and aid to lift the lumbering giant of Asia out of the misery its people have long suffered.
That was the spirit of 1979, when Deng Xiaoping toured the country, met Jimmy Carter at the White House and wore a 10-gallon hat at a Houston rodeo. Anything seemed possible then, because China seemed to be listening to what America wanted from it.
But recent history has interfered: the Tiananmen massacres in 1989, the secretive nuclear assistance to Pakistan in the 1980's and 1990's, and the continued barriers to America in most of China's market.
In such circumstances, perhaps there is another way to approach the Chinese.
In 1984, when Mikhail Gorbachev was emerging as the most promising successor to the post-Brzezhnev line of Soviet leaders, the Reagan Administration made it clear to him that deep anti-Communist sentiments in Congress, and in American society, would prevent progress on ending the cold war unless he agreed to change Soviet behavior on a broad front, including human rights, an end to military confrontations and a general raising of the Iron Curtain.
China has never been the global enemy that the Soviet Union was during the cold war, and it is not in the state of economic near-collapse that impelled Mr. Gorbachev to accept Mr. Reagan's terms.
But there are similarities in the political problem Beijing has handed American leaders.
Beijing wants to make progress on the trade and economic front. Forty percent of its exports are sold to Americans.
China needs more American capital and technology to develop its industries and power plants.
Beijing's leaders also need an end to American sanctions against high technology sales.
But Beijing's insecure leaders refuse to help any American leader make the political case for ending the lesser cold war that exists across the Pacific. China, its leaders say, will change in its own good time. Meanwhile, America should make the concessions.
Deng Xiaoping, still brooding after the Tiananmen massacres, said as much to former President Richard Nixon on a visit to China in October 1989: "The United States should take the initiative, but it's not possible for China to do so, because the U.S. is strong and China is weak, China is the victim. Don't ever expect China to beg the United States to lift the sanctions. If they lasted 100 years, the Chinese would not do that."
The men poised to succeed Mr. Deng seem even less capable of initiative. And no Gorbachev-like figure has emerged in China to find the voice with which to talk plainly to an American President. But that does not have to prevent an American leader from speaking more directly to China about the minimum standards of behavior it expects Beijing to meet
For four years, Mr. Jiang and his hard-line Prime Minister, Li Peng, have refused to move decisively to end the captivity of so many political prisoners or to disclose what Beijing's scientists helped erect in Pakistan's nuclear basement.
 
 
 
Standing Pat
 They have refused to end the simmering military confrontation that threatens Taiwan, and they have refused to demonstrate to the people of Hong Kong or Taiwan that sovereign confederation with the mainland is a safe bet for keeping their freedoms. And, grimly, China's secret policemen have turned Tibet into a windowless prison.
Like President Clinton in his first term, whoever is President next year will be far freer to take political risks over China than the Presidents who faced the Soviet Union, if only because there is no consensus on China.
But Beijing's leaders seem to be betting that they can keep getting concessions from Mr. Clinton without paying any price. By their refusal to bend, they betray their fear that what Mr. Gorbachev wrought in engaging America was an end to the system that produced him and an end to his personal power. China's leaders think they can dig in their heels, even as their soaring economy drags them toward a future where monolithic control by the Communist Party will be laughable. But resistance has become their religion.
The next President is bound to try to pull them forward again in an effort to constrain these instincts. China is too big to ignore, even if the only reward for the struggle may be a return to the place where the effort started.

HEADLINE: Snooze Alarm;
The Year of the Yawn

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio

 BODY:
NOT a vote has been counted, but one return is already in: This will almost certainly be remembered as one of the dullest Presidential campaigns in recent times.
Bob Dole sees it in the small crowds he finds in his travels. President Clinton's aides, with perfunctory apologies, are already talking about the election in the past tense, wondering only how low the turnout will be. Local newspapers in cities like this one and network newscasts reflect the nation's mood by the amount of attention they devote to the contest between the two candidates, which is very little. 
 The conventional wisdom for 1996 is set: Even with Mr. Dole's furious campaign windup and questions about Mr. Clinton's fund-raising, this was the boring election -- just as surely as the 1988 Presidential election was the one that pioneered vicious attack ads. And if history is any guide, it is only a matter of days before the backlash begins, with flags raised about the damage a low-impact election inflicts on the democratic process.
But before the recriminations begin, one question needs to be answered: Is a boring Presidential election every once in a while really such a bad thing?
On the most obvious level, the placid waters of the 1996 Presidential campaign suggest a nation at peace with its politics. Many voters may simply choose to stay home. The economy is good, the country is not at war and President Clinton has rebounded from the depths of his unpopularity just two years before. Elections can be wrenching and divisive affairs -- witness Richard M. Nixon's contest with George S. McGovern in 1972. And after a run of particularly quarrelsome contests these past few years, voters might be grateful for an intermission.
The White House certainly thinks so. George Stephanopoulos, one of Mr. Clinton's senior aides and strategists, argues that a Presidential contest that he predicts will leave "no cultural imprint" is a healthy sign of "maturity and community" in the country. From that high point, Mr. Stephanopoulos jumped to offer a more self-interested analysis of what he views as its benefits.
"When you're an incumbent, and the economy is doing well," Mr. Stephanopoulos said recently, "boring is good."
But while this campaign was dull, there is a strong argument that it should not have been. The 1996 contest had the potential to be an ideological pivot, comparable to Franklin D. Roosevelt's second Presidential victory in 1936 against Alfred M. Landon (a Kansan like Mr. Dole), a win that inspired Mr. Roosevelt to title his Presidential papers that year, "The People Approve." What the people approved in 1936 was Mr. Roosevelt's activist view of government, and it set the political tone for this country for close to 40 years. What the people might have approved this year -- had Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton been more obliging -- was either of the competing views of government presented by House Republicans in 1994 or by the more governmentally ambitious Mr. Clinton who ran in 1992.
 
'Me Too'
Why the political campaign turned out the way it did is a reflection on both the skills of Mr. Clinton and the shortcomings of Mr. Dole. From the start of this contest the White House did all it could to diminish interest in the race. Candidate Clinton in 1992 blazed out of New Hampshire brimming with fresh ideas: He would guarantee health care for all, end welfare as we know it, reform the campaign finance laws, provide college scholarships that would be paid with public service and reduce the size of government. Those ideas stirred small audiences in the grange halls of New Hampshire in January 1992, and huge audiences in college gyms at this time four years ago. For better and for worse, they set the tone for Mr. Clinton's first two years in office.
This year, a politically chastened and timorous Mr. Clinton ran on a far lighter agenda. And he proceeded to embrace Republican positions with such relentless efficiency that Mr. Dole was left taunting his opponent as the "Me Too" President. There was not much else for the Republican Presidential nominee to say.
And even if there had been much to talk about, Mr. Dole was not the man to do it. Mr. Dole's performance this year made clear that communication or vision -- "so-called vision," as Mr. Dole liked to call it -- was not his strength. He never presented a vision for the country because, it became clear, he could not. He never had to during his years as a legislative leader in Congress. And he was uncomfortable with the hard economic and social lines drawn by Speaker Newt Gingrich and Republicans in the House, when they took power in 1994.
 
Flight From the Contract
Like Mr. Clinton, Mr. Dole made his own pragmatic ideological calculation last spring that linking himself to Mr. Gingrich's policies would doom his race for the Presidency. With Election Day now upon him, more than a few members of Mr. Dole's party, and a few academics, are arguing that he might have found a way to associate himself with the more attractive elements of the Contract With America, without being scuttled by association with Mr. Gingrich. But he never tried to do that.
"From the Republican standpoint, what the Congress has done over the last year and a half -- and what they have tried to do -- could be defended a lot more strongly and intelligently than Dole has managed to do," said William G. Mayer, an assistant professor of political science at Northeastern University. Or as Mr. Stephanopoulos put it: "We had a lot of help from Dole. He never made news."
Students of American elections, the very people who tend to define the conventional wisdom every four years, are suggesting that the country will pay a price for a bland election. "It's bad because what a campaign should be is something that exposes hidden facets of these candidates -- and that gives us a better opportunity to judge them as potential Presidents," said Michael R. Beschloss, the historian. "When you've got a campaign that doesn't really do that, what it means is you're left at the end of the campaign with the same information you had at the beginning."
Doris Kearns Goodwin, the Presidential biographer, said with the campaign ending she felt a profound sense of disappointment, particularly after the hopes raised by Mr. Clinton's ambitious candidacy of 1992. "I remember feeling that I wanted my kids to live through one of those periods when people really cared about politics," Ms. Goodwin said. "I look back at the 60's -- being part of the civil rights movement and going to Mississippi. It makes you feel large.
"Human nature hasn't changed," she continued. "That capacity to get involved is still there. But campaigns now are not designed to bring that out in people."
 
Democracy in Distress
Those comments are reminiscent of the warnings echoed after most recent elections. In 1988 it was the hard edge of President George Bush's campaign against Michael S. Dukakis, which many politicians and academics said polluted political discourse. In 1992 voters were alienated by excessive attention to the mechanics of politics -- focus groups, polling, production of advertisements -- rather than a discussion of policy. In retrospect, it's unclear whether either contest caused lasting damage to the nation.
But 1996 is one case where the warnings might prove right: there really might be a price to be paid for this election, in the form of four more unsettled years in Washington and some important decisions delayed. If Mr. Dole wins, the only mandate he can claim is to push through his tax-cut plan. Mr. Clinton would take a second term with even less guidance from voters. Should Mr. Clinton decide to pursue an unpopular political initiative -- which is what many of his supporters from the left hope he will do if he wins this, his last election -- he will have to do so without citing the election returns as an endorsement of his platform or philosophy. In 1992 he was able to refer to his election when he presented his proposal for universal health care to Congress.
The elections of 1992 and 1994 hinted at what might have been. The election of 1996 had all the potential to resolve the unanswered questions of those previous contests.
Of course, voters might be getting exactly what they want. Maybe the campaign was boring because Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole both sensed that America wasn't ready to make a stark choice; remember that the campaign season's top epithet was "extreme." Resolving the conflicts of a political era is interesting, but sometimes people prefer the less stirring course of groping for a middle ground.
For better or for worse, that bridge -- to borrow perhaps the only memorable metaphor of this long campaign -- will not be crossed anytime soon.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Will Rogers;
To an Enduring Wit, Election Day Was More Fun Than Halloween

BYLINE: By ANNE CRONIN 

 BODY:
"ALL I know is just what I read in the newspapers." Will Rogers's famous setup line could also have been, "All I know is what I write in the newspapers." In 1922 the humorist, who became known as the "Cowboy Philosopher" while working in the Ziegfeld Follies, agreed to produce a weekly column for The New York Times and the McNaught Newspaper Syndicate that would echo his stage material. His first Sunday column appeared in The Times on Dec. 24. By the time of his death at 56 in a plane crash in 1935, Rogers's daily syndicated column and his special dispatches to The Times had 40 million readers -- a third of the American population.
Rogers opined on everything from bootleggers to baseball, but (like a certain latter-day rich Texan) the Oklahoman saved his best digs for politics. Rogers always claimed that this was fate, since his birthday, Nov. 4, 1879, happened to be Election Day. 
 These newspaper writings, some from The Times and some from the syndicated columns, may have originally taken aim at Warren Harding, Calvin Coolidge and Herbert Hoover, but it does seem that the fellow who "never met a man I didn't like" might have had premonitions of candidates to come. ANNE CRONIN
The reason I want to touch on the Senate today is that, as I am writing this, they are having what is called a filibuster. The name is just as silly as the thing itself. It means that a man can get up and talk for 15 or 20 hours at a time, then be relieved by another, just to keep some bill from coming to vote. . . . One Senator threatened to read the Bible into the record as part of his speech. And I guess he would have done it if somebody in the Capitol had had a Bible.
 
PUB-DATE: March 4, 1923
 
There is only one way to get even with Harding now and that is to leave him in there another term. Besides, the Democrats come nearer getting what they want when they have a Republican President than they do with one of their own. They wanted this League of Nations thing and couldn't get it with their own gang. Now it looks like the Republicans are going to give it to them under an assumed name [the World Court, which the Senate later rejected] -- of course, it may just be for spite.
Then the Democrats wanted the farm loans. Well, they got that. They didn't want the ship subsidy, so they didn't get that. So, personally, I think that it has been one of the best Democratic Administrations that the Republicans ever put on.
 
PUB-DATE: March 18, 1923
The income tax has made more liars out of the American people than golf has.
 
PUB-DATE: April 8, 1923
When I started on this job I was expected to write and tell America's secrets during the War. Well, as we had none, there was no demand from Washington to keep them. There's the one thing that no nation can ever accuse us of, and that is secret diplomacy. Our foreign dealings are an open book, generally a checkbook.
 
Oct. 21, 1923
Everything nowadays is a saying, or slogan. . . . Congress even has slogans: "Why sleep at home when you can sleep in Congress?" "Be a politician -- no training necessary." "It is easier to fool 'em in Washington than it is at home, so why not be a Senator?" "Come to Washington and vote to raise your own pay." . . .
Even political campaigns are run and won on slogans. Years ago some fellow run on "the Full Dinner Pail" and after he was elected they opened it and there was nothing in it. . . .
Some fool that didn't know American politics had J. W. Davis run on "honesty." Well, that had no more place in politics than I have in the Harvard faculty. . . .
Coolidge ran on "economy," which is always good for the boobs. It's like getting up at a dinner and saying, "I am proud to be here." It's an old gag but it always goes. Economy beat honesty by 8 million, and as soon as he got in he raised Congress' and the Senate's salary and redecorated the White House. So away goes another slogan!
 
PUB-DATE: April 11, 1925
I have a scheme for stopping war. It's this -- no nation is allowed to enter a war until they have paid for the last one.
 
Aug. 29, 1928
A lobbyist is a person that is supposed to help a politician to make up his mind, not only to help him but pay him.
 
Aug. 24, 1929
We are all in a lather over lobbying. If a man with no official connection can change a whole conference, it's not him you want to investigate; it's the "buys" that he influenced. If we have Senators and Congressmen that can't protect themselves against the evil temptations of lobbyists, we don't need to change our lobby, we need to change our representatives.
Any person that can't spot a propagandist and lobbyist a mile away must be so blind that they still think toupees are deceptive and can't tell a hotel house detective from a guest.
 
Sept. 29, 1929
This country has come to feel the same when Congress is in session as we do when the baby gets hold of a hammer. It's just a question of how much damage he can do with it before we take it away from him.
 
PUB-DATE: July 4, 1930
Come pretty near to having two holidays of equal importance in the same week, Halloween and Election, and of the two Election provides us the most fun. On Halloween they put pumpkins on their heads, and on Election they don't have to.
 
Nov. 2, 1930
Mr. Hoover, the consolation you have from the whole American people is no doubt greater than that ever shared by a losing President. There was nothing personal in the vote against you. You just happened to be associated with a political party that the people had just "lost their taste for." There is something about a Republican that you can only stand him for just so long. And on the other hand there is something about a Democrat that you can't stand him for quite that long. Nov. 9, 1932

There just seems to be something about running for President that you can never get out of a fellow's head. He never seems to figure his chances. It can be on an "off year," or "Leap Year" and just nominate him, and he is perfectly tickled to death. That he will wind up just being a defeated candidate never seems to enter his head. That "the time is not ripe for it" is as foreign to his thoughts as the moon.
 
Nov. 20, 1932
I was born on Election Day, but never was able to get elected to anything. HEADLINE: War's Plunder and the Swiss;
The New Old News of Nazi Loot

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
IT is sensational news: tales of looted gold, stolen art treasures and other wartime plunder secretly passing from the Nazis to the well-manicured hands of bankers in Switzerland.
The steady drumbeat of recent stories has fascinated readers and viewers. But a small group of historians and writers who have researched the subject say they are baffled: Why has the known suddenly become news? 
 "The basic outline of all of this has been known for many years and for people to pretend they have sensational new stuff is simply not true," said Arthur L. Smith Jr., a retired professor of history at California State University and the author of "Hitler's Gold" (Berg Publishers, 1989).
History sometimes has a curious way of lying dormant before the right spark ignites attention and touches off wide reverberations. The current firestorm over Swiss banks appears to have been stoked by the end of the cold war, the 50th anniversary of World War II and a recent convergence of political interests.
"In 1996, it seems to be ringing the right bells," said Marc Masurovsky, who has studied the "Safehaven" program, the American wartime effort to prevent the Nazis from secreting wealth to neutral countries like Switzerland. Records from that program are the source of some of the supposed new revelations, but Mr. Masurovsky said, "Anyone could have walked into the National Archives in the 1970's and seen these documents."
It has long been known that after the war, Swiss banks were left with numerous unclaimed (and still unquantified) deposits made by Jews throughout Europe who were fearful their assets would be seized by Germany. Many of those Jews later perished in the Holocaust. There has also been little doubt that Switzerland, fearful of Nazi conquest, accepted tons of gold looted from European governments by the Nazis as they marched across the continent.
But for decades the Swiss banking industry, which takes pride in its secrecy and discretion, thwarted inquiries about the fate of such lucre. And since the 1970's, recovering it had not been the top priority for many major Jewish organizations, which were occupied with more pressing matters like tracking down surviving Nazi war criminals. The collapse of Communism, however, reinvigorated Jewish efforts to reclaim lost wartime properties in Eastern Europe, and the 50th anniversary of the end of the war last year rekindled interest in the war's murkier episodes. It was only a matter of time before the focus became Switzerland.
Under pressure from the World Jewish Congress and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, the Republican chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Swiss bankers agreed this spring to let independent auditors for the first time to search their archives for any unclaimed wartime accounts.
The issue of unclaimed Jewish accounts became commingled with broader (and embarrassing) questions about Switzerland's handling of Nazi gold and about the accommodations this supposedly economically-neutral nation had made with the Third Reich. In September, the British Government issued a report saying that the Swiss could still be holding much of the Nazis' stolen gold.
As Switzerland's war past has leaped from obscure history books into the popular media, some new details have emerged, but a lot of history has been born again as news. One example: Mr. D'Amato's staff publicized "recently declassified" documents showing that the Wehrli Bank, a defunct Swiss concern, had been a clearinghouse for Nazi assets. The wartime history of that bank was well documented by Nicholas Faith, an English journalist, in his 1982 book "Safety in Numbers" (Viking).
Little-known facts often get lost in history, and sometimes it takes time, changing attitudes and the right circumstances for them to attract attention. In 1951, Seymour J. Rubin, a former American Government official, wrote in a legal journal about a 1949 pact between Switzerland and Poland under which unclaimed assets of Polish nationals in Swiss banks could be used to compensate Swiss citizens whose property had been confiscated by Poland's Communist regime. Many of those assets presumably belonged to Jews and others killed by the Nazis.
In that era of cold-war calculation, the United States may have been loath to antagonize the Swiss over the deal. But when Mr. D'Amato and Jewish groups released documents about the Polish deal at hearings in Washington last month, they created a furor. The deal even struck many Swiss as news, at least at first blush. In any case, Swiss officials promised to determine what happened to deposits affected by such agreements with Communist countries.
 
 
 
Cooperation
 Such cooperation is a sign that the postwar generation now in power in Switzerland may be ready to come to grips with the nation's past, and that may be the biggest change. Israel Singer, the secretary general of the World Jewish Congress, said, "Today, we are only dealing with responsible parties, not guilty parties."
But while new inquiries could yield genuine revelations, there may be disappointments. Mr. Faith, for one, suspects that the amounts of money left in the abandoned Jewish bank accounts are relatively small, because many Jews refused to believe the Holocaust was coming until it was too late and didn't have time to safeguard their assets. And the task of tracking down abandoned accounts 50 years later is daunting, because many were opened through middlemen and some of the banks active during the war have since collapsed or been absorbed.
Still, some progress has already been made. Even before agreeing to an outside audit, Swiss banks said they had found 774 accounts totaling about $32 million, a figure rejected by Jewish groups as absurdly low. (In the 1970's, the banks also conducted a study of unclaimed assets and said they had found $5.2 million, which they turned over to charity.)
Mr. Singer said his group and others would not be satisfied until they have a full accounting of all the property stolen from Holocaust victims.
"This is the last unfinished business of the Holocaust," he said. "It is time to draw a black line at the bottom and finalize these accounts."

HEADLINE: A Bulgarian Is Slain And Motives Are Many

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Who killed Andrei Lukanov, the longtime Bulgarian Communist leader who was close to the Russians, friendly with the Americans and respected by many Bulgarians?
"This was 100 percent a political murder; he had a lot of information on corruption," said one of his confidants, Kancho Stoychev, publisher of Now, a newsmagazine here. 
 "He was a victim of accounts that had to be settled," said Ivan Tatarchev, the prosecutor who investigated Mr. Lukanov's Communist past. "It is no secret that he was one of the millionaires of Bulgaria. How he became a millionaire when he was a civil servant others can answer."
Friends and foes talk freely about the killing of Mr. Lukanov, 58, who was gunned down at midday on Oct. 2 outside his apartment house here in the capital. He was the highest-ranking Communist leader from the 1970's and 80's still active in the murky nexus of Bulgarian politics and business.
The bottom line, many Bulgarians say, is that there were plenty of motives for some current senior Government officials to want Mr. Lukanov out of the way, and there is little confidence here that anyone will be charged.
A spokeswoman for the Interior Ministry, Rossitsa Marinova, said the assassination of Mr. Lukanov remained under investigation.
Killings are not unusual in this crime-hardened country, but Mr. Lukanov's slaying was different. It was the first killing of a major political figure since the period between World Wars I and II.
Mr. Lukanov, who was born in Moscow and climbed the Bulgarian Communist apparatus to its Politburo, was widely respected, even by critics who said they could grudgingly admire though not approve of his political and economic tactics.
In the mid-1980's, as Deputy Prime Minister in charge of the economy, he was responsible for negotiating Bulgaria's foreign loans and setting up its trading companies abroad.
He helped engineer the ouster of the Stalinist dictator Todor Zhivkov in 1989. The first Prime Minister in post-Communist Bulgaria, Mr. Lukanov was believed to have been active in diverting Communist Party funds into businesses headed by former Communists.
When opposition forces won elections in 1991, Mr. Lukanov was investigated for embezzlement. The prosecutor's office charged him with using Government money for the financing of Communist Party activities abroad in the 1980's. But after he was elected to Parliament, he was immune to further prosecution.
As the Bulgarian economy collapsed this year, Mr. Lukanov came into sharp conflict with the current Prime Minister, Zhan Videnov, 37.
Mr. Lukanov wanted Mr. Videnov to make more concessions to the International Monetary Fund, experts here said. The two men also came into conflict over the power of rival economic groups: Mr. Lukanov was loosely allied to Multigroup, while Mr. Videnov was said to have links to Orion, a business group headed by his cronies.
When their political differences became wider, Mr. Lukanov started to brand Mr. Videnov's circle as "scavengers," apparently an allusion to the fact that Mr. Videnov's businessmen were still trying to profit from the pulverized Bulgarian economy.
Mr. Lukanov's associates say the former Prime Minister was ready to confront Mr. Videnov with corruption charges inside a meeting of the governing Socialist Party. Mr. Videnov has not commented publicly on the reports of corruption.
"Lukanov knew virtually everything and he was no friend of the groups around Videnov," said Krassen Stanchev, executive director of the Institute for Market Economics.
Mr. Stoychev said Mr. Lukanov hoped Mr. Videnov would go voluntarily. "He wanted the Prime Minister to resign, and his idea was to present information on the corruption in the Prime Minister's circle to the parliamentary group," Mr. Stoychev said.
Mr. Lukanov had been invited to attend the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars as a visiting scholar starting in October. Mr. Lukanov and Mr. Stoychev met the day before his killing to go over logistics for his trip.
"We were discussing such things as how to get a cheap hotel, rent a cheap car in Washington," Mr. Stoychev said. "He told me very briefly, 'Things are mature.' From this I understood he was ready to act. He was planning to unite people who are or might be opposed to Videnov and act through the parliamentary group." The next day, Mr. Lukanov was leaving his apartment for a meeting when, according to Mr. Stoychev, a gunman emerged from a car across the street and shot Mr. Lukanov at the front door.
At the funeral, many Bulgarians noticed that Mr. Lukanov's widow refused to shake the hand of Mr. Videnov, who had expressed his condolences and praised Mr. Lukanov.

HEADLINE: Matthew Miles, 69; His Research Led To School Reform

 BODY:
Matthew Bailey Miles, a psychologist and theorist on the educational process, died on Oct. 24 at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 69 and lived in Tappan, N.Y.
The cause was lymphoma, his family said. 
 Dr. Miles, a former professor of psychology and education at Teachers College of Columbia University, was a senior research associate at the Policy Research Center of New York and Washington.
He studied what he called the "social architecture" of schools. His investigations of group dynamics, organizational development, school reforms and qualitative data analyses charted the field of educational change. He provided educators with guideposts for observing, evaluating and making constructive adjustments in the classroom.
He was the co-author, editor and author of some 20 books on such subjects as parent-teacher dynamics, networking, innovation and lasting school improvement. Over the years he conducted research projects for the Office of Education in Washington, the New York City school system, the World Bank and the Carnegie and Ford Foundations, among others.
Born to missionary parents in Burma, he graduated from Antioch College in Ohio and earned a doctorate in education at Teachers College, where he taught from 1954 to 1970.
Dr. Miles is survived by his wife of 47 years, Betty Baker Miles; two daughters, Sara Miles of San Francisco, and Ellen Miles of Montpelier, Vt.; a son, David, also of Montpelier; a brother, Paul R. of North Scituate, Mass.; a sister, Josephine M. Schuman of Phippsburg, Me., and three granddaughters.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NORTH CAROLINA;
He Isn't Soaring This Time, But Helms's Foe Gains Ground

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 2

 BODY:
Six years ago, Harvey Gantt's race against Senator Jesse Helms was not so much a campaign as it was a crusade. The crowds were big and boisterous, the rhetoric broad and sweeping. Even when the Democratic challenger did not say so explicitly, the campaign was clearly out to make history, both by ending the career of a conservative icon and by electing the first black Southerner to the Senate since Reconstruction.
Either because North Carolina was not ready for him, or because Mr. Helms was, Mr. Gantt fell just short, losing 53 percent to 47 percent. The margin of defeat came from white voters, only 35 percent of whom cast ballots for Mr. Gantt, perhaps five or six percentage points less than he needed. 
 In his rematch against Mr. Helms this year, Mr. Gantt must capture the white voters he failed to persuade in 1990. To do so, he has focused his campaign not on the racial or social issues that Mr. Helms used to great advantage back then, but on a portfolio of populist economic issues -- increasing student loans, raising the minimum wage, creating tax credits and deductions for day care and college tuition, and protecting Medicare -- that have helped him define his differences with his opponent. There is more talk this year about Head Start than about history.
There are other contrasts with the 1990 campaign. At 75, Mr. Helms is six years older and noticeably less healthy. With the Republicans controlling Congress, he is more powerful, a factor that cuts both ways. Mr. Gantt has kept pace with the four-term incumbent in fund raising, with both men collecting about $7 million.
It is a Presidential year, which should drive up turnout. There are nearly 700,000 more voters on the rolls, many of them transplants who have moved to North Carolina to take advantage of a booming economy. And unlike 1990, when Mr. Gantt was blindsided by a Helms advertisement on affirmative action, the Democratic challenger has placed Mr. Helms squarely on the defensive in the final days of the campaign.
But the primary difference is that Mr. Gantt, hoping to de-emphasize the issue of race for the white voters he so desperately needs, has effectively focused his campaign on the question of which candidate most supports average families. With some voters, at least, the tactic seems to be working.
"I like his values on education and his ideas on taxes," said Debbie A. Oliver, a white 24-year-old mother of one who moved to Burlington, N.C., from West Virginia five years ago. "Jesse Helms, I don't know, he just seems like he's not for the everyday person."
There are still plenty of North Carolinians who disagree. Polls show Mr. Helms holding a slight lead, and most political scientists predict that he will win again, although few discount the possibility of an upset.
"It's never over because Helms's negatives are so enormous that if the right people turn out, you can beat him," said Ted Arrington, a professor of political science at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. "But I don't think it's very likely."
Among his traditional supporters, Mr. Helms is beloved not only for his beliefs but also for his backbone. "You may not agree with everything he says but you always know where Jesse stands," said Cicely A. Steffen, a 56-year-old mother of seven children from Graham.
The wild cards in the race are the state's new voters, most of whom are white. Many are assumed to lean Republican, but not as far to the right as Mr. Helms.
Dr. Hodges Davis, an orthopedic surgeon originally from Louisiana who moved to Charlotte four years ago, said he voted Republican more than half the time but planned to vote for Mr. Gantt. "Harvey Gantt's not my perfect candidate, but Jesse Helms is just everything I'm against," he said.
But his wife, Rebecca, a devoted Republican, said she considered Mr. Gantt to be too liberal and planned to cancel out her husband's vote.
Mr. Helms is sticking largely to his traditional script. His television advertisements label Mr. Gantt a liberal and tie him to homosexual causes, a tried-and-true tactic for turning out the incumbent's conservative base. "He's raised millions from gay activists from New York to San Francisco," an announcer says of Mr. Gantt in an advertisement that hit the airwaves this week.
Mr. Helms has again used his advertising to insinuate race into the campaign, but in a far more subtle way than in 1990. A recent Helms advertisement contends that in the 1980's, Mr. Gantt "used his minority status" to purchase an interest in a Charlotte television station.
Late this week, the state Republican Party mailed fliers to half a million households in three Congressional districts pairing a photograph of Mr. Gantt with that of the incumbent Democratic member of Congress in each district. Two of the three, Representatives Melvin Watt and Eva Clayton, are black. "Eva's bad enough . . . do you want Harvey too?" one mailing asks, before asserting that Ms. Clayton has voted for higher taxes and spending and against balancing the budget.
Democratic strategists consider the fliers a racial appeal. But Robert Wilkie, the executive director of the state Republican Party, pointed out that mailings had also been sent into the district represented by W. G. (Bill) Hefner, a white Democrat. "The racial charge has become so trite now that it's lost its meaning," Mr. Wilkie said.
In 1990, Mr. Helms surprised Mr. Gantt in the last two weeks of the campaign with a now infamous television advertisement that showed a pair of white hands holding an employment rejection letter while an announcer suggested that Mr. Gantt favored affirmative action policies that would cost whites their jobs.
But this year, it is Mr. Gantt and his supporters who have put Mr. Helms on the defensive.
Mr. Gantt, a 53-year-old architect and the former Mayor of Charlotte, has used television advertising to criticize Mr. Helms for voting for cuts in the growth of Medicare, and Mr. Helms has responded with commercials that accuse Mr. Gantt of "running dishonest TV ads to smear Jesse Helms on Medicare." In public appearances, the Senator leads his crowds in chanting, "There has never been a vote to cut Medicare."
In both speeches and commercials, Mr. Gantt has spent the last week attacking Mr. Helms, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, because the private foundation that operates Mr. Helms's archives has accepted large contributions from major corporations and foreign governments, including Taiwan and Kuwait.
"When you are making policy in the interest of the United States Government, you shouldn't be tempted -- you shouldn't have this appearance of conflict of interest," Mr. Gantt told a crowd in Burlington on Thursday.
Mr. Helms has been forced to respond in speeches and in two separate commercials, and the charges seem to have thrown him off his stride. Answering a television reporter's questions about the gifts this week, Mr. Helms first asserted that he did not know who had contributed to the foundation but he told the reporter moments later that his own station was the second-largest contributor.
"You can't influence me," Mr. Helms told the reporter. "Nobody can except the truth, and you put that in your pipe and smoke it, old boy."

HEADLINE: AMERICAN PROFILES -- Oregon;
In This Campaign, the Most Telling Signs in Oregon Say 'Help Wanted'

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: HILLSBORO, Ore., Oct. 31

 BODY:
On the day that Bob Dole was saying, "The evidence of a weak economy is everywhere -- everywhere!" Brian Norris, a longtime Republican, wondered what country Mr. Dole was talking about.
For more than a year, Mr. Norris has been trying to find enough construction workers for jobs here in the Portland suburbs, where housing subdivisions and new software factories are sprouting like Douglas firs on the ever-wet Oregon coast. 
 Just recently, Mr. Norris painted a large plea on the sidewalk window of the temporary labor agency he manages here: "We Need More Workers." Even at pay up to $25 an hour, there are simply not enough bodies to fill the job needs of the roaring Oregon economy.
"There is a huge shortage of workers, especially in construction," Mr. Norris said. "You'd be hard-pressed trying to convince anyone that these are gloomy times."
Like Oregon, many other parts of the country, from Virginia to the Great Plains to the San Francisco Bay area, are experiencing a labor shortage, according to Federal Reserve Bank regional reports. Even as the growth of the nation's economy slowed last month, which prompted Mr. Dole's outburst on Wednesday, perceptions are something else.
What seems more convincing than any political posters in this election year, in Oregon as elsewhere, are help-wanted signs. They tell a story, reflected in polls here and in most other states, about an absence of fear and a surfeit of hope.
"Take off the mask," Mr. Dole said. "It's not Halloween. Take off the mask! The economy is not good."
In the little Oregon village of Progress, at a costume store called Party Depot, the manager, Nick Apap, was asked about business.
"Excellent -- the best Halloween ever," said Mr. Apap, dressed in a costume with jailhouse stripes. "The only problem is, we are having a lot of trouble finding cashiers."
Painted on his store window, as big as the sales posters, was a message: "Now Hiring!"
In 1993, more than 70 percent of the people surveyed in an Oregon poll said the country was headed in the wrong direction. Now, those numbers have reversed themselves, said Tim Hibbitts, a pollster.
From the vineyards of the Willamette Valley, where the last of this year's plump pinot noir grapes are being crushed, to the vertical playground of Mount Hood, where an early snowfall has brought October skiers to the slopes, politics has become something of an afterthought.
People say they have largely made up their minds about their choice for President, and they are voting for a status quo they can see no reason to change.
"I don't have much use for politics, but business is terrific," said Vern Hass, who at the age of 68 is enjoying a second career as a nursery owner near the town of Tigard. "Clinton's been doing all right and Dole just seems like he's not up for the job. My relatives will kill me for saying this, but I already voted absentee, and I went for Clinton."
Although there is a close race for the Senate seat of Mark O. Hatfield, a Republican who is retiring, and there is a tough fight for a freshman Republican Congressman, Jim Bunn, Oregon residents seem spent in a campaign they describe as interminable.
The talk on these afternoons of buttery sunlight is more likely to be about hunting elk in the Coast Ranges, or about why the Oregon Ducks are foundering on the college football circuit.
Oregon, with a population of just three million in an area that stretches from the Pacific Coast to the desert of the Great Basin, has long had a buoyancy of character even in the hardest of times. The state was founded as a farming pot of gold at the end of the Oregon Trail rainbow. Towns with names like Promise, Pleasant Home and Sunnyside are a long way from American Gothic.
But the state economy went into a severe tailspin in the late 1980's and early 1990's when its timber industry collapsed, and there was little to fall back on. Since then, Oregon has grown an economy that President Clinton has cited as a model for a trade-dependent future, with new high-tech factories turning out computer chips and wafers for sale around world. Last December, for the first time, employment in technology concerns surpassed that in forest products.
In the Portland metropolitan area, full of new homes looking out at the pyramidal 11,239-foot summit of Mount Hood, unemployment is around 3 percent. Intel, the California-based chip manufacturer, is investing $2.2 billion in new factories it is building west of Portland, generating demand for everything from wallboard laborers to booth operators at drive-through espresso shops.
Certainly, none of the scores of people interviewed in this state echoed Mr. Dole's sentiment that this is the worst economy in 20 years. Retailers are offering big clothing and food discounts as sweeteners to fill cashier jobs at $7 an hour.
"It's bordering on a boom town around here," said Bill Calder, an Intel spokesman who used to work for Senator Hatfield. Intel is hiring retrained former loggers for many manufacturing jobs, Mr. Calder said, but the company is experiencing "a tremendous shortage of software engineers."
"All you have to do is go into an electronics store and watch 40-inch televisions sail out the door," Mr. Calder said. "Or go to the auto dealer on Saturday and see new Hondas get sold in a frenzy, like it's a grocery store. There's a general feeling in the air that things are pretty good."
Much of the Oregon boom was driven by California exiles fleeing the recession in the Golden State. But now the migration north has slowed to a trickle, and still Oregon has little but blue skies ahead in the next five years, said the state's chief economist, Paul Warner.
Up and down the West Coast, where Mr. Clinton holds double-digit leads in the polls, there have been multiple-digit gains in employment. California, while its unemployment numbers are slightly higher than the national average, has made up the 500,000 jobs it lost in the early 1990's. Last month, a record-high number of people, 14,489,000, held jobs in California, and the state's 7 percent unemployment rate was the lowest since 1991.
In Washington State, the Puget Sound area is adding 50,000 new jobs a year -- a 4 percent growth rate that is more than twice the national average -- as the Boeing Company and numerous software concerns fatten their payrolls.
Mr. Norris, the Republican, is voting Democrat for President this year. He was laid off by United Parcel Service, but landed on his feet in this suburb west of Portland. He made up his mind on the Presidential race after the first debate and has paid little attention to politics since then.
"It was obvious after that debate that Clinton was going to win," Mr. Norris said. "I decided to vote for him because I think we need to look to the future, not the past."
He does not trust Mr. Dole's promise of a 15 percent tax cut, saying, "I have yet to hear how he's going to pay for it." And he likes the family leave law, which Mr. Clinton championed. Time, he said, is more important than money.
Voting in this state has become something of a jugling act, as the ballot is crammed with dozens of proposals. The airwaves are devoid of Presidential commercials but are jammed with arguments about the numerous ballot measures.
The beleaguered Oregon voter has to make decisions on such things as banning cows from salmon streams, using bait and dogs in bear hunts, raising the cigarette tax 30 cents a package to pay for health care, and deciding whether to count nonvoters as "no" votes on ballot measures. The last proposal would most likely end up counting some dead voters as "no" voters, The Oregonian noted in an editorial.
And there is a proposal to raise the Oregon minimum wage to $6.50 an hour by 1999, to put it well above the national minimum, which goes to $5.15 from $4.75 on Sept. 1, 1997.
A ballot measure that would require insurance companies to pay for alternative health care like herbal and vitamin remedies is the only real political issue that excites Bernhard Ruppel, a Republican.
Mr. Ruppel, who lives in the town of Boring, is a Dole supporter. He said his town's name would pretty much describe how people feel about the Presidential election.
"People are apathetic," he said. "They say Dole has already lost, to forget about it. Myself, I can't go for Clinton because of moral decline and Clinton's ethical problems."
Under the dryers and curlers at the Hair Hunters Salon in Hillsboro, the talk has not dealt with politics for some time, said Terri Stansell, the owner.
"Those who have talked about it said they were going for Clinton," Ms. Stansell said, "not because they like him, but because Dole doesn't do anything for them."
Independent polls show Mr. Clinton with a 20-point lead in Oregon, a state that has long been Republican but has gone Democratic in the last two Presidential elections. More typically, this state is full of independents. Signs for Ralph Nader and Ross Perot are more ubiquitous than Dole or Clinton signs in many areas.
Despite Oregon's recent run of good luck, there is a subcurrent of cynicism, even among the prosperous. Asked to rate the state of American democracy in this last Presidential election of the 20th century, Mr. Hass, the nursery owner, said, "Probably a 4 on a scale of 1 to 10. We've lost some of our vision, our goals. You think of Washington, Lincoln, Teddy Roosevelt. Those were Presidents you could get excited about."

HEADLINE: Tribe Famous for Horses Sees Future in Them

BYLINE: By JIM ROBBINS 

DATELINE: LAPWAI, Idaho

 BODY:
As Rudy Shebala walks through a pasture full of quietly grazing horses on a nickel-gray autumn day, a long-legged colt approaches him and nuzzles his arm, and Mr. Shebala reaches out and scratches the sleek beast's nose.
It is an unusual horse Mr. Shebala is stroking. This cross between an appaloosa and a rare Central Asian breed called akhal-teke is the centerpiece of a campaign the Nez Perce Indians hope will resurrect their horse culture, a proud tradition of selective breeding and horsemanship that was destroyed by a 19th-century war. 
 Tribal leaders also hope the breeding program will provide a "culturally appropriate" business on a reservation plagued with an unemployment rate as high as 70 percent.
Mr. Shebala, a Navajo Indian who is married to a Nez Perce, runs the breeding program. "We were once horsemen, we once raised cattle and worked our own land. These horses will help us get the old ways back."
The Nez Perce were famous among Western tribes for the quality of their horses and sophisticated breeding. In 1805, when Lewis and Clark stumbled out of the Bitterroot Mountains into present-day eastern Idaho after a torturous trip, the Nez Perce gave them food and shelter. In his journal, Meriwether Lewis wrote of the Nez Perce: "Their horses appear to be an excellent race. Many of them look like fine English coursers and would make a figure in any country."
In the summer of 1877, the Nez Perce were ordered by the United States Army to leave their homeland in the Wallowa Valley of eastern Oregon for a smaller reservation in Idaho. But the Indians fled. Some 800 men, women and children and 2,000 horses traveled more than 1,100 miles in four months, battling the pursuing Army, trying desperately to reach Canada.
Most were caught in a final battle in north-central Montana 30 miles south of asylum, where their leader, Chief Joseph, made the famous statement that he would "fight no more forever." The Nez Perce warhorses, bred over generations, were scattered, and the breed disappeared.
Deprived of their horses and with their nomadic existence at an end, the Nez Perce people severed contact with this distinctive part of their past.
"The loss of horses was like the loss of a good friend, like losing a dog," said Angel McFarland, whose parents are taking part in the tribal breeding program. "It's similar to taking away our braids, our strength; and with the horses, we have that strength back."
Four akhal-teke stallions were donated to the tribe by a Minnesota breeder. The idea is to blend the appaloosa's blocky, muscular traits as well as the distinctive "blanket" -- spots on the rump -- to the slim and elegant akhal-teke horse of Turkmenistan. Akhal-tekes are believed to be similar to the original Spanish horses brought to North America, which were the progenitors of the Nez Perce war horse.
The offspring, Mr. Shebala says, will be similar to the type of horse that was lost. The first foal crop of 24 horses was born last spring, and are distinctive looking, with long legs, an erect neck and a narrow chest and head. Along with their graceful look, they have been bred for their endurance and riding comfort.
This new breed, Mr. Shebala says, has been named the Nez Perce horse. "We want a horse that people will remember us for," Mr. Shebala said. A registry of the new breed is being created, and it is hoped that the demand for the horse will be enough to create employment for the tribe. The new breed has brought a renewed interest in the old ways on the reservation, where many stories handed down about Nez Perce horsemanship are still remembered. "My great-grandfather was called Man of the Horses," said Horace Axtell, a tribal elder. "He would walk a circle around his horses and they wouldn't leave it."
The breeding program dovetails with two others the tribe has developed to help young people. The Young Horseman's program aims to instill the horse tradition in 20 Nez Perce, ages 13 to 21, each year, teaching them to care for, raise and ride horses. Most of the participants had never been on a horse; now they are helping with cattle roundups and taking tourists on trail rides.
Another program, called Mounted Scholars, is for children from elementary to high school age who are doing poorly in school because of problems at home. Math, history and other subjects are taught, with the curriculum built around horses. Classes include riding instruction. "The outside of a horse," said Rosa Yearout, a board member of the program, "helps the inside of a kid."
The pride generated by the horses on a reservation beset with high unemployment and other social ills is almost palpable.
"His name is Skeeter, and he's my little horse, 'cause I always ride him," said one 12-year-old girl in the Mounted Scholars program, as she sat on an appaloosa. Children are taught about Jackson Sundown, the nephew of Chief Joseph, who was the saddle bronc champion at the Pendleton, Ore., roundup in 1916. With his braids tied together under his chin, the 50-year-old Nez Perce rode a horse name Angel to victory.
The Nez Perce program is part of a trend to create "culturally appropriate" development on reservations throughout the country. The breeding program, which has cost more than $500,000 so far, was financed by the United States Department of Health and Human Services, the Nez Perce tribe and a nonprofit group called the First Nations Development Institute, which promotes such businesses in Indian country.

HEADLINE: THE 1996 CAMPAIGN: The Election: A Voter's Guide To the Issues And Candidates;
Races in Connecticut for Congress and Plan to Widen Crime Victims' Rights

 BODY:

HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
 
Second District Candidates
 
EDWARD W. MUNSTER, 55, Republican. Retired statistician at Pfizer. Served one two-year term in the State Senate before challenging Mr. Gejdenson in 1992, a race he lost by 4,000 votes, and again in 1994, when he lost by only 21 votes.
 
SAM GEJDENSON, 48, Democrat. Seeking his ninth term, the dean of the Connecticut delegation to the House. A former farmer from the rural community of Bozrah.
 
The District
 
The Second is the state's largest district geographically, covering most of eastern Connecticut. It has been in flux economically as military jobs have declined and as gambling and tourism have increased with the rise of the Foxwoods Casino in Ledyard and the recent opening of Mohegan Sun Resort in Montville.
 
The Issues
 
As in his previous campaigns, Mr. Munster has characterized his opponent as a liberal and "career politician" who has lost touch with his constituents. Mr. Gejdenson has criticized Mr. Munster for his alliance with Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House. Both candidates say they support welfare reform, abortion rights and Medicare, though Mr. Gejdenson says the Munster-supported Contract With America would have "thrown elderly people out on the street." For his part, Mr. Munster has accused his opponent of playing the "Medi-scare" card with the elderly. On the sensitive local issue of Indians annexing land, Mr. Munster says that laws need to be changed to protect property owners, while Mr. Gejdenson says issues should be worked out between tribes and towns.
 
Analysis
 
After nearly defeating Mr. Gejdenson in 1994, Mr. Munster has been even more aggressive in this campaign. But Mr. Gejdenson has also been running hard. Both candidates have run negative advertisements. A recent independent poll showed Mr. Gejdenson leading by 13 percentage points, and his aides say he will benefit if Mr. Clinton wins a substantial victory in the state.
 
Fifth District CandidatesGARY A. FRANKS, 43, Republican. Seeking his fourth term; was the first black Republican elected to the House in 60 years. Former labor relations executive who lives in Waterbury.
 
JAMES H. MALONEY, 48, Democrat. Former state senator from Danbury and a lawyer; making his second attempt against Mr. Franks.
 
The District
 
The Fifth is economically diverse, with wealthy suburbs like Ridgefield and blue-collar cities like Waterbury and Meriden. Once a Democratic stronghold, it was seized by the Republicans in the 1984 Reagan landslide. It was the only Connecticut district George Bush won handily in 1992.
 
The Issues
 
Mr. Maloney is again trying to paint Mr. Franks as a Congressman out of touch with his district who has voted against moderate propsals like increasing the minimum wage and family leave. Mr. Franks defends his record while emphasizing economic development and his commitment to tax cuts and a balanced budget.
 
Analysis
 
Several factors may make this a close race: Mr. Franks benefited two years ago from having John G. Rowland, the Republican Governor who once held Mr. Franks's seat, on the ballot; and four years ago a third-party candidate split the Democratic vote. Mr. Maloney has also raised a relatively sizable campaign fund -- $440,000 as of Oct. 15 -- and is devoting more than a third of it to advertising. Mr. Franks raised $390,000, and has not campaigned aggressively, spending $85,700 on advertising as of Oct. 15. In addition, President Clinton's strong lead in the district may help Mr. Maloney.
 
But although Mr. Maloney has gained 5 percentage points since July 31, according to a recent independent poll, Mr. Franks still has a 10-point lead. To win, Mr. Maloney has to overcome a significant hurdle: many voters still do not know who he is.
 
Other House Races
 
(X denotes incumbents)
FIRST DISTRICT Kent Sleath, Republican; Barbara B. Kennelly, Democrat (X)
 
THIRD DISTRICT John Coppola, Republican; Rosa L. DeLauro, Democrat (X)
 
FOURTH DISTRICT Christopher Shays, Republican (X); Bill Finch, Democrat
 
SIXTH DISTRICT Nancy L. Johnson, Republican (X); Charlotte Koskoff, Democrat
 
PROPOSITIONS
 
Question No. 1
 
Under the proposal, the State Constitution would be amended to provide certain rights to crime victims.
 
As well as other guarantees, victims would gain the right to make statements to the court before a plea agreement was accepted or the accused was sentenced, would be entitled to restitution, could communicate with prosecutors, be notified of court proceedings as well as the arrest, conviction, sentence, imprisonment and release of the accused.
 
The Issues
 
Supporters, pointing to repeated instances in which victims have been treated poorly in court, say they want to "level the playing field" between the accused and victims.
 
Supporters of the proposition point to one celebrated case in Litchfield County: The mother of a murder victim, James B. Irwin Jr., was ordered by the judge to leave the courtroom, the judge publicly criticized comments made by the father, and they had to seek help from the State Legislature to receive a trial transcript.
 
Opponents say trials would be turned into victim advocacy programs, diluting the primary interest of justice: determining the guilt or innocence of the accused. They predict erosion of the presumption of innocence, and a diminishing of the court's position of detachment in enforcing the law.
 
They predict that a defendant could receive a lesser penalty if a prosecutor were persuaded by victims to reject plea bargaining and go to a trial when evidence is weak.
 
Analysis
 
Some 20 states have already approved similar resolutions. With the Connecticut Legislature overwhelmingly passing a resolution to place the issue on the ballot, the amendment is widely expected to pass, especially considering the unprovocative language of the question: "Shall the Constitution of the State be amended to provide certain rights to victims of crime?"

HEADLINE: THE 1996 CAMPAIGN: The Election: A Voter's Guide To the Issues And Candidates;
Guide to New Jersey Elections for the Senate and 13 Seats in the House

 BODY:

UNITED STATES SENATE
 
Candidates
 
ROBERT G. TORRICELLI, 45, Democrat. Elected to the United States House of Representatives in 1982; has been a member of Congress's Committee on International Relations and its Select Committee on Intelligence. Lawyer in private practice from 1981 to 1982; later served as an aide to Gov. Brendan T. Byrne and as assistant counsel to Vice President Walter F. Mondale. Born in Paterson, now lives in Englewood. Has raised more than $7 million for this race.
 
RICHARD A. ZIMMER, 52, Republican. Elected to the House in 1990; has been a member of Congress's Committee on Ways and Means. Served in the State Assembly from 1981 to 1987 and in the State Senate from 1987 to 1990. Lawyer in private practice from 1969 to 1975; general attorney at Johnson & Johnson from 1975 to 1990. Born in Newark, now lives in Delaware Township, in rural Hunterdon County. Has raised more than $4 million.
 
PAUL A. WOOMER, Green Coalition Party
 
RICHARD J. PEZZULLO, Conservative Party
 
MARK WISE, Future Now Party
 
STEVEN J. BAELI, Protecting Freedom
 
WILBURT KORNEGAY, Independent People's Coalition
 
MARY JO CHRISTIAN, Natural Law Party
 
OLGA L. RODRIGUEZ, Socialist Workers Party
 
The Issues
 
Mr. Zimmer is a self-proclaimed fiscal hawk who has placed a priority on cutting spending and taxes and eliminating the Federal deficit. Mr. Torricelli says that he, too, wants to balance the budget but would fight cuts in Medicare, environmental protection and education aid.
 
Mr. Torricelli's television advertisements have focused on government services his opponent has voted to cut, calling him "too extreme for New Jersey." Mr. Zimmer, meanwhile, has attacked Mr. Torricelli's spending record, calling him "foolishly liberal," as well as his character, referring to the assistance he gave to the daughter of a fugitive.
 
Analysis
 
Polls throughout the campaign have found the candidates in a dead heat, but 50 percent of voters are not firmly committed to either candidate, an unusually high percentage for a Senate race.
 
In the final stretch, both campaigns have been criticized by political leaders around the state for the negative tone of commercials that have dominated the race, which they say have turned off voters.
 
Bob Dole's flagging campaign has not helped Mr. Zimmer, who has distanced himself from the Presidential candidate recently. President Clinton's significant lead in New Jersey bodes well for Mr. Torricelli, but both parties agree the race remains close.
 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
 
Because ballot order is selected randomly by county, candidates are listed alphabetically.
 
Eighth District Candidates
 
BILL MARTINI, 49, Republican. Won election to the House of Representatives in 1994 after an expensive and bitter race against Herb Klein, a freshman Democrat. Served on Clifton City Council and Passaic County Board of Chosen Freeholders; also a former assistant United States Attorney for New Jersey.
 
WILLIAM J. PASCRELL JR., 59, Democrat. Has been Mayor of Paterson since 1990 and a member of the State Assembly since 1987. Previously served as Paterson's public works director and its director of policy, planning and development. Taught public school for 12 years and served as president of the Paterson Board of Education.
 
The District
 
The Eighth includes the blue-collar urban centers of Paterson and Passaic as well as suburban towns like Glen Ridge, Wayne and West Orange. Once a haven for Democrats, it is now highly competitive. Mr. Martini became its first Republican Congressman in 35 years when he won in 1994, with 49.9 percent of the vote.
 
The Issues
 
Mr. Martini has campaigned as a fiscal conservative, calling for more spending cuts and a reduction in size of the Federal Government. Mr. Pascrell has focused on social issues, attacking the Republican Congress's proposal to slow the increase in Federal spending on Medicare by $270 billion over seven years and calling for more federally financed anti-crime programs. Both candidates say they would support a balanced-budget amendment and a reduction of the capital gains tax.
 
Analysis
 
The Democrats consider this their best chance to win back one of the eight Congressional seats held by New Jersey Republicans. Mr. Pascrell has repeatedly linked Mr. Martini to the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, and the Contract With America, much of which Mr. Martini supported during his freshman term. Mr. Martini has tried to distance himself from the Republican leadership, stressing his own environmental record and support for an increase in the minimum wage. The candidates have predicted they will spend more than $1 million apiece, making this the state's most expensive Congressional race. Leaders in both parties agree that it is also one of tightest.
 
Ninth District Candidates
 
KATHLEEN A. DONOVAN, 44, Republican. Has served as the Bergen County Clerk since 1988. Spent 19 months as chairwoman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and served one term in the State Assembly. Spent 20 months as chairwoman of the state Republican Party. Resident of Lyndhurst.
 
STEVEN R. ROTHMAN, 44, Democrat. Left his job as the Bergen County Surrogate Court judge in January to run for Congress. Mayor of Englewood from 1983 to 1988; currently works for a law firm in Saddle Brook while living in Fair Lawn.
 
The District
 
Covering parts of Bergen and Hudson Counties, the Ninth is one of the smallest in size and most densely populated of New Jersey's 13 Congressional districts. Democrats outnumber Republicans by a 2-to-1 ratio, and the district usually favors Democratic candidates, but half of the registered voters are independents.
 
Robert Torricelli, the Democratic Senate candidate, has held the Ninth District seat since 1982.
 
The Issues
 
The candidates have similar positions on many issues: both support abortion rights, gun control and federally funded environmental programs. Ms. Donovan has portrayed herself as a moderate who would not feel obligated to vote with the Republican majority and who opposes Bob Dole's proposal for a 15 percent tax cut. Mr. Rothman has focused on taxes and Government spending, criticizing "corporate welfare" and calling for a tax deduction for college tuition.
 
Analysis
 
Odds favor Mr. Rothman, since the district has elected a Democrat Congressman, Mr. Torricelli, since 1982 and Mr. Rothman shares the Democratic ballot with Mr. Torricelli and President Clinton. But both parties have devoted extra resources to this race, and it is considered close. And Ms. Donovan, who has better name recognition and is stressing her moderate views, is the district's strongest Republican Congressional candidate in years.
 
12th District Candidates
 
DAVID M. DEL VECCHIO, 39, Democrat. Has served as the Mayor of Lambertville since 1991. Once an aide to Gov. Jim Florio, is on leave from a job in the State Treasury Department.
 
MIKE PAPPAS, 35, Republican. A partner in a family-run insurance business who has served as a Somerset County Freeholder since 1984. Served one year as the Mayor of Franklin, in Somerset County, and now lives in Rocky Hill.
 
The District
 
One of New Jersey's largest and wealthiest districts, the 12th encompasses 41 towns in five counties.
 
It includes rural areas, shore towns and middle-class and wealthy suburbs. Most registered voters are independents, but the electorate almost always favors Republicans.
 
The Issues
 
Neither candidate is well known, and both have struggled for name recognition in a district that stretches from the Delaware River to the Jersey Shore.
 
Mr. Pappas is a staunch opponent of abortion; Mr. Del Vecchio supports abortion rights and has made it a campaign issue, labeling the race "the mainstream versus the extreme."
 
Both candidates have portrayed themselves as fiscal conservatives, calling for a balanced-budget amendment and a reduction of the capital gains tax.
 
Analysis
 
Mr. Pappas's opposition to abortion helped him defeat three more moderate Republicans in the primary, but the Democrats are hoping his conservative platform will alienate the district's large number of independents and moderate Republicans. The Republicans contend that Mr. Pappas's chances are strong in a bedrock Republican district whose popular outgoing Congressman, Richard Zimmer, is on the Senate ballot. Mr. Pappas has raised more money than Mr. Del Vecchio, and has outspent him in the final weeks of the race.

PROPOSITIONS
 
Public Question No. 1
 
The environmental bond act being proposed would provide $300 million for dredging, disposal of dredged material and pollution cleanup: $205 million would be used to dredge shipping channels in North and South Jersey and to dispose of the dredged material; $70 million would be used to clean up polluted sites and water supplies; $20 million would finance economic development projects in South Jersey; $5 million would be spent controlling plant growth in lakes.
 
The Issues
 
Political and business leaders have long warned that New Jersey's ports, which pump billions of dollars into the economy, will languish if the polluted silt that has collected in shipping channels is not removed. They point out that since New Jersey cannot continue dumping contaminated silt offshore because of Government regulations coming into effect in 1997, this money would help finance alternatives. Critics, who argue against increasing the state's long-term debt, have been fairly quiet in any opposition.
 
Analysis
 
Businesses, labor unions and environmental groups have thrown their support behind the proposal, forming a coalition that has widely publicized and promoted it. Since New Jersey has a long history of approving environmental bond acts, this one is expected to pass if voters have learned about it ahead of time.
 
Public Question No. 2
 
An amendment to the State Constitution would dedicate 4 percent of the revenue from the corporate business tax -- about $48 million a year -- for pollution cleanup. One-third of the money would be spent on improvements to underground storage tanks, and at least one-sixth would be spent testing and improving water quality. The rest would be spent cleaning up polluted sites around the state.
 
The Issues
 
State officials argue that the Department of Environmental Protection, which stands to lose $10 million in the next fiscal year, can keep paying for cleanups at 100 polluted sites around the state only through next summer. By setting aside revenues from the corporate business tax, the proposal would guarantee a steady source of funds. There has been no organized opposition to the proposal.
 
Analysis
 
Since the amendment does not involve a tax increase, and New Jersey voters consistently rate the environment as one of their biggest concerns, this proposal has a good chance of passing.
