HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE SENATE;
Democrats Battle Odds to Regain Senate Control

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Democrats could regain control of the Senate in Tuesday's elections, but they would have to overcome the odds and win more than two-thirds of the many races that appear to be close.
The outlook is unusually hazy because there has not been another year recently, party officials and students of politics say, when so many races for the Senate seemed to be up in the air this near Election Day and when so many voters were saying they had not decided on a candidate. 
 In New Jersey, for example, a poll this week showed that about one-third of those questioned planned to vote for Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican candidate, about one-third supported Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democrat, and the other third were still undecided. [Page 48.]
Polls show close races in other states, from Maine to Oregon, in urban states like Massachusetts and Illinois and rural ones like South Dakota and Wyoming.
As a result, party control of the Senate in the Congress that convenes next year may be determined on Tuesday by the last-minute decisions of voters in more than a dozen states.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, predicted in an interview that Republicans would end up with 54 to 56 of the 100 Senate seats in the next Congress. His counterpart, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, is forecasting a Democratic victory.
But most independent authorities discount those predictions. "Anybody who is confident about the outcome of the Senate elections should be ignored," said Stuart Rothenberg, publisher of a nonpartisan newsletter about Congressional elections.
This is the arithmetic:
Republicans now hold 53 Senate seats to the Democrats' 47. That means Democrats must gain a net of three seats on Tuesday to have a majority, assuming President Clinton is re-elected and Vice President Al Gore can cast the tie-breaking vote.
Sixty-six senators (34 Republicans and 32 Democrats) are not up for re-election . Of the 34 contested seats, 19 are now held by Republicans, 15 by Democrats.
In 15 of the contested races, senators who are running for re-election seem to have their races more or less locked up. Ten of those senators are Republicans; 5 are Democrats.
In two other states, Kansas and Rhode Island, popular Congressmen, one a Republican and the other a Democrat, are the heavy favorites to replace senators from their party who are retiring.
That leaves 17 states where the vote in the Senate race could go either way. Democrats must win 12 of those races to have the 50 seats they need for a majority. Republicans need to win only 6 of the 17 to have the 51 seats they would need with a Democratic Vice President.
Such a disproportionate share of victories in close races, which the Democrats need to gain a majority, is unlikely, but it has happened.
In 1980, 13 Senate races were decided by 4 percentage points or less. Republicans won 10 of them and took control of the Senate. In 1986, 6 Senate races were decided by such a small margin. Democrats took 5 of those races and won back the Senate.
Mr. Rothenberg suggests that the likelihood of the Democrats regaining the Senate in this election is about 1 in 3. Charles E. Cook Jr., who publishes a competing nonpartisan newsletter that also handicaps Congressional races, puts the chances at no better than 1 in 4.
Both say that the best bet is that the close races will break more or less evenly between the parties. Based on past experience, the Presidential election will probably have no effect on the outcome of the Senate elections.
The Senate races this year have produced some of the most compelling political contests in years.
In Massachusetts, Senator John Kerry, a Democrat, is being challenged by the Republican Governor, William F. Weld. Both are tall, handsome, wealthy and articulate Ivy Leaguers with thoroughbred pedigrees, and they are proven vote-getters. The winner will have his ticket stamped to national prominence.
The race, which has been neck-and-neck all year, could come down to Senator Kerry's party affiliation against Governor Weld's personality. Democrats have a 3-to-1 advantage in voter registration in Massachusetts. Governor Weld has cultivated a charming, laid-back manner, while Senator Kerry sometimes seems aloof.
In North Carolina, Senator Jesse Helms, a Republican who is the scourge of liberals across the country and the implacable foe of Federal aid to the arts and whose campaigns over the years have often included subtle appeals to racial anxieties, is being challenged by a black architect, Harvey Gantt, a former Mayor of Charlotte. Six years ago, Mr. Helms narrowly defeated Mr. Gantt.
In Minnesota, there is another rematch. Senator Paul Wellstone, a Democrat, is facing Rudy Boschwitz, the former Republican Senator he ousted in 1990. Mr. Boschwitz could have run for an open Senate seat two years ago and probably would have won handily. But the word in Minnesota is that he preferred to seek revenge against Mr. Wellstone.
In Maine, the tight race to succeed Senator William S. Cohen, a Republican who is retiring, is between two candidates whose backgrounds could hardly be more dissimilar. Joseph E. Brennan, 61, has been on almost every ballot since he was first elected to the Maine Legislature in 1964. A liberal Democrat, he was Governor from 1978 to 1987 and a Congressman from 1987 to 1990. He ran for Governor again and lost in 1990 and 1994. His opponent, Susan M. Collins, 43, is a moderate Republican who has never held elective office.
Jill Docking, a stockbroker, has a chance to become the first Democrat elected to the Senate from Kansas in 64 years. She is running against Representative Sam Brownback to fill the last two years of the term of Bob Dole, who resigned to concentrate on running for President.
The other seat from Kansas, which is being vacated by Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Republican who is also retiring, will almost certainly be won by Representative Pat Roberts, also a Republican.
Representative Tim Hutchinson is hoping to be the first Republican Senator from Arkansas since Reconstruction.
One reason there are so many close races is that 14 senators (8 Democrats and 6 Republicans) are resigning. This is by far the greatest number of open seats since popular election of senators began in 1914. (Before then, senators were elected by their state legislatures.) The previous record was 10 open seats in 1978. Four of those open seats are in the South, and they could be the key to which party winds up controlling the Senate.
The Democratic Senators who are resigning -- Howell Heflin in Alabama, David Pryor in Arkansas, Sam Nunn in Georgia and J. Bennett Johnston in Louisiana -- almost certainly would have won had they sought re-election. That would have vastly improved the Democratic prospects of taking over the Senate. Now, all four seats are up for grabs.
Democrats calculate that they must hold at least two of those seats and probably need at least three to have a majority in the next Congress. Republicans are counting on winning at least two and think they may take all four.
In the close races, Republicans believe they have the edge in Alabama, Maine, North Carolina, Wyoming and Kansas for the Dole seat.
Democrats feel somewhat confident of winning in Georgia, Illinois, Louisiana, Minnesota, Nebraska and South Dakota.
If both sides are right, party control of the Senate will boil down to the elections in six states: Arkansas, Colorado, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey and Oregon.
If Republicans win just one, they will retain control of the Senate.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "AT A GLANCE: The Senate Races -- What to Watch"
 
THE ARITHMETIC
Republicans now hold a 53-to-47-seat advantage in the Senate; 34 seats are being contested this year. Democrats must gain at least a net of 3 seats to win control of the Senate -- assuming President Clinton is re-elected and Vice President Al Gore has the tie-breaking vote.
 
SAFE SEATS: 11 REPUBLICANS
 
Thad Cochran of Mississippi, Larry E. Craig of Idaho, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, Phil Gramm of Texas, James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, Ted Stevens of Alaska, Fred Thompson of Tennessee, Strom Thurmond of South Carolina and John W. Warner of Virginia. In addition, Representative Pat Roberts of Kansas is expected to hold for Republicans the seat left open by the retirement of Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum.
 
SAFE SEATS: 6 DEMOCRATS
 
The Democrats are Max Baucus of Montana, Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, Tom Harkin of Iowa, Carl Levin of Michigan and John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia. Representative Jack Reed of Rhode Island is expected to keep for Democrats the seat left open by the retirement of Senator Claiborne Pell.
 
TOO CLOSE TO CALL: 8 SEATS HELD BY REBUPLICANS
 
Colorado
 Hank Brown is retiring
 Republican: Representative Wayne Allard
 Democrat: Tom Strickland, lawyer
 The environment is the biggest issue in this race, which looks like a dead heat. Clinton is strong in Colorado, and that could give Strickland a leg up. But a conservative ballot initiative on parental rights could bring Republicans to the polls and give Allard an advantage.

 Kansas
 Bob Dole resigned. His replacement, Sheila Frahm, was defeated in the Republican primary.
 Republican: Representative Sam Brownback
 Democrat: Jill Docking, stockbroker
 Both candidates are excellent campaigners. Brownback represents the most conservative wing of the party. Docking has never held office, but the name is well known because her husband, Tom, was Lieutenant Governor, and his father and grandfather were popular Democratic Governors. She has an uphill fight. Kansas has not elected a Democratic Senator since 1932.

 Maine
 William S. Cohen is retiring
 Republican: Susan M. Collins, former Cohen staff member
 Democrat: Joseph E. Brennan, former Governor and former Representative.
 In a battle of contrasting personalities, a moderate, pro-choice, 43-year-old Republican woman who has never held public office may have a slight lead over a 61-year-old liberal Democratic man who has been on the ballot running for one office or another for a quarter of a century.

 New Hampshire
 Republican: Senator Robert C. Smith
 Democrat: former Representative Dick Swett
 Smith, one of the most conservative Republicans in the Senate, is facing an unusual Democratic tide in what is normally the most reliably Republican state in the East, but Swett, a moderate Democrat, is by no means home free.

 North Carolina
 Republican: Senator Jesse Helms
 Democrat: Harvey Gantt, former Mayor of Charlotte
 A rematch of the 1990 race in which the conservative Senator used an 11th-hour advertising campaign to defeat the Democrat hoping to be the first black Southern Senator since Reconstruction. Few North Carolinians are neutral about Helms. He always has had close races. In the past he has done better on Election Day than he did in pre-election opinion polls.

 Oregon
 Mark O. Hatfield is retiring.
 Republican: Gordon Smith, State Senate president
 Democrat: Tom Bruggere, business executive
 Smith has already lost one Senate race this year, when he ran for the seat of Bob Packwood, a Republican, who retired in disgrace. Bruggere has never run for office before. Both men earned fortunes in business. The race is going down to the wire.

 South Dakota
 Republican: Senator Larry Pressler
 Democrat: Representative Tim Johnson
 Both men have repeatedly been elected statewide. South Dakota voters may have been subjected to more television commerecials on a Senate race than voters in any other state. This looks like the Democrats' best chance to oust a Republican Senator.

 Wyoming
 Alan K. Simpson is retiring
 Republican: State Senator Mike Enzi
 Democrat: Kathy Karpan, former Wyoming Secretary of State
 Usually Republicans get elected in Wyoming. Enzi has had surprising trouble locking up this race, but the smart money is probably on him.

TOO CLOSE TO CALL: 9 SEATS HELD BY DEMOCRATS

 Alabama
 Howell Heflin is retiring.
 Republican: Jeff Sessions, State Attorney General
 Democrat: Roger Bedford, State Senator
 All year, this has looked like the Republicans' best hope of winning a Democratic seat. Sessions still seems to have the edge, but Bedford cannot be counted out.

 Arkansas
 David Pryor is retiring
 Republican: Representative Tim Hutchinson
 Democrat: Winston Bryant, State Attorney General
 The outlook has bounced around all year. Lieut. Gov. Mike Huckabee seemed to have the seat sewed up. Then last summer, Gov. Jim Guy Tucker resigned over charges related to Whitewater. Huckabee decided to abandon the Senate race and become Governor. That made Bryant the favorite for the Senate. Then Hutchinson was persuaded to run for the Senate, and the race has become neck and neck.

 Georgia
 Sam Nunn is retiring
 Republican: Guy Millner, business executive
 Democrat: Max Cleland, Georgia Secretary of State
 Cleland is probably the betting favorite, and Democrats are confident of winning. But Republicans smell an upset in a conservative and increasingly Republican state.

 Illinois
 Paul Simon is retiring
 Republican: Al Salvi, former State Representative
 Democrat: Representative Richard J. Durbin
 Salvi, representing the right wing of his party, won the primary over a more moderate Republican. Democrats thought this handed them the Senate seat. Durbin, a liberal, will probably win, but Salvi has been a more formidable candidate than Democrats expected.

 Louisiana
 J. Bennett Johnston is retiring
 Republican: Woody Jenkins, State Representative
 Democrat: Mary Landrieu, former State Treasurer
 Jenkins may be too conservative on social issues for Louisiana. Landrieu must shore up her support among blacks. Landrieu seems to be ahead. But Jenkins, with strong financial support from the party in Washington, closed fast in the primary, and he could do so again.

 Massachusetts
 Republican: Gov. William F. Weld
 Democrat: Senator John F. Kerry
Neither man has a clear edge. Both are liberal on social issues. Weld takes the national Republican line on economic matters like limiting spending on social programs, while Kerry generally sides with the state's senior Senator, Edward M. Kennedy. The race may boil down to a contest between Weld's personality against Kerry's party affiliation in this normally strong Democratic state.

 Minnesota
 Republican: former Senator Rudy Boschwitz
 Democrat: Senator Paul Wellstone
 Wellstone defeated Boschwitz in 1990. Boschwitz is seeking revenge is a bitter match between ideological opposites. Wellstone is probably the most liberal Senator. Boschwitz was a middle-of-the-roader in his 12 years in the Senate, but he is running now as a down-the-line conservative.

 Nebraska
 J. James Exon is retiring
 Republican: Chuck Hagel, investment banker
 Democrat: Gov. Ben Nelson
 A month ago Nelson, a popular Governor with moderate political views, seemed to have an insurmountable lead. But Hagel, a proponent of tax cuts, seems to have rallied. Nelson is still favored, but late polls show the race to be close.

 New Jersey
 Bill Bradley is retiring
 Republican: Representative Richard A. Zimmer
 Democrat: Representative Robert G. Torricelli
 This has been one of the most bitter and costly races in the country. Voters will have to slog to the polls through all the mud that has been slung by both candidates in commercials and debates. DAVID E. ROSENBAUM (pg. 34)

HEADLINE: Fordham and Garden Renew Tower Dispute

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

 BODY:
In a clash that has spanned two years of discussion and legal challenges, two Bronx cultural titans, the New York Botanical Garden and Fordham University, are facing off again over a proposed radio tower on the college campus.
Last week, Botanical Garden officials, who say that the planned 480-foot tower for the campus radio station, WFUV, across from their property would mar the tranquillity of the garden's prized Conservatory, offered a new alternative: a flagpole radio tower measuring 185 feet that they said would be just as effective. 
 But Fordham officials accuse the garden officials of using the flagpole to delay an imminent decision by the Federal Communications Commission on whether Fordham can complete the radio tower.
"To insist that further exploration of hypothetical alternatives and continued public debate are required is simply another attempt to delay resolution of an unreasonably prolonged and increasingly costly dispute," said Fordham's president, the Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare.
A spokesman for the Botanical Garden, Karl F. Lauby, scoffed at the suggestion that the garden's proposal was a stalling device. The garden, he said, has come up with several plans that suit the needs of both institutions, including a tower designed by a team of engineers. He said that garden officials were puzzled about Fordham's stance and questioned whether Fordham was building the tower, which can be leased to other broadcasters, for financial gain.
"Fordham has known for months, since the summer, that the garden has been working on an alternative that involved a structure that was more esthetically pleasing and met their broadcast needs," Mr. Lauby said. "The idea that Fordham would suggest we sprung this on them and the F.C.C. at the 11th hour is ridiculous."
The skirmish between the two institutions began in May 1994, when Fordham began construction of the 45-story tower on Southern Boulevard across from the famed Enid A. Haupt Conservatory in the Botanical Gardens. The tower would replace an antenna atop a campus building, and its additional height, university officials said, was needed to comply with F.C.C. guidelines that seek to reduce public exposure to radio waves. Officials said the tower would also help the noncommercial station to continue to reach its audience of 15,000, which it depends on for support. The site, officials said, is on a firm rock foundation chosen after an exhaustive search.
Two months later, garden officials, who knew nothing of the initial plans, took their objections to the Building Department, which ordered an immediate halt to construction pending review. More than half the tower had already been built.
Garden officials argue that the steel structure, even at its unfinished height, intrudes upon swaths of pristine glens and flower beds on the 250-acre property, casting an ugly shadow over the conservatory, which is undergoing a $25 million renovation. At the least, they say, public hearings should be held to give Bronx residents a chance to respond.
"This part of the Bronx is one of the most beautiful areas," Mr. Lauby said. "The tower has a jarring impact visually. It mars the garden and really looms over the conservatory. The tower is a slap in the face to the Bronx. This tower would not be tolerated in Central Park or Prospect Park. It does not improve this part of the Bronx. It denigrates it and devastates it."
Fordham agreed early to undertake a new search for alternative spots, in collaboration with garden officials. After considering several other sites, including one at a highway interchange in the Bronx and one on city-owned property outside the city, the university decided to stick with its original decision.
"We were talking," Mariellen Gallagher, a Fordham spokeswoman, said of the two-year process. "It seemed then that the talks were civil and productive, then finally it didn't seem to be going anywhere."
The garden has suffered several setbacks in its efforts to block the tower. The Buildings Department ruled in November 1994 that the steel skeleton could be built 25 feet from where the uncompleted tower now stands. The garden appealed the decision, and lost last year.
Then, on June 10, 1996, Justice Sheila Abdus-Salaam of the New York State Supreme Court ruled that the garden would not "suffer any significant economic harm."
The garden appealed that decision, and last week proposed the new alternative.

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
In His Own Words

 BODY:

BILL CLINTON
Speaking at a rally yesterday in San Antonio:
" What do you think the Republicans would be saying if they had a President who had presided over an Administration that had cut the deficit by 63 percent, that had the highest job growth rate of any Republican Administration in 20 years, the lowest average inflation in 30 years, the biggest decline in income inequality among working people in 27 years, the lowest combined rates of unemployment and inflation since Lyndon Johnson was President 28 years ago -- if they had a record like that, what do you think they'd be saying? 
 "They'd be saying it is morning in America. They'd be saying that the President can virtually levitate. Why? Why are they doing what they're doing? Why is the election in doubt? Why aren't we ahead in Texas in the polls? It is an affair of the heart. It is because we have practiced the politics of division for so long, we have tried to turn our opponents into aliens. We have been told, oh, those Democrats, they don't really believe in work and being tough on crime and all that. This is an affair of the heart.
"And I tell you, this country does well when we find common ground, when we build bridges together, when we acknowledge it does take a village. And when we say we're on our own and our opponents are our enemies, and they're no good, and we need to be divided from one another, we always pay the price. "

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Tax Could Lower Pay

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
If the owners somehow ratify the labor agreement at their meeting in Chicago on Wednesday, Major League Baseball will have a new economic scorekeeping system. The revolutionary luxury tax will change how player payrolls are computed.
Scheduled to be in effect for the next three seasons, the luxury tax is designed to put a drag on player salaries by inducing teams to lower their payrolls to avoid paying the tax. The new method for computing payrolls will differ in four ways from the long-used system: 
 *Average annual value of multiyear contracts will be the basic figures used instead of yearly salary plus a prorated share of a bonus.
*Contracts for a team's 40-man roster will be included instead of limiting the payroll to players who are on a team's 25-man major league roster or disabled list on Aug. 31.
*If a player plays for more than one team during a season, a proportion of his salary, either on a one-year contract or based on average annual value of a multiyear contract, will be charged to a team for as many days of the season as he is with that team. Until now, the entire salary was charged to the team that had the player Aug. 31.
*The cost of players' benefits, about $5 million a team, will be added to each payroll instead of being separate from the payroll.
Cecil Fielder serves as a useful example. Under the long-used method of computing payroll, once the Detroit Tigers traded Fielder to the Yankees on July 31, his 1996 income of $9,237,500 would be charged to the Yankees' payroll. Even though the Tigers paid Fielder for two-thirds of the season, they would not be charged for any of his 1996 salary.
Under the pending method, with the annual average value of Fielder's contract $7,237,500, the Tigers would be charged with $4,864,549 for 123 days of the season, the Yankees $2,372,951 for the remaining 60 days.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Labor Deal in Jeopardy as Selig Stays Silent

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
When they meet in Chicago on Wednesday, baseball's team owners will decide whether they want to have peace with the players for the next four years under terms their chief labor executive has negotiated or renew the war from which their business has still not recovered. Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, is apparently not afraid of a renewed war.
As the meeting approaches, more and more people on both sides have expressed the view that without Selig's endorsement, the pending labor agreement is dead. No endorsement has been promised. 
 Selig says he will not tell the clubs what he thinks of the agreement their negotiator has negotiated. He wants each club to decide for itself, he says. What Selig is apparently saying is that he doesn't want to influence someone to vote for the agreement, then have that person discover sometime down the road that he doesn't like the deal, blaming Selig for it.
"Is there any chance this deal can be resuscitated at the 11th hour?" a lawyer who has been involved in the labor war said yesterday. "Sure, there's a very remote chance, but the momentum is so negative, it's going the other way."
The five-year agreement is centered around a luxury tax that would be in effect for the next three seasons. The plan is designed to induce teams to avoid paying a tax by lowering their payrolls.
The absence of a Selig stance is one reason the deal appears to be in the throes of death. The continued silence of the silent majority is another.
While Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox and other owners opposed to the deal lobby their colleagues intensively to vote no, owners who favor the agreement have not campaigned in its -- or their -- behalf. With 21 of 28 votes needed, the outcome will be decided by a small group of owners or officials of clubs who can be swayed.
Five "no" votes seem to be definite: Reinsdorf; the Tribune Company, owner of the Chicago Cubs; Wayne Huizenga of the Florida Marlins; David Glass, chairman of the Kansas City Royals, and Claude Brochu, managing partner of the the Montreal Expos. John Harrington, chief executive officer of the Boston Red Sox, has emerged as a Reinsdorf ally and will most likely vote no.
In fact, within days of each other, newspaper columns appeared in Chicago and Boston newspapers that reflected the tenor of the current campaign against the deal. Reinsdorf and Harrington were seen by people on both sides as the sources of the attacks. One attack was on Randy Levine, the owners' chief negotiator, the other on Donald Fehr, the players' chief negotiator. In the attack on Levine, in a Chicago paper, unnamed owners called for his dismissal, saying the only reason he would not be fired was that his mother-in-law is a friend of Selig's wife.
Reinsdorf's hand appeared to be so evident in that attack that during a conference call of Major League Baseball's executive council last Wednesday, other owners criticized Reinsdorf, a council member, for it.
In the absence of a Selig endorsement, baseball people wonder whether he even likes the deal. If he doesn't, they wonder why he allowed Levine to negotiate it. When Levine became the owners' latest point man in the effort to get a new collective bargaining agreement, Selig told the union, "When you talk with Randy Levine, you're talking with me."
But despite Fehr's efforts to elicit his position, Selig has declined to back Levine, who has been the only management negotiator or official in two and a half years to induce Fehr and his aides to move close enough to the owners' position to make a deal.
If the owners repudiate the agreement Wednesday, Levine is expected to resign shortly thereafter. His forced departure would recall the forced resignation four years ago of Fay Vincent as commissioner. Selig and Reinsdorf wanted Vincent out of the way because they were preparing to go to war with the players and they knew Vincent would stand in their way. They denied that intention at the time, but events have cast serious doubt on their denials.
Besides the resignation of Levine, who had previously worked in the Giuliani administration in New York City, the owners' rejection of the agreement would produce other results:
*Interleague play scheduled for 1997 would be dead. That would also end the likelihood of placing the two expansion teams, Tampa Bay and Arizona, in different leagues.
*Small-revenue clubs would not receive money from their wealthier brethren for 1996 under the new revenue-sharing plan, meaning five clubs, including Montreal and Kansas City, would forfeit more than $4 million each.
*An estimated $500 million to $1 billion in prospective sponsorship deals would continue to lie dormant, further delaying the game's economic recovery from the 1994-95 strike.
*The 11 players who need service time from the strike to be eligible for free agency would have to remain with their clubs.
Because Selig's endorsement is seen as so critical to the Wednesday vote, some who favor the agreement have suggested a way to elicit his view. When Tom Ostertag, general counsel in the commissioner's office, calls the roll, they said, he should call Milwaukee first. Even though Selig has said his daughter, Wendy, will cast the Brewers' vote, it would certainly reflect her father's view.
But it is possible that Selig will have a secret ballot.

HEADLINE: SIGNALS FROM ROME -- A special report.;
Shift to Right Looms at Top for U.S. Catholics

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS and GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
The Roman Catholic Church in the United States is on the verge of a major shift in its leadership that would cement years of appointments of conservative bishops by Pope John Paul II.
Within the next few years, four of the most important and influential archdioceses -- New York, Chicago, Washington and Philadelphia -- are likely to see vacancies, through the retirement or death of the cardinals who head them. The openings will give the Vatican a sweeping opportunity to reshape the profile of Catholicism's top American leadership. 
 "We're at a kind of crucial watershed," said James Hitchcock, a prominent Catholic conservative who teaches history at St. Louis University. "We'll have a national leadership that looks quite different in a couple of years."
Catholics and non-Catholics alike have a stake in the change in the church's leadership, in view of the size of the Catholic population (approximately 1 in 4 Americans) and the importance of the church's network of parishes, schools, social services, hospitals, colleges and universities.
The bishops are the main governing figures in Catholicism, with broad powers within their dioceses to teach authoritatively, regulate parish life and appoint or remove priests and other church officials. Cardinals are usually Vatican officials or the archbishops of major dioceses appointed to serve as papal advisers as well as electors in the choice of a new Pope.
A decade ago, a series of moderately liberal bishops spurred the National Conference of Catholic Bishops to take high-profile stands on national issues through pastoral letters that criticized American policy on the use of nuclear weapons and called for economic justice for the poor. But those men have since retired or left leadership positions in the conference.
These days, after a decade of new appointments by the Vatican, the bishops' conference has become more cautious and inward-looking, devoted to internal matters like balancing the conflicting demands of traditionalists and feminists in new translations of the liturgy. While church leaders continue to speak out on political issues, they no longer employ the open hearings and revised drafts that made the earlier pastoral letters churchwide events.
The shift toward conservatism will soon become all the more evident when the bishops lose their most influential moderate, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago, long valued as a premier consensus-builder. Two months ago, he announced that the cancer for which he was operated on last year had returned and was incurable. Last week, he turned over all his routine duties to an auxiliary bishop.
Former Archbishop John R. Roach of St. Paul and Minneapolis said Cardinal Bernardin's death would have a "very serious" effect on the operation of the bishops' conference. "Not so much because he is the voice of liberalism," Archbishop Roach said, "but the voice of sanity, and a voice credible to great numbers of people.
"I don't see any replacement," he added.
Everyone agrees the church's leadership will become more conservative, but not on what this will mean in practice. Will it halt or accelerate the growing tendency of many Catholics to ignore church teachings when making up their minds on sexual and moral issues?
The bishops could become more -- or less -- outspoken on politically charged issues. They could shift away from their recent focus on the condition of the poor and immigrants, and concentrate on sexual conduct, the permanence of marriage, abortion and euthanasia.
Or their conservatism could be manifest mainly as circumspection, in which the prelates refrain from acting decisively at the national level and leave the initiative to local bishops, who in turn wait upon signals from Rome.
Such predictions are not easy, particularly because the Pope's recent appointments, although usually Vatican loyalists and theological conservatives, show important differences in style and temperament.
Very few of them, for example, resemble Bishop Fabian W. Bruskewitz of Lincoln, Neb., who threatened this year to excommunicate local members of groups who challenged church teachings or sought liberalizing changes in its practices.
For non-Catholics and for many Catholics who are only occasional churchgoers, the shift in leadership will affect how they perceive the church as a force in the nation's public life and how persuasive they find its messages on moral issues.
For practicing Catholics, the shift will affect not only how attractive they find the public face of their church but also the morale of their parish priests, the quality of their Sunday worship, the character of their children's religious education and dozens of the other concrete aspects of church life that either stir parishioners' enthusiasm or drive them into apathy.
The bishops, of course, do not constitute all of Catholic leadership. The church has its thinkers, preachers and artists, its philanthropists, neighborhood apostles and organizational geniuses.
Few bishops, for example, have had as much impact on American Catholicism as Thomas Merton, the monk and writer, or the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, former president of the University of Notre Dame.
But most of the church's institutional levers are ultimately in the hands of diocesan bishops and the auxiliary bishops who assist them, because church tradition makes them, in union with the Pope, the ultimate interpreters of doctrine and because, for the most part, they hold the deeds to church property.
These men's public pronouncements and choice of key officials can set the tone for a diocese.
A bishop's control of the seminary can influence the kind of young people who are drawn there and what the future clergy will be like.
Faced with the growing shortage of priests, a bishop can encourage greater roles for lay professionals (most of them women) in team ministries, or he can hope to attract new aspirants to the priesthood by maintaining clear distinctions between priests and laity.
By requiring approval of speakers invited to diocesan events, a bishop sends a message that some Catholics will read as rejecting new ideas and others will view as being doctrinally conscientious.
At a time when Catholic social service agencies are feeling the consequences of government cutbacks and Catholic hospitals are under pressure to merge or sell their facilities, the very survival of such institutions -- and whether they can maintain their Catholic character -- often depends on how adroitly a bishop can blend administrative talents, bargaining flexibility and religious purpose.

The Succession
 
Retiring Prelates Produce Shift
Even before Cardinal Bernardin announced that he was dying, the ebbing of his style of leadership was signaled by the retirements of three former presidents of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops: Archbishop Roach, Archbishop John R. Quinn of San Francisco and Bishop James W. Malone of Youngstown, Ohio. Each was succeeded in his diocese by a bishop known to be more conservative.
Archbishop Roach described these retiring bishops as having "great faith in collaboration and in an open process."
"We were willing to run some risks," he said. "We thought that if we were open enough, an enormous amount of the spirit of God would come through the people."
By comparison, he said the more conservative bishops recently appointed had a greater fear that by departing from established practices, doctrinal "truth will be compromised."
Archbishop Roach was one of the few church leaders willing to be interviewed on the record. Many bishops shy away from discussing internal church decisions, fearing that they sound purely political. In addition, it is an unwritten rule for bishops never to comment on their own prospects for further advancement -- and none of the individuals now frequently discussed in church circles were asked about their chances.
Two decades ago, Pope Paul VI enacted a change requiring all bishops to submit offers of retirement at age 75. The effects of that change are starting to be felt in the major American sees.
Cardinal O'Connor, at 76, continues as New York Archbishop at the Pope's request. James Cardinal Hickey of Washington is 76 and continues to serve. Anthony Cardinal Bevilacqua of Philadelphia turns 75 in 1998.
The Pope will decide their successors. He will, however, receive recommendations from the Vatican's Committee for Bishops and the Papal Pro-Nuncio, Archbishop Agostino Cacciavillan, Rome's representative in Washington.
"I think the person who's really going to have a lot of influence here is Cardinal O'Connor," said the Rev. Thomas Reese, a senior fellow at Woodstock Theological Center at Georgetown University. As a member of the Committee for Bishops, Cardinal O'Connor is "in the perfect position to make recommendations," Father Reese said.
While the Vatican can be expected to appoint men it perceives to be strong loyalists, it also takes into account administrative skills, links to the outgoing prelate or to influential officials in Rome, and ties to a diocese with an opening.
Chicago, for example, has a long tradition of liberalism among the clergy and laity, and a bitter memory of conflict with the reclusive and conservative John Cardinal Cody, Cardinal Bernardin's predecessor. The manner in which a new archbishop asserts his authority could spell the difference between peace and turmoil.
Some of the names mentioned for the Chicago position are moderately liberal prelates with a link to the city or to Cardinal Bernardin: Archbishop Thomas J. Murphy of Seattle, or Archbishop Michael J. Sheehan of Santa Fe.
But some church leaders say a more likely candidate would be a moderate conservative like Archbishop James P. Keleher of Kansas City, a former Chicago priest. Bishop Edward M. Egan of Bridgeport, Conn., another Chicagoan, and Bishop John J. Myers of nearby Peoria, Ill., are perhaps too conservative, some church leaders said, although they have strong connections to Rome, as does Archbishop Justin F. Rigali of St. Louis.
Two solidly centrist Midwesterners are also logical candidates: Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk, Cardinal Bernardin's successor as Archbishop of Cincinnati, and Bishop Anthony M. Pilla of Cleveland, the current president of the bishops' conference.
The individual most frequently mentioned as likely to fill one of the cardinal-level positions is Bishop Donald W. Wuerl of Pittsburgh. A decade ago, he became nationally known when appointed bishop co-adjutor to Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen of Seattle, a liberal the Vatican was trying to rein in. The appointment earned Bishop Wuerl the distrust of church moderates, but he has won high marks as a pastoral leader and administrator since succeeding Cardinal Bevilacqua in Pittsburgh.
Others mentioned as possibilities, most often for New York, are Bishop James T. McHugh of Camden, N.J., who once charted the bishops' anti-abortion strategy, and three prelates originally from New York: Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark, Bishop Henry J. Mansell of Buffalo, and Auxiliary Bishop Edwin F. O'Brien of New York.
Any speculation, however, comes with a caveat: Past experience shows it is very difficult to predict the Vatican's choice. And recurring questions about John Paul's health and longevity add another layer of uncertainty.
Cardinal O'Connor, for example, had served less than a year as Bishop of Scranton, Pa., when he became New York Archbishop in 1984.
"John O'Connor wouldn't have been on anybody's list 12 years ago," said George Weigel, a Catholic moderate conservative and former director of the Ethics and Public Policy Center in Washington, who is working on a biography of the Pope. "So be prepared for interesting things."
Archbishop Roach warned against exaggerating the shift in the hierarchy. He and other church leaders said the bishops have not abandoned their interest in public policy or determination to defend groups like the poor and immigrants.
They were outspokenly critical of the welfare overhaul bill, and persist in urging unpopular causes like foreign economic aid. If there is a change in outlook, it is subtle, perhaps a greater tendency to respond to Government initiatives than to undertake their own.
Some of those most identified with the hierarchy's conservative wing are highly vocal on social issues. Cardinal O'Connor has come to the aid of labor unions. Cardinal Law has testified to the Massachusetts State Legislature against the death penalty. Roger Cardinal Mahony, Archbishop of Los Angeles, has opposed measures restricting immigration.

2 Different Approaches
 
Many New Leaders Show Flexibility
Even on matters of theology, church authority and traditional practices, many of the emerging conservatives are showing themselves flexible managers of their own dioceses, while they repudiate any questioning of traditional principles.
Archbishop Harry J. Flynn, who succeeded Archbishop Roach in St. Paul, for example, is a gracious but firm proponent of traditional theology. He seems content to put his weight to the conservative side without issuing a blanket challenge to liberals unhappy with aspects of official church teaching or practice.
"Ideologically we may be different," Archbishop Roach said of his successor. "He may have drawn some people to the right but he has not alienated anyone. His pastoral instincts are just superb. I don't see this diocese changing radically."
On the issues that have riled the bishops' conference, Archbishop Flynn has kept a low profile.
By contrast, Archbishop William J. Levada has established himself as one of the national spokesmen of the conservative wing of the church hierarchy. Archbishop Levada is a friend of Josef Cardinal Ratzinger, for whom he toiled in the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, the office responsible for maintaining Catholic orthodoxy.
At the twice-yearly conference sessions, Archbishop Levada, a physically imposing man, is frequently at the microphone, raising objections, defending amendments, always striving to assure that no phrase or action opens the door to deviations from past teachings or weakens church authority.
But a different picture emerges from his initial months in San Francisco, an archdiocese with a liberal reputation. Priests there say that he has moved carefully.
"Everyone asks, 'How are you doing?' " said one priest, who asked not to be identified. "But he has not come down heavy on anyone yet."
The priest described Archbishop Levada's participation in events aimed at strengthening communities and defending immigrants.
"Social justice-wise, the Archbishop has been excellent," he said. "He likes to talk to people. He doesn't have to be the big expert; he can listen."
This kind of nonconfrontational approach by theologically conservative bishops has been profoundly disappointing to many conservatives.
Professor Hitchcock and his wife, Helen Hull Hitchcock, director of Women for Faith and Family, worry that liberal views remain entrenched in diocesan staffs.
"Bishops often go into a diocese and don't change any of the staff," Mrs. Hitchcock said.
James Hitchcock added: "The Vatican is taken with a diplomatic mindset; it would like people who would supposedly turn things around with extreme finesse."
 
The Future
 
Some See Lack Of Leadership
The new conservatism among bishops may not produce a dramatically different kind of leadership, but rather less leadership altogether.
A priest whose work takes him into dioceses around the country said that too many bishops lacked a vision or strategy that would give the clergy and lay leaders a long-run sense of a diocese's direction.
At the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, several bishops and other church leaders agreed that there is a growing reluctance to raise questions or make proposals unless the approval of leading cardinals and Rome is signaled ahead of time.
"The trust level among the bishops is far lower than a decade ago," a church official said.
Many Catholic leaders see the handful of active cardinals becoming an alternative center of leadership for the American church, which would make the forthcoming appointments all the more important.
The substitution of the cardinals, who are named by the Pope, for the national conference, which operates on the principle of one-bishop-one-vote, would be a return to an older form of leadership that last flourished when Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York was the official face of American Catholicism for most Americans.
Many conservatives would welcome a weakening of the bishops' conference, because they believe that the organization, influenced by liberal bishops and staff members, has interfered in the prerogatives of local bishops and created a buffer between the Vatican and dioceses.
Centrists and liberals counter that the church needs an effective and credible national voice both to get a hearing in public affairs and to deal with internal church matters, like the revelations of sexual abuse of minors by priests, which become national issues.
No one in the leadership appears to want one almost inevitable consequence of weakening the authority of the bishops' conference, a situation in which journalists would, in effect, be determining the voices of the church as they spotlighted whatever bishops or cardinals were found to be most personable, flamboyant or controversial.
Archbishop Roach does not anticipate any sudden U-turns in the bishops' leadership but something harder to gauge. What he fears, he said, is not conservative activism, but "a kind of deadlock."

HEADLINE: New Union Contract Lets G.M. Trim Some Labor Costs

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 2

 BODY:
After months of sometimes acrimonious negotiations and strikes that idled tens of thousands of workers, the United Automobile Workers union and the General Motors Corporation concluded a new three-year labor contract early this morning.
The deal, which will probably be ratified soon by 215,000 G.M. workers, averted a likely national walkout by the U.A.W. after Election Day. G.M. and the U.A.W. also settled a four-day strike at a crucial truck parts factory in Indianapolis this evening that had idled four G.M. truck assembly plants. Both sides continued trying tonight to resolve a walkout at a highly profitable assembly plant in Janesville, Wis., that makes medium-duty trucks and the mammoth Chevrolet and GMC Suburbans. 
Gerald A. Knechtel, G.M.'s vice president for personnel, said at a 2 A.M. news conference today that the new national labor contract generally followed the pattern of deals that the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation had already signed with the U.A.W. Those contracts were structured to make the Detroit auto makers keep overall employment close to current levels while letting them reduce labor costs to compete with nonunion factories that Japanese and European auto makers have built in the South. The employment guarantees slightly reduce the incentive for auto makers to rely on outside suppliers.
The deal does give the auto makers an incentive to hire more workers by allowing them to pay somewhat lower wages in auto parts factories they buy or build. Ford has already begun a broad review of what parts can now be manufactured in-house to make use of the lower wages.
But the auto makers, apparently including G.M., gained a little more flexibility this autumn to sell a handful of unprofitable auto parts factories. And while the union won wage increases that will exceed the inflation rate by an average of a couple of percentage points a year, it was not so aggressive in demanding pay increases as it has been in some contracts negotiated during other prosperous times in the auto industry.
"The U.A.W. has decided the only way to maintain union employment in the auto industry is to be more competitive on labor costs with the nonunion companies," said Ronald A. Glantz, an auto analyst at Dean Witter in San Francisco.
While U.A.W. officials were cheerful at their news conference, and they emphasized that their bargainers had agreed unanimously on the deal, John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, was a little more cautious.
"Like any negotiation, you never get everything you want," he said. "We're pleased with the way it has worked out; we can get the things done that we need to get done."
In a rare departure from G.M.'s legendary buttoned-down style, Mr. Smith and Mr. Knechtel both had open collars at the early morning news conference. Mr. Smith wore a dark gray tweed jacket, black slacks and a striped white shirt. Mr. Knechtel wore a black suit with a gray shirt. Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W. president, and his aides were also not wearing ties when they held a separate conference at G.M. headquarters here.
Auto makers have a tradition of letting the union take credit for labor contracts at first, particularly until the workers vote on ratification. Union concessions tend to be disclosed much later.
When Ford reached the first deal with the U.A.W. on Sept. 16, some auto analysts raised concerns that G.M., with its large and relatively inefficient work force, could not afford to follow Ford's example in guaranteeing to keep employment at a minimum of 95 percent of current levels. But those fears began to subside as word trickled out that the Ford contract would allow work force reductions to accommodate productivity gains. U.A.W. officials also said that while they needed a 95 percent guarantee at all three auto makers, they were prepared to show some flexibility with G.M. by excluding a few factories from this requirement.
The guarantees of employment levels are mainly intended to prevent the auto makers from transferring auto parts manufacturing to outside vendors and drastically trimming their own work forces.
G.M. and U.A.W. officials refused to discuss the details of the pact. Workers and investors will be interested in the arrangements that G.M. makes with workers at the parts factories that will be sold. G.M. particularly wanted, and apparently received, permission to sell a factory in Flint, Mich., that makes hinges and electric window mechanisms and a factory in Livonia, Mich., that makes interior car-door panels.
"I know they're going to go ahead with the sale, but I don't know what they're going to do by our workers," said James D. Hale, the president of the U.A.W. local at the Flint factory, in an interview on Friday. After a three-week strike by the Canadian Automobile Workers that ended on Oct. 23, G.M. agreed to guarantee for nine years the pensions and health benefits of workers at two parts factories in Ontario that it is selling.
The Canadian union has already reached separate deals with Chrysler and G.M. and is trying to reach an agreement with Ford by next Wednesday. A short strike there cannot be ruled out, but few industry experts expect a prolonged walkout.
Strikes anywhere can disrupt the flow of needed parts among factories. G.M. said on Friday that 19,000 of its American workers still had not been able to return to their jobs because of the lingering effects of its three-week strike.
There may still be a few isolated walkouts at G.M. factories in the months ahead. While the U.A.W. and G.M. concluded the national agreement this morning, many of the union's local units have not yet reached factory-level agreements over issues like assembly-line staffing or purchases of goods and services from outside vendors.
When asked whether local disputes might lead to further walkouts like the strikes in Janesville and Indianapolis, Mr. Yokich responded with a thinly veiled warning to G.M. "We can't tell you what's going to happen at the other locals -- I would suggest that the company work very hard and get their locals cleaned up," he said.
G.M.'s sprawling empire of assembly plants and auto parts factories, which produce a little more than 1 percent of the nation's economic output, has suffered several major strikes this year, during the greatest labor unrest in the North American automobile industry since 1970. In addition to the Canadian strike and the two current local walkouts, a 17-day strike last March at two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, forced G.M. to close most of its North American assembly plants and lay off 177,000 workers temporarily.
Analysts put G.M.'s losses from these strikes at about $1.3 billion in after-tax profits. The strikes have also cost the Federal Government as much as $600 million in taxes that G.M. would have paid on these profits.
G.M. recouped some of its losses from the Dayton strike by subsequently asking workers to put in a lot of overtime, and it may be able to do the same with the latest two walkouts, Wall Street experts said.
G.M., the nation's largest company in terms of sales, has a history of acceding to U.A.W. demands during strikes. But Mr. Smith contended that the latest walkouts in Janesville and Indianapolis had not forced the auto maker's hand. "This agreement started going before the truck strikes," he said. "I don't think the truck strikes affected it at all."
This morning's settlement came after Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich had publicly urged both sides on Friday to reach an agreement. Mr. Reich said that Labor Department officials had tried to "make sure that all parties know that there is a national interest at stake, that we hope and encourage them to reach a settlement."
But it was unclear whether Mr. Reich's efforts had affected the timing of this morning's deal. Labor Department officials also had told union leaders and company executives that Federal mediators were available if needed. But both sides' negotiators declined the offer.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT -- On the Final Weekend, a Restrained Clinton and an Insistent Dole;
Unity Is Stressed by President in Texas Visit

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 2

 BODY:
At a rousing rally in the shadow of the Alamo today, President Clinton began what he called "the last weekend of the last campaign of my entire life" with the upbeat oratory of unity and progress, promising to practice "the new politics of common ground" but getting in last licks at his opponent all the same.
"Common ground is better than division, and it works," Mr. Clinton told a crowd of thousands of supporters, using the dominant, poll-tested theme of his campaign in front of the old stone fort where Davy Crockett, Jim Bowie and company stood their ground against Santa Anna in the Texas war of independence from Mexico in 1836. 
 Surrounded by a bevy of Texas politicians, from former Gov. Ann W. Richards to Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros -- all of whom made sharp attacks on Bob Dole and Congressional Republicans -- Mr. Clinton strove to sound an appeal to reason, reciting his record on issues like declining crime, shrinking welfare rolls and a healthy economy.
"What do you think the Republicans would be saying" if they had a similar record? Mr. Clinton asked the cheering crowd under crystal blue skies and bright sunshine. "They'd be saying it is morning in America. They'd be saying that the President can virtually levitate."
But in a catch phrase he has begun using in the last two days and is apparently still experimenting with, Mr. Clinton also suggested that he was trailing in states like Texas because the election was "an affair of the heart," in which Democrats bore the burden of years of Republican efforts to demonize them as soft on crime and welfare. White House aides were later at some pains to explain or elaborate on Mr. Clinton's almost mystical language.
Campaigning with his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, in a state where he is trailing in the polls but hopes to pull off an upset, Mr. Clinton proved that his tongue is sharp enough when he wants it to be. He said that he had remembered the Alamo when the Republican-controlled Congress dared him to shut down the Government or accept its budget last fall.
"They said, 'Oh, he'll blink,' Mr. Clinton recounted. "And I said: 'You know, I'd a lot rather see the American people hurt for two or three weeks or two or three months than 20 or 30 years. Shut her down! I'm not going to buy your budget.' "
And he derided Mr. Dole's accusation this week that the national economy was at its worst level in 20 years. "I ask every person in Texas who believes it is the worst economy in 20 years to vote for Senator Dole, and every person who knows better to vote for me," Mr. Clinton said. "I'll gladly take the results of that election in Texas."
As usual, the party surrogates sitting beside him were much tougher. Mr. Cisneros, his voice booming, rolled off the list of Democratic catch phrases from F.D.R. to J.F.K. and accused the Republicans of efforts to cut the budget and attack Mr. Clinton's character that "have made this election personal."
Mixing Spanish and English, Ms. Richards assured the crowd that "Newt Gingrich y sus pistoleros are on the way out!" referring to the House Speaker and his "henchmen."
The President and Mrs. Clinton were joined on the platform by the actors Tommy Lee Jones and Jimmy Smits, and Mr. Clinton stepped up to the lectern to the strains of the theme from "Lonesome Dove."
After months of sharply worded television advertisements attacking Mr. Dole and just as many months of modest proposals for low-cost, popular programs aimed squarely at middle-class families, Mr. Clinton's aides said he had long intended to end the campaign on a conciliatory note.
The President used the speech here and his weekly radio address to sketch his bleak version of the state of the nation he campaigned to lead four years ago and his equally effusive view of the changes since then. In the process, he sought to paint his Presidency not as the conflicting series of accommodations, compromises and missteps that his critics attack, but as a consistent effort to forge a new kind of post-partisan politics.
"I had a simple strategy," Mr. Clinton said in the radio speech, summing up his efforts. "Reject old labels, false debates and divisive politics; instead, strengthen America's basic bargain -- opportunity for all Americans, responsibility from all Americans and a stronger community of all Americans."
To that end, Mr. Clinton said, he decided that he had to strive to balance the Federal budget while also protecting Medicare, Medicaid and educational and environmental programs, had to hire more police officers while also cracking down on guns and fostering crime prevention, and had to overhaul welfare while trying to create new jobs to move people off the rolls and into work.
Of course, Mr. Clinton's opponents and many objective observers would not agree that he has made such progress or has pursued such a lofty strategy. But he marshaled the statistics he loves to cite to make the best case he could: 10.7 million new jobs and 4.5 million new homeowners in the last four years, 2 million fewer people on welfare since he took office and crime rates at a 10-year low.
Later today, Mr. Clinton planned to campaign for Democratic Senate candidates in Louisiana and his home state, Arkansas, before flying off to Florida in hopes of becoming the first Democratic Presidential candidate to carry that state since Jimmy Carter in 1976.
In large and enthusiastic rallies in Santa Barbara, Calif.; El Paso, and Las Cruces, N.M., on Friday, Mr. Clinton reached into his grab bag of promises that amount to his agenda for a second term: offering tax credits and deductions for college education, connecting every school classroom to the Internet, expanding access to health insurance for children and the unemployed, extending the Family and Medical Leave Law to let parents attend teacher conferences and doctor's appointments with their children, and creating a corps of volunteers to tutor elementary school students in reading.
"If you want all these things I talked about," Mr. Clinton told his listeners at the edge of the Pacific in Santa Barbara, "in the end it will be to some extent an affair of the American heart.
"We must be willing to say, I tell you again, that in this country, all we need to know about you is whether you embrace our Constitution, our Bill of Rights, our Declaration of Independence; whether you are willing to show up for work or school tomorrow; whether you are willing to give your neighbors the elbow room to pursue their personal lives and their freedom; whether you are willing to treat people, even those with whom you dramatically disagree, with genuine respect, if they are law-abiding, hard-working citizens.
"And we ought to say, 'If you're that way, we don't need to know anything else about you -- you're part of our America, and we're going to build a bridge together to the 21st century.' "

HEADLINE: Oct. 27-Nov. 2;
Quick, Is the Economy Better or Worse?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
At the campaign's end, it was about the economy. But the question was which economy.
There is the economy Bob Dole kept talking about -- the "Clinton recession" he called it -- in which the 2.2 percent growth in the gross national product announced last week for the third quarter was a sure sign that good times were over. But it was hardly the statistic he was looking for, and by most estimates economic growth for the year will be 2.8 percent, well above Republican and Democratic predictions 12 months ago. 
 Then there is President Clinton's economy, where jobs grow on trees and -- his best news of all last week -- the deficit is headed down dramatically. For the 1996 fiscal year, it was $107 billion, hardly chump change but the lowest level since Ronald Reagan took office in 1981. It has declined 63 percent since Mr. Clinton came to office. Naturally, both parties haggled all week over which side was responsible for that. And neither mentioned that, for reasons too complicated for campaign speeches, it is likely to go back up. DAVID E. SANGER

HEADLINE: Dole Should Look at Affirmative Action Facts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bob Dole has attacked affirmative action programs as being ineffective and unfair, arguing that they create discrimination rather than equal opportunity (front page, Oct. 29). 
 But the reality is more complex than his political rhetoric indicates.
In a study of 3,200 companies of all sizes in Atlanta, Boston, Detroit and Los Angeles that compared companies using affirmative action to those that do not, we found that minority-group members hired under affirmative action had weaker educational credentials than the white males.
But when managers were asked to judge their performance on the job, minority-group members and women hired under affirmative action were rated no worse than white males.
Most studies find that minority-group members in the United States still have fewer resources and less opportunity to pursue educational credentials than do whites; and even with comparable credentials, members of minority groups and women still face discrimination in the labor market relative to white males. Affirmative action helps to equalize opportunity across these groups.
 
HARRY J. HOLZER
DAVID NEUMARK
East Lansing, Mich., Oct. 30, 1996
 
The writers are professors of economics at Michigan State University.
