HEADLINE: Can Harvard's Powerhouse Alter the Course of Black Studies?

BYLINE: By Peter Applebome; Peter Applebome is the national education correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
On a gorgeous early fall afternoon, in a conference room overlooking Harvard Square, Henry Louis Gates Jr., has somehow moved from Hegel, to the lives of black slaves to the starship Enterprise.
 "The thing about black culture has always been that it was fundamentally dependent on the dominant culture, but it turned it inside out," he told five American Civilization graduate students from such disparate places as Japan, Alaska and the South Bronx. "It mimics it. It signifies upon it. It ironizes it. It riffs on it. How many people watch "Star Trek?" There's one that I really love where this guy gets trapped for eternity within a negative universe. This guy is trying to kill him, and if he kills him, then the whole universe will die because of matter and anti-matter. It was a relationship that was hostile, but, it was also the opposite, complicitous, in the way that matter can't exist without anti-matter, in the way that black people by pushing the limit, living on the fringe, define what happens in the rest of society." 
 Life is full of those kinds of excursions these days at Harvard's Department of Afro-American Studies, which since the arrival of Mr. Gates in 1991 from Duke has gone from a famously underachieving, largely unwanted stepchild at Harvard to perhaps the most celebrated assortment of scholars in America. For better or worse, and people see some of both, it's academia's version of the best party in town.
 On one level, the department's celebrity -- particularly with the arrival of the philosopher and author Cornel West from Princeton in 1994 and the sociologist and policy guru William Julius Wilson from the University of Chicago this fall -- is a yawningly predictable case of the rich getting richer. What could be less surprising than Harvard cornering the market on talent in a high-profile, left-leaning field?
 The question worth asking then, is what this means for African-American studies and the academy in general. O.K. Gates, West, Wilson Inc. -- and other less celebrated, but equally high-powered scholars who work with them -- are great for Harvard. What does it mean for the rest of us?
 Harvard certainly is not alone in embracing African-American studies, at a time that hundreds of departments and programs are competing for scholars and attention. But if the department that Mr. Gates has built in the end lives up to all its celebrity, it will have something to do with Mr. Gates' unlikely noodling around in the kingdom of Mr. Spock. It will be because Gates et al. will play a major role in finally taking African-American studies from an often marginalized and patronized field at the edges of the academy to its center.
That would be no small feat in a field born of campus unrest rather than academic initiatives and one that is often characterized as encompassing both serious scholarship and dubious racial polemics.
 "Everything today is show business, but you have a very interesting combination there," said Stanley Crouch, the iconoclastic black writer and critic. "You have a major scholar in Wilson, you have an extremely good organizer in Gates, you have an exceptional performer in Cornel West. So you have everything. Now, like anything that happens in Hollywood, you can have all the elements right and you can end up with a flop or you can end up with "The Godfather," where you have popular entertainment, enduring art and something that's extremely profitable."
 He continued: "But I'll tell you, that Gates is an extremely ambitious man, who I don't think wants to go down in history as just a guy who opportunistically got ahead because of the inability of white people to tell the difference between black quality and black fraud or black quality and black mediocrity. He's very ambitious and very smart, and you have to watch someone like that. He just might turn into something."
 "In retrospect, everything looks inevitable right?" Mr. Gates said as he peered at the sheet of yellow legal-sized paper that contains the outline for the department he wanted to build at Harvard. "But I'm telling you, not long ago, there was no prayer that this could happen. Once I got here we decided to concentrate on the humanities, cultural studies, go with our strengths. Be modest, but go deep. I'm mixing my metaphors here. I run out of sugar by 3 o'clock."
 Mr. Gates may run out of sugar, but his energy never seems to flag, which may be what it took to build the department at Harvard. A 46-year-old Yale graduate with a doctorate in English language and literature from Cambridge University, Henry Louis (Skip) Gates has gone from Yale to Cornell to Duke to Harvard, where he has built a department that has been compared to the monumental 1927 Yankees at the same time he has been cranking out pieces for publications, particularly The New Yorker, on race, politics, film and culture, at a pace that looks like a full-time job to most mortals.
 Of Harvard's big three, he's perhaps the most controversial, considered by some skeptics, particularly at the schools he left, a little too glib and ambitious for his own good. Those at more established black studies programs, like the one at Temple University, bristle at the notion that he's setting Harvard up as the model of how to do African-American studies.
 But, like Bill Clinton, another former Yalie whose energy, brains, charm and political savvy he shares, Mr. Gates has had great success in winning over his doubters. So far he has raised $11 million for various black studies projects at Harvard. One sign of the department's growing status is its move later this year from temporary offices over a drugstore to the campus' new Barker Center for the Humanities -- where the department and its research arm, the W.E.B. Dubois Institute for Afro-American Studies, will be the second-biggest tenant.
 "Part of Skip's mission is creating a constituency for what we're doing, and he's very good at it," said Kwame Anthony Appiah, a noted philosopher and novelist from Britain. Mr. Appiah is often viewed as Mr. Gates's intellectual alter-ego, and went with Mr. Gates from Cambridge to Yale to Cornell to Duke to Harvard. "What people don't understand is that he's a guy who really enjoys his life. He's not a guy who wants to be a big fish in a small pond. He wants to have the company of other impressive people, build something important, do something that matters. And that's what he's doing here."
 Liberal orthodoxy notwithstanding, Harvard's experience with black people and black studies has been extremely mixed. In its earliest days, students and professors and at least two university presidents owned slaves. As late as 1922, a university president, Abbott Lawrence Lowell, prohibited black students from living in the freshman dormitories, as was required for all white students. "I was in Harvard," said the writer W. E. B. Du Bois, who in 1895 became the first black recipient of a doctorate from Harvard, "not of it."
 Black studies at Harvard came about as a result of the campus unrest in the 1960's, and partly because of that, it never prospered, being viewed more as a political necessity than an intellectual one. When he was recruited from Duke in 1991, Mr. Gates began by having Henry Rosovsky, then Harvard's dean of the faculty of arts and sciences, coach him in the arcane academic politics of Harvard. The two sipped sherry late in the afternoon and plotted strategy on how to build support for African American studies. . What emerged from those sessions and others were ideas specific to Harvard and ones about the discipline as a whole.
 At Harvard, Mr. Gates presides over both the Department of Afro-American studies and its W. E. B. Du Bois Institute for Afro-American Research. The department has seven faculty members, all with joint appointments in other fields like English, philosophy or economics. Forty-three students are majoring in Afro-American studies. The department now offers only undergraduate degrees, but a doctoral program is being planned.
 The Du Bois Institute, the oldest research institute in the field, this year sponsors 23 fellows studying subjects ranging from African oral literature, to the Harlem Renaissance, to the Atlantic slave trade to jazz and hip-hop.
 "To me what we're doing, not only us but other people in our field, is trying to establish the field as a valid area of study, as a valid area of intellectual inquiry," Mr. Gates said. "Imagine you were in a field that had been created by students occupying the library and the president's office. Chemistry wasn't created that way. English wasn't. There's a lot of energy these days in African-American studies, but there's a lot of wishful thinking, too. You can't make it up, man. You have to do the archival work, you can't just intuit the historical work, which is a lot of what's going on."
 Whether you accept his notion of the field in general, it's hard not to be stunned by how much is now going on in the department and the Du Bois Institute. Mr. Gates and Mr. Appiah, as co-editors, are hard at work on a breathtakingly ambitious revival of Du Bois' greatest dream, an Encyclopedia Africana of the entire African experience, both on the continent and around the world. There are already parts of a pilot version on CD-ROM with plans to eventually do the work on line, on disk and in print. In 1994, Harvard became home to the Image of the Black in Western Art photo archive, started in 1960 by Jean and Dominique de Menil of Houston, which documents 5,000 years of the representation of blacks in Western art in various media.
 In addition, Mr. Gates and Mr. Appiah revived Transition, a cheeky journal of culture and politics that was founded in Uganda in 1961 by some of Africa's best-known intellectuals. The journal features contributions by a glittering cast of black and white intellectuals. It's sort of a high-IQ, multicultural Wired for the world's 3,000 most clued-in academics and literary types. An upcoming issue, for example, is dubbed The White Issue -- non-whites writing on white culture, with pieces on subjects like the racial politics of gardening, "white trash," the cultural significance of white folks' hair, filmmakers Leni Reifenstahl and Martin Scorsese and white Africans.
 The Harvard Guide to African-American History, modeled after the Harvard Guide to American History, is a comprehensive guide to primary and secondary sources for African-American studies. Like the American history guide first published 40 years ago, it attempts to define the field and its source materials.
 The Black Periodical Literature Project, HE??TK??started at Yale in 1980 and all-but completed, is an attempt to collect and annotate all the short stories, poems and literary criticism that appeared in African-American periodicals from 1827 until 1940. The trans-Atlantic Slave Trade Database is an attempt to gather detailed information on some 25,000 voyages in the Atlantic slave trade from 1650 to 1867 into a single database that will be the largest uniform, consolidated database of its kind in the world.
 And beyond that, Harvard is attempting to become the beehive around which black intellectual life buzzes with its conferences, lectures and an extended ensemble of regular contributors, ranging from the playwright and 1986 Nobel Laureate Wole Soyinko to the novelist Jamaica Kincaid to the filmmaker Spike Lee.
 "What I want to see happen, from a purely academic point of view, is I'd like to see people in our department be part of the generation that ends that cycle that African-American studies have been trapped in for a century -- each generation has to reinvent the wheel," Mr. Gates said, "the basic facts, things as basic as how many slaves left the West Coast of Africa boarded on ships, and how many got off on the other side. Those basic facts have never been established. You kill a field that way. I think we are doomed or blessed to be the generation that finally digs everything up so that another generation can do dazzling, brilliant, elaborate analysis."
 Mr. Gates' grand ambitions might sound wildly overblown if not for the team he has already put in place at Harvard. In truth, African-American studies at Harvard is far more than Skip Gates, William Julius Wilson and Cornel West. The department includes Mr. Appiah, an expert in African and African-American philosophy and literary theory; Evelyn Brooks Higginbotham, an expert in African-American women's history; John F. Kain, an economist now studying the impact of suburbanization on the educational achievement of African-American children; James Lorand Matory, who studies African and Afro-Latin religion, and Werner Sollors, who specializes in 20th century literary history. All of the current faculty are on joint appointments with Afro-American Studies and with other departments -- a framework that is not uncommon at Harvard. And they often interact with other distinguished black faculty members at Harvard like Charles Ogletree and Randall Kennedy of Harvard's Law School, the sociologist Orlando Patterson, the government professor Martin Kilson, the education professor Sara Lawrence-Lightfoot and others.
 Still, the department's three high-profile stars help define what Mr. Gates wants to do.
Cornel West's office is like the academic answer to the "Sorcerer's Apprentice." It's as if the books stacked, horizontally, vertically and diagonally, piled in groaning, rickety piles on the floor, poking from the tops of overloaded shelves, have multiplied time and again, until there's nothing left but the space on his desk that's free of them, and there's not much of that.
 In the same way, Mr. West's lectures are far-ranging rambles through the vast thickets of race, culture and class. Mr. West, whose appointment is also at the Divinity School, is best known for his eclectic disquisitions on race and politics in books like "Race Matters," published in 1993, that combine elements of religion, democratic socialism and trade unionism into a new vision for the left and for racial rapprochement.
 Mr. West, 43, is the most overtly political of the three. But agree with him or not, it's hard not to be mesmerized by his teaching, and his classes are already among the most popular on campus.
 "The single most memorable class I've taken at Harvard was West's lecture on African-American music," said Nell Brown, a white senior majoring in Afro-American studies. "I remembered the way he closed his eyes as Ella Fitzgerald was singing, and you could tell, he just loved it so much. It was just a great experience. Plus it's amazing how accessible they are, even ones like Gates and West. I've found it easier to get time with them than with some associate professors of history."
 On the day, Mr. Gates was teaching his seminar (along with Ms. Higginbotham) Mr. West was teaching to a packed lecture hall at the opening session of his survey course in African-American studies.
 Attired in a blue suit, one hand clutching a piece of chalk, the other a well-worn copy of W. E. B. Du Bois's "The Souls of Black Folk," he paced back and forth, arms out, leaning forward, bending back, voice rising and falling, one foot in the academy, the other in the pulpit.
 "Will we be able to talk about race in such a way we can get beyond the finger-pointing and name calling and actually be self-critical and critical of each other so we can be empowered and enabled instead of paralyzed and debilitated?" he said. "It's so easy to talk about race in America, Du Bois would say, in a way in which we're paralyzed, and debilitated or just completely depressed."
His voice drops to a flat tone of generic Middle American ennui.
 "Dang, this problem's just so overwhelming. Let's have a drink. How's Michael Jordan? Let's turn on Oprah. Maybe she can help us solve the race problem. She's so nice. She's doing really well. She's No. 1."
 The Cornel West voice returns.
 "But she's got relatives and friends broke as the 10 Commandments," he said. "Just focusing on Oprah won't show us how the race problem can be solved. It's more complex than that. Du Bois said begin with art, because art tries to take us outside of ourselves. It's a matter of trying to create an atmosphere and a context so conversation can flow back and forth, and we can be influenced by each other."
 If Mr. West is both scholar and showman, William Julius Wilson is so staid, serious and somber, you figure he's the grown-up who's been brought in to maintain some semblance of order.
 His office is over at the Kennedy School, not Afro-American Studies, and though he moved in in September, it's impeccable. The books, including long neat rows of professional journals, are arrayed with perfect precision. His desk is spotless. While both Mr. Gates and Mr. West rattle on at a fever pitch, ideas tumbling around like laundry in a dryer, Mr. Wilson, in his dark glen plaid suit, oxford blue shirt and sober tie, is quiet, thoughtful, austere.
 Mr. Wilson first gained attention in 1978 for his still-controversial book, "The Declining Significance of Race." The book noted the increasing divergence of the black middle-class and the black poor in an attempt to take a look with more nuances at the workings of race in the United States and to develop more effective strategies for addressing inner-city poverty.
 His "The Truly Disadvantaged", published in 1987, is one of the most influential books on inner-city poverty, and his new book, "When Work Disappears," despite getting mixed reviews, has helped solidify his reputation as one of the most influential thinkers on race, class and poverty. Admirers say he has, as much as anyone, pointed policy makers toward the real economic issues, such as job loss, at the heart of inner-city poverty. Some black critics, however, say he has understated the persistence of racism.
 His arrival at Harvard after 24 years at the University of Chicago -- and previous courting by Harvard -- was Mr. Gates's biggest coup and perhaps biggest surprise, because Mr. Wilson's sober policy perspective is so different from the multicultural intellectual pyrotechnics associated with Mr. West and Mr. Gates.
 But, in the end, he said, his decision to move came because he agreed with Mr. Gates that many great minds are better than a few, that both in terms of affecting policy and being stimulated, there's a real logic to Mr. Gates' efforts to make Harvard something akin to the Brookings Institution for black America.
 "I didn't make the move because I was trying to enhance my academic career," said Mr. Wilson, 60, as he sat upright in a straight-backed chair, his hands folded in his lap. "I made the move because I wanted to be around a community of scholars who are public intellectuals, people who are doing very, very careful work but are concerned about reaching a wide audience, people who are concerned about the direction of the country and are trying to influence public perception, public policy. And there's a collection of scholars here, a critical mass of public intellectuals, the likes of which we haven't seen anywhere."
 There were other attractions.
 Mr. Wilson, who is not teaching this semester while he promotes his new book, said he knew of no African-American studies program with a focus on public policy and he was intrigued by Mr. Gates's desire for him to build such a program at Harvard. He also liked Mr. Gates's notion of a department that was expansive and looking from the black experience outward rather than merely focusing on the minutiae of the black experience itself.
 "We're looking at the growing convergence between Europe and the United States with respect to the concentration of poverty and race and the ways countries deal with those issues," he said. "We feel this discussion would help to inform the public policy debate, not just in this country, but in other countries as well. Countries in Europe are very, very concerned about what is happening in their inner cities. We gave a lecture at the London School of Economics in June, the day of the subway strike. People said no one would show up because of the strike. Well, the lecture was entitled "Are American Style Ghettos Emerging in Europe?" and the place was packed. So I think it's important for students who are concerned about issues of race to learn to get across cultural perspectives on these problems."
 If Mr. West's office is agreeable chaos and Mr. Wilson's is scholarly precision, Mr. Gates's is a pragmatic mix of the ethereal and the worldly, intellect and celebrity. There are plenty of books and tapes but there's also the Sony tape recorder, on which he records his New Yorker interviews; a framed ad his publisher took out for his memoir, "Colored People"; and pictures of him with Al and Tipper Gore, with his mentor at Harvard, Henry Rosovsky, with historian John Hope Franklin from Duke, and others.
 He's wearing a checked oxford blue shirt, a dark tie and sport coat, and everything about him -- from his tweedy look to his stunning verbal facility to his endless connections -- suggests the kind of figure a mad chemist might have invented as the perfect person to make African-American studies a success at Harvard.
 Indeed, while Mr. West seems open to anything -- Tolstoy as the greatest oblique chronicler of the African-American experience, for example -- Mr. Gates is as much strategist as thinker, studying the terrain, calculating the angles, figuring out the next moves to lure the next big stars. He's open about his intention to bring more big names to Harvard and adamant that it's about more than empire building.
 "The model for building excellence in every other great department in any given field has been to bring people together. Why should it be any different for us?" he said. "What happened with us when Afro-American studies was invented in the late '60's was they would put one here, one in Columbia, one at Yale, one at Princeton, it was like Johnny Appleseed dropping seeds, and 20 years later some great apple tree was supposed to sprout up. But we want to build a forest. The English department is the second or third best in the United States because you've got 20 good scholars. The history department is excellent because you have a dozen good scholars. That is the model for building a field. But where the logic broke down was in the creation of Afro-American studies departments. When we try to do what every other department is doing, we appear anomalous. But it's not. We're just building in the traditional way that departments in the academy build."
To some academics, there's something suspect about the blend of celebrity, appealing to a mass audience and advocacy that goes into the idea of being a public intellectual, a tag that has been applied to Gates, West, Wilson and others at Harvard. And some professors at Harvard quietly bristle at the notion that although the department's stars, like Mr. West and Mr. Gates, may be celebrities, they are not producing the kind of serious scholarship that is expected of others at Harvard. But the majority view is that it is hard to argue with the turnaround Mr. Gates has produced in the department and that the notion of celebrity scholars and public intellectuals hardly began at Harvard with Mr. Gates.
 "Harvard has always had people like this," said Harvard's president, Neil Rudenstine. "You can go back to Ralph Waldo Emerson or Henry David Thoreau -- he wasn't on the faculty, but he was around here enough. Different institutions have different temperaments and personae, and Harvard's always been a place where outspoken public intellectuals and scholars coexisted, either side by side or often in the same person."
 Outside Harvard Yard the view is often a little different.
 "Grrrrrrrrrrrrr. She's not going," growled a spokeswoman for the University of Pennsylvania when the mere mention of interviewing legal scholar Lani Guinier came up. Ms. Guinier is now at Penn, but is known to be on Mr. Gates' wish list. (Ms. Guinier, usually accessible, did not respond.) "Hasn't enough been written about Harvard? Don't you want to write about Penn?"
 Envy aside, the most outspoken critic of Harvard's department may be Molefi Kete Asante, chairman of the department of African American studies at Temple University.
 Temple has the nation's largest African-American studies program, one that has produced 42 Ph.D.'s and is the dominant Afrocentric program in the country, with its own flurry of journals and research projects like its Journal of Black Studies, and journals on dance and drama.
 Mr. Asante says he likes and admires the people at Harvard, and they say the same about him, but they represent the two poles of black scholarship: Temple stresses a "transcontinental and transgenerational" Afrocentric interpretation of culture and the black experience, stressing African heritage and roots. Harvard stresses the place of the black experience in the American experience. Mr. Asante argues that Eurocentric scholarship has slighted the role of the African experience and that to understand the black experience in America or elsewhere, you have to start with an Afrocentric approach. The scholars at Harvard, for the most part, agree with some elements of the Afrocentric approach, but they consider much of its scholarship suspect and its focus misplaced.
 "I think we're primarily interested in modernity, where they tend to spend more time on the pre-modern period, Egypt," said Mr. West. "I think they're partly right, but I still tend to think the modern experience of black people is a bit more discontinuous. There was a disruption. Asante's a good friend. We just have very different starting points."
 But Mr. Asante, for all his profession of admiration for Mr. Gates et al. isn't overflowing with praise for them. He said Mr. West profoundly misdiagnoses the ills at the heart of black life and Mr. Wilson's view of the declining significance of race has been proved wrong. And he said that by relying on joint appointments with other programs rather than a unified departmental approach, Mr. Gates' vision of African-American studies at Harvard is diluted, eviscerated and unfocused."
 "We're a full-fledged department with 13 faculty members, 12 black, one white, and we offer B.A., M.A. and Ph.D. programs," he said. "Harvard only has a B.A. degree. They're not in the same ball game with us. In fact, by relying on joint appointments, they've committed discipline suicide. When departments around the country look for a model, it's not Harvard. It's Temple. What they're offering is African-American studies on white terms."
 Similarly, Mr. Asante takes offense at Mr. Gates' notion that much of the Afrocentric teaching relies on suspect research and that the basic facts of African-American studies need to be defined once and for all by projects like the ones at Harvard.
 "Get out of here," Mr. Asante said. "We're not waiting for the messiah to come from Harvard. The database is already at Temple."
 With some 300 universities offering departments or programs in black studies, there are certainly any number of other approaches.
 Manning Marable, the distinguished historian at Columbia University, said that while Harvard is geared toward political and media elites from the White House to The New Yorker, and Temple is focused on a fairly small pool of Afrocentric scholars, neither is in touch with the black mainstream, including black students at historically black universities.
 "If we are really going to change the black community, we must educate those institutions which are educating black students. And that is what Harvard does not do," he said. "Harvard has an extraordinary group of scholars, but Wilson's concern is to influence the Democratic Party and President Clinton. My concern is to influence the Congressional Black Caucus and the N.A.A.C.P."
 To that end, Columbia's Institute for Research in African-American Studies recently sponsored a conference on African-American studies, bringing together participants from historically black and historically white institutions. Mr. Marable said he also writes a column for 250 black newspapers and his institute is surveying black households around the country to document the views of mainstream African-Americans, something that neither Harvard nor Temple is likely to do.
 "Black studies is about a commitment to academic excellence, but it also has to be socially responsible -- that's really the model Du Bois had in mind," he said. "It only has vibrancy and meaning if it illuminates problems in the daily life of black people and its historical roots. There's a profound crisis out there, and I don't think as a whole we've done a very good job of addressing it."
 Still, if some other departments think Harvard may get -- or claim -- too much attention, more common is a recognition that just as Harvard sets the pace for so much in academia, it's full-bore embrace of African-American studies and the high-powered team it is putting in place ultimately has to help the field overall.
 "I think the only bad publicity is no publicity," said Frank Matthews, publisher of Black Issues in Higher Education. "Given the caliber of the intellectuals there, it bodes well for all the black studies programs around the country. We tend to overlook other programs, but that is not Harvard's fault. That is just the nature of being the No. 1 institution."
 And Mr. West adds that the trick is not to be seduced by the perquisites of celebrity and status at Harvard, but to use it in positive ways.
 "You can use anything for good," he said. "You can let celebrity status go to your head, which is stupid, because you're up one day, down the next, or you can use it to highlight issues that end up not being highlighted, issues of working people, poor people, the legacy of white supremacy. Clinton and Dole aren't talking about it. If you have visibility, whether deserved or not, you need to use it to connect to a cause bigger than you. I think that's what we're trying to do here."

HEADLINE: Courses at Your Convenience

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN; Maria Newman is an editor at The New York Times.

 BODY:
A student in Tisha Bender's Reading for Writing class at the New School for Social Research in New York City wanted to contribute to an ongoing class discussion.
 "Now that I have cleaned up from dinner, cleaned out the potty, put away the laundry and congratulated my friend on giving birth, I will hope to tap into the 'collegiate' side of my brain," wrote Stacy Moskowitz, the student. 
 Like all her classmates -- and the professor -- this student was not in a classroom. She was at home in Hillsdale, N.J., tapping into the class through cyberspace.
 The class is among the fast-growing number of continuing education courses that colleges and universities around the country have begun offering to anyone with access to a computer, a modem and an Internet address.
 The trend is an outgrowth of colleges making more frequent use of computer technology in undergraduate degree-granting programs or to earn master's degrees in business administration or in engineering at schools like Harvard and Duke. Some colleges are offering classes that are a combination of on-line dialogues, videotaped lectures and in-class work that, of course, require being on campus.
 But now students who are not enrolled full-time in such universities, and those who live far away from a particular university, can take their pick of a plethora of courses without ever setting foot on those campuses, if they have access to the Internet or the World Wide Web. No one knows how many on-line classes are being offered, but a search of the Web indicates that new ones are being added almost daily.
 The selection of courses is mind-boggling. They range from "How to Open a Beer Bar or Brew Pub" (New School), to "Faces of Ancient Egypt" (University of Chicago), and "Shamans and Healing: the Anthropology of Traditional Medicine" (University of California at Los Angeles Extension).
 With on-line classes, if a student prefers to work in the wee hours of the night, he or she can access a professor's lectures and even a class discussion at any time.
 Students usually enroll on line, pay their tuition on line via credit card -- fees for on-line courses are generally comparable to that of on-campus classes -- and then receive a password that will give them access to a world of learning.
 Lectures are presented on line, and professors may pose questions to begin the on-line discussions. In a physical classroom, a lecture can last an hour and a half. In the virtual classroom, it can last for weeks.
 Sometimes students meet with their professors in "chat rooms" with catchy names like the Patsy Room at the Blue Moon Cafe, a place in the virtual class "Parent-Child Relationships" taught by Charles Smith, a professor at Kansas State University.
 Students can retreat to the privacy of E-mail to consult with their professors, and the required writing assignments or exams are graded via E-mail.
 Some professors grouse about not having one-on-one contact: Students cannot hear the inflection in a professor's voice when he or she is trying to make a point.
 "Sarcasm, for example, is very difficult to convey in this medium," said Andrew Shaindlin, who was the director of Bruin, an on-line program of courses offered by the alumni office of Brown University. But Mr. Shaindlin, who pioneered on-line alumni education at Brown, said that an advantage to on-line education is that students and professors have a written record of what everyone in the class says during discussions.
 "In the written format, you can still interpret what people are saying, but you can cut and paste exactly what they wrote when you respond to them," Mr. Shaindlin said.
 The new technology has spawned a new language in academia, with professors tossing around phrases like "asynchronous learning network" -- a term used to describe a conversation between professors and their students that doesn't take place all at once, but rather as students log on and retrieve or send messages. They talk about "lurkers" -- those students who enroll in class and observe all the conversations, but who choose not to contribute.
 Universities are conducting seminars to discuss the implications of these new tools on learning, like a workshop this month at Virginia Tech, in Blacksburg, Va., with panel discussions entitled "E-literacy: Renegotiating Pedagogy in Electronic Environments," or "The Computer Is Down -- and So Am I," and finally, "Muse Meets Mouse."
 The explosion of on-line learning has also led many scholars to worry over the future of traditional classroom learning. Kathy McGuire, the director of Distance Learning at the U.C.L.A. Extension, a continuing education program affiliated with the University of California in Los Angeles, said scholars should be looking at the new technology as a way to reach older students, who every year make up a larger proportion of college populations nationwide.
 "They're not going to stop learning, but they're not going to want to drive all over the place to do it," she said.
 A peek at some on-line classes shows that serious discussions are taking place in a format that requires students to carefully articulate their thoughts as they write them into cyberspace for classmates to see. Some of the discussions are also amusing.
 In a class entitled "The History of Western Civilization" offered at Boise State University in Utah, in between wide-ranging dialogue about whether the Roman Emperor Augustus truly believed in "The Republic," one student breaks in: "Hey ya'll get off the Web and turn on old-fashioned cable TV. The movie Cleopatra is on all night tonight on AMC. 1934, but looks like it's been color-enhanced. Pass the popcorn!"
 "Election96" offered by the New School, Professor Herbert Greenhut described the course to students and then proposed several questions to guide a discussion on the role of the Federal Government in issues of concern to voters during the Presidential election. The students, who ranged from a doctor in New York to a retiree in New Mexico and another student from Canada, sounded off on the topics in a discussion that went from an analysis of free public schools to the widening disparity of wealth in America.
 Here is a sampling of colleges or universities that offer on-line continuing-education classes. For more information, search through the home pages that many individual colleges and universities have set up on the Web or call the school of your choice for more information.
 Brown University
 (http://www.brown.edu) A course called "Democracy in America" will be offered this spring; (401) 863-3307.
 California State University System
 (http://sieg.calstate.edu/itsi) About half of its 22 campuses offer some non-credit and credit courses on line in such fields as literature and business; (310) 985-2740.
 Indiana University School of Continuing Education Studies

 (http://www.indiana.edu/scs/dl.html) More than a dozen courses this fall in psychology, writing, computer science and journalism; (317) 274-3449.

 Kansas State University

SECTION: Section 6; Page 24; Column 4; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1005 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Just Driving By

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
IT BEGAN WITH A SLIP of the tongue by President Clinton. At a campaign visit to a Rhode Island hospital, he joined the criticism of limiting maternity stays to 24 hours. But instead of reading his derogation of drive-by deliveries, a phrase first directed in print last year at hurry-up hospitals by Carol M. Ostrom of The Seattle Times, Mr. Clinton mistakenly used the term drive-by pregnancies, a quite different, not unknown but hitherto unlabeled problem. A Dole-Kemp news release called attention to this minor gaffe under the headline "Much More Fun Than a Drive-In Movie."
This focused the attention of lexicographers on the adoption of a compound adjective by speakers who like to be on the cusp of English usage: drive-by. 
 "Two men were shot to death on Hollywood streets in separate 'drive-by' incidents" was the lead of an Associated Press article from Los Angeles on Feb. 12, 1981, in the first citation I can find of the term; its use within quotation marks indicates it had been in spoken use earlier. From its first, literal meaning -- "gunfire from a vehicle driving past the target" -- drive-by shooting soon assumed the meaning of "random, senseless violence aimed not at a particular victim but at any individual nearby."
Drive-by delivery was preceded by drive-through delivery, first cited in June 1995 in The Chicago Tribune, and defined as "shortened hospital stay for childbirth" by John and Adele Algeo in their Among the New Words feature in the Spring 1996 American Speech quarterly. Drive-through began with fast-food chains (based on drive-in, coined in 1933 by a New Jersey movie theater operator) and was picked up by banks (which also use drive-up), both serving customers who never had to leave their cars.
But it is drive-by, not drive-through, that is getting metaphorical extension in the language. In a January 1994 article on "squeegee men," Newsweek reported on a "a new fad -- drive-by haranguings." A year later, Anne H. Soukhanov reported in The Atlantic Monthly Michael G. Gartner's use of drive-by hatred, which she defined as "seemingly motiveless acts of loathing directed at a victim not personally known to the perpetrator." Margaret Carlson of Time later that year wrote of "liberal baby-boomers, who thought drive-by sex and drugs were fine for them but want limits for their offspring."
As it is used more often, the compound adjective is losing its frightening quality and is accentuating its random or casual sense: "You can hear," wrote The Washington Post of Jack Kemp's debate performance, "an increasing volume of drive-by criticism like this on the Republican side."

Hole Card
 
 Tom Brokaw of NBC called to ask me about Vice President Al Gore's charge that the Dole-Kemp suggestion to cut Federal income tax rates by 15 percent would "blow a hole in the deficit."
Because that charge was repeated by Clinton surrogates, it is safe to assume that Democrats carefully considered that phrase. But the figure of speech is off key: to blow a hole in means "to destroy" or at least "to diminish"; the image is that of a torpedo striking a ship below its Plimsoll line.
However, to blow a hole in the deficit is to reduce the deficit, a consummation devoutly to be wished by just about everyone in politics. The meaning Mr. Gore intended was that the Dole tax-cutting idea would increase, balloon or even skyrocket the deficit -- thereby to blow a hole in hopes of balancing the budget.
Mr. Brokaw's observation was sound, and he was right to torpedo the overblown rhetoric. This did not stop the House majority leader Dick Armey, from subsequently telling David Brinkley of ABC, perhaps tongue in cheek, that the Clinton agenda was "likely to blow a big hole in the deficit and result in the need for massive tax increases."

The Scheme Plan

 Democratic campaigners adopted a two-track approach: Vice President Gore employed a railroad track in "It would knock our economy off track," and then switched to a hunting trope in deriding the Government shutdown: "President Clinton stopped them dead in their tracks."
Bob Dole tried to sidetrack the deft Democratic response to the Dole tax package. Mr. Clinton called his own proposal a "targeted plan," while characterizing the Dole proposal as a "risky scheme."
His use of scheme riled Dole. "I'm a little offended by this word scheme," he said in their second joint appearance. "Last time, you talked about a 'risky scheme,' and then Vice President Gore repeated it about 10 times."
Is the noun scheme pejorative, as the verb to scheme is? Fred Mish at Merriam-Webster says it is, and Prof. Randolph Quirk of University College in London agrees: "Used to designate a plan," says Quirk, "scheme has a negative connotation." But David Crystal, editor of The Cambridge Encyclopedia of Language, differs: "The noun has come down to us as a neutral term. I think of its connotation as quite positive." (He probably benefits from his insurance scheme.)
My judgment is that the noun scheme in British usage can be either positive or negative, but in American usage, the word is always negative. Here, a plan is a "design," which is good, while a scheme is more of a "plot," which is bad. A man with a plan is to be admired, but a schemer is to be distrusted. No wonder Dole took offense.
The G.O.P. Vice Presidential candidate, Jack Kemp, used a football metaphor skillfully: "We cannot just run the clock out on the 20th century." However, he missed the extra point on the classics with "Clearly, the Gordian knot needs to be broken in one fell swoop."
The difficult knot was tied by Gordius, king of Phrygia, who decreed that it would be untied only by the future ruler of all Asia; Alexander the Great crossed him up by cutting the knot with his sword. Thus, a Gordian knot can be untied or cut, but not -- as Kemp suggested -- broken, even in one fell swoop (in which fell means "fierce, cruel," evoking the image of a hawk dropping suddenly on its prey, and has the same root as felon).
