SECTION: Section 6; Page 42; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 8211 words

HEADLINE: Adventures of a Republican Revolutionary

BYLINE: By Jeffrey Goldberg; Jeffrey Goldberg is a contributing writer for the Magazine. His last article, about the F.D.A.'s war on tobacco, appeared in August.

 BODY:
Mark W. Neumann, A FRESHMAN REPUBLICAN Congressman from Janesville, Wis., is a sometimes-mutinous soldier in the army of Newt Gingrich who believes that extremism in the pursuit of deficit reduction is no vice. He also has a tendency to yell at his constituents, which is inadvisable, considering that he rather desperately needs their votes on Tuesday. This penchant of Neumann's is on display during a recent campaign stop at the Sons of Norway lodge in downtown Janesville, a monochromatic American everywhere of a city an hour and a half west of Milwaukee.
The Golden K Kiwanis club is holding its monthly breakfast meeting here, and Neumann waits impatiently as the Kiwanians sing Kiwanis songs and the club president tells the ritual "Lars and Sven" joke. Neumann, a 6-foot-2, straw-thin 42-year-old, is wired this morning on caffeine and righteous anger, and when his turn finally comes he careers into his presentation. A former math teacher, he always brings along a dozen charts and an overhead projector. His theme is simple: Washington is choking America with debt. The subtext is also simple: he is ready to rescue America from Washington. 
 He unleashes a river of numbers: Medicare numbers, deficit numbers, Social Security numbers. It is too early in the morning for debt charts, but the Kiwanians are facing the unthinkable -- a math teacher with actual power -- and they are cowed into listening. "This debt can crush us," Neumann says. "Do I have a great deal of confidence that the budget will really be balanced by 2002? I know I'm a Republican and I know what I'm supposed to say, but I think that if the Republicans are in power, our chances are about 50-50, and if the Democrats are in power, it'd be about 50-50 too. We're going to have to get over this Democrat-Republican stuff if we're to get over this problem."
The lodge is filled with Republicans who appear bewildered by Neumann's attack on his own party. They grow more confused when Neumann answers a question about the Dole-Kemp tax-cut proposal this way: "It looks like a good plan on paper, but if you hear skepticism in my voice, it's because in Washington, it's not unusual to do the easy thing and not do the hard part. The easy thing would be to cut taxes. The hard part is to do deficit reduction, which means spending cuts. You will not see me vote for a tax cut if Medicare is hurt, Social Security or veterans' benefits are hurt or if the deficit goes up."
The next question lights Neumann's fuse. "Isn't it true," an elderly man asks, "that it was when Reagan was President and Dole was in the Senate that the debt went up?"
Boom.
"This debate is exactly what's leading our country down the path to destruction!" Neumann yells. "Reagan and Dole did it, and the Democrats did it! People on both sides of the aisle are willing to do anything to get power in this country, even if means the destruction of our country!"
His questioner is stunned into silence. Neumann's face is tomato red. "I've got to get my blood pressure down!" he shouts. He gathers himself. "I'm sorry I answered so strong," he tells the Kiwanians a moment later. "This Republican-Democrat thing -- it's just so destructive. If the Democrats want to take credit, I don't care. They raised taxes in 1993 and it brought in more revenue and so the deficit is going down."
After the breakfast, I ask Neumann if he can afford to yell at his constituents. In November 1994 he won his seat by 1,120 votes, the smallest margin of victory of the 73 Republican freshmen elected two years ago nationwide. The First District of Wisconsin, home to massive General Motors and Chrysler plants, is a stronghold of the avowedly anti-Republican United Auto Workers. And while its geographical center, Walworth County, is agricultural and solidly Republican, the Democrats are used to being in charge here -- the late Democratic powerhouse Les Aspin represented the First District for 22 years. Four years ago, President Clinton took this district; even Michael Dukakis won here.
"Yeah, I guess I shouldn't do that," Neumann says of his yelling. "I just get so frustrated sometimes. People have to understand that this country is heading toward disaster. We're spending our children's money. The people need to know."
Neumann and his Congressional classmates, the horsemen of the so-called Gingrich revolution, have become famous for their ideological purity and moral surety, and no freshman is more convinced of his own rightness than Mark Neumann. He is a leader of the rejectionist faction, the 15 or 20 chain saws who most typify the class's public image: contemptuous of compromise, scornful of career legislators, suspicious of party leadership. It doesn't matter, Neumann says, that he has already driven to distraction everyone around him -- the consensus-builders, comity-seekers and pork-barrelers, the more moderate freshmen and the Speaker of the House. "I'm not in this for fun," he says. "I'd rather lose than change."
Changing isn't a possibility, then, but losing is. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has poured tens of thousands of dollars worth of negative TV advertising into the district, which works to the benefit of his Democratic opponent, Lydia Spottswood, a 45-year-old former nurse who is an alderman in one of the district's largest cities, Kenosha. Neumann does have the advantages of incumbency, with five times more cash on hand than Spottswood. He needs it. Charles E. Cook Jr., the political analyst and handicapper, says of the race: "Neumann's a pretty strong swimmer but there's a pretty strong undertow out there." Cook calls Neumann vulnerable, giving him a 55-45 chance of returning to Congress.
What is certain is that the race between Neumann and Spottswood has become as mean as any Congressional race in the country. Although both candidates address the issues that drive voters -- Medicare, Social Security, pension protection -- neither is reluctant to trash-talk the other. Neumann, who is a millionaire, bashes Spottswood for being a millionaire (her husband is a wealthy physician): "She claims to speak for the working class, but that's a fraud." He says that she has no vision for a fiscally sound future and that she drives foreign cars, a death charge in this district. (Her family does own a Toyota 4Runner, but not a Mercedes, as he had claimed.) Neumann also says a dead raccoon stuffed into his home mailbox was the work of radical anti-Republican environmentalists; his neighbors now watch over his house with shotguns.
Spottswood's strategy is to portray Neumann as someone who likes numbers more than people, and to tar him with every nasty thing ever said about the freshman class. "He is a total extremist, a one-issue candidate," she told me as we toured the 4-H exhibition at the Kenosha County Fair one evening this past summer. "I'm for balancing the budget, too, but I'm for keeping balance within the budget." She has also referred to him as "Alfred E." Neumann.
Though Neumann has his moments of ease, Spottswood is the warmer of the two. She is voluble and bright-faced, with kind words for the voters she meets at the fair, their children, the animals in the 4-H exhibition -- for everyone but Neumann. "I mean, he's a creep," she says, stopping by a pigpen. "He gives me the willies. This is a man who doesn't like serving his constituents. He doesn't even like his job. Have you ever seen a more rigid person than Mark Neumann? He is an angry white male who got his and now wants to pull up the ladder behind him."
 ON TUESDAY, DEMOCRATS SAY, THE AMERICAN voter will exact her revenge on the angry white males who rode into Congress on an illusory crest of anti-Government, anti-Clinton sentiment. Republicans, of course, hope Tuesday is the day that the two-year-old revolution will be permanently ratified. It wasn't that long ago when the freshmen were celebrated as the vanguard of the revolution that made Newt Gingrich king and forced President Clinton to defend his relevancy. They came waving the Contract With America over their heads and promising a purification of Congress: Out with calcified tradition! In with term limits and a balanced budget! And don't drink the water; it'll give you Potomac Fever. They had ousted the princes of the Democratic Party -- Tom Foley, Dan Glickman, Jack Brooks -- and they descended upon the Capitol in a storm cloud of righteousness.
But in their triumph, they overreached. The new Speaker tripped on his personality. The President outsmarted the House leadership in budget negotiations and pickpocketed one Republican message after the other. The freshmen began to look childish instead of revolutionary, this one going weak for the militia movement, that one trying to gut environmental regulations with all the subtlety of Agent Orange.
Through it all, the freshmen, the ones who weren't self-destructing or worming their way into the system, found themselves battling their own leadership. For them, issues like deficit reduction were hard principle, and they turned against veteran lawmakers who were too easy to compromise. Some of these freshmen realized that they owed their victories as much to Perot voters disgusted with split-the-difference cynicism as to Republican regulars, and did not dare give in on things like the deficit.
Neumann, in whose district Perot received 23 percent of the vote in 1992, became a leader of this freshman camp. Not a leader in the cheerleading, vote-counting sense -- he is too obstreperous for that. But many of Neumann's classmates look to him for guidance, not only on fiscal matters but on ways to resist pressure to conform. Steve Largent, the former N.F.L. all-pro wide receiver for the Seattle Seahawks and now a Republican freshman from Oklahoma, refers to Neumann as a "real William Wallace" -- a reference to the 13th-century Scottish rebel who battled both the oppressive English crown and the duplicitous Scottish nobility. (Wallace was lionized in Mel Gibson's "Braveheart," a film that has become to the conservative wing of the Republican Party what "Patton" was to Nixon.)
Within his first three months in Washington, Neumann wrote his own budget plan, which he says would have led to a balanced budget by 1999. It ended so-called corporate welfare -- tax breaks and subsidies for big business -- and froze defense spending. As a sop to the freshman class, the House leadership allowed Neumann's plan to come to a vote. Only 89 members supported it, the vast majority of them Republican freshmen. The leadership had assumed, rightly, that the plan was too radical to go anywhere.
Neumann says, "There was a lot of misinformation put out about the plan," suggesting that it wasn't only Democrats putting out the misinformation. "It was the famous cloakroom stuff. It was one of my first lessons in how Washington works."

A DAY IN THE LIFE OF A KAMIKAZE FRESHMAN
"Stupid, stupid, stupid," Neumann is saying. "It's just so stupid."
A muggy June morning, not a notable day in Washington except that it is Neumann's worst day in Congress yet. He is leaving a meeting of the House Appropriations Committee, where he has just proposed cutting every appropriations outlay by 1.9 percent. He withdrew the idea when exactly none of the other 50 or so Representatives in the room would agree to it. Now he is moving briskly toward the basement cafeteria of the Longworth House Office Building. He is dressed on this hot day, as he is most days, in the style of a Mormon missionary: a white, short-sleeved shirt, muted red tie and blue slacks.
I ask him if he will be going to the Republican National Convention.
"Do you really think they want me at the Republican convention?"
He bumps into Phil English, a fellow Republican freshman, an affable, working-stiff type from Erie, Pa.
Neumann stammers out a greeting: "Hey Phil, sorry about going at you like that last night."
"That's all right, Mark," English says soothingly, "that's all right."
A little later, as we are leaving the cafeteria, I ask Neumann, "What did you say to English last night?"
"Nothing. Just that he was destroying the country."
He pauses, and then elaborates. "Phil's a real good guy. The freshmen are good people. It's just that there's pressures, you know?"
Here is the issue that upset Neumann so violently: the night before, the House and the Senate agreed on a budget resolution, a key step toward a final budget. The vote largely went along party lines, except that Neumann and a small band of Republicans, mostly freshmen, joined Democrats in voting no.
Neumann voted against the plan, he said, because it contained spending that would temporarily spike the deficit. The Republican leadership had promised that the deficit would drop precipitously, only not right away. Neumann wasn't buying it.
"Let me ask you a question," he says. "Five years from now, if the Republicans had a choice, do you think they would rather remain in control of Congress or have balanced the budget and brought the deficit down?"
It is, I gather, a rhetorical question.
"They will do anything to remain in power," he says. "People in Washington will do anything to remain in power. Anything."
No, I don't suppose they want him at the Republican National Convention.
Neumann did not simply vote against the budget resolution; he violated House mores by "whipping" -- trying fiercely to enlist additional votes for his dissident cause. Along with a few other freshmen, he spent the evening barricaded in his cramped office, lobbying his classmates by telephone to stay pure in the face of party pressure. Few did.
There is no punishment in store for Neumann -- this time. The Republican leadership had punished him before, most notably in the summer of 1995, when he was booted from the Appropriations Defense Subcommittee for trying to block funding for the United States intervention in Bosnia. When his classmates found out that he was sacked, they revolted and forced the leadership to give Neumann a seat on the Budget Committee.
Neumann seems untroubled by the thought of being disciplined -- he rages against his party's leadership, all the way back to his office. "What do Republicans stand for?" he asks. "Balancing the budget and deficit reduction. That's why we were elected. It's just so stupid what they did last night." He stops for breath. "My blood pressure's going up -- I have to count to 10."
When he gets upset, Neumann silently counts to 10.
"I don't know what we're going to do," he says, as we sit in his office. "They're just loading up those appropriations bills with pork." The "they" are his Republican elders.
Neumann soon dashes out of his office to his apartment, a studio three blocks away, to gather some papers for an afternoon news conference.
He is so down that I find myself unwittingly trying to buck him up. I suggest that the day isn't a complete disaster, what with the big news conference coming up. Today, he is unveiling his Social Security Preservation Act, which, if passed into law, would stop the Treasury from dipping into the Social Security trust fund to pay for Government operations. The bill already has 62 co-sponsors, nearly all Republican freshmen, and has been widely touted in deficit-hawk circles.
So, I say, things aren't so bad after all.
"They're gonna bury us," he says.
Oh.
"Who's gonna bury you?"
"Who? The leadership, that's who."
"Why?"
"If you were running for re-election, would you want to tell the American people that the deficit is really $65 billion higher than we've told you before, because what we've been doing is raiding the Social Security trust fund to make up the budget shortfall, and depositing I.O.U.'s into the fund, which is supposed to be there for people's Social Security? Would you?"
"But you're running for re-election," I say.
He stares blades into me.
"I'm not going to betray my principles to get re-elected," he declares. "I'd sooner quit."
Neumann plunges on, to the Capitol. A security guard asks him for identification. "Umm, sorry, I'm a member," he says. It is customary for members of Congress to wear a lapel pin that exempts them from security checks. Neumann isn't wearing his, and I ask him why.
"Oh, you mean the 'Treat me like God' pin?" he says, grimacing. "Yeah, whatever."
The news conference, held in a basement room in the Capitol, draws a crowd of reporters. Also on hand, to Neumann's relief, is a good slice of the freshman class, including David McIntosh of Indiana, an ambitious Dan Quayle protege who would be voted, if such a vote were held, the freshman most likely to be Speaker, and Wes Cooley of Oregon, who will not be a candidate for anything -- like the ill-starred Enid Greene (formerly Waldholtz) of Utah, scandal (financial and ethical) is forcing his early retirement from the House.
"This is about honesty," Neumann tells the reporters, "which we haven't been real good at in Washington. We've been using the Social Security trust fund money to mask the true size of the federal deficit. We're fooling the American people into thinking the deficit is smaller than it is."
His fellow freshmen applaud, but the initiative fails to overwhelm the press, or, as Neumann predicted, the House leadership. As the 104th Congress passed into history, the Social Security Preservation Act of 1996 lay dormant in committee.
No one said being a freshman would be easy.

FINDING AN ISSUE IN A MATH CLASS
Mark Neumann is a deeply observant evangelical Lutheran who came to Washington not to fight against abortion and gay rights but to fight for the bottom line. Not to say that his votes on social issues don't hew to the Republican platform -- and his church's. But for Neumann, the fiscal is moral. "He has a strong belief that balancing the books is the ethical position," says his father, Kurt, a retired automobile engineer, who with his wife, Stella, taught Mark and his four siblings fealty to God and respect for General Motors.
Neumann had an aggressively wholesome childhood, as he describes it: sports, farm work and his girlfriend, Sue. They met in fourth-grade Sunday school, and married the year after they graduated from high school. When he graduated from college, Neumann began teaching high-school math, which is when, searching for real-life problems to teach his students, he stumbled upon the deficit.
Teaching was his calling, he says, but by the time he and Sue had three children, they were skirting poverty. "I remember one time we were in the supermarket and we had to put the cheese back on the shelf because we didn't have enough money," he says. "We were running $200 behind a week."
So he decided to mortgage himself to the entrepreneurial dream. He took work as a real-estate agent, and three years later was running his own construction company. "We almost lost our shirts the first year," he says, "but we learned how to budget, and by the fourth year, we were putting up 120 homes." Today, he is a coupon-cutting millionaire who has contempt for people who live off the taxpayers.
Neumann is all unsheathed edge; he is more intense, as Garrison Keillor might say, than the average Lutheran. He is a difficult boss, a taskmaster and a prude who discourages "cussing" in his office. He is also pathologically unable to keep his mouth shut. Even when he aims for diplomacy, he stumbles. I once asked him if he was bothered, as a Christian, that Gingrich and Bob Dole divorced their first wives under questionable circumstances. "Thank goodness you can't force me to answer that one if I don't want to," he said, answering anyway.
Like other millionaires who spend fortunes to gain elective office, Neumann is possessed of a certain messianic quality that precludes easy compromise, and keeps him focused obsessively on questions of debt. It is the singularity of his interest that sometimes leaves him ill at ease in his party, even within its most conservative wing. This became apparent to me one afternoon last summer during a weekly Washington lunch held by Paul Weyrich -- the godfather of conservative activism -- for right-wing lobbyists and Congressmen. Weyrich's is an alternate Republican universe in which Gingrich is demonized not as a right-wing extremist but as a spineless leftist. The group was upset on this day by the Speaker's treatment of Bob Dornan; Dornan, the famously unglued California Representative, had drawn Gingrich's wrath by endorsing a pro-life insurgent over a sitting Republican Congresswoman.
Neumann, a Weyrich regular, addressed the group on the relative merits of loyalty to Gingrich and the party. "To me," he said, "the most important thing is God, morals and ethics first. Then comes family. Then comes your constituents. Fourth would be the party."
The meeting was interrupted by the sudden appearance of Dornan himself, who rushed the podium. Before he could launch his attack, he was told that a reporter was present. He pointed at me and declaimed: "You have penetrated the inner sanctum of the revolution! We are the bravehearts and they are the nobles!" He denounced the Republican leadership, and then excoriated Steve Gunderson, the gay Republican representative from Wisconsin. Not long before, Dornan had outed Gunderson on the House floor; now he condemned him for letting his partner ("wife," in Dornan's locution) support Dornan's Democratic opponent.
All the while, Neumann sat quietly, staring at his hands.
"That wasn't normal," is all he would say afterward. It is not that he hides his position on homosexuality: "If I was elected God for a day," he says, "homosexuality wouldn't be permitted, but nobody's electing me God."
The meeting underlined Neumann's predicament: while he came to Washington to battle the deficit, he found his fellow fiscal conservatives distracted by issues like gay rights, abortion and affirmative action. While he certainly votes the Republican social platform -- he has a 100 percent Christian Coalition rating -- he argues that the 104th Congress has lost sight of the mandate of 1994. "When we had freshmen orientation, we didn't agree on very much," he says. "We didn't agree on social issues, even regulatory issues. The whole freshman revolution was about three things -- the line-item veto, term limits and balancing the budget. That's it. But people lost focus. All sorts of social issues. Personal promotion in their districts. Ambition in Washington. If we don't refocus on the central issues of '94, we're going to be taken out.
"People don't understand. It wasn't a Republican revolution. It was a common-sense revolution."

NEUMANN, NEWT AND THE LESSONS OF SCOTTISH HISTORY
The question on the table is, Did the freshmen fail?
"In the real world of real power, we've won," Newt Gingrich answers. "The Clinton welfare bill was $10 billion in more spending and it centralized power in the Washington bureaucracy. The bill he's now going to sign is $55 billion in savings, and it returns power to state and local government and to charities. So you tell me, did the freshmen win?"
Gingrich is sitting in his office under a framed photograph of Martin Luther King Jr. It is a few hours after President Clinton announced that he would sign the Republican welfare bill, ending the Federal guarantee of aid to poor people first made by Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
The Speaker, shoeless and content, flashes a benevolent smile. He has a point, of course. There would have been no need for a Dick Morris to push the President rightward had there not been the stunning Republican victories of 1994. The freshmen make up one-third of what Gingrich calls his "manuever element," and they are the most stouthearted third. But it is the freshmen, too, whose inability to compromise has helped sink Gingrich's approval ratings, and prompted the Dole campaign to distance itself from the Congress and the Contract.
Because the welfare victory is so fresh, today is not the best day to ask Gingrich to analyze the weaknesses of the revolution. He loves the freshmen today, even the ones who occasionally make him miserable. These are the ones, in fact, who interest Gingrich the most. "There's a wonderful scene in 'True Grit,' " he says, "where Wayne is going across the river in a boat and the girl jumps in the river with her horse after she's told she can't go. And Wayne says, 'That girl reminds me of me.' The freshmen remind me a lot of the 1979 me."
These are the same freshmen who defied Gingrich by opposing the budget resolution in June and who voted to keep the Government closed last January; choosing his words carefully, Gingrich calls them "prophetic." "They start from the premise that they know what they're doing and they know what is right," he says. "Now, do I want 235 fellow prophets? No. Do I want 10 or 15? Yes."
If there are only 10 or 15 of these prophets afoot in Congress, then why does the public seem to think that the 73 freshmen are uniformly radical?
"They were using you guys," Gingrich says with a laugh, referring to the press. "They got together, and said, 'If we stand together and chant, the press will cover us as if we're actually powerful, and if we're really powerful, we'll get a lot done.' "
What they seem to have done is let their rigidity alienate the electorate. I ask Gingrich to name his worst mistake in handling them.
"Why would you assume I made a mistake in handling the freshmen?" Gingrich asks, baring his teeth.
"Everybody's fallible."
"I'm sure I am," Gingrich says, "but I haven't worried much about that part of it."
Though most freshmen came to Washington worshiping Gingrich, and still praise him -- "He's the most brilliant man I've ever met," Neumann says -- many now see him as a typically untrustworthy Washington politician. I tell Gingrich that some freshmen, pointing to his eventual compromise in the budget battles, have likened him not to William Wallace but to Robert the Bruce, the leader of the Scottish nobles, who through most of "Braveheart" is portrayed as weak and indecisive (but who, in actual history, led the Scots to victory over England).
"I plead guilty to being Robert the Bruce," Gingrich says. "The Wallace is a great figure. But the Wallace is to the Bruce as Goldwater is to Reagan, the great romantic, idealistic leader who creates the movement but can't manage it.
"I think it's wonderful to have freshmen who are gallantly courageous and willing to rush onto the field and fight for the cause they believe in," he continues. "But I would like some of them to have a longer view."
I ask Gingrich to describe Neumann's performance in Congress. "He's an absolute prophet of balancing the budget, brilliant and idealistic," he says. "Every once in a while, he has his moments. It's really a matter of drawing distinctions." And then, as if addressing Neumann's rejectionist faction itself, Gingrich says: "If it's a matter of conscience, you should never give in. . . . But there are a lot of times, frankly, when you just get to be a pain in the neck."

HOW TO ATTRACT THE ATTENTION OF THE LEADERSHIP (AND THE COPS)
Neumann's independent streak surfaced early. Just two months after arriving in Washington, he had his first run-in on the Defense Appropriations subcommittee.
"I'm brand-new at this point," he recalls. "I'm sitting at a little added-on table at the end of the big table -- like a kid's table. An emergency spending bill came up. It was $3.2 billion in additional spending and we had $1.8 billion in spending cuts. So I asked where the balance was coming from, the $1.4 billion. They looked at me like I was from another planet. I understood they were adding another $1.4 billion to the deficit, but I wanted to hear them say that. I said I wouldn't vote for it. Gingrich called me in and said I had to vote for it. It was like a threat.
"They said I had signed a pledge not to oppose the leadership," he continues. "Some staffer told me this, and I told him to stuff it, that I would never sign a pledge like that. I was in the housing business, so I read everything that I sign."
It turned out that Neumann was never asked to sign the pledge, and he opposed the spending bill to the end. (It passed without his vote.) His next confrontation with the Speaker was the one that launched the freshman revolt. In September 1995, Neumann proposed an amendment to a Defense Appropriations bill, stating that troops couldn't be sent to Bosnia without Congressional approval. "They took my amendment out," he says, "and this time the bill was defeated, and I was blamed because I was on the committee." Neumann immediately heard from Bob Livingston, the Appropriations chairman. "He called me into his office and started screaming at me. It got so bad that two Capitol police officers came to the door to see if anything was wrong."
Neumann went home for the weekend, and soon received a call from the Governor of Wisconsin, Tommy G. Thompson. "He just wanted to tell me that I was doing a great job," Neumann says. "I thought that was nice, the Governor and all, but Sue said 'Something's wrong.' She's got radar."
As soon as he returned to Washington, Neumann was told he no longer sat on the Defense subcommittee. The Speaker summoned him. "Newt was very cool and collected," he recalls. "He said I had a great first year, that I should claim victory and move on. I didn't know what to say. I had never been kicked out of anything before. What I remember most is the Speaker's balcony. It's like sitting on Lake Beulah, where I grew up. The esthetic patriotic value of that scenery, the Washington Monument, is somewhat overwhelming."
When Neumann's class learned of his punishment, says David McIntosh, the Indiana freshman, "you could see a wave going across the House floor. Every single freshman said that that is outrageous. It was a defining moment for us."
A delegation of freshmen demanded a meeting with Gingrich. "We let him know that he would have a riot if he tried to punish Mark for standing up for what he believes in," McIntosh says.
To avert the politically disastrous spectacle of rampaging freshmen, Gingrich and Livingston struck a deal with Neumann's allies. "Everybody in the class sees Mark as a future Budget Committee chairman," McIntosh says, "so someone proposed that Mark take a slot on Budget, and stay on Appropriations, but not the Defense subcommittee. The person who was not in the room who Livingston kind of stuck it to was John Kasich." (Kasich, an Ohio Republican, is the deficit hawk who is chairman of the Budget Committee.) "But Mark made a real effort to say to John, 'I'm not going to ruin your committee.' John realizes that Mark is like he was 10 years ago."
Neumann, who is now the only freshman to sit on both Budget and Appropriations -- his only punishment, in the end, was to bounced off the powerful Defense subcommittee of Appropriations while remaining on two less-mighty subcommittees -- remains nonplussed by the sudden fame his obstinancy brought him. "Washington is the only place," he says, "where you get attention from doing what you say you're going to do."

THE ROAD TO WASHINGTON, WHICH HE HATES
Like most Republican freshmen, Neumann does not hide his hatred of Washington. He chose not to move his family there, but to keep them in Wisconsin; in a famous incident, he returned home early one week, missing several important votes, to take his son hunting. Wisconsin Democrats ripped him for that, but they misjudged the reaction in their state, where deficit reduction is important, just not as important as killing deer with a loved one.
No Georgetown dinner party has ever been graced by Neumann's presence; he has never heard of Ben and Sally, and, like most freshmen, the significance of Embassy Row escapes him. Pat Schroeder, the retiring Democratic Congresswoman who is particularly acid on the subject of the Republican freshmen, says: "They don't have any desire to deal with anything outside America. And they don't have any desire to deal with Washington. All you hear is that Washington is a pit, Washington is going to poison them, yap, yap, yap."
Neumann himself has a neutron-bomb view of Washington -- the people he could live without, but the buildings he loves. It is the buildings, in fact, that inspired him, he says, to enter politics.
"We hadn't traveled much when we first visited Washington," Neumann recalls, describing his family's fateful vacation to the capital. He is telling me the story of his family's 1989 trip as we drive from Janesville, in the western part of his district, to Racine, on Lake Michigan, for a Fourth of July parade. We're accompanied by Sue Neumann, dressed in patriotic colors, and Tricia, the Neumanns' 18-year-old daughter. Their two sons, Andy, 20, and Matt, 14, make up his advance team, and are already in Racine.
As we pass signs advertising "Fireworks -- Cheese," Neumann becomes preoccupied. "Last year, we had a bad scene at the parade," he says. "They threw cherry bombs at us, little firecrackers. Then some guy grabbed me into the crowd and wouldn't let me go."
He returns to his story. "We were only planning on staying in Washington three days, but it turned into a week," he says. "We saw all the monuments. We went to the Jefferson and to the Lincoln --."
"You walk up the stairs to the Lincoln Memorial," Sue Neumann interrupts, "and read the words on the walls --."
"And you realize that the country is going in the exact opposite direction of what it says," her husband says.
"Which words?" I ask -- the Gettysburg Address, the second Inaugural address?
"All the words," Sue says.
"Then we went to Arlington National Cemetery," she continues, "and to see row after row of men who gave everything for their country, it's just --."
"We just realized that the country was going down, and we had to do something," Neumann says.
I ask, "So reading the inscriptions on the Lincoln Memorial is what got you into politics?"
"Yes," he says.
Mr. Smith in the flesh, it seems.
The Neumanns decided that Mark would run for Congress. The only problem: the First District seat was occupied by Les Aspin, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. In 1992, the Neumanns spent $1 million of their own money trying to defeat Aspin. They hired political consultants and attacked Aspin's free-spending ways -- Mr. Smith goes negative.
Aspin won with 58 percent of the vote, but then President Clinton appointed him Secretary of Defense, and a special election was called for 1993. Neumann ran again, this time against Peter Barca, a state representative from Kenosha. This time, a squeaker: Barca won on a recount.
Neumann, who spent $250,000 of his own in 1993, announced the end of his political career. But six months later, according to Neumann, Governor Thompson summoned him to Madison and asked him to make one last try.
"I decided to do it myself this time -- no consultants," Neumann says. "The problem with consultants is that they come from Washington. Once they get their hooks into you, you're owned by them."
In 1994, Neumann and Barca both ran negative campaigns, filled with accusations of "push-polling" -- planting negative notions about your opponent in the course of a telephone "poll" -- and other deceits. Neumann won, squeezing into Congress with just less than 50 percent of the vote.
"It was an insult that we lost this district," says Douglas Frazier, the retired president of the United Auto Workers union, who was recently in Wisconsin to endorse Spottswood. The district's Democrats are still shocked by Neumann's 1994 win, but Wisconsin voters are famous for ticket-splitting heterodoxy. As Roy Cohn wrote in his biography of Joe McCarthy, the state's most famous contribution to the Republican Party, "Many have pointed out that Wisconsin is not an easy state to analyze politically." Wisconsin, with its deep progressive tradition, is a fundamentally conservative, churchgoing state with an openly gay Republican Congressman and two Democratic Jewish Senators.
Russell Feingold, the state's junior Democratic Senator and something of a maverick himself ("some people call mine a Mr. Smith approach," he told me), maintains that Neumann snuck into office by masking his true intent. "I think when he was elected," Feingold says, "the people of this district did not realize how extreme his politics are. There is deep suspicion of extremism in this state. There are two kind of Republicans here. One is the Rotary type, the economic type. They don't have the extremist moral agenda. Then there's the new kind of Republican, the extremists Neumann is associated with, the ones who are heavily moralistic in approach."
Feingold admits that Neumann's economic message does resonate with Wisconsin voters, who are proud of their state's reputation for parsimony. The state receives fewer Federal dollars per capita than almost any other, and its most popular politician of recent years was Senator William Proxmire, the Democrat, now retired, known for his "Golden Fleece" award for wasteful Government projects. But fiscal conservatism, Feingold says, hardly equals Gingrich extremism. "There was no Republican revolution in Wisconsin," Feingold says. "Neumann is out of step with Wisconsin voters."
Neumann would certainly seem to be out of step in Racine, which is why he's expecting trouble at the parade. This is a Democratic town, and Neumann is seen as not just any Republican, but a Gingrich Republican, a freshman Republican, an extremist. As we drive into town, he's searching for his place in the parade lineup. "I think we have to go down one of these," he says, driving past side streets blocked by police officers.
"Why don't you tell them you're the Congressman?" I suggest. "They'll let you through."
"Oh yeah, right, what do you think this is, Washington?"
He finally finds his place, in front of a convertible carrying Miss Racine. She is dressed in a blue, sequined dress that reflects the morning sun, as do the freshly scrubbed fire trucks and the gigantic construction machinery. The crowd is five-deep along the sidewalk.
"America," Neumann explains to me, his foreign guest.
He walks over to Miss Racine to congratulate her, but steps aside when a photographer appears. "No, Mr. Neumann," the photographer says. "I want you in the picture."
"Oh. Me?"
The parade steps off, and the Neumanns brace themselves for the unknown. But no one boos. As the Congressman walks Racine's main streets, he does hear the occasional admonition -- "Don't touch my Medicare!" one woman shouts. But he also hears bursts of enthusiastic applause, and shouts of encouragement: "You give it to 'em, Mark," and "Stick it to 'em, Mark."
Word has got back to Racine that its Congressman is giving Washington a hard time.

FEAR AND LOATHING (AND TEARS) ON THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL
"It's all a sham," says Lydia Spottswood. We are talking just after the grand opening of the Walworth County Democratic campaign headquarters, where an hour's worth of envelope stuffing gets you in a photograph with cardboard cutouts of Bill and Hillary Clinton. All of this guff about Neumann's vaunted independence, Spottswood is telling me, is Republican propaganda, designed to throw voters off the scent of a true Gingrichite.
She has a case -- and doesn't have a case -- because Neumann is both a party loyalist and a party defector. He is committed to the Republican social agenda; he is anti-gun-control, anti-affirmative-action and anti-United Nations. He supports Constitutional amendments to balance the budget, to ban flag burning and to outlaw abortion.
But his idea of party loyalty is idiosyncratic, which seems to confuse Spottswood.
"You know, the Republicans don't like him," she tells me.
"Isn't that a compliment, coming from a Democrat?"
"He'd like to think so," she says, dropping the subject.
It is not entirely true that Republicans don't like Neumann. And even those who don't like him do need him to win on Tuesday. That might be why Bob Livingston, who threw Neumann off the Appropriations Defense subcommittee, recently held a fund-raising breakfast for him, and donated $1,000 from his own campaign fund to Neumann's.
I asked Neumann why Livingston has become so friendly. "Bob wants to be chairman next year, too," he replied. In other words, a Republican majority, even if made up off recalcitrant ideologues like Neumann, returns people like Living ston to power and a House full of Lydia Spottswoods does not. Neumann has also received support from his other chairman, John Kasich, who has campaigned for him in Wisconsin, and from Governor Thompson.
When I asked Neumann if he would like Bob Dole to campaign for him, he said, "Elizabeth Dole." When I repeated "Bob Dole," he repeated, "Elizabeth Dole."
Spottswood also takes the unusual step of attacking Neumann for votes she herself would have made, for example, his vote in favor of the minimum wage increase. She says that Neumann violated his own principles in order to win votes. "Why would this rich businessman vote for that?" she asks. "It goes against his whole platform."
Neumann disagrees. "The minimum wage isn't one of my core issues," he says. "My vote didn't raise the deficit, and so if my constituents want the minimum wage increased, I'll vote for it."
Spottswood also attacks him for being one of only 37 Republicans to vote against the spending bill that will finance President Clinton's anti-terrorism and anti-drug programs. Neumann's response? "They only gave us two hours to read a 15-inch stack of documents. I have to know what I'm voting for before I vote."
Spottswood: "Here's a guy who doesn't trust the committee system and the House leadership." She doesn't immediately realize that she has accused Neumann of distrusting Newt Gingrich.
For the most part, Spottswood is running what might be called a cultural campaign, suggesting to reporters and voters that Neumann and his belief system -- his fundamentalist Christianity, his anti-government rhetoric -- are alien to politically progressive Wisconsin. She regularly attacks Neumann's character: she told me stories, all apparently baseless, that call into question Neumann's business ethics, even his parenting skills.
When I comment on the nastiness of the race, she begins to cry. "When you say that you're expecting both of us to be nasty, that's so contrary to who I am," she says, wiping away tears. "I look at this as public service. Politics has become a blood sport."
Neumann harbors no Mr. Smith-like illusions that politics, even in a supposedly genteel state like Wisconsin, should be anything but rough. "Campaigns are like war," he says, "just without blood."

THE SOUL OF AN ANTIPOLITICIAN
 Mark Neumann has set a deadline for himself: six terms in Congress, and out. But what happens in his 12th year if he's suddenly offered the chairmanship of the Budget Committee, his dream assignment?
"No hesitation," he says. "I'm out. Twelve years and out, no matter what. I gave my word to the people of the First District." He's getting angry at me now. "And I'm not going to break my word!"
If only Spottswood Continued on page 88
could find an example of Neumann's breaking his word, perhaps she could break Neumann. What she says she has found, however, is quite the opposite: countless examples of Neumann serving abstract principle at the expense of his constituents. "This is a Congressman who doesn't understand that you want to bring money home," she says.
Neumann is unremittingly opposed to all pork-barrel projects, even when the Federal funds would be headed to his district. His job, he says, is to protect the taxpayer from his greedy Congressional colleagues. Along with several other freshmen, he has agitated for a revamping of the entire House committee system, in order to break the hegemony of the Appropriations, Commerce and Ways and Means Committees. It is a movement that, so far, has not moved an inch.
Spottswood charges that Neumann opposes pork not out of principle, but because he can't get any for his district. "Maybe he's afraid of failure," she says. "Maybe he knows he doesn't have friends on either side of the aisle, and therefore he can't deliver."
That's not quite right. Neumann was placed on Appropriations because he won election so narrowly, and the leadership hoped he would use his place at the trough to strengthen his hold on the district. It hasn't worked out that way.
Such is the case with the sewer commission of Walworth County. This summer, a county delegation requested financing from Neumann for a new sewer system for an unincorporated area around Lake Como. The area's residents are mainly poor senior citizens, and it was widely agreed that the project was worthy of government aid.
That is where Neumann came in. After losing his place on the Appropriations defense subcommittee, he remained on the subcommittee that appropriates money to the Housing and Urban Development Department and to Veterans Affairs. "HUD-V.A. has a revolving fund where money is allocated to states on a formula," Neumann explains. "The states decide where they need it the most and then allocate."
Many of those allocations, like the allocations of any appropriations subcommittee, go to the pork-barrel projects of connected Congressmen. "We went to Mark and said that these Congressmen are stealing our [expletive] money," says Patrick J. Moore, a Walworth County sewer commissioner. "We said we want our share of it and we want it now. Then Neumann gets verbally violent with us. He starts yelling about treason and the Constitution and our grandchildren's money and all this stuff."
Neumann: "They asked me to put in a pork project and I said no. There's two ways of doing things here. One is called pork-barrel spending and one is called the proper procedure."
"But," I asked him, "didn't the leadership assign you to Appropriations because --."
"What? Because I only won by 1,120 votes, so I should pork to get re-elected? That may be why they put me on the committee, but I'm not porking. These people in Lake Como would have had their money if other members hadn't porked all the money."
After a three-hour meeting between Neumann and the county delegation, it was agreed that Neumann's office would support the commissioners through the state allocation procedure. "It's a sound project," Neumann now says, "but the best thing I can do for them is make sure that pork doesn't get through next year so there's money left for legitimate projects."
"That's not going to make you too popular on Appropriations," I say.
"I don't care about that."
"Why?"
"I'm at peace with myself," he says. "I know that everything's just temporary. I have everlasting life through Jesus Christ. So if I'm here in Wisconsin only temporarily, I'm in Washington really temporarily."
Neumann pauses. "I can get them pork," he says. "But if I start putting in pork projects, I can't go tell anyone else to stop putting in pork. I couldn't do it. I would have to resign."
Mark Neumann, with two years in Congress, has not lost his fervor; he has not been, to use a word favored by his rejectionist colleagues, "housebroken."
There is much that is troubling about Neumann's record: his annoyance with the democratic process and his unthinking isolationism, to name just two. And there is a meanness that sometimes sneaks into his voice when he talks about cutting Government. "Fourteen people lost their jobs, and we're not sending them to job-retraining," he gloated to supporters one day, describing the freshman-driven campaign to end ice delivery to Congressional offices.
In his excesses, he may be typical of his freshman class; in his willingness to challenge authority, he is in a surprisingly small minority. This may turn out to be Neumann's most rewarding role -- the proud heretic banging on the oak doors of power, condemning the status quo. "In Washington," he likes to say, "both party structures are equally morally bankrupt."
Only a Congressman so devoted to his own vision -- in this case, an especially flinty vision of a debt-free, shrunken Government -- would be so uninterested in currying the approval of his elders. And though he recognizes that deficit spending is not quite the equivalent of human bondage, he sees the fight for a balanced budget as a modern-day analogue to Lincoln's fight against slavery. "We're enslaving our future generations with debt," he says. "I'm not equating the debt to actual slavery, but Lincoln saw slavery as morally and ethically unacceptable and the debt and the deficit are morally and ethically unacceptable, too."
One day, sitting in a Cracker Barrel restaurant in Janesville, he handed me some of his campaign literature. It was treacly, and ostentatiously patriotic. One brochure in particular caught my eye. Its cover read, "Values -- Principles -- Integrity -- Vote Mark Neumann U.S. Congress." But instead of Neumann's face, the cover featured a photograph of the Lincoln Memorial.
"Getting a little bit sold on yourself?" I asked him.
He picked up the pamphlet and looked at Lincoln.
"He was a weird guy, too," he said, "don't you think?"

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28; Column 4; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: THE BIG CITY;
A Kick for the Economy

BYLINE: By John Tierney 

 BODY:
FOR NEW YORKers, the Presidential campaign has been a depressing reminder of how happy our fellow Americans are. We keep hearing about an economic boom that has created millions of jobs, but New York still hasn't recovered all those lost during the last recession. Other cities have labor shortages; New York's unemployment rate remains one of the highest in the country. What are we doing wrong?
Free-market zealots mistakenly blame City Hall. They think New York's distinctively weak economy is somehow related to its distinctively strong government. It's true that the economy is more heavily regulated than any other city's, a fact that companies like to point out when they leave town. But as everyone must know by now, New York City imposes all these regulations because it is determined to help business. Whenever private businesses blunder, the City Council can be counted on to hold a public hearing to devise a rescue plan. Officials in other cities struggle just to take care of basic responsibilities like streets and schools, but New York's have found time to advise the rest of us how to do our jobs. 
 These public servants turned management consultants have been so productive that businesses have a hard time keeping up with their recommendations. That's the real problem. The expertise of city officials is being squandered. New York's best entrepreneurial minds are trapped in public service. What would happen if their talents were unleashed on private businesses? Their departure from government would be a great loss (as the officials have explained to us during the current debate about the term-limits referendum). Still, applying their talents privately could absolutely invigorate the economy. Consider a few of the enterprises they could start:
Pure Peter's Pub. If restaurateurs knew their customers as well as City Council President Peter F. Vallone does, they might not be complaining about losing business because of his anti-smoking ordinance. They've argued that it's an unnecessary intrusion on private business -- people were always free to patronize nonsmoking restaurants -- but they don't understand their patrons' devotion to health. In his own establishment, Vallone would be free to introduce other life-saving innovations. Would Pure Peter's be alcohol-free, too? Fat-free? Make your reservations early.
Fort Eldridge: The Safe Savings and Loan. After Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge was mugged at a cash machine in 1991, she championed the nation's first law requiring security measures at A.T.M. parlors. Bankers, who noted that their facilities already had better security systems than the sidewalks outside, claimed that the measures would force them to spend $120 million per year, close parlors and raise fees. Some experts believed that the total cost to consumers might be more than what Eldridge lost in the robbery.
The Council's investigation never resolved the mystery of why banks, which spend so much money competing for customers, would endanger their reputations by skimping on security measures. One possible, though undocumented, explanation: Market researchers discovered that customers are more likely to put their money into an institution known for frequent muggings, because it's a sign that the bank keeps its machines well stocked with cash -- why else would the muggers be hanging around?
Despite the law's passage, muggings have occurred at cash machines --and one mugging is one too many, as Eldridge knows. If she opened a bank, its fortified A.T.M. bunkers could set a new industry standard.
The Dapper Donna. When Pathmark was seeking approval to open a supermarket in her Queens district last year, Councilwoman Juanita E. Watkins convinced the company to "donate" $400,000, to be distributed to "the community" under her supervision. Watkins was forced to cancel the deal, but her efforts wouldn't be lost in the private sector. Her skill could revive a New York industry weakened by the loss of John Gotti.
Green's Greens. In 1990, Mark Green sent undercover investigators from the Department of Consumer Affairs into the city's salad bars. They caught the owners charging for salads without deducting the weight of the plastic containers. Green announced that the fraud, which amounted to a few pennies per salad, cost consumers a total of $12 million annually. Apologists for salad bars argued that the owners should be free to determine prices however they wanted, and that they would just make up the $12 million difference by charging more for salad ingredients. But there's an important principle at stake here. Consumers who care about this issue would welcome Green's establishment with its slogan: "Our lettuce may cost a little more, but the plastic is FREE!"
Koslowitz & Freed Cleaners. Councilwoman Karen Koslowitz is crusading for a law that would, as she says, "persuade" dry cleaners to stop charging more for a woman's shirt than for a man's. At a hearing in September, a spokesman for the dry-cleaning industry claimed that some women's shirts are more expensive to clean than men's because they're too small to fit on the automatic presses and need to be ironed by hand, but Council members knew better than to fall for that line.
A more likely explanation is that the dry-cleaning industry, dominated by immigrants from countries with patriarchal cultures, is engaged in a conspiracy to oppress women. The typical female consumer isn't able to shop around for a better deal, partly because price comparisons require complex mathematical calculations and partly because there's simply no choice in most New York neighborhoods. (Within two blocks of my apartment there are only nine dry cleaners.) Overhauling the industry will require someone with more initiative than the ordinary immigrant -- someone like Councilwoman Kathryn Freed.
At the hearing, when the dry cleaner mentioned the problem with the automatic press, Freed suggested, "Your automatic machine should be a little more adjustable." Eureka! A technological breakthrough that had eluded the industry's best minds! A few more innovations like that and our economy could be booming again.

HEADLINE: THE 1996 CAMPAIGN: The Election: A Voter's Guide To the Issues And Candidates;
In New York, 31 Seats for the United States House of Representatives

 BODY:
Except where noted, candidates are listed in the order in which they appear on the ballot.
 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
 
First District Candidates
 
NORA L. BREDES, 46, Democrat. Served on the Suffolk County Legislature for the last four years and is making her first run for Congress.
 
MICHAEL P. FORBES, 44, Republican. Freshman incumbent who in 1994 rode a wave of anti-Clinton sentiment to beat a four-term Democrat.
 
The District
 
The First is the largest Congressional district geographically on Long Island, covering the eastern half of Suffolk County. Economically, it is still recovering from the loss of military jobs at the former Grumman Corporation, now merged into Northrop Grumman and once the Island's largest employer.
 
The Issues
 
Mr. Forbes, an early Newt Gingrich supporter, finds himself defending the Republican Contract With America and his mixed record on environmental issues. Ms. Bredes, a leader in the battle to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant, hopes to capitalize on her history of seeking tough clean-air and water standards.
 
Analysis
 
Though registered Republicans outnumber Democrats by a 3-to-2 ratio in the district, Democrats have held the seat for almost all of the last 35 years. On the coattails of President Clinton, who some polls suggest has a 30 percent lead over Bob Dole on Long Island, Ms. Bredes could return the seat to the Democratic Party.
 
Fourth District Candidates
 
CAROLYN MCCARTHY, 52, Democrat. Nurse whose husband was killed and son wounded three years ago in a shooting on the Long Island Rail Road. Has lobbied for gun control. First run for public office.
 
DANIEL FRISA, 41, Republican. Freshman Congressman and former state assemblyman.
 
ROBERT S. BERKOWITZ, Liberal Party
 
VINCENT P. GARBITELLI, Right to Life Party
 
The District
 
This Long Island district, which covers Nassau County's South Shore, may be a Republican stronghold, but there are Democratic enclaves in the heavily Jewish Five Towns area and among black and Hispanic voters around Hempstead.
 
The Issues
 
Mrs. McCarthy, a Republican until she accepted the Democratic nomination, says she was drawn into the race because of Mr. Frisa's vote against the assault weapons ban. She favors strict gun control, strong environmental regulations, abortion rights and moves to make health care more affordable. Mr. Frisa, who also supports abortion rights, is making a central issue of Mrs. McCarthy's opposition to the death penalty.
 
Analysis
 
Mrs. McCarthy's valor in coping with tragedy brought her national attention and a groundswell of support, particularly among women. Polls by Nassau Democrats show her leading. Mr. Frisa, regarded as vulnerable by officials of both parties, is relying on a direct-mail campaign, and the party organization is working vigorously to bring out Republican voters.
 
19th District Candidates
 
RICHARD S. KLEIN, 59, Democrat. Physician who gave up private practice to make his first bid for elected office. A resident of Chappaqua, has a long history of volunteerism.
 
SUE W. KELLY, 59, Republican. Had never held office before being elected to the House in 1994. A resident of the Westchester village of Bedford, had been a Republican fund-raiser, real estate broker, advocate for women's health issues and junior high school teacher.
 
JOSEPH J. DIOGUARDI, Conservative and Right to Life Party
 
WILLIAM E. HAASE, Independence Party
 
The District
 
This is a predominantly Republican district covering part of White Plains and all of Westchester north of White Plains, as well as Putnam County and parts of Orange and Dutchess counties. The district has traditionally sent Republicans to Congress, including Hamilton Fish Jr., who held the seat for more than two decades.
 
The Issues
 
As in other Congressional districts, the race here has become something of a referendum on Newt Gingrich's Contract With America. Mr. Klein has criticized Ms. Kelly for joining the Congressional Republicans in what he describes as attacks on the environment, Medicare and student-loan programs. She is also being criticized as a closet liberal by Mr. DioGuardi, a former two-term representative who waged a bitter campaign against her and lost in the Republican primary. But Ms. Kelly has not disavowed her ties to the House leadership, instead casting herself as a social and fiscal moderate who supports abortion rights, tax cuts and a balanced budget. She has also sought to portray her opponents as extremists who are out of touch with the district's largely moderate voters.
 
Analysis
 
Though many incumbents in other races are more entrenched, Ms. Kelly's political future is far less certain. Mr. Klein could benefit greatly from Mr. DioGuardi's campaign criticizing the first-term Republican as a "Democrat in disguise" with liberal views on abortion and gay rights. Widely considered an underdog, Mr. Klein is counting on Mr. DioGuardi to take votes away from Ms. Kelly.
 
26th District Candidates
 
MAURICE D. HINCHEY, 58, Democrat. Two-term incumbent from Saugerties in Ulster County. In 1974, became the first Democrat elected to the Assembly from his district in 61 years and held the seat for 18 years. In both his races for Congress, won by 3 percentage points or less over the Republican, Bob Moppert.
 
SUE WITTIG, 41, Republican. Owns and runs a wallpaper store in the town of Ulster. Has never run for office before but is president of the local Republican Club and has worked on Assembly races and Mr. Moppert's campaigns. Also a resident of Saugerties, has been active in the National Rifle Association and the property rights movement.
 
DOUGLAS W. DRAZEN, Independence Party
 
The District
 
Stretching across eight counties, from the Hudson River town of Beacon to Ithaca on Cayuga Lake, the 26th is a classic swing district, politically diverse and notoriously fickle. It voted for George Bush in 1988, Bill Clinton in 1992. Binghamton, its largest city, is marginally Democratic but has a Republican mayor and Council. And though Republicans slightly outnumber Democrats, it has nevertheless elected a Democrat to the House for years. Mr. Hinchey would seem too left-leaning for this largely rural conservative region but has managed to win by carrying liberal Ithaca while splitting the rest of the district.
 
The Issues
 
The candidates differ sharply on most things. They agree that the economy is the main issue, but Mr. Hinchey says he would use targeted tax incentives and grant programs to spur growth while Ms. Wittig would cut a range of taxes and eliminate government regulations. Ms. Wittig is staunchly anti-abortion; Mr. Hinchey defends abortion rights. She supports a balanced-budget constitutional amendment; he opposes it. She contends environmental policies have infringed on property owners' rights; he has been a strong advocate of tough environmental regulations.
 
Analysis
 
The Right to Life Party candidate won almost 5,000 votes here in 1994, quadruple Mr. Hinchey's margin of victory. So Ms. Wittig contends that she will win because she has the Right to Life, Conservative and Republican Party lines. But just as Mr. Hinchey's liberal positions almost cost him the race in 1994, she may have positioned herself too far on the right to win in 1996, when many New Yorkers are expressing dismay with conservative Republicanism. Moreover, since Mr. Hinchey survived the 1994 Republican tide, analysts say he will be much harder to beat in 1996, when polls indicate that President Clinton will win the state by a comfortable margin. In a close race, Mr. Drazen, scion of a well-known Binghamton family who lost the Republican primary, could siphon anti-incumbent votes away from Ms. Wittig.

PROPOSITIONS
 
Proposal 1
 
The Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act authorizes the state to borrow $1.75 billion over the coming 35 years to pay for projects that reduce water and air pollution, protect drinking water supplies, close landfills, encourage recycling and clean up abandoned industrial sites. Interest payments on the bonds will bring the total cost to taxpayers to more than $3 billion.
 
The Issues
 
Proponents say that unless the proposition is approved, essential environmental projects will be postponed for years. They also say that many of the projects are required under state and Federal laws, and that the state can lighten the burden on local taxpayers by issuing long-term bonds. The total cost, they say, will be less than $4 a person per year and will not require a tax increase.
 
Critics, including some Democratic legislators, antitax groups and property-rights activists, say New York already has more debt than any other state, is facing a $3 billion projected budget shortfall next year and has one of the lowest bond ratings in the nation, largely because of its heavy debt load. Though many opponents say they support the bond act's objectives, they say many of the projects are politically motivated and unessential. Critics want the state to pay for environmental projects out of its annual budget rather than incurring additional long-term debt that they contend could someday force the Legislature to raise taxes.
 
Analysis
 
Voters have demonstrated growing anxiety about the state's huge, ever-expanding debt -- now more than $30 billion -- by rejecting the last two bond acts, including a 1990 proposal to finance environmental projects.
 
But this year could be different. The economy is stronger, which could allay fears about state borrowing; the proposition is promoted by Gov. George E. Pataki, whose standing as a fiscal conservative could win over Republican voters who tend to oppose bond acts, and President Clinton's lead in the polls could depress turnout among Republicans, who are more likely to vote against the bond act.
 
Finally, supporters have built a larger vote-pulling operation than opponents, who are relying almost exclusively on television advertisements.
 
Proposal 2
 
This city proposal -- entitled "A local law to amend the New York City Charter, in relation to terms limits and staggered terms" -- would change the existing term-limits law that now allows city officials to stay in office for no more than eight years. Instead, officials, including the mayor, comptroller, public advocate, borough presidents and City Council members, could serve up to three consecutive terms, or 12 years. The law would affect anyone who has been in office since Jan. 1, 1994.
 
The Issues
 
Voters approved term limits for all city elected officials in 1993. A yes vote for this new referendum would extend the existing limit. Council leaders, the main proponents, argue that unless the law is changed, virtually all officials would have to leave office at once in 2001 and then every eight years after that. They contend that the longer limit would allow a smoother turnover and more experienced Council members. Opponents urge a no vote, saying that the proposal would overturn the voters' will as expressed in 1993 and would only buy more time in office for politicians.
 
Analysis
 
Urging New Yorkers to keep term limits as they are, opponents have tapped into the same voter discontent over career politicians that prompted passage of limits three years ago. They have also exploited the fact that the Council is trying to undo the earlier referendum. But voters may be swayed by the Council's argument that the new referendum would not eliminate term limits, just extend them into a more workable form. Council leaders have also questioned the motives of Ronald S. Lauder, the cosmetics heir who is spending about $2 million on commercials to try to defeat the proposal. Mr. Lauder, who critics say is trying to push his own political career, spent more than $2 million on the 1993 limits campaign.

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 20; Column 1; Education Life Supplement
