HEADLINE: An Economics Lesson: The Candidates' Plans for Education

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL; Peter Passell writes about economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:
In an era of widespread dissatisfaction with public schools, it's no surprise that education issues have been as important a part of the Presidential campaign as foreign policy or defense for candidate Bob Dole. Nor is it surprising that Bill Clinton has countered with a potpourri of proposals designed to show that Americans already have an education President.
 What may come as a surprise, though, in light of the candidates' enthusiasm for classroom initiatives, is that Uncle Sam is really only a minor player in the big battles over education. Nor is the Federal Government likely to become a major player, because the deficit-riddled budget offers little room for experimentation. 
 "The Federal Government has a tiny role in education, and little financial leverage over states or local school districts," says Caroline Hoxby, an economist at Harvard University.
 But political symbols matter, too, particularly when they come from the bully pulpit of the White House. And both candidates are trying to make waves with proposals that emphasize their ideological differences.
 Bob Dole wants to encourage states to adopt tuition-voucher plans that, he argues, would break the hold of government bureaucrats (and teachers' unions) on publicly funded primary and secondary education. Bill Clinton wants to remove the remaining financial obstacles to state-supported post-secondary education at a time when virtually all the fruits of economic growth are going to Americans with college degrees. And while both initiatives have enthusiastic audiences, they raise as many questions as they answer on subjects that deeply divide educators and economists.
 Some basics.
 Eric Hanushek, an economist at the University of Rochester, notes that the Federal Government covers only 6 percent of the nation's $200 billion-plus budget for public primary and secondary schools. Local property taxpayers bear the lion's share of the financial burden in most places, with a substantial chunk coming from the states and directed toward reducing spending disparities between school districts.
 Leaving aside subsidies for university-based research, Washington's reach into higher education is longer than in public primary and secondary schools education though not by much. Of the roughly $50 billion spent by colleges this year, just $12 billion to 13 billion will come from Uncle Sam.
 But the Federal Government's limited role hasn't stopped either Presidential candidate from promising additional goodies. Along with abolishing the Department of Education -- a move he argues would save money without cutting substantive programs -- Mr. Dole would make interest on student loans deductible from income taxes, permit families to set up education-investment accounts that allow tax-sheltered withdrawals for college tuition and give employer-financed education permanent tax-free status.
 Mr. Clinton would offer $5 billion to reduce the local interest burden for school construction bonds, expand financing for Head Start, help to fund state plans for improving technology education and provide $1,000 merit scholarships for the top 5 percent of the nation's high school graduates.
 But each candidate is reserving most of his political powder for tax-based proposals that accent differences in what they see as the proper role of the Federal Government. For Mr. Clinton, it's accessibility to higher education; for Mr. Dole, it's vouchers.
 Start with the former. President Clinton's "Hope Scholarship Tax Cut" would give all high school graduates a $1,500 tax credit (payable in cash if students or their families had less than $1,500 in tax liability) to cover tuition for a first year of college. Students who maintained a B average, provided they weren't convicted of a drug felony, would be eligible for another $1,500 credit for a second year of higher education. Those who did not take advantage of the Hope Scholarship would be allowed to deduct a total up to $10,000 in tuition for higher education, provided their incomes were below $100,000.
 Mr. Clinton proposes offsetting the projected losses in Federal revenues with fees on international airport departures, sales of airwave rights and restructure taxation of profits made by multinational corporations.
 The appeal is straightforward. In the words of the Department of Education's press release, it would "make 14 years of education -- at least two years of college -- the standard for all Americans."
 So is the economic rationale. Although wages for those with college educations have risen substantially in the last two decades, workers without post-secondary training are, at best, running in place. In 1979, for example, the average college-educated worker earned 47 percent more than the average high school graduate. By 1993, the gap had risen to 81 percent. That fact has not been lost on America's youth, noted Lawrence Katz, an economist at Harvard and former aide to Robert Reich, the former Secretary of Labor: in 1980, 26 percent of Americans between the ages of 18 and 24 were in school. By 1994 the figure had risen to 35 percent.
 The catch, Mr. Katz says, is that all of the increased college attendance in those 14 years has been among middle- and upper-income families. The proportion attending college from families in the bottom quarter of the income distribution is stuck at very low levels. "Poor kids are being hit twice," he concludes, because rising tuition has made college less affordable, even as the financial payoff to higher education has risen.
 "Clinton's college tuition subsidies," he adds, "would ease the pain."
 The Hope Scholarship program is loosely modeled after one in Georgia that is financed by a state lottery. The Georgia program offers a free education to residents who maintain a B-average and attend a public university. Those who choose a private college can receive partial scholarships.
 But some, including James Heckman, an economist at the University of Chicago, question the underlying premise of both the Georgia program and the Clinton plan. Colleges, he says, already work hard to recruit low-income students.
 "Long-term environmental factors that leave these students poorly motivated and poorly prepared are far more important than financial constraints" in limiting college attendance, Heckman says.
 Others, who do accept the idea that money has a lot to do with who goes to college, worry that the Clinton approach will not yield the maximum bang for a buck.
 Lawrence Gladieux, executive director for policy analysis at the College Board, notes that most of the $43 billion in tax revenue sacrificed over seven years for the tuition tax credits and the $10,000 tuition deduction would be pocketed by families of students who would go to college without added Federal help.
 "For them, it would be a windfall," he says -- one the country can ill-afford in an era of lean Federal budgets.
 Thomas Kane, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, is skeptical that Hope Scholarships will have the desired impact, even for low-income students. Some community colleges charge less than $1,500 tuition, he argues, and would almost certainly raise their fees rather than leave the money on the table. Others, with tuition in the $2,000 to $3,000 range, would presumably also be tempted to raise tuition. And while it is possible that the extra revenue would be used by states to augment education, it is also possible that the money would end up funding state roads or public employees' salaries -- or, for that matter, state tax cuts.
 A far more efficient approach, Mr. Gladieux argues, would be to use the money to beef up Pell Grants, the need-based Federal scholarship program. Spent directly, the $43 billion in lost revenue would be enough to double the funding for this time-tested program. And because the money would be narrowly targeted, it would be less likely to induce colleges to raise tuition, he says.
 But there are two big political disadvantages to this route, which have plainly not escaped the attention of White House campaign operatives.
 Unlike tax credits and deductions, Pell Grants add to Federal spending -- a no-no in the smaller-government-is-better 1990's. Perhaps more important, the voters considered likely to decide the outcome of this election are middle-class suburbanites, who are not likely to give President Clinton much credit for making it easier for only the poor to attend college.
 Tuition vouchers, Mr. Dole's high-profile education initiative, if enacted, would no doubt generate greater public passion, both pro and con, than the Clinton college scholarships.
 The Republican candidate proposes a four-year, $12 billion demonstration program providing "opportunity scholarships" of up to $500 a year for primary school students and $750 a year for high school students to attend any school of their choice. States (initially, up to 15 of them) would be obliged to match the scholarships at least dollar-for-dollar. In return, the states would have considerable discretion in setting eligibility criteria. But the Dole proposal does specify that recipients must come from "low and middle-income families" and that the scholarships can be spent on "any accredited school -- public, private or religious -- that chooses to participate."
 There is certainly a receptive audience for tuition vouchers, with free market-oriented economists in the forefront. The appeal is simple, they argue: public school authorities effectively have a monopoly on affordable primary and secondary education. By giving "consumers" a choice, vouchers would force public schools to compete for students the way pizza chains compete for pepperoni lovers. And the resulting competition, it is claimed, would create a win-win situation in which parents could opt for private education alternatives tailored to their tastes and needs.
 If vouchers are put in place, Ms. Hoxby of Harvard expects the big winners to be the urban poor.
 "People in central cities now have very few options," she points out, even when communities technically permit students to choose schools outside their neighborhoods. And while other experts disagree sharply on this point, Ms. Hoxby is supportive of recent research that she feels demonstrates "private school competition improves achievement levels in the inner city."
 More surprising, perhaps, Ms. Hoxby sees vouchers as an aid to heading off a greater financial crisis in public education. The school-age population is now rising: the Department of Education expects that enrollment will rise from 51 million this year to 54 million in 2006. "There is no way spending will keep up," she says. Hence, in her view, public schools are going to have to learn how to use resources more efficiently and voucher-driven competition could be the catalyst.
 The voucher proposal also offers a political bonus to the Dole campaign in focusing attention on the influence of teachers' unions within the Democratic Party. The National Education Association, a major donor of cash and workers to the Democrats, is adamantly opposed to vouchers, and Mr. Dole is making the most of it.
 "You cannot reform our schools and at the same time reap generous campaign contributions from the very groups who have run our public schools into the ground," Dole argued in a speech on July 17.
 But there is also plenty of non-partisan criticism for vouchers. Some educators worry that private and religious schools will cream off the students who can be educated at least expense, leaving demoralized public schools to cope with the tough cases. And they argue that parents are ill-informed about what educational techniques produce the best results, and will thus be prone to fads.
 What's more, even fans of vouchers raise questions about the Dole plan. The most prominent drawback, they say, is the limited amount of money: $500 to $750 per student from Uncle Sam is peanuts compared with tuition at nonsectarian private schools.
 The aid, especially after it is matched by states, would make more of a dent in the fees typically charged by religious schools. In New York, Mr. Dole has pointed out, Catholic elementary school tuition averages $2,500. But the low tuition is misleading because religious schools usually depend on contributions (cash and kind) from their congregations to cover the bills. Thus, were enrollment to expand substantially, nontuition support would be diluted and religious schools would almost certainly be forced to raise their fees.
 "Mr. Dole is proposing vouchers on the cheap," concludes Mr. Hanushek of Rochester.
 By the same token, there is concern that the money would be poorly targeted. While the Dole proposal does call for a family income cut-off for eligibility, the states would not be obliged to give priority to poor, inner-city residents. And even at just $500 to 750 per student, $3 billion a year would only cover a modest fraction of the school-age population.
 A very different criticism is that ideologically pure voucher-based education could undermine more pragmatic approaches to school reform.
 With grudging support from teachers' unions, charter schools -- schools licensed and financed by government but independently operated -- have been mandated by state legislatures in some two dozen states. And, as President Clinton argues, if they are given adequate room to experiment, they could provide the competition that critics of public school monopolies see as the primary benefit from vouchers. Indeed, Mr. Kane suggests that successful innovation bred in charter schools might flow more quickly to public schools "because charter schools pose less of a perceived threat" to vested interests.
 Will politicians' calls for vouchers and community college scholarships fade after the voters cast their ballots this week? It may be naive to assume that, once safely installed in the White House, Bob Dole or Bill Clinton would give education more attention than the traditional issues of war, peace and pork. But as they have been framed in the election campaign, either issue offers the next President a golden opportunity to scratch where Americans are really itching.
 "And in the era of just say no to Federal spending," Mr. Hanushek says, "such issues do not come along every day."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Philadelphia;
18-Story Building Makeover, With a 9-Floor Garage

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
AFTER a three-year downtown hiatus, construction cranes for office buildings are expected to rise again next spring when a mothballed 40-year-old building is renovated as the new headquarters for Morgan Lewis & Bockius, the nation's third-largest law firm, with 825 lawyers in 14 offices worldwide.
The firm, which is negotiating a 15-year lease, tentatively plans to move into 200,000 square feet of office space at Six Penn Center in mid-1998. The Rubin Organization, which jointly owns the 18-story building at Market and 17th Streets with Equitable Real Estate Investment Management, plans to gut it and use floors 2 through 10 for 490 parking spaces, with ramps built in a separate adjacent structure. Offices will occupy the 11th through 18th floors. If more office space is needed, a parking deck can be converted within a few months, said Joseph Coradino, Rubin's executive vice president. 
 "It's very flexible and may be the only transaction of its kind in the country," Mr. Coradino added. "When Conrail moved out of the building in January 1993 it remained the premier location in Philadelphia, but there weren't a lot of tenants who wanted 400,000 square feet of space."
Several law firms, insurance companies and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency are shopping for 150,000 to 300,000 square feet of office space downtown. But only a half dozen downtown buildings have that much space available.
A decade ago, said Mark Dichter, the managing partner of the Philadelphia office of Morgan Lewis & Bockius, tenants calling for 200,000 square feet of space were large enough to induce a developer to put up a new building. But these days, he added, tighter financing has meant that developers are loath to go further than than a significant renovation.
"With new construction you end up at numbers that are unacceptable for service firms, given what's going on with the revenue side of the equation," Mr. Coradino said. "In a renovation you have to be consistent with those rental figures and the premium is what you can gain in efficiency over time."
Rents for prestigious downtown buildings have stagnated in the last few years, hovering in the mid-$20's per square foot. Although Mr. Coradino would not discuss the rents being asked at Six Penn Center, nor the cost of the renovation. But brokers and developers familiar with the project estimated that the office space alone would cost at least $20 million. No one would venture an estimate on the cost of the parking garage and ramp structure.
PLANS drawn up by Kohn Pedersen Fox, the Chicago architectural firm, move the building's entrance to Market Street from 17th Street and give the ramp structure escalators and elevators in a building between Six Penn Center and the Mellon Bank Center, a 54-story, 1.3-million-square-foot building completed by Rubin in 1990. A courtyard sits between the ramp structure and the Mellon tower.
A new temperature-control system, new elevators and upgraded plumbing are among the operational improvements. And the current limestone facade that resembles old computer punch cards with its square, dark windows will be redesigned with bands of windows.
Moving from the triangular floors of its 200,000-square-foot current offices at One Logan Square in the West Market Street area to the rectangular Six Penn Center will mean "significantly" more usable space, said Mr. Dichter. Desktop computers linked to various data bases have obviated the need for a large central library in the new offices, where there will be more conference rooms for lawyers to work in teams.
"We were looking at other buildings or staying here and refitting the existing space. It would be more costly to renovate this space to our needs than to fit out new space," Mr. Dichter said. "It was the efficiency and productivity factor that motivated us. It's unusual because we can't predict the amount of space we'll need."
The firm, founded in Philadelphia in 1873, is the city's largest law partnership with 215 lawyers in a total of 425 employees. In 1983, Morgan Lewis & Bockius was among the first law firms to move from Broad Street to the West Market Street area. And its next move to Six Penn Center may be the early indicator of a revival in prime downtown office rentals.
Broad Street, on the city's north-south artery within a few streets of City Hall, had long been the backbone of Philadelphia's financial and service companies, But with the construction of new office buildings in the 50's and 80's the east-west Market Street has become the premier business location. And Six Penn Center at 17th and Market Streets is widely considered a pre-eminent location for its convenience to highways, commuter rail stations and most of the city's major employers or government offices.
Downtown Philadelphia has 14 buildings with 4 million square feet of space in mothballs -- meaning they are shut down and no longer marketed -- and as much as 900,000 square feet of space available for sublet, said Michael Kennedy, senior vice president at Jackson-Cross/Oncor International. Even top-tier buildings are losing tenants, or could, because of mergers, acquisitions or shifts of workers to surrounding suburbs.
"Companies no longer feel compelled to pay absolutely top dollar for first-class space for what is essentially a back-office operation," he said. "The nature of what's happened in Philadelphia's economy is that everyone has taken it on the chin. A lot of companies are looking to move upward into nicer space at money that is comparable, if not equal to, what they paid in the past for where they are."
The Six Penn Center lease is unusual in that few companies could take 200,000 square feet of space to be the sole or primary tenant or owner, Mr. Kennedy said. Those who do occupy entire buildings here include Sun Oil, Independence Blue Cross and Bell Atlantic.
"There's always the uncertainty with the central business districts that you'll get hammered with a negative event, like the Conrail-CSX merger announcement," said Al Schwacke, executive vice president of the Legg Mason Realty Group. "Something's going to happen and I don't think the destination is a teardown." There may be conversions to residential use or interim conversions to retail stores at street level, Mr. Schwacke said, "to carry certain buildings since the prices have come down so dramatically."
OTHER Philadelphia law firms have cut their operating overhead and pursued suburban clients by creating satellite regional offices in corporate campuses in such places as Malvern, Pa., or Cherry Hill, N.J. That strategy did not appeal to Morgan Lewis & Bockius, said Howard Meyers, the firm's managing partner.
But, he said, it was the firm's decision to retain its legal and back-office employees in one building to provide greater efficiency.
"We hope to construct a state-of-the-art conference center and a moot courtroom with a three-judge bench and jury box and lawyer's tables," he said. "Ideally, you'd have a room like that to prepare lawyers and witnesses. And a room with a camera to play that presentation back and review it."
Mr. Meyers, who manages the firm's 14 offices from Philadelphia, has overseen expansion projects from New York to Indonesia. The firm, which has offices in Princeton, N.J.; Pittsburgh, Jakarta, Indonesia, and Singapore, has relocated to new space in Frankfurt, Germany, and Tokyo within the last three years. The New York office has doubled the number of employees since 1994 and the Washington office will soon occupy a renovated building on Pennsylvania Avenue.

HEADLINE: Busy Week of Treasury Sales

 BODY:
In addition to the regular weekly bill auction of new three- and six-month bills, the Government plans to hold its quarterly refunding this week, selling 3-year notes on Tuesday, 10-year notes on Wednesday and a 30-year bond on Thursday, along with a 52-week bill.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the three-month bill was 5.01 percent; a six-month bill was 5.08 percent, and the 52-week bill was 5.15 percent. Late Friday, in when-issued trading the 3-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.90 percent, the 10-year note at 6.37 percent and the 30-year bond at 6.68 percent.

HEADLINE: To Whitman, Signs of Fiscal Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

 BODY:
Local property tax revenues rose by 3.6 percent across New Jersey this year, a relatively modest increase that is surely welcome news to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's administration. It would seem to bolster her contention that her state income tax cut and a freeze in state aid had not -- despite Democrats' dire warnings -- led to sharply higher local taxes.
But a closer examination of the property taxes in 8 of New Jersey's 21 counties shows that there are exceptions, towns where local taxes jumped by double and triple the percentage increase in their county, in some instances by 10 percent or more. These towns generally fall into two categories: older, blue-collar towns that suffer from a shrinking number of commercial and industrial taxpayers or a declining value of business properties, and rapidly growing towns struggling to keep up with rising school populations. 
 The local property tax bills in these towns rose anywhere from $400 to $800 this year, a painful slice from the household budgets of thousands of aging pensioners and young families just settling into their first homes in new developments.
The towns that had property tax increases at or below the percentage increase in their county were generally established middle- and upper-middle-class suburbs that already have relatively high property taxes.
Governor Whitman -- who is to discuss property taxes at a news conference today in Trenton -- was swept into office in 1993 in large part because of her promise to cut state income taxes. Others politicians, from Gov. George E. Pataki of New York to the Republican Presidential candidate, Bob Dole, have recognized the advantages of such promises, and offered their own tax-cut plans. But to date, there has been little evidence that tax cuts at one level of government necessarily translate into tax increases at a lower level of government.
But freezes in state aid and basic inflationary increases in local operating costs forced towns to control their expenses more aggressively and in some cases, as in the township of Dover in Ocean County, use surplus funds from previous budget years to prevent major tax increases.
Statewide, the increase in property tax revenues, to about $12.1 billion from $11.7 billion in 1995, is one of the smallest this decade and a far cry from the annual increases of 12 and 13 percent of the last half of the 1980's. The overall figures provide the Governor and her budget aides a measure of exoneration. When she started phasing in her state income tax cuts three years ago, Democrats warned of deep cuts in state aid to towns and schools and of skyrocketing property taxes in the state.
Governor Whitman's response was that she did not levy local taxes, but that local officials would do well to follow her lead and cut wasteful spending as well as share some services with neighboring towns.
At the same time, the Whitman administration has curbed spending in local school districts by imposing limits on their budgets. For the last two years, these caps have ranged from 3.6 percent to 4.8 percent in all but the poorest urban districts, down from 14.7 percent in the 1990-91 school year. Correspondingly, negotiated pay increases for teachers statewide averaged 4.9 percent last year, down from about 9 percent in 1990-91, according to the New Jersey School Boards Association. Teacher contracts settled last spring reduced annual pay increases to below 4 percent.
Traditionally, teachers' pay is the biggest single expense paid by taxpayers.
But the Whitman administration's three-year freeze on state school aid at $4 billion has helped force taxes up in districts with new housing and rapidly increasing enrollments. Aid to these districts is not pegged to their full enrollment growth.
The Governor, in response to a State Supreme Court demand to equalize school spending between rich and poor districts, has proposed a state ceiling on spending for each student and requiring voters to approve any local spending above the maximum. If enacted by the Legislature, this plan would absolve the state from blame for future increases in school taxes.
Some analysts, like Neil Upmeyer, head of the Center for Analysis of Public Issues in Princeton, say the combination of inflation and flat or reduced state aid will inevitably lead to sharper property tax increases in coming years.
"It will happen," he said. "it just takes time to play out."
In Lyndhurst, all the talk about fiscal and tax policy is arcane and hollow for Jose Pazos, 68, a retired forklift operator. He moved here in 1987 and paid $2,300 in property taxes then. "Now it's $4,000 and something," Mr. Pazos said outside a supermarket. "So it's up more than 100 percent in nine years. It's incredible. They say it's the schools, it's this, it's that. All I know is I pay more taxes and am making less money."
Eleanor O'Neil, 75, complained about a $400 increase in her property taxes this year. She and her husband, James, 80, live on pensions and Social Security and are worried that ever-increasing taxes will drive them from the home they bought here in 1950. "It's terrible," she said.
Mr. Pazos and Mrs. O'Neil both grumbled about local spending and said the Governor's income tax cut was meaningless to them.
Lyndhurst's overall tax bill for local government and schools and county government rose about 5 percent this year, said the town treasurer, Deborah Ferrato. But the local government share was up about 13 percent, she said. The big culprit was successful tax appeals by office buildings near Giants Stadium. Those rulings, by the New Jersey Tax Court, cut about $200 million from the town's $1.6 billion tax base and shifted the taxes the buildings had paid to homeowners. In addition, the tax court ordered Lyndhurst to refund about $5 million in tax overpayments to the building owners.
Mrs. Ferrato, whose property taxes rose by $823, said, "Unfortunately, the people who really get hurt are the little residential people, especially the retired ones."
As in Lyndhurst, taxes in some other older blue-collar communities in southern Bergen County exceeded the statewide increase, including Fairview, up 18.1 percent. Fairview suffered in part because town officials used $1.6 million in budget surplus the last two years to stabilize taxes and had no more extra money this year, leaving property owners with an $800,000 bill, said the town's lawyer, John Schettino. Another problem, he said, is a $1 million cut in state aid for schools and municipal government since 1991.
Taxes in another small blue-collar town with a stagnant tax base, Jamesburg in Middlesex County, rose by 12.4 percent, primarily to meet the first payment on a $6 million, 25-year bond for expansion of one of its two schools, said Vincent Olivo, the business administrator.
And in Sayreville, an older industrial town in Middlesex County, the total tax bill rose 16.2 percent, or about $420 on the average home, the treasurer, Wayne Kronowski, said. The biggest culprit was a $4.5 million increase, nearly 77 percent, for the municipal budget. Last year, he said, Sayreville officials used $3.3 million in surplus to stabilize taxes. This year, only $1 million was available. In addition, general expenses rose $1.3 million, Mr. Kronowski said.
In parts of central New Jersey, a boom in housing developments has pushed property taxes up, most notably in the once-rural towns of West Windsor (up 10.6 percent) and Montgomery (up 18.1 percent) north of Trenton. School enrollments in each are soaring, so much so that new schools now being built are already too small for all the new students expected in the near future.
Montgomery's enrollment is about 2,500 students, up 58 percent in four years, said the Superintendent, Jamie Savedoff. Taxpayers have started repaying $32 million in school expansion bonds and are preparing to vote in February on $30 million more to build a new elementary school, expand another and provide for a second floor for a middle school scheduled to open next September.
The story is about the same in the nearby West Windsor-Plainsboro regional school district.
"Our growth is the equivalent of one small school a year," said the district's business administrator, Richard Guellnitz. Its enrollment is now 8,000, up from about 3,000 in 1980, he said, and 2,000 more students are expected in coming years.
A new high school for 750 students is to open next fall, and the district is already planning to expand it for 750 more students and to build a middle school and an elementary school. To pay for all this, voters approved a $58 million bond issue on Oct. 1, guaranteeing higher taxes for years.
The state has not helped much, Mr. Guellnitz said.
"Our state aid has been flat for the last four years," he said.

HEADLINE: In America;
Opportunities Missed

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Bob Dole never had much of a chance. Voters like sunny personalities and his is too easily associated with gloom. But any slender chance the former Senate majority leader had of winning the Presidency was squandered. He was dealt a lousy hand by his party, and he played it about as poorly as you can.
Mr. Dole began the campaign as the standard-bearer of a party that misconstrued its mandate of 1994. The G.O.P. came to be seen as the party of the National Rifle Association, assault weapons and the militia movement. It was widely perceived as a slash-and-burn party dominated by ideologues who wanted to squeeze money out of popular programs like Medicare so they could give tax cuts to the very wealthy. Most egregiously, it was the party of that ubiquitous political hobgoblin Newt Gingrich and his fanatical, irresponsible followers, a wild and crazy group that would go so far as to shut down the Government in fits of childish pique. 
 Many voters, especially women, looked on in horror.
Daniel Yankelovich, the president of Public Agenda, a nonpartisan research organization that closely monitors public opinion, said: "One of the biggest leaps of the gender gap occurred when the Republicans insisted on staying with the plan to modify Medicare and give a tax cut to well-to-do people at the same time. That was not Dole's doing, but the leap in the gender gap among older women was phenomenal."
Mr. Dole did little to repair the damage. His idea of appealing to women was to note that he hadn't read the G.O.P. platform (with its strong anti-abortion plank) and to invite Representative Susan Molinari of Staten Island to deliver the keynote address at the Republican Convention in San Diego.
Meanwhile, Bill Clinton was playing his cards judiciously and well. An accomplished waffler, the President had already stolen everything that was politically useful from the Republicans, and denounced the rest as extreme. By signing the Republican welfare bill, Mr. Clinton had bolstered his poll numbers and thwarted the race-baiters so essential to Republican campaigns. (The cost, as Mr. Clinton saw it, was relatively minor -- a million or so additional kids in poverty.)
A logical strategy for Mr. Dole would have been to present himself as the steadfast and sober alternative to Mr. Gingrich's revolutionary rantings, and to Mr. Clinton's persistent waffling. Bob Dole needed to be the grown-up. Instead, he resigned from the Senate and donned the disguise of the outsider -- a bright blue blazer. (It fooled nobody.) And then he unveiled as the centerpiece of his campaign the very kind of supply-side tax-cut fantasy he had spent the better part of two decades ridiculing.
"He became a waffler himself," said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute of Public Opinion. "He was moving from Senator Dole to citizen Dole, from a fiscal conservative to a tax cutter. There was a lot of that."
When the tax-cut idea fizzled, Mr. Dole decided on a full frontal assault on Mr. Clinton's character. He went at it relentlessly. It was as if he were saying to himself: This ought to work. This ought to work. He hadn't learned the lesson of 1992 -- that it wouldn't work. Mr. Dole's frustration was palpable. "Where's the outrage?" he asked his audiences. "Where's the outrage?"
Mr. Miringoff could have told him that the character strategy was doomed. Marist pollsters asked potential voters, "If you had to choose what you feel is more important in a President, would you pick someone who has the highest personal character or someone who agrees with you on issues?"
The results weren't even close. By 71 to 29, the respondents preferred someone with whom they agreed on the issues.
Neither candidate seriously addressed the tough issues -- the future of entitlements like Medicare and Social Security, continuing economic inequality, the enormous number of Americans who still lack health coverage, the plight of the inner cities, the sorry state of public education, race relations, campaign finance reform. That would have required political courage and leadership.
Maybe next time. Perhaps in four years, on Election Day 2000, we'll have a better choice, at the end of a better campaign.

HEADLINE: U.S. Entrepreneur Is Gunned Down in Moscow

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 4

 BODY:
An American businessman involved in a long dispute over control of one of Moscow's best-known hotels was shot to death today by an unknown assailant with a machine gun.
The businessman, Paul E. Tatum, 39, a native of Edmond, Okla., and a former fund-raiser for the Oklahoma Republican Party, was killed near the entrance to the Kievsky metro station in downtown Moscow, a police spokesman said. The station is located near the Radisson-Slavyanskaya hotel, where Mr. Tatum had his office. 
 The police spokesman, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that the shooting had occurred at 5:10 P.M. and that top-level police officials were investigating the case.
Russian businessmen have frequently been killed since the collapse of Communism, although the slaying of foreign businessmen has been relatively rare. Many of the murders are contract killings and remain unsolved.
Mr. Tatum, a founding partner of the riverfront hotel, was involved in a long power struggle with the management of the joint venture that administers the property. Courts in Moscow and the United States have been looking into the dispute.
The struggle came to a head in 1994, when Mr. Tatum tried to oust the joint venture's director, reportedly going as far as to cut off his phone lines. In response, guards were posted at the hotel entrance to keep Mr. Tatum out.
The dispute is said to involve the Moscow city government and the Radisson Hotel Company, the Minnesota-based company that is Mr. Tatum's American partner.
Matt Seward, former chairman of the Oklahoma Republican Party, said his longtime friend refused to be intimidated. Mr. Tatum told him a few weeks ago that he expected a decision in the dispute soon. "And he was 95 percent sure he had won," Mr. Seward said.
Mr. Seward described Mr. Tatum as the "quintessential entrepreneur" who became fascinated by the business potential in Russia in the decade before the break-up of the Soviet Union.
"Paul's a risk-taker -- he wouldn't have built a hotel in Moscow if he wasn't a risk-taker," Mr. Seward said.
The Radisson-Slavyanskaya houses a string of shops and Western offices, including those of large broadcast media companies, and serves as the home in Moscow for dozens of expatriates. President Clinton has been staying at the hotel during his trips to Moscow.
Mr. Tatum had vowed to continue doing business in Russia despite the hotel struggle.
"This is entrepreneurs' heaven," he said in a 1994 interview. "There's no telling how quickly this country could develop and how much it could look like the United States in a very short period of time."
Officials at the hotel refused to answer questions today, and phone calls to hotel management in the United States went unanswered.
The American Embassy in Moscow had no immediate comment, apart from a terse statement saying: "We deplore the murder of any U.S. citizen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul E. Tatum. (Otto Pohl for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Eleanor L. Dulles of State Dept. Dies at 101

 BODY:
Eleanor Lansing Dulles, an economic specialist for the State Department who played a major part in planning the reconstruction of West Berlin in the 1950's, died on Wednesday in the Knollwood military retirement home in Washington. She was 101.
Her death was reported by The Associated Press on Friday. 
 Mrs. Dulles, who was sometimes called "the Mother of Berlin" for her enthusiastic efforts to revitalize the economy and culture of that battered capital as it recovered from World War II, managed to carve for herself a formidable reputation even though her two brothers, John Foster Dulles and Allen Welsh Dulles, held much higher rank in the American Government.
She was offered the State Department's Berlin desk in 1952, just before Foster Dulles was named Secretary of State.
She quickly saw trouble coming, she said in a memoir published in 1980, because Foster had been criticized for using his influence to get Allen the top job in the C.I.A. and wanted to avoid further accusations of nepotism. She was already a career diplomat, and her West Berlin position came through before Mr. Dulles's appointment, yet once he was in office, he tried to force her out. He did not succeed, she noted with some satisfaction.
Mrs. Dulles said it was difficult for a woman to serve in the State Department in that era.
"This place is a real man's world if ever there was one," she said in 1958. "It's riddled with prejudices. If you are a woman in Government service you just have to work 10 times as hard -- and even then it takes much skill to paddle around the various taboos. But it is fun to see how far you can get in spite of being a woman."
Mrs. Dulles was born in Watertown, N.Y., one of five children of a Presbyterian minister and his wife. One ancestor, John Welsh, served as envoy to Britain in Rutherford B. Hayes's Administration, and her grandfather John W. Foster and an uncle, Robert Lansing, each served as Secretary of State, under Presidents Benjamin Harrison and Woodrow Wilson, respectively.
She graduated from Bryn Mawr College with a major in social sciences, worked in refugee rehabilitation and reconstruction projects in France after World War I and returned to Bryn Mawr to earn a master's degree in labor and industrial economics.
She took odd jobs in the early 1920's -- running a punch press at the American Tube & Stamping Company in Bridgeport, Conn., and working as payroll clerk for a hair net company in Long Island City, Queens.
She also traveled extensively in Europe, studied at the London School of Economics, investigated industrial methods in 75 British firms and received a master's degree from Radcliffe College and a doctorate in economics from Harvard.
In the 1930's she studied and taught economics and finance in Paris, Geneva, Basel, Boston, the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, and Bryn Mawr. She produced scholarly books including "The French Franc, 1914-1928," "The Facts and Their Interpretation" and "The Bank for International Settlements at Work." She wrote more than a dozen books in all.
When she was 30 she met David Simon Blondheim, a philologist who, as an Orthodox Jew, was not regarded by her family as marriage material, she indicated in her memoir. She married him anyway, in 1932. In 1934, not long before the birth of their son, Dr. Blondheim committed suicide.
Mrs. Dulles, who used her maiden surname, entered Government service in 1936 as director of financial research for the Social Security Board. In 1942 she moved on to the State Department. At the Bretton Woods international monetary conference in New Hampshire in 1944, she was a prominent member of the American delegation.
The next year, she went to Vienna as the State Department's financial attache. She demonstrated keen bargaining powers -- helping to feed starving Austrians by arranging the barter of horses for German cabbages and potatoes.
Later, as special assistant to the director of the State Department's office of German affairs, Mrs. Dulles was credited with "working miracles," as one biographer put it. She helped to reduce West German unemployment and increase production.
To hasten those developments, she said, she would "send requests from Berlin for money and rush back to Washington in time to compose favorable answers." She wangled more than $1 billion for West Berlin, adorning it with the now-famous Congress Hall, which Berliners for many years fondly referred to as the "Dulleseum" and "Frau Dulles's Hut," as well as a hospital and educational centers.
Beginning in 1959, Mrs. Dulles was assigned to studying foreign aid programs and visited 60 countries on behalf of the State Department's office of intelligence and research.
She left the State Department in 1962, after her brother Allen had been dismissed from the C.I.A. in the wake of the Bay of Pigs catastrophe. Leonard Mosley wrote in his 1978 book "Dulles" that early in 1962, during the Kennedy Administration, Secretary of State Dean Rusk summoned her and said, "The White House has asked me to get rid of you."
Mrs. Dulles, in her memoirs, "Eleanor Lansing Dulles: Chances of a Lifetime," published in 1980, wrote affectionately of her older brothers but did not hesitate to say that since childhood there were frictions among the siblings. She also admitted that her strong personality won her her share of enemies.
She suffered from poor eyesight since childhood and developed deafness but remained active well into her old age.
Her survivors include her son, David, of Washington, and her daughter, Ann Dulles Joor, of Manlius, N.Y., and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: New York's Looming Welfare Burden

 BODY:
The new welfare law threatens to impose huge costs on New York City taxpayers. The city's nonpartisan Independent Budget Office, created earlier this year as part of the city's Charter reform, estimates that Federal cutbacks and requirements to put welfare recipients to work could cost the city as much as $4.3 billion over the next six years.
The 1996 law strips disability insurance and food stamps from all legal immigrants, and other forms of public assistance from new immigrants for at least five years. It will knock many children off disability rolls and limit families to five years of Federal cash assistance. The budget office expects about a third of welfare recipients to hit the five-year ceiling. 
 The budget office's estimates vary widely because it cannot predict future events and policies. Will poor families who lose Federal benefits be added to the state welfare program, Home Relief, which is paid for entirely by state and local taxpayers? The State Constitution would seem to require such a course. Will the state comply with the Federal mandate to put recipients to work within two years -- at $2,200 per placement -- even though noncompliance carries no sanction? Will the economy grow quickly or slowly?
Much also depends on whether Albany, which now splits the cost of taking care of the poor with the city, lowers its share. Any effort by the state to do so should be fiercely opposed, because local governments that pay to place most of their recipients in long-term jobs risk driving taxpayers into less-ambitious, lower-tax jurisdictions.
Depending on how these questions are answered, the budget office estimates that welfare reform could cost the city between $200 million and $4.3 billion over six years. In 2002 alone, when the city will be spending about $25 billion of its own money on all public programs, welfare reform will cost it as much as $1.2 billion. Costs will rise even higher if New York State's constitutionally guaranteed welfare system encourages migration by poor families from nearby states.
There are circumstances under which the budget projections could prove unduly pessimistic. The Republican sponsors of the Federal law say that it will radically alter the culture of the poor, prodding them into jobs and off welfare. This is possible but improbable. For more than two decades, states have steadily driven down the value of welfare payments by 30 percent or more, yet welfare rolls remain persistently high.
The cost estimates could prove too high for a second reason: Welfare recipients who reach the five-year time limit might find jobs more quickly than the budget office expects. American labor markets have proved remarkably resilient -- absorbing millions of women into the work force since the early 1970's without rising unemployment rates.
The conscientious work of the budget office proves the value of expert, nonpartisan analysis for policy makers reviewing complex options. While the office's six-year projections are full of guesswork, they provide strong evidence that life for the city under the welfare law could prove mightily unpleasant for recipient and taxpayer. Congress put the welfare burden exactly where it does not belong -- on state and local government. If the cost estimates are anywhere close to the truth, the city will face an unenviable choice between coarsening its treatment of the poor and starving its schools and other public programs of desperately needed cash.

HEADLINE: The Network Computer As the PC's Evil Twin

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The so-called network computer is an unproven product chasing a market that does not yet exist. Yet the concept of the network computer, promoted as a low-cost alternative to the personal computer, is already stirring waves of interest in corporate America.
Last week, Sun Microsystems Inc. introduced its Java station model, joining I.B.M., Oracle and a few other companies that are just beginning to market these stripped-down computers. The no-frills desktop machines typically sell for less than $1,000, including a keyboard and monitor. 
 The network computer is appealing both economically and as a management tool. It promises to reduce the costs of equipping workers with computers and it also promises to give companies more control of how their workers use information technology.
Emphasize the cost reduction and the network computer is simply bringing the benefits of modern technology to a larger audience, almost as Henry Ford did with the Model T. Emphasize the opportunities for information control and the network computer can be seen as a potential tool of tyranny, as if plucked from George Orwell's novel "1984."
"The line between these network computers being used as really effective corporate tools and being used as mind-control tiger cages is a fine one," said Paul Saffo, a director of the Institute for the Future, a research firm in Menlo Park, Calif. "There will be a real temptation for corporate managers to go too far in the direction of control."
It is only prudent to be skeptical about how a technology innovation like the network computer will be used, according to Shoshana Zuboff, a professor at the Harvard Business School, who is a social psychologist. Ms. Zuboff is the author of a landmark book on technology and work patterns, "In the Age of the Smart Machine," published in 1988.
In that book, Ms. Zuboff asserted that computer-based information technology held out the possibility of transforming the nature of work, breaking down old hierarchies as information and power were shared widely within corporations.
Since then, Ms. Zuboff has continued with her case studies of how information technology is employed. She is working on a new book on the subject, and she has become increasingly pessimistic. "The paradise of shared knowledge and a more egalitarian working environment just isn't happening," she said. "Knowledge isn't really shared because management doesn't want to share authority and power."
In many ways, the network computer seems to be a manager's dream: a closed box, no slots for inserting floppy disks or CD-ROM's. The messy, often costly, individualism of the personal computer environment can be jettisoned for greater efficiency.
No more workers installing their favorite software on an office PC. Sure, some of it may be harmless, but corporate managers recognize that that kind of openness also means vulnerability to computer viruses, hackers and high-tech thieves.
With a network computer, employees can send E-mail, write memos, schedule meetings and even browse the Web. But access to those technology resources is rationed by the managers who control the corporate computer network. For any company so inclined, it would be easy to prevent employees from tapping into Web sites that distribute information not deemed work related, from sports scores and soft porn to news and political commentary.
That kind of central control has its appeal, and it is part of the sales pitch for the network computer. Scott McNealy, the chairman of Sun Microsystems, contrasts the efficient purity of the network setting with the world of the personal computer, which he characterizes as a chaotic, costly haven for time-wasters.
To give a worker a personal computer, he says, is to invite trouble. "What's a floppy disk?" Mr. McNealy asked rhetorically. "It's a way to steal company secrets."
Personal computers, he added, are loaded with unnecessary frills that become distractions from real work as employees spend countless hours fiddling with the fonts, typefaces and other fancy features in today's multi-megabyte software.
At Sun, Mr. McNealy went so far as to ban one or two popular personal computer programs earlier this year. There may have been some initial grumbling, but Mr. McNealy explained: "I'm sorry, but who owns the computer? At my company, that's not up for debate."
To personal computer zealots, Mr. McNealy's comments are heresy, an authoritarian throwback to the bygone era of the mainframe, the high tide of centralized control in computing. The PC purists regard the personal computer as not just a product but also a movement, an instrument for advancing individual freedom and empowerment.
The personal computer has many fans among the 200 million or so people worldwide who use one. Its foremost fan has been known to run his lucrative fief in Redmond, Wash., with an autocratic hand on occasion, but he is eloquent in his defense of the empowering nature of the personal computer and of the rights of the modern knowledge worker.
"The key question is do you want to take away the individual flexibility and freedom that the personal computer provides," said William H. Gates, the chairman and cofounder of the Microsoft Corporation.
Mr. Gates accuses the champions of the network computer, led by Mr. McNealy and Larry Ellison of Oracle, of trying to portray "PC's as evil" as a marketing gimmick in an effort to sell their own products.
The campaign against PC's espouses what he calls "grinch management," a short-sighted effort to take tools away from workers and control their behavior.
"People do play computer games at work, but they also doodle with pencils," Mr. Gates said. "Do you take away their pencils? And the notion of telling workers they can go to this Web site, but not that one is silly. That's not the way a modern work force is managed. You've got to trust people."
Still, even Mr. Gates concedes that his industry must reduce the expense of owning personal computers by making them easier to use and run in corporate networks.
The total cost of a personal computer in an office network is about $13,000 a year, estimates the Gartner Group, a research firm in Stamford, Conn. The initial hardware and software costs represent less than 20 percent of the total, with the rest coming from the time spent on maintenance, training, support and users futzing with their machines.
The companies marketing network computers say their machines linked to hub computers and software, called servers, can reduce the total cost per desktop by 60 percent or more, compared with PC's.
Gartner is now conducting a cost-of-ownership study of the network computer. The results are not yet in, but William Kirwin, a research director at Gartner, says the estimated cost savings are typically far less than the network computer makers claim, probably in the 25-to-30-percent range. In addition, Mr. Kirwin noted, the estimated savings from network computers result from comparison with a poorly managed network of personal computers.
Whether the problem is workers wasting time or costly computing, the answer, it seems, is as much a management issue as a technology issue.
The corporate pilot testers of network computers agree. The CSX Corporation, a big railway and transportation company, has been experimenting with a dozen Sun Microsystem network computers for a few months. John Andrews, president of CSX Technology, the company's information technology unit, is encouraged by the early results.
"But unless you manage it properly, you can spend as much or more on network computers and expensive servers as you do on a personal computer network," Mr. Andrews said. "And you can be just as unproductive with network computers as you are with personal computers."
Mr. Andrews, in fact, has no intention of ripping out the 10,000 personal computers at CSX and replacing them with network computers. Instead, he views the network computer mainly as a gradual replacement for the company's 15,000 "dumb terminals." These are little more than monitors and keyboards linked to a mainframe or minicomputer, used for data entry, claims processing and other routine chores.
There are as many as 50 million workers worldwide using dumb terminals, still captive to the mainframe era. For them, even a stripped-down model like the network computer would seem a big step forward technologically.
For the network computer makers, the dumb-terminal replacement business is a sizable market, though far less glamorous than trying to unseat the personal computer.
Yet the terminal-replacement market has also attracted the attention of Mr. Gates. Last week, Microsoft and Intel, the dominant suppliers of personal computer technology, announced a set of specifications for their own stripped-down machine, called the NetPC. It was their answer to the network computer.
"We think we can go after the dumb-terminal market, too," Mr. Gates said.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton and 2 Senators Support Torricelli

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Nov. 3

 BODY:
In two black churches, at a labor breakfast and at a big rally in a hotel here in New Jersey's largest city, Representative Robert G. Torricelli spent the next-to-last day of his campaign for the United States Senate visiting traditional Democratic strongholds to appeal passionately for help on Election Day.
Mr. Torricelli then joined President Clinton at a rally outside City Hall in Union in the late afternoon, where both the President and New Jersey's two current Senators, Frank R. Lautenberg and Bill Bradley, urged the state's undecided voters to select Mr. Torricelli in the very tight race. 
 Mr. Bradley, who is retiring after 18 years in the Senate, passed a symbolic paper torch to Mr. Torricelli as a crowd of more than 5,000 applauded.
At his earlier appearances, Mr. Torricelli, a Democrat, tried to sum up his campaign.
"My friends, I stand before you today like a young lawyer in front of a jury of millions," he said to an enthusiastic crowd of nearly 1,000 at a breakfast rally organized by Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James, at the Robert Treat Hotel. "I've made my case. I've explained who I am and what I represent. I've put my life and all that I believe before you."
At each appearance before core Democratic supporters here, in Jersey City and in Garfield in southern Bergen County, Mr. Torricelli talked of his support for an array of Federal initiatives intended to help city dwellers.
He mentioned the television commercial produced by his opponent, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, that showed Mr. Zimmer and his wife, Marfy Goodspeed, feeding the sheep on their farm in rural Hunterdon County.
"I don't know from sheep," Mr. Torricelli said. "But I know the city of Newark."
Turnout by traditional Democrats in New Jersey's cities will be important for Mr. Torricelli on Tuesday, but so too will be the votes cast by tens of thousands of undecided voters, most of whom live in the state's sprawling suburbs.
Mr. Torricelli courted those votes today when he joined President Clinton at the Union City Hall. Union is among the vital areas in the center of the state, along a corridor between Newark and Trenton -- through Union, Middlesex and Mercer Counties -- where independent and undecided voters are likely to be critical to the outcome of the race. Polls continue to show the contest as virtually even.
"I've tried to make my case for a continuation of the moderate, bipartisan tradition in New Jersey," Mr. Torricelli said. He spoke of his support for gun control, education, environmental protection, Medicare and other matters important to middle-class voters. He also cited Mr. Zimmer's support for the conservative agenda of the House Republican leadership, mentioning in particular the fact that the Government had been shut down twice because of budget battles in Washington.
"Dick Zimmer said it was necessary," he said. "I said it was a disgrace."
Earlier in the day, Mr. Torricelli dashed from a black Baptist church in Jersey City to Mr. James's breakfast rally in Newark, and then back to breakfast in a Jersey City hotel as a guest of the Hudson County Central Labor Council, before completing his morning at another black Baptist church in Garfield. At each stop, he sought to differentiate himself from Mr. Zimmer by highlighting his support for new Federal money for mass transportation, for Federal tax credits for corporations that invest in low-income housing and for additional Federal educational aid for teaching math and science.
Mr. Torricelli said he had voted for each of these initiatives, which would bring particular benefits to urban residents. "And Dick Zimmer voted against every dollar," he said.
"These are the choices that govern our lives," he told the large crowd in the Newark hotel ballroom. Mr. Torricelli cited, too, as he has throughout the general election campaign, his votes to protect Medicare for the environment and for gun control.
He tried to link city dwellers with the mostly suburban residents of his own Congressional district, which includes parts of Bergen and Hudson Counties. He contended that affluent suburbanites would also benefit if poor children in the cities received first-rate educations and if cities experienced significant economic growth.
"I represent the people of the state because we've heard enough division," he said. "We have a common future. One future for one people."
But Mr. Torricelli was concerned primarily today with moving his core supporters to action on Election Day, to help get out the vote. "This election soon passes from me to you," he told about 400 labor union members at the Quality Inn in Jersey City. "The decision is yours. Bring home a victory on Election Day that we'll all be proud of."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Free TV Time? Zimmer Makes the Most of It

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

DATELINE: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Nov. 3

 BODY:
With only two days left to campaign in a Senate race that is one of the tightest in the country, Representative Richard A. Zimmer took advantage of 20 minutes of free television time today to lay out his philosophy of "Christie Whitman Republicanism" and to take a few swipes at his Democratic opponent.
During his appearance on WNBC-TV's "News Forum" and later in a visit to the Elks lodge here, Mr. Zimmer also showed a growing confidence. 
 "The undecideds are breaking in my direction because they see me as the candidate who stands for Christie Whitman Republicanism -- smaller government, more freedom, more economic growth, more opportunity," he said on the program.
He later expanded on that, saying to the 150 Republicans gathered at the Elks lodge that he was heartened when he picked up the morning's newspapers and saw that he was neck and neck with Representative Robert G. Torricelli, his Democratic opponent, in the latest poll conducted by the Eagleton Institute of Politics and The Star-Ledger.
"Eagleton had Christie down by 12 points" when she was running for governor three years ago, he noted. "Eagleton has me down by just one point." Then, he boasted, "I'm ahead."
The poll, completed Saturday, showed Mr. Zimmer with 41 percent support, Mr. Torricelli with 42 percent and 15 percent still undecided. The margin of error in the poll was 4.5 percentage points, which means that the race is statistically a tie. Because New Jersey's voters are known to be fickle, polls this late in a race often turn out to be off. And that's what Mr. Zimmer seemed to be referring to today.
He also had the advantage of being the only New Jersey Senate candidate on the WNBC program today because Mr. Torricelli declined the invitation. A spokesman for Mr. Torricelli, Josh Isay, said that Mr. Torricelli could not fit the 1 P.M. show, whose host is Gabe Pressman, into a long-planned schedule that included an appearance with President Clinton.
"Bob Torricelli and Dick Zimmer agreed to two debates," Mr. Isay said, "and we had two debates."
Mr. Zimmer referred a couple of times in his television appearance to Mr. Torricelli's absence, saying, "In a campaign that has been defined by 30-second ads, it's an unusual opportunity to sit on a couch together and debate the issues."
With Mr. Torricelli not present to defend his record, Mr. Zimmer described himself as the "most fiscally responsible member in the entire Congress" and his opponent as one of the biggest spenders of Federal money in the House.
Asked about Mr. Torricelli's criticism of his votes on Medicare, he said he had not voted to cut Medicare, but instead had voted against expanding Medicare. "It will be broke in five years unless we take measures to deal with it," he said.
He then criticized Mr. Torricelli for votes that made it easier for inmates on death row to appeal, saying, "You can't spend years and years abusing the court system when it's quite clear that you are guilty and you deserve to be executed."
While Mr. Zimmer often mentioned his similarities to Governor Whitman in the interview, he talked about Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential candidate, only when he was asked to. And he frequently distanced himself from Newt Gingrich, the unpopular Republican House Speaker, saying he was the most independent of the 235 Republicans in the House.
"I vote with the interest of our state and with the interest of my own conscience," he said. "I believe that is in the grand tradition of New Jersey Republicanism."
Later, in a warm room at the Elks lodge, Mr. Zimmer urged a raucous crowd of Republicans to elect him "to keep the liberals from rolling back the progress that we made this year." After that gathering, Mr. Zimmer, his wife, Marfy Goodspeed, and their two grown sons headed to a private fund-raising event.
As he has throughout the Senate campaign, Mr. Zimmer planned a minimal schedule of public events for Monday.
Both Mr. Zimmer and Mr. Torricelli have relied almost solely on television advertising to sway voters. This weekend, Mr. Zimmer began broadcasting a slightly different version of a commercial that has been on major Philadelphia and New York stations for weeks that calls Mr. Torricelli "foolishly liberal." The new version, which was broadcast during sporting events today and will appear during Monday night football, is a takeoff on a beer commercial in which frogs croak, "Bud-wei-ser." The frogs in Mr. Zimmer's ad, however, croak, "Lib-er-al" as they gaze at Mr. Torricelli.
"Everyone who has seen it has laughed, but they get the point," said Larry Weitzner, Mr. Zimmer's campaign consultant.

HEADLINE: An Old Friend Called Giuliani, and New York's Cable Clash Was On

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
It began with a phone call to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on Sept. 20, an entreaty that would soon mire City Hall in a feud between two media conglomerates. On the line was an old friend of the Mayor, Roger Ailes, a former Republican political consultant who is now chairman of the 24-hour news channel started by Rupert Murdoch.
Mr. Ailes was blunt: Time Warner was refusing to transmit the new channel to its 1.1 million cable customers in New York City. Would Mr. Giuliani try to get the company to reverse its decision? 
 Recently disclosed court records show the phone call from Mr. Ailes was the opening maneuver in an aggressive effort by Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation to gain the Mayor's support in the clash with Time Warner, a burst of lobbying that led to an unusual alliance between government and a major corporation.
In all, Mr. Murdoch's lieutenants have held more than 25 conversations and at least 2 private meetings with senior Giuliani administration officials since Sept. 20, often to coordinate strategy as the Mayor battled Time Warner on behalf of Mr. Murdoch, according to the records and interviews.
The contacts are documented in thousands of pages of court papers in a lawsuit that Time Warner has filed against the administration. Time Warner wants a Federal District Judge, Denise Cote, to continue to bar Mr. Giuliani from transmitting Mr. Murdoch's Fox News Channel on one of the five stations that the city controls on Time Warner's cable systems. A ruling could come as early as today.
The basic conflict between the two companies is over Time Warner's refusal in the middle of September to accept the Fox News Channel. Time Warner said at the time that there was no space on its cable systems, and that more than 30 other programmers were also waiting for slots.
Mr. Murdoch and his aides labeled that explanation ludicrous, saying that Time Warner was engaging in anticompetitive behavior to protect its own news channel, CNN, which it acquired recently in a merger with Turner Broadcasting.
It was less than three days after Mr. Murdoch learned of Time Warner's rejection of the channel that Mr. Ailes called Mr. Giuliani, court papers show.
The Mayor and his aides defend their conversations with the News Corporation, stressing that they want the Manhattan-based Fox News Channel to succeed to protect local jobs. Time Warner executives contend that the contacts demonstrate that Mr. Murdoch, a prominent conservative who also owns The New York Post, wields excessive influence over the Mayor.
News Corporation executives had previously described in interviews how they had received promises of help from a trio of powerful Republicans -- Mr. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki and Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco -- after lobbying them at a party that Mr. Murdoch threw in Manhattan on Oct. 1 to celebrate the debut of his channel. Though that event seems to have been the only instance when Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Murdoch talked in person about the dispute, their chat led in part to the Mayor's decision a week later to try to transmit the Fox News Channel on the city-run Crosswalks cable station, administration officials said.
But sworn depositions and affidavits in the court papers show how executives at the News Corporation began reaching out to the Mayor and his top aides before the party -- and how they received a swift response.
For example, after the conversation with Mr. Ailes on Sept. 20, the Mayor called Fran Reiter, his Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Ms. Reiter said in a deposition.
The Mayor told her to look into the matter immediately, so that day she called Mr. Ailes and Arthur M. Siskind, Mr. Murdoch's chief counsel.
Mr. Siskind and a senior vice president at the News Corporation, Bill Squadron, then met with several senior administration officials on Sept. 26. Among those present were Ms. Reiter and Paul A. Crotty, the city's corporation counsel.
Mr. Siskind and Mr. Squadron urged Ms. Reiter to call the chairman of Time Warner, Gerald M. Levin, to persuade him to reconsider the company's refusal. She asked the News Corporation executives to put their complaints in writing.
The next day, Mr. Siskind sent her a three-page letter urging the administration to "take whatever steps are necessary" to punish Time Warner.
Ms. Reiter said in her deposition that over that weekend -- Sept. 28 and Sept. 29 -- she and her aides repeatedly tried to find a home number for Mr. Levin or Time Warner's president, Richard D. Parsons, so she could call them. She said she finally located another executive at Time Warner, Derek Johnson, at his home. She told Mr. Johnson that it was very important for her to speak with Mr. Levin or Mr. Parsons.
"I said that if it were convenient for them, that I would be happy to get on a plane and make myself available to them someplace other than New York," she said in her deposition, "but that I thought these were very serious issues and that if the city could help in facilitating a solution, we very much wanted to do that."
According to the court records, a few days later, after Ms. Reiter had still not spoken to Mr. Levin, Mr. Siskind left a message for Ms. Reiter's chief of staff, David Klasfeld. "Arthur's understanding," the message said, "is that Mr. Levin will be in town through Wednesday and then going out to the West Coast."
Administration officials had such close ties to the News Corporation that in August and September, Mr. Klasfeld handled some of the arrangements for Mr. Murdoch's party on Oct. 1, according to the court documents. After at least three conversations with Mr. Squadron, Mr. Klasfeld helped the News Corporation obtain permission to put up a tent and block off part of 48th Street for the event. Those duties are usually handled by lower-ranking officials.
Mr. Giuliani and his aides acknowledged that they had many conversations with News Corporation executives, but they said there was nothing inappropriate about them. They said some of the contacts were little more than 30-second exchanges of information.
They pointed out that they typically have dozens of discussions a week with big local companies about economic development issues, so it was not unusual for them to talk to the News Corporation. The Mayor has repeatedly said that if the Manhattan-based Fox News Channel is not shown in much of the city, the nation's largest media market, it would not be successful, threatening hundreds of local jobs.
"You know, excuse me if, as the Mayor of the City of New York, I don't feel like it's my obligation to fight for them," Mr. Giuliani said on his radio show last month.
The Mayor has declined to describe his contacts with executives from the News Corporation, saying only that he may have spoken to Mr. Murdoch and Mr. Ailes three or four times. Pressed by reporters to provide more details, he replied, "I am not going to allow you to interrogate me. That is just absurd."
Asked about the contacts with the News Corporation, Mr. Klasfeld, Deputy Mayor Reiter's chief of staff, said, "During the period of time in question that you are talking about, our office had at least as many conversations with officials and representatives of Time Warner as we did with officials and representatives of the News Corporation."
Mr. Murdoch has declined requests for interviews, referring questions to Mr. Siskind.
The court records show that Mr. Siskind alone had more than a dozen conversations with the administration. He said in an interview that he could not recall how many times he had spoken to administration officials, but he said he did not tell them what to do. "We were very pleased that they were responsive," Mr. Siskind said. "That is what mayors and governors are supposed to do, look out for the economic welfare of their constituencies."
But Time Warner executives accused the Mayor of going out of his way to aid Mr. Murdoch because he is a powerful conservative who owns two important media outlets in the city, The Post and WNYW, Channel 5, where Mr. Giuliani's wife, Donna Hanover Giuliani, works.
"The extent that this was done shows that they were aware how much political power they have over the administration, and they are willing to use it," said Richard Aurelio, president of Time Warner's cable subsidiary in the city. "This was a really incredible exercise of political power. And it is the way that the Giuliani officials responded that is really more alarming, the ferocious nature of it."
The Giuliani administration has denied accusations the Mayor is influenced by the News Corporation because of his wife's job, and Mr. Squadron, the News Corporation senior vice president, scoffed at Time Warner's complaints.
"It is incredibly disingenuous for Time Warner, which has a huge and sophisticated lobbying operation, to criticize another company for raising concerns with public officials," Mr. Squadron said. "We wouldn't question their fundamental right to petition government, nor would we expect them to question ours."
