HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
Campaigns Fail To Stir Passion Among Voters

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Bill Clinton and Bob Dole have crisscrossed the land for months, even years, to inspire voters. Businesses, unions and parties have spent hundreds of millions of dollars to drill home differences between the candidates. Ominous accusations have been traded. The reputations of political consultants have shot to glittering heights, then burst spectacularly.
And all of it has left Larry Edwards merely wistful, longing for the passion of a movie about politics he once saw on television. 
 "It would be great if that's what things were really like," Mr. Edwards said about the movie, "Speechless," in which two speechwriters vie on behalf of their candidates and fall in love. "But this is the real world, and there's nothing that exciting. I would love to get excited about a candidate and donate my time and walk the streets for him, but, gosh, I just can't."
The Presidential campaign and the electorate this year are strangely wan, according to pollsters, television ratings and even Mr. Dole. Mr. Edwards settled on perhaps the least exalted of reasons to vote for President Clinton, in an absentee ballot he had already sent to Montana, where he lived until recently.
"It's a question of who can hurt us the least," said Mr. Edwards, a 43-year-old power systems dispatcher for the Department of Energy here. "I don't think Clinton's going to hurt us, because he's got too many other things to worry about."
The candidates may be fighting hard for Arizona, but their passion is not widely reciprocated here, judging from lengthy interviews with more than three dozen residents in the last two days. For all the millions of carefully chosen words delivered this year, Marisela Munoz, who became a citizen last November after 23 years here, heard nothing to move her to register to vote, despite the registration booth at the company where she is an account representative.
Some who pay attention to politics, the ones who speak longingly of men like Hubert H. Humphrey and Barry Goldwater, said the candidates dumbed their campaigns down, aggravating voters' cynicism by repeating mindless messages in endless loops.
"This is not 'War and Peace,' " said Jill Gering, sitting in her courtyard in the historic Willo district here Saturday evening. "It's more like a Harlequin romance." She explained: "The hero has dark hair or light hair, but the stories are the same. The writing is light, but with no substance."
Her voice rose with indignation as Mrs. Gering, a housewife and Clinton supporter, described the "Chinese water torture" of Mr. Clinton's bridge to the 21st century.
"Sometimes you feel like strangling them more than voting for them," she said. "How stupid do they think we are?"
While the repetition may have offended those who pay attention, it has not been enough to break through to some who do not. Despite all the advertisements, Tim Gitch, an electrician, did not know about Mr. Dole's proposed tax cut until a reporter told him. Nor, once told, did he much care. "I just got tired of listening to all of their stories," he said of politicians.
Each voter, here and across the country, has his or her own reason for tuning out, or in. Aggregated, the reasons can form clumps big enough to support any interpretation for the stasis of the 1996 campaign -- for the fact that Mr. Clinton's lead in the polls has scarcely budged for a year, while voters, yawning, channel-surfed away from the conventions and debates.
Some say the economy's strength explains it; others blame the press, excessive polling, or advertising; still others say the candidates stuck to bland topics.
But the exasperation of voters like Mrs. Gering is still far from indifference. For all the talk about picking the lesser of two evils, or voting against a candidate rather than for one, many here said they were still following the campaign, if less closely than campaigns past. Some are enthusiastically committed to their candidate.
Told of Mrs. Munoz and Mr. Gitch, David Flint, a volunteer manning the Dole headquarters alone at 10:30 Friday night, just shook his head. "There has been a lot of interest on both sides in this campaign," he said doggedly, "at least among people who care."
While Mr. Gitch may have stopped listening, in the cinder-block ranch house right next door in the suburb of Chandler, Brian Shaw likes to watch "Meet the Press" on Sunday mornings with a Republican friend and debate Mr. Clinton's character. And Mr. Shaw, a loan officer, has plenty of other matters to worry about, including four sons, three of them triplets 2 1/2 years old.
Earl de Berge, who edits the independent Rocky Mountain poll here, said voters might mouth cynicism learned from the media, but ultimately vote with hope. "Does the voter really go in and vote 'no'?" he said. "I don't think so. I think the voter goes in and votes for their aspirations for the country."
If voters are excited about the campaign anywhere, they should be excited here. Arizona has been fiercely contested, with both candidates paying late-campaign visits. If he wins Arizona, Mr. Clinton would be the first Democrat to do so since 1948. A poll in today's Arizona Republic put Mr. Clinton ahead by 12 points.
The economy is booming here. The White House is only too pleased to supply statistics showing a gain of 336,100 jobs over the last four years, with home building rising 16 percent a year. Senator John McCain, a Republican, said such growth helps explain the absence of political ferment. "People are generally satisfied with their lives," he said. "There is just not a lot of the fervor that there was in 1994. But even in 1994 there was not the fervor that there was in other parts of the country."
Mr. McCain predicted on Friday that his former colleague would carry Arizona, but many voters said that with the economy strong Mr. Dole had not proved a convincing alternative.
"What race?" asked Beryl Shears over his back fence, when asked what he made of the Presidential contest. Mr. Shears, who owns a small aerial firefighting business and supports Mr. Dole, said he nevertheless considered the contest over when Mr. Dole won the nomination. "I didn't think he had the dynamics to compete with Clinton," he said. "I don't think he's dynamic or eloquent enough to get his points across."
That conclusion has been reflected in national polls for months, a key difference between this race and the one in 1992. As early as July, 71 percent of voters nationally had concluded Mr. Clinton would win, said Andrew Kohut, the pollster who directs the Pew Research Center.
"It's how voters size up Dole," Mr. Kohut said. "They sized him up as not much of a threat to Clinton's re-election, and they did it early."
That kind of talk drives some crazy. "I've been waiting for somebody to ask me questions for years," said a delighted Eric Scott Bloom, pausing as he pushed his son, Kyle, in a stroller past the shops of downtown Tempe. Mr. Bloom, an artist, said he disbelieved polls because he knew no one who had been questioned. "The polls are horsehockey," he said.
Some voters said the polls seemed to reflect the bias of the press, which they said helped lock in Mr. Clinton's lead. "They always show Dole on the balcony of his condo, like he's not doing anything," said Fay Harris, as her bulldog, Jezebel, snuffled about her Willo district living room. "They always show Clinton out there smiling and shaking hands."
But up the aisle of palm trees along her street, Palm Lane, a television news producer reflected not bias, but indifference toward the race. "I have about no interest in it, except what I put on my show," said Corey Lewis, the producer of the KTVK weekend morning program. Mr. Lewis is not voting this year.
Some said news reports blunted the public appetite, not by slanted coverage, but by focusing on strategy. Bob Connelly, a Clinton supporter, angrily recalled an Arizona Republic headline after Mr. Clinton's visit here Thursday: "Clinton Plays It Safe."
"It was a strategy headline rather than an issues headline," he said, sounding like as much an editor as the fire captain he is. "That doesn't tell me anything about what he said." He said coverage of Mr. Dole's campaign marathon boiled down to: "Will the old goat make it?"
No voter cited the advertisements bombarding them as an influence on their thinking, except as a negative. But the campaigns do not believe that. Playing to cynicism about politics, or at least about Bob Dole, the Clinton campaign has a radio advertisement here that asks: "When's the last time you heard Bob Dole say something that would actually help solve a problem?"
Such commercials are influencing at least one family. Trish Karpurk plans to vote for Mr. Dole. But her son, Christopher, who is 8 years old, backs Mr. Clinton.
Christopher allowed that he hoped Mr. Clinton would lower taxes. But he also offered a unique reason for throwing his support behind the President, one that had nothing to do with choosing the lesser of two evils: "I like Socks," he said.

HEADLINE: Casino Jobs in Indiana Attract People Who Want a New Life

BYLINE: By DANIEL I. DORFMAN 

DATELINE: EAST CHICAGO, Ind., Nov. 2

 BODY:
Irene Moore, who has lost so many times before, stood among the hopefuls looking to come out as winners of jobs at a new casino here.
"I like the atmosphere," said Ms. Moore, a 45-year-old unemployed woman from nearby Gary, explaining the attraction of casino work. "It puts you into a fantasy world. This is especially true when you live in Gary and you look at the obituaries to see who got shot the night before. This is a chance to forget all your troubles." 
 Ms. Moore, who is on disability and spends most of her time caring for her mother, who has Alzheimer's disease, was one of about 300 applicants seeking jobs at the Showboat Mardi Gras riverboat casino, which is scheduled to open next April. For practical reasons like job security, or simply in the hope of adding a thrill to their lives, people of all income levels gathered at a local high school for initial interviews, hoping to become dealers in games of blackjack or poker or to preside over a roulette table. The prize: $4.50 an hour, plus tips that can add $10 an hour more.
Kathy Bravo, 42, who also lives in Gary, is not interested in a job for the electric casino atmosphere. Her motivation is cold cash.
Mrs. Bravo is a safety director for a trucking company that is on shaky financial ground. With her only son in college, she wants an income that is certain. She said she was tired of worrying whether her paycheck would clear: "I've had one check bounce already."
East Chicago, a town of 34,000 people about 20 miles southeast of Chicago, reached its heyday a generation ago with a robust economy based in oil refining and steel. Now, as those industries have employed fewer and fewer people, the city is punctuated with empty lots and abandoned buildings.
"When you graduated from high school, all you had to do was show up the next Monday and your job was waiting for you at the steel mill," said Edward Williams, a lifelong resident.
Mr. Williams is now the director of education and development for Showboat, the company that will operate the riverboat. It is the first to be developed in East Chicago, and the fourth in northwest Indiana, since riverboat gambling was approved by the state in 1993.
East Chicago, which is 42 percent Hispanic and 32 percent black, has a per capita income of just over $9,000 a year. Unemployment approaches 40 percent among members of minority groups in the area.
In an effort to turn those dreary statistics around, East Chicago allowed Showboat to come in, with the promise of 1,800 jobs, including 500 dealer positions. First priority for the jobs will go to East Chicago residents, with second priority to other northwest Indiana residents.
On this cold morning, not just the disadvantaged showed up with the hope of gaining a dealer job. Arthur Leeds, 47, a financial investment researcher from the affluent Chicago suburb of Glenview, made the trip. Mr. Leeds, who estimated his income at $50,000 a year, said seeing new faces was motivation for wanting to revive a career he had in Las Vegas 20 years ago. "Right now," he said, "I spend a lot of my time alone. With this job, you meet people, you get to know regular customers, and you build up a rapport with some of the people."
Scott Jones, 24, of Merrillville, Ind., has visions of being a blackjack dealer for a combination of reasons. The first is financial, as he was furloughed on Friday from his $12.40-an-hour job as a track laborer at a local railroad company.
But Mr. Jones was also attracted by the bells and whistles of a casino. "I know the railroad job will eventually turn into a nice job from which I'll be able to retire," he said. "But this is a more exciting environment than pulling railroad tracks."
Those offered jobs who have never worked in a casino before will have to go through a training program. But even those with no casino experience may find that certain skills picked up in other jobs are useful.
Ms. Bravo was asked in her interview how would she handle a customer who used foul language. "I've worked at a trucking company," she said she told the interviewer. "Foul language is not a problem."

GRAPHIC: Photo: About 300 people lined up on Saturday at Central High School in East Chicago, Ind., to apply for jobs at the Showboat Mardi Gras riverboat casino, which opens in the city just outside of Chicago in April. (Jack Spratt for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Election Jitters; Pound Reaches Another High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell to another low against the British pound yesterday and ended mostly weaker against other currencies, hurt by traders selling the dollar ahead of the elections. Although a victory today by President Clinton has been factored into the market, traders said a fear of strong Democratic gains in House and Senate races was putting pressure on the dollar.
The Democrats are perceived by some traders to be more willing than Republicans to increase the budget deficit, which would increase the risk of inflation and, to some, undermine the confidence of investors in dollar-denominated assets. 
 "I think there's some apprehension if the Democrats retake Congress," said Robert Katz, a trader at the MTB Bank Corporation in New York. "We might have seen some people getting out of the dollar because of that."
Tom Hoge, a vice president for corporate foreign exchange at the Bank of New York, added: "You've got concern that the Democrats could come away with more than just a Presidential win. That would be a pretty resounding negative for the dollar."
Late in New York yesterday, the German mark traded at 1.5104 to the dollar, down from 1.5145 on Friday. The pound was up to $1.6449, from $1.6370, its highest level since March 1995.
Against the yen, the dollar ended a little higher at 113.75, up from 113.31 on Friday. Traders attributed that partly to widespread weakness in the yen, particularly against the pound. The dollar briefly dipped against the yen early in the afternoon in the United States, after Toyoo Gyohten, a former top Japanese finance official whose views are considered influential, said the yen was too weak and should trade at 110 or less to the dollar. But the dollar began to recover shortly afterward.
The pound sterling has been rising for the last few weeks. British interest rates have increased, and with that, the attractiveness of pound-denominated assets.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Friday included: 1.2662 Swiss francs, down from 1.2690; 5.1090 French francs, down from 5.1200, and 1,517.50 Italian lire, up from 1,515.50. The Canadian dollar sold for 74.85 cents, compared with 74.97 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Up In September

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Construction spending rose unexpectedly in September, led by the biggest jump in government-financed building projects in more than five and a half years, the Commerce Department said today.
Total spending on new construction rose 1.9 percent, to a record annual rate of $573.4 billion in September, the department said. It was the biggest increase since a 2.3 percent gain in March and stood in contrast to economists' forecasts of a one-tenth of 1 percent decline. 
 Analysts said stronger government spending was taking up the slack from sluggish private-sector spending after a strong first half in which new housing construction surged.
Spending on privately financed and public projects rose in September, but by far the largest part of the increase came in government spending, which jumped 6.4 percent, to a $147 billion rate, after falling 1.4 percent in August.
There were big gains in spending to improve highways and streets and smaller increases for housing and redevelopment, schools and hospitals and for water treatment plants.
Spending edged up four-tenths of 1 percent, to $426.4 billion, on private projects after rising 1.4 percent in August.
"Pubic outlays are essentially supporting the construction industry," said Marilyn Schaja, economist for the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York.
The department said spending on construction of single-family homes fell to $155.9 billion in September from $157.3 billion in August.
"Residential construction spending is slipping, but not by very much," said Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass.
The department said last month that construction starts on new homes and apartments fell 6 percent in September after a 4 percent gain in August.
Ms. Latta noted there were signs that office-building could pick up since shortages of space in many cities were pushing commercial rents higher.
"I think we can look forward to some recovery on the commercial side over the next year," she said.
During September, spending on new nonresidential buildings like offices and industrial parks jumped to a $142.3 billion rate from $140.3 billion in August.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Am I Better Off?

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Am I better off than I was four years ago?
No. In a way important to me I am not only worse off than in 1992 but worse than ever before in my adult life. I have been cheated of the opportunity to make a decision satisfactory to me in the choice of a President, the single most important privilege of citizenship. 
 When politicians running for office put that question, somehow it is taken for granted that the question and the answer both mean economically.
I have been poor. I did not care for it and do not intend to be poor again. I never will have a lot of money, not even a little lot.
My most important assets are political and they make me and my fellow Americans richer and happier than most of the people on earth. I plan to look after them like the money in the bank and annuity they are. When I feel my pocket being picked I will shout my head off.
That is not sentimentality but the essence of realism in a democratic society. The combination of a constitutional right and the understood privilege of being able to exercise it with whatever intelligence and judgment a citizen can muster is the essence of a functioning democracy. Without the privilege, the right withers until all that is left on the political branch is cynicism, a foul fruit.
For the first time in my voting life, neither major party has offered us a choice that pays suitable honor to our intelligence and citizenship. (What Ross Perot showed in 1992 about his lack of personal stability disqualifies him from the Presidency).
Bob Dole's problem was not that he did not want the Presidency enough, as some of his critics and friends say, but that he wanted it too much. He wanted it so much that he would not tell himself the truth. He was equipped to be a senator but not leader of the nation. No shame in that, unless you refuse to face it.
He showed little intellectual range and no intellectual clarity. They are the minimum requirements to win a change in leadership -- the ability of a challenger to display his hopes and mind so clearly that the voters consider him at least the inspirational equal of the incumbent they have come to know for four years.
Mr. Dole could not do that. He not only did not speak or think clearly -- much of the time he was unintelligible.
And whatever the campaign or his Senate career showed, it was not the ability to make a decision effectively -- consult or inform those who had to be, operate candidly at least with his own staff. The thought of him mumbling and ducking through a national security crisis quickly moved from amusing to terrifying.
And then, the major mistake -- he acted as the party's prisoner, not its chief. He ran on positions he knew were unacceptable to most people.
Mr. Dole told David Brinkley his basic slogan is "I keep my word." Maybe -- but in his case a frightening thought. That means he would keep his word to fight the right of abortion, keep a cuckoo-land position that tobacco was not really addictive, keep fighting gun control, keep struggling for a deficit-boosting tax policy he once said was like playing football without a helmet, keep an anti-immigrant line so nasty that he would throw little kids out of school unless their parents had the right immigration papers. This man would make breaking his word a gift to the nation.
That brings us to President Clinton. When he breaks his word he does it big. At home, he broke it about his much-proclaimed love for the poor, about immigration and about all his promises to run an ethical Administration.
Abroad he broke it even bigger -- by sacrificing the human rights of the Chinese people in favor of kowtowing to the Chinese Communists, a historical disgrace for him and the U.S. He seems about to break his word to keep U.S. forces in Bosnia no more than a year. He allowed Islamist militancy to establish its first European beachhead by permitting Iran to send arms to Bosnia's Muslims. When Saddam Hussein attacked the Kurds in northern Iraq, Mr. Clinton ordered a few futile missile attacks in the south. That's how he kept his word to contain Iraq.
Neither man is a satisfactory choice. But not voting is a civic dereliction. So I will go to the booth to choose one but will keep shouting that my pocket has been picked.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Edge Upward, With Dow Climbing by 19.75

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks edged up yesterday in cautious trading before today's elections.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.75 points, to 6,041.68, struggling past a 10-point morning deficit as interest rates edged lower in the bond market. Broader measures were mixed, with blue-chip and other big companies outperforming speculative issues, even in the volatile technology sector, where established names gained ground and smaller companies edged lower. 
 "If you had some money burning a hole in your pocket, you put it in liquid names with a degree of comfort where nobody can yell at you tomorrow," said Charles G. Crane, director of research at the investment firm Spears, Benzak, Salomon & Farrell.
Stocks drew some support from the bond market, where the yield on the 30-year Treasury -- a key determinant of corporate and consumer borrowing costs -- fell to 6.66 percent, from 6.68 percent on Friday.
But many traders continued to limit their exposure to any potential jolts from the elections. Analysts have expressed concern about inflationary government spending if the Democrats take control of Congress in addition to the White House.
The highlight of the lackluster session was British Telecommunications' proposed $22 billion acquisition of MCI Communications, which was announced on Sunday after a flurry of rumors on Friday that prompted MCI to confirm that talks were under way. MCI shares, which jumped 5 1/8 on Friday, gained an additional 1/2, to 30 3/4, as the Nasdaq's most active issue yesterday. British Telecom's American depository receipts -- each representing 10 ordinary shares -- soared 6 1/8, to 61 5/8, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. But AT&T slumped 5/8, to 33 3/4, and Sprint fell 1 5/8, to 41 7/8, amid concerns about tough competition from their big new rival. In a separate deal that added some spark to yesterday's lackluster trading, J. C. Penney announced Sunday that it was expanding its drugstore business by acquiring Eckerd for about $3.3 billion in cash, stock and assumed debt. Eckerd jumped 4 3/8, to 33 1/4, while Penney fell 1 7/8, to 51 1/8.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.96 points, to 706.73, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.39, to 375.07.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 1.30, to 1,220.48, cushioned by some gains in technology bellwethers such as Intel, up 1 5/8, to 110 3/8, and Cisco Systems, up 3/8, to 110 3/8.
Shares of General Motors rose 1 5/8, to 55 5/8, as workers at an important metal stamping plant in Indianapolis returned to work.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1701 words

HEADLINE: Empty Buildings, Precious Space;
Long Island Debates Future of Psychiatric Hospitals

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I.

 BODY:
More than a century ago, Manhattan's insane asylum, as it was called then, opened an experimental farm colony on 1,000 acres of wild countryside here. The property cost $25 an acre.
Inmates cleared the land, constructed buildings, made the furniture and mattresses, sewed their clothing, grew crops and raised dairy cattle, pigs and chickens. 
 The idea of a self-contained community quickly caught on with the state's Commission on Lunacy. Before long, western Suffolk County, with an abundance of cheap land and a steady supply of patients from New York City, became the global capital of psychiatric hospitals.
At its peak, in the 1950's, the system of state institutions housed 33,000 patients.
"I remember reading in the Guinness Book of Records in the 1970's that the three biggest mental hospitals in the world were, in order, Pilgrim State, Central Islip and King's Park -- all of them right here," said Suffolk's planning director, Stephen M. Jones. In addition, the system included an institution for the retarded, the Long Island Developmental Center.
Today, everything has changed. The hospitals are closing, prompting intense debate over the future use of the properties, which include about 270 buildings.
Suggestions ranging from nature preserves to casinos reflect the conflicting desires to preserve a low-density suburban style but also foster development for property-tax relief and new jobs for Long Island's struggling economy.
The debates echo across the nation as more psychiatric hospitals close their doors.
Decades of deinstitutionalization have emptied nearly all the Suffolk institutions. The Developmental Center closed in 1993. This month, its small residual operation at Central Islip Psychiatric Center will move out. Next month, Kings Park will shut down. About 1,300 patients will be consolidated in a small, renovated part of Pilgrim that will be the token survivor of the old system.
As the hospitals have faded away, relentless suburban sprawl has enveloped them, with more than a million people now living within several miles of the four sites. And the old hospital properties, once so cheap, are among the largest and most valuable tracts left here.
The state is eager to sell them to raise cash. To attract bidders, officials are considering selling the land -- totaling nearly 2,000 acres, or more than twice the size of Central Park -- all at once.
But what is to be done with the sites?
"These are tremendous assets and opportunities, and we don't want to blow it by letting them fall into wrack and ruin or by developing them improperly," Mr. Jones said.
A delicate issue arose over the all-but-forgotten cemeteries at three hospitals. About 24,000 indigent patients are buried there, most without visible markers.
"I suggested one cemetery for more active use like a soccer field or picnic area, but people were just offended," Mr. Jones said. When he proposed moving another cemetery to make way for a courthouse, "everybody was horrified," he said. "So now we're treating it as inviolate open space."
To date, the most striking proposal calls for a commercial recreation "sportsplex," like the Chelsea Piers in Manhattan, on 100 acres at Pilgrim. Planners say it would cost $157 million, create 2,150 jobs and generate $147 million a year in business.
A proposal from State Senator Owen Johnson would add a 7,000-seat minor league baseball park on 35 acres at Pilgrim. Other plans include housing, golf courses, parks, schools, retail stores, offices and light industry.
Critics contend that in its eagerness to profit from the sites, the state has forgotten the hospitals' purpose and should earmark the proceeds for psychiatric services. D. J. Jaffe, a spokesman for the Alliance for the Mentally Ill, a patients' rights group, said, "These properties are a legacy that should be used to benefit the mentally ill."
Nationwide, the rising pace of closings is setting off debates that parallel Suffolk's. From 1970 to 1990, 14 psychiatric hospitals closed, according to the National Association of State Mental Hygiene Program Directors. But since 1990, 32 have closed and 10 more are to shut down soon.
In Connecticut, the closing of a hospital in Norwich last month left the state with just one psychiatric hospital. The fate of the 800-acre Norwich campus is undecided. Local officials favor using it for a community college, but there is speculation that Gov. John G. Rowland will sell it to a developer.
Suffolk's hospitals have been a minefield for politicians. Gov. Hugh L. Carey angered Brentwood residents when he converted part of Pilgrim into a prison in 1982. Campaigning to succeed him, Mario M. Cuomo promised to close it, and did. But in the 1990's, he angered the neighbors of the Long Island Developmental Center in Melville by trying to use 50 acres for a headquarters for Olympus America, the camera company. Opponents blocked it in court.
Chastened by such backlash, Gov. George E. Pataki's administration devised an elaborate process to decide what to do with the land. The Empire State Development Corporation, a state agency designed to bring business to New York, and a state interagency group are working with consultants, county and town officials and a citizens' advisory panel at each site.
No one is sure why the hospitals were clustered here, besides the obvious factors of open space and access via the Long Island Rail Road.
The original idea was to give patients fresh air, refuge from urban stress and work that allowed exercise, therapy and job training. But critics say that banishment undoubtedly played a role. Many patients spent their lives here without ever being visited by a friend or relative.
Central Islip opened in 1889. The next year came Kings Park, an offshoot of the Kings County asylum in Brooklyn. Pilgrim joined the system about 1930. The Long Island Developmental Center opened in 1965.
The hospitals built their own roads, water supply, sewers and heating and power plants. Until the 1950's, patients grew fruits and vegetables and ran printing presses, shoe shops, dairy plants, slaughterhouses, bakeries and laundries. They did plumbing, carpentry, cleaning, and cooking. They formed a marching band and symphony orchestra, staged variety shows and made toys and dolls to sell.
For decades, western Suffolk's landscape was dominated by the hospitals' drab red-brick towers, topped by green copper roofs. With 15,000 employees, the hospitals also dominated the economy.
"This was the Grumman of Suffolk," said Desmond Ryan, who became the fourth generation of his family to work at Kings Park as a ward attendant. Now he is the director of the Association for a Better Long Island, a developers' group.
Change began with the advent of psychotropic drugs in the 1950's. They enabled many patients to function more normally and move into apartments and group homes. Scandals over dismal conditions -- not a charge lodged against Suffolk's hospitals -- accelerated the trend.
Now the empty buildings, with their barred windows, pose problems. Some are adaptable, but others are not. Neglect, vandalism and fire have taken a toll. Even demolition would be costly, with complications like asbestos removal.
Each site has unique features that shape the planning debate.
Unlike the others, Central Islip has already spun off most of its more than 1,000 acres, leaving only 87 to be developed.
"The hospitals kept these towns humming, and Central Islip went into a tailspin" when downsizing hit, said Mr. Jones, the planner. Desperate for new jobs, Islip officials enticed the New York Institute of Technology to the site in 1982. It was a good fit, right down to keeping a street name, Admissions Drive.
Other developments followed: a golf course, a park, several hundred homes, light industry and a complex of state and county courts. Now under construction is a $212 million Federal building to house 1,300 workers. For the remainder, planners recommend 300,000 square feet of business offices and a 130,000 square-foot shopping center.
Of the sites, Pilgrim has the best highway access. Years ago, large chunks were parceled off: 207 acres for Suffolk Community College and other pieces for industry, a preserve and youth detention center. But 840 acres remain, only 60 of which are needed for the hospital. Besides the sportsplex, plans call for 500 or more homes, stores and light industry.
Brentwood's leaders support development because "commercial property is desperately needed for revenue," said the school board president, Anthony F. Felicio. But people in nearby Dix Hills complain that they will get no revenue and will bear the brunt of the traffic and noise.
Another disagreement emerged over the Long Island Developmental Center, which has 1.3 million square feet of buildings on 467 acres. Planners are calling for about 1,500 new homes, mostly for the elderly. Some local leaders want to include a village green and community center. But others fear that would attract too many families with children, burdening the schools, so they want a golf course instead. The plan offers both options, with no final decision.
Kings Park's great asset is scenery. The grounds cover about 600 acres of woods on the Nissequogue River, two marinas and vistas of Long Island Sound.
"Here's the million-dollar view," said the hospital's chief executive, Alan M. Weinstock, as he stood on a bluff overlooking the river and Sound. "Everybody comes here and drools and says we've got to do something with it, but no one has figured what."
Because Kings Park is far from the Long Island Expressway and Suffolk's commercial core, planners say it is best suited for residential use. They have proposed 1,319 units, from single-family homes on two-acre lots to apartments, plus a shopping center and village center.
Kings Park's plans seem the most tentative, which some experts welcome.
"This is one of the few places where the government owns the views and access to the water, so let's keep it," said Smithtown's planning director, Frank De Rubeis. "I think the decision on what to do will linger, or fester, depending on your point of view, for some time."

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Refuse Case on Whether Health Care Networks Must Be Open to All Doctors

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Bypassing a growing legal dispute over the organization of managed care health plans, the Supreme Court today refused to hear a case on whether states can insist that health care networks open their doors to any doctor who wants to practice with the group.
The debate over these laws, now on the books in about half the states, pits doctors, who want access to the networks, against insurance companies and sponsors of employee benefit plans, which save money on health care by negotiating for medical coverage at what is essentially a volume discount. 
 These plans, often called preferred provider organizations, meet their cost-saving goals only if each doctor can maintain the high patient load needed to make the reduced per-patient fees economically attractive. The ability to limit the number of doctors in the group in turn gives leverage to insurance companies and plan sponsors, because a doctor who does not cooperate in holding costs down can face expulsion from the network.
The case before the Court was an appeal by the State of Louisiana, which enacted a law in 1984 to authorize groups of doctors and employers to contract with one another for medical services. The law contained a guarantee that "no licensed provider who agrees to the terms and conditions of the preferred provider contract shall be denied the right to become a preferred provider." Guarantees of this type are known as "any willing provider" laws.
Earlier this year, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, overturned the Louisiana provision on the ground that it was pre-empted by the Federal law that governs employee benefit plans, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.
This law, E.R.I.S.A., essentially displaces state laws or regulations that "relate to any employee benefit plan." The appeals court, ruling in a lawsuit brought by Cigna Health Plan and its subsidiary, the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company, held that the Louisiana law did "relate to" employee benefit plans because it limited the structure of the provider networks that a plan might choose for its members.
Although Cigna and the insurance company won their lawsuit, they agreed with the state that the Supreme Court should resolve the issue. The National Association of Manufacturers, which also supported the appeals court's decision, also urged the Justices to hear the case.
There have been conflicting decisions on the issue from other Federal and state courts, and it is likely that the Court will step in eventually. Earlier this year, the Connecticut Supreme Court held that Connecticut's somewhat different version of an "any willing provider" law did not relate to employee benefit plans and so was not pre-empted.
While all sides in the Louisiana case today were in agreement that the Court should hear the appeal, Louisiana v. Cigna, No. 96-316, they differed sharply in their characterization of the issues. The state, describing the law as an effort to "keep the system fair for patients and health care providers alike," said the appeals court decision "seriously impedes patient choice and a provider's right to earn a living."
By contrast, Cigna and Connecticut General said that "limiting the size of the provider network is key to its success" and warned that employers would drop this method of health care delivery if they lost the ability to control the size.
The purpose of E.R.I.S.A.'s broad pre-emption provision is fairly straightforward: to make sure that employers do not have to navigate a sea of conflicting state regulations. But the provision is also as vague as it is broad, necessitating a constant flow of Supreme Court decisions to apply in various contexts.
Just last week, for example, the Court agreed to hear a case on whether E.R.I.S.A. pre-empts the operation of state community property laws that give spouses an automatic share in each other's pension plans.
This new case, Boggs v. Boggs, No. 96-79, involves the application of Louisiana's community property law to a pension annuity that a retired worker's second wife received after the worker's death. The man's first wife, who had died years before he did, had left most of her estate to their three sons.
The sons are now claiming in a lawsuit in Louisiana State court that they are entitled to the pension because it was part of their late mother's community property that belonged in her estate. The Fifth Circuit rejected the second wife's argument, in a Federal court counter-suit, that E.R.I.S.A. pre-empts any conflicting community property laws and that she was therefore entitled to continue receiving the pension. The Justices will hear her appeal.
There were these other developments at the Court today.

School Prayer
Also without comment, the Court turned down an appeal by the State of Mississippi from a ruling by the Fifth Circuit blocking enforcement of a law to permit students to lead voluntary prayers at various public school events.
The Mississippi Legislature passed the School Prayer Statute in 1994 in response to a public uproar after a high school principal had been disciplined for permitting students to lead prayers over the public address system. The law permits "non-proselytizing, student-initiated voluntary prayer" at assemblies, sports events, graduations, and other official functions.
The law has not taken effect because the Federal District Court in Jackson granted an injunction soon after its passage. Under the terms of that 1994 ruling, which the Fifth Circuit upheld, the only permissible student-led prayers are those at graduation ceremonies. The Supreme Court has ruled that graduation prayers led by members of the clergy are unconstitutional, but has not ruled on student-led prayer.
In its appeal, Moore v. Ingebretson, No. 96-331, Mississippi did not address the constitutional merits of the case but argued that the lower courts should not have intervened before the law had a chance to go into effect.

Term Limits
As the result of a stay granted by the Court over the weekend, the ballot in Arkansas on Tuesday will include a voter initiative to instruct members of the state's Congressional delegation to "use all of the powers" of their office to approve a constitutional amendment limiting senators to two terms and representatives to three. The Arkansas measure also provides that, if it passes, members of the delegation who ignore it will have next to their names on future ballots the phrase: "Disregarded voter instruction on term limits."
Last month, the Arkansas Supreme Court declared the measure unconstitutional as an evasion of the requirements for amending the Constitution as specified in Article V of that document: passage by two-thirds of each house of Congress and ratification by three-quarters of the state legislatures, or in a convention called by two-thirds of the state legislatures. The state court said the Arkansas proposal "clearly" violated the requirement that constitutional amendments "must come either from Congress or state legislature -- not from the people."
The stay of that decision -- permitting the measure to appear on the ballot -- will remain in effect until the Justices can decide some weeks from now whether to hear a full appeal in the case, Arkansas Term Limits v. Arkansas, No. A-310. Justices John Paul Stevens and Ruth Bader Ginsburg dissented from the decision to issue the stay.

HEADLINE: Some Owners Consider Altering the Labor Deal

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
As baseball's club owners approach a critical meeting tomorrow, a move was afoot yesterday to maneuver the responsibility of killing the pending labor agreement from the owners to the players.
The owners will meet in Chicago ostensibly to vote on ratification of the agreement that was negotiated mostly in August, then concluded Oct. 24. However, some owners talked of the possibility of making a change in the agreement -- most likely removing the players' option for a sixth year -- and sending it back to the union for its approval. 
 The owners would expect the union to reject an altered agreement, but then it would appear that the players and not the owners were undermining labor peace. One person on the owners' side branded the idea "a cheap publicity stunt."
Donald Fehr, the union chief, was in London for a speech, but a person on the players' side said of the possible switch, "That would be a thinly veiled attempt to shift responsibility but a clear rejection of what was negotiated by the negotiators." Another person said, referring to Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, "Bud can't get this monkey off his back no matter what he does."
An owner familiar with Selig's thinking said he plans to have a discussion on the pending agreement, then take a yes-or-no vote on it. Selig has said he will not state his position on the agreement, preferring to let the owners vote without his possible influence. Yet it has become the prevailing view on both sides that without Selig's endorsement, the deal would be rejected.
"No" votes by eight clubs would block ratification. The two Chicago teams, Florida, Kansas City, Montreal and Boston have been counted among the opposition. Yesterday, a person keeping a loose tally said the Cleveland Indians also were leaning toward the "no" column.
If the deal dies, so will the plan for revolutionary revenue sharing among the clubs. According to figures that have been revised upward, that means four teams would lose $5 million or more in revenue-sharing money for 1996 -- Montreal, $5.5 million; Detroit, $5.1 million, and Kansas City and Pittsburgh, $5 million each.
Montreal and Kansas City are two of the teams prepared to reject the new agreement despite the loss they face. Without saying how the Expos would vote, Claude Brochu, their managing partner, explained the club's position on the potential loss of $5.5 million.
"For once in our lives," he said by telephone from Montreal, "we've all got to think about the business, not so much in a short-term and on a selfish basis but long term. We have to address the economic condition of our business. That's first and foremost."
Based on previous comments by Brochu, the Expos apparently believe that the only way to address baseball's economics is with a salary cap, an idea the players rejected two and a half years ago. The heart of the pending five-year agreement is a luxury tax, where teams would be taxed for the portions of payrolls over a designated threshold ($51 million for 1997).
The tax would be in effect for the next three years, then disappear in 2000. No tax would exist either for 2001, which would become a sixth year in the agreement at the players' option. Many owners object to any tax-free years but especially oppose the idea of a second tax-free year.
If the owners alter the pending agreement, one person on their side said, they most likely would eliminate the option year. At this stage, the union would be expected to reject that change.
"This deal was negotiated as a package," said a person on the players' side. "Tremendous concessions were made to get where we are. Three tax years for two no-tax years was a compromise."
If the agreement falls apart, such elements as revenue sharing and interleague play will fall with it despite the belief by some owners that they could still get both. For revenue sharing and interleague play to take effect, the union would have to approve them, and union officials have said they will not approve anything on an isolated basis.
While Montreal and Kansas City oppose the agreement despite the revenue-sharing money they would receive, four of the five clubs that would pay out the most are prepared to vote for the deal.
They are the Yankees, who would pay $5.7 million for 1996, Baltimore ($5.2 million), Atlanta ($3.7 million) and Los Angeles ($3.6 million). Only the Indians ($5.6 million) are leaning toward opposing the agreement.

HEADLINE: In Saudis' Heartland, Unrest Is Aimed at Rulers and U.S.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: BURAIDA, Saudi Arabia

 BODY:
Far from the palaces of the capital and the Red Sea coast, this is Saudi Arabia's religious heartland, where beards are worn untrimmed and resentment toward those in power is not easily disguised.
It was in Buraida two years ago that Saudi dissent last spilled into the streets, when several thousand people joined a radical cleric in a 36-hour protest. In the clampdown that followed, the authorities arrested the cleric and hundreds of dissidents and have banned political discussion from the country's mosques. 
 But along a main street of shabby shops and Toyota pickup trucks, there were some still willing to divulge to a Western visitor their unhappiness with the monarchy that has ruled Saudi Arabia since it was forged 64 years ago.
"The people are angry, but for now, there's not much we can do," a shopkeeper in his 30's said. "We talk to each other, and we talk to God."
Rocked by two terrorist bombings in year, and facing a potent blend of flat oil revenues, a population boom and a religious militancy that increasingly questions the legitimacy of its rulers, Saudi Arabia is facing evident challenges at home.
They may be most clearly on display here, in this city at the historic heart of the Nejd region where Abdel Aziz al-Saud led a religious brotherhood drawn from local tribes in the conquests that gave him thrall over all of Arabia.
"These guys are under pressure in ways they've never been under pressure before," an American Government official said of the Saudi royal family.
In recent conversations around the country, the vast majority of Saudis assured a visitor of their strong support for the monarchy, while senior Saudi officials insisted that there was no reason for alarm.
"One thing to keep in mind in thinking about dissent in the kingdom is how minor is, and how abhorrent it is to the majority of Saudis, particularly when violent methods are used," said Prince Turki bin Faisal, who heads the country's Department of General Intelligence.
But within the Clinton Administration, American officials say, a gloomier view has been expressed in recent months by the Central Intelligence Agency, with analysts beginning to question how long the monarchy can survive.
An Administration official said several high-level meetings had been held recently in Washington to assess how the United States would be affected if a less friendly regime came to power in Saudi Arabia.
It is virtually impossible to accurately gauge the depth of discontent in a society like Saudi Arabia's, where dissent cannot openly be voiced and people guard their privacy fiercely.
But in Buraida, a hotbed of religious militancy, and even in the poorer neighborhoods of Riyadh, 200 miles to the southeast, what proved notable was the extent to which a number of residents echoed strains of the case against the monarchy advanced by dissidents abroad and militants in this country, many of whom are now in jail.
A significant number spoke also of Saudi Arabia's economic situation and the narrower horizons they now see for themselves and for a country that once seemed blessed with almost limitless wealth.
Saudi Arabia still sits on one-fourth of the world's known oil reserves, and it currently produces eight million barrels of oil a day, more than twice the daily yield of any other country.
But it has had to make amends for years of unrestrained spending, cutting back on the generous subsidies that helped to buy the good will of its citizens and making clear that many of those now entering the job market will have to accept sub-par positions once delegated to foreigners.
Opponents of the Saudi Government, who say the royal family has betrayed its role as custodian of Islam's holiest sites, have also accused its members of having squandered the country's wealth through wastefulness and greed.
And in Buraida, a city of 200,000 where women are seen in public only when shrouded all in black and where the religious police enforce the five-times-daily call to prayer, it was apparent that the attack had found resonance.
"You remember that bomb in Al Khobar?" one young merchant said over tea in the back room of his shop, referring to the car-bomb blast in June that killed 19 American airmen at a base in Dhahran. "I did not like it, but only for one reason: it hit only the Americans, when the target should have been the Government itself."
 
The Religion
Dynasty's Founder Took Title of Imam
Like the father and three brothers who preceded him to the throne, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia relies on the approval of his country's religious leadership, which in turn acts as protector of the Wahabi Muslim principles on which the kingdom was founded.
From the beginning of his rule, King Abdel Aziz -- the founder of the royal family -- assumed the title of imam, or law giver, and his sons have been bestowed that role by the religious leadership, known as the ulema.
But a minority among the followers of King Abdel Aziz never accepted him as their imam, and they rose against their leader in the Ikhwan rebellion of the late 1920's, which ended only when the King put them down by force.
In weathering conservative challenges since then, the Saudi Government has similarly had to face down religious extremists who do not regard its rule as legitimate.
Many people in Saudi Arabia describe the latest challenge, which began to surface in 1992, after the Persian Gulf war, as amounting to another rebellion, but one reinforced by signs that the Government has lost support from elements of the religious establishment, including militant preachers like Sheik Salman al-Awdah, who preached regularly at the Buraida mosque.
Along with Sheik Safar al-Hawali and others, Sheik Awdah applied the unyielding Wahabi tenets, based on a literal reading of the Koran, to describe the conduct of royal family as secular and corrupt. These clerics accused the Sauds of betraying the laws of Islam, in part by permitting infidel Western troops a presence on the Arabian Peninsula, the site of Islam's two holiest sites.
While the clerics never advocated violence, the Wahabi outlook allows little room for rival ways of thought, even among fellow Sunni Muslims. Saudi experts on radical Islamic movements say these attacks -- recorded on cassette tapes that circulated throughout the kingdom -- have helped to fuel deep antipathy to the Saudi Government.
"To the extremists, to declare the Government as illegitimate makes it an infidel government," said Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist. "And the moment they declare a government an infidel government, they believe they have the right to fight against it."
Warned to quiet his attacks, Sheik Awdah instead gathered thousands of followers in the rally here that ended with his arrest and those of Sheik Hawali and at least 400 others around the country. But while both clerics remain in prison, interviews found that support for them remains powerful in Buraida, whose residents proudly describe it as the most conservative place in Saudi Arabia.
Apart from the march two years ago, residents say, the town has demonstrated no outright signs of dissent. But cassettes of Sheik Awdah's sermons still circulate clandestinely, and videotape shot during the demonstration has formed lasting impressions on the minds of American officials whose responsibilities include this country.
Describing scenes that included "at least hundreds of young men running about," one Western diplomat said, "It was all very dramatic, because this is Saudi Arabia, and this never happens."
 
The Economy
Decline in Income Magnifies Discontent
In the last 15 years, per capita annual income in Saudi Arabia has plunged by about two-thirds, to about $6,700, mostly because of a population boom. That has magnified discontent and given new ammunition to those who accuse the royal family of failing to manage the country's resources wisely.
"The people need to eat," a Saudi in his 20's said in an interview in a poorer quarter of Riyadh, whose residents include Saudis and low-paid foreign workers from Pakistan and India. "And as life has become more difficult, we have begun to believe that someone must bear the blame."
For many in Saudi Arabia, the United States is an easy target. Despite evidence to the contrary, most Saudis remain convinced that the American Government profited from the gulf war at the expense of the Saudi treasury.
And religious conservatives, who contend that the presence of some 5,000 United States servicemen here contravenes the Wahabi interpretation of Islamic law, have condemned what they describe as an unwholesome American influence on the country and its rulers.
Both criticisms have attracted new adherents in the last year, a time when Washington's perceived pro-Israeli bias in Middle East peace talks has angered public opinion across the Arab world.
And in the aftermath of the bombings, both have been fanned by Saudi dissidents abroad, including Osama bin Laden, the billionaire exile who in September called on his followers to begin a "holy war" against the United States and its military presence.
"The Americans don't understand that they are not wanted," Khalid bin Abdelrahman al-Fawaz, a close associate of Mr. bin Laden, said in an interview in London. "They only understand the language of violence. It happened in Lebanon: they ran away only after there was major bloodshed. The same thing happened in Somalia. So the Saudi people thought: why don't we give them bloodshed?"
Except in extraordinary circumstances, Muslims are forbidden under Islamic law to kill fellow Muslims, so even Islamic extremists find it far easier to countenance attacks against so-called infidels.
Most American and Saudi experts nevertheless see the bomb attacks of the last year as evidence of opposition to the Saudi Government, whose decision to allow American forces to base themselves in the kingdom to repel Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 found little support within the Saudi population.
But even the most outspoken among the Saudi dissidents in London acknowledge that they have neither the ability nor the intention to challenge the Government with force. And in interviews in Washington and Riyadh, American experts and Western diplomats said they did not believe that the Government faced a near-term threat.
"I don't see any signs that the Al Saud are in any imminent danger whatsoever," a Western diplomat in Riyadh said. "The question is: over the next 5 to 10 years, will they make the changes they need to keep themselves in power, or will they make fatal choices that will undermine their rule?"
 
The Outlook
Rulers More Wary Over Ties With U.S.
If the nightmare scenario for the West is the collapse of the Saudi Government in an Iranian-style revolution, the consensus among Western analysts is that such an outcome remains extraordinarily unlikely. There is no evidence, the analysts say, of any mass inclination to confront the Government by taking to the steets.
But under King Fahd, who suffered a stroke late last year, the Saudi monarchy appears to be treading carefully around public sentiment, perhaps most notably by its refusal this fall to allow the United States to mount its latest round of attacks against Iraq from Saudi bases.
The Saudis have also seemed determined to keep American investigators at arm's length from their investigation of the Dhahran bombing, a stand based either on sovereignty concerns or wariness about allowing outsiders to take stock of their internal difficulties.
A sense of unease also has been apparent in the attention given by Saudi newspapers recently to religious seminars whose consistent theme has been that loyalty to the imam, to the King, is a Muslim virtue. The country's second-ranking religious figure, Sheik Mohammed bin Otheimin, ruled that to criticize the King from within the chamber of the mosque would be to commit an act of heresy.
After bombings that Clinton Administration officials said underscored how much about Saudi Arabia the West still did not know, a puzzle that remains in a society that does not allow dissent is how to weigh the complaints that do surface.
On that subject, a Saudi man who politely turned a visitor away from his office in Buraida stopped first to offer a piece of advice.
"The official point of view," he said, "is that the Americans are our friends -- friends to the gulf in general, and friends to the kingdom. That is the policy of the Government, and if people are asked a question here, that is the way they are expected to answer."

HEADLINE: A Telecom Marriage Made Somewhat Shy of Heaven

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
It was hard to tell from the lofty price tag, the jet-setting management structure or the elegant corporate moniker, but the deal that created Concert was not the first choice of British Telecommunications P.L.C.
BT, as the British company is known, agreed to consider an acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation only after it failed in its effort buy another British international phone company, Cable and Wireless P.L.C. Though MCI pushed for the deal, it, too, had considered several other potential partners, including the GTE Corporation and at least some of the seven regional Bell companies. 
 These considerations were largely lost in the hoopla of Sunday's announcement that MCI and BT had agreed to merge their operations to create Concert, the world's first trans-Atlantic telephone carrier. But now, as shareholders and regulators place the $23 billion deal under a microscope, questions about its strategic rationale will come to the fore.
"MCI wasn't the first bride they considered," said David Roddy, chief telecommunications economist at the accounting and consulting firm Deloitte & Touche. "This is a consolation prize for British Telecom."
BT negotiated to acquire Cable and Wireless over five months earlier this year after management turmoil left that company open to a new owner. But the talks collapsed in May, largely over disagreements on price.
Mr. Roddy and other experts said Cable and Wireless would have been a more attractive partner for British Telecom than MCI is because it would have enabled BT to fill out its geographic footprint in Asia. The major asset of Cable and Wireless is Hong Kong Telecom, a publicly listed company of which BT owns 58 percent. By contrast, the MCI merger solidifies BT's foothold only in North America -- something that analysts say had already been secured by its 20 percent equity stake in MCI.
Analysts said that Asia -- with a population of about 2.3 billion, explosive economic growth and one phone line for every 96 people -- represents a larger and less tapped opportunity than the American market, which is both mature and beset by regulatory uncertainty.
Executives at British Telecom, however, rejected the notion that acquiring MCI was Plan B after missing out on Cable and Wireless.
"We had a very successful alliance with MCI, but it was only addressing a portion of the market," said John Butler, director of regulatory affairs for BT. "Our discussions with Cable and Wireless were really sort of independent of what we were doing with MCI."
The architects of the deal -- Bert C. Roberts Jr. of MCI and Sir Iain Vallance of BT -- betrayed no second thoughts yesterday as they promoted the deal in television interviews. They plan to meet today with Reed E. Hundt, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, whose support will be critical in order for the deal to clear regulatory hurdles.
Analysts said that concerns about how long it might take to close the deal dampened the performance of MCI's shares, which rose just 50 cents, to $30.75, yesterday in Nasdaq trading, after a gain of $5.125 on Friday, when word of the impending deal became known. BT's shares showed surprising resilience in the London market yesterday, rising 22 pence, to 3.73, or roughly $6.10. The increase in BT's stock price added about $1 billion to the value of the deal.
Though Mr. Roberts, who is the chairman of MCI, said the merger would give his company more artillery to battle for local phone customers and expand its ability to serve global business customers, the combination with BT is an about-face of sorts for MCI, too.
In May 1995, MCI agreed to invest $2 billion in Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation -- on the assumption that it could bridge the worlds of telecommunications and entertainment. MCI also poured $600 million into American Sky Broadcasting, a satellite television service that was to be MCI's vehicle to enter the consumer video market.
Some MCI shareholders viewed the investment as little more than a subsidy of Mr. Murdoch's global ambitions, however, and the BT deal amounted to a repudiation of the strategy. MCI said it would limit its investment in the News Corporation at the current $1.3 billion. It wants to reduce its equity stake in A Sky B to less than 20 percent. And Mr. Murdoch, a director of MCI, will not join the board of Concert.
"People could never understand that deal," said Eric Strumingher, an analyst who follows MCI at the Chicago Corporation, "If this gives MCI a way to back out of it gracefully, that's a good thing."
In a conference call with analysts on Sunday, the otherwise ebullient Mr. Roberts was circumspect about the reasons for the shift.
"We're already going down a path with News Corporation," he said. "We intend to restructure that investment." Executives at the News Corporation declined to comment yesterday.
If MCI is being tight-lipped, however, executives at BT were eager to explain why a merger with MCI was preferable to a deal with Cable and Wireless -- even with a price tag of $23 billion.
Although Hong Kong Telecom has a commanding position in the huge Hong Kong market, Mr. Butler noted that it was vulnerable to political instability, particularly with the coming of Chinese rule of the British colony next July.
Moreover, British Telecom already has a web of smaller alliances with carriers in India, Japan and South Korea. With its expanded size, he said, Concert would be in a stronger position to make strategic deals with Asian telephone companies than either BT or MCI alone would be.
Nippon Telegraph and Telephoneseems destined to be the major target of Concert's affections.
"N.T.T. must rank as an excellent prospective partner," Mr. Butler said of the giant Japanese company. And other BT executives noted that their company's chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, who will also be the chief executive of Concert, came to BT from a British computer manufacturer, ICL, which happens to be owned by Fujitsu of Japan.
Whether Sir Peter can persuade N.T.T. to become a player in Concert remains, of course, to be seen. And Mr. Butler acknowledged that Cable and Wireless would have given British Telecom an immediate and powerful beachhead in Asia.
Yet he added, "At the end of our discussion, we had too many uncertainties as to the prospects for that company."
For Mr. Roberts and BT's chairman, Sir Iain, the challenge now is to prove that their mammoth merger is less risky than the road not taken.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE FUND-RAISERS;
Indonesian Magnate and Clinton Talked Policy, White House Says

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
James T. Riady, an Indonesian billionaire with a financial stake in American policy toward Asia, discussed trade policy with President Clinton and perhaps senior aides in some of the more than a dozen visits he made to the White House, Administration officials acknowledged today.
After weeks of declining to provide details of the visits by Mr. Riady, the central figure in the current campaign finance uproar, the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said that a preliminary internal review showed that Mr. Riady had been a guest at the Executive Mansion at least 15 to 20 times over the last four years. 
 Mr. McCurry said the purpose of the visits was to pay social calls, lobby the Clinton Administration to appoint more Asian-Americans and occasionally discuss policy issues with the President and his advisers. But Mr. McCurry and other Administration officials said they were unable to describe with any level of precision how often Mr. Riady was there, with whom he met, what policies he was advocating and what briefings he received during his visits. The Wall Street Journal today reported that there were at least 14 visits and quoted Mr. McCurry that they were for "outreach to the Asian-American communities."
Mr. McCurry said the review had determined that Mr. Riady had discussed Asian trade policy generally with the President, may have met with Robert E. Rubin, then the head of the National Economic Council, for an unspecified policy meeting and may have had conversations with other advisers as well.
"We have established that he saw a variety of people and that some related to concerns he had on policy matters," Mr. McCurry said in a telephone interview during a campaign stop in Cleveland. "There would be nothing inappropriate about this."
In the closing weeks of the Presidential race, Republicans and Ross Perot have suggested that big campaign donations by people with ties to the Riadys, who control a $12 billion empire of real estate, banking and other holdings, allowed the clan to influence unduly American policy toward Asia, where most of the family's holdings are. When Mr. Riady worked in the late 1970's at an Arkansas bank partly owned by his family, he became friendly with Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Riady and other family members control the Lippo Group, which has its headquarters in Jakarta, and whose holdings include Lippo Bank, a small bank based in California. In the 1990's, the family's senior executive in the United States was John Huang, who left for a trade post at the Commerce Department that the Riadys have said they helped secure in exchange for their political support of Mr. Clinton. Mr. Huang left Government earlier this year to become a senior fund-raiser for the Democrats. He was suspended last month after reports that he had solicited questionable contributions.
Clinton campaign aides have denied the accusations of undue influence, saying Bob Dole's financial patrons received the same kind of access in Republican circles as Mr. Clinton's did at the White House.
But the latest disclosure suggested that Mr. Riady was a more frequent guest than had previously been known. It was also the first official acknowledgment that Mr. Riady was doing more than simply paying social calls on his visits to the Executive Mansion. White House aides had previously disclosed that Mr. Riady met with Mr. Clinton three times at the White House and played down the significance, describing the visits as "brief" and "informal."
Mr. McCurry said the review had not uncovered precisely what policies Mr. Riady had pressed for in his visits, although associates of the Riadys have said that they were interested in American concerns about human rights in East Timor and worker rights more generally in Indonesia. The Riadys have also been interested in the Administration's decision to approve most favored nation status for China, particularly since the family is developing a $1 billion power plant in southern China with the Little Rock unit of the Entergy Corporation.
"From time to time, Riady would talk to the President in a philosophical way about why the United States should be more interested in Asian trade," Mr. McCurry said today.
But Mr. McCurry added that White House records indicated that Mr. Riady had also been interested in discussing particular issues with White House aides, although the subjects remained unknown. On April 19, 1993, for instance, Mr. Riady requested a meeting with the President. He had a brief meeting with Mr. Clinton and a mutual friend from Little Rock, Mark Grobmyer.
That same day, Mr. Riady was referred to Thomas F. McLarty, then the White House chief of staff, who directed Mr. Riady to meet with Mr. Rubin, who was then the head of the National Economic Council and is now the Treasury Secretary.
Howard Schloss, Mr. Rubin's spokesman at the Treasury Department, said that Mr. Rubin had no recollection of seeing Mr. Riady and that he did not know whether a meeting had occurred.
The meetings occurred in six trips Mr. Riady made to Washington. But the White House records do not present a complete picture of discussions between the President and Mr. Riady. Associates of Mr. Riady have said in interviews that he said he had discussed American trade policy toward China and Indonesia with the President, including a discussion earlier this summer in the President's limousine. That visit would not show up on White House logs.
Mr. McCurry said White House aides were continuing to tabulate Mr. Riady's visits and that the approximation of visits was necessary because Mr. Riady, a citizen of Indonesia, used his family's Chinese name on some occasions when he was cleared at the White House.
Mr. McCurry said some of Mr. Riady's visits were with Mark Middleton, a former White House assistant to Mr. McLarty, who knew Mr. Riady from when they both worked in Little Rock. In recent days, Mr. Middleton has denied accusations that he had been involved in efforts to solicit money for the Democrats from a senior official in Taiwan Nationalist Party this year.
Nearly a dozen committees of the Republican-controlled Congress have begun inquiries into the Riady family, Lippo and contributions to the Democrats.
But in recent days, Lippo has had a difficult time finding a lawyer in Washington. Several prominent lawyers have turned the company down because of potential conflicts of interest. The company recently approached Brendan V. Sullivan Jr., the Williams & Connolly partner who became a nationally known figure when he represented Oliver North in the Iran-Contra scandal. Mr. Sullivan reportedly wanted to do the legal work for Lippo but was vetoed by his partners because David Kendall, another Williams & Connolly partner, represents President Clinton.
Other lawyers have said they have had to turn down Lippo because they have White House clients who could become involved in the multiple investigations that have begun in recent weeks at the Justice Department and in Congress.
