HEADLINE: When Shoppers Walk Away From Pedestrian Malls;
Downtown Retailing Trend Again Favors a Car Culture

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

DATELINE: KALAMAZOO, Mich.

 BODY:
Sandwiched between Chicago and Detroit, this city of 80,000 people always had one little retail thrill to distinguish itself from its bigger neighbors. It was home to the country's first pedestrian mall, a charming European-style enclave of trees and water fountains built in 1959, lined with shops and restaurants that awaited the strollers who popped in from around the state.
Now, Kalamazoo wants to rip up two of the four blocks of its mall, replace them with streets, and bring back cars, a proposal made by the City Council and a business association that city residents will vote on today. 
 The issue is not an isolated one: in fact, from Sacramento, Calif., to Westhampton Beach, L.I., towns across the country are evaluating what to do with their pedestrian malls. More often than not, they are opting to get rid of them.
Such malls may soon be a relic, a quaint urban planning blip of the late 1960's and early 1970's, when most of the country's pedestrian malls -- streets closed to automotive traffic where pedestrians can walk and shop freely -- were created.
"We were the first ones to have it, and we should have been the first ones to tear it down," said Nancy Arcadipone, the director of business and housing development for Downtown Kalamazoo Inc., a nonprofit business association promoting the initiative.
Kalamazoo hopes to lure back merchants who have abandoned the downtown strip because, they complain, weekends, evenings and snowy afternoons -- of which there are no shortage in western Michigan -- leave the pedestrian mall deserted.
Like dozens of other cities, Kalamazoo also hopes to take advantage of a small but significant shift as shoppers, tired of the endless sameness in the country's enclosed suburban malls, are looking to shop outside them, even back on Main Street.
"The most successful downtowns throughout America today are those that are moving back to what they were in the beginning," said Doyle Hyett, the chairman of Hyett Palma, an urban renewal consulting firm in Alexandria, Va., that studied Kalamazoo and many other cities with pedestrian malls.
"They are moving back to much more of a neighborhood feel, as original city centers," he said. " 'Pedestrianization' as we define it today is not to close off cars; it is to make it easy to move through." The firm did consulting work for Kalamazoo about the mall, and favored the idea of opening it to motorists.
Of the roughly 200 pedestrian malls that once dotted the country, at least half are in some form of transformation, Mr. Hyett said.
Some cities, like Eugene, Ore., have ripped up pieces of their pedestrian malls. Others, like Milwaukee, have taken the whole strip down. Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Raleigh, N.C., are just two of the many other cities considering similar moves.
Retail experts note that pedestrian malls never took into consideration the preferences of most shoppers, who arrive downtown in their cars and want to park near their shopping area, or have easy drop-off access to stores; pedestrian malls do not offer either. Trees and birds are perfectly nice, but no one really goes shopping to see them.
Pedestrian malls, built to invigorate aging downtowns, started to founder as the shopping world became peppered with regional enclosed malls during the 1970's. Shoppers quickly abandoned the idea of strolling about trees and man-made rivers to get their shopping done, and weekend and evening foot traffic quickly dried up. In some cases, the downtown malls became menacing crime zones at night because they were so isolated.
The only places that pedestrian malls tend to be a hit, retail consultants say, are at the centers of large college towns like Boulder, Colo., where there are fewer drivers than normal, or in tourist areas that lend themselves to strolling, as in Miami Beach and in Santa Monica, Calif.
By contrast, cities like Kalamazoo are hard pressed to get retailers into their malls' storefronts -- even at the $8 a square foot charged by the Kalamazoo Downtown Mall.
"In the downtown area, 19 new businesses have come in the last 18 months and the same number have left," said Kimberly Williamson, president of Downtown Kalamazoo Inc. "We have heard what merchants downtown want, which is access, visibility and convenience. The mall in its current configuration does not address these needs."
Towns that have embraced the bulldozer often seem to have an almost instant turnaround. "I think it has been probably the most important thing that has happened downtown," said Russ Brink, the executive director of Downtown Eugene Inc., which was part of the coalition that has pushed to tear down that town's H-shaped pedestrian mall. One leg was opened to traffic four years ago, and another leg is in the process of doing so now.
"The idea that you could close off the center of the city from vehicular traffic and still have a viable commercial area never clicked," Mr. Brink said. "Plus, people stopped coming downtown because of perceptions of safety. After we took part of the mall out, there was a pretty remarkable transformation.
"There is night life, new restaurants, a nice area that sprang up after the reopening," he said. "In 1992, the retail vacancy rate was 30 percent for the whole pedestrian mall, and in March it was down to 7 percent."
Questions about what to do with downtown landscapes have become more urgent as retailers inch out of the giant enclosed malls and into new locales -- stand-alone shops along busy freeways, sprawling super-centers in the middle of nowhere and, even, back to downtown.
"Big box" retailers like Home Depot, Baby Superstores and CompUSA got the ball rolling by introducing their giant stores in strip malls. Many other retail companies -- including the Limited, Nordstrom and Saks Fifth Avenue -- are setting up shop outside enclosed malls.
But American shoppers have been spoiled by the one-stop convenience that enclosed malls offer, and car-free strips generally do not meet the demands of time-pressed shopping trips downtown. In this current wave of downtown revitalization, charm may be yielding to convenience.
"What you saw in the 70's were days of urban renewal which tended to look at plazas, above-ground malls and above-ground connections between malls," said Frank Fish, a principal at Buckhurst Fish & Jacquemart, an urban planning firm in New York.
"But those things were not designed well; they were not based on how people really interact," he said. "The shopping destination does have to provide traffic access and parking. The key is balance."
Still, residents tend to split over what to do with their pedestrian malls, for reasons that range from sentiment to fears over how to pay for renovations.
In Kalamazoo, most stores -- from Jacobson's, the largest downtown merchant, to the little local bookseller -- love the demolition plans. The local newspaper, which has made no secret of its support for the demolition, has rallied for the change.
Yet a handful of enraged merchants and hundreds of residents who want to save the mall gathered signatures to get the issue on the ballot. Some grow elegiac at the thought of bulldozing a piece of Kalamazoo's history.
"We're not against improving the mall, but I am against the cars on the mall," said Marvel Neal, the owner of Terrapin Worldwide Imports, a gift shop on the mall.
"It is the one place in Kalamazoo where you don't have to worry about traffic," he said. "People walk down here by the hundreds to sit on the lawn and eat their lunch. It's just great. Plus, now we will have to deal with car exhaust."
But other mall merchants argue that lunchtime business alone will not pay the bills. "I'll be disappointed if we don't have the vision to go forward with this," said Bruce Johnson, a co-owner of Gazelle Sports, an athletic goods shop.
Yet other residents are skeptical of both sides. "I would love to see the downtown revitalized, but I just don't think they are going to get the kind of business they think they're going to get just by taking up the mall," said Florence Nelson, a homemaker who has watched downtown retailing dry up over the years.
Indeed, retailers like Gap Inc. have said that -- more than its pedestrian strip -- it is Kalamazoo's small size and proximity to a suburban mall which work against the town's downtown.
Like most towns that have dug up pedestrian malls, Kalamazoo plans to pay for the changes with a mix of private and public funds. The cost of a total downtown revitalization should be between $7 million and $9 million, Ms. Williamson said; about a third is earmarked for the mall.
Yet urban planners and retail experts warn that even if retailers do flock to reconfigured strips, they alone can not save downtowns.
"If you are really going to compete with the suburban malls, you have to create an equal or greater draw," said Eugene A. Pinover, the head of the real estate group at Willkie Farr & Gallagher, a New York law firm. "Shoppers need to have the reason to leave their home. You need theaters, restaurants and things that are at least in part entertainment. You have to make a there there."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Recoups Losses; Canadian Money at New High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher yesterday, deriving strength from diminished anxiety about the outcome of the American election, as well as new signs of economic weakness in Japan and Germany.
Many currency traders had sold the dollar in advance of the voting yesterday, fearing that the Democrats might retake control of Congress. Some in the financial markets view Democrats as less fiscally responsible than Republicans and more inclined to let the budget deficit increase, which can be inflationary. 
 "I think that concern has abated somewhat," said Pierce Acheson, chief dealer of foreign exchange at the Chicago office of Nationsbank. "With that abating, we had some money movement back into dollars."
As the dollar rose, traders who had bet on a falling dollar were forced to buy to minimize their losses, further bolstering the currency in what is known as a short-covering rally.
At the same time, many remained cautious and were not bidding the dollar beyond recent trading ranges.
Late in New York yesterday afternoon, the dollar rose to 1.5192 marks from 1.5104 on Monday and to 114.15 yen from 113.75. The pound traded at $1.6446, down marginally from its 20-month high of $1.6449 on Monday.
The notable exception in the dollar's movement was its weakness against the Canadian dollar, which jumped to the highest levels in nearly two years from a strong rally in the Canadian bond market. Traders were receiving many orders for Canadian dollars needed to purchase securities in Canada. The dollar ended at 75.21 Canadian cents, compared with 74.85 cents on Monday.
The dollar first rose against the yen in Asian dealings after a major property developer, Sueno Kosan, and two affiliates sought bankruptcy because of debts estimated at nearly $5.3 billion. It was the latest sign of financial problems confronting Japanese banks and lending agencies.
"It shows the complete lack of recovery in Japan and the fact that low rates in Japan are there to stay," Mr. Acheson of Nationsbank contended. Low rates in Japan have helped depress the demand for yen-denominated assets.
The mark was hurt by a German Finance Ministry report that manufacturing orders dropped sharply in September, reviving talk of a possible further easing of interest rates in Germany.

HEADLINE: Experts Disagree on Adding Fatty Acid to Infant Formula

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY 

 BODY:
IN the last year and a half, the issue of adding a certain fatty acid to infant formula has become an international cause celebre.
The additive in question, a major component of fish oil called docosahexaenoic acid, or DHA, is present in breast milk and is important to the proper growth of an infant's brain. 
 Some argue it is unethical not to give formula-fed babies a supplement of this fatty acid, along with a companion, arachidonic acid, or AA, that is also present in breast milk but not in formula. And some infant formula producers in Europe and Asia have already begun to include these fatty acids in formula destined for premature babies, who miss the full benefit of their mothers' supply in the last weeks or months of fetal life.
In this country the Martek Biosciences Corporation of Columbia, Md., which has developed a way to grow marine microalgae in the laboratory and extract DHA from it, has used a public relations agency to convince the American public to support the addition of DHA to infant formula.
But other medical experts and American formula producers, citing the first law of medicine, "First, do no harm," are urging caution. They are awaiting the results of several dozen clinical studies now under way here and abroad that are expected to show whether this nutritional boost is necessary, safe and effective in enhancing an infant's neurological development. Thus far, the American Academy of Pediatrics Committee on Nutrition has taken no stand on the issue, calling it too complex and the data too limited to warrant a definitive statement.
Some facts are clear:
*DHA is essential to neurological development and one of the two most prominent fatty acids in the brain and retina.
*The peak period of brain development occurs during the last three months of fetal life and the first several months of infant life.
*Human breast milk contains DHA (the amount varying according to the mother's diet), but infant formulas sold in the United States do not.
*Humans can make DHA from another fatty acid, alpha linolenic acid, that is now in all infant formulas, but the conversion ability of newborns, especially preterm babies, may be unable to keep up with the demands of the nervous system.
*Blood levels of DHA fall after birth in babies who are bottle-fed, but less so if at all in breast-fed babies. And bottle-fed babies who die in infancy have less DHA in their brains than breast-fed babies.
*In this country breast-fed babies seem to be smarter than bottle-fed babies, as measured by average I.Q., which is is eight points higher at the age of 8.
The question is: Should DHA be added to infant formula? If so, should it be given only to premature babies or to all babies?
The body is perfectly capable of making its own DHA. In order for it to do so the diet must include two polyunsaturated fatty acids, linoleic and alpha linolenic acid, which are components of vegetable oils that are found in all infant formulas. From these so-called essential fatty acids, the body can manufacture the two long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids, AA and DHA, respectively.
Dr. William E. Connor, a nutrition researcher at Oregon Health Sciences University in Portland, said that the conversion occurred slowly both in infants and adults, but that through the years adults accumulated DHA and AA and stored it in their body fat. During pregnancy and lactation, the fatty acids are released from a woman's body fat to supply her fetus and infant.
What has been called into question is whether newborns who are bottle-fed, and particularly those infants born prematurely, can produce DHA and AA efficiently enough on their own to develop optimally.
"A driving force in the matter is whether there might be another required nutrient" that must be supplied in the diet to assure normal growth, Dr. J. Thomas Brenna, a Cornell University nutrition researcher, said in an interview. He and Dr. Peter Nathanielsz at Cornell's College of Veterinary Medicine are examining the extreme: whether pregnant vegan monkeys, which get no DHA or AA in their diets, can adequately supply their fetuses with these fatty acids.
Last week, a group of experts convened under the auspices of the Harvard School of Public Health and Ross Laboratories, a formula producer, discussed the reasons for not rushing headlong into supplementing infant formulas with DHA and AA, even though it might seem logical and, on the surface at least, vital to optimal infant development.
"We should assure that formulas are as good as possible, but we must never make formulas less safe," said Dr. Stanley Zlotkin, pediatric nutrition specialist at the Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto.
"Current formulas are very good and very safe and babies consuming them develop well," Dr. Zlotkin said. "From a nutritional point of view, it is very hard to tell the difference between babies who are breast-fed and those who are bottle-fed."
Dr. Alan Lucas, an expert in child nutrition at the British Medical Research Council in London who directed the I.Q. study of breast-fed and bottle-fed babies, said there were a great many differences between breast milk and infant formula beyond their fatty acid content. "If all the factors in breast milk were important," he said, "we should be seeing an epidemic of illnesses among bottle-fed babies. We shouldn't regard breast milk as the perfect guide for making formula."
It is also not yet clear what, if any, differences between breast milk and formula might influence intelligence. Dr. Robert B. McCall, a psychologist and child development specialist at the University of Pittsburgh, said: "While breast-fed babies are smarter, the question is why. Other factors in milk than DHA could also account for the higher intelligence of breast-fed babies."
Furthermore, he said, mothers who choose to breast-feed are likely to be different in some important ways from mothers who choose to feed their babies formula. These days, nursing mothers tend to be better educated and economically more secure. Even though studies account for factors like the mother's education and socioeconomic level and the status of the baby at birth, there is no way to control for the effects of the postnatal environment, which can strongly influence a child's performance on I.Q. tests and in school.
The only way to be certain that the kind of nutrition given is responsible for the developmental differences observed is to assign babies randomly to receive either regular formula or formula supplemented with DHA and AA, Dr. McCall said. Such studies are now under way both in preterm and full-term babies, who must be followed for several years to determine first if there is a developmental advantage to the supplemented formula and second if that difference persists beyond the first few years of life.
Researchers are examining such effects as the development of babies' visual systems and differences in their so-called attentional behavior (how long they look at novel and familiar images), which is predictive of later I.Q.
Dr. Robert T. Hall, chief of the division of human development at Children's Mercy Hospital in Kansas City, Mo., said that the largest North American study to date had found that in full-term babies, "there's nothing more than a transient difference in visual development at 2 to 4 months of age in babies fed supplemented formulas; after that, the differences disappear."
But Dr. McCall said two studies of premature babies showed that those receiving supplemented formula had better attentional behavior in the first year of life, but that he "wouldn't bet the farm" on whether this translated into higher intelligence.
There are also safety concerns. In studies of premature infants fed formula supplemented with fish oil, the babies' visual development was enhanced but their growth was impaired. They were shorter, weighed less and had smaller heads than comparable infants given standard formula, Dr. Lucas said.
"We now think that fish oil is inappropriate to use" as a source of DHA, since other ingredients in the oil could have had adverse effects on growth, Dr. Lucas said. He said it was currently not possible to add pure DHA to formula because "it comes mixed with other things."
While fish oil is the major dietary source of DHA, it originates in plants -- specifically the microscopic algae that grow in the ocean and that work their way up the food chain, becoming increasingly concentrated as they go.
Dr. Ronald Kleinman, a pediatric nutrition expert at Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School, noted, "The amount of DHA in breast milk can vary as much as twentyfold, depending on the mother's diet." The more fish she eats, the more DHA would appear in her milk. He said that while DHA was most important to the brain and visual system, it was also important to the development of the immune, gastrointestinal and reproductive systems.
Dr. Connor said his advice to women would be to "eat fish during pregnancy and lactation" to build up a supply of DHA and "to breast-feed their babies, if at all possible, for the first three or four months of life, the time of the most rapid incorporation of DHA into the brain." He noted that in the days before milk was fortified with vitamins A and D, babies were routinely given cod liver oil, a rich source of DHA. As for current infant formula, he said: "In my view, we should mirror human milk as much as possible because that is what nature intended infants to have. Once it is determined to be safe to add these fatty acids, we should do it."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
If you're looking for a New Year's Eve cruise
in 1999, now is the time to get in line.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
AS Times Square and other traditional New Year's Eve sites plan for the arrival of the year 2000, the travel industry is also busy preparing to ring out the old and ring in the new.
Carnival Cruise Lines, for example, will not publish its 1999 itineraries or prices for another 13 months, but is already accepting reservations -- for the waiting list. For cruises departing or under way on Dec. 31, 1999, potential passengers must submit a written request to Carnival with an initial deposit of $150 a person for three- or four-day cruises, $250 a person for seven days or longer. 
 Its brochures declaring "It only happens once every thousand years," Kvaerner's Cunard Lines is currently accepting reservations for its five millennium cruises. QE2 passengers will have an opportunity to sing Auld Lang Syne off the coast of Barbados while watching a fireworks display, while passengers on the Royal Viking Sun will celebrate in Acapulco harbor. The Vistafjord will be steaming toward Kenya that historic night, after having departed Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt. Sea Goddess I passengers will gather on the beach at Virgin Gorda Sound in the British Virgin Islands while Sea Goddess II will be in Paula Naira, a cluster of islands in Indonesia.
Reservations for all Cunard cruises require a $1,000 deposit.
 
Smoking Aloft
Air France passengers between Paris and the United States are forbidden to smoke in their seats, but the airline has added smokers' bars that are open throughout the flight except at mealtime. The two bars, one for economy class and one for business and first class, are enclosed by drapes and ventilated by special smoke-extracting fans.
 
The Occupancy Factor
Almost two months ago PKF Consulting, the international hotel consulting firm with headquarters in San Francisco, predicted the re-election of President Clinton in yesterday's election -- based on an analysis of the performance of the United States lodging industry since 1929.
The firm predicted that the average occupancy for United States hotels in 1996 will be 1 percent greater than last year. "When the average occupancy rate for U.S. hotels has increased during a presidential election year," said Robert Maandelbaum, the director of research, "there is a 70 percent chance that the Democratic candidate will win."
 
Corporate Travel Powwow
The 1,600-room New Orleans Hilton Riverside was host recently to 125 corporate meeting planners and travel managers at a four-day business summit meeting, complete with 11 working sessions. The Hilton Hotels Corporation property, which has 127,000 square feet of meeting space (and eight indoor tennis courts atop the parking garage) already is host to some 400 meetings and conventions a year, and corporate travelers account for some 45 percent of the hotel's business.
Mike Taylor, the hotel's director of marketing, said that as corporate meetings had been increasing along with an improving economy, such summit meetings were valuable for exchanging ideas about catering, audio-visual equipment, and what amenities business travelers look for in their rooms. He added that fitness rooms, which some hotel officials still regard as white elephants, were getting much more use from business travelers than ever before.
 
Spend and Fly
Pan Pacific Hotels' Mauna Lani Bay, the resort on the Kohala Coast of Hawaii, will close from May 9 through Aug. 1 next year for a $10 million renovation. Meanwhile, there is still time to earn a million frequent-flier miles on American, Delta, United or T.W.A. The catch? Just stay 30 consecutive days and nights in any of the resort's five bungalows, at a mere $4,500 a night. If that is a bit steep, Don Dickhens, the resort's general manager, recently noted that 100,000 mileage points required a minimum stay of only five consecutive days and nights at the $4,500-a- night rate.
 
Caution on Gifts
Think twice before giving foreign customers or associates a holiday gift. Dean Foster, director of the Berlitz Cross-Cultural division, warns never to give a gift of leather in India, for your recipient could be Hindu, and most leather comes from cows, sacred incarnations of life in the Hindu religion. Muslim friends or associates would appreciate a fine silver compass, he said, which would allow them to locate Mecca for their daily prayers no mater where in the world they are. Clocks are not good gifts for Chinese associates, since the Mandarin word for clock is similar to the word for death. And a fine bottle of brandy or Scotch is appreciated by Japanese, who are the world's largest consumer of both products, A box of citrus fruits, which are very expensive in Japan, is also highly prized.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Post Sharp Increases

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Weak economic data and a strong dollar, combined with expectations in the stock and bond markets that the post-election political landscape will not change, sent bond prices sharply higher yesterday.
The benchmark 30-year bond surged 31/32 , to a price of 1026/32 to yield 6.58 percent, down from 6.66 percent on Monday and the lowest since March 26, when it was 6.57 percent. A bond's yield moves in the opposite direction of its price. 
 Investors yesterday saw yet another sign of slowing economic growth, as September home completions fell 5.8 percent, to 1.358 million units, from a a revised 1.442 million units in August.
The downturn in completions further removed concerns that the Fed might raise interest rates at its coming Federal Open Market Committee meeting on next Wednesday, or at the final meeting for this year on Dec. 17. The first meeting for 1997 will be Feb. 4.
Foreign demand for Treasury securities caused by the rising dollar also pushed prices higher. Weak retail sales reports also contributed to the rally.
Analysts said the bullish tone in trading yesterday also eased fears about the market's ability to absorb the large amount of Treasury paper coming to market this week.
The market reacted to early exit polls that showed President Clinton leading the Republican challenger, Bob Dole, but the Democrats failing to make headway in their effort to regain control of one or both houses of Congress. The market had feared that if Democrats were successful, there would be less incentive to cut the budget deficit.
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the optimistic view on the election this week, was for a Democratic President with a Republican Congress. "Expectations among Wall Street traders and investors are that we will continue having the two parties work toward a solution in reducing the budget deficit, pretty much the way they have for the past few years," Mr. Regan said.
Mr. Regan said that yesterday's three-year note auction, the first part of the Government's quarterly refunding, was a "fair auction" and came in as advertised. He noted that noncompetitive bidding was a little less than expected, with the bid-to-cover ratio, or the number of bids compared with size of the total auction, a little on the light side. The bid to cover at yesterday's auction was 2.28 to 1, compared with an average of 2.49 to 1 over the last four auctions.
The yield came in at 5.889 percent, in line with expectations.
Mr. Regan said the retail sales reports helped alleviate inflation fears.
"The weekly retail reports released yesterday were a little lighter than they had been in the prior week," he said. Today the Treasury will auction 10-year notes, but with the yield in the 10-year and 30-year maturities lower than they have been since last March, Mr. Regan said, "it may prove to be more formidable to auction the 10-year, considering that we still don't know the full effects of the election at the present time."
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said that while a resurgence of foreign demand helped propel the market along to lower yields, "the Street fought it the whole way, believing that it is dangerous to press the market higher during a refunding auction."
In when-issued trading ahead of today's and tomorrow's auctions, the 10-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.27 percent, down 7 basis points from the previous day, while the 30-year bond was offered at a price to yield 6.54 percent, down 8 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-year notes:

HEADLINE: Auto Makers Fell Shy of Expectations

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Vehicle sales were below expectations last month, rising only slightly from the lackluster period a year before. Sales of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans were strong but the results were dragged down by car sales.
Overall sales rose 2.2 percent in October, a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 14.9 million light vehicles. The mediocre sales results could be a factor in the decision next week on interest rates by the Federal Reserve, Wall Street analysts said. 
 Separately, the General Motors Corporation said that a tentative agreement had been reached at its highly profitable plant in Janesville, Wis., ending a strike by 4,800 members of the United Automobile Workers local there. A ratification vote was scheduled for Wednesday at the plant, which builds G.M.'s popular Suburban sport utility vehicle. A settlement would end G.M.'s latest round of labor problems.
The Ford Motor Company said today that its sales rose 2.7 percent. Sales of its sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks rose 8.3 percent, while car sales fell 3.9 percent. Ford is the last big auto maker to release its monthly sales figures.
Some Wall Street analysts yawned. "The month was decent," Joseph S. Phillippi of Lehman Brothers said, adding that "it probably was below a lot of people's expectations," but that most of the declines were explained by one-time events.
Still, he said, the figures suggested that the economy was not overheating.
October's auto sales "show the Fed that there is no need to tinker with interest rates," Mr. Phillippi added.
Shares of Ford rose 12.5 cents today to close at $31.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. G.M. shares closed unchanged at $55.625, while Chrysler eased by 25 cents, to $33.125.
Sales figures for the Ford Windstar, Ford Taurus and Mercury Grand Marquis were especially strong, but those for the Ford Ranger, Ford Aerostar and Mercury Sable were weak. October was the first full sales month for Ford's new large sport utility vehicle, the Expedition. It sold just over 13,000 of them, and said it would have sold more if it could have built them faster.
"Expedition is the right product in the right market at the right time," said Bob Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing and sales. "The only question appears to be 'how high is up?' and we won't know the answer until our dealers have greater availability."
Auto dealers echoed that sentiment. Lee Weinman, a Ford dealer on the north side of Chicago, said, "Our only problem with Expedition is we can't get enough -- we are selling every one we can get."
Sales at his dealership were especially brisk last month -- up 20 percent over those in October 1995. He said he expected sales for the rest of the year to stay fairly strong.
"Selling cars is not a mystery," Mr. Weinman said. "When people are working and interest rates are decent, they buy cars."
Pete Greiner, a Ford dealer in Casper, Wyo., said his sales were up, too, and predicted "a good finish for 1996." Mr. Greiner added that "the hottest product we have is the F-series truck," with the Explorer and Expedition sport utility vehicles a close second and third.
Many auto makers had already reported record October results. Chrysler on Friday said its sales rose 18.6 percent. Honda sales were up 8.8 percent; Toyota, up 15.7 percent, and BMW, increasing 24.8 percent. All percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate because there were 27 selling days last month and 26 in October 1995.
Some others fared poorly. G.M. said Friday that its sales dropped 7.9 percent, with car sales falling 24 percent, while pickup trucks, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles rose 22.2 percent.
Wall Street analysts said the October sales figures only partly reflected G.M.'s recent labor troubles: the full effect of a three-week strike in Canada and of local strikes at two important factories in the United States, they indicated, was likely to be felt in November and December.

HEADLINE: Carl H. Pforzheimer Jr., 89, Leading Investment Banker

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Carl Howard Pforzheimer Jr., a leading New York investment banker, book collector and benefactor of medicine, education and the arts, died on Monday at his home in Stuart, Fla. He was 89 and a former resident of Purchase, N.Y., and Manhattan.
At his death, he was the senior partner in Carl H. Pforzheimer & Company, which was founded by his father in 1901 because, the son once recalled, his father was "manic about the horseless carriage" and had begun to invest in oil. The investment firm continued to concentrate on oil and gas after his death in 1957. 
 Mr. Pforzheimer Jr. also took over the work of the family's Carl and Lily Pforzheimer Foundation, which was endowed by his parents in 1942. Among its recent beneficiaries were Mount Sinai Medical Center, Radcliffe College, Bank Street College of Education, Lincoln Center Institute, Wellesley College and Harvard University.
Mr. Pforzheimer was also a Mount Sinai trustee for more than half a century. Through the foundation, he supported innovative programs at the School of Medicine, scholarships for medical students, nursing scholarships and other programs in clinical care, medical education and scientific research.
At his father's death, he became the patriarch of a family of bibliophiles and steward of a treasure trove Mr. Pforzheimer Sr. had amassed in his huge library in Purchase. It included a Gutenberg Bible, acquired in 1923, and a wealth of early English literature.
As the library's focus shifted toward 19th-century English romantics, Mr. Pforzheimer sold the Gutenberg in 1978 to the University of Texas for a record $2.6 million.
Eight years later, H. Ross Perot acted as middleman in the sale of some 1,100 books and 250 manuscripts, dating from 1475 to 1700, from the Pforzheimer collection. Mr. Perot advanced funds to the University of Texas for that sale, which at $15 million was considered the largest sale of rare books ever. It helped finance the new scholarly interest in 19th-century works within the Pforzheimer collection.
Then in 1987, Mr. Pforzheimer and his son, Carl 3d, presented their collection to the New York Public Library. The legacy of three generations, it contains 8,000 original manuscripts and 13,000 printed volumes, including numerous journals, poems, essays, letters and sundry memorabilia of Shelley, Keats and Byron.
Mr. Pforzheimer, who was born and raised on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, graduated in 1928 from Harvard College and two years later from Harvard Business School..
He was a colonel on the United States Army General Staff in World War II and later took on a number of civic assignments. He was a member of the New York State Board of Regents from 1958 to 1978, and was vice chairman for the last three of those years. He was a past president or officer of the National Civic League, the National Association of State Boards of Education, the New York Public Library and the Economic Development Corporation of New York City.
Mr. Pforzheimer is survived by his wife of 65 years, Carol Koehler Pforzheimer; his son, a resident of Scarsdale and managing partner of Pforzheimer & Company; a daughter, Nancy P. Aranson of Manhattan; seven grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Borough Development Units Are Turned Down by Pataki

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill yesterday that would have shifted some of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's authority over economic development in New York City to the five borough presidents.
The bill, which both houses of the Legislature passed by overwhelming margins, would have set up a state-sponsored Industrial Development Agency in each borough. The borough agencies would have had the power to grant millions of dollars in tax incentives and other inducements to companies to persuade them to create or retain jobs. 
 Supporters of the legislation had contended that City Hall often focuses its economic development efforts on Manhattan, neglecting to nurture companies in the other boroughs. They said job-creation agencies run by the borough presidents would better serve the other boroughs.
Mr. Giuliani had fought the bill, arguing that it would lead to competition among the boroughs that would cost the city money. He had also said the borough president should not be allowed to grant incentives like tax cuts because the presidents do not have responsibility for the impact of those reductions on the city budget -- the Mayor and the City Council do.
There is already a citywide Industrial Development Agency, which would have continued to operate if Mr. Pataki had signed the legislation, so the city would have had six such agencies.
Since 1974, the citywide agency has assisted local companies in more than 750 projects through the issuing of $5 billion in bonds, officials said. That has helped retain 140,000 jobs, they said.
Under the bill, the Mayor would have had veto power over deals made by the borough development agencies, but only after a final agreement had been reached. Giuliani administration officials had said that it might be difficult for the Mayor to reject agreements after they had been negotiated because that might anger the companies involved.
Mr. Pataki vetoed a related bill last year that would have established a separate Industrial Development Agency only in the Bronx. He said in a statement accompanying the veto yesterday that the legislation passed this year would have undermined the Mayor's control over job creation.
"This bill, if approved, would inevitably trigger competition among the boroughs for certain economic development projects," the Governor said, "and thus place the Mayor, through his approval or veto power, in the untenable position of having to choose among the boroughs."
"A bidding war for projects could escalate the size of the tax exemption packages to the detriment of the city's and the state's budgets."
Charles Millard, a top Giuliani aide who is president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, praised the Governor.
"We are very grateful," Mr. Millard said. "It was a stupid bill, but it had a lot of political support. It would have Balkanized economic development in New York City. Economic development in one city has to have a citywide strategy."
Assemblyman Roberto Ramirez, a Bronx Democrat who sponsored the bill, attacked the veto, saying that the Governor now had an obligation to present alternative legislation for reviving the economies of areas like the Bronx. Mr. Ramirez said he would introduce the bill again when the Legislature returned in January.
"It is unfortunate that the Governor obviously made a political decision and ignored the merits of what was a meritorious idea for bringing capital into poor communities," he said. "I have a very strong suspicion that the Republican Mayor and the Republican Governor are not interested in the communities that I represent, and that is a shame."

HEADLINE: Brewery's Exit Leaves a Bitter Taste

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The breweries that made Milwaukee fa mous Schlitz, Pabst and Miller -- were a source of good jobs and civic pride for generations and became as much a part of this city's image and soul as the winds howling off Lake Michigan.
In the glory days, Detroit made cars; Milwaukee made beer. Beer money sent the worker's children to college and their parents across the sea to visit the old country. Women met their husbands in the massive plants, and the family toasted their good fortune and sometimes their bad luck with a six-pack or two of the company brew. Fathers and sons and daughters worked side by side and then went to the ball park on summer nights to cheer the hometown team, the Milwaukee Brewers. 
 But those days are almost completely dead. Schlitz closed in 1982 and now Pabst, the granddaddy of the city's once mighty breweries and one of the oldest businesses in Wisconsin, is shutting down its Milwaukee operations by the end of the year, leaving 250 people without jobs.
Miller is now the last survivor of the major Milwaukee beer makers, the last direct survivor of a way of life that began here in the 1840's when German immigrants first began brewing a sweet taste of home.
Today, the taste of Pabst Blue Ribbon beer is as bitter as betrayal.
"They just didn't kill a bunch of jobs for brewery workers," said Wayne Watkins, who has worked at Pabst for 28 of his 51 years. "They killed a family."
The announced shutdown of Pabst after 152 years has set off a firestorm of protest by unions, politicians and Pabst drinkers far beyond the economic impact the death of the plant will have on Milwaukee.
Beer has not been a major fuel of the local economy for a long time. In the 1960's there were thousands of brewery workers in the union. Today there are only about a thousand. Still, beer making has continued to be a powerful symbol of the city's blue-collar roots and its identity as Brew Town U.S.A. or, as the more worldly sometimes called Milwaukee, the American Munich.
The Pabst Brewing Company, saying that the plant here had not turned a profit in several years, announced the closing last month. The beer will be produced instead at the Stroh Brewery Company's plant in La Crosse, Wis.
Gary Lewitzke, a spokesman for Pabst, said shutting down the plant was a difficult decision because of the workers and because of what the brewery has meant to Milwaukee.
"It was very, very tough," he said. "But a company can't print money. Survival is paramount."
Pabst left open the possibility that the plant could be reopened when the contract with Stroh's expires in 1998.
"The brewery isn't necessarily closed for good," Mr. Lewitzke said. "We'll take another look at the situation when the contract expires."
Jim Robinson, an official with Local 9 of the Brewery Workers Union, said, "I believe that like I believe I own the Brooklyn Bridge."
The union has filed an unfair labor practices complaint with the National Labor Relations Board, charging that Pabst failed to negotiate in good faith before deciding to lay off workers and move out of town. A hearing is scheduled for Nov. 12.
The union is trying to block Pabst from cutting off medical benefits to about 700 retired union members, but has lost an early round in court.
"I've looked at insurance and everybody wants $800 a month," said Frank Peritz, 58, who, after 32 years at Pabst, retired last May largely because he was diagnosed with colon cancer. "I just can't afford that. That's half my pension."
Now there is talk of a national boycott of Pabst products. Taverns across the city and suburbs have stopped selling Pabst and many have held Pabst dumping parties, an idea that would have been nearly sacrilegious a few years ago.
Anthony Zielinski, a Milwaukee County Supervisor, introduced a resolution seeking to ban the sale of Pabst in buildings owned and operated by the county.
For workers like David Lipske, who put in 34 years at Pabst, and Tom O'Brien, who has been with the company for 29 years, the shutdown is a personal tragedy. "I don't have any skills," said Mr. O'Brien, 51. "I'm just a brewery worker. That's what I did all my life."
For the city itself, the closing of Pabst "is the end of an era," said Maggie Jacobus of the Greater Milwaukee Convention and Visitors Bureau. Even though microbreweries are popping up all over the city and there are still plenty of beer drinkers, Ms. Jacobus said, "beer is a great piece of our heritage and Pabst has been such a landmark, and now an outsider is taking it away."
In 1985 a California company, the S & P Company, bought Pabst and, according to John Gurda, a local historian and author of several books on Milwaukee, did little to promote the beer in the highly competitive market.
"There's a sadness that a business that had been so central to Milwaukee is dead for all practical purposes," Mr. Gurda said. "It's certainly unwelcome but not unexpected news. Everyone knew the patient was very sick and the doctor was incompetent."
Mr. Lewitzke, the Pabst spokesman, said the company had continued to advertise, but could not compete with the advertising budget of the Miller Brewing Company, which is owned by Philip Morris.
Mr. Watkins, the Pabst worker, joined a group of fellow workers at the union hall the other day. Like so many beer workers in Milwaukee, Mr. Watkins's father worked for a brewery, and so did his uncle. His uncle was in his mid-40's when his brewery, Schlitz, shut down. His personal finances deteriorated; his marriage failed.
"He never recovered," Mr. Watkins said. "Some people don't come back from it. I bet before this is all over there'll be a suicide, divorces, houses lost."
Mr. Watkins said he could become a casualty himself. For the last year, anticipating the end of Pabst, he has been looking for a new job. He said he had 16 job interviews and 16 rejections. Now he is uncertain how he will make his mortgage payments on a house he built five years ago.
Still, the hardest day of his job, he said, fighting back tears, "was when I walked into a tavern and for the first time in my life not ordering a product with a PBR label on it."
For 30 years a Pabst sign has hung outside Danny Lynch's bar in West Allis, a Milwaukee suburb. In a few days that sign is coming down, said Joe Lynch, who, along with his brother, Jim, runs the bar for their father. Until then, the brothers have taped a red slash through the heart of the word "Pabst."
"It's very hostile around here with Pabst right now," Joe Lynch said as he served the lunchtime crowd pizza and Miller. "Everybody seems real united against Pabst. Now, it's just a matter of finding out what they want to drink."
In the old days, most people who came in drank Pabst. But recently, Mr. Lynch went around to his customers to find out what kind of beer they wanted instead. Some said Coors or Bud and one man asked for Corona Lite. Mr. Lynch did not mean to laugh in the man's face, but he could not help it. "Buddy," he said, "this is still Milwaukee."

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE NATION -- THE DECISIONS;
For Ohio Republicans, Shifting Allegiance Was Hard; for Some, Too Hard

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE: The Day for Decisions

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 5

 BODY:
When it was all said and done, Sally Efremoff, 57, a family court magistrate and longtime suburban school board member, walked into her polling place, Trinity United Church of Christ in Plain Township, and cast her first vote ever for the Democrat for President.
"I considered not voting for President," she said. "I kept going back and forth, I talked about it more than I ever have in my life -- I even was discussing it with my dentist. But in the end there were issues that were too important." She was upset with Bob Dole's positions against abortion and for school vouchers. 
 On the other hand, her friend Nancy McPeek, an assistant vice president at Bank One and a lifelong Republican, who agrees with Ms. Efremoff on abortion and vouchers, sat on the fence for months and then walked into her polling place at Holy Cross Lutheran Church in Plain and voted for Mr. Dole today. "I could listen to Dole and not hear these things I disagreed with, so it was easier," she said. "Clinton, I just didn't trust."
The two friends were the story of the election here tonight. In the end, many Republicans like Mrs. McPeek, who were undecided for months, returned to their party's Presidential candidate, but not enough to offset the swing vote for President Clinton. With over half the precincts counted, Mr. Clinton led in Stark with 46 percent to 38 for Dole, and 14 percent for Ross Perot.
People seemed to have lost the anger of 1994. Every single incumbent in the local races, from clerk to appeals court judge, won. Only the tax levy to keep the public bus system running lost.
Representative Ralph Regula, a Republican, could see it coming this morning, as he fed the horses and cattle on his farm. "I personally think Clinton will win, but not by as much as the polls have been showing," said Mr. Regula, who was easily re-elected to his 13th term.
Nancy Levengood seemed to be leaning toward Mr. Clinton in August as she presided over the best pie contest at the county fair. But today, she just could not bring herself to do it and returned to the Republicans. "I'm just worried about all these things that could happen if Clinton were elected again," she said.
Lucy Smith, a secretary and Republican voter, was greatly affected when she lost her job in a bank buyout last year and for months the anger she felt was pushing her toward voting for Mr. Clinton. But more recently, she found a higher-paying job as a school secretary, and on Monday night at 10, she decided she would vote for Mr. Dole this morning at 7:30. "I have the feeling that voting for Clinton would be giving a stamp of approval for the kind of person he is," she said.
It was in swing sections of the county, like Perry and Plain Townships, that it was easiest to find people who voted Republican for President in 1992 switching to Mr. Clinton. Casting his vote among Porsches and Grand Cherokees at Plain precinct 29 -- the rear showroom of Kempthorn Motors -- Maxion Leeper, an assistant manager for a Speedy Foods convenience store, went for the Democrat for President for the first time in his memory.
And at the Grange Hall and First Christian Church polling places in Perry, a blue-collar, Reagan Democrat area, Larry Smith, the local school board president, as well as Sandra Eash, Jack Kraus and his wife, Rusty, all voted for Mr. Clinton today though they supported the Republican Presidents in the 1980's. "I didn't like that Dole is against Medicare and education," Mrs. Eash said. "I have a young child and have to worry about the future a little bit."
"Dole's too old," Mr. Kraus said. "We don't need a President who will fall asleep at meetings."
And Mr. Smith, who voted Bush in 1992, did not like Mr. Dole's repeated criticism of teachers' unions.
Shortly after the polls opened at 6:30 A.M., W. R. Timken Jr., the fourth-generation Timken to run the steel and bearing company here, arrived at the tiny village hall in the upper-class suburb of Hills and Dales.
"Good morning, Mr. Timken," said Rose Graybell, a poll worker.
Afterward, a reporter asked how he voted. "All R's, all R's as usual," he said, adding that he expected Mr. Dole to win. His company has been experiencing record profits the last two years and Democrats here have cited it as a symbol of a robust economy under President Clinton.
"Bill Clinton and the Government are not running my company," Mr. Timken said, "The associates of the Timken Company are the ones responsible for its success. The idea that Presidents have that kind of influence over the economy is pure baloney." After voting, he headed downtown. "We have a lot of work to do down at the company," he said.
As he arrived, Ron Stokes, president of the 4,200-member steelworkers union local at Timken, one of the nation's largest, and two other officers, were at the Harrison Avenue gate for shift change, handing out campaign literature endorsing President Clinton. While many of the rank and file interviewed supported Mr. Clinton -- Charles Becker ("I'm a Democrat"), Sam Ward ("the economy's going good"), John Guilliouma ("he's for the working man") and Tim Shirey ("he stands for the same thing I do,"); there were a significant number of Dole supporters, too, including, Jerry Olson ("I like his whole story"), Louis Vinson ("taxes are killing us") and Roger Fout ("I'm anti-abortion.")
In 1992, Jim Repace, president of the 2,000-member electrical workers' local at the Hoover Company voted for Ross Perot, but switched to Mr. Clinton this time, and was handing out A.F.L.-C.I.O. literature at the factory gates.
Still, it was clear that Mr. Perot also cut into the President's margin here, which had been 23 points, according to a poll by The New York Times and the Ohio State University survey center taken two weeks before the election.
Jeannie Strittmatter, a floral designer who had voted for Mr. Perot in 1992, had planned to vote Mr. Clinton today, but switched back to Mr. Perot when she realized that he would do better than originally expected here.
During the last week, Bob Craven, head of the small Christian Coalition chapter here, distributed 40,000 voters' guides with his wife and a half-dozen members. His first stop on Thursday was a testament to the Coalition's organizational skill.
Mr. Craven lives a two-minute drive from the Firestone Road Baptist Church, but had no idea its members were interested in his group until he received a printout from the Coalition headquarters in Virginia. The Firestone pastor had sent a request to Virginia, which in turn reported the information to Mr. Craven and sent extra voters guides.
As Mr. Craven walked into the church, he handed a secretary a packet of guides and said: "This is a nice church. I didn't even know you were here."
The Rev. Joel Cochran, of the Chapel in Marlboro, a fast-growing evangelical church, got his guides from Mr. Craven on Thursday and left them out for interested members on Sunday. Mr. Cochran voted for Mr. Dole, and said there had not been much talk of the election around church. He estimates two-thirds of his 900 members voted Dole.
Jennifer Hubbell, a Republican and mother of three who was impressed with the Chapel and considered joining, but decided not to because it was too fundamentalist for her, voted for Mr. Clinton today, in part because she agrees with his position on abortion.
Michael Hanke, editor of The Repository, which last week endorsed a Democrat for President for only the second time in 181 years, voted at the Free Methodist Church in Jackson, but would not say for whom.
This afternoon, in downtown Canton, Lynn Hamilton, a vice president for Key Trust Company and a lifelong Republican, studied the stock market for hints of how the election might turn. In 1980, Jimmy Carter had led in the polls, but on Election Day, when Mr. Hamilton checked, he noticed defense stocks were way up. "That told me investors believed Reagan would win," he said.
Today the Dow was up 39 points, and Mr. Hamilton felt investors were confident the status quo would continue, the Republicans would keep control of Congress and though Mr. Clinton might win, it would not be a sizable enough victory to give him a mandate. "I also noticed that tobacco stocks were up, and took that as an indication that investors didn't feel too threatened by Clinton," he said. "It's reassuring."
 
An American Place
Living midway between Democratic Cleveland and Republican Columbus, the citizens of Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County have a history of voting for the winning Presidential candidate. This is the 36th article in a yearlong series that seeks to explore the forces shaping the political debate at the grass roots. (Previous articles are available to computer users on The New York Times on the Web, at http://www.nytimes.com/specials/canton.)

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Has 7-Hour Heart Surgery And Doctors Say It Was a Success

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 6

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin came out of a seven-hour, multiple-bypass heart operation in a hospital here on Tuesday with his doctors declaring the operation a success. They said they were optimistic about the 65-year-old Russian leader's chances of resuming a full workload.
At a news conference in the hospital an hour after the operation, the doctors said the surgery went without a hitch. Mr. Yeltsin's heart was stopped for 68 minutes during one phase of the operation. 
 Mr. Yeltsin signed a decree this morning reassuming his presidential powers, the Kremlin said. Sergei Yastrzhembsky, his press spokesman, said the President signed the document at 6 A.M. (10 P.M. Tuesday, Eastern time), 23 hours after he had delegated the powers to Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin on Tuesday morning, minutes before undergoing anesthesia..
In the operation, surgeons sewed five grafts to restore blood flow to coronary arteries. They had become constricted by the fatty deposits of atherosclerosis that had built up over a period of years and deprived the organ of vital nourishment, leading to two heart attacks.
Even if all goes well for Mr. Yeltsin, it may yet be months before he can run the country again. And when he does return to the Kremlin, many find it hard to imagine that he will be the same forceful leader who has for five years driven Russia away from Communism and toward a market economy. [News analysis, page A12.]
On Tuesday, Mr. Yeltsin was reported in stable condition in an intensive care unit, where he remained connected to an artificial respirator used during the operation. He opened his eyes early Tuesday evening but had not fully awakened from the anesthesia. Patients usually awaken from 6 to 18 hours after such surgery.
Mr. Yastrzhembsky said today that the President felt better than his doctors had expected. "He surprises doctors with his good state," the press secretary said. "He feels quite well for this stage."
 Mr. Yeltsin still faces certain potential risks like bleeding, infection and kidney failure as he enters a critical phase the next several days. Other possible complications after such surgery include neurological damage, like a stroke, or memory loss that may not become apparent until later.
But Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, the American heart surgery pioneer who consulted in Mr. Yeltsin's case and observed the operation, called it "a complete success."
"President Yeltsin will be able to return to his office and carry out his duties in normal fashion," said Dr. DeBakey, 88, of the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston.
Dr. Renat S. Akchurin, 50, the surgeon who headed the team, said Mr. Yeltsin's heart muscle was now getting enough blood to function normally. The doctor's face and voice reflected exhaustion from performing the operation.
With the advent of managed care in the United States, many patients now leave the hospital four or five days after undergoing bypass operations. But hospital stays in Russia are generally much longer. And experience suggests that a few months will pass before Mr. Yeltsin feels fully recovered from the surgery.
Nevertheless, the favorable comments from the surgeons are likely to ease tension about Mr. Yeltsin's health just as Dr. DeBakey's comments did at a news conference here six weeks ago after he examined Mr. Yeltsin. At that time, Dr. DeBakey said that Mr. Yeltsin had a condition known as a "stunned myocardium" and that it would take 6 to 10 weeks for Mr. Yeltsin's heart to improve function and for several other medical problems to clear up before he could undergo the bypass operation with minimum risk.
Ever since Mr. Yeltsin announced on Sept. 5 that he needed heart surgery, the Kremlin had been combating rumors that he could never serve out his term, which ends in 2000. That created an enormous power struggle in the Kremlin.
A number of doctors not connected with Mr. Yeltsin's case criticized Dr. DeBakey for delaying the surgery. But Dr. DeBakey said their criticisms were unfounded. Mr. Yeltsin's aides contributed to the problem by saying he had liver and kidney failure. But tests showed that he did not have those conditions, Dr. DeBakey said in September.
Dr. DeBakey said in an interview on Tuesday that "everything went beautifully." The apparent success of Mr. Yeltsin's operation "vindicated my position a little over a month ago when there was doom and gloom all over the place," Dr. DeBakey said.
As further evidence, Dr. DeBakey said that a measure of heart function known as the ejection fraction rose to 40 percent just before the surgery from 20 percent in September. The ejection fraction is the amount of blood the heart expels with each beat -- usually about 65 percent of the blood in the heart's main chamber.
A dietary regimen imposed in September lowered Mr. Yeltsin's cholesterol level from 350 then to 187 on Monday, Dr. DeBakey said. A cholesterol level less than 200 is considered desirable. Controlling cholesterol now may prevent recurrences in the grafts that were placed on Tuesday. And the true test of the success of a bypass operation is how many years the grafts stay open.
There was heavy security at the Cardiology Research Center, where the operation was done. The center is named for Dr. Yevgeny I. Chazov, who pioneered in the modern clot dissolving techniques used to stop heart attacks in progress. Such therapy was used to stop a heart attack in Mr. Yeltsin last summer.
Dr. Akchurin carried out the operation like a standard bypass, except for the security and visiting experts, including two German surgeons who were observing, Dr. Axel Haverich and Dr. Thorsten Wahlers, both of Hanover Medical School.
Also at the hospital were Mr. Yeltsin's wife, Naina, and daughter Tatyana Dyachenko, Mr. Chernomyrdin and Anatoly B. Chubais, the Kremlin chief of staff.
After slicing the skin over Mr. Yeltsin's upper chest, Dr. Akchurin's team split his breastbone, or sternum, with a saw. Then they used a metal retractor to lift the rib cage while Dr. Akchurin removed an internal mammary artery from Mr. Yeltsin's chest. Meanwhile, other surgeons removed a vein known as the saphenous from his leg.
As they continued, the surgeons fashioned the arteries and veins to construct five grafts to revamp the blood supply to Mr. Yeltsin's heart completely, Dr. DeBakey said.
Dr. DeBakey said the surgeons sewed an internal mammary artery to the left anterior descending artery on Mr. Yeltsin's heart. They also made four grafts from the leg vein. Two were used to bypass blockages in the obtuse artery, the third for the right coronary artery and the fourth for the diagonal artery.
Until the circulation was repaired, the left side arteries on Mr. Yeltsin's heart were nourishing that side and much of the right side.
Stopping a heart for 68 minutes during a bypass operation is "not unusually long" for such a procedure, Dr. DeBakey said. Blood is pumped through a heart-lung machine during that period.
Dr. O. Wayne Isom, chief of heart surgery at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in New York City, who is not connected to Mr. Yeltsin's case, agreed. It usually takes surgeons from 7 to 15 minutes to sew each graft and the variation depends on anatomical factors, Dr. Isom said in a telephone interview from New York on Tuesday.
Dr. Akchurin's technique differs from that of most American surgeons, who wear jeweler type loupes while performing bypass operations. Before Dr. Akchurin became a heart surgeon he repaired severed digits and limbs by using microsurgical techniques and by looking through an operating microscope suspended from overhead. Dr. Akchurin has continued using such a microscope in sewing grafts in heart vessels.
During the operation, Dr. Akchurin said he "tried to forget that this is the President and imagine this is a normal ordinary patient that we are operating on."
When Dr. Akchurin's team had finished sewing the grafts and was ready to get Mr. Yeltsin's heart to beat again, it "came back right away," Dr. DeBakey said.
"That's always a very good sign that heart function is good, and I think he is going to really get a good result and be able to go back to his normal duties," Dr. DeBakey said in the interview.
In addition to his recent intestinal bleeding, Mr. Yeltsin bled from a stomach ulcer several years ago, Dr. DeBakey said.
Because of the past problems of bleeding, Dr. Akchurin's team asked Dr. DeBakey to bring experts in hematology and transfusion medicine from Houston to consult in Mr. Yeltsin's case.
So before Dr. Akchurin sewed up Mr. Yeltsin's breastbone and skin, he took extra time to observe the areas where he had placed stitches to make sure there was no bleeding from them. There was none.
"The risk of bleeding now is very remote," Dr. DeBakey said. "The odds are in Mr. Yeltsin's favor now."
