HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- LOOKING AHEAD;
The Second Term: Promise and Peril

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

 BODY:
Four years ago Bill Clinton won the Presidency with an outsized agenda and an underwhelming mandate, and the gulf between the two left him struggling in the first half of his term simply to establish his legitimacy. By the midpoint, the President had been reduced to proclaiming his own relevance.
Last night Mr. Clinton won re-election with a larger margin but with a manifesto both smaller and less clear. And if the promise of achievement glistens, potential pitfalls abound, from the ancient feuds of Bosnia to the paper chase of special prosecutors at home. 
 Campaigning in El Paso last week, Mr. Clinton declared, "This is an election of enormous moment, with great consequences." But for more than a year the President has steadily strived to blur the traditional divisions of American ideology in a politics of pointillism, at once capturing the electorate's vital center and renewing questions about his own.
In this President's effusive view, it is possible to both balance the budget and provide new tax breaks for college education, to force families off welfare and find new jobs for them, to expand the Federal role in everything from encouraging school uniforms to deterring violence on television -- all the while declaring that "the era of big government is over."
Surveys of voters leaving the polls yesterday showed that 6 in 10 did not believe he could cut the deficit and pay for his programs at the same time, and that a like number did not believe that their President was either honest or trustworthy. He and his wife, Hillary, face a raft of pending or continuing investigations into their financial and ethical conduct and their party's fund-raising practices. Still, nearly half those surveyed said they were either optimistic or excited about a second term.
"This is not about liberal or conservative," Mr. Clinton told a rally in Little Rock, Ark. last weekend, in one of the most pointed formulations of an argument he made in the last weeks of the campaign, citing Republican and Democratic predecessors alike as his heroes. "We have run by far the most fiscally conservative Government, and we've done more to stand against crime, and we've stuck up for this country in having a strong foreign policy. I think the record will stand on its own.
"This is about whether you're going to be diverted and divided," Mr. Clinton continued, "or whether we're going to find common ground and build that bridge to the 21st century together."
To that end, one of the closest Presidential advisers says, he expects Mr. Clinton to demand the resignations of all his Cabinet secretaries and accept some of them, to name a prominent Republican to at least one major Cabinet post, to put a premium on bipartisanship in dealing with a narrowly divided Congress and to expand his peacemaking efforts in hot spots from Ireland to the Middle East.
"I don't buy this notion at all that it's a small agenda," said George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's senior adviser. "If you balance the budget and make welfare work and put 100,000 cops on the street and cut the deficit in half, I defy anyone to say that's minimalist."
Still, the President sounds a less certain trumpet for a second term than he did for the first. In 1992, Mr. Clinton vowed to guarantee health care for all Americans, "end welfare as we know it," overhaul education, reduce the size of the Government and reform the campaign finance laws.
After mixed success, at least one stunning failure (health care) and one heavily compromised promise kept (welfare), his goals are far more modest: to preserve the essence of the Democratic social safety net and expand it at the margins, by extending health insurance to children and the unemployed and by offering new tax credits and deductions for college education, a volunteer literacy program for elementary-school students and a public-private effort to connect every classroom in the country to the Internet.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton has already backed so far away from the biggest ambitions that attended his first election that his aides long ago took to describing his first four years as two terms: first the halting missteps through controversies from homosexuals in the military to health care, and then the battles with the Republican-controlled Congress that let him reposition himself as a moderate standing firm against extremes.
That juxtaposition of expansive impulses and accommodationist tactics has been the hallmark of Mr. Clinton's career ever since he was turned out of office after one term as Governor of Arkansas by voters who thought he had overreached, only to win re-election two years later as a chastened, scaled-down centrist.
Once again Mr. Clinton has a chance for a fresh start, and his capacity for adjustment has repeatedly helped him turn weaknesses into strengths and setbacks into progress, in a perpetual campaign in which winning is all.
The tantalizing difference is that for the first time in his life, Mr. Clinton will be running no longer for re-election but instead for his place in the history books he loves to read.
In their more exhausted moments, Mr. Clinton's own longest-serving aides sometimes wonder aloud what he stands for besides winning, and they assume the world will finally find out.
Douglas Brinkley, a professor of history and director of the Eisenhower Center at the University of New Orleans, said, "One of the fascinating things about Clinton is that if he had not won a second term, he would have gone down as a totally forgettable character, with no accomplishments that you could put under glass in a Presidential library."
But, Professor Brinkley said, Mr. Clinton's "basic competence," coupled with a second, stronger victory, "makes him an interesting historical character."
"He really is a work in progress," the professor said, "and the fair question the public is entitled to ask is, What will he be?"
 
The Goals
 
Health and Welfare, Jobs and Education
Mr. Clinton's advisers suggest that the answer is plain enough, apparent in the President's own words and actions of recent months. And indeed 6 in 10 voters surveyed in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, up from 49 percent in September, said Mr. Clinton had made clear what he wanted to accomplish in the next four years.
"I think the President's agenda is clear," said Bruce Reed, a senior domestic policy adviser who has toiled, at times in near solitude, for nearly a year now to help chart it. "Finish the job of balancing the budget, take on the challenge of reforming education and expanding college opportunity, move people from welfare to work and help families get ready for the 21st century by making sure that they have access to quality health care as well as the tools to raise their children the way they want."
Mr. Reed, who was one of the President's earliest moderate advisers in the 1992 campaign and whose star rose as Mr. Clinton tacked to the right during the first term, added: "All of those are big, difficult challenges. They don't necessarily involve big programs, but will require a lot of hard work, in Washington and across the country."
White House aides explain the President's emphasis on modest initiatives that once might have seemed beneath Presidential notice -- like encouraging the telecommunications industry to provide cellular telephones to neighborhood watch groups -- by saying their public opinion surveys show that voters no longer much trust the Government to do big things.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton's own initial decision to reduce the deficit, and his subsequent pledge to balance the Federal budget by the year 2002 as the Republicans demanded, have insured that fiscal resources will be tight for the foreseeable future.
Dick Morris, the political strategist and pollster who helped the President recover from the despair of the 1994 midterm elections by re-emphasizing the moderate themes that had always animated Mr. Clinton, contended last spring that many of the nation's most pressing problems were behavioral, not programmatic. Mr. Morris, who was forced to resign in a sex scandal on the day Mr. Clinton was renominated this summer, argued that Government programs could not make much headway on issues like values and families, for example, but that the bully pulpit could.
Aides say nothing else so convinced Mr. Clinton of the dangers of overreaching as the collapse of the health care legislation drafted under the supervision of his wife. And nothing else so convinced him of the power of his own office -- and of Presidential oratory -- as the public's positive response to his reassuring demeanor in the wake of the Oklahoma City bombing and, eventually, to his initially unpopular decision to send American troops to enforce a tenuous peace in Bosnia.
Accordingly, aides say, Mr. Clinton came to realize that in the White House, symbolism is often substance, and that being seen as effective is as important as being effective.
 
Unfinished Business
How He'll Address 3 Thorny Problems
Much of Mr. Clinton's agenda centers on addressing problems left unsolved in his first term, from making further incremental stabs at extending access to health insurance to mitigating the harshest aspects of the welfare overhaul, which he signed to keep the Republicans from using it as a campaign issue against him.
The new Congress will be narrowly divided, however, and Mr. Clinton will have to find a way to use Republicans not only as an electoral foil, as he did successfully in the second half of his first term, but also, if he wants to leave a legislative record, as genuine partners in compromise. No one expects that to be easy.
The biggest problems of the coming decades -- how to keep Medicare and Social Security solvent in the face of the demands that Mr. Clinton's baby-boomer generation will place upon them -- remained almost entirely unaddressed during this campaign. Aides say Mr. Clinton is all but certain to favor naming blue-ribbon commissions to confront those problems.
Likewise, his aides expect a commission to address how to overhaul the campaign finance laws. Mr. Clinton pledged in 1992 to change those laws, but never seriously tried to. Instead, he raised record amounts of so-called soft money to help the Democratic Party skirt existing limits on contributions to individual candidates.
Mr. Clinton seldom exudes more enthusiasm on the stump than when he talks about the difference that education made in his life, and advisers insist that his election-year goal of offering a $1,500 tax credit to help make at least two years of college as nearly universal as four years of high school is already more than a politically popular offering, rather something like his bid for a legacy.
"Then, the big, big megillah's going to be his peacemaking stuff," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
For much of his first term, Mr. Clinton seemed to shy from foreign policy, in part because he had been elected on so big a domestic agenda.
But increasingly, aides say, he has come to feel more comfortable on the world stage, one of the few areas where any President has the latitude to act with unilateral authority, and more certain that he has a role to play there.
Here too, though, there are problems.
Just one year ago Mr. Clinton promised that American troops would be in Bosnia only about a year. As the deadline approaches, the Administration has yet to acknowledge the virtual certainty that many will have to stay a good while longer.
Though his efforts to intercede in places like Northern Ireland and the Middle East have so far produced mixed results, his advisers expect him to intensify his efforts, much as Ronald Reagan pursued glasnost with the Soviet Union in search of his own legacy.
Expanding the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to include the former Soviet satellites of Eastern Europe will also be at the top of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy program, as he pursues the concept that his national security adviser, Anthony Lake, once dubbed "democratic enlargement."
 
The Risks
 
So Many Inquiries, So Much Peril
The history of second terms is replete with disasters, from Franklin D. Roosevelt's court-packing fight to Richard M. Nixon's Watergate scandal to Ronald Reagan's Iran-contra affair. Reminded of that, Mr. Stephanopoulos just laughed heartily and said the Clinton Administration got its problems "out of the way in the first term."
Still, dangers lurk for Mr. Clinton, from the prospect of turmoil in staff turnover to continued Congressional and criminal investigations into questions arising from the first term, or well before: Whitewater, the travel office dismissals, the gathering of F.B.I. files on prominent Republicans, and the Democratic Party's fund-raising relationships with foreign donors.
Already, for example, Attorney General Janet Reno has begun a preliminary review toward determining whether to seek appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate the fund-raising questions. That could complicate any decision by Mr. Clinton to replace Ms. Reno, or to appoint someone with a highly political background, like Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor, to succeed her.
Many of the President's senior aides, including Mr. Stephanopoulos and the chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, have made no secret of their intention to leave the Administration, and one senior aide said Mr. Clinton hoped to name a successor to Mr. Panetta before leaving on vacation and a trip to Asia next week. If he does not do so by then, this aide warned, that will be a sign of disputes within the inner circle over what to do, and thus of potential trouble ahead.
Vice President Al Gore, whose Presidential aspirations for 2000 are already plain, will be thrust into an even higher role than he has so far played, and with that will come more potential for conflict with his boss. Mr. Gore could well be torn between wanting Mr. Clinton to leave a strong record for him to run on, and wanting the President to avoid getting involved in policy compromises with Congress that could complicate Mr. Gore's efforts to win the Democratic nomination in a primary fight.
At the same time, the First Lady's role in a second term remains cloudy. On the campaign trail at Labor Day, she joked that in a second term, she might get the last laugh.
But Mrs. Clinton is at the center of most of the legal investigations still swirling around the Administration, and no one at the White House expects her to take a formal policy role, though the President has suggested that she might get involved in implementing welfare overhaul.
"She'll travel," one aide said, "and she'll keep up her interest in children and families. But she can never again be seen as having an overt, official job, and she knows it."
 
Legacy
 
Just How Close Does Greatness Lie?
As for Mr. Clinton himself, his aides agree that he has finally settled into the Presidency. The black rages that used to punctuate his workdays are "less frequent," in the words of one aide who bore the brunt of them, and he has more time to think, read and telephone informal advisers. Gone forever are the moments of antic informality that marked his last campaign, as when he was once asked his favorite Elvis Presley movie and replied enthusiastically with a straight face, " 'Viva, Las Vegas!' "
Though his once-salt-and-pepper hair is now almost completely silver, Mr. Clinton remains a young man, and on leaving the Presidency at 54 could still expect to live another 30 years. He might have not only the next term but a long lifetime to burnish his legacy.
"In the world that we live in now," Mr. Stephanopoulos said, "his presence will extend beyond his Presidency, because of the global village and the power of celebrity, among other things."
None of his aides really expect Mr. Clinton to go home and run for mayor or the school board, as he sometimes jokes, but they fully expect that he will be waging one campaign or another, with his Presidential library or a nonprofit foundation as a base.
By his own lights, Mr. Clinton's has been a transitional Presidency in a transitional time, the sole two-term Democratic island in the late-20th-century sea of Republican dominance of the office.
Indeed, that alone might be his principal legacy: that he managed to reshape the old New Deal coalition of liberals and labor into a new alliance of suburbanites and service workers, enough to drag his fractious party into a new century at least tenuously united.
In the end, Mr. Clinton's Presidency remains intriguing precisely because he is perpetually recalibrating it.
"One of the things that make Clinton exciting is the unpredictable nature of it," said Professor Brinkley, the historian. "Clinton-watching is a sport in America because at any moment it's a tightrope act. If there's anything we've learned about the guy, it's not to underestimate him. We have not seen a politician as astute as Bill Clinton since Franklin Roosevelt, so I feel he will be able to avoid the pitfalls, and constantly work around them.
"He's not there yet," Professor Brinkley added. "But he's never dull, and he has the potential here of going down as a truly great President."

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY;
Excerpts From President Clinton's Victory Address at Arkansas Statehouse

 BODY:
Following are excerpts of a transcript of the speech President Clinton delivered last night outside the Statehouse in Little Rock, Ark., after his re-election:
Thank you. My fellow Americans, thank you for being here. 
Just four years from now, we will enter a new century of great challenge and unlimited possibility. Now, we've got a bridge to build, and I'm ready if you are.
Today the American people have spoken. They have affirmed our course. They have told us to go forward. America has told every one of us -- Democrats, Republicans and independents -- loud and clear: it is time to put politics aside, join together and get the job done for America's future.
In the last four years, we've made remarkable progress. But in our schools, our families, our workplaces and our communities, our journey is not done. . . .
I would like to say a special word of thanks to Senator Dole, and I ask you join me in applause for his lifetime of service to the United States.
And I thank Jack Kemp for his service to America and his devotion to the proposition that this a country in which everyone should have a chance to live free and equal and to have a chance at success.
Let me say, and I had a good visit with Senator Dole not too long before he went out to speak. I thanked him for his love of our country, for his years of service.
I applauded the campaign that he fought so bravely to the very last minute. I thanked him for the work we did together to advance the common cause of America. And on behalf of all Americans, I wish him well and God speed.
Four years ago, on these very steps, we set forth on a journey to change the course of America for the better, to keep the American dream alive for everyone willing to work for it, to keep America the world's strongest force for peace and freedom and prosperity, to come together as one American community.
The time was one of widespread frustration and doubt about our economic and social problems, about our ability to deal with the vast sweep of change that was all around us. The scope and pace of those changes were threatening to many and our values seemed to be under attack on all sides.
But, together, you and I vowed to turn our country around, with a strategy to meet our challenges and protect our values, opportunity for all, responsibility from all, an American community of all Americans.
We have worked hard to end the politics of who's to blame and instead to ask, what are we going to do to make America better.
Tonight, we proclaim that the vital American center is alive and well. It is a common ground on which we have made our progress. Today, our economy is stronger, our streets are safer, our environment is cleaner, the world is more secure and, thank God, our nation is more united. . . .
We must make our democracy stronger by enacting real, bipartisan campaign finance reform. Talk is no longer enough. We must act and act now. And the American people will be watching the leaders of both parties to see who is willing not just to talk but to act. I am willing to act, and I ask others to join me.
And we must keep America the world's indispensable nation. Finishing the unfinished business of the cold war, meeting the new threats to our security through terrorism and the proliferation of dangerous weapons and seizing these extraordinary opportunities to extend our values of peace and democracy and prosperity.
Every American here tonight and every American within the sound of my voice can take pride in the fact that in these last few years for the first time in all of human history, a majority of the human beings living on this globe live under democracies where the people rule.
The challenges we face, they're not Democratic or Republican challenges. They're American challenges. What we know from the budget battles of the last two years and from the remarkable success of the last few weeks of this Congress is the lesson we have learned for the last 220 years -- what we have achieved as Americans of lasting good, we have achieved by working together.
So let me say to the leaders of my Democratic Party and the leaders of the Republican Party, it is time to put country ahead of party.
We do not know the final outcome of the Congressional elections but we know this: The races are close. The American people have been closely divided. The Congress, whatever happens, will be closely divided.
They are sending us a message: Work together. Meet our challenges. Put aside the politics of division and build America's community, together. . . .
What we need to do is to do the work of America, the way we seek to do the work of raising our children and doing our work and supporting our religious institutions and our community institutions.
If we would simply be Americans, the way we seek to live in all of our other roles, there is no stopping America. Our best days are still ahead.
And so, I say, when we look into our hearts and simply ask what is right for the American people and the future of our children, when we set aside our differences and build on our shared values of faith and family and work, when we roll up our sleeves and work together, America always wins. . . .
I got here tonight, my fellow Americans, because America gave me a chance. That is what all the children of America deserve. Our people have to give them the tools to give them not a guarantee, but that real chance to live up to their God-given potential.
And I ask you to join me in that commitment. Every child deserves the main chance that I was given.
And so I say again let us resolve to run our country the way we try to run our lives. Whether you are the party of Thomas Jefferson or the party of Abraham Lincoln, whether you're an independent or unaffiliated, remember that we all belong to the greatest nation in history.
To us, much has been given, and much is still expected. We must rise to the challenge of building that bridge to the 21st century. Tonight is a night for joy, not just for us here but for all Americans.
For the 53d time in our history, our people have made their quiet and deliberate decision. They have come together with their powerful voice and expressed their will.
Tonight we celebrate the miracle of America. Tomorrow we greet the dawn and begin our work anew. I am more grateful than I can say. You have given me an opportunity and a responsibility that comes to few people.
I will do my best, and together we will -- we will build that bridge to the 21st century. Thank you. Good night, and God bless America. Thank you.

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: NEW JERSEY -- THE CHOICE;
Strategy of Torricelli Painted Foe as Extreme

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
Convince New Jersey's independent, middle-class voters that Congressional Republicans endanger Federal programs they care about. Campaign relentlessly against Speaker Newt Gingrich. Portray your Republican opponent as a Gingrich ally and an extremist out of step with the state's moderate tradition.
The strategy that carried Representative Robert G. Torricelli to victory in the race for the Senate was not particularly complicated. 
 Mr. Torricelli, a Democrat, spent much of the campaign mirroring the words and tactics of President Clinton, invoking a carefully calibrated mantra: education, Medicare, the environment.
He repeatedly accused his Republican opponent, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, of having voted with Mr. Gingrich to cut the growth of Medicare, and to reduce Federal financing for programs to support education and protect the environment. Mr. Torricelli, a seven-term veteran of the House, had promised he would work to insure that those programs remained intact.
"The politics of protection," David P. Rebovich, a professor of political science at Rider University in Lawrenceville, N.J., called the Democratic strategy in New Jersey and around the country. "It resonated."
By a ratio of about 11 to 8, a majority of New Jersey's voters disapproved of what the Republicans in Congress had done in the last two years, a survey of people leaving polling places found yesterday. And of those who disapproved, more than 8 in 10 said they had voted for Mr. Torricelli.
When the voters were asked in the poll what issues mattered most to them in their vote for President, they listed the economy and jobs, taxes, Medicare and Social Security, and education.
Except for taxes, those were the issues Mr. Torricelli had emphasized during the campaign. Two-thirds of the respondents who said that Medicare mattered most to them said they had voted for Mr. Torricelli. More than three-quarters of those who said that education mattered most said they had voted for the Democrat. And two-thirds of those who listed the economy as most significant also voted for Mr. Torricelli.
"I liked what Torricelli had to say about education," said Paul DeMarse, a Paramus resident who teaches in a New York City junior high school.
Mr. DeMarse, interviewed after voting at the Parkway Elementary School in Paramus, said he was a registered Democrat. "I also thought Medicare was an important issue, and I'm fearful of what Congress wanted to do," he said.
Many of the issues that Mr. Zimmer emphasized did not appear to have served him well with voters, nor did his some of his campaign tactics.
A majority of survey respondents who said that taxes mattered most to them said they had voted for Mr. Zimmer, by a ratio of more than 2 to 1. Mr. Zimmer, who presented himself as a fiscal conservative and a social moderate, said often that he would never vote for a measure that would result in a tax increase.
Mr. Zimmer had also said that eliminating the Federal budget deficit was a paramount concern. But only about 1 in 20 voters said they considered the deficit the most important issue, and half of those said they had voted for Mr. Torricelli.
Mr. Rebovich contended that Mr. Zimmer and his advisers were aware that voters were responding to the Democrats' issues this year. Mr. Rebovich said he thought that was why they decided to make direct attacks on Mr. Torricelli's character and ethics.
"So how do we stop him?" Mr. Rebovich said, describing the Zimmer strategy. "By telling people that he's unelectable on ethical grounds."
Mr. Zimmer tried to convince voters that Mr. Torricelli's character was flawed, concentrating in television commercials on several accusations, including an accusation that Mr. Torricelli had helped the daughter of a former campaign contributor who had been indicted on charges of bank fraud and had fled the country.
Mr. Zimmer acknowledged in his concession speech last night that his effort to make the election a referendum on Mr. Torricelli's character, and not on Republican Congressional policies, had failed.
"Ultimately, this was a debate not of personalities, but of philosophies," Mr. Zimmer said. The survey of 1,752 voters, conducted by Voter News Service, also showed that several broad categories of New Jersey voters had proved critical for Mr. Torricelli. Black voters preferred him by a ratio of nearly 9 to 1. People between the ages of 45 and 59 selected Mr. Torricelli by a ratio of 3 to 2.
Not surprisingly, a large majority of those who described themselves as liberal voted for Mr. Torricelli, while most who said they were conservative voted for Mr. Zimmer.
Of those who described their political views as moderate -- half of the electorate, according to the exit poll -- Mr. Torricelli was preferred by a ratio of nearly 3 to 2.
Mr. Zimmer, apparently aware that the political winds were not blowing his way, insisted often that he too was a moderate on many issues. He noted often that several national environmental groups had given him high marks.
But voter sentiments expressed in the exit poll and in separate interviews yesterday indicated that the constant criticism of Congressional Republicans by Mr. Torricelli and other Democrats had reverberated with voters.
New Jersey voters have sometimes split their votes, selecting a Presidential candidate from one political party and a Senator from another, but this was not one of those times. Nearly 9 out of 10 of the voters who selected Mr. Clinton also voted for Mr. Torricelli, the exit poll found.
Many of Mr. Zimmer's commercials had attacked Mr. Torricelli as "foolishly liberal," a tactic that had worked in many recent elections around the country. It was not successful yesterday in New Jersey.
"People may have seen that movie too many times," said Hank Morris, a Democratic political consultant in New York City.

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
MIDWEST

BYLINE: This report was written by Keith Bradsher, Robert D. Hershey Jr., David M. Herszenhorn, Neil A. Lewis, Jane H. Lii, John T. McQuiston, Steven Lee Myers, Gustav Niebuhr, Eric Schmitt and Richard W. Stevenson. 

 BODY:

ILLINOIS -- CLINTON
President Clinton won Illinois. Dole supporters leaving the polls said that they chose their candidate particularly because they trusted him, but Clinton voters said that the President shared their vision of the future. 
 Representative Richard J. Durbin, a seven-term Congressman from the sparsely populated 20th District in southwestern Illinois, won the race to succeed Senator Paul Simon, a 67-year-old Democrat who is retiring. The national Republican Party had made Senator Simon's seat an early target, but suffered a setback when a moderate candidate with broad appeal was defeated in the state primary by Al Salvi, a wealthy conservative. Mr. Salvi campaigned vigorously for a ban on so-called "partial-birth abortions" and called for a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution.
Mr. Durbin, a former aide to Senator Simon, who strongly endorsed his protege, is best known as a crusader against tobacco interests. He had the disadvantage of being relatively unknown in heavily Democratic Chicago, and the advantage of being a popular Democrat in the fairly conservative downstate region.
The struggle to replace Mr. Durbin in the 20th District, which includes Springfield, the capital, produced a very close race between John M. Shimkus, the Republican treasurer of Madison County, and Jay C. Hoffman, a Democratic State Representative.
Representative Michael Patrick Flanagan won national fame two years ago when, at the age of 31, he beat Dan Rostenkowski, the disgraced former Ways and Means Committee chairman. But Mr. Flanagan was unable this year to hold on to the Fifth District, which covers Chicago's northwestern suburbs.
A weak fund-raising effort and the district's Democratic tradition undid Mr. Flanagan as Rod R. Blagojevich, a Democratic State Representative, won the race by a wide margin.
Republicans seemed secure in their control of the State Senate, but struggled to retain their majority in the Illinois House.

Clinton -- 1,900,013 -- 55%
Dole -- 1,226,044 -- 36%

Durbin -- 1,927,399 -- 57%
Salvi -- 1,344,564 -- 40%
 
INDIANA -- DOLE
Indiana has voted for a Democratic candidate only once since 1932 -- for Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964. And Bob Dole kept the streak alive, although President Clinton mounted a stronger than expected challenge for the state's 12 electoral votes.
Even with Mr. Dole's victory in one of the nation's Republican redoubts, the Democrats held on to the Governor's office, which is being vacated by Evan Bayh, a popular Democrat stepping down after the maximum of two terms.
In one of the tightest governor's races, Mr. Bayh's Lieutenant Governor, Frank L. O'Bannon, defeated Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis, a Republican who has a national reputation for his efforts to "reinvent government" by putting municipal services out for bids by private companies.
Mr. Goldsmith's campaign was beset with problems, including the resignation of the city's police chief after a drunken brawl by off-duty police officers. At one point, a frustrated Mr. Goldsmith blamed the Dole campaign for his travails. "My numbers are obviously repressed by Dole," he said.
In House races, the Republicans appeared to have fewer worries. In the Second District, Representative David M. McIntosh held off a challenge by Marc Carmichael, a former state legislator. But in the Eighth District, Representative John Hostettler, another freshman, faced a strong challenge from Jon Weinzapfel, a former aide to Representative Frank McCloskey, the Democrat Mr. Hostettler defeated two years ago.
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, a 16-term Democrat, prevailed in his rematch against Jean Leising, a Republican State Senator who nearly upset him in 1994.

IOWA -- CLINTON
Iowa has been friendly territory to Democratic Presidential candidates in recent elections, and this year was no exception. President Clinton captured the state's seven electoral votes in 1996, as he did four years ago.
Senator Tom Harkin, a veteran liberal populist, won re-election to a third term, beating back a strong challenge by Representative Jim Ross Lightfoot, a six-term Republican who is chairman of a House Appropriations subcommittee. In a race that seemed to tighten considerably at its end, Mr. Harkin had promoted his support for abortion rights and an increase in the minimum wage, while Mr. Lightfoot portrayed himself as a budget cutter.
Mr. Lightfoot's decision to challenge Mr. Harkin threw open his seat in the Third District, an area that encompasses many of the state's southern counties, which are largely rural. In that contest, Leonard L. Boswell, a farmer and the State Senate president, campaigned on his support for education financing, while the Republican, Mike Mahaffey, a county attorney and former state party chairman, promoted his support for a balanced budget.
But the race in the neighboring Fourth District, encompassing southwestern Iowa, drew far more national attention. A freshman Republican, Representative Greg Ganske, a plastic surgeon who upset a 36-year Democratic incumbent in 1994, won a second term, turning back a strong challenge from Connie McBurney, a well-known former television weather forecaster who is well known throughout the state. Ms. McBurney had been trying to buck history: Iowa has never sent a woman to Congress.

KANSAS -- DOLE
 As expected, the Republican Presidential nominee, Bob Dole, won his state's electoral college votes. The Senate seat he vacated stayed in the Republican column.
Mr. Dole's sudden retirement from the Senate in May to concentrate on his campaign touched off a race to fill the remaining two years of his Senate term. The Republican nominee, Sam Brownback, a House freshman, won a bitterly fought primary in August that wounded state party unity.
Despite Mr. Dole's position at the top of the ticket and the traditional Republican hold on Kansas politics, Mr. Brownback fought hard to defeat his Democratic opponent, Jill Docking. Mr. Brownback, a member of his party's conservative wing, had the support of Kansas's Christian conservative movement. He opposes abortion rights while Ms. Docking supports them.
The Brownback-Docking contest somewhat overshadowed the race to fill the full-term Senate seat vacated by Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a retiring three-term Republican. While Kansas politics has been unpredictable this year, Pat Roberts, an eight-term Republican member of the House, won comfortably over his opponent, State Treasurer Sally Thompson.
Mr. Roberts, who gained state and national attention by pushing a major farm law revision through Congress, attacked Ms. Thompson as a relative newcomer to Kansas, in that she has lived in the state only since 1985, while his family has resided there for several generations.
With the many retirements announced this year in Kansas, both in the House and Senate, Representative Todd Tiahrt, a freshman Republican, stood the chance of becoming the state's senior House member. He faced a strong challenge from Randy Rathbun, a Democrat and a former United States Attorney. Mr. Tiahrt won in 1994 by defeating Representative Dan Glickman, a nine-term Democrat.

MICHIGAN -- CLINTON
In the state that made Reagan Democrats famous, a strong economy and low unemployment helped President Clinton keep a lead through the autumn and win the state again. Both Presidential candidates made frequent visits, but Mr. Dole had difficulty convincing voters of the need for his 15 percent tax cut at a time when the auto industry is booming and the state government is looking for ways to lure skilled workers from other states.
Senator Carl Levin, a Democrat, retained his seat, defeating Ronna Romney, a conservative Republican and former radio talk show host, according to exit polls.
Strong backing from anti-abortion groups and gun control opponents helped Mrs. Romney win the primary against a moderate Republican businessman, Jim Nicholson, but proved less useful in the general election.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. poured money into the state's many hotly contested Congressional races, and business groups responded by buying many television advertisements, too. In the days before the election, almost every advertisement during the evening news broadcasts was for some candidate. One of the most hard-fought campaigns came in the Eighth District in central Michigan, where Representative Dick Chrysler, a freshman Republican, faced Debbie Stabenow, a state legislator.
Representative John D. Dingell, the longest-serving current member of the House, benefited from generous campaign contributions and was a favorite to defeat Jim DeSana, a former Democratic Mayor of Wyandotte, a town in the district. Mr. DeSana switched parties for the race.
Representative David E. Bonior, the Democratic whip, and Representative Sander M. Levin, a senior Democrat, both had comfortable leads in October polls.
The vote count was very close on a state referendum to approve casino gambling in Detroit, which has watched for years as tourists crossed the Detroit River to the casinos of Windsor, Ontario. Detroit residents also voted on whether to approve another tax on hotels and rental cars to help the Detroit Lions football team move downtown from Pontiac, Mich. Two wealthy landowners spent more than $1 million to back an initiative limiting the hunting of bears, a practice that sometimes involves trespassing and has been criticized as inhumane, but polls showed limited public support.

MINNESOTA -- CLINTON
President Clinton's success never appeared in doubt in this traditional Democratic stronghold, now the only state to vote Democratic in the last six elections. So the Republicans focused their attention on recapturing the Senate seat held by Paul Wellstone, a Democrat embroiled in a rematch against the Republican Senator he narrowly defeated in 1990, Rudy Boschwitz.
It was one of the most competitive campaigns in the nation, and one of the nastiest, but Mr. Wellstone withstood the challenge.
Mr. Boschwitz and the National Republican Senatorial Committee produced many negative television advertisements, calling Mr. Wellstone "embarrassingly liberal."
The Senator's decision to vote against the new welfare restrictions pushed by Republicans in Congress and signed by President Clinton -- he was the only Democrat seeking re-election to do so -- fueled the attacks.
Saying that the law would only create more poverty, Mr. Wellstone, perhaps the most unabashedly liberal Senator, strongly defended his vote. He also countered with his own attacks, accusing Mr. Boschwitz of voting in the Senate against an increase in the minimum wage.
And by the end, there were signs that Mr. Boschwitz's harsh advertisements had backfired. According to one poll, 44 percent of those who saw the advertisements said they made them more likely to vote for his opponent. At the same time, Mr. Boschwitz's approval ratings sank.
In the House races, Democrats sought to hold seats they narrowly won two years ago. The most competitive race was in the First District, where the Democratic candidate, Mary Rieder, a former Republican and an economics professor, challenged a freshman Republican, Gil Gutknecht. Mr. Gut knecht was singled out by Democrats and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. as one of the most vulnerable Republicans in Congress.

MISSOURI
Bob Dole traveled to Missouri 12 times this campaign season, but President Clinton maintained a narrow, steady lead in the state, which he visited four times this year and won by a margin of 10 percentage points over George Bush in 1992.
Mr. Clinton's coattails helped the first-term Democratic Governor, Mel Carnahan, win his bid for a second four-year term against his Republican challenger, Margaret Kelly, the State Auditor. Poor fund raising hurt Ms. Kelly, who trailed Mr. Carnahan throughout the race.
Most House incumbents looked safe, including James M. Talent, a two-term Republican who won a rematch with a former Democratic Congresswoman, Joan Kelly Horn, and Ike Skelton, a Democrat who is a senior member of the National Security Committee. Mr. Skelton defeated Bill Phelps, a Republican.
Representative Harold L. Volkmer, a Democrat, faced the toughest challenge: a rematch against Kenny Hulshof, a Republican who lost to Mr. Volkmer by only six percentage points in 1994.
One of the country's most unusual contests was the three-way race to fill the seat of Bill Emerson, a Republican who died in June. His widow, Jo Ann Emerson, missed the filing deadline for Republican candidates, but, running as an independent, she defeated Emily Firebaugh, a Democrat, and the Republican primary winner, Richard A. Kline. Republican Party officials at the state and national levels backed Mrs. Emerson, who promised to continue her husband's legacy.
Democrats hoped a Clinton win in Missouri could bolster their State Senate majority.

NEBRASKA -- DOLE
The Republicans had their appetites whetted when Senator Jim Exon, a three-term Democrat, announced his retirement in what is essentially a conservative state. The Democrats were able to persuade Gov. Ben Nelson, who is enormously popular in the state, to run for the open seat. But the victor was the Republican, Chuck Hagel, an Omaha businessman.
Both candidates ran on conservative platforms, although Mr. Hagel's campaign was noteworthy in that it featured earnest and explicit support for Bob Dole's call for a sizable Federal tax cut.
Both candidates presented themselves as abortion opponents.
In the state's Second Congressional District, Representative Jon Christensen, a freshman Republican, campaigned unabashedly on the Contract With America, the House Republicans' 1994 campaign manifesto, and held on to his seat. Mr. Christensen narrowly defeated a three-term Democrat, Peter Hoagland, two years ago, and Democrats mobilized strongly to oust him this time. Mr. Christensen began to rely heavily on the Christian Coalition in his re-election bid.
The Democratic nominee, James Martin Davis, tried to attach his wagon firmly to the Nelson campaign and depicted himself as a moderate-conservative.

NORTH DAKOTA
Only once since 1944 has a Democrat carried North Dakota, and that was in the Johnson landslide of 1964. George Bush carried the state easily four years ago, despite a strong showing by Ross Perot, who took 23 percent of the vote. But the latest statewide poll this year, in mid-October, showed President Clinton ahead, 41 percent to 35 percent, in a two-way race against Mr. Dole. The poll did not measure Mr. Perot's support.
Democratic Congressional candidates have always fared better in North Dakota than Democratic Presidential candidates have, perhaps reflecting the state's populist, agrarian history. Both Senators, Byron L. Dorgan and Kent Conrad, are Democrats, as is the state's House member, Earl Pomeroy, the only member of the Congressional delegation up for re-election this year.
Mr. Pomeroy won his race by emphasizing his moderate voting record and arguing that his challenger, Kevin Cramer, would be a loyal Gingrich soldier pushing a radical Republican agenda. Mr. Cramer did not argue. In fact, he invited Mr. Gingrich and Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader, to hold fund raisers for him.
Mr. Cramer, the state's tourism director, trailed in polls throughout the race. His strategy was to argue that the state needed a Republican in its Congressional delegation since the Republicans controlled Congress.
Gov. Edward T. Schafer, a Republican, won a second term against Lee Kaldor, a member of the State House. Mr. Schafer campaigned on his record of cutting taxes and increasing spending on education.

OHIO -- CLINTON
President Clinton won Ohio, though by less than polls had suggested until the final few days. No Republican has won the White House without Ohio in this century, and Bob Dole was unable to overcome Mr. Clinton's persistent lead.. The state suffered from a case of the "political blahs," one prominent commentator said, despite dozens of visits by both major-party candidates and their wives and running mates.
The main suspense for the state involved Congress, where the Republicans captured a Senate seat and four House seats from the Democrats two years ago, with all freshmen now vulnerable along with a sophomore, Martin R. Hoke, whose comments about a female journalist's anatomy weakened him.
Mr. Hoke, twice the beneficiary of opponents who self-destructed, was opposed by Dennis J. Kucinich, a Democrat who as a 32-year old Mayor of Cleveland two decades ago presided over his city's bankruptcy, a fact that Mr. Hoke hammered home. The irrepressible Mr. Kucinich, now a State Senator, ran advertisements in which the incumbent was represented by a parrot that squawked "Gingrich." Mr. Hoke could have suffered from a September prediction by a fellow Republican Congressman that he would have lost an election held then.
Representative Frank A. Cremeans of the Sixth District in Appalachia looked to be the most vulnerable of the Republican freshmen as he faced Ted Strickland, the Democrat, in a rematch of their 1994 race, when Mr. Cremeans's margin was just two percentage points. The contest was regarded as a referendum on the Republican agenda, which Mr. Strickland, a psychologist who held the seat from 1992 to 1994, criticized as hurting working people and the poor.
Labor flooded the district with advertisements on Medicare. Mr. Strickland made tactical errors, but Mr. Cremeans lost important newspaper endorsements.
Among the other Republican freshmen -- Steve Chabot, Bob Ney and Steven C. LaTourette -- only Mr. Chabot had a lead that could be called comfortable.
Representative Tom Sawyer, a five-term Democrat who squeaked to victory last time, faced a challenge from Joyce George, a Republican who is a former United States Attorney and state judge.

SOUTH DAKOTA
In one of the toughest United States Senate races this year, Representative Tim Johnson, a Democrat, defeated the Republican incumbent, Larry Pressler.
Late last month, the first independent poll in the race showed Mr. Johnson, with a 10-percentage-point lead. Mr. Pressler, the chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, was seeking a fourth term. A Rhodes Scholar with a law degree from Harvard, he was first elected in 1978.
Mr. Johnson, elected to Congress in 1986, has three degrees from the University of South Dakota.
Mr. Pressler had accused his opponent of supporting "Washington's failed liberal philosophy of tax and spend versus South Dakota's conservative, common-sense values," while Mr. Johnson had accused the Senator of blocking campaign finance reform and of not supporting farmers strongly enough.
The race was followed closely by national party officials. South Dakota's other Senator is Tom Daschle, a Democrat and the minority leader.
Mr. Daschle's longtime staff director, Rick Weiland, lost the fight for Mr. Johnson's old job, the state's lone House seat. The victor was John Thune, a Republican businessman and onetime aide to former Senator Jim Abdnor.
The Presidential race in South Dakota was a tight contest over just three electoral votes. Bob Dole led in most polls.

WISCONSIN -- CLINTON
Buoyed by a booming economy and a lack of major controversies, voters in Wisconsin for the most part maintained the status quo.
As expected, Bill Clinton beat Bob Dole. Although Mr. Dole gained in the polls in the state as the election neared, he still all but wrote off Wisconsin after the Republican convention this summer, concentrating instead on Ohio and other Midwestern states. That prompted complaints from the state's Republican Governor, Tommy G. Thompson.
The race in the First Congressional District, between the Republican incumbent, Mark W. Neumann, a supporter of Newt Gingrich and the Contract With America, and his Democratic opponent, Lydia Spottswood, was too close to call early today in what once had been a Democratic stronghold. Mr. Neumann portrayed himself as a deficit hawk who dared to buck the House leadership over a military spending bill.
In the Second District, the Republican incumbent, Scott L. Klug, defeated the Democratic candidate, Paul R. Soglin. Mr. Soglin sought to tie Mr. Klug to Mr. Gingrich by morphing Mr. Klug's image into that of Mr. Gingrich in a television advertisement. Mr. Klug countered with a commercial in which his image was morphed back from that of Mr. Gingrich.
In the Fourth District, the Democratic incumbent, Gerald D. Kleczka, defeated Tom Reynolds, a Republican.
In the Fifth District, Thomas M. Barrett, the Democratic incumbent, won re-election over his Republican rival, Paul D. Melotik.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1420 words

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- NEWS ANALYSIS;
Economy Helps Again

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

 BODY:
Four years ago, a faltering economy persuaded American voters to give Bill Clinton a chance as President. Yesterday, surveys of voters leaving the polls showed, a robust economy persuaded them that he deserved a second term.
Four years ago, only 39 percent of voters said they thought the country was headed in the right direction -- a key indicator of the nation's mood. That figure grew this year to 53 percent. 
 But Mr. Clinton's success in occupying "the vital center," as he called it in his victory statement, in a phrase borrowed from the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., did not extend to Capitol Hill. He and his party failed in their quest to recapture control of the Senate, and they appeared headed for failure in the struggle for dominance of the House of Representatives. So he and his country face two more years at least of divided Government.
After a campaign filled with fund-raising abuses on a grand scale, Mr. Clinton pledged early action on campaign-finance reform. His Vice President, Al Gore, said he was ready to work with the Republicans, and the President himself said, "It is time to put country ahead of party."
But appeals to eschew partisanship may be lost in the clamor of investigations of alleged scandals in the first Clinton Administration.
The returns showed little diminution in the conservative trend that has coursed through the country since the 1970's. The new Senate will be more conservative than the old. In California, the most publicized initiative of the year, opposing affirmative action, was approved.
Bob Dole did everything he could to refocus the Presidential contest, the last of the 20th century, as Mr. Clinton said so often. He quit the Senate. He abandoned his long-term insistence that deficit reduction must take precedence over tax cuts. He chose Jack Kemp, with whom he had often quarreled, as a running mate. He tried to persuade Ross Perot to withdraw. He gambled everything on a long shot in California, where he had little chance.
At the end, like George Bush in 1992, he assailed Mr. Clinton's character and ethical standards.
None of it worked. None of his tactical zigs and none of his tactical zags changed the strategic reality: Presidents, even Presidents like this one, mistrusted by the electorate, are unlikely to be cast from office in times of peace and prosperity.
Especially when the President is as politically adept as Mr. Clinton. Mr. Dole, 23 years older, reared in a bygone political culture, could not match the President as a campaigner. He provided this wistful analysis of his own in an interview with CNN shortly before the end of the campaign: "You have to give the President credit. He's a very smooth talker. He hits the right buttons. He'll adopt things, things the Republican Congress has passed."
The discombobulation of Mr. Dole's campaign was epitomized when the campaign prematurely sent to newsrooms a fax conceding that he had lost. After a flurry of telephone calls, he became the first Presidential candidate in history to unconcede, however temporarily.
Mr. Clinton also had a valuable electoral insurance policy: his popularity (and his main rival's unpopularity) among women, which apparently resulted at least in part from the Republican Party's resolute stand against abortion. But it was not just abortion; there was an even larger gender gap in the Massachusetts Senate contest, where both candidates defended abortion rights.
In the Presidential campaign, it was almost as if there were two elections, one for men, who gave Mr. Dole a majority, and one for women, who gave the President a larger one.
So Mr. Clinton, derided in 1993, humiliated by a Republican sweep in 1994, forced to defend his own political relevance in 1995, won a second term -- something accomplished by only two other Democrats in this century. It was a remarkable achievement, especially for one so tainted by scandal. More than half those who voted said they doubted the President's trustworthiness.
He did better than he had four years ago, approaching if not reaching 50 percent, though not quite as well as some of his strategists had hoped.
Florida, where Mr. Clinton lost by a hair four years ago, swung easily into his column this time, perhaps because the state's many elderly voters believed the Democrats when they said the Republicans threatened Medicare. One of the Sun Belt mega-states, Florida constituted one of the night's big prizes.
Nowhere in the early returns did Mr. Dole surprise. His best big state was Texas, but he was unable effectively to challenge Mr. Clinton anywhere in the broad swath of states that form the Northeast quadrant of the country. From Ohio to Maine and south to Maryland and Missouri he took only Indiana.
Mr. Clinton swept the Pacific Coast states. Mr. Dole showed more strength in the South, but not nearly enough, and a good deal more in his native region, the Great Plains.
The larger question, unanswered in the voting, was what kind of second-term President Bill Clinton would prove to be. The liberal of his first two years? The moderate of his second two? Operating under financial stringency, his options will be limited, and they may be limited further if, as anticipated, the final tally leaves the Republicans in control of both houses of Congress.
In the final days of the campaign, Republican leaders appealed, in speeches and in television commercials, for mass ticket-splitting, arguing that if Mr. Clinton won, it would be even more important to elect a Republican House and Senate to prevent the President from completely dominating Washington.
It appeared that the Democrats had succeeded in their efforts to demonize Mr. Clinton's tormentor from the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue, Speaker Newt Gingrich. Six of 10 voters said they held an unfavorable opinion of the Speaker, and of those, more than two-thirds backed Mr. Clinton.
Voters said that rather than character issues, the economy and jobs mattered most, followed by Medicare and Social Security. More than 6 in 10 said the economy is in good shape, and Mr. Clinton got most of their votes.
The cleavage was clear. About 3 voters in 10 said their own finances had improved during the Clinton years, and two-thirds of them voted for the President. About 2 in 10 said their finances had worsened since the last election, and two-thirds of them, cast their ballots for Mr. Dole.
Mr. Dole's furious closing onslaught against the ethics of the White House, delivered in an increasingly frayed voice, apparently had an impact, if not enough to turn the election around. According to the exit poll, conducted by Voter News Service, a consortium of television networks and The Associated Press, voters who waited until the last minute to make up their minds went to Mr. Dole by two-to-one.
And Republicans "went home," as the politicians say, as the campaign came down to the wire. Mr. Dole took a greater share of their votes, according to the exit polls, than earlier surveys had suggested he was likely to do.
But the election left a bad taste in the country's mouth.
Half the voters interviewed for the exit poll said they cast their ballots with reservations about the man they were voting for. Most were skeptical about what the candidates told them; they had doubts that Mr. Clinton could pay for his social programs and cut the deficit at the same time, and they had doubts about Mr. Dole's ability to cut taxes and reduce the budget deficit.
Democratic chances of taking control of the Senate were damaged in the South, where the retirement of four Democratic incumbents in the days when Mr. Clinton seemed unlikely to win re-election created open seats. Democrats lost two of those seats, those being relinquished by Senators Howell Heflin of Alabama and David Pryor of Arkansas, though they held two others.
In House contests, it appeared that the Democratic efforts to unseat Republican freshmen, bolstered by millions of dollars of trade-union money, were falling short.
Two pieces of American political lore remained intact as the result of yesterday's voting: No Republican has ever been elected President in the modern era who failed to win the New Hampshire primary, which leads off the quadrennial voting marathon. Mr. Dole was beaten this year by Patrick J. Buchanan, the outspoken conservative.
And Mr. Clinton also won Ohio, a reliable bellwether in Presidential elections. No Republican has ever been elected without taking that state's electoral votes.

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON ELECTED TO A 2D TERM WITH SOLID MARGINS ACROSS U.S.; G.O.P. KEEPS HOLD ON CONGRESS

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
William Jefferson Clinton was re-elected President of the United States yesterday, capping a yearlong political resurgence that made him the first Democrat since Franklin Delano Roosevelt to win a second term as President.
Mr. Clinton built a landslide in the Electoral College and won a decisive victory in the popular vote, overwhelming Bob Dole in all regions of the country except the South and the High Plains, where the Republican won several states. The President's sweep carried to California, where Mr. Dole, in an enormous gamble, diverted millions of dollars from other states and stumped doggedly in the final weeks of the campaign. 
 Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire who ran on the ticket of the Reform Party he had created, finished a distant third, drawing roughly half of the 19 percent he won in 1992.
With 84 percent of the popular vote tallied at 3 A.M. today, Mr. Clinton drew 49 percent; Mr. Dole 41 percent, and Mr. Perot 8 percent. The President surpassed his showing of 43 percent of the popular vote in 1992.
A state-by-state breakdown of those returns gave Mr. Clinton more than the 370 electoral votes he won four years ago, a commanding showing in the Electoral College, which requires 270 votes for victory.
The support for Mr. Clinton did not run deep enough to allow Democrats to declare a reversal of the Republican tide that swept Congress two years ago. The Republicans retained control of the Senate; by early this morning, they appeared headed to keep a majority in the House.
With a Democrat still in the Oval Office and Republicans still dominating at least one chamber of Congress, the nation's political landscape remains competitive and unsettled.
Shortly after midnight, eastern time, Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore and their families emerged before a joyous crowd jamming the streets in front of the Old State House in Little Rock, Ark., where they had their victory celebration four years ago.
"Today the American people have spoken," Mr. Clinton said, recognizing the power of the mixed message that voters seemed to be sending him and Congress.
"America has told every one of us -- Democrats, Republicans and independents -- loud and clear: It is time to put politics aside, join together and get the job done for America's future."
Paying tribute to Mr. Dole, the President called on the partisan crowd to "join me in applause for his lifetime of service to the United States." Mr. Clinton said he spoke with his rival last night, adding, "I applauded the campaign that he fought so bravely."
Less than an hour earlier, Mr. Dole, accompanied by his wife, Elizabeth, and his daughter, Robin, appeared at a hotel ballroom in Washington that was packed with his cheering supporters.
"Tomorrow will be the first time in my life I don't have anything to do," he said. He added: "It hurts to lose an election. But stay involved and keep fighting the good fight because you are the ones who will make the 21st century the next American century."
At times over the past two years, winning his party's nomination appeared as vital to Mr. Dole as winning the White House. He said last night, "I've never been prouder in my life than to have been the Republican nominee for President of the United States."
The 50-year-old Mr. Clinton offered himself as a vigorous leader for a new century, but the success of his campaign turned largely on his ability to seize a litany of Republican issues as his own, welfare, crime and balancing the budget. Often, the President seemed to be running as much against Newt Gingrich, the unpopular Speaker of the House, as against Mr. Dole. Mr. Clinton's nimble and aggressive political organization, and the fact that he has presided over a relatively hardy economy in peacetime, left Mr. Dole with few openings to make his case.
Perhaps the most striking example of Mr. Clinton's electoral strength was his victory in Florida, where both candidates campaigned strenuously. Mr. Clinton was particularly determined to win Florida because he viewed a victory there as emblematic of the Democrats' breaking the Republican stranglehold on the South.
In addition, the President lost the state very narrowly in 1992, even though he barely campaigned there. The last Democrat to win Florida was Jimmy Carter in 1976.
Besides Florida and California, Mr. Clinton's electoral victories included New Jersey, Connecticut, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Tennessee. Mr. Dole's biggest prize was Texas.
Among women, Democrats, Asian-American and Hispanic voters, Mr. Clinton won more support than he did against George Bush in 1992.
Though his attempt to stage a Trumanesque upset never materialized, Mr. Dole managed to hold his own with some important voter groups.
Independent voters and suburbanites, whom both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole courted assiduously, supported those candidates equally, according to a survey of voters leaving the polls conducted by the Associated Press and the television networks.
Voters who waited until the final hours to make up their minds gave their votes to Mr. Dole by 2 to 1. And Republicans stepped forward for their nominee more vigorously than earlier polls had suggested they would.
Mr. Dole, who is 73, said he was offering the nation a chance to return to the values of the World War II generation. But though he won his party's nomination this year, on his third try, he was unable to appeal to a wider audience in the general election, despite a series of self-consciously dramatic gestures.
In one of the most memorable moments, Mr. Dole resigned as Senate majority leader after three decades in Congress. He also put forth an ambitious 15 percent across-the-board tax-cut plan that went against decades of his own strong belief in deficit reduction. He picked Jack Kemp, with whom he has had strained relations, as his surprise choice for a running mate. And in the final weeks, after agonizing in public over whether he was risking his carefully nurtured reputation as a man of rectitude, he began slamming Mr. Clinton as unethical.
Indeed, the survey of voters leaving the polls showed that they were willing to set aside any concerns they had about Mr. Clinton's character in favor of their satisfaction with the humming economy -- and their general perception that the country was headed in the right direction.
Democrats hailed the outcome as a triumph for a politician who as recently as four years ago was still Governor of Arkansas.
After a hectic campaign schedule, Mr. Clinton arrived in Little Rock early yesterday morning, only to play hearts with Leon E. Panetta, his chief of staff, and Douglas Sosnik, the White House political director, until the sun rose. He voted just after midday at a renovated train station in his hometown.
Mr. Dole cast his paper ballot just after noon at his hometown of Russell, Kan., before flying to Washington on the last leg of his often sleepless 96-hour campaign marathon.
Even before Mr. Dole formally conceded, his aides and prominent Republicans were engaged in a round of soul-searching as well as searing port-mortems over some major decisions of the campaign, particularly the move to transform the final weeks of the race into essentially a battle for California.
In the wake of the 1994 midterm elections, expectations had been high for the campaign of 1996. Republicans lined up to take on a vulnerable-appearing Mr. Clinton. Many prominent politicians toyed with running as independents, only to back down in the end. And one of the most gripping stretches was in 1995, during Colin L. Powell's will-he-will-he-not process of mulling over a White House bid.
Still, throughout this year, the campaign often seemed more perfunctory than passionate, with the battle over the control of Congress offering the most suspense. The Presidential match-up was largely between two candidates who have long been well known to the American public. And no disruptive world or national events altered the contours of the race.
Mr. Clinton's lead over Mr. Dole in the polls never wavered from October 1995. It was around that time that Democrats succeeded in blaming Republicans for the budget standoff in Congress that led to the Government shutdown.
Nevertheless, Mr. Clinton's re-election was an impressive turnabout for the President. Only two years ago, he was faulted for the Republicans' takeover of the House and Senate, the first time in 40 years that the party gained control of Congress. And only a year ago, he was widely viewed by leading Republicans, and even many Democrats, as eminently beatable.
Mr. Clinton will now be a lame duck, the first Democrat to be subject to the ban on Presidents serving more than two full terms. Increasingly, the attention and speculation will shift to Mr. Gore, who delivered a long introduction of Mr. Clinton in Little Rock this morning and who has left no doubt of his intentions to seek the White House in 2000.
Yesterday's election may also have brought an end to the role of Mr. Perot as a major political player. By piling up more than 5 percent of the vote, Mr. Perot insured that his Reform Party will continue to get Federal financing for a run in 2000. Yet unlike four years ago, when Mr. Perot's message about eliminating the deficit and overhauling the campaign finance system altered the political dialogue, he did not loom large over the 1996 campaign.
This year, according to the survey of voters leaving the polls, voters who backed Mr. Perot in 1992 gave Mr. Dole nearly half their support, and split the rest between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Perot.
But in his concession speech, Mr. Perot vowed not to fade away, saying: "We're going to keep the pressure on the major issues. I think they've gotten the word on campaign finance reform, don't you? They've repented and been reborn."
Even after he glides to another term, the specter of scandal still looms over Mr. Clinton. More than half of the voters in the survey said Mr. Clinton was not honest or trustworthy. Seven in 10 of those voters backed Mr. Dole. Six in 10 voters said the President had not told them the truth about the Whitewater case.

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTION: NEW JERSEY -- 12th District;
Pappas Overcomes Del Vecchio Charges

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
In New Jersey's tightly contested 12th District, Mike Pappas, a Republican, defeated his Democratic opponent, David M. Del Vecchio, overcoming Mr. Del Vecchio's attempt to paint Mr. Pappas's opposition to abortion rights and gun control as too extreme.
With 100 percent of election districts reporting, the vote was:
 
Pappas 133,377 (50%)
 Del Vecchio 123,804 (47%)
Unlike many other Republican Congressional candidates, Mr. Pappas did not distance himself from Mr. Gingrich. Instead, during his campaign, he often praised Mr. Gingrich's Contract With America. 
 "The victory was hard fought from Day One," Mr. Pappas told his supporters. "We fought an opponent and at times we fought some in the media."
Throughout the race, Mr. Del Vecchio, 40, had portrayed his Republican opponent as far to the right of the moderate voters of the 12th District, which includes all of Hunterdon County and parts of Monmouth, Mercer and Middlesex counties.
Mr. Pappas, 35, defeated two more moderate Republicans in the June primary. He played down his views on social issues this fall and instead campaigned as a fiscal conservative who supported Bob Dole's proposed 15 percent tax cut.
Neither candidate was well known in the Republican 12th District, which has been represented by Mr. Zimmer since 1990.
Mr. Del Vecchio, the Mayor of Lambertville since 1991, is on leave from a job as senior executive for economic development in the State Treasury Department. He was an aide to former Gov. Jim Florio, which Mr. Pappas used in radio commercials to portray his opponent as "even more liberal than Bob Torricelli," alluding to television ads used by Mr. Zimmer to attack his opponent in the United States Senate race.
 MELODY PETERSEN

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE NATION -- THE GOVERNORS;
Democrats Make Inroads In Elections for Governor

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
As President Clinton won a second term tonight with surprising victories in former Republican strongholds like Florida and New Hampshire, Democratic candidates for governor also headed to victory in states well known for their Republican leanings.
In Indiana, which Mr. Clinton failed to win for the second time, voters kept the governor's office Democratic. Lieut. Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon narrowly defeated Stephen Goldsmith, the Mayor of Indianapolis, who was widely perceived as a rising star in the national Republican Party. 
 And in New Hampshire, where a Democrat has not served as governor in 16 years, Jean Shaheen, a longtime state legislator, defeated her Republican challenger, Ovide Lamontagne, the former head of the State Board of Education.
The Democrats had even more to celebrate last night as victories by four incumbent Governors -- Thomas R. Carper in Delaware, Mel Carnahan in Missouri, James B. Hunt Jr. in North Carolina and Howard Dean in Vermont -- gave them a majority of the 11 gubernatorial contests this year. In Washington, another Democratic candidate, Gary Locke, the King County executive, defeated his Republican challenger, State Senator Ellen Craswell, according to an Associated Press projection.
Cecil Underwood, a Republican who became the youngest governor of West Virginia when he was elected in 1956, became the oldest -- he turned 74 yesterday -- by defeating Charlotte Pritt, a coal miner's daughter, in a race to succeed West Virginia's Democratic Governor, Gaston Caperton.
After serving one term through 1960, Mr. Underwood spent the next 36 years as a coal industry executive, a college president and real estate developer.
The Republican incumbent in North Dakota, Edward T. Schafer, won by a wide margin over Lee Kaldor, a Democratic State Representative. The Republican incumbents in Montana, Marc Racicot, and in Utah, Michael O. Leavitt, were expected to win easily.
Indiana, where Gov. Evan Bayh was also barred by law from seeking a third consecutive term, has supported a Democrat for President only four times this century and not since Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964.
But Mr. O'Bannon said the voters were impressed by the eight-year record of Mr. Bayh, who has taken credit for 350,000 new jobs in his two terms, a 30 percent drop in the number of welfare recipients in the last two years and a budget surplus of $1.67 billion last fiscal year.
"This is a positive message, saying we have built a strong foundation over the last eight years," Mr. O'Bannon said in an interview, adding that his victory reflects "a strong combined well-put-together plan" by state Democrats to make gains at all levels in a conservative state.
It was a stinging defeat for Mr. Goldsmith, who won national attention for efforts to privatize city agencies and held a steady lead in statewide polls through the summer. But then a series of problems, including a police scandal that led to the resignation of the Indianapolis police chief, gave Mr. O'Bannon an opening, and by last weekend, Mr. O'Bannon appeared to move into a safe lead.
Mr. Goldsmith also ruffled a few Republican feathers when he blamed Bob Dole for his fall in the polls.
A big embarrassment for Mr. Goldsmith was failing to carry Marion County, which includes Indianapolis.
In New Hampshire, Ms. Shaheen, 49, a three-term State Senator who appeared to benefit from a succession of visits by Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, became the state's first female governor. The only woman serving as a state's chief executive is Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, who was elected in 1993.
Yet, Ms. Shaheen fought through a strong tradition of male and Republican domination in New Hampshire by campaigning on popular themes of improvements in health care, schools and employment while she pledged not to raise taxes or impose new ones.
She also won wide support among women for her position favoring abortion rights and initiatives she helped push through the State Legislature, including measures that provide portability for health insurance and require health insurance companies to cover people with pre-existing conditions.
The victories by Mr. Carper in Delaware, Mr. Carnahan in Missouri, Mr. Hunt in North Carolina and Mr. Dean in Vermont were wholly expected, and those by Mr. Carper and Mr. Carnahan kept two other women from moving into governor's mansions. Mr. Carper defeated Delaware's treasurer, Janet Rzewinicki, and Mr. Carnahan prevailed over Margaret Kelly, the state auditor.
Mr. Hunt, who also served as governor from 1976 to 1984, beat the majority whip in the State House of Representatives, Robin Hayes, and Mr. Dean, who helped engineer Vermont's escape from economic recession, easily defeated John Gropper, a Republican consultant.
