HEADLINE: Wall Street Votes: Dow Soars 96.53

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Investors and voters seem to agree: They want more of the same.
The Dow Jones industrial average soared 96.53 points, to 6,177.71 yesterday, setting a closing high for the first time since Oct. 18, as Wall Street showed it thinks a renewal of the political status quo was the best possible election outcome. 
 The bond market did not join in the celebration, with sentiment there weighed down by a lack of enthusiastic buyers for a new 10-year Treasury bond issue.
But in the stock market, the 24 hours after the elections witnessed a number of trading stretches -- the first just as the Congressional election returns became clear -- in which prices spurted upward.
"Wall Street loves it," said David Shulman, the chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, speaking of the election results.
The stock market had concluded some time ago that it liked a divided Government, with a Democratic President and the Republican Congress able to block extreme measures from each other.
"It's hard to believe that Wall Street would applaud so loudly for continued gridlock," said Hugh Johnson, the chief investment officer at First Albany. But that, he said, is what it is doing.
In recent weeks, it had been taken for granted that President Clinton would win re-election, but there was some concern that the Democrats might be able to regain control of the House of Representatives, and perhaps even the Senate. That had led to some money managers selling stock index futures, a tactic that would have protected them in the event of a market decline.
Instead, with the Republicans keeping control of Congress, those money managers have had to buy back the stock index futures -- buying that has helped push share prices higher in recent days.
Stock index futures, unlike the stock market itself, now trade almost around the clock, and futures on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index began to rise sharply just after 9 P.M. on Tuesday, as the Republicans voiced confidence that they would hold on to Capitol Hill.
Prices settled back early in the morning -- a time dominated by Japanese traders -- then began rising again after the stock market opened in New York yesterday morning. The rally calmed down late in the morning, but then surged again in the afternoon.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also set a closing high yesterday, gaining 10.45 points, to 724.59. The Nasdaq composite gained 16.42 points, to 1,245.49, though it remains below the high it established last month.
Some of the strongest stocks were viewed as beneficiaries of election results directly or of the checks maintained on Democratic power. For instance, tobacco stocks rallied, with Philip Morris up 3 7/8 a share, to 97 3/8. Health maintenance organizations, which survived hostile ballot propositions in California, also did well. United Healthcare added 3, to 40 1/8, and Oxford Health was up 4 5/8, to 51 1/2.
It is no wonder that investors might like the idea of a Democratic President and a Republican Congress. The last two years have been among the best ever on Wall Street. Measured from Election Day 1994 to Election Day 1996, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 58.7 percent, making it the third-best two-year period since the Dow was reformulated during World War I.
Bears -- there are still some -- may take pleasure from what has happened following the three other Congresses that saw moves of 50 percent or better in the Dow. Those were in 1926-28, 1934-36, and 1984-86. In each case, the market suffered a substantial setback during the next term.
Many on Wall Street believe that the standoff for control of the Government will mean continued progress on reducing the budget deficit, though some worry that progress itself might prove to be a problem should the economy slow and require some fiscal stimulus.
And there is some optimistic talk that the two political parties will be able to find common ground on reining in expensive entitlement programs -- this despite the fact that many Democrats ran on a platform of denouncing Republican efforts to do just that.
Economically sensitive stocks, which do the best when the economy is growing strongly, have generally lagged in the current rally, a sign that investors do not expect much stimulus for the economy. One such stock, that of General Motors, was down fractionally yesterday, while consumer goods companies, which suffer less in a weak economy, did well. Procter & Gamble rose 3 1/8 a share, to 105 1/8.
While the stock market was zooming, many other financial markets showed little if any change. The bond market, which had been rallying in recent weeks, showed small price declines, with the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, which moves in the opposite direction to its price, rising three-hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.61 percent.
The dollar was marginally lower, though the moves seemed to have more to do with overseas events than with reaction to the elections. And gold prices, which have been edging down amid a total lack of concern over inflation, continued to do so. Gold for December delivery fell 90 cents, to $378.70 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Ruling

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the ruling yesterday by Judge Denise Cote of Federal District Court in Manhattan barring the Giuliani administration from forcing Time Warner to add the Fox News Channel to its cable system.
I find that the evidence at the hearing establishes the following, when taken as a whole. In response to learning that it had not won the bidding battle with MSNBC, Fox used its direct access to the Mayor to seek the city's assistance. The city, in a strategy developed and executed by the Mayor's senior staff, then undertook to convince and, if necessary, force Time Warner to place Fox News on one of Time Warner's commercial channels. Fox and the city understood and agreed that Fox News could not run on television for any significant length of time without commercials, and, therefore, it was essential that Time Warner be convinced to place Fox News on a commercial channel. . . . 
 With respect to the city's purported desire to increase the diversity of news programs available to New Yorkers, it must be observed as an initial matter that it is not self-evident that this is in fact a constitutionally permissible purpose when the city has favored specific speakers in pursuit of this goal. . . .
The conclusion is inescapable that the city's intonation of the rubric "diversity" is a thinly disguised reference to its preference for the editorial content of Fox News. As such, this rationale for the city's actions cannot constitute a permissible purpose for its actions. The city's second justification fares no better. While the economic health of a city and the preservation and creation of jobs is an appropriate and essential concern of city government, the record here does not indicate that this concern was other than pretextual in the context of this dispute. . . .
The city's actions create a chilling effect under which Time Warner will feel pressure to capitulate to city requests that it accommodate a New York City commercial programmer who has direct access to City Hall. In such cases, if Time Warner refuses the city's requests, then the city can simply turn Crosswalks into a competing commercial system of channels. . . .
The city's purpose in acting to compel Time Warner to give Fox one of its commercial channels was to reward a friend and to further a particular viewpoint. As a consequence, Fox was the recipient of special advocacy. The very fact that the city chose Fox News out of all other news programs -- not to mention the significant number of other programs which have been denied space on Time Warner's commercial network -- is by itself substantial evidence that the city chose Fox News based on its content. . . .
The city has engaged in a pattern of conduct with the purpose of compelling Time Warner to alter its constitutionally protected editorial decision not to carry Fox News. The city's actions violated longstanding First Amendment principles that are the foundation of our democracy. . . .

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE REGION -- THE VOTERS;
Fear of G.O.P. Cuts Emerges In Clinton's Northeast Sweep

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
New York State barely saw Bill Clinton during the campaign, and its economy remains sluggish. Yet the President's overall victory in the popular vote on Tuesday stemmed in large part from substantial margins from New York and surrounding states, support that both Democrats and Republicans said demonstrated clear regional support for the government programs Mr. Clinton vowed to preserve.
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut combined to produce nearly one-third of President Clinton's 7.6-million-vote margin of victory. Add Massachusetts and Rhode Island to the mix and the percentage of his margin goes up to 44. 
 In New York State, it appeared Bob Dole was able to win only 11 counties, compared with the 33 taken by George Bush in 1992. (Several counties were still too close to call.) Areas around New York City where Mr. Bush did well four years ago, like Orange and Suffolk Counties, moved solidly into the Democratic column this year.
Mr. Clinton took 57 percent of the three states' vote -- 59 percent in New York, 53 percent in New Jersey and 52 percent in Connecticut. The regional sweep was galling to local Republican leaders, who watched helplessly as the Dole-Kemp campaign wrote off the area in favor of the South and West.
"We've got a problem on our hands," said Guy V. Molinari, the Borough President of Staten Island, who was the city chairman of the Dole campaign. "Our party is in bad shape in this area of the country, and we're going to have to deal with it. I can't fault them for not campaigning here, but it had a big impact. I had people calling and asking for bumper stickers, and there were none to be had."
Mr. Molinari agreed with his Democratic counterparts that the Northeast remained so much more reliant on the kinds of government programs that Republicans had tried to cut that the outcome was not surprising after the party's takeover of Congress in 1994.
Bill Lynch, the New York City Democratic strategist who assembled the coalition that elected Mayor David N. Dinkins in 1989, said the President was able to rely on an ingredient more potent than even the economy: fear.
"It was fear of the Republican agenda, pure and simple," Mr. Lynch said. "People in the Northeast felt that the Republicans went too far with their contract, on issues like Medicaid and school aid. Those are the issues that really resonate around here."
Exit polls taken around the country on Tuesday showed a striking difference between New Yorkers and residents of other states in their views of whether government should be doing more or less to solve problems. Half the New Yorkers surveyed said the notion that government should be doing more was closer to their view. By contrast, only 40 percent of those in Florida felt that way, 38 percent in Ohio, 37 percent in California and 31 percent in Texas.
Republican setbacks in the region were not limited to the Presidential race. Of the handful of House seats picked up by Democrats, one each came from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island. In the New York State Assembly -- where in 1994 Republicans, fresh from their victory over Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, vowed to take 20 seats -- the party actually lost a seat on Tuesday. Party leaders said they were lucky the defeat wasn't worse.
"It was a great night for us being able to hold on to what we had, in light of the Dole campaign not campaigning in this state," said Thomas M. Reynolds, the Assembly minority leader, from western New York. "I think we overcame great odds in light of the whole climate out there."
Mr. Dole found himself unable to reach many of the demographic and ideological groups that might have formed the base of his support, exit polls showed. In fact, name the demographic group in New York State, and Mr. Clinton won it on Tuesday: all races, all religions, all income groups, all ages, all educational levels, both sexes. Only in certain demographic subgroups, like white non-Catholic Christians, did Mr. Dole win small pluralities.
A majority of independent voters in New York State supported Mr. Clinton, who also picked up 18 percent of voters who said they voted for George Bush in 1992, and 23 percent of the 1992 vote for Ross Perot. (Mr. Perot only won 34 percent of those who voted for him in 1992, exit polls indicated; 40 percent of those voters went for Mr. Dole this time.) The President also won 29 percent of those voters who consider themselves conservative.
Mr. Clinton got more than three-fourths of the vote in New York City, where his margin was 28 percent greater than it was four years ago. In several Assembly districts dominated by black voters, Mr. Dole barely appeared to be on the ballot. In the 55th District, in Brownsville, Brooklyn, Mr. Dole received only 324 votes, compared with 23,084 for Mr. Clinton. In the 70th District, in Harlem, Mr. Dole received 684 votes, and Mr. Clinton got 30,819.
But the decisive turnaround came in the suburbs -- the swing voters of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties -- where Mr. Clinton's margin over the Republican was more than five times greater than in 1992.
In the previous election, Mr. Clinton got 44 percent of the vote in those four counties, and Mr. Bush 41 percent. This year, Mr. Clinton got 54 percent, and Mr. Dole 37 percent, with many of the President's votes coming from former Perot supporters. In Suffolk County, for example, Mr. Clinton lost to Mr. Bush by 9,000 votes four years ago, but beat Mr. Dole by 70,000 votes.
A similar turnaround could also be seen in other suburban areas, including northern New Jersey. For instance, Mr. Clinton lost Passaic County in 1992 by 1,000 votes, but won it this time by 31,000 votes.
"Mr. Dole's natural appeal has never been an urban Republican appeal," said Prof. Michael J. Malbin, director of the Center for Legislative Studies at the Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany. "He wasn't able to get the Northeast Catholic swing voter, and even Republicans in the Northeast didn't want a revolution that would challenge the New Deal. When the issue became framed as whether the government is your enemy, a lot of swing voters around here said, 'This is where I'm getting off.' "
A symbol of these ambivalent swing voters, of course, is Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican Mayor of a Democratic city. Almost every Republican candidate he endorsed in Tuesday's election lost, including two from out of state.
The Mayor had to vote for Bob Dole to avoid the outrage of his party, but his heart was clearly never in it, and he waited until the last possible moment to essentially endorse Mr. Dole's running mate, Jack F. Kemp. After the results were in, Mr. Giuliani immediately began saying that they were inevitable and that the country was in good hands.
"I don't think tonight's result is tragic, I guess because I'm not that partisan a person," he said Tuesday night. "I think President Clinton is a good man, he's a very decent man, and the country has run pretty well."
The Mayor added yesterday that he believed the city would be unaffected by the outcome.
One local official who was affected by the outcome was Representative Charles B. Rangel Democrat of Manhattan. He would have become chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee if the Republicans had not kept their majority in the House.
"It hasn't caused me any concern, and I'll explain all that in my suicide note," Mr. Rangel joked yesterday. He added that the overall effect on the city would be determined by the ideological path to be chosen by the President, a decision he said he could not predict.

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE -- BALLOT QUESTION;
Riding the Bond Act Victory, Pataki Tries to Widen His Appeal

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
With the passage of the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act, voters have given Gov. George E. Pataki the opportunity to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on three politically crucial areas -- urban renewal, job creation and the environment -- with just a year to go before the 1998 gubernatorial campaign begins.
For most of the two years that he has been in office, Mr. Pataki has been largely defined by a sparely conservative agenda to cut taxes and spending, reimpose the death penalty and trim welfare rolls. 
 But with the passage on Tuesday of the $1.75 billion bond act, which Mr. Pataki proposed and guided through the Legislature, he has in one bold stroke brought an expansive spirit to a state government he had pledged to shrink.
With money borrowed through the sale of long-term bonds, the administration will be able to finance cleaning up scores of abandoned industrial sites in urban areas, replacing hundreds of coal-burning furnaces in city schools, closing landfills including Fresh Kills in Staten Island and building sewage treatment plants in rural villages and suburban towns. In the process, it will pump hundreds of millions of dollars into the state's economy and create as many as 60,000 jobs.
For Mr. Pataki, the promise of those programs has helped him broaden his political base beyond fiscally conservative suburban and rural voters, whose overwhelming support catapulted him to victory in 1994, to include more city dwellers, union members and moderate Democrats.
Indeed, exit polls on Tuesday as well as two recent statewide public opinion polls have indicated that the bond act campaign has helped lift Mr. Pataki's approval rating above 50 percent for the first time in his term. The polls have also shown that Mr. Pataki's support in New York City, where he received only 28 percent of the vote in 1994, has been steadily climbing.
"The net result is, it is a political plus for the Governor," said State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who campaigned for the bond act. Mr. McCall, a Democrat, is viewed as a likely challenger to Mr. Pataki in 1998.
The Governor also used the bond act campaign to claim the mantle of Teddy Roosevelt-style progressivism. For Mr. Pataki, invoking Mr. Roosevelt's image does more than recall New York's proud history. It gives the Governor a means to distance himself from United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who is Mr. Pataki's mentor but who polls show to be deeply unpopular. Through the bond act, Mr. Pataki is able to define himself as an independent and to appeal to centrist voters.
And it does all those things just as the Governor is preparing to release a tough new welfare policy and a spare new budget -- plans that are likely to draw charges of mean-spiritedness from Democrats. The bond act victory may blunt those charges in the minds of many moderates.
Looking haggard but happy at a news conference this morning, Mr. Pataki recalled Mr. Roosevelt once again, saying, "New York State now is positioned again to lead the nation in environmental issues as we approach the next century, just as at the turn of the century we led the nation in environmental issues with Teddy Roosevelt leading the state."
With 98 percent of precincts reporting this afternoon, voters had approved the proposition by 2 million to 1.6 million, or 56 percent to 44 percent. City voters supported it by a 3-to-1 margin and suburban voters supported it by a 2-to-1 margin, but voters upstate rejected it by a 3-to-2 margin.
The poor showing of the bond act in the state's northern, central and western reaches raises questions about whether Mr. Pataki has hurt himself in his base of support among fiscally conservative voters, who have been the driving force behind his efforts to cut state taxes and spending.
Indeed, members of one of the state's most prominent anti-tax groups, Change-N.Y., spent about $800,000 on an advertising campaign attacking the bond act as frivolous and politically motivated. Many of those same people have been contributors to Mr. Pataki, prompting the Governor's aides to lament that the anti-tax group had undermined its conservative cause by criticizing the Governor so harshly.
But Thomas Carroll, Change-N.Y.'s president, said he thought conservative voters would soon forgive Mr. Pataki's bond act, which he described as a "grab for downstate, liberal, Democratic voters."
Mr. Carroll said that once the Governor releases his welfare plan, which is expected to include sharp new restrictions on benefits, he would once again win favor among conservatives. "He has a strong record on taxes and crime," Mr. Carroll said. "It's not a life or death thing."
Many Democrats who supported the bond act have quietly fretted that its passage will now give Mr. Pataki the opportunity to travel about the state, disbursing millions of dollars on popular programs and talking about policies he has not often talked about before, like urban renewal.
During the bond act campaign, Mr. Pataki often used empty, forlorn-looking downtown factories as backdrops to promote the "brown-field" programs in the proposition. Under that program, municipalities will receive grants to clean up abandoned industrial sites with the goal of using them for manufacturing again.
At just such a site along the Mohawk River last week, Mr. Pataki told two Democratic mayors that "unless cities like Troy, Albany and Schenectady do well, we're all in trouble."
Democrats say that the bond act money could not have come at a more opportune time for Mr. Pataki, since the Legislature may have to cut spending in other areas to balance next year's budget. "It's great governmentally for him," said Hank Morris, a Democratic political consultant. "It gets him out of his budget mess."

HEADLINE: What's 4-H Without Competition for Blue Ribbons? Extremely Stormy

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: LE MARS, Iowa, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Kari A. Beitelspacher has been bringing home blue ribbons for years from 4-H club competitions at the state fair in Des Moines. But this year, even her well-received homemade salsa did not win first place.
The 16-year-old was disappointed, but then so were thousands of other children who belong to 4-H, a rite of passage in rural America. In an experiment this year, 4-H gave 3,500 Iowa State Fair competitors the same multicolored ribbons recognizing participation, rather than awarding the traditional first, second and third place ribbons. 
 From small cities like this one to the state capitol, the reaction has been nearly hysterical. While the children were unhappy with the new ribbons, the grown-ups were really riled up.
One critic successfully introduced a plank in the state's Republican Party platform assailing "the encroachment of socialism" in 4-H. The Des Moines Register carried articles about the controversy on its front page, prompting a slew of letters to the editor.
Here in the heartland, where radio stations list corn prices as often as urban radio stations report rush-hour traffic tie-ups, the changes in 4-H, which stands for head, heart, hands and health, seemed to many to challenge not just a cherished program, but also a way of life.
Linda K. Mohning, a former 4-H leader, said, "To us, 4-H has been a microcosm of traditional American life and values, values that have worked for 200 years."
Mrs. Mohning, author of the Republican plank on socialism, said, "Free enterprise is a bedrock value of America and we would be concerned about any move to stray from that." She and her husband grow corn and beans and raise hogs and cattle on their farm near Remsen, a small town in northwestern Iowa.
Some opponents of the move even said it would undermine the work ethic and make it harder for children to learn how to prosper in today's global economy.
"This is a competitive world," said Evan Rayl, who breeds Angus cattle at his farm in Bridgewater, in southwestern Iowa. "How in the world is a 4-H leader supposed to explain to an 18-year-old why we didn't all get the job?"
He fondly recalled the 4-H motto he had learned as a boy: "to win without bragging and to lose without squealing."
Faced with such an uproar, Iowa 4-H leaders have been quick to beat a retreat. They have declared the ribbon experiment over, and at next summer's state fair they plan to award blue, red and white ribbons for first, second and third place finishers.
"The whole issue surrounding whether 4-H is socialist is a ridiculous discussion," said Joseph R. Kurth, the state 4-H director. "There is certainly no basis in truth for that."
The multicolored ribbons were one part of a pilot project that affected all nonlivestock contests at the state fair in August, he said. Children displaying projects in woodworking, food, clothing and other events liked other parts of the experiment, like one-on-one discussions with judges, and those will be continued, Mr. Kurth said.
Many 4-H leaders agree that the 4-H flap is overblown. "I don't know what has really got people so stirred up," said Chris D. Gleason, a longtime 4-H leader who raises sheep in Greenfield, a town about an hour's drive southwest of Des Moines. "Maybe it is because they do see such value in 4-H."
But here in Le Mars, a city of about 10,000 near Sioux City, where Iowa meets up with Nebraska and South Dakota, 4-H club members were simply glad to have the chance next year to win a blue ribbon again.
"I like the blue ribbons better personally because then you know how you rank among the other 4-H'ers in the state," said Kelsea A. Jacobson, 17, who has won all blue ribbons at state fairs in past years. Her multicolored ribbon this year rewarded the prom for elderly neighbors that she and several friends organized.
Three of Ms. Beitelspacher's projects won local and county prizes to qualify for the state fair this year -- the salsa, a display promoting the benefits of calcium, and a scrapbook describing her family's nearly five-decade heritage with 4-H membership.
"It was kind of disappointing to say you'd gotten all the way to state fair and then everybody received the same ribbon," she said.
Critics said they object to more than just the new kind of ribbons handed out at the fair this summer. "The ribbon thing was just kind of the tip of the iceberg of this liberal agenda," Mr. Rayl said. He objected after 4-H began requiring last year that all new leaders agree to a criminal background check and a check for drunken driving violations.
"The trouble is, they'll do all this checking and they won't discover a one -- there are legions of uncaught out there," Mr. Rayl said. Because parents know the leaders have been screened, they will have a false sense of security, he said.
Mr. Rayl said he worried the requirement might drive away good 4-H leaders. "How much fun is it to have a rap sheet be run on you -- even if you're spotless -- to do a volunteer job?"
Mr. Kurth, the Iowa 4-H leader, said the new requirements were similar to those found in most other states and those used by other youth organizations like the Boy Scouts. They are designed to deter criminals by making them think twice about signing up as volunteers, he said.
"You just can't do a youth program in the 90's without some kind of protections" for the safety of children, Mr. Kurth said.
The 4-H organization also drew criticism when it asked all local leaders to agree to uphold 4-H's mission, vision and values by signing a form that described them. It outlined goals like teaching children citizenship, leadership and a positive self-concept, and described values including favoring volunteerism, diversity and prevention programs.
Mrs. Mohning balked at signing the form because she believes it is wrong for the government "to designate a required set of values that everyone has to agree to." She said she was dismissed from her volunteer post as a 4-H leader for refusing. "It was a tough decision because we have been involved in 4-H for a long time," she said.
But Mr. Kurth said she misunderstood the intent of the values statement. "There may be a fear that these values replace local values -- that is certainly not the case."
The Republican Party platform also reflected Mrs. Mohning's objection to a discussion at a 1993 conference attended by hundreds of Iowa's high-school-age 4-H members. One of many topics was tolerance for homosexuals. Mrs. Mohning said that was not the usual bill of fare. "Usually it deals with hog diseases and horticulture, but this time it dealt with homosexuality," she said.
Her plank in the Republican platform reads, "We protest the teaching to 4-H'ers that homosexuality is an acceptable alternative lifestyle and we oppose the encroachment of socialism in 4-H competition at fairs."
Brian M. Kennedy, chairman of the Iowa Republican Party, hastens to point out that "this was just one little plank in a lengthy platform," and said that he did not know of the plank until after the state convention in June. "Every year there is one or two like this in each party's platform," Mr. Kennedy said.
Some Iowa 4-H leaders praised the group's efforts to modernize. "It has to stay up with the times," Mrs. Gleason said. "We live in a very diverse society and rural Iowa is going to have to admit it," she said. "Our kids are not going to be staying down on the farm anymore."
Indeed, the changes in 4-H may have come under attack precisely because membership has been such a mainstay of growing up here.
"There is a whole lot of change going on in society today," Mr. Kurth said. "People want to find things they can count on that are stable, and the 4-H program is one of those things."

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- THE STRATEGY;
Stung by Defeats in '94, Clinton Regrouped and Co-opted G.O.P. Strategies

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
As he struggled to come to terms with the 1994 Republican sweep of Congress, President Clinton made one point to anyone who would listen: he had lost the fight to overhaul health care, the centerpiece of his agenda, because his opponents went on television and defined his program.
He would never let it happen again. 
 And so, as the battle over the Republicans' sweeping plans to shrink the Federal budget was about to be joined in August 1995, the President's political consultants were ready. They had cut two 30-second commercials that accused the Republicans of seeking to cut Medicare.
Expecting an instant Republican counter commercial, the consultants had an emergency drill in place to respond quickly once the air war began.
Dick Morris, the President's chief strategist, would reach out to Mr. Clinton, at any time, anywhere, to approve a new script. Robert Squier and Bill Knapp would produce the spot. Mark Penn and Douglas Schoen, the pollsters, would rush it out for their signature "mall testing," in which shoppers view and judge an advertisement. If all tested well, they would be back on television fast.
They waited. And waited. And waited. "Every week that went by, we'd look at each other blankly," Mr. Knapp recalled.
In the end, the Republicans did not go on the air at all, even as the Democrats kept up a more than $1 million-a-week advertising campaign throughout the fall. In effect, the anxious President had planned and won the first skirmish of his re-election drive with the opposition never firing a shot.
Certainly Presidential campaigns have many turning points. Ruminating on Air Force One today, his arm draped across the shoulder of his adviser, George R. Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton traced the beginnings of his extraordinary political comeback to the bombing of the Federal building in Oklahoma City in 1995, which he said had caused Americans to "move back to the vital center."
He said the policies enacted in his first two years in office, like his deficit reduction plan and his anti-crime legislation, had come to be appreciated only in 1996. And he cited his ability to work with Congress at the end of this legislative session as "the thing that sealed all this."
But it is also the case that the television blitz of 1995 and the unused emergency drill foretold much about Mr. Clinton's re-election. For the contours of this Presidential race were largely set in 1995 when Mr. Clinton rediscovered his voice, found his target audience and forged his main campaign appeal from out of the budget battle. He co-opted the Republican idea of a balanced budget and then turned the debate to how to balance it -- focusing on Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment, areas where the voters favor Democrats.
Moreover, the Republicans made many mistakes: their failure to go on television; their political misjudgment in forcing two Government shutdowns; the missteps of a single day in October when Bob Dole told one audience that he had voted against Medicare at its inception and Speaker Newt Gingrich told another audience that he expected to see the agency that administers Medicare, "wither on the vine."
To the very last hours of his last campaign day, Mr. Clinton was running as much against the Republican Congress as he was against Mr. Dole.
"The Republicans have given us great gifts," the White House political director, Douglas Sosnik mused one day last spring. "Whether it's shutting down the Government or the revolutionary rhetoric of Newt Gingrich or Bob Dole's inability to articulate a message, they all compound to create a much more favorable environment for Bill Clinton."
Still, it was only in retrospect that Mr. Clinton's advisers called the Republican rout of 1994 a blessing in disguise, only later that they would say that it shocked the President into discipline and helped him return to the "New Democrat" roots that had seemed to disappear in his first two years in office.
In the days after the Republicans took control of both houses of Congress, Mr. Clinton was frustrated, raging, and depressed. "I want my Presidency back," he said, according to a high-ranking aide who recalled the plaintive mood.
The immediate task facing Mr. Clinton's political team was to ward off the kind of divisive primary that had helped defeat Jimmy Carter in 1980 and forced Lyndon B. Johnson into retirement in 1968. Despite fears about how they would do, Mr. Clinton's aides decided to begin fund-raising earlier than any President had before. In part, the effort was designed to scare anyone else out of running. In part it was to have a war chest if an opponent materialized.
Mr. Clinton, meanwhile, was struggling to regain his voice. In the aftermath of the 1994 defeat, he had fired most of the strategists who had staffed his fabled War Room of 1992. In their place, he turned secretly to Mr. Morris, who had known him for nearly two decades and rescued him from his defeat as Arkansas governor.
Mr. Morris had long since become a Republican, working for candidates who made him anathema to many on Mr. Clinton's staff. But he had a knack for listening to Bill Clinton. He could finish his sentences and take the scattered shards of his ideas and build them into a campaign mosaic.
He and the team of pollsters and strategists he brought in with him created a counterbalance to Mr. Clinton's more liberal advisers, led by senior adviser, George R. Stephanopoulos and the deputy White House chief of staff, Harold M. Ickes. And Mr. Clinton would navigate between the two feuding groups, sometimes siding with one, sometimes with the other, to create his own synthesis.
Still, Mr. Clinton could not immediately regain his bearings. At a prime-time news conference in April, he was reduced to insisting that he was still relevant in the face of the Republican juggernaut.
His salvation came in tragedy. The bombing of the Federal building in Oklahoma City caused the stricken nation to focus on the President with an intensity it had drifted away from in the aftermath of the cold war. Mr. Clinton rose to the moment, firm in his vow to fight terrorists, comforting in his turn to liturgy.
One aide close to Mr. Clinton called the speech given by the President "perhaps the single most important turning point," in restoring the President's voice and sense of purpose. On Air Force One today, returning to Washington from Arkansas, Mr. Clinton, too, called the bombing a turning point but said it was because it changed the public mood. "The American people sort of began to move back to the vital center after Oklahoma City," he said. Recalling the "bitter, bitter rhetoric" of the time, he said the bombing "broke the spell in the country as people began searching for the common ground again."
The next pivot point was Mr. Clinton's decision to embrace the Republican goal of balancing the budget. Virtually his entire White House staff opposed it, afraid the President would take the spotlight off the Republican program cuts and keep the Democrats from running as the defenders of Medicare, Federal health insurance for the elderly.
But Mr. Morris and Mr. Schoen, one of the pollsters he had brought with him, had an eye on Perot voters and suburban independents. They advised Mr. Clinton that he had to embrace fiscal conservatism to become relevant to those voters. The President heeded them and announced his conversion on national television. The speech enraged liberal Democrats, but it shifted the debate from whether to balance the budget to how to balance the budget.
Over the summer Mr. Clinton similarly used a series of speeches to diffuse social issues. He opposed a constitutional amendment on school prayer but said religious expression was allowed in schools. He joined the crusade against media violence. He defended affirmative action, but said that overt quota programs should be eliminated.
"He was saying yes and saying no at the same time," said Mr. Stephanopoulos. "He was stealing the center, creating the center."
 
Deciphering The Electorate
By the end of the summer, Mr. Clinton had put much of his campaign framework in place.
His strategists, particularly the pollster Mr. Penn, had looked closer at the voting public and discovered a sharp divide between single people and married couples with children, who had a more negative view of Mr. Clinton. The campaign's target group became the great American middle, but unusually defined: middle-aged parents with children.
Some of Mr. Clinton's White House aides argued that he should wage a populist campaign on pocketbook issues as he did in 1992. But his new crop of consultants said this was not suitable for an incumbent who had to run on his record. They also contended that it would be counterproductive. "When you divide rich and poor, the middle class sides with the rich," said Mr. Schoen.
Instead, Mr. Clinton chose to reach out to his target voters by stressing values. This did not mean that the President would not talk about pocketbook matters, like Republican plans to slow the growth of Medicare. But he would not speak about them in specifically economic terms.
And so one of his first Medicare advertisements proclaimed that Mr. Clinton "is right to protect Medicare, right to defend our decision as a nation, to do what's moral, good and right by the elderly."
By October, the President's campaign against the Republicans was having its effect. Mr. Clinton's approval ratings were creeping up. The Republican Congress was dropping in voter esteem. But the question in the White House was how long to keep up the fight.
Mr. Morris insisted that Mr. Clinton needed to clinch a budget deal to be viewed as an effective leader. Mr. Ickes, Mr. Stephanopoulos and Congressional Democrats opposed a deal, afraid it would nullify the contrast between Republicans and Democrats.
Mr. Clinton, in the end, could not swallow Republican proposals to put Medicaid -- the Federal health insurance for the poor -- under the control of the states, and he fought on.
He had laid his groundwork well, his advertisements driving home the theme that he was the moderate, protecting programs that Americans valued from extremists. The Government shutdowns cemented that view and many of Mr. Clinton's strategists believe the shutdowns won Mr. Clinton re-election. "The budget fight was a turning point," Mr. Clinton said today.
Mr. Clinton was helped further by his announcement that he was sending troops to Bosnia. The very unpopularity of the move undercut the image of him as a waffler, created in his first two years as President.
December brought another victory. On the day that Hillary Rodham Clinton showed up in New Hampshire to register her husband as an official candidate in the nation's first primary, she was the lone Democrat to make the pilgrimage. Mr. Clinton, through prodigious fund raising and behind-the-scenes courting of the party base, had escaped a primary challenge.
 
Small Government, Small Ideas
There are moments in politics when the public will give someone a second look. Mr. Clinton's moment came in January 1996 and he was ready for it -- unveiling a new line of argument in his State of the Union Message that cemented the gains he had won in the budget fight.
What attracted attention in Washington was Mr. Clinton's pronouncement that the "era of big government is over" -- his official divorce from Democratic orthodoxy. But what truly distinguished the speech was its focus on small initiatives that would soothe the anxieties of Mr. Clinton's target voter group.
Some of these proposals were economic, such as a tax break for college tuition. Some were sheer exhortation, such as the President's endorsement of school uniforms. Some went to the heart of people's fears of crime, such as a promise to battle youth gangs.
Mr. Morris told colleagues that this was a "new dialogue" in American politics. It seemed unpresidential after the dramatic concerns of the cold war. But it marked the realization -- attuned to the aging Baby Boom generation -- that, as one White House aide put it "the personal is political." What concerned voters most was their marriage, their children, their neighborhood.
These issues particularly resonated with women. But the President also had an argument for men: the economy. The 1993 deficit reduction package, particularly its tax increases, had helped brand Mr. Clinton as a liberal. But it also brought an economic dividend. Mr. Clinton could point to more than 10 million new jobs and a drop in the deficit for four years in a row. "Historians will say that this Administration had the most serious attempt to put together a comprehensive economic policy of any administration in 60 years," Mr. Clinton said today.
In an odd way, by the time Mr. Dole had triumphed in the primaries to become the Republican standard bearer, the Presidential race was over. Mr. Clinton's approval ratings suggested that a majority of the public had swung to Mr. Clinton's side. And nothing that Mr. Dole tried served to shake loose enough independent voters.
"There was never anything from the day that Bob Dole wrapped up the nomination to Election Day that fundamentally altered either the nature or the dialogue of the race," said Joe Lockhart, a Clinton aide.
When Mr. Dole, strapped of cash, sought to use his post as Senate majority leader to showcase his leadership, Mr. Clinton's strategists worked with Congressional Democrats to tie him in knots.
Convictions in the Whitewater trial of Mr. Clinton's former business partners and the discovery that a White House aide had requested hundreds of F.B.I. files of former White House officials gave Mr. Dole an opening to revive questions about Mr. Clinton's character and ethics. But the Clinton camp had a counter argument. In essence they redefined character around public, not private, behavior. Character, they said, was taking on the National Rifle Association or the tobacco industry.
"I think that you can demonstrate character most effectively by what you fight for and for whom you fight," Mr. Clinton told a television interviewer. "And I believe that the fact that I've stood up for the American people for the things like fighting for the family-leave law or the assault-weapons ban or the Brady bill or the V-chip for parents or trying to keep tobacco out of the hands of kids."
 
Metaphors: The Future and Past
Even when Mr. Morris himself revived questions about Mr. Clinton by having to resign because of a report he had been having an affair with a prostitute, Mr. Clinton's approval ratings did not drop.
Nor did Mr. Dole's pledge of a sweeping 15 percent tax reduction work. Mr. Clinton's aides said their polls showed the American public had become suspicious of any big promise, whether of a health care overhaul or a dramatic tax cut.
And even Mr. Dole's carefully choreographed, nearly flawless national convention did not give him a lasting increase in support.
But it did give Mr. Clinton a great gift -- the metaphor on which he ended his campaign. For half a year, an unstated theme of the Clinton campaign had been the age difference between the 73-year-old Mr. Dole and the 50-year-old Mr. Clinton. It was touched on obliquely when Mr. Clinton surrounded himself with college students at his campaign rallies, when he talked of education, the Internet, and family concerns.
But the Clinton campaign made the contrast much more explicit when Mr. Dole in his lyrical speech accepting his nomination said, "Age has its advantage. Let me be the bridge to an America that only the unknowing call myth."
If Mr. Dole would offer a bridge to the past, then Mr. Clinton would offer a bridge to the future, a bridge as he would say, "to the 21st century, wide enough and strong enough to take us to America's best days."
By the end of the Democratic convention, it seemed nothing could stop Mr. Clinton. He sailed through the debates and he coasted through rallies conjuring up visions of a glorious millennium.
The Republican Congress -- concerned about its own survival -- struck compromises with him on a host of bills in the last six weeks of the session. "I think the thing that sealed all this was that we had such a great six weeks," Mr. Clinton said today.
The prodigious money raising Mr. Clinton had set in motion so long ago with his insistence on an early television advertising campaign, paid for by the Democratic National Committee, came back to haunt him as questions arose about some of the donors and about John Huang, one of the fund-raisers. But Mr. Clinton simply rode out the storm to a second term.
Very early in the morning on Election Day, in a scene that could have been from a Busby Berkeley musical, spotlights focusing mid air in the Sioux Falls arena captured Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, walking across a bridge suspended mid air, music blaring and a fan of American flags arrayed behind them. "We just need to run our country the way we want to run our lives," Mr. Clinton said ruminating on his 23 years in politics as he ended his last rally before flying home to Little Rock. "That is what I learned in 23 years, and that is what I ask you to vote for tomorrow as we build our bridge to the 21st century."

HEADLINE: Genetic Soybeans Alarm Europeans

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
As genetically engineered soybeans from the United States begin to arrive in Europe, concerns about possible health risks raised by consumer groups and critics of biotechnology are prompting a boycott by some food producers and supermarket chains.
Soybeans are one of the United States' biggest farm exports to Europe; oil from the crushed beans is used in a wide variety of grocery items, including margarine, cake and chocolate, and soymeal is fed to livestock and poultry. 
 The bioengineered beans, developed by the St. Louis-based chemical producer Monsanto to yield larger harvests at lower costs, have been approved by both the Food and Drug Administration in the United States and the European Union.
But by the time the first shipment of American soybeans that included the bioengineered bean docked in Hamburg, Germany, today aboard the freighter Ideal Progress, European consumer groups had made the soybean their main line of resistance against a coming wave of bioengineered crops, including corn, chicory and rapeseed.
In Germany -- where anxiety over tampering with the food chain has been raised to a high pitch by mad cow disease, which spread among old British cattle and, as it turned out, some diseased cows were recycled as cattle feed -- packaged-food companies including Unilever and Nestle Deutschland A.G. have pledged not to use the Monsanto product.
Food industry associations in Sweden, the Netherlands and other countries are concerned that products using the beans could be challenged in court by consumer groups demanding further testing of their long-term safety. Grocery chains, including Sainsbury, Tesco and Safeway P.L.C. in Britain, are demanding that American producers keep the Monsanto beans separate and labeled as altered.
In the European Union, environmental campaigners are to try next week to reverse its approval of the soybeans and to block future shipments of similarly engineered crops unless they are labeled, Hiltrud Breyer, a European Parliament member, said in an interview the other day.
And while many companies, including Nestle S.A., the giant Swiss-based parent of Nestle Deutschland, are committed to the new products and see their acceptance as inevitable, the industry is concerned about starting off amid panic as environmental groups like Greenpeace fan consumer anxieties.
Ever since genetic engineering arose in the 1980's, it has provoked an unease among many people at the idea of humans disturbing the natural genetic order. And despite the Food and Drug Administration's position that there is no evidence that bioengineered foods require special precautions, critics who oppose taking any chances continue campaigning to have such foods tested as thoroughly as any new food additive.
Monsanto is counting on the controversy dying down as consumers get enough information, a spokeswoman for the company, Lisa Watson, said. "There is a lot of noise out there now by groups trying to make consumers believe there is something wrong," she said.
But an influential European business representative urged caution. "Our message from our customers is that for whatever reason they would prefer not to have it in their foodstuffs," said Henrik Kroner, secretary general of Eurocommerce, a Brussels-based lobbying association for hundreds of retail and commerce groups in 20 countries.
"We should do more to make them change their minds," Mr. Kroner said. But he added: "I am telling the American exporters to please, in this season, if you are wise, don't ship those soybeans to Europe because you may trigger a lasting reaction. And, if you must, separate and label them."
With soybeans second only to corn as a cash crop in the United States, biotechnology engineers have experimented for years to produce a higher-yield variety. Monsanto's eventual solution was to transplant a gene from another plant to make soybeans resistant to its best-selling herbicide, Roundup.
Roundup generally kills any plant with leaves. So by planting a soybean that can withstand it, farmers can use a single treatment of Roundup, instead of the customary two applications of other weedkillers, and in the process kill more weeds.
Plants that have to compete with fewer weeds can produce more soybeans, and so farmers -- in theory -- save time and money while harvesting a larger crop. Monsanto sells its technology to seed companies, which incorporate it into their soybeans. The soybeans are in turn marketed under the label Roundup Ready, and Monsanto makes money licensing the technology and by selling lots more Roundup, too.
Seed companies began marketing the soybean only this year, and the variety is expected to constitute less than 2 percent of the United States' production of 59 million tons.
But Greenpeace, which sent out a barge today to interfere with the docking of the Ideal Progress, sees that trickle as the opening for a flood of bioengineered crops.
"This will be the first time genetically engineered ingredients have appeared in a wide range of everyday supermarket products," Michelle Sheather, a campaigner for Greenpeace, said in a telephone interview from headquarters in Amsterdam. "If the food multinationals have their way, millions of tons of engineered crops will be grown."
Food companies, indeed, have invested enormous amounts of money in biotechnology research to develop new varieties of crops, from corn to tomatoes, with higher yields or lower costs.
Altering genes by transplanting them from different species instead of crossbreeding related varieties, bioengineers have already made corn and potatoes more resistant to insect pests. In coming years, exports of these products are expected to total billions.
With the stakes so high, some American exporters say that the opposition in Europe in recent weeks has already caused soybean exports to the Continent to drop 10 percent.
The United States Department of Agriculture is skeptical, attributing the drop to higher soybean prices at a time when European grain production is greater than usual. In any case, officials say, soybeans that cannot be sold in Europe will find a market elsewhere.
The fight against genetically engineered food products may also be fed, in part, by recent disputes in which Europeans have accused the United States of trying to control commerce beyond its borders, such as American sanctions against countries that trade with Iran, Libya or Cuba. And there may well be resentment over the assumption that if a United States agency has deemed a product safe, that should be good enough for Europeans. But the opposition is also driven by activist groups like Greenpeace, which European businesses say are overly zealous but impossible to ignore.
"The soya bean has wide-ranging approval and in our assessment it is safe," said Frank Vanooyen, a spokesman for Unilever in the Netherlands. "But the fact remains we are a consumer-driven company, and therefore we leave the decision up to our operating companies on a country-by-country basis."
Surveys have found that 85 percent to 90 percent of European consumers support clear labeling of bioengineered products, and are less enthusiastic than American consumers about embracing what the Europeans see as novel foods.
But the large food companies here agree with Monsanto that once the public is informed of the benefits of newly developed crop varieties and what the producers insist are their low risks, there will be widespread acceptance.
"This is not in itself a big deal, but it sets signals for things to come," said Claus Conzelmann, an assistant vice president for Nestle, in a telephone interview from company headquarters in Vevey, Switzerland.
"We are perhaps a little more realistic about it," he said. "If the consumer finally does not want it, we will draw the final conclusion. But we are convinced biological engineering will remain an important field. In our opinion, it increases the efficiency of agricultural production with positive repercussions on the environment."
Monsanto, of course, is not alone; Ciba-Geigy, Du Pont, Dow Chemical, Zeneca and Hoechst have also aggressively invested in genetically engineered crops. In the United States, analysts say the compelling economics of bioengineered soybeans and the crops to follow will win out.
The soybeans have "been on sale in the United States and it has not caused any problems," said William Young, of the brokerage firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, who follows the grain industry.
"I can't predict politics but economics will triumph in the end," he added. "The simple truth is that organic food is a lot more expensive."
American farmers have a say, too. And they are watching developments in Europe closely before they return to Monsanto this winter to buy more bags of expensive Roundup Ready seeds, according to Philip Paarlberg, a trade specialist at Purdue University.
By the time next year's planting starts in May and June, he said, "We will be able to assess the damage properly."

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE CONGRESS;
New Faces In the House

 BODY:

FLORIDA
 
Jim Davis
Democrat, 39. A lawyer, Mr. Davis has served in the Florida House since 1988 and is currently the majority leader. His campaign strategy included emphasizing local issues and his moderate stance and assuring voters that if elected, he would not become a tool of Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader. Mr. Davis's rival for the open seat in Florida's 11th Congressional District was Mark Sharpe, a former Navy intelligence officer who brought in Speaker Newt Gingrich to help raise campaign money and said it was important for Republicans to keep control of Congress "if only to prevent national health insurance." 

INDIANA
 
Julia M. Carson
Democrat, 38. In a race that was declared a dead heat by both campaigns, Ms. Carson defeated her Republican challenger, Virginia Blankenbaker, and will succeed Andrew Jacobs Jr., a Democrat retiring after 30 years. Ms. Carson became Indianapolis's second black Congresswoman. But uncomfortable carrying the banner of race ("I am not your African-American candidate, I am the Democratic candidate for Congress," she said), Ms. Carson instead emphasized education, health care and her record as the trustee of Center Township, which she helped recover from a budget deficit.
 
KANSAS
 
Jim Ryun
Republican, 49. A motivational speaker and track star in the 1960's, Mr. Ryun is renowned for holding the world record in the one-mile run for nine years. He is a new face not only in the House but also in politics. Born and reared in Kansas, he is a conservative who advocates strong family values and a balanced budget.
 
OKLAHOMA
 
Wes Watkins
Republican, 57. A home-building contractor and economic developer, Mr. Watkins has traveled a long and winding road back to the House. A former Democratic Representative, he served in the House from 1977 to 1991. In 1992, he left the House in an unsuccessful bid for the Democratic nomination for Governor. After losing, Mr. Watkins supported Ross Perot for President in 1992 and made another unsuccessful race for governor as an independent in 1994. Last year, he switched parties. This year, Mr. Watkins defeated his Democratic challenger, Darryl Roberts, and won the seat opened up by the retirement of Representative Bill Brewster, a Democrat.
 
NORTH CAROLINA
 
David E. Price
Democrat, 56. A professor of political science, Mr. Price has taught at Yale and Duke for 19 years, was North Carolina's Democratic Party chairman in 1983 and 1984, and represented his state's Fourth Congressonal District from 1987 to 1994. Armed with his belief that "politics is more exciting than political science," he took a leave from Duke this semester in an effort to regain the seat he lost in 1994 by 1,215 votes. Mr. Price defeated Fred Heineman, the Republican who defeated him two years earlier. Mr. Price cast the election largely as a referendum on the agenda set by the Republican leadership of the 104th Congress, saying, "Newt Gingrich and his 95 percenters like Fred Heineman have had their shot and people have been alarmed by what they've seen."
 
OHIO
 
Dennis J. Kucinich
Democrat, 50. A former video producer and public power consultant, Mr. Kucinich was first elected to office in 1969, serving on the Cleveland City Council until 1971. In 1977, at the age of 31 and with little political experience, he was elected Mayor of Cleveland. He was nicknamed the "boy mayor" and he came under heavy fire the next year when the city defaulted on its debt. He tried unsuccessfully to get elected to Congress in 1972, 1974, 1988 and 1992. In a race for the Ohio Legislature in 1994 Mr. Kucinich became the only Democrat to oust an incumbent Republican.

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Liberal Use of 'Extremist' Is the Winning Strategy

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

 BODY:
In the epithet wars that were the 1996 Congressional and Presidential campaigns, "extremist" proved to be a more dangerous label than "liberal."
Because of more than a year's worth of consistent Democratic and labor advertising linking Bob Dole to Newt Gingrich and assaulting the Republican Congress as extreme, Bill Clinton was able to control the political agenda. He threw Republicans nationwide on the defensive, in the view yesterday of weary Democratic and Republican strategists, as well as independent experts. 
 The advertising campaign may also have rewritten the book on how early Presidents should start paying to promote themselves.
"It was the key in which all of these races were played," said Stuart Stevens, a one-time advertising strategist for Mr. Dole, who also created the advertising in Gov. William F. Weld's losing bid for the Senate in Massachusetts. "Clinton had very impressive coattails in these races, in the sense of turning them into a referendum on a mythical enemy. He set up a straw man and then attacked it. He set up a series of code words that other Democratic candidates could use."
Battling back by spending heavily for their own advertising, Republican Congressmen were generally able to survive the onslaught by reversing the strategy they used in 1994. This year they isolated themselves from a national conservative movement to run as the voices of their specific districts.
But at same time, a traditional Republican tactic -- attacking a Democrat as liberal -- may have lost its edge in 1996. Arthur J. Finkelstein, a pollster and Republican consultant known for his relentless use of this line of attack, lost three Senate races, including one against Paul Wellstone, who had been labeled "embarrassingly liberal."
"Calling Paul Wellstone liberal in Minnesota is like calling Jim Innocenzi an Italian," said Jim Innocenzi, a Republican advertising consultant who worked for a dozen winning Congressional candidates this year. "The liberal thing, the liberal attack, has no traction except in the South. Using the liberal label without a huge justification is a waste."
Mr. Finkelstein did not respond to a telephone message yesterday.
Mr. Dole also tried to use the liberal label. But he changed advertising messages even more times than he changed advertising teams, making it hard to judge which message might have been effective, had it been sustained.
Alex Castellanos, one of Mr. Dole's advertising men, designed a campaign mocking the President as a dishonest liberal. Playfully but pointedly, the advertisements, using clips of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton, provided lessons in "How to talk liberal."
Evidently concerned that the advertisements were too harsh, the Dole campaign only broadcast one of them, toning it down to soften its suggestion that Mr. Clinton was a liar.
Mr. Castellanos acknowledged that it was harder this year to brand a politician as liberal, "now that there are two Republican Parties." But, he said, "if it were a term of endearment, Clinton would not have run away from it as fast and as far as he did."
Mr. Castellanos said of the Dole campaign: "We bounced around too much from drugs to economy to trust to everything. The other guy's running the one commercial for a year and a half: 'Dole-Gingrich is extreme, and I'm trying to protect you.' "
No Presidential campaign had ever advertised as early or as often as the Clinton-Gore campaign and the Democrat National Committee did, using the same firm, Squire Knapp Ochs. "It was an unprecedented effort by the party to resuscitate the party," said Bill Knapp, a partner of the firm. "This was a party that was dead. It was flat. There were road marks on our backs."
Blessed without opposition in the Democratic primaries, Clinton officials decided to strike early against the Republicans in part because of their experience during the debate over health care reform, when the officials concluded that they lost the public debate by ceding the advertising war to interest groups. Such early advertising may now become the standard, some consultants said.
"I do, in fact, tip my hat and congratulate Squire and Bill Knapp and company for running a spectacularly successful advertising campaign," said Greg Stevens, another on Mr. Dole's final advertising team. "They came out early and defined the race, and defined Bob Dole. They did it in a very disciplined way."
Mr. Clinton's first advertisement of the campaign ran on June 27, 1995, praising the President's record on crime. But the commercial that, in retrospect, seemed to form the template for most Democratic advertising did not appear until August. It was paid for by the Democratic National Committee.
"The Republicans are wrong to want to cut Medicare benefits," the announcer declared, in a commercial broadcast in select states that showed faded images of the faces of Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Dole floating beside the Capitol. "And President Clinton is right to protect Medicare, right to defend our decision as a nation to do what's moral, good, and right by our elderly."
A more traditional, old-school Democratic advertisement might have taken a class warfare tack, arguing that the Republicans wanted to cut Medicare to give a tax break to the rich. In fact, that was the claim that the American Federation of Labor made in its Medicare advertisements attacking Republican Congressmen.
Instead, the Presidential advertising always emphasized that cutting Medicare "was a violation of our duties and our values," Mr. Knapp said. "That was a huge departure, and a critical, critical difference."
As Mr. Clinton made his bid for the political center, one of his campaign's guidelines for advertising was to emphasize values rather than Government programs. Another was to stress unity rather than class warfare.
The Presidential spots, supplemented by the labor advertising, formed the backdrop for many tight Congressional races, helping candidates like Debbie Stabenow, who prevailed in Michigan's Eighth Distict over Representative Dick Chrysler, a Republican freshman.
The tightly focused, repetitive Democratic advertising kept many Republicans on the defensive, at least until campaign finance questions began to dog Mr. Clinton in the final weeks of the campaign, said Charles E. Cook Jr., an independent analyst of House races.
Paradoxically, Republican incumbents may have benefited from Mr. Clinton's lead in the polls, as well as the strength of the economy, consultants said, because many voters stopped paying attention to politics.
"Nobody clued in, so it became an incumbent year, and so the Republicans played to that by isolating their races," said Doug McAuliffe, a Republican consultant who, among other races, helped Representative J. D. Hayworth of Arizona fend off a stiff challenge.
To isolate their races, incumbents highlighted their role providing constituent service.
Mr. Innocenzi, for example, discovered that one of his candidates, Representative Steven H. Schiff of New Mexico, was under withering advertising fire as a Gingrich clone. He responded with a 60-second commercial in which a man described how Mr. Schiff had intervened to help his son, a former gang member who had changed his ways and was serving in the Navy. Having discovered the man's checkered past, the Navy was on the verge of kicking him out, his father said, when Mr. Schiff intervened to get him a hearing.
"That's ultimately what you want," Mr. Innocenzi said."Someone to represent you and take care of you."
Mr. Schiff won.
The other way to isolate the race was by attacking the challengers -- "ripping their faces off," in the words of Mark Mellman, a consultant to the Democratic Congressional leadership. And a last-minute advertising blitz by the Republican Party probably shored up several vulnerable Republicans.
Consultants on both sides said that they were astonished by the amount and the ferocity of the advertising this year. Candidates were broadcasting commercials up to three times more frequently than they might have 10 years ago, some said, partly because there are so many more channels now, and so much more advertising clutter.
Mr. Mellman recalled winning a Connecticut race in 1982 by buying only enough air time for two negative commercials so that voters would see the spots eight times.
"Today, that wouldn't get you on the radar screen," Mr. Mellman said. "You have to speak loudly and carry a big stick."

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- THE ADMINISTRATION;
Same Star, but Supporting Cast to Change

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton came home to a sentimental rally on the South Lawn of the White House this afternoon -- and to a Cabinet and senior staff shuffle already swirling around him.
By the time Air Force One touched down at Andrews Air Force Base in the early afternoon, bringing Mr. Clinton back from his victory celebration in Little Rock, Ark., his Secretaries of State, Defense, Commerce and Energy, or people close to them, had let it be known that they would not be staying on. 
 Minutes later, the Cabinet members sat like so many schoolchildren in red, white and blue T-shirts proclaiming, "Welcome Home President and Mrs. Clinton!" Taking note of his dapper Secretary of State's unorthodox attire, Mr. Clinton said, "That picture of Warren Christopher in that T-shirt gets out -- he'll be on Letterman and Leno within 48 hours."
In fact, Mr. Christopher will soon be home in Santa Barbara, Calif., sipping one of his favorite chardonnays. The 71-year-old Secretary, who headed Mr. Clinton's transition team in 1992, spent two hours in Little Rock with him on Tuesday afternoon, informing the President of his intention to leave sometime after Inauguration Day. The list of possible successors includes former Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine and Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, who is retiring.
The White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, marched down the steps of the South Portico to the cheers of his assembled troops, telling the President: "Before you are the engineers, the designers and the workers who will build that bridge to the future."
But Mr. Panetta will not be among them, off instead to his home in California, perhaps to run for governor. Senior White House aides said Mr. Clinton was working hard to persuade his former deputy chief of staff, Erskine B. Bowles, who now heads his own investment concern in North Carolina, to return as White House chief of staff.
"It's close," one senior aide said of Mr. Bowles, who is known to be reluctant to return but who has also become one of the President's most trusted friends and who has already been advising him for weeks on the transition, along with Vernon E. Jordan, the Washington lawyer and longtime Clinton confidant. "But it's not there yet."
Defense Secretary William J. Perry informed members of his staff today that he intended to leave early in the new Administration, although he, too, is expected to remain at the Pentagon for a few months, until a successor is confirmed by the Senate, officials said. His possible successors include the Director of Central Intelligence, John M. Deutch, a former Deputy Defense Secretary, and Mr. Nunn, the former chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor, one of Mr. Clinton's earliest political comrades in arms, has also told the President he does not want to continue in the job he took after the death of Ronald H. Brown, or to be considered for other posts.
The White House also made it clear today that Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary will go. Among those mentioned most often to succeed her is Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico.
Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena is also expected to leave, and the brother of Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago, William M. Daley, a lawyer who was a leading candidate for the post four years ago, may claim it this time.
But at least one oft-mentioned change will now apparently not occur: Mr. Clinton has been said to want to replace Attorney General Janet Reno, but she has made her desire to stay on equally plain. White House officials acknowledged today that pending inquiries into the Democratic Party's fund-raising practices meant that Ms. Reno would stay for the time being.
While some aides strongly encouraged Mr. Clinton to seek the pro-forma resignations of all his Cabinet members -- as Richard M. Nixon did after his re-election in 1972, for example -- Mr. Panetta decided it would be more orderly to sound out members informally. Over the last several weeks, aides said, he has done so, and made the President's wishes clear.
"Nobody had to be kicked," one senior aide said.
Mr. Clinton had initially hoped to have enough work done on the transition to leave for a weeklong vacation in Hawaii next Tuesday before beginning a 10-day official visit to Australia, the Philippines and Thailand. But top aides said they now expected him to delay his departure until later next week, to get as much done as possible. Once he leaves, the President is to be out of the country until Thanksgiving, and the White House is eager at all costs to avoid the last-minute decisions that plagued his first transition.
As it is, the President's schedule is busy. Tonight he attended a thank-you dinner dance for major Democratic donors at the National Building Museum here, and aides said he might hold a news conference on Friday if he had appointments to announce by then.
Among Mr. Clinton's economic advisers, musical chairs are possible. Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the National Economic Council, appears undecided about her next move. Her husband and son have moved back to Berkeley, Calif., where she was a professor before joining the Administration, and she has been commuting between California and Washington almost every week. But she might be persuaded to stay if she is offered a Cabinet job, her colleagues say.
The most frequently mentioned alternative for her is Labor Secretary, if Robert B. Reich, whose family has moved back to Boston, leaves the Administration. Mr. Reich has not yet indicated what he plans to do. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, already one of the President's most influential advisers, is expected to stay on.
George Stephanopoulos, the onetime "war room" wunderkind who has functioned as Mr. Clinton's all-purpose adviser, conscience, mind-reader and occasional whipping boy for nearly five years, will leave the White House staff soon, and he is exploring job options in academia and the news media with plans to make speeches on the side.
Hovering over the whole transition is Vice President Al Gore, and aides said they expected him to have a say in all major decisions. His appearance at the welcome-home rally today amounted to the first step in his own expected campaign in 2000.
Mr. Gore joked that he would now join the short list of Democratic Vice Presidents elected to two terms: John Nance Garner, Thomas R. Marshall, Daniel D. Tompkins and George Clinton.
"He was the first, so from George Clinton to -- from Clinton to Gore!" the Vice President told the crowd, which began chanting, "Four more years!" at that apparent reference to his own plans.
"Oh, oh, no, no, no -- no, no, no, no, no!" Mr. Gore insisted. "You misunderstand me. George Clinton, 1805 to 1812, from New York, first Democratic Vice President to be elected. The other, I assure you, is just a slip of the tongue."
