HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE STATES -- THE GOVERNORS;
Chinese Roots of Winner Delight the Pacific Rim

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Surrounded by news crews from all over the Pacific Rim, Gary Locke was asked today what it felt like to make history. A Democrat who won the Washington State gubernatorial race by a landslide, Mr. Locke will become the nation's first Chinese-American governor.
"It's hard for me to think of myself as a role model," said Mr. Locke, the son of Chinese immigrants. "I'm just an average guy." He likes to tinker with plumbing, is a baseball fan and will occasionally break out in Broadway song. 
 On election night, as supporters handed out fortune cookies and danced, Mr. Locke was singing "Something Good," from the movie "The Sound of Music."
In the wake of Mr. Locke's 20-point victory over Ellen Craswell, a Republican, many of Mr. Locke's supporters were treating him as anything but average.
"It's a big story -- the American dream come true for Asian-Americans," said Judy Yu, who has been acting as an intermediary for the Asian media crews that have swarmed around Mr. Locke and his wife, Mona Lee Locke. "It's very rare for Asian people to go into politics to begin with."
Indeed, Mr. Locke has said that his family was discouraged when he decided to go into politics after he graduated from Yale University.
In January, he will move into the Governor's Mansion in Olympia, a few blocks from where his grandfather once worked as a houseboy. His grandfather later returned to China. But his father emigrated to America, fought against the Germans in World War II and settled in Seattle.
Mr. Locke was elected governor of a state with an Asian-American population that makes up only about 4 percent of the state's 5.5 million people.
He won, many analysts said, not by playing up his ethnicity -- it was never an issue in any public forum -- but by advancing his ideas and his personal narrative as someone who grew up in public housing and did not even speak English until after his fifth birthday.
In the 24 hours since Mr. Locke was elected, leaders in China and Taiwan have already invited him to visit their countries on trade missions, he said today.
Washington, the most trade-dependent state in the country, has long had close economic ties with Asia, selling Boeing airplanes, Microsoft software and Yakima Valley apples abroad and importing electronic goods and clothes.
The majority owner of Seattle's major league baseball team, the Mariners, lives in Japan.
Up and down the West Coast, the age of the Pacific Rim has long been heralded as an inevitable pivot of history. But while trade and cultural connections between the American Pacific coast and Asia have grown considerably in the last decade, the political power of Asian-Americans has developed more slowly.
With all the negative publicity over the Democratic National Committee's ties to questionable Asian fund raising, the Locke victory has provided a positive counterpoint, Mr. Locke's supporters said.
"People are just so proud," said Dorothy Chen, president of the Seattle Chinese Womens Club.
"This is front-page news in Taipei, in Hong Kong and Beijing," said United States Representative Jim McDermott, a Democrat from Seattle who has known Mr. Locke for 15 years. "You get a first-generation Asian-American elected governor by a huge margin -- it's just a marvelous statement about the values of America."
Mr. Locke attributes his rise toeducation.
He was an Eagle Scout and graduated from Yale University, then worked as a prosecutor. He spent 10 years in the State Legislature. Now 46 years old, he is serving his first elected term as King County Executive, governing the most populous county in Washington.
"Education," he said on election night, "is the great equalizer." He tried to interest his 800 or supporters gathered in a ballroom in Seattle to chant the words about education, which he said would be his No. 1 issue.
Republicans had tried to portray Mr. Locke as a tax-and-spend liberal. On social issues, he favors gay rights and affirmative action -- two positions that Republicans thought would give them some traction in the race.
But Mr. Locke benefited from an opponent who was so closely tied to the religious right that about 1 in 5 Republicans said they could not vote for her, according to late independent polls. Mrs. Craswell said she was going to run state government according to "God's plan," and she criticized homosexuals as immoral. Several prominent Republicans publicly supported Mr. Locke.

PUB-DATE: November 7, 1996

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1699 words

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON PREPARING FOR 2D TERM WITH SHUFFLE OF TOP OFFICIALS

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
President Clinton followed his 31-state electoral sweep yesterday by beginning to build a new Government, accepting the resignations of some of his top Cabinet officials, including Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
The moves indicated that Mr. Clinton intended to act swiftly to inject some freshness into a second term in which he is facing a much-reduced agenda and a Congress still controlled by the Republicans. 
 White House officials said Mr. Clinton might hold a news conference later this week at which he would discuss his Cabinet shuffle and name some replacements.
Others who have told Mr. Clinton that they plan to depart include Defense Secretary William J. Perry; Leon E. Panetta, the chief of staff, and Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor. The leading candidate to replace Mr. Panetta is Erskine B. Bowles, a friend of the President who is his former deputy chief of staff.
Although the shuffling consumed the White House yesterday, it was not a surprise that a shake-up was in the offing. Several of Mr. Clinton's top lieutenants, including Mr. Christopher and Mr. Perry, have signaled their desire to move on for weeks or, in some cases, months.
But some of the talked-about changes, like replacing Hazel R. O'Leary, the Energy Secretary, were said to be wanted by the President. Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, has told friends that he plans to resign for personal reasons. But Administration officials said one much-rumored change -- the resignation of Attorney General Janet Reno -- was rejected out of concern about pending investigations of the Clintons and their friends and aides.
Officials said that Mr. Clinton did not want to appear to be interfering in those investigations by removing Ms. Reno and that in any case, he feared he would have trouble getting Senate approval for her replacement in the current political climate.
It was not clear how many of the other members of Mr. Clinton's Cabinet, if any, would be leaving.
The composition of the new Cabinet and the rest of Mr. Clinton's new Government may provide some clues about his priorities as he tries to work with the new Republican Congress.
During the campaign, he did not offer much in the way of a second-term agenda, beyond small-gauge proposals that were intended by his strategists more to appeal to specific groups of voters than to provide a blueprint for governing.
Rather than talk about Republicans in Congress, Mr. Clinton dwelled today on his own victory over Bob Dole. Despite the President's dominance of most regions of the country, with 379 electoral votes (270 are needed to win), he won 49 percent of the popular vote -- falling short of the 50 percent he had hoped for to claim a mandate from the American voters. Mr. Dole drew 41 percent, with 8 percent for Ross Perot.
Returning triumphantly to the White House yesterday afternoon from Little Rock, Ark., the President told his staff at a welcoming ceremony on the South Lawn, "This race was won because of the record we made and because of the plans we have and because we have established in the minds of the American people that it's more than talk with us -- that we work at it hard every day."
Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, congratulated Mr. Clinton, but he said the President had been re-elected only because he had adeptly appropriated Republican issues for himself.
"It was a super campaign, and Bill Clinton is a super candidate," Mr. Barbour said at a news conference in Washington. "He is the most outstanding political performer of my lifetime, and he deserves great credit. But we have to say straightforwardly that he campaigned as a moderate Republican, which was the right thing to do because that's where the American people are."
He added, "Bill Clinton went out and there were days that sounded like Ronald Reagan had taken over his body."
In one of the many postmortems among Republicans yesterday, Tony Fabrizio, Mr. Dole's pollster, conceded, "We never really controlled the agenda."
With all the whispering about musical chairs in the Administration, it was striking how swiftly the attention of official Washington turned yesterday from electoral politics to the business of governing. That may be because election night on Tuesday will not be remembered as particularly gripping. Mr. Clinton's victory over Mr. Dole had been widely expected for weeks, and there was no shift in control of Congress.
The absence of suspense may also help explain why the turnout on Tuesday was the lowest level for a Presidential election since 1924.
About 49 percent of the nation's voting-age population voted, according to a survey of voters leaving the polls. The final tally could rise slightly after several hundred thousand absentee ballots are counted.
Yet the outcome of the election only prolonged the unsettled state of American politics, with neither Republicans nor Democrats able to claim the upper hand.
Mr. Clinton, who drew 43 percent of the vote four years ago, is the first President since Woodrow Wilson to be elected twice without a majority of the popular vote. As a result, he may again face a struggle to reassert his relevancy with the Republicans on Capitol Hill.
White House officials are already fretting because some Republican leaders yesterday made clear that they intended to pursue with vigor inquiries into ethical and campaign finance allegations swirling around the President and the Democratic Party.
But at least for the day after the election, the watchword was cooperation, as both the President and Republican leaders in Congress talked of their desire, and need, to continue to work together.
Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, said the election results "gave us all another opportunity to work together." But he also seemed to put the White House on notice. Referring to voters at a news conference in Washington, Mr. Lott said: "It's obvious that they have some reservations about President Clinton. On the other hand, they did return our Republican majority to the Congress to sort of keep an eye on him."
Yet tensions are certain to continue on both sides of Pennsylvania Avenue because while Republicans hung on to Congress, they could not claim an overwhelming mandate either. In the 435-member House, the Republicans' majority of 236 seats fell to 225 seats won, with 4 seats undecided and 2 depending on a runoff election next month in Texas. In the 34 Senate races, the Republicans' majority grew to either 54 or 55 seats, depending on the outcome of a race in Oregon.
Not surprisingly, Republicans and Democrats offered far different interpretations of the Senate and House results.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, general chairman of the Democratic Party, said at a news conference in Washington that after the Republican takeover of Congress two years ago, the outcome amounted to a "repudiation of the so-called Republican Revolution and an endorsement, at least, of common sense leadership."
He emphasized that voters had turned out more than a dozen Republican incumbents in the House, though an overwhelming number held on to their seats.
But Mr. Barbour, the Republican chairman, said the results only reaffirmed the takeover in 1994. "In 1994," he said, "Republicans won the greatest midterm majority sweep of the century. We went from minority to the majority, winning more -- and up and down the ticket, and across the country. And often in our political lifetimes after that, there's a rebound. And a lot of people predicted a rebound here, but instead of a rebound, we got a reaffirming election."
And Speaker Newt Gingrich, who was as much the target of Mr. Clinton's campaign as Mr. Dole, said of the Republicans' showing in the House: "It's pretty amazing, a truly historic moment.
"The last time the G.O.P. successfully defended a House majority was 1930, during the Presidency of Herbert Hoover."
James Innocenzi, a Republican consultant, said the election could have a moderating influence. "This was a softening election," he said. "All the extremists on both sides lost."
There was less of an effort yesterday to interpret how Mr. Clinton won re-election. That may be because Mr. Dole's defeat had been expected and because the healthy economy and Mr. Clinton's adept re-election organization seemed to give the Republicans little hope of winning back the White House. Still, Republicans vowed that they would once again claim their dominance of the White House.
Among those thinking about the race in the year 2000, the attention focused on Vice President Al Gore, particularly since two of his possible rivals for the White House were disappointed on Tuesday night: Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, had hoped to become Speaker.
And Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, would have enhanced his reputation significantly if his party had reclaimed the Senate.
White House aides said Mr. Clinton had intentionally put off most staff decisions until now because he feared he would jinx the election. But in the days leading up to the election, he dispatched Mr. Panetta to meet with several top appointees to gauge their interest in staying on -- and to strongly drop hints if the President did not want them to continue.
"This is the natural end point and the natural starting point," said George Stephanopoulos, the senior adviser to the President who for months has talked openly of leaving after the election.
But there was no immediate reshuffling after President Ronald Reagan's re-election in 1984, although T. H. Bell, the Education Secretary, announced his resignation a few days after the election.
Mr. Perry, the Defense Secretary, informed his staff yesterday that he intended to leave early in the new Administration. But he told reporters traveling with him to Europe last month that there was never a good time to leave.
"I don't think there is any good time or bad time walking away from the job as Secretary of Defense," he said. "There is always a problem. There is always a crisis. There's always some program that is halfway completed."

THE ELECTIONS
 
Quintessentially Long Island
Long Islander, mother, candidate -- Carolyn McCarthy became the first Congresswoman in Long Island history. And her story is quintessential Long Island. Not the stereotypical Long Island of Joey Buttafuoco and Howard Stern, but the real Long Island -- of hardworking, middle-class people just trying to get through the week. [Page A1.]
 
After Mrs. McCarthy's victory, Nassau County's Republican Party chief said he was receptive to giving her the Republican nomination for re-election in 1998. [B14.]
 
Northeast Critical to Clinton
New York State barely saw Bill Clinton during the campaign, and its economy remains sluggish. Yet the President's overall victory in the popular vote stemmed in large part from substantial margins from New York and surrounding states. [A1.]
 
New Jersey Democrats Cheered
The 1990's have been a good decade for Republicans in New Jersey. They have seized control of the governorship and both houses of the Legislature. But many Democrats ran unexpectedly well in the state, raising the party's hopes for a year from now, when Governor Whitman is up for re-election. News Analysis. [B12.]

G.O.P. Wins Court Seats

Giving Needles, Not Judgment
Needle exchanges have cut in half new H.I.V. cases among New York City's intravenous drug users, according to research made public in 1994. Though prosecuted in the early 1990's as purveyors of drug paraphernalia, the city's six free exchanges have been financed by the state for more than two years. [B21.]

Nobody should be surprised at the revelation that Frederick Phineas Rose and Sandra Priest Rose contributed $20 million to the Museum of Natural History for its new plan to rebuild the old Planetarium. The Roses have a habit of doing this sort of thing. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B21.]

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE REGION -- THE CHOICE;
In New Jersey, Democrats See Renewed Hope

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
The 1990's have been a good decade for Republicans in New Jersey. They have seized control of the governorship and both houses of the Legislature. But many Democrats ran unexpectedly well in the state on Tuesday, raising the party's hopes for a year from now, when Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is up for re-election.
Even the Republican Senate candidate, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, mentioned in his concession speech that Mrs. Whitman's re-election campaign had now begun. 
 That may be distressing news for the public, reeling from weeks of saturation political advertising on television. But as the gubernatorial race gathers steam, the strong showing by President Clinton and Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democrat who defeated Mr. Zimmer in the Senate contest by an unexpectedly wide margin of 53 to 43 percent, will encourage many of the half-dozen or so Democrats who have been contemplating a challenge to the popular first-term Republican Governor.
Women and minority-group voters responded enthusiastically to the Democrats' themes this year, a survey of voters leaving the polls in New Jersey found. Turnout in the cities and other traditional Democratic strongholds was heavy. In the Eighth Congressional District, which includes Paterson and Passaic, a Democrat, Mayor William J. Pascrell of Paterson, defeated an incumbent freshman Republican, Representative William J. Martini.
It would be hard to fault Democrats, after their dismal statewide showing in recent years, for not seeing in the election results at least the glimmer of a brighter future.
Representative Robert E. Andrews, a Democrat from Camden County who will probably seek the nomination to challenge Mrs. Whitman, said he thought the debate had now shifted to issues like jobs, education and the environment, giving Democrats the upper hand.
"When the debate shifts, we win," Mr. Andrews said. "There is no question that what happened yesterday was a revival of the Democratic base."
But several experts said Democrats and Republicans should be cautious about reading long-term trends from the results on Tuesday, especially any that might involve the Governor.
"The Democrats have reason to be encouraged, but they shouldn't get heady," said Stephen A. Salmore, a professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University and a Republican campaign consultant.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Torricelli ran well by capitalizing on voters' anxieties about cutbacks in popular middle-class programs, like Medicare, educational aid and environmental protection, that had been proposed by Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Republican leadership in the House.
Fifty-four percent of New Jersey voters disapproved of the Congressional leadership, a survey of people leaving polling places on Tuesday found, while 41 percent approved. Mr. Torricelli was able to seize on that dissatisfaction by portraying Mr. Zimmer as too extreme for the state's moderate voters.
But tagging Mrs. Whitman as a Gingrich clone would be difficult for potential Democratic challengers. She does not vote in Congress, and unlike Mr. Zimmer, she is well known throughout New Jersey with a substantial record of her own.
Seeking to counteract Mr. Torricelli's tactics, Mr. Zimmer had tried to characterize himself as fiscally conservative but socially moderate, "a Christie Whitman Republican," as he said countless times.
Mr. Zimmer failed to make that connection with voters. But Mrs. Whitman will surely have much less difficulty making the case.
There were also some encouraging signs for the Governor in Tuesday's survey of voters. Fifty-seven percent of those surveyed said they approved of her performance in office, with 40 percent saying they disapproved.
The poll of 2,018 voters on Tuesday was conducted by Voter News Service, an association of ABC News, CBS News, CNN, Fox News, NBC News and The Associated Press.
A slight plurality of voters said they thought government should do more, rather than less. A large majority, 57 percent to 39 percent, said they thought it was possible for the Federal Government to cut its deficit while also reducing taxes.
Mrs. Whitman won election in 1993 by promising a 30 percent cut in the state income tax, and she made good on that promise. The Governor is an advocate of a smaller, more streamlined government and of using tax cuts to stimulate the economy, and her positions continue to mesh well with voters' sentiments.
When Democrats controlled Congress, New Jersey tended to be a little more conservative than the rest of the country and to vote Republican a little more often, largely because it is wealthier and more suburban than most states, Mr. Salmore of Rutgers said.
With the Republicans having retained their majority in Congress, New Jersey is now slightly to the left of the rest of the country, he said.
"What that says is that a Republican in New Jersey has to be a little more moderate than the party as a whole, and that's Christie Whitman," Mr. Salmore said.
Mr. Zimmer was unable to separate himself from the Republican leadership in Congress this year, but other Republicans in New Jersey did. Six Republican Representatives were re-elected on Tuesday, including Marge Roukema of Ridgewood, a moderate who represents parts of Bergen, Passaic, Sussex and Warren counties in northern Jersey, and Frank A. LoBiondo of Vineland, in South Jersey, a centrist who has been rated well by environmental organizations.
David P. Rebovich, a professor of political science at Rider University, said it would be a mistake to see the election results as a broad ideological shift, primarily because the President and Mr. Torricelli had concentrated their campaigns on a few, highly charged issues, like education and Medicare.
Many political professionals were surprised by the margin of Mr. Torricelli's victory, but they also noted that the dynamic in the Zimmer-Torricelli race would be different from Mrs. Whitman's re-election campaign.
Cliff Zukin, a professor of political science at the Eagleton Institute, said the Governor had to be considered "a prohibitive favorite," because she will begin her campaign as a well-known and popular figure. Whoever emerges as the Democratic candidate is likely to be much less known statewide.
"Voting publics are generally loath to turn out known, well-regarded incumbents," Mr. Zukin said. "And they are unwilling to do that in the face of an unknown. It's a big risk."

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE -- BALLOT QUESTION;
With Term Limits Affirmed, Politicians Ponder the Future

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
One day after New York City residents voted to keep limiting elected officials to only eight years in office, many City Council members spent the day yesterday pondering their options once they are forced to step down in 2001.
While Council members contemplated retiring, returning to private life or seeking other public office, most of the other city officials affected by Tuesday's vote -- the Mayor, the Comptroller, the Public Advocate and the Borough Presidents -- said the pending deadline meant little to them because they had never planned to stay in their positions beyond another term. 
 The vote soundly rejected a proposal that would have lengthened the existing limit of two terms, or 8 years, to three terms, or 12 years.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has not yet announced plans to run for re-election next year but is expected to do so, said yesterday that he was not disappointed by the eight-year limit on the Mayor's office.
"I think two terms is an adequate time to get done the things you want to get done in government," he said. "I had always been a supporter of a three-term limit for New York City mayors because of the history and tradition of New York City. But I don't have a real quarrel with two terms."
In this century, 3 of the 19 Mayors served three four-year terms: Fiorello H. La Guardia, Robert F. Wagner and Edward I. Koch.
The Mayor said, however, that he was concerned about the implications of having virtually all City Council members leave at the same time. "I think that will be a terrible situation for the city in the year 2001," he said, "and I'll consult with the Speaker of the City Council to see if there are any other ways to address that."
The Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, led efforts to defeat term limits in 1993 and spearheaded this year's referendum to change them. But he said that he would not further challenge term limits. Instead, he has started to consider ways to strengthen the Council's professional staff, so that when a largely freshman Council takes office in 2002, there will be sufficient support to help them understand the workings of city government.
The vote was 505,120 in favor of lengthening term limits, and 586,890 in favor of keeping the two-term limit enacted in 1993. Manhattan was the only borough where the measure to lengthen term limits had majority support, picking up 52 percent of the vote. Longer term limits were most strongly opposed on Staten Island, where 69 percent voted against them, and in Queens, where 56 percent voted no.
While the effect of term limits will be felt most immediately in city government, the limits could reverberate beyond into state and national politics.
With 49 of 51 Council members facing unemployment in five years if they run and are re-elected to the Council next year -- the other two, elected more recently, can serve until 2003 -- many will probably consider running for higher office.
Others may return to private law practices or labor union jobs, or go to work for other elected officials. Or they may become lobbyists.
"It's going to be up to every individual and their constituents, but obviously there's going to be major change and we have to start preparing for that," said Kenneth K. Fisher, a Brooklyn Councilman who is considered a likely candidate for Speaker of the City Council if Mr. Vallone leaves before 2001.
Walter L. McCaffrey, a Queens Councilman who also is considered a candidate for Speaker, said, "This is not the kind of thing that you can plan fully in life, but I think all of us are probably thinking about ways to try to make our so-called marks in history."
Mitchell L. Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center, said state legislators and Congressmen from the city will soon realize that the city's term limits could mean serious challenges in what otherwise would have been sleepy re-election bids in which incumbents are routinely victors.
The fact that Mr. Giuliani will be limited to two terms, for example, could affect the field of candidates that emerges to run against him in next year's election.
"You have to assume that some people who haven't yet announced their intentions to run for mayor next year probably wanted to wait and see how this vote went," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Borough President of Manhattan, who has said that she plans to run for mayor in 1997. "It could both encourage and discourage people from entering the race."
Hank Morris, a political consultant who is close to Alan G. Hevesi, the city's Comptroller, said Mr. Hevesi had not yet considered how the term limits might affect his decision on whether to run for mayor.
Mr. Morris said, however, that some potential candidates might decide not to run in 1997, thinking that their chances would be greatly improved if they waited until 2001, when they would not have to face Mr. Giuliani.
He also noted, however, that many people have run for office prepared to lose a first election so that they could position themselves better to win in a subsequent election.
"So there might be people who decide to run in 1997, figuring they'll lose to Giuliani, but that will make them stronger candidates in 2001," he said. "No matter what happens, it'll definitely make for some interesting times."

HEADLINE: Booming Brooklyn

 BODY:
One of the truly heartening urban success stories of the past decade has been the quiet transformation of downtown Brooklyn, fueled by a series of well-conceived joint public and private investments. The resurgence of New York City's most populous borough will gain fresh momentum today with a ceremonial ribbon-cutting opening Atlantic Center, a new 400,000-square-foot shopping complex at the junction of Flatbush and Atlantic avenues. The site, a city-owned urban renewal property, was proposed 40 years ago for a new stadium to persuade the Brooklyn Dodgers not to flee to Los Angeles. It has stood vacant ever since.
The new retail development features suburban-style "big-box" outlets for Caldor, Old Navy, Sports Authority, Marshalls, Pathmark and other stores. It is expected to provide more than 1,200 permanent jobs in addition to shopping opportunities for a neighborhood that is not well served by big retail chains. 
 Six blocks away, meanwhile, work has begun on a new Marriott hotel, Brooklyn's first new hotel in 50 years. The hotel site is located across the street from Metrotech, the growing office complex begun in 1986 on 10 blocks of blighted property. Metrotech's success led to the rediscovery of Brooklyn as a commercial center, convenient to Manhattan's business districts and able to offer lower rents.
A new report by the Regional Plan Association rightly calls Brooklyn's revitalization "a sign of optimism for the entire country." The report cautions, however, that future progress could be difficult, in part because Brooklyn's image as an "old inner city" persists despite the new construction and general sprucing up in the area, involving universities, arts institutions and businesses. In addition to providing a much-needed economic and psychic boost for New York City, the opening of Atlantic Center should help erase that image. After years of decline, Brooklyn is coming back.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: NEW JERSEY;
Voters Approve Bond Act for Dredging Harbor

 BODY:
A bond act that will provide $185 million to help pay for dredging New York Harbor and other waterways passed with 68 percent of the vote on Tuesday.
On another ballot measure, 70 percent of voters said yes to a constitutional amendment that would dedicate 4 percent of corporate taxes to cleaning up hazardous waste sites and removing underground storage tanks. 
 Donald T. DiFrancesco, the president of the State Senate, said he would offer proposals for implementing the bond issue.
Another $125 million will be used for economic development plans in South Jersey, restoration of inland waterways and lakes and cleanup hazardous waste sites.
On the local level, ballot proposals authorizing the Board of Freeholders in Passaic County to raise taxes for buying open space and developing parks apparently squeaked through Tuesday, officials said yesterday.
According to unofficial returns, a measure to allow property taxes to rise as much as 2 cents to buy land was approved by 600 votes out of more than 80,000 cast. A second measure to allow a similar increase for park development passed by 338 votes. The tax increase could raise more than $9 million a year, said Robert Calise, the county's finance director. A tally of absentee ballots will not available until next week.
In Monmouth County, voters approved a similar tax increase by a vote of 140,000 to 51,000.

HEADLINE: In Toulouse, High Culture Embraces High Tech

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: TOULOUSE, France

 BODY:
"The paradox of Toulouse," Mayor Dominique Baudis says of this southern French city of 600,000 people, "is its combination of one of the most complete heritages from the past and the most advanced technology in all of France, all in the same place."
France may eventually bankrupt itself trying to keep up at both ends of the time scale, but the results here are unusual. 
 At the high-tech end, near the city's airport, two huge aircraft manufacturers, Airbus and Aerospatiale, dominate a Silicon Valley-like landscape.
At the historical end, in the ancient streets of the center of the city, rises the terraced spire of the 12th-century Romanesque Basilica of St. Sernin, the most celebrated of a cluster of churches and monasteries that made Toulouse a major stop on the medieval pilgrimage route to the shrine of St. James of Compostela.
For two weeks in October, the two faces of the city turned toward a celebration of musical instruments that were at the summit of the art of mechanical engineering until the Industrial Revolution -- the historic pipe organs in St. Sernin and a dozen other city churches -- with the first international organ festival of Toulouse.
"We worked on this festival for 20 years," said Mayor Baudis, 49, before the final concert. "My thinking was that we had 20 historic organs in the city, more than in any other city in France, and that we ought to make the most of the legacy. I wanted this festival to be for the organ what the Salzburg Festival is for the opera."
At least 10,000 people came to the festival's 21 concerts, paying $17 a seat at most of them. Both the city and the national Government also contributed millions of dollars to repair or restore a dozen of the historic organs.
Just to restore the famous three-keyboard, 54-stop instrument in St. Sernin, a symphonic organ built by Aristide Cavaille-Coll in 1890, cost $720,000, evenly divided between city and state, said Jan Willem Jansen, one of the church's organists, who also helped run the festival.
Thanking the Mayor for the city's support, Mr. Jansen said the festival would be repeated next year. "The organ is, if not exactly a marginal instrument, one that needs, perhaps, a second wind these days," he said.
They do not build organs in Toulouse these days, but airplanes have figured importantly in the city's economy ever since the days when the author Antoine de Saint-Exupery was a pilot based here.
Airbus Industrie, a consortium of four European aviation companies, is working on the design for a new plane to succeed the Boeing 747, currently the largest jumbo jet.
Aerospatiale, which owns 37.9 percent of the consortium and does the final assembly of most Airbus planes here, is planning to merge with the privately owned Dassault Aviation as a public stock company next year.
Under pressure to compete more efficiently, it has reduced the size of the labor force by 17 percent over the past three years, mainly by attrition, and unemployment in the Toulouse area is now about the same as the French national average -- 12.5 percent.
"We don't know yet if the merger will bring further cuts, but everybody is nervous," said a union official who asked not to be identified.
But in this city, people recognize that technological advances sometimes have their limits. The organ restorers at St. Sernin, Jean-Loup Boisseau and Bertrand Cattiaux, collaborated in a partly unsuccessful attempt to computerize the mechanical components of the organ at Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris in 1992. Here, they left well enough alone.

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTIONS: THE STATES -- THE INITIATIVES;
In California, Foes of Affirmative Action See a New Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

 BODY:
Supporters of a measure to dismantle state-sponsored affirmative action programs in California predicted yesterday that its approval would begin a new era of equal opportunity by wiping out preferences based on race or sex in public hiring, contracting and college admissions.
But civil rights advocates said that the results did not necessarily foreshadow a surge of opposition to affirmative action in other states or in Congress. 
 California approved the measure, Proposition 209, on Tuesday by a vote of 54 percent to 46 percent.
The measure was supposed to take effect immediately, but critics, including minority contractors, filed a lawsuit yesterday in Federal District Court in San Francisco to block enforcement. The suit maintained that the measure denied "equal protection of the laws" to women and members of minority groups in violation of the 14th Amendment to the Federal Constitution.
On the other hand, the Pacific Legal Foundation, a conservative group representing supporters of Proposition 209, filed a suit in state court in Sacramento yesterday, seeking prompt enforcement.
The proposition amends the California Constitution to say, "The state shall not discriminate against, or grant preferential treatment to, any individual or group on the basis of race, sex, color, ethnicity or national origin in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting." The new ban also applies to cities, counties, public schools and public colleges. It does not affect any court order or consent decree or any act required as a condition of receiving Federal money.
The measure means, for example, that the University of California may not consider race or sex as a factor in student admissions and that city governments may not set aside contracts for businesses owned by black or Hispanic people.
The measure was one of 90 initiatives put to voters across the country on Tuesday. California and Arizona voted to legalize the use of marijuana as medicine to combat nausea or alleviate pain, and in California supporters celebrated by smoking marijuana cigarettes. Florida rejected a tax on sugar producers to create revenue to help clean up the Everglades. Maine rejected a ban on clear-cutting of forests.
In California, Gov. Pete Wilson and Attorney General Daniel E. Lungren hailed the vote for Proposition 209 and vowed to resist legal challenges.
Bob Dole had endorsed the California measure, and Mr. Wilson had hoped to use it to mobilize support for Republicans in the election.
"Beginning today," Mr. Wilson said, "Californians will be judged by one standard and one alone: their individual merit. I can think of no better way to reinstill the basic American principle of equality for all under the law."
The campaign against affirmative action has had particular resonance in California, where such programs have been hotly debated for nearly two decades. Most recently, in July 1995, the University of California Board of Regents voted to curtail affirmative action. Opposition to affirmative action was a cornerstone of Mr. Wilson's brief Presidential campaign, and he championed the ballot initiative.
Robert K. Best, president of the Pacific Legal Foundation, said: "California initiatives tend to be trend-setters. When California moves with a populist initiative on an issue high on the public agenda, it is often mimicked in other states."
But civil rights advocates and educators said it was important not to exaggerate the measure's effect.
Mary Frances Berry, chairwoman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, and Wade J. Henderson, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a coalition of national organizations, said yesterday that they did not expect a wave of similar measures.
"This issue did not go anywhere in the Presidential campaign," Ms. Berry said in an interview. "It didn't seem to help Bob Dole. So for national politicians, there do not seem to be great benefits in pursuing the issue. We have all kinds of evidence of heightened racial tensions in America -- F.B.I. hate crime statistics, church fires, a riot the other day in St. Petersburg, Fla., continuing fallout from the O. J. Simpson verdict. I don't see anybody in Congress who thinks they could win fame and fortune by leading an anti-affirmative action campaign."
Mr. Henderson said that women emerged as a powerful force in this election, and that as a result politicians might be wary of attacking affirmative action programs, which often benefit women. He added that President Clinton had deflected anger over the issue with his strategy of "Mend it, don't end it."
David R. Merkowitz, a spokesman for the American Council on Education, an umbrella group for the nation's colleges and universities, said that although he was disappointed by the vote in California, universities would remain committed to the goal of affirmative action. "It in no way changes our position on affirmative action and racial diversity," he said. "We will work with our member institutions in California to find ways to maintain access to higher education for all groups and to promote diversity, which we regard as a key ingredient in educational quality."
Richard C. Atkinson, president of the University of California, said the university "will comply with the law." In a letter yesterday to university officials, the provost, C. Judson King, said, "Effective immediately, campuses may no longer use race, ethnicity, sex or national origin" as a criterion for selecting students.
But Mr. Atkinson said the university would find ways to admit "greater numbers of disadvantaged young people" -- for example, by working with elementary and secondary schools to prepare such youngsters for college.
Nancy M. Zirkin, a lobbyist at the American Association of University Women, predicted that Proposition 209 would have "a very minor impact on Congress." In the last two years, she said, proposals to ban affirmative action did not make much progress on Capitol Hill, and she does not expect them to win more support in the new Congress.
Governor Wilson issued an executive order yesterday directing state agencies to identify programs that grant or encourage preferences based on race or sex. At the same time, he said, state agencies should try to "recruit qualified applicants from all segments of the relevant work force."
Here is a summary of results on other ballot questions.
 
Marijuana
The California measure permitting use of marijuana for medical purposes prevailed by a vote of 56 percent to 44 percent; the vote in Arizona was 65 percent to 35 percent.
The California initiative says, "No physician in this state shall be punished, or denied any right or privilege, for having recommended marijuana to a patient for medical purposes." It does not require doctors to prescribe marijuana.
The Arizona measure says that any doctor licensed to practice in the state may prescribe marijuana to treat a disease or to relieve the pain and suffering of a patient who is seriously or terminally ill.
Federal officials vehemently opposed both measures, but it is unclear whether Federal authorities will take action against doctors or patients in either state.
Mr. Lungren, the Attorney General of California, said, "We're going to have a very confused legal situation here," because doctors who recommend marijuana may find themselves in violation of Federal law.
 
Term Limits
Voters in nine states signaled support for Congressional term limits. But five other states rejected such limits.
The nine states expressing support were Alaska, Arkansas, Colorado, Idaho, Maine, Missouri, Nebraska, Nevada and South Dakota. Those rejecting them were Montana, North Dakota, Oregon, Washington and Wyoming.
The United States Supreme Court ruled last year that, in the absence of a constitutional amendment, neither states nor Congress could set term limits for members of Congress.
Typically, the measures on state ballots this year asked candidates to pledge support for Congressional term limits. Those who refuse to do so or who violate such a promise after making it would have their positions noted on the ballot in future elections.
 
Wildlife and the Environment
In Florida, voters rejected a proposal to impose a tax of one penny on each pound of raw sugar grown in the Everglades region. The money would have been used for conservation and protection of the Everglades. At the same time, Florida amended the state Constitution to require a two-thirds majority of voters to approve new taxes.
Robert H. Buker, vice president of the United States Sugar Corporation in Clewiston, Fla., the state's largest sugar producer, said: "Floridians clearly said no to higher taxation. Everyone has a desire for a cleaner environment, but there is a heavy antitax sentiment here. The sugar tax would have put many of Florida's sugar producers out of business. They could not have competed with producers in other states and foreign countries."
Rindy M. O'Brien, vice president of the Wilderness Society, said: "The sugar industry poured a lot of money into this campaign. Advertising determined the outcome, persuading voters to go in and vote against the initiative. If we had been able to match the industry dollar for dollar, the outcome would have been different."
In Maine, a proposed ban on clear-cutting on 10 million acres of northern forests failed after the most expensive referendum in the state's history. Among the opponents were the paper industry, which spent more than $5 million, and Gov. Angus King, who said the plan would have cost the state thousands of jobs.
"The gun that has been pointed at the head of the Maine economy is now uncocked, unloaded and off the table," Mr. King said yesterday.
Among Maine residents voting on the issue, 47 percent expressed support for a competing measure that would reduce but not ban clear-cutting. This measure, the Compact for Maine's Forests, was developed by timber companies and some environmental groups, with support from Mr. King. It will be put on the ballot in a future election.
Robert C. Deis, a spokesman for Citizens for a Healthy Forest and Economy, a coalition of business and environmental groups, said, "We are very pleased that the citizens of Maine rejected the extreme proposal to ban clear-cutting and supported the competing measure." Ms. O'Brien of the Wilderness Society said she did not regard the outcome as a setback for environmentalists. Indeed, she said, the strong support for the compromise measure shows that Maine has made "a major advance over where it was 5 or 10 years ago."
Voters approved ballot measures to place limits on hunting in Alaska, Colorado, Massachusetts and Washington State. Idaho and Michigan rejected measures that would have limited hunting. Oregon voters upheld a measure, adopted in 1994, that bans the use of bait and hounds to hunt black bears and cougars.
Wayne P. Pacelle, vice president of the Humane Society of the United States, said ,"This is a strong rejection of inhumane and unsportsmanlike hunting practices that inflict needless suffering on animals," he said.
 
Other Measures
Colorado rejected a proposed amendment to the state Constitution declaring that parents had inalienable rights to "direct and control the upbringing, education, values and discipline of their children."
California rejected two proposals to impose tough new regulations on health maintenance organizations.
Crime victims won new protections in Connecticut, Indiana, Nevada, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Carolina and Virginia.
Casinos and other gambling proposals lost out in Ohio, Arkansas, Colorado, Nebraska and Washington.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Operating Room

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
So, to sum it all up with clarity and charity: The American people chose as President a man most of them do not trust and who has not revealed his goals for his new administration, except to build some kind of cockamamie bridge. And, God bless America, they were right -- given the circumstances.
As I walked to cast my grumpy vote I was mindful of the time a couple of years ago when the doctor told me I had to have coronary bypass surgery. That seemed outrageous. I demanded to know the alternative. He informed me immediately. Given the circumstances I leapt toward the operating room. Now the blood courses like a wild torrent through my body lithe and lean. 
 Facing the alternative offered by the current attitudes, agenda and candidates of the Republican Party, the voters decided reasonably if not joyously to give themselves over once more to a Clinton administration.
That decision was set in motion soon after the Republican Congressional victory in 1994. Speaker Gingrich happily cried out that the new American revolution had arrived. That made his popularity with the public last about 10 minutes.
President Clinton then understood that America wanted a non-revolutionary, all neat and polite, to stand between it and Congress. He knew exactly the man.
Republicans could have saved themselves had they freed the party from its ideologues and modified hard-line positions on abortion, gun control, immigration. But no. Then they came up with a candidate whose idea of leadership was to repeat the same phrases three or four times without drawing breath, so that the stupids out there could grasp them.
For the past four years, the two parties have been doing everything possible to destroy each other. Now we come to the traditional post-election rituals.
Democrats and Republicans will prattle awhile of how they will cooperate like mad. Nobody fooled, nobody hurt -- a little non-snarl time lets everybody pause for another ritual, telling the winner how to be a big success after he takes the oath.
I have only one suggestion, Mr. President. Be candid with yourself, what you have done and are doing.
Decide for yourself whether John Huang or anybody else broke the law against mixing fund-raising with political dealing. If so, get rid of all those involved. If you had any hint, say so. It is the best way to avoid the impalement for which your enemies plan and slaver.
You have gone back on your promise to use American economic pressure to diminish repression in China. Your aides say you will break your promise not to keep American troops in Bosnia for more than a year. Facing yourself: Can you do nothing to salvage your name?
You have promised to try to find jobs for people thrown off the welfare rolls under the bill you signed. Will you keep your word? Tell yourself, then us.
Do you mean it when you say affirmative action should be mended, not ended, or will you go with the flow to kill it? Did your own contacts in Arkansas and the color of your skin not affirmatively help your career?
Will you become America's leader against drugs? Devote the time and heart needed? If so, why did you not lead the fight against the near-legalization in California of marijuana, the proven gateway drug to hard drugs and mean deaths?
You know that money from tax-free foundations, particularly those of George Soros, pushed the marijuana proposition to success. Do you also know that the legalizers expect to put across more such legislation in states across America -- using more from Mr. Soros and other folk whose own children are not likely to wind up in gutters, brains crippled by drugs?
What does your mirror tell you about how hard and often you will expose that?
Will you stop pretending nuclear danger has disappeared, and talk to Americans about how China sells weapon-grade nuclear materials and techniques to rogue states and the danger of nuclear smuggling from Russia to terrorists?
So on. The President can create a second term worthy of the pride of the nation and his descendants. But he needs inner and public candor to achieve it. Whether God's blessing on America will include that, we cannot tell, but Mr. Clinton can.

HEADLINE: New Cabinet In Japan: Quite a Lot Like the Old

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto was formally re-elected in Parliament today, inaugurating a loose coalition Government that says it is serious about streamlining the national bureaucracy.
Mr. Hashimoto's re-election, after his Liberal Democratic Party's victory in general elections last month, marks a return after three years to the customary situation in Japan in which the Liberal Democrats hold all the Government posts. 
 In the new Cabinet, which Mr. Hashimoto made public today, Foreign Minister Yukihiko Ikeda retains his post, as does Seiroku Kajiyama, the chief Cabinet secretary. Other Cabinet ministers are new, but they are mostly figures who have been in and out of similar posts before and are not expected to shake the Government up dramatically.
"A Cabinet that may be forced to make severe choices has been formed," Mr. Kajiyama said, adding that the new administration's most important challenges will be to streamline Government and bolster the national finances.
Mr. Hashimoto, 59, bowed to supporters in Parliament today and did not make a speech, but he has suggested that he intends to press ahead with economic deregulation and Government restructuring. Commentators have been skeptical, though.
It is expected to become more clear in the next few months how strenuously Mr. Hashimoto will push for economic and political changes. All parties, including the Liberal Democrats, campaigned on platforms of far-reaching change, but among the top few parties the Liberal Democrats seemed least enthusiastic about the idea.
Mr. Hashimoto is scheduled to meet President Clinton at a conference of Asia-Pacific leaders in the Philippines this month, and the Government here hopes to forge a strong relationship with Washington during Mr. Clinton's second term. Mr. Hashimoto has been a tough negotiator during trade disputes, but he is a strong supporter of the American-Japanese security relationship.
The new Government is a bit of an oddity, more than a minority Government but less than a full-fledged coalition.
The Liberal Democrats governed Japan as a virtual one-party state for most of the nation's postwar history, but for the last two years they had to share Cabinet posts with other parties to remain in the Government. In last month's elections, they won 239 seats in the 500-member lower house, the more important chamber in Parliament, just a dozen short of an absolute majority and many more than any other political party.
So the Liberal Democrats worked out agreements with two smaller parties, the Social Democrats and New Party Sakigake, which between them have 17 seats. The two smaller parties are supposed to cooperate with Mr. Hashimoto in most respects, but they will not have any Cabinet posts.
In addition, some independents will support Mr. Hashimoto. As a result, Mr. Hashimoto was elected Prime Minister today with 262 votes, a slim but workable margin that suggests he will be able to hold on to power for some time -- though perhaps not for the full four years until the time when the next general elections must be held.
Among other major posts, the Finance Minister's job went to Hiroshi Mitsuzaka, a 69-year-old party leader who has already served as Foreign Minister and in other top positions. The new Minister of International Trade and Industry is Shinji Sato, 64, who is a former Transport Minister and the son of former Prime Minister Eisaku Sato.
Kabun Muto, 69, a former Foreign Minister, was named head of the Management and Control Agency, with responsibility for overseeing plans to streamline the bureaucracy.
Traditionally, Cabinet secretaries have often been little more than figureheads, with the real decisions made by career bureaucrats in the ministries.
But Mr. Hashimoto appointed seasoned officials not just to the top posts in each ministry but also to the posts of parliamentary vice minister, apparently in a signal that he wishes to exert greater political control over the bureaucracy.

HEADLINE: 3d Quarter Saw Only Slight Rise in Productivity

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
The productivity of the American workplace barely increased last summer, the Government said today in a report that contained hints of possible inflationary pressures.
The Labor Department reported that nonfarm productivity -- output per number of hours worked -- inched up just two-tenths of 1 percent at a seasonally adjusted annual rate from July through September. 
 The growth, short of the rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in the April-June quarter, was the slowest since productivity fell 1.1 percent in the final three months of 1995. Many analysts had expected a decline of about two-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter.
"It confirms we have a classic late-cycle slowing of productivity under way," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
Mr. Roach, who had previously said that the economy was entering a period of markedly improved productivity from corporate job cuts and restructuring, now said he believed that the earlier efficiencies were temporary.
"Companies have not really uncovered the Holy Grail on what makes their processes more efficient," he said.
Economists consider increases in productivity to be a critical factor in raising Americans' standard of living. The sluggish growth in productivity for more than two decades has been cited as a reason for stagnant personal incomes.
Productivity increases averaged just 1 percent from 1973 to 1995. That was only about a third of the growth rate of the 1950's and 1960's.
Greater efficiency means businesses can increase wages without raising prices, because workers are producing more with the same amount of work. If unmatched by productivity gains, increases in labor costs must often be passed on to consumers.
Indeed, the report showed that unit labor costs -- typically two-thirds of a product's price -- shot up at a 3.7 percent rate in the summer. Costs had risen 3.3 percent in the second quarter and just 1.5 percent in the first.
"That's where inflation starts," Mr. Roach said. "We're seeing yet another early warning sign."
In the report, the Labor Department said output rose at a 2.5 percent rate in summer, down from 3.2 percent from April through June. The number of hours worked increased at a rate of 2.2 percent, compared with 2.4 percent the previous three months.
Manufacturing productivity increased at a 6.3 percent rate, more than twice the 2.9 percent rate in the second quarter and the fastest pace since a 6.7 percent rate in the first three months of 1994. Manufacturing represents about 18 percent of American employment.
Total business productivity, including farming, was up at a rate of three-tenths of 1 percent. It had shot up at a 1.1 percent rate in the second quarter and a 2 percent rate in the first.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "U.S. Productivity" shows index of output per hour of all people in nonfarm business from 1992 to 1996. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: In America;
The Farce Before the Storm

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Fasten your seat belts and shoulder harnesses, you are going on a wild, wild ride. Forget the nice-nice talk coming out of Washington. The daggers are only temporarily sheathed. To get from here to Election Day 2000, voters will have to travel a chaotic and confusing route through a succession of political combat zones.
At the moment, perennial warriors like Al D'Amato, Newt Gingrich and Trent Lott are trying on camouflage outfits. Senator D'Amato, whose Whitewater hearings backfired, causing more damage to him than to the President, is now saying, with a straight face: "It's not the time to be looking at investigations. . . . We should leave that in the hands of the special prosecutor and shouldn't be attempting to substitute our judgment." 
 Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Lott are talking about compromising and finding "common ground" on tough issues with Bill Clinton and the Democrats. Any day now I expect them to show up in the Oval Office, drape their arms around the President and sob in unison, "We love you, man!"
This is the farce before the storm.
Reality is somewhere in the high-pitched wail of Ross Perot. That's where you will hear, if you can stand it, serious warnings about some of the conflicts to come. The lineup of existing and potential investigations into Whitewater, the firings in the White House travel office, the misuse of F.B.I. files, Democratic fund-raising practices and other matters is daunting. And there is every danger that a circus-like atmosphere will surround the Supreme Court hearing early next year on whether a sexual-harassment suit against Mr. Clinton should go forward while he is in office.
Bipartisanship in the face of such matters is a fantasy. Mr. Perot believes the country is headed toward a constitutional crisis that could take two or more years to resolve. "The last thing we need," he said, "is to lose two more years while our Government is frozen because the President is being investigated."
Meanwhile, despite all the talk about a centrist consensus, there are sharp and sometimes bitter divisions among the voters and within both parties. Daniel Yankelovich, the president of Public Agenda, a nonpartisan research organization, said in an interview more than a week ago that he believed Tuesday's election would be remembered for "institutionalizing the gender gap."
Women have not been nearly as willing as men to buy into the idea of dismantling government. Women have tended to be much more concerned about carefully defining the role of government and maintaining a social safety net.
Said Mr. Yankelovich: "The question from women is, 'What should government do?' We never had that debate and we are going to have to have it now because of the gender gap."
The views of a large percentage of women voters were reflected in a number of issues that candidates from both parties have recently rallied around: protecting Medicare and Medicaid, defending the environment, investing in education, increasing the minimum wage, making health coverage more portable.
Robert Borosage, co-director of the Campaign for America's Future, a progressive advocacy group, said, "Just four years ago, that would have been called a liberal agenda."
Even as the Republican Party is trying to figure out how to appeal more effectively to women, its far-right wing is hard at work in its search for a suitable troglodyte to support in 2000. The Christian Coalition's president, Pat Robertson, was quoted yesterday in The Times as saying, "We were not consulted on this campaign. We were peripheral."
He said that wouldn't happen again.
While the G.O.P. fights that one out, the Democrats will be confronted by huge numbers of voters who are upset by the Administration's lurch to the right and the economic inequality that persists despite the President's claims that the economy is doing swell. And Big Labor is back and wants its voice heard. Al Gore will have plenty of company in his quest for the nomination.
All of this will be played out against the mania that is bound to accompany the arrival of the 21st century. Hang on. You have never been on a ride like this before.

HEADLINE: Manufactured Home Makes New Bid for Chateau Properties

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Manufactured Home Communities Inc., the mobile home operator controlled by Sam Zell, the Chicago financier, yesterday withdrew its hostile tender offer for the rival Chateau Properties Inc. and proposed a revised bid aimed specifically at winning over Chateau's largest shareholders.
The new deal offers Chateau investors a choice between $26 a share in cash, the same as Manufactured's original offer, or a sweetened package of convertible preferred securities intended to appeal to those Chateau shareholders who want to defer taxes. J. P. Morgan, which is advising Manufactured, values the convertible securities at $26 apiece. 
 "The offer now puts all parties involved on an equal footing in a transaction that creates the company with the best assets, the respect of the investment community and the best position to dominate this market," said David A. Helfand, the chief executive of Manufactured.
The new offer, with a total value of $387 million, is yet another attempt by Manufactured to head off a merger between Chateau and ROC Communities Inc., another mobile home operator. Analysts have valued that deal at $24 a share or less, depending on the stock prices of the two companies.
In a statement yesterday, Chateau said it would review Manufactured's offer "in due course." So far, Chateau has refused to have any discussions with Manufactured, saying it was not for sale.
Almost 60 percent of Chateau is controlled by holders of operating partnership units, known as O.P. units, securities created by real estate partnerships to avoid steep taxes when they convert their holdings into publicly traded real estate investment trusts, or REIT's. The units have no voting rights until converted to common shares, which creates a tax liability for their holder.
Unit holders had complained that Manufactured's original deal, which offered Chateau investors $26 a share in cash or 1.15 Manufactured shares or O.P. units, was worth less to them than to shareholders.
If they took the cash, they would incur a hefty tax liability. But the stock swap option would give them securities valued at just $22.43 apiece based on Manufactured's closing price yesterday -- a 14 percent discount to the cash offer.
Since it made its original offer in August, Manufactured has been negotiating with several of Chateau's unit holders in an effort to address their concerns. The company's sweetened offer gives the unit holders tax shelter, an option to sell their Manufactured units back to Manufactured should the price drop below $26, and a $2-a-unit annual dividend, better than the $1.62 dividend they would get in a Chateau-ROC merger.
"From the Chateau unit holders' perspective, it's a significantly better offer than what had been on the table previously," said Jim Sullivan, an analyst at Greenstreet Advisers, a real estate advisory firm in Newport Beach, Calif. Manufactured has not had any discussions with John A. Boll, chairman, founder and largest O.P. unit holder of Chateau. Mr. Boll holds 3,378,906 O.P. units, or about 23 percent of the total shares and units outstanding.
Mr. Sullivan said Mr. Zell's new offer could create a division between Mr. Boll and his co-founder, J. Peter Ministrelli, who is no longer active in Chateau, and other unit holders. Together, the two men own roughly 5.75 million O.P. units, or about 39 percent of total shares and units outstanding. Other investors hold the remaining 3.3 million units.
"From the minority unit holders' standpoint, economic considerations are paramount, and Manufactured's new offer is attractive economically," Mr. Sullivan said. "Economics are important to Mr. Boll and Mr. Ministrelli, too, but there appears to be other factors which are affecting their decision-making."
Manufactured also said yesterday that it had withdrawn its request for a preliminary injunction to block the Chateau-ROC merger.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Pace Declined During September

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Consumers remained cautious as the summer turned to fall.
For the first time in more than three years, borrowers in September paid off more credit card and other nonmortgage debt than they newly borrowed and installment loans declined 2.7 percent at an annual rate. 
 The Federal Reserve's midafternoon report helped explain why household spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, slowed, braking the economy's growth sharply this summer. For the holiday shopping season to improve over a poor 1995 Christmas, consumers would have to reopen their pocketbooks. And that is exactly what most economists are expecting.
"It's a voluntary, temporary pullback," contended Christine Chmura, chief economist at Crestar Bank in Richmond. "The economy is in good shape, which suggests that consumers are just pausing."
Indeed, retailers reported a good start to the fall, with sales in October up significantly nearly across the board.
The decline was in keeping with other reports that showed virtually no change in personal spending in September and a summer quarter in which consumption growth decelerated to a pace of just four-tenths of 1 percent from 3.4 percent in the spring.
It was also consistent with a modest reported tightening of bank lending standards at a time of record credit card delinquencies.
"We're going to see the consumer retrenching a bit," said Martin Regalia, economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce. But he pointed to growing employment, continued high confidence, swelling stock market wealth and even a jump in the savings rate as factors arguing against a serious spending slowdown.
The Fed's report showed declines in automobile debt to a pace of 3.1 percent and in a category that includes education, mobile homes, vacations and boats to a rate of 9.1 percent.
The third major category, revolving debt, advanced but at only a 2.6 percent pace following 6.7 percent growth in August and 18.9 percent in July. This was regarded as a clear sign of retrenchment even though this statistical series has become muddied by increasing use of credit cards for convenience or to get such benefits as frequent-flier miles rather than for actual borrowing.
According to Kenneth R. Crone, a senior vice president at Visa U.S.A., 60 percent of card users now pay their entire balance within 30 days, up from 50 percent five years ago.
It is also hard to tell "confident" borrowing from "distress" borrowing, analysts say, especially since the Fed provides only a net change in outstanding debt with no breakdown of extensions and repayments.
The most recent decline was in May 1993, when the economy was still expanding at a subpar pace following a slight first-quarter decline in total economic activity. Consumer installment debt, generally viewed as an indicator that tracks the economy's current performance, also fell during several months of the 1990-91 recession.
On a year-to-year basis, growth of installment debt peaked at about 15 percent in July 1995 and has now eased to 9 percent, Ms. Chmura calculated.
The decline in automobile credit was $1 billion in the latest month, an amount exactly offset by the rise in revolving credit, the report also showed. The "other" category slumped $2.6 billion to account for the overall decline to $1,172,500,000, from $1,175,100,000 in August.
"In the long term, this should brace the economy," said Oscar Gonzalez of John Hancock Financial Services in Boston, referring to the trend of debt deceleration. "In the short term, it reduces the threat posed two years ago when borrowing and debt had reached unsustainable levels."
Credit unions fared best last month, raising their outstanding volume by $1.1 billion while savings institutions and commercial banks added $800 million each. Nonfinancial businesses had a $2.4 billion reduction.
The Fed's report also showed that interest rates on new cars at auto finance companies edged up to 10.52 percent from 10.49 percent, while the average maturity rose to 51.9 months from 51.4. The average size of a car loan was $17,182, up $255.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Consumer Borrowing" shows net change in total installment credit outstanding from Aptil 1995 to Sept. 1996. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)
