HEADLINE: Focusing on Black South Africa;
Returning After 8 Years, Kodak Runs Into White Anger

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 7

 BODY:
When most blacks here want a picture of a birthday party, a child's first day at school, or even a new dress, they rarely take it themselves. In the townships, a camera is an expensive and sometimes daunting piece of equipment, something to be handled by a professional like Innocent Mahoa.
Mr. Mahoa, 21, is one of thousands of street photographers who charge roughly 85 cents a photo -- a pittance, to be sure, especially when customers order only one. But the Eastman Kodak Company, returning to South Africa after an absence of nearly eight years when it agreed to observe sanctions against apartheid, is trying to make sure that every nickel-and-dime photo opportunity is another Kodak moment. 
 "I am not doing this only to make a profit," Mr. Mahoa says. "I want to prove to my children that photography is important. That it is not for white people only."
This is music to the ears of Kodak, which is vigorously pursuing the black consumer market while it tries to win back the favor of whites, some of whom resent it for leaving in the first place. When Kodak left the country in 1987, it had 60 percent of the film market. When it returned in 1994, it had only 4 percent -- all of it gray-market purchases for professional photographers.
The Fuji Photo Film Company and, to a lesser extent, Agfa, a unit of the Bayer Group, and Konica had stepped into the gap. And since 1994, despite the company's world-famous name, Kodak's market share has returned to only about 12 percent.
Part of the reason is that the Fuji distributorship, owned by the Premier Group, a large food, pharmaceutical and retailing conglomerate, has a tight grip on the South African market. It owns or has contracts with 600 of the country's 950 small labs, requiring that they use only Fuji paper and chemicals and stock 80 percent Fuji film, according to surveys by S.A. Photo, an industry magazine.
And, as Kodak acknowledges, there is lingering animosity among some whites. "We stock their film because tourists ask for it," said the manager of a Foto First lab in the wealthy northern suburbs here. "But a lot of people here won't buy Kodak because it left the country. Fuji stuck it out during the bad times."
That is a painful lesson many American corporations that left during sanctions have learned. There is little gratitude for having done the right thing: the Mandela Government gives no special breaks to companies that honored sanctions. Whites, who still have most of the disposable income, are loyal to companies that stayed. Blacks, only now getting a piece of the economic pie, don't know the brands that left.
"A whole generation has never been exposed to Kodak," said Brian Schwartz, who owns a new Kodak Express lab in the Woodmead Shopping Center, in a white neighborhood in northeastern Johannesburg.
Yet some companies that left prospered, finding ways to continue selling their products. Coca-Cola, for instance, moved only to Swaziland, a small independent nation surrounded by South Africa, and distributed through South African Breweries. Pepsico truly left, and its market share plummeted.
Pepsi is trying to come back, touting itself as "the drink of liberation," buying lots of billboards in the townships and using prominent black Americans like Whitney Houston and Johnnie Cochran as spokesmen. Coke still dominates the market.
Unlike cola, however, film has until now been a business for white customers. Nearly all the small labs are in white neighborhoods, or in downtown shopping areas patronized by people of all races. During Kodak's absence, Fuji and Agfa did little to expand the customer base. Roughly the same number of rolls -- 10 million -- were sold in this country last year as in 1990. That's about a quarter of a roll a person a year, compared with roughly two rolls a person in the United States.
To expand, Kodak is franchising its own small labs, like Mr. Schwartz's, that stock only Kodak products. It hopes to have 110 by 1998, but it's slow going. Virtually every mall already has a Fuji-connected lab, and there are very few malls in black areas.
Kodak is also mailing free test rolls of its newest slide film to professional photographers. It is advertising on television. But the ads, unlike Pepsi's, are nonracial and apolitical -- the same "Kodak for the Moments of Your Life" ones used in the United States.
Its most important strategy, however, said Ron Crane, managing director of Kodak South Africa, is to encourage blacks to shoot pictures. "Seventy percent of South Africans have never taken their first picture," he said.
In areas where blacks shop, Kodak is selling rudimentary plastic 35-millimeter cameras with batteries and film for about $27. In two places, they are marked: "Uses Kodak Film," a calculated statement since any 35-millimeter film would fit.
Fuji's reaction to the threat is dismissive. Kodak executives and outside analysts say that Fuji is arrogant, and a conversation with Malcolm Ryan, managing director of Fuji South Africa, seemed to bear that out.
"Obviously, as a household name, they are going to gain some market share," he said. "But I don't think it will be significant. I believe they'll take it from Agfa, since their 35 percent share is unreal.
"We're the leader," he said. "It's for them to chase us."
Mr. Ryan also suggested that appealing to black customers was futile. "We've done a lot of study of that market," he said. "Blacks don't see their own past as a happy memory, so they don't want photos of it. For example, they don't see their kid going to school on the first day as a happy thing, because they have to go to a township school or walk five miles to school."
Asked about that, Innocent M. Ndlovu, Kodak's man in charge of reaching out to street photographers like Mr. Mahoa, sneered. "What a load of rubbish," he said. "You can see why they've never shown any commitment to the black market."
Calculating that its best point of entry is street photographers like Mr. Mahoa, Kodak is going to great lengths to win them over. A two-month survey by the company found that what they wanted most were lessons in photography and business, and those can be pretty basic. Public education for blacks has been bad for decades, and some street photographers can barely read and write.
But Kodak has done things in a highly visible way, bringing over living legends like Gordon Parks to teach workshops.
"I learned from him to change the aperture when the weather changes," said Midion Mthimkhulu, who was sitting by a waterfall in a downtown park, hoping for customers to pose beside it.
Kodak has also had senior officers of local banks explain how to open a checking account. It offers kits to registered freelancers that include not only Kodak camera bags to spread the brand name, but also business cards and invoice books.
Perhaps most important, the company has developed a special film, ProFoto II, for them. Its emulsion chemistry is adjusted for taking black faces in bright sunlight. (Professional photographers all over Africa complain about the difficulty of getting such high-contrast exposures right.)
The film is also trimmed long, so that a careful photographer can get 40 shots from a roll of 36. And, in a price-sensitive market, it costs only $2.75 a roll -- compared with about $5 for Kodak Gold and $3.50 to $4.50 for Fuji or Agfa.
"We obviously try to keep it as far away from the amateur market as we possibly can," said Anthony Doyle, Kodak's marketing manager. "To buy it, they have to show a card saying they're in our freelance program."
Kodak also supports labs catering to street photographers, whose customers typically return in a day or two to look at the picture and pay for it. Thomas Thosa's lab on Bree Street downtown offers inexpensive processing for ProFoto II, plus a lounge, kitchen and lockers.
"A lot of the photographers live in squatter camps, and the postal service is no good there," Mr. Ndlovu explained. "And they can leave their gear in the box. There are a lot of robberies on the trains to the townships."
Mr. Thosa, a former street photographer, appreciates Kodak's attitude. "I come from a background where blacks weren't supposed to know anything," he said. "We buy photographs, but we don't think we can take them.
"Kodak explains how it works, and they say 'You need this thing -- when a child is born, you need a picture.' And besides -- a lot of blacks are moving into the middle class. They can afford to go on holidays to Kruger Park, or to the beach. There are no street photographers there."
Right now, said Mark Young, S.A. Photo's editor, customers say Kodak still seems disorganized. Its expanding sales force has trouble returning phone calls and getting deliveries in on time. "But I imagine they'll get that sorted out," he said.
Harvey Thomas, the publisher, said he expected Kodak's growth to take time. "They're fighting for market sectors, and they didn't choose the battleground," he said, adding that in 10 years' time, Kodak may be the film of choice. "But the Americans are going to have to spend a lot of money to get back," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Kodak is aggeressively courting street photographers like Innocent Mahoa, 21, who take most photos of black South Africans, shooting events like a class portrait in Johannesburg, above, and a used car salesman, below. (Photographs by Graeme Williams for The New York Times)
 
Graphs: "A Re-Emerging Market" shows a breakdown of the film market in South Africa for 1986, 1991 and 1996, (Sources: South African Photography Trade Association (1986), S.A. Photo magazine surveys)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slumps Against Yen After Tokyo Aide's Remark

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The dollar, which has appreciated by roughly 40 percent against the yen in the last 18 months, fell sharply yesterday after a key architect of its rise strongly suggested the yen had fallen far enough.
In comments to Nihon Keizai Shimbun, the leading Japanese financial newspaper, Eisuke Sakakibara, director general of the Finance Ministry's International Finance Bureau, said, "We are not thinking of leading the yen any lower." 
 The dollar, which rose to its highest level in more than three years last week, when it reached 114.92 yen, fell after the remarks were published. Late in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 111.60 yen, down 2.33 yen from 113.93 late Wednesday. During the day, the currency had fallen as low as 111.32 yen.
"The dollar was technically fragile, and the statement from Mr. Sakakibara pushed it over the edge," said Russell LaScala, head of the spot trading desk at Citibank.
Ron Leven, global currency strategist at J. P. Morgan, said the bulk of the dollar selling was done by speculators, not by Japanese investors, who have been big buyers of dollar-denominated assets, particularly United States Treasury securities, for more than a year.
But Mr. LaScala took issue with that view.
"Most of the action we saw was from international investors and the Japanese, who were big sellers of dollars," he said.
Perhaps more important, traders and analysts say, is that the pace of trading, which has been extremely lethargic for much of the year, is beginning to revive. That could mean that volatility in currency movements will return.
"For most of this year we went through a period where the world was confident that all things were converging," said Richard E. Witten, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "Most importantly, that inflation around the world was low. That reduced volatility a great deal. Now we seem to be getting back to a more normal trading market."
To illustrate the dollar's lack of volatility, Mr. Leven said that for the year as a whole up until now, the dollar had traded in a three-pfennig range against the German mark.
"If the dollar doesn't break 1.55 marks by the end of the year, it will be the narrowest range for that rate since 1972, when the dollar started to float," he said.
Late yesterday, the dollar was quoted in New York at 1.5120 marks, down from 1.5175 marks late Wednesday.
Mr. Sakakibara's comments were the first by any official from a major country about the dollar since President Clinton was re-elected on Tuesday, and the first in more than a year that questioned the continued strength of the currency.
Mr. Sakakibara's comments were in contrast to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's most recent statement on the dollar.
Last Friday, Mr. Rubin told reporters at the White House that he believed "in a strong dollar."
Although traders like Mr. LaScala said they expected the dollar to weaken a bit more against the yen, some analysts said Mr. Sakakibara's comments yesterday may have been prompted by recent criticism leveled against Tokyo by C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research organization.
In an article in the current issue of The Economist magazine, Mr. Bergsten, a former Treasury official, accused Japan's Ministry of Finance of seeking a further 10 to 20 percent decline in the value of the yen against the dollar as a way of bolstering economic growth.
But Mr. Leven of J. P. Morgan said the Japanese had not been seeking a weaker yen to increase exports.
"Japanese exporters can compete very nicely with the yen at 90 to 95 to the dollar," he said.
"The reason they are pushing the dollar up is to shore up their fragile banking system."
Mr. Leven said that if the dollar were to weaken below 108 yen, Japanese banks, which are big owners of American assets, would be forced to sell their positions. He said he did not expect those levels to be tested, and suggested that the Bank of Japan would step in to buy dollars in the event they were.
Still, "for the time being the dollar has peaked against the yen," he said. "And longer term, the dollar will go down against the yen. We are still running trade deficits, and Japan is still running surpluses. And over the last 10 to 15 years, deficit-country currencies go down. That is not likely to change in the next five years."

HEADLINE: Stocks Set Record Again As the Dow Passes 6,200

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks set records for a second day yesterday, helped by an optimistic forecast for fourth-quarter sales from the Intel Corporation and a better-than-expected sale of 30-year bonds that sent yields back to eight-month lows.
"The environment is almost ideal" for investing, said Peter Canelo, chief investment strategist at Dean Witter Reynolds. "You've got a benign inflation environment" and a soft economic environment that's about to pick up. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average passed 6,200 for the first time, rising 28.33, to 6,206.04, after reaching an all-time high Wednesday. It was the Dow average's 33d record in 1996. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 3.06, to 727.65, its 31st record of the year. The Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 8.65, to 1,254.14, about 4 points shy of its closing record of 1,258.10. Stocks were buoyed by a rebound in bonds, which erased early losses after the Government sold $10 billion in securities at a maximum yield of 6.62 percent, an indication of strong demand for United States Government debt. Yields slid 8 basis points, to 6.53 percent, from 6.61 percent on Wednesday. The sale was the last of this week's auctions of $38.5 billion of notes and bonds.
"The market is definitely a little at the frothy end, but there is some reason for it, with the election and rates," said Patricia Chadwick, chief investment strategist at Chancellor LGT Asset Management, with $28 billion in assets. "Any concerns about things like health care that Clinton may have threatened are dead."
Intel, the world's largest maker of chips for personal computers, said it expects fourth-quarter sales and gross margin to beat third-quarter levels on increased new orders and strong sales of its Pentium line of computer chips. The company's shares jumped 3 1/4, to 122 1/8, spurring a host of technology shares higher.
"Strength is in technology today," said Edward Riley, chief investment officer at the Bank of Boston Corporation. "It is an industry that people expect will continue to beat numbers." Among PC makers, Gateway 2000 Inc. jumped 4, to 53; Hewlett- Packard Company rose 2 1/2, to 48, and the Compaq Computer Corporation rose 5/8, to 73 7/8.
The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index rose 4.68, or 2.31 percent, to 207.34. The index has jumped 11 percent in the last five days.
The surge in United States stocks has further to go in 1997, according to some of Wall Street's top strategists. Goldman, Sachs & Company's Abby Joseph Cohen, co-head of Goldman's investment policy committee, said the Dow could reach 6,600 in the next six months. Retail shares lost ground amid a spate of mixed forecasts. Best Buy Company, an office products company, and Lowe's Companies, which sells hardware, said earnings would fall short of expectations. Best Buy fell 3 3/4, to 12 1/2, and Lowe's slumped 3 7/8, to 39 1/2.
Limited Inc., which sold a portion of its Intimate Brands division to focus on women's and men's outerwear, said its earnings could rise to 15 cents a share, a penny above analysts' estimates.
Its stock fell 2 1/8, to 18, because its 83 percent owned Intimate Brands Inc. unit, retailer of Victoria's Secret lingerie, said earnings would be lower than expected. Intimate Brands lost 3 1/2, to 16 1/2.
The Lockheed Martin Corporation shares fell 5/8, to 89 3/4, after the General Dynamics Corporation said it would buy two Lockheed units for $450 million. General Dynamics rose 1 1/4, to 68 1/2. The General Re Corporation rose 4 3/8, to 154 3/8, after the company said it earned $2.31 a share, down from $2.39 a share.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Continues to Gain; Coffee Prices Also Increase

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper jumped yesterday for a second day, reaching the highest price in almost two weeks, following a forecast for a smaller surplus than traders previously expected.
On other markets, coffee prices rose. 
 On Wednesday, Bloomsbury Mineral Economics halved its estimate of this year's global copper surplus to 50,000 metric tons. The London-based firm said it had lowered the forecast because global mine and smelter expansions were slowed by strikes, accidents and technology glitches.
The production decline comes at a time of dwindling copper inventories held in exchange warehouses. During the last two months, London Metal Exchange copper stocks plunged 56 percent, to 121,175 metric tons, their lowest since August 1990. A metric ton is 1.1 tons.
"Copper stockpiles will keep falling, even if it's at a slower pace," said Michael Casey, a vice president at Metal Commodities Inc. in St. Louis. While a surplus is still expected, exchange stockpiles may not see the new supply, he said, because "it goes to consumers and bypasses the warehouses."
Copper for December delivery rose 2.9 cents, to 95.55 cents a pound on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the biggest one-day gain since Oct. 8.
Coffee prices surged for the third day, reaching a two-month high, amid concern that record-low exchange stockpiles and the slow pace of imports could cause a shortage in the weeks ahead.
Earlier this week, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York said stockpiles available for delivery to fulfill futures contracts totaled only 804 bags, the lowest since records began in 1980.
Though imports from this year's harvests in Colombia and Central America are starting to arrive, traders say they are already committed to roasters and will not enter exchange stocks.
"There is no available coffee for prompt sales," said Oscar Schapps, a trader at Hencorp Coffee Group in Miami. "There's coffee coming in, but those coffees are already committed."
December coffee rose 3.05 cents, to $1.2735 a pound, the highest price since Aug. 30.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ELECTION: Anatomy of a Loss -- A Special Report;
How Bob Dole's Dream Was Dashed

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
On a gusty evening three and a half weeks before Election Day, Bob Dole was standing on a makeshift stage in an airport hangar in Wichita, Kan., smiling out at the audience. The scene before him was not inspiring. The hangar was just over half full, even though Mr. Dole was in his home state on a Friday night in the heat of the election season. A sizable portion of those who had shown up were Clinton supporters, there to disrupt the event.
Mr. Dole's, older sister, Gloria Nelson, who had driven 150 miles from their hometown of Russell, Kan., to join him, worked her way across the stage to stand beside him. "How's it going?" she whispered. 
 Mr. Dole's smile never left his face, and his eyes never left the crowd.
"Pretty rough," he said.
On Tuesday, Mr. Dole's political career, one of the most enduring in American political history, effectively came to an end. To run for President, he had resigned his seat in the United States Senate and given up the position he was, by many accounts, best suited for, majority leader.
Mr. Dole sacrificed these things not merely to lose the Presidency, but to run one of the most ineffectual Presidential campaigns in recent memory. Always the legislative tactician, Mr. Dole, according to his close associates, approached the Presidential race much as he did a Congressional negotiating session, believing that the key to victory was a clever endgame strategy. But so bleak were the polls, and for so long, that Mr. Dole was forced to realize, far earlier than most losing candidates, that the endgame would probably not be enough.
The week after he confessed his private pain to his sister, Mr. Dole, in two tense and scolding conversations with his campaign manager as he sat in a hotel room in southern California, offered what now appears to be an autopsy of his campaign. He was upset about the embarrassment of the bungled attempt to win Ross Perot's endorsement. He was mystified by the states his campaign had sent him to visit. He was unhappy with the television advertisements. He was convinced, in short, that the Presidency was about to escape him yet again.
At 73, Mr. Dole often seemed a man out of step with the times, and in President Clinton, he faced an opponent who had come to personify the methods of modern American politics. From the very start of his candidacy, Mr. Dole's friends wondered whether he had the political agility to take on Mr. Clinton, or whether it was worth risking his hard-won reputation for the uncertain prospect of unseating an incumbent in good economic times. By Tuesday, when Mr. Dole had completed his frantic shuttling across America and landed in Russell to vote, it seemed painfully clear that he did not, and that it was not.
Although he had built a career embracing deficit reduction, he had, in the hope of political gain, subordinated that goal to a call for a 15 percent tax cut. Although he had worked diligently to broaden the Republican Party, he found in the end he could barely hold onto its core voters. And although he had spent decades trying to live down his reputation as a "hatchet man," he finished his campaign on a note of bitterness.
There was something haunting, yet also finally authentic, about the way Mr. Dole ended his fourth and last national campaign, losing once again to a rival who, he clearly believed, was less deserving than himself. In the final weeks of the race, as it became apparent that there was no last-minute maneuver that would rescue him, Mr. Dole cut himself off almost completely from the aides who were trying to persuade him to end on an upbeat note. In frustration, he turned his attacks from his opponent to the press and finally to the voters themselves.
"Where," he demanded, again and again, "is the outrage?"
 
A Campaign Begins By Fits and Starts
Eight months before the first Republican primary, Mr. Dole -- reluctant and nervous -- went before an audience of film executives in Los Angeles to denounce what he described as the corrupting influence of Hollywood values on American culture. It was the spring of 1995, and Mr. Dole, it was assumed, was laying down one of the cornerstones of his campaign. The speech won him a flurry of attention both from the mainstream media and from the conservative activists who would be key to his electoral prospects.
But then, the issue disappeared. Mr. Dole barely discussed it. He did not incorporate it into his major speeches and it was never highlighted in his advertisements.
In retrospect, the Hollywood speech was a defining event for Mr. Dole's campaign, but not for the reasons the candidate and his aides might have hoped. It was the first of a series of bold statements and gestures that had no follow-up, a pattern that would prove devastating to his candidacy. In the most telling example, when Mr. Dole officially resigned from the Senate in June, the move seemed to create the perfect opening for the candidate to articulate the themes of his candidacy. That opening was never filled.
"We're trying to get good pictures," Mr. Dole instructed the huge contingent of reporters aboard his plane the first day after his resignation. "Don't worry very much about what I say."
Mr. Dole's third run for the Presidency was plagued by missteps, indecision and strategic blunders so fundamental that they bordered on amateurish. In any year, mistakes by a candidate and his staff can be damaging. But in the political environment Mr. Dole found himself in -- with a strong economy and an adept opponent -- they proved disastrous.
By now, many of Mr. Dole's weaknesses as a candidate have been abundantly documented. He is a halting public speaker who tends to ramble off the topic. He often comes across as stiff, even sullen, on television. He is given to wry off-the-cuff remarks that undermine his own arguments.
But beyond the traits that were in daily evidence as he traveled the country, Mr. Dole, it became clear, was limited by a view of the world shaped by over 35 years as a member of Congress. He was never ever to make the transition from legislative tactician to Presidential candidate, and he paid the price for that from the day he announced in Russell until the day he conceded in Washington.
"Dole has a lot of strengths and he has fewer weaknesses than people think," said Bill Lacy, one of the senior campaign advisers who was forced out after Mr. Dole lost the New Hampshire primary. "But he thinks like a legislator, which means he tends to think in cycles. He is not linear. Every day is new. Every day holds out hope."
Mr. Dole was always arguing that important campaign decisions could be delayed -- "His argument was that, 'we don't need to focus until the convention, until Labor Day," one aide said -- as long as possible. In that sense, he approached the election as if it were an omnibus bill, where the final compromise is forced by the deadline of a Congressional adjournment.
Similarly, Mr. Dole never managed to present a unifying rationale for his candidacy. As the Senate Republican leader, his job had been to focus on short-term tactics, not to conceptualize a broad agenda. And while some of Mr. Dole's allies came to argue that the notion that a candidate for President needs an overarching vision was a false construct, even they were dismayed by Mr. Dole's scattershot approach.
Some tried to coax him to change his ways. Gov. Steve Merrill of New Hampshire, for example, riding with Mr. Dole in a van shortly before his state's crucial primary, politely suggested to Mr. Dole that someone running for President needed to deliver the same speech at least four or five times, in order to assure that it seep into the public discourse. Mr. Dole, he recalled, seemed genuinely surprised by this observation, and rejected it, arguing it was "intellectually dishonest" to deliver the same speech over and over.
As the campaign progressed, on any given day, no one in Mr. Dole's camp could be quite certain what he might say -- much less whether he would address what was supposed to be his central topic. His aides responded by withholding advance texts of Mr. Dole's speeches from the press in case he did not deliver them. They fed reporters questions to ask Mr. Dole, so that he might say to them -- on airport tarmacs, in driveways, on the street -- what he had failed to say in the formal setting of his speeches. They critiqued Mr. Dole's speaking style to the press in the hope that Mr. Dole might take from the newspapers advice he had not taken from his staff. They aggressively shielded Mr. Dole from impromptu conversations with reporters, to avoid the flip remark that might turn into an embarrassing story.
By the end, Mr. Dole's aides and advisers had not only given up attempting to change his style, but were beginning to wonder if it had been a mistake to try. And for his part, Mr. Dole had taken to actively defying their efforts to protect him from himself. During the last 10 days of the campaign, he routinely ignored his teleprompter, and would wait until his press secretary had retired to the campaign plane's restroom and then bolt out of his seat to walk back and talk to reporters.
 
An Uneasy Team Goes Into Free Fall
In an effective campaign, the organization compensates for the shortcomings of its candidate. A stronger campaign team might have made up for Mr. Dole's weaknesses. Instead, the organization Mr. Dole assembled reflected and amplified his limitations, producing a kind of anti-synergy where the whole was less than the sum of its parts.
Mr. Dole surrounded himself with a group of like-minded people, short-term tacticians without strong ideologies. They were, by and large, young and inexperienced in the complexities of Presidential campaigning. Perhaps just as significantly, they had little personal history with Mr. Dole; few could say they felt comfortable with him and many had little personal loyalty to him.
Like the candidate, the campaign manager, Scott Reed tended to focus on immediate goals, rather than on long-term planning. His detractors at campaign headquarters took to privately mocking his habit of drafting endless "to-do" lists, which he kept neatly stacked on his desk. ("To do: find a message," was how one of his colleagues parodied the exercise.) Mr. Reed, who did not return phone calls seeking comment for this article, seemed to share Mr. Dole's faith that the election could be won in the fall, publicly asserting that the campaign was due a lucky break and privately confiding to reporters that newspapers were preparing devastating stories about the President's personal life. No such story was ever published.
The shortcomings of Mr. Dole's campaign team were apparent already last March when it became clear, though not yet official, that Mr. Dole would be the Republican Presidential nominee. Even in the darkest moments of the primary season, when Mr. Dole lost in New Hampshire, he had always remained the obvious front runner, so his victory could hardly be called a surprise.
Still, Mr. Dole's campaign was, according to those who worked on it, utterly unprepared for this moment. The months of April, May and finally June passed without anything approaching a general election plan. Mr. Dole was not advertising on television, pleading poverty after the primaries, though there was Republican National Committee money the campaign could have used, had it chosen to. In the meantime, the campaign organization began to break down into warring factions. Mr. Reed, the campaign manager, was barely talking to Don Sipple, whom he had hired to be the campaign's new chief strategist.
The Reed faction argued that Mr. Sipple was not producing, and made fun of the memorandums he wrote, which were filled with broad -- some called them fuzzy -- concepts, but no clear directives on how to proceed. ("Steady dependable leadership to secure America's future," was the slogan Mr. Sipple advised in one memorandum that was later distributed by his critics in the campaign, eager to discredit him.)
The Sipple faction, meanwhile, complained that its ideas were being ignored. So mistrustful were the two sides of each other that Mr. Sipple took to basing his memorandums on the NBC/Wall Street Journal polls rather than on the campaign's own internal polling data. The week after Labor Day, Mr. Sipple was forced out.
It was in that context of backbiting and infighting that the campaign essentially backed into what would eventually be its organizing theme: a 15 percent across-the-board tax cut that Mr. Dole proposed just before the convention. Some of Mr. Dole's advisers pushed the idea despite the fact that the campaign's own polling data suggested that, after the last two Presidents had promised tax cuts and not delivered, it would not be a winning issue. They also pushed it despite the concern among some of Mr. Dole's friends that it was so at odds with the former Senator's own history in Congress, and that it would undercut the argument that he was the more trustworthy of the two candidates.
By Labor Day, it had become clear that the tax cut plan was not catching on. Lacking any other unifying theme, Mr. Dole bounced through the fall, experimenting by the week with different messages: That Mr. Clinton was responsible for an increase in teen-age drug use. That he was a liberal. That he could not be trusted. That he was too liberal. That he was unethical. One result of these quicksilver changes, in the view of some of his own aides, was that Mr. Dole undermined his description of himself as steady and dependable.
With typical detached acerbity, Mr. Dole commented on his campaign's increasingly obvious deficiencies during the first round of debate preparations in October. Mr. Dole's debate advisers sought to put him through a run of trial questions and answers, according to a participant, but the candidate cut them off: "What I want to hear is not questions and answers: I want a strategy for winning this debate and winning this election."
Mr. Dole paused, and then delivered his own verdict to his assembled staff, seated behind tables in the ballroom at the Seaview Hotel in Bal Harbour, Fla. "We've never had a strategy for winning this election," he said.
With polls showing Mr. Dole's position growing not better, but worse, the infighting in the campaign became all the more public. Other aides made it known that Mr. Dole had long ago stopped talking to his own communications director, John Buckley, blaming him for the frequent leaks and constant feuding in the campaign. And they were furious, but not surprised, to learn that Mr. Reed, in an interview with The New Yorker six days before the election, had analyzed the campaign he was then still running in the past tense.
By the eve of the election, the campaign was involved in a full-bore brawl over who should bear responsibility for the defeat: Mr. Dole or Mr. Dole's campaign organization. The final consensus emerging yesterday was that there was plenty of fault for everyone -- but the campaign organization had ultimately failed the candidate with its fractious performance.
"This campaign couldn't sell a tax cut," one senior adviser said. "If we were a bordello, we'd go out of business."
 
Candidate Struggles To the Finish Line
On the first night out on the 96-hour, campaign-ending journey that would return him to Washington to concede on Tuesday, Mr. Dole stopped at a bowling alley in East Lansing, Mich. It was one of those ostensibly spontaneous, though in fact entirely staged events that campaigns routinely arrange -- a quick drop-by to win a flash of attention in the local press.
Once again, things did not quite turn out as planned.
Mr. Dole's campaign had publicized the "spontaneous" appearance in advance and, as had by now become routine, Democratic hecklers were waiting for him. As Mr. Dole picked up the microphone to address the assembled Friday night bowling leagues, Mr. Clinton's supporters broke into a chant of "Four more years!" At first Mr. Dole tried to yell over them -- "No more years!" -- but he had been campaigning for 14 hours straight and his voice was failing. Even at a distance of five feet, his words could barely be heard. Looking ashen and frustrated, he quickly gave up and led his entourage back to the caravan of buses waiting in the night.
For almost a year, Mr. Dole had struggled to make himself into what he was not: A "private citizen, a Kansan, an American, just a man" who had not really spent his adult life on Capitol Hill. A devoted tax cut advocate. "The most optimistic man in America," as he described himself in his acceptance speech in San Diego.
Now, at the end of the campaign, Mr. Dole knew he had lost, and he reverted to form. He took control over the schedule, the message, even the itinerary. It was he who decided that the campaign would go on the non-stop 96-hour trip. It was he who decided the campaign should approach Ross Perot and ask him to drop out of the race.
"The captain has taken control of the helm," his press secretary, Nelson Warfield, reported, with more than a little relief. In the final days of the campaign, Mr. Dole -- unplugged and unfettered -- was antic, focused, defiant, sometimes bitter but often funny. He seemed genuinely to be enjoying himself, even as his last campaign was spiraling out of control.
It all ended Tuesday night, in a hotel suite on the 11th floor of the Renaissance Hotel in Washington. Mr. Dole was there with his wife, his daughter, Robin, Mr. Reed and Senator John McCain of Arizona. He watched calmly as the election results came tumbling in, confirming what he had known since that moment his sister had turned to him on the stage in Wichita and probably even before that. Still, there was one last bit of business to attend to.
It was nearly 11 o'clock, and with the election at its unsurprising conclusion, Mr. Dole turned to Mr. McCain, his loyal friend from the Senate.
"We ought to start planning my speech," he said.
 
Late Night With Dole
(By The Associated Press) -- With no transition duties to worry about, Bob Dole is headed for an appearance with David Letterman.
Mr. Dole is a scheduled guest on "Late Show with David Letterman" tonight, along with the broadcaster Ted Koppel and the singer Mary Chapin Carpenter, a Letterman spokeswoman said.
Mr. Letterman's show is being broadcast from Washington tonight, part of a series of trips he is making around the country.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Squeeze U.N. And the City Feels the Pain

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
DURING the Presidential campaign -- in fact, because of it -- a prominent foreign resident was mugged on the East Side of Manhattan. At least, that is how some observers of this scene describe what happened, people who usually know what they are talking about.
The mugging, you should know, was political in nature. The victim: Boutros Boutros-Ghali, Secretary General of the United Nations. Months ago, the Clinton Administration let it be known that it would rather walk barefoot over hot coals than allow him to continue working in Turtle Bay after his present term ends on Dec. 31. No Secretary General has ever been denied a second term, but the American threat to veto attempts to extend Mr. Boutros-Ghali's tenure means that he will probably spend Christmas packing his bags. 
 With the election behind us, the struggle over who will lead the United Nations is expected to get intense in a hurry. And many foreign diplomats and commentators consider this a political mugging, because they see no good reason to give the boot to Mr. Boutros-Ghali. These people are convinced that the Administration beat up on him only to outflank the Republicans among voters ready to blame the big building on the East Side for everything that ails us, including fallen arches.
By now you may be wondering what this has to do with New York City. The short answer is: Plenty.
OUTRAGE at Washington is running high among foreign nations, which resent being pushed around on this issue by a country that is a chronic deadbeat, running up a debt to the United Nations that now stands at $1.5 billion. Any New Yorker knows that deadbeats do not get pushing-around rights. They're the ones who have to worry about being visited by those fellows whose nicknames show up in the tabloids wrapped in parentheses.
Not surprisingly, some resentful member states of the United Nations are asking why nearly half the organization's procurement contracts -- by far the largest share -- should go to the United States. Those contracts involve far more than dry-cleaning striped pants. They cover everything from ball-point pens to window washing.
Whom do you think United Nations people turn to when hallways need to be painted and light bulbs replaced? They do not haul out the Jakarta Yellow Pages. They call, obviously, on contractors in and around New York City. Should the prevailing hostility to the United States be translated into concrete action, it would inevitably come at New Yorkers' expense.
"There's a feeling among some states that if you don't pay your dues, why should you get our contracts?" said Sylvana Foa, the spokeswoman for the Secretary General.
A few diplomats in town have been heard muttering privately that the United Nations ought to just pick itself up and move out of the United States -- lock, stock and pork barrel. But this comes from a tiny minority. There is no campaign to flee New York. As one city official put it: "Honestly, for the U.N. to move, it would cost an awful lot of money. Where would they go?"
BUT scaling back on local contracts is a distinct possibility, and indeed it is already under way, a result of general belt-tightening and the budget crunches created by Washington's debt. Repairs have been delayed, construction plans are on hold and existing office equipment is stretched to the limit. Much of this affects the pockets of New York contractors and suppliers.
According to the United Nations Secretariat, procurement agreements with businesses in the New York region were worth $104.4 million last year. The 1996 figure, through September, is way down, to a mere $28.6 million. "No contracts are being awarded in many areas," an official at the Secretariat said, "and that has a domino effect. You may not hire an architect, and that affects his hardware suppliers, which may not hire as many workers, and so on."
Required cutbacks have led the United Nations to encourage 425 headquarters employees to take early retirement since Jan. 1, 1995. Their jobs have been left unfilled. And while most were foreigners, all lived here and spent money in local shops and restaurants.
Sometimes, New Yorkers become distracted by stories about foreign envoys racking up parking tickets or stiffing some store owner, and they forget that the giant diplomatic community here generates an estimated $3.3 billion in overall economic development and more than 15,000 jobs.
They might keep that in mind, especially should the numbers shrink, however slightly, because of the perceived mugging in Turtle Bay.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ELECTION: THE INVESTIGATIONS;
D'Amato Declares His Pursuit Of Whitewater Inquiry Is Over

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato reiterated today that he would not seek to reopen Senate hearings into the Whitewater real-estate venture of President Clinton and his wife, Hillary.
"It seems to me we've done our job," Mr. D'Amato said in an interview. "Now it's time for us to let the special prosecutor do his. In my opinion, we should let the special prosecutor do his work and don't second-guess him." 
 Mr. D'Amato, who is up for re-election in 1998, has seen his approval ratings slip since he began leading the hearings in 1994. Exit polls on Tuesday showed that 59 percent of New York voters disapproved of how he does his job and 34 percent approved. At the same time, Mr. Clinton won New York with 59 percent of the vote. The numbers suggest that Mr. D'Amato's dogged attacks on Mr. Clinton, and particularly the First Lady, may have backfired in the minds of voters.
Mr. D'Amato said in the interview he had never had any intention of holding a new set of hearings, a fact that he said had been known for months. He said he repeated his position on Wednesday in response to a reporter's question at a news conference on other matters. He added that his position on Whitewater had nothing to do with the election results or with his approval rating.
In fact, it would be nearly impossible for Mr. D'Amato to convene more hearings. His committees' authorization to investigate Whitewater expired last June. New hearings would require a new resolution from the Senate, but the atmosphere has changed sharply in the 18 months since the Senate voted 96 to 3 to investigate the Whitewater deal.
Earlier this year, Republicans were barely able to win approval to extend the investigation. Now, Democrats would probably filibuster such a proposal to death. It takes 60 votes to end a filibuster, and the Republicans will have only 54 or 55 seats in the Senate, depending on the final election results.
And the Republicans' zeal for investigating the Whitewater affair has waned, as there is little indication that their pursuit of the matter played well with voters.
Still, Whitewater is not likely to fade from the headlines. The White House has repeatedly attacked the special prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, over the last few months as little more than a Republican political operative. In the coming months, Mr. Starr will be faced with decisions about whether to end his investigation or press on, possibly into the White House.
Mr. D'Amato said today that it was time for him to move on to the pressing issues that face ordinary people, especially the impending crisis in Medicare. "I'm going to concentrate on doing the things people want: smaller government, more efficient government and to be able to keep more of their money."
And he is not concerned, he said, about his approval rating.
"Two years is a lifetime in politics," Mr. D'Amato said. "You make a big mistake trying to pattern everything on the basis of a poll."
But an adviser close to Mr. D'Amato said aides believed his pursuit of the Clintons and Whitewater had hurt him significantly in New York and was largely responsible for his poor showing in polls.
Mr. D'Amato is now trying to recast himself in a new, softer image that will appeal to moderates in New York, the adviser said. One element of his new campaign was his support of the environmental bond act on Tuesday's ballot in New York, which he hoped would make him more appealing to environmentalists, the adviser said.
The Republicans lost the race for the Presidency, Mr. D'Amato said, because they failed to bring home to people how the Dole economic plan would affect them. "We could have done a better job of talking about the economic plan sooner," he said. "People are hurting. We should have argued the case that the biggest part of the tax plan was the $500 tax credit for each child."
And the Republicans failed to counter the Democrats' "chilling message" that Republicans wanted to make large cuts in Medicare, he said.
As a result, Mr. D'Amato's relationship with his party and with former Senator Bob Dole has been somewhat strained over the last year.
But Mr. Dole telephoned Mr. D'Amato on Wednesday for what the Senator described as a "personal" conversation.
"Here he was in all this pain and what-not," Mr. D'Amato said. "He's a great person. We're good friends and I'm hurting for him."

HEADLINE: Nigerian Plane With 141 Aboard Is Missing

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 7

 BODY:
A Nigerian passenger plane disappeared today on a domestic flight with 141 people on board.
The Aviation Development Company, the owner of the missing Boeing 727, said the plane had been flying from Port Harcourt, in Nigeria's southeastern oil-producing region, to Lagos, the capital, with 132 passengers and 9 crew members. 
 "A search and rescue operation is going on," the company said in a statement. A company spokesman said, "We are expecting the manifest from Port Harcourt."
Airport officials said they presumed that the plane had crashed. They said several foreigners, probably oil company executives, were on board.
Nigeria has had a spate of air disasters in the last few years when the economy has been in trouble and taken a toll on infrastructure.
The airline company, which is owned by Nigerian shareholders, operates domestic services and also flies to some West African countries. One of its plane crashed in Liberia last year. In January, a Nigerian presidential aircraft crashed in the north of the country, killing the son of the military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha. The crash was followed by another in Jos, in central Nigeria, in which a state military governor and several other officials were killed.

Crash Laid to Pilot Error
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Pilot error probably caused a chartered Boeing 757 to crash into the Atlantic in February, killing all 189 people aboard, Dominican aviation authorities said today.
Most of the victims were German tourists returning to Frankfurt and Berlin. Also killed were 11 Turkish crew members, 7 Poles and 2 Dominican flight attendants.
The plane, leased by Alas Nacionales, a small Dominican carrier, crashed from 7,300 feet on Feb. 6, six minutes after takeoff from Puerto Plata, a popular resort on the north coast of the Dominican Republic.
In a final report, the Dominican civil aviation agency said the crew of the Birgenair plane did not recognize the danger of stalling when the steering column began shaking, a warning that a stall is possible.
The crew also was confused about different airspeed readings, including a false reading that the plane was flying too fast, the report said.
In March, Turkey's Transport Ministry blamed a faulty airspeed indicator for the crash.
Other factors contributed to the crash, the Dominican report said. It said the crew was not familiar enough with the 757's systems, including the automatic pilot system and procedures to follow when indicators show different airspeeds.
It also blamed a Birgenair ground crew for failing to cover airspeed sensors known as pitot tubes while the plane was being serviced. The ground crew then failed to insure the tubes were operable before releasing the plane, the report said.
Aviation industry sources and the United States National Transportation Safety Board, which took part in the investigation, have said airspeed indicators might disagree if dirt or debris blocked an external sensor.
Today's report did not say whether a pitot tube was blocked.
Blocked sensor ports may have also caused the Oct. 2 crash of an Aeroperu flight, which killed all 70 people aboard, Peru's Transportation Ministry said earlier this week.

HEADLINE: Perspectives and Musings on Clinton's Round 2;
Victory Inflation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Once again the strange workings of our Electoral College have confounded pundits and misled headline writers. You say (front page, Nov. 6) that Bill Clinton won "with solid margins across U.S." Other newspapers proclaim a "big sweep" and a "landslide," although Mr. Clinton won only 49 percent of the popular vote!
Because of the winner-take-all rule in the Electoral College, Mr. Clinton's ever-so-modest success at the polls was inflated into a lopsided electoral-vote victory -- 379 to 159. 
 In fact, Mr. Clinton's percentage of the popular vote was the second-lowest winning percentage in the last seven Presidential elections. The only candidate who received a smaller percentage of the vote and still won was Mr. Clinton himself in 1992.
 
JAMES P. LEVINE
New York, Nov. 7, 1996
 
The writer is a professor of government at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, CUNY.

HEADLINE: Retailers Beat Expectations For October

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Retailers beat analysts' expectations for October same-store sales yesterday with numbers that appeared to be a harbinger for a decent holiday shopping season.
Winners of particular note included department stores, which have been having a weak fall, and specialty apparel stores, which generally suffered dismal same-store sales in October 1995. Indeed last October marked the start of record-low sales for retailers, which served as a portent for an equally dismal Christmas. 
 But this October proved strong, in part because retailers were going up against very easy comparisons with last October, and for factors ranging from strong consumer confidence to fresh apparel buys in the clothing stores to the inexplicable urge that seized many shoppers and sent them into the stores ready to spend. These gains followed a relatively weak September.
As a result, some retailers raised their earnings estimates for the fiscal third quarter. The Goldman, Sachs retail composite index, which tracks same-store sales data, or sales at stores open at least a year, from about 60 retailers, gained 3.3 percent in October, well above the five-tenths of a 1 percent gain in October 1995.
"We are increasing our Christmas estimate from a gain of 5 to 5.5 percent to 5.5 to 6 percent for the season," Jeffrey M. Feiner, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc., said.
"Consumer confidence is at its highest in seven years, there is low inflation and low interest rates. This is in combination with a very apparel-driven environment. And at the bottom line retailers are still budgeting for very low inventories and tight expenses."
The retail sales figures came out on the same day that the Federal Reserve reported that consumer credit fell 2.7 percent in September, the first decline in more than three years. But revolving credit, which includes credit cards, showed a modest increase and analysts said that the numbers would not affect the holiday shopping season.
"Consumer credit numbers have been shrinking gradually for much of the year," David Blitzer, chief economist at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said. "Consumers in general should be really bullish. I think the retailing season should be good. There is nothing in the consumer credit numbers that should raise concerns."
As with each month of sales reports, some themes emerged. Like athletes who throw more and more weight on their bench press, stores that had a consistently strong fall got stronger still: Ross Stores Inc., an off-price apparel chain based in Redwood City, Calif., reported a gain of 17 percent in same-store sales, up from gains between 9 percent and 16 percent between July and October. The J. C. Penney Company, which had a fairly poor September but an otherwise improved fall season, soared ahead with a 13.1 percent gain in same-store sales.
And some of the weakest players got more sand kicked in their faces. The Kmart Corporation, which has barely eked out sales gains this fall, reported a 1.3 percent gain yesterday, down from last year's 2.4 percent gain in October and trailing Wal-Mart Stores Inc., which had a 4.2 percent gain, and Target Stores, which reported a 9.6 percent gain.
After months of sales that were all over the board, some themes within sectors also appeared.
Computer sellers, for example, almost all reported weak sales in October, despite easy comparisons with the year before. The Tandy Corporation said that sales fell 10 percent, although last year's October brought a mere 1 percent gain for the company. Circuit City Stores Inc. reported a loss of 9 percent in same-store sales, even though it lost 1 percent last year. The Best Buy Company reported a whopping 15 percent decrease in sales.
Compare this with specialty apparel chains, which by and large got clobbered last October and last holiday season. Stores like the Limited, Ann Taylor and Eddie Bauer all took advantage of poor 1995 October sales with strong showings yesterday. The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation reported a 15.9 percent gain over last year's 13.2 percent loss; Eddie Bauer gained 4 percent over a 1 percent loss last year and Gap Inc. had a 4 percent gain over last year's 2 percent upswing.
"There is still too much capacity in the hard-goods sector," Robert F. Buchanan, a retail analyst at NatWest Securities, said. "Also, there isn't much in the way of new product, no Windows 95 this year."
Department stores, too, have made some progress. Federated Department Stores Inc., after a rather soft fall, zipped in with a 4.9 percent gain, above last October's 1.8 percent loss and a mere eight-tenths of 1 percent gain in September. The May Department Stores Company, which has been inconsistent since last year, reported a strong 4.6 percent gain.
Anyone selling merchandise with strong brand names is sure to score a hit, retail experts say, because consumers cannot get enough of names like Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein. Department stores watch designer items fly out, and discounters sell the second runs or last year's merchandise to the masses.
As such, several companies raised their earnings estimates for the third quarter. Ann Taylor said it expects to earn one penny, or two cents more a share than the consensus estimate of 19 cents; Ross Stores, which analysts were predicting would have earnings of 50 cents to 52 cents a share, said that it expects to gain something closer to 63 cents and Limited said that it will earn 15 cents, a penny more than the 14-cent expectation.
The Limited's stock got hammered nonetheless yesterday when its Intimate Brands unit announced that it expected earnings to rise about 22 percent in the third quarter to 11 cents a share, better than the period last year but a penny less than analysts' estimates.
The Limited's shares closed at $18, down $2.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. Intimate Brands, which operates the Victoria's Secret and Bath and Body Works chains and is 83 percent owned by Limited, fell $3.75, to $16.25, in heavy trading.
While the holiday season is almost certain to shine, some analysts are still worried about what is in store once the trees are taken down and the last of the eggnog has been cleaned off kitchen counters. "There is no question in my mind that we are going to have a good if not great Christmas," Mr. Buchanan of NatWest said. "What bothers me is what happens next. By next year, now that the Presidential election is over, the Fed is more inclined to tame the inflation beast.
"I think Christmas is already in retail stocks," he added. "We are telling people to sell the group."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 11, 1996, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Friday showing leading retailers' sales in October misstated the last year's percentage change for Talbots in stores open at least a year. Such sales rose -- they did not fall -- by 2.3 percent.

HEADLINE: Smoking Report Sees Signs Of Grim Fates, and of Hope

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
More than five million Americans now under the age of 18 will die prematurely from smoking, according to new Government projections that reflect increasing tobacco use by teen-agers.
But the Government also said yesterday that figures from California and Massachusetts showed how much success a combination of anti-tobacco advertising and higher cigarette taxes could have in reducing adult smoking. A third report showed wide differences among the 50 states in their percentage of adult smokers. 
 "These studies show the potential for prevention," said Michael D. Eriksen, director of the Office of Smoking and Health at the national Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which published the research in its Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report. "The five million deaths is a projection that doesn't have to become reality. This is a wake-up call."
Dr. Eriksen said the studies underscored the need for the Food and Drug Administration's recently adopted regulations to curtail tobacco marketing that appeals to young smokers and to reduce their access to cigarettes. The tobacco industry, which is mounting legal challenges to the agency's authority to impose the new rules, dismissed the new studies as old news rehashed to build support for the regulations.
"It's reminiscent of things we've seen before," said Walker Merryman, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute in Washington.
The Government said its estimate of five million premature deaths was a conservative one based on current smoking rates. It included an allowance for people who will stop smoking after the age of 35 and thus have a reduced risk of early death from tobacco-related illnesses. The report estimated that the cost of treating such illness in today's young smokers at $200 billion in 1993 dollars.
The state-by-state figures reflect surveys made last year. Utah, where the anti-tobacco stance of the Mormon Church is influential and only 13.2 percent of residents 18 or older smoke regularly, is the only state below the 15 percent level that the Federal Government has set as a national target for the year 2000. Kentucky, a tobacco-growing state with very low tobacco taxes, has the highest rate, 27.8 percent.
The report on California and Massachusetts said those states had rapidly cut their rates of adult smoking by imposing a 25-cents-per-pack tax increase and dedicating some of the new revenue to statewide anti-tobacco advertising. From 1992, the year before Massachusetts adopted its measures, to 1996, the state spent $116 million on tobacco control programs, including $43 million on advertising. The number of cigarettes smoked by the average adult in the state fell 2.2 percent annually, based on state tax receipts.
The annual decline in the same period in California, which introduced similar measures in 1990, was 2.7 percent. Smoking rates also fell in 41 states that did not have such programs and for which data were available, but the annual decline was much lower: 0.8 percent.
The report cautions that Massachusetts' performance might not have been as good as the 19.7 percent overall decline suggested by the figures because cigarette sales jumped in neighboring New Hampshire, indicating that some people may have simply bought their cigarettes out of state rather that quit.
The results are also murkier than health officials would like because a price war in the tobacco industry cut local cigarette prices. Once inflation is considered, smokers ended up paying no more than before the taxes.
Still, tobacco critics say, the trends are clear enough to encourage similar programs in Arizona, which began them last year, and Oregon, whose residents voted on Tuesday to increase cigarette taxes by 30 cents a pack and to step up its tobacco education programs.
Mr. Merryman of the Tobacco Institute said such measures reduced smoking but also had side effects overlooked by their advocates, including encouraging smuggling, which could cost a state like California tens of millions of dollars in tax revenue while hurting retailers.
Some tobacco critics also said yesterday that a closer examination of the experience in California and Massachusetts might lead to renewed disputes over whether anti-tobacco efforts had become overly focused on young smokers. Adult smoking rates in California have actually risen slightly since 1994, when Gov. Pete Wilson and the tobacco industry diverted anti-tobacco advertising money into other health programs and focused on young people's smoking. 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 14, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about new research on smoking misstated the decline in smoking rates for adults in a study comparing California and Massachusetts statistics with those from other states. The decline was 2.2 percentage points in Massachusetts (from 23.5 percent to 21.3 percent), 2.7 percentage points in California and eight-tenths of a percentage point in 41 other states, not 2.2 percent, 2.7 percent and 0.8 percent respectively.
The article also misstated measures used to calculate the declines. The rates were based on the percentage of adults who smoke cigarettes, not the number of cigarettes smoked by the average adult, and were calculated by comparing two three-year periods, 1990-1992 and 1993-1995, not annual figures.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Down Again vs. Yen; Policy Shift Is Still Suspected

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar weakened further yesterday on concerns that Japan and the United States wanted a stronger yen, despite assurances from Japanese officials that their foreign exchange policy remained unchanged.
Traders were skeptical because the backtracking came a day after the dollar's plunge. Many suspected the statements were merely an attempt to slow the dollar's fall. Their doubts were increased by a lack of comment from United States officials supporting the dollar. 
 Traders reacted by selling the dollar going into the weekend.
"There seems to be a degree of concern out there," said Joseph Pedone, vice president at the New York branch of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan. "We just don't get a sense yet of what may be a shift in policy."
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 111.50 yen, from 111.60 yen on Thursday. The dollar traded at 1.5053 German marks, down from 1.5120. The British pound rose to $1.6464 from $1.6448.
A senior Japanese monetary policy maker surprised the market on Thursday and sent the dollar tumbling against the yen by asserting that the yen's prolonged period of weakness was over.
The official, Eisuke Sakakibara, director of the Finance Ministry's International Finance Bureau, also said the market had overestimated the weakness of the Japanese economy. Traders took this to mean that Japan's record-low interest rates could start rising, which would tend to increase the value of the yen.
Mr. Sakakibara, who is widely credited with orchestrating the gradual decline of the yen over the last 19 months, toned down his remarks yesterday, saying that the Finance Ministry has not altered its position.
In addition, Japan's new Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, said the dollar had not finished recovering against the yen from the lows reached in the spring of 1995.
Still, many traders said they believed these officials were simply trying to slow the yen's sudden ascent. "You've still got some nagging fears that the first thing out of people's mouths is what they really meant, and now they're trying to stop the damage," said Elliott Dix, assistant vice president of foreign exchange at the Signet Banking Corporation in Richmond.

HEADLINE: Eileen C. Dugan, 51, State Assemblywoman

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Eileen C. Dugan, a Brooklyn Democrat who was elected to her ninth term in the New York State Assembly only on Tuesday, died yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center. Ms. Dugan, who lived in Carroll Gardens, was 51.
The cause was breast cancer, according to her family. 
 Gov. George E. Pataki, who served in the Assembly with Ms. Dugan, ordered state flags to be flown at half-staff in her memory.
Since 1991, Ms. Dugan, one of the principal political tacticians in the Assembly, had served as the chairwoman of the Democratic Assembly Campaign Committee, a major fund-raising and strategy-making arm of the party. This year, despite a determined Republican effort, Democrats won an additional seat in the Assembly and will hold 96 of its 150 seats when the new session begins in January.
Ms. Dugan, who won her most recent election with 70 percent of the vote as the candidate of the Democratic and Liberal parties, represented the 52d District, which includes not only Carroll Gardens, but also Bay Ridge, Cobble Hill, Red Hook, Sunset Park, Brooklyn Heights and Boerum Hill.
The district includes much of the Brooklyn waterfront in Red Hook, an area Ms. Dugan was dedicated to revitalizing through the establishment of open space and park land and the introduction of new business. She sponsored legislation that committed funds for studies to accomplish these ends.
At the time of her death, Ms. Dugan was chairwoman of the Assembly's Committee on Economic Development, Job Creation and Industry and a member of the Governmental Employees Committee, the Labor Committee, the Rules Committee and the Ways and Means Committee.
In 1985, five years after she was first elected to the Assembly, Ms. Dugan became the first female member of the powerful Ways and Means Committee, which writes the budget.
As chairwoman of the Committee on Economic Development, she was successful in establishing economic development zones in deteriorating neighborhoods.
As a member of the Subcommittee on Displaced Homemakers, she was active in the passage of legislation to commit funds for training divorced or battered women in marketable skills at centers throughout the state.
Ms. Dugan was born in Carroll Gardens and attended the Grace Institute in Manhattan. She began her career in government in 1974 as a special assistant to the New York City Comptroller .
She is survived by her sister, Patricia Curtin of Sound Beach, L.I., and two brothers, Brian, of Holbrook, L.I., and Brendan, of Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: Treasury Securities Prices Lower in Shortened Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved lower in a shortened session yesterday, as investors took profits following Thursday's rally.
Prices surged on Thursday following an auction of new 30-year bonds that was better than expected. Yesterday, the price of the newly issued 30-year fell 2011/32 , to 100. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, edged up to 6.50 percent, from 6.48 percent at the close of trading on Thursday, but still down from the average yield at auction of 6.619 percent. Trading ended at 2 P.M. yesterday, and the market will be closed on Monday in observance of Veterans Day. 
 Investors are typically reluctant to hold securities over a long weekend, and yesterday they used a Government report on wholesale trade as a reason to sell. The report showed a 1.3 percent drop in inventories -- the third consecutive monthly decline. Shrinking inventories suggest that there may be an economic rebound ahead.
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a research analysis firm, said he was not surprised by yesterday's profit taking, noting that prices rose steadily this week through the Treasury's quarterly refunding.
"Now that supply is out of the way people will likely go back to looking at what is the state of the economy," he said.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, said the strong demand seen in the 30-year bond auction on Thursday boded well for the market in the short run.
Next week, the market will turn its attention to reports on consumer and producer prices, retail sales, industrial production and trade.
Mr. McCarthy said: "I think the economy is growing moderately, but it is slowing down. As a result the Fed is not going to do anything and I expect longer-term rates to continue to decline. The key is that the consumer spending is tapped."
Mr. Chan said the reports on producer prices and consumer prices should give additional clues on the worrisome subject of labor pressures. "My suspicion is that the numbers will still portray only small, incremental increases in overall inflation, but one has to keep in mind that these increases could begin to add up over time," he said.
While Mr. Chan acknowledges the data on labor cost pressures have been spotty, he fears that the Fed will not react to the growing tightness in the labor market fast enough. The Fed's interest-rate policy group, the Federal Open Market Committee, will meet on Wednesday, but few in the market expect the central bank to change rates.

HEADLINE: Norfolk Raises Bid for Conrail To $10 Billion

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Norfolk Southern Corporation raised the ante yesterday for Conrail in the battle to control rail freight in the East by increasing its bid by 10 percent, to $10 billion cash, or about $1.5 billion more than the offer from its rival bidder, the CSX Corporation.
Only three days ago, CSX sweetened its own cash-and-stock offer and Conrail reaffirmed its Oct. 15 merger agreement with CSX and strengthened the ties between the two railroads. CSX offered $110 a share in cash for 40 percent of Conrail's stock immediately. After the merger is approved by Federal regulators, CSX would acquire the remaining 60 percent through a stock swap. At yesterday's closing price, the entire offer is worth about $93 a share. 
 Norfolk Southern now is offering $110 cash a share for all shares of the Consolidated Rail Corporation and the $17-a-share gap between the two offers may be too much for either CSX or Conrail to ignore. Some analysts expect that CSX will have to take some action, possibly before Conrail's board meets on Tuesday to issue a response to Norfolk Southern's hostile tender offer. In the meantime, Conrail, which is based in Philadelphia and controls nearly all freight traffic in the Northeast, has asked shareholders not to act on the offer from Norfolk Southern.
"CSX's offer is of lesser economic value and it makes it harder for the Conrail board to forget their fiduciary responsiblity," said Douglas W. Rockel, an analyst at Furman Selz Inc. "If they still want to acquire Conrail they have to consider revising their offer."
The latest move by Norfolk Southern sent Conrail's share price up by $3.375 to close at $96.375 on the New York Stock Exchange, while Norfolk Southern's shares closed down 37.5 cents at $86.625 and CSX was unchanged at $44.25.
Norfolk's richer offer might have pushed Conrail's stock even higher, but the battle for Conrail is complicated by anti-takeover laws in Pennsylvania designed to protect companies from hostile acquisitions.
Conrail shareholders have to approve the merger ultimately, but under state statutes, the company's directors can shun a higher offering price in the interests of the corporation and employees. In addition, the merger agreement between CSX and Conrail contains a $300 million breakup fee, more than $100 million in stock options for CSX and a freeze-out provision that bars Conrail from negotiating with another bidder until July.
Norfolk Southern, which has referred to the merger agreement as a "coercive" front-end-loaded offer that forces Conrail directors to give up their fiduciary responsibilities, is hoping to entice shareholders, if not Conrail directors, with its all-cash offer. "This offer demonstrates our commitment to acquire Conrail," said David R. Goode, chairman of Norfolk Southern. "This will make it possible for the shareholders to accept what seems to us to be a clearly superior offer."
CSX declined comment on the new offer, but whatever the railroad opts to do, the bidding war is probably coming to a close. For now, Conrail remains committed to what it calls a strategic merger with CSX.
Soon the battlefield will shift to Federal District Court in Philadelphia and to a special meeting of Conrail shareholders sometime in mid-December. A court hearing is scheduled for Nov. 18 on Norfolk Southern's request for a preliminary injunction blocking the Conrail-CSX merger. Norfolk Southern plans to argue that at the very least Conrail's directors are obligated to consider its offer under Pennsylvania law. But legal experts and Wall Street analysts give Norfolk Southern only a slim chance of overturning the friendly merger in court.
Perhaps more importantly, Norfolk is lobbying stockholders to oppose a change in Conrail's bylaws, which require anyone who buys more than 20 percent of the company to offer to purchase the remaining shares for the same price, in this case $110 a share. The change would allow CSX to acquire more than 20 percent of Conrail stock without offering $110 in cash for every remaining share. That enables CSX to acquire as much as 19.9 percent of Conrail stock before the December meeting and then to vote in favor of the change. Many analysts expect CSX to acquire the first block of stock, because it is offering $110 cash, the same price as Norfolk Southern.
But many institutional shareholders and arbitragers who favor Norfolk Southern's higher offer say they will oppose the provision allowing CSX to go beyond 20 percent. That would provide an opening for Norfolk Southern, which is offering $110 cash a share, versus a CSX stock swap that would value the remaining 60 percent of Conrail stock at $82.13 a share, based on Friday's price.
"We need some help from stockholders," one person in the Norfolk Southern camp conceded.
"The court hearing and the shareholder vote in mid-December take on paramount importance with the increased bid from Norfolk," said Brian Routledge, an analyst at Prudential Securities Inc. "The court case will determine whether Norfolk can penetrate the legal barriers erected against their offer and the vote will show whether shareholders are willing to accept a lower offer from CSX."
But some analysts now are worried that the sale price for Conrail has escalated beyond reason. The gains from a merger with either CSX or Norfolk Southern are pushed further and further into the future, said Steven Lewins, an analyst at Gruntal & Company.
"The bidding has gotten beyond what even Maverick would go for," Mr. Lewins said. "From an economic and political standpoint, the shootout here at the O.K. Corral should be turned into a negotiation at the round table. Nobody loses if they sit down and talk. Everybody can lose if they don't."
