HEADLINE: Dow Keeps On Ascending at Record Pace

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose to records in a late day rebound amid prospects for growing profits and low inflation, giving the Dow Jones industrial average its best weekly gain in more than three months.
The rise in the Dow was led by Merck & Company as the index rose 13.78, to 6,219.82, bouncing back after falling almost 25 points. 
 "The market has just been extraordinary," said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer at New Amsterdam Partners, which manages $340 million. "Given the way the economy has shaken out, it's not surprising. Inflation seems to be under control. I don't see imminent recession signs. Profits have held up fairly well -- they will continue to hold up."
The Dow closed above 6,200 for the first time this week, buoyed by optimism for economic and political stability following Tuesday's election. The advance came as investors bought an estimated $6 billion of mutual funds in the last three days, according to Charles Biderman, an analyst at Mutual Fund Trim Tabs. Investments that high are equal to a $40 billion monthly rate, which has not been seen since January, he said.
Still, at near-record levels, the question is, "How much are people willing to pay for the big-cap, solid earnings stories?" asked Jon Hickman, lead portfolio manager for $2 billion in growth stocks at Wells Fargo Asset Management Group in San Francisco.
With the Dow industrials up 3.29 percent for the week and the benchmark Standard & Poor's 500 Index up 3.84 percent in the last five days, "The market isn't going to do a whole lot more from here to year-end," Mr. Clayman said. "The market is in the fairly valued range."
Among broad indexes, the benchmark Standard & Poor's 500 index rebounded 3.17, to 730.82, after falling 2.43, to 725.22, setting its fourth straight record. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 3.37, to 1,257.51, within a point of its all-time high.
Major regional banks such as Nationsbank Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C., retreated after the Government said inventories shrank in September and sales rose, suggesting the economy may pick up steam as companies replenish their stocks to satisfy consumer demand. Nationsbank fell 1/2, to 94 1/8.
"At some point you're going to get some unpleasant or surprising inflation numbers," said Larry Rice, director of research at Josephthal Lyon & Ross, before the report. That's likely to unsettle both bond and stock markets, which have been "stretched," on a valuation basis, by the latest recent rally, he said.
Stocks were helped this week as the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond plunged to eight-month lows amid signs of tepid growth in the economy.
Dime Bancorp Inc. bucked the trend, gaining 7/8, to 16, in trading of 3.8 million shares, more than nine times its daily average. Investors said the New York-based savings and loan is a prime takeover candidate. Trading in options to buy Dime shares at 17 1/2 by next Friday tripled.
Norfork Southern Corporation raised the stakes in the bidding for the Northeast railroad Conrail Inc., increasing its all cash offer to $10 billion, or $110 a share, some $17 more a share than the CSX Corporation offered for Conrail in cash and stock.
Earlier this week, CSX raised the cash portion of its bid to $110 a share. Conrail rose 3 3/8, to 96 3/8. Norfork Southern fell 3/8, to 86 5/8. CSX was unchanged at 44 1/4.
Shares of liquor companies such as the Seagram Company and the Brown Forman Corporation advanced after a trade group decided to lift a self-imposed ban on television and radio advertising to increase flagging sales.
Seagram, distiller of Chivas Regal and other liquors, rose 1 1/8, to 38 5/8. Brown Forman, which makes Jack Daniels, rose 1 1/8, to 45 3/8.

HEADLINE: Canada Tries to Shake Off Economic Doldrums

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Gordie Howe ruled hockey and Howdy Doody was a big man on TV the last time interest rates in Canada were as low as they are today.
Canada's central bank reduced rates for the 20th time in 18 months today, dropping the prime rate to 4.75 percent, the lowest it has been since 1956. The prime rate is used by commercial banks to determine mortgage and credit card interest rates as well as the rates for car, consumer and business loans. 
 But even such invitingly low rates have not been sufficient to get Canada's consumers spending again. Retail sales have been so depressed for so long that stores, desperate for a good Christmas season, set up seasonal displays and started advertising heavily weeks before Halloween.
Nor have the lowest rates in 40 years stimulated enough growth to reduce the country's high unemployment rate. Today, Statistics Canada reported that unemployment rose to 10 percent in October, matching its highest level in two years. But Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns in Toronto, said the figures were not as bad as they might appear at first glance. For one, she said, the jobless rate was distorted by the three-week strike at General Motors.
Still, experts see good times ahead. Canada has been undergoing a substantial revamping in government and in the private sector, much as did the United States in the 1980's and Mexico after its disastrous devaluation in 1994. Economists say that while today's announcements of lower rates and higher unemployment seem to be contradictory, they reflect painful steps already taken that will lead to a recovery, perhaps by early next year.
"Basically, there is a lag of about 12 to 18 months between the decline in interest rates and the response of the economy," said Carlos Leitao, an economist at the Royal Bank of Canada. Mr. Leitao is forecasting a growth rate for 1997 of 3 percent, almost double the expected rate for this year. Growth could be even stronger in subsequent years, he said.
In recent weeks Canada's economy has had a lot to celebrate. Besides the dwindling interest rates, inflation has been holding at 1.5 percent, about half the rate in the United States. The Toronto Stock Exchange has hit several record highs in the last two weeks and the Canadian dollar has gotten steadily stronger, rising from about 73 cents to one United States dollar in September to around 75 cents this week.
Though stronger, the Canadian dollar is still considered undervalued, and that has helped Canada post record levels of exports this year. In August, Canada recorded its largest trade surplus ever. Led by exports of vehicles and agricultural products, Canadian exports increased 2.7 percent and totaled a record $23.2 billion.
At the same time, imports dropped by 2.7 percent, with imports from the United States slipping most.
All this has delighted Canadian businessmen. "The Good Times are Back" is the splashy headline on this month's Canadian Business magazine. The optimism is partly fired by the actions of Canada's provincial and federal governments, which have aggressively cut spending and reduced deficits. Seven of the 10 provinces are already showing budget surpluses and it is expected that by 1998, the federal Government will not need to seek any new borrowing to balance its accounts.
Many economists now talk of a virtuous cycle in Canada in which government revamping allows interest rates to decline, which in turn enables governments to trim budgets even more, and so on.
But there is a down side. While lower mortgage rates have sent the sale of existing houses soaring, the construction of new houses plummeted 9.8 percent in October, a sign that builders remain unconvinced that a recovery has started. And two weeks ago civil service unions in the Toronto area helped organize one of the largest demonstrations in Canada's history to protest deep cuts in the Ontario provincial budget. Pensioners and savers have watched the return on their investments shrink as interest rates declined.
In a speech this week, the head of the central bank, Gordon Thiessen, rejected suggestions that the Bank of Canada should be willing to accept a higher rate of inflation to spark the economy.
"Inflation will work as a lubricant," Mr. Thiessen said, "only if it fools people into believing that they are better off than they really are."

HEADLINE: Religion Journal;
Voters of Various Faiths Return to Democratic Fold

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
Looking at a map of the Electoral College after Tuesday's election, one could begin to discern a certain broad religious division between the states won by President Clinton and those that went to Bob Dole.
The Republican candidate captured 19 states, most of them in the Great Plains and the Southeast, regions that form much of the heartland of Protestant America, in its mainline and evangelical varieties. 
 President Clinton, by contrast, triumphed in a more religiously diverse territory, taking states in the Northeast, upper Midwest and West Coast, as well as parts of the Sun Belt. Many of the states he won have very substantial Roman Catholic populations (Illinois, Louisiana and New Mexico, for example), large concentrations of Jewish voters (Florida, New Jersey and New York) or significant minorities of people who claim no religious affiliation at all (California, Nevada and Washington State).
Although this religious division between the two candidates' supporters is hardly precise, statistical evidence for it turned up in a nationwide poll taken among voters on Election Day.
The poll, in which Voter News Service surveyed 16,359 voters, indicates that Mr. Dole won the backing of 50 percent of the people who identified themselves as Protestants, while 41 percent of them supported President Clinton (who drew a lot of his Protestant support from Northeastern states).
Catholics presented an almost reverse image: 53 percent cast their ballots for the President, while 37 percent went for Mr. Dole, according to the poll.
Among the smaller groups, Jewish voters backed Mr. Clinton by a margin of almost 5 to 1, while voters who claimed no religious affiliation also favored the President over Mr. Dole, 59 percent to 23 percent.
The survey had two more categories that are very broad: people who said they belonged to a faith other than Judaism and Christianity, and people who described themselves as "other Christians" -- a very diverse group in itself that would include Orthodox Christians, Mormons and many others. More voters in both these categories said they voted for Mr. Clinton than for Mr. Dole.
Looking over the statistics, John Green, an authority on political trends among religious voters, said the Catholic results were the most interesting, as they recalled the margin of Catholic support Democratic Presidential candidates seemed to have lost years ago. "I think you'd have to go back to the 1970's to have that kind of division" of Catholics' votes, said Professor Green, director of the Ray C. Bliss Center of Applied Politics at the University of Akron.
When it comes to voters' religious affiliations, the Republican Party has long counted on white Protestants -- Episcopalians, Presbyterians and the like -- to provide a core of its strength, especially in Midwestern states like Kansas (home, by the way, to Mr. Dole, a Methodist).
For several decades in this century, Democrats looked to a more diverse base: white Southern evangelical Protestants, who called themselves born-again Christians; Northern Catholics; Jews, and black Protestants. Majorities of these groups helped elect Roosevelt, Truman and Kennedy. But this fragile alliance fell apart in the 1970's.
Evangelicals began deserting the Democrats in droves, lured by the social and fiscal conservatism increasingly voiced by Republicans. Many have found the Republican Party a comfortable home. On Wednesday, the Christian Coalition, the conservative political group, released a poll of 1,030 people by Wirthlin Worldwide showing that born-again Christians who frequently attended church chose Mr. Dole over President Clinton, 53 percent to 36 percent.
Since the 1970's, Catholics, too, have shifted politically, but the picture they present is less clear. "There is no monolithic 'Catholic vote,' " wrote David C. Leege, a professor of government and international studies at the University of Notre Dame, in the magazine Commonweal two months ago. Older Catholics, whether they regularly attend Mass or not, tend to identify themselves more as Democrats, he wrote, while a younger generation -- more moderate on social issues and less likely to attend Mass -- leans Republican, largely for economic reasons.
Ronald Reagan won substantial Catholic support in 1980 and 1984. Four years ago, Mr. Clinton captured a plurality of Catholic votes, but President Bush was close behind.
That Mr. Clinton was able to draw such a wide margin of Catholic support this time may have resulted, Professor Green said, partly from negative reactions among Catholics to the Republican Congress's efforts to cut social welfare programs.
But does this mean that Mr. Clinton has reassembled the Democrats' old coalition? "If I was pressed," Professor Green said, "what I would say is what Bill Clinton was able to do was halt a certain progression away from ethno-cultural politics toward ideological politics."
He added that this might be only temporary. "Maybe this won't survive Bill Clinton," he said.

HEADLINE: Carolyn Agger, 87, Lawyer and Widow Of Justice Fortas

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Carolyn Eugenia Agger, a prominent tax lawyer and the widow of former Justice Abe Fortas of the Supreme Court, died on Thursday at her home in the Georgetown section of Washington. She was 87.
The cause was pneumonia, said the Washington law firm Arnold & Porter, where she retired two years ago as a senior partner and head of the tax practice section. 
 Ms. Agger was at the center of a rebellion that ruffled the world of big-ticket law offices in 1960 when she led an exodus of partners from the firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. A partner in the firm's Washington office, she defected to Arnold, Fortas & Porter and took the entire Washington office with her.
At the time, Mr. Fortas was a member of the firm, now known as Arnold & Porter. And he was loath to give up his lucrative partnership when President Lyndon B. Johnson tried to cajole him into joining the Court in 1965. Mr. Fortas refused several times, but Mr. Johnson was not one to take no for an answer.
The assent to the bench meant a sharp financial loss, to $39,500 from an estimated yearly salary of $200,000, something that Mr. Fortas openly derided. It also angered Ms. Agger, suddenly the couple's principal breadwinner by far. It was Mr. Fortas, an Associate Justice from 1965 until resigning in 1969, who steered her into a legal career after their marriage in 1935.
Carolyn Eugenia Agger, who was born in New York City, graduated from Barnard College in 1931. After obtaining a master's degree in economics in 1932 at the University of Wisconsin, she worked in staff positions at various New Deal agencies.
She graduated from Yale Law School in 1938 and went into private practice when few women did. She was associated with Lord, Day & Lord and then advanced to a full partnership in Paul, Weiss before moving to Arnold, Fortas & Porter.
Mr. Fortas died in 1982 after 47 years of marriage. There are no immediate survivors.

HEADLINE: Japanese Premier to Name a High-Level Commission to Guide Promised Reforms

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledged today to appoint a blue-ribbon commission this month as the first step toward a major streamlining of the Government and deregulation of the economy.
"The first problem that I want to tackle with the new Cabinet is administrative reform," he said at a news conference, a day after he was formally re-elected in Parliament. 
 "It goes without saying that the socio-economic system that has sustained Japan for the last 50 years since the war is now showing its limits."
"Reforms will lead to a fundamental redesign of the public administration system in Japan," he added. He repeatedly emphasized his seriousness and suggested that the drive for restructuring was different from abortive attempts in the past.
But Mr. Hashimoto gave few specific examples of areas that could be streamlined or deregulated. Commentators and the public alike are skeptical that Mr. Hashimoto and his new Cabinet will really introduce dramatic restructuring.
Calls for political and economic change were a fundamental theme of the general elections last month, in which Mr. Hashimoto's Liberal Democrats won the largest number of seats. But Mr. Hashimoto's Cabinet, appointed on Thursday, seemed to have been chosen primarily on the basis of balancing rival political factions, and very few of the new Cabinet members have ever in the past shown zeal for sweeping change.
The centerpiece of Mr. Hashimoto's speech today was the promise of the new commission, which is to report back in a year. The commission will be directly under the Prime Minister and will cut across ministerial lines. Its members will be drawn from business and academia, with no bureaucrats allowed.
The proposals made by the commission are then to be presented to Parliament in 1998 and, ideally, will be put in place by 2001, Mr. Hashimoto said.
In the past, however, the problem has not been generating ideas for restructuring, but putting them into effect. Japanese libraries are full of studies and reports calling for change, but any of the proposals would harm powerful interests.
"In any bold reforms, resistance and opposition grow fierce," Mr. Hashimoto said, adding that his proposal would require tremendous political determination to carry out.
While his focus was on administrative reform, like reducing the number of ministries, he also talked about economic deregulation.
He especially emphasized the need to deregulate financial markets. "Over the last decade, the world's financial markets have been greatly reformed, but Japan's have been stuck in a rut," he said.
Asked about foreign policy, Mr. Hashimoto said his Government would work hard to reduce the burden of American military bases on Okinawa. In a sign of China's growing importance to Japan, he went out of his way to say his Government would also emphasize a good relationship with Beijing.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ELECTION: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
President Makes It Official: He May Send More Troops to Bosnia Next Year

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he was considering sending more American troops to Bosnia next year as part of a follow-on force to keep the peace, acknowledging something his aides have said for weeks.
NATO military commanders are drawing up detailed recommendations for what kind of force might be required after the current NATO mission, which includes some 16,900 American troops in a total force of about 50,000, expires on Dec. 20. Those troops are leaving gradually and will be out of Bosnia by mid-March, Pentagon officials say. 
 Under consideration is a new and smaller force, under a new mandate to preserve the peace. During the Presidential campaign, Republicans accused Mr. Clinton of waiting until after the election before disclosing his plans to put more troops into Bosnia. Last year, after the Dayton Accords brought peace to Bosnia, the Administration promised that all American troops would be out of Bosnia by this Christmas.
At his first news conference since the election, the President said he was still awaiting NATO's recommendation on what a new force should do, where it should be based and how large it should be.
"It is conceivable that we could participate," he said, "but it depends upon exactly what the recommendation is."
But before deciding, the President said, "we would like to see the proposed mission, we would like to see what our contribution would be. I'm going to assess the risks as I always do and the possible benefits, and then I will make a judgment."
The Atlantic alliance is studying options ranging from having no follow-on force at all to a heavily armed force like the current one. Defense Secretary William J. Perry has said he finds three options to be most plausible: complete withdrawal, without a follow-on force; a force capable of deterring the renewal of serious fighting, but relying on air power, without American ground troops in Bosnia; and a deterrent force also able to provide freedom of movement for Bosnians, which would require ground troops.
Most American officials and alliance diplomats think the last option is most likely. They suggest that a more lightly armed follow-on force of some 20,000 troops, including perhaps 5,000 Americans, could keep Bosnia stable and allow its new Government a better chance to take hold. Britain and France insist they will not field troops if the United States does not. But some American officials want to explore the possibility of keeping all or most Americans on standby outside Bosnia, in Germany, Croatia or Hungary, for example.
On other foreign topics, Mr. Clinton spoke optimistically about a larger Middle East peace once the Israelis and Palestinians can complete an agreement on an Israeli withdrawal of troops from most of the West Bank city of Hebron, where about 450 Israeli settlers live amid more than 100,000 Palestinians.
"If we can clear the Hebron hurdle -- it has such emotional significance to both sides as well as such practical significance -- I believe that will open the door to go on and fulfill all the other challenges that are there before us," he said.
He also promised to continue to work on bringing peace to Northern Ireland, but emphasized that "a genuine cessation of violence" was a prerequisite.
"All the parties have to be able to rely on one another not to start killing again, either in Northern Ireland or Great Britain, in order for this peace process to go forward," he said.
Mr. Clinton said he wanted a new Secretary of State who would have the qualities of a magician and an athlete, able to solve difficult issues from terrorism to expanding trade, and, like Warren Christopher, withstand "the rigors of intense travel, followed by intense meetings, followed by more intense travel."
The President said he would emphasize the building of "the first undivided democratic Europe in history," through a successful expansion of NATO that "solidifies our partnership with a democratic Russia, instead of undermining it"; peacemaking in the Middle East, Northern Ireland and Bosnia; handling the global threats of terrorism, organized crime and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and finally, "to take advantage of the extraordinary economic opportunities for the United States in building a global economic structure that is increasingly more open and fair, that will stabilize the rest of the world, and help America's prosperity to continue."
Mr. Clinton concluded his riff this way: "So I want a Secretary of State that can do all that. I guess that means I want a magician."

HEADLINE: The Tony Store That Poon Built;
Savior of Harvey Nichols Has His Eye on Barneys

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The scene would be absolutely familiar to viewers of the British television show "Absolutely Fabulous." Edina and Patsy, the two vodka-swigging fashion-victim protagonists, are heading for Edina's office in her limousine, when Patsy tunes in to her inner voice, the one crying out: "I must go shopping!" She turns to Edina. Why not stop just for a minute, she wheedles, at Harvey Nicks?
The two always do go to Harvey Nicks -- or Harvey Nichols, as the sleek London department store is officially called -- emerging hours later tipsy with wine from the black-and-chrome bar and laden with $1,300-and-up clothes from designers like Christian Lacroix and Dolce & Gabbana. They have succumbed, it seems, to what their favorite department store itself proudly calls "the Harvey Nichols experience." 
 Why they head for Harvey Nichols and not, say, Harrods -- which stands like an enormous dowager ship just down Brompton Road in the tony Knightsbridge section of London -- is due more than anything else to the leadership of Dickson Poon, the flamboyant Hong Kong billionaire whose company, Dickson Concepts (International) Ltd., bought the store in 1991. Not only has Mr. Poon -- who has a 51 percent stake in Dickson Concepts -- presided over Harvey Nichols's transformation from a past-its-prime department store into a mecca for the trendily well-heeled, but he also has, in the space of five years, turned it into a true financial success story.
That combination presumably is what Mr. Poon figures he could bring to Barneys New York, the fashionable American chain in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings for which he reportedly bid $350 million this summer in Dickson Concepts' first foray into the United States.
Should the sale go through -- an outcome that is by no means certain, with Saks Fifth Avenue, Neiman Marcus and possibly others also looking at a deal -- Barneys would be just the latest acquisition in Mr. Poon's vast empire, an array of boutiques and restaurants spreading outward from Hong Kong into China, Taiwan, Indonesia and Japan.
Some people close to the Barneys situation say Mr. Poon, miffed over public disclosure of his interest, has grumbled that he just might not want to buy the New York retailer after all. But these people also say that negotiations are continuing full force.
In Britain, Mr. Poon has cause to be proud of Harvey Nichols's financial performance. In 1991, the company posted an operating loss of $6.3 million; for the fiscal year ended last March, it showed an operating profit of $14.9 million. Sales per square foot have steadily increased, to $945 in the 1996 fiscal year. (By comparison, Harrods did about $805 of sales per square foot for the fiscal year ended last January.) Meanwhile, net sales soared -- from $83.5 million in the 1993 fiscal year, to $137.1 million in the 1996 fiscal year.
In April, Mr. Poon floated 49.9 percent of the company on the London Stock Exchange at slightly above $4 a share, giving the company a valuation of $224.2 million -- or nearly triple his company's initial investment. Since then, the shares have risen to 342.5 pence.
This week, Mr. Poon announced plans to list its wholly owned S. T. Dupont subsidiary, a French manufacturer of men's wear and other items, on the Paris stock exchange, a step he said would add to Dickson Concepts' $90 million cash hoard for future acquisitions.
Harvey Nichols's contribution to this rosy financial picture is due, analysts and people in the fashion business say, to the impeccable retailing sense of Dickson Poon and the keen financial acumen of his top lieutenant at the store, Joseph Wan, the chief executive.
"Harvey Nichols has changed very dramatically in the last five years," said Hayley Owen, a 33-year-old bridal designer, shopping there at lunchtime earlier this week. "It was a little old-fashioned, a little staid. But now it's young, it's vibrant, it's trendy, and the clothes are of great quality. Plus, they have a brilliant food hall."
It was in 1991, at the height of Britain's grinding recession, that Mr. Poon defied conventional wisdom by paying some $157 million for the ailing Harvey Nichols. The store by then was a musty 178 years old, having started as a family-owned linen shop and then gradually expanding to become a 150,000-square-foot department store, focused on clothing. In 1985, the Burton Group, a retailer based in London, bought it from its then-owner, Debenhams, but its reputation remained second-rate and its financial outlook was poor.
"Everybody said he wouldn't be able to do anything with it," Amit Thakar, a small companies analyst with ABN Amro Hoare Govett, said of Mr. Poon. "And within three years the business was turned around totally."
Victoria Melendez, the Britain retail analyst for Morgan Stanley, which advised the company on the initial public offering, attributes the turnaround to three things: a multimillion-dollar modernization and refurbishment program, strict inventory and cost controls, and a changed sales mix that leans more heavily toward concession sales.
First off, Mr. Poon announced that he had had it with the store's dowdy, downscale image. "When Dickson took over, he said, 'I want you to make this the most up-market store in Europe,' " said Mary Portas, Harvey Nichols's marketing services director. "Under the Burton Group, rightly or wrongly, the store had gone more mass market. We went for the biggest market share of the smallest group."
The store was revitalized, floor by floor. On the top floor, traditionally considered a department store wasteland, the management closed down the sleepy carpet department and unprofitable beauty salon, and summarily moved the space-consuming executive offices to another building.
The move opened up some 25,000 square feet of retail space, which was transformed into a food fetishist's paradise, with a restaurant, coffee bar, and cafe that attract London's bold and beautiful (among them Harvey Nichols's highest-profile customer, the Princess of Wales herself). Mr. Poon also created a less unwieldy version of the famous Harrods food hall, with hard-to-find imported goods at steep prices (a 6-ounce . bag of Nestle's chocolate chips sells for nearly $5), expensive meat and produce, and an array of Harvey Nichols's own foods in silvery containers.
The other floors also underwent almost $17 million worth of repainting, refurbishing and reconfiguring. Big-name designers like Ralph Lauren, Moschino and Vivienne Westwood were brought in to help woo the store's target customers -- not the tourists who favor Harrods, but women who live within a 10-mile radius of the store and are willing to pay about $1,600 for, say, a velvet Vivienne Westwood skirt with an enormous bustle.
"Harvey Nichols became a directional, fashion-forward store," said Helen David, whose English Eccentrics label sells upper-end clothes, like $1,000 velvet devore black-and-silver evening wraps, at Harvey Nichols. "Their customers are the type who rush in at the earliest possible moment to see what's there. We can sell long velvet dresses in heat waves in June, because they're new in the store."
As the store upgraded its goods, it also spiffed up its image. It put up dramatic window displays, such as an enormous silver fish made of cans and extending across all the windows. It created sharp, witty advertisements, using a model dressed entirely in spaghetti to herald the opening of the food hall, for instance.
Unlike some cutting-edge stores -- Barneys comes to mind, with its sometimes scary ambiance -- Harvey Nichols is designed to welcome, not intimidate. "Retail comes down to gut feeling," Ms. Portas said. "You put glamour, sex, slightly radical and leading-edge images in the window, but when you get inside you've got to make people feel comfortable, that it's an environment they can feel safe in."
At the same time, all the new features were designed to create what Ms. Portas calls a "shopping experience" that encourages customers to proceed from coffee in the basement, through the fashion racks, to a fashionable meal on the fifth floor.
The store also began taking tough financial measures, including cutting payroll costs, trimming executive perks and bringing in more concessions -- individual retailers who sell their own products, using their own staff, in the store. (Presumably it is this kind of management prowess that Mr. Poon would bring to Barneys.) In return for the space, the concession-holders pay Harvey Nichols a service charge and a percentage of sales, subject to a guaranteed minimum amount.
Harvey Nichols now has about 70 concessions that account for about 40 percent of nonfood sales, a figure that is a bit higher than for comparable stores. While somewhat lowering the store's gross profit margins, analysts say, the increased concessions have given the store a steady stream of income and allowed it to drastically lower its inventory, reducing the need for money-losing discounting.
"There is a monitoring process that wasn't there before, with incentives for concessions to perform well," Mr. Thakar said approvingly. "If the concessions don't perform well, they're kicked out of the store."
But the arrangement seems to work for the concessions, too. "Harvey Nichols has very loyal customers who will go in to the store and do all their shopping, rather than walking up and down the street," said Nancy Oakley, a spokeswoman for Nicole Farhi, the London designer. "It's like a complete luxury, the idea of shopping there."
In recent months, Dickson Concepts has expanded in Britain, opening an already popular restaurant, Oxo Tower, on the South Bank of the Thames and, in October, opening a second Harvey Nichols store in Leeds, a city whose residents were apparently crying out for the chance to buy shiny Jean Paul Gaultier shirts for about $575 apiece. Though the company has not yet released sales figures, the early signs are good: on the first day, the store was so crowded that guards had to close the doors and let in customers in batches, every 30 minutes.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 36; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 633 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
For Japan's Auto Makers, Windfall From Yen

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 8

 BODY:
A sharp fall in the value of the yen in the last year has been providing an earnings windfall to Japan's major automobile companies.
Owing largely to currency fluctuations, the Toyota Motor Corporation reported today that net income for the first half of its fiscal year more than quadrupled as automobile exports surged. The Nissan Motor Company, meanwhile, recorded a first-half profit for the first time in five years. 
 Even with the help of currency, however, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation reported a 26.3 percent first-half decline in net income as its sales in its home market declined.
Toyota, Japan's largest automobile manufacturer, said its unconsolidated net income for the six months ended Sept. 30 reached 131.5 billion yen, or $1.17 billion, its highest level since the tail end of Japan's bubble economy in 1990. Sales rose 9.6 percent, to 4.08 trillion yen, or $36.46 billion.
Operating income grew more than sevenfold, to 205.4 billion yen, or $1.83 billion. But 140 billion yen of that gain resulted from the fact that a given amount of dollar-based sales overseas was worth a lot more yen this year than last year. The currency rates averaged 108 yen to the dollar in the first half of this year compared with 89 yen to the dollar a year earlier.
The weakening yen also helped Toyota register a stunning 17.1 percent increase in exports, as measured by units, more than offsetting the company's slight decline in sales in its home market. Paced by strong demand for its 4Runner and RAV4 sport utility vehicles, Toyota's exports to the United States rose 12.1 percent, to 228,000 units in the half.
Auto exports from Japan have been declining steadily in the last few years as the yen had strengthened and as the companies moved production offshore. Now the export slide has halted, and might even be reversing, which could heat up trade tensions. Exports for the Japanese automobile industry as a whole, however, are nowhere near as strong as for Toyota and many executives say the long-term trend is still to move more manufacturing out of Japan.
Exports by Nissan, for instance, declined by 9.5 percent in the first half as measured in units. Its domestic vehicle sales also declined 2.8 percent.
Yet thanks to currency changes and cost-cutting it recorded a net profit of 11.6 billion yen, or $103.5 million, compared with a loss the year before of 13.4 billion yen. Sales were 1.74 trillion yen, or $15.5 billion, up 1.5 percent.
Mitsubishi said its net income was 7.90 billion yen, or $70.5 million, down 26.3 percent. Sales fell 8.1 percent, to 1.18 trillion yen, or $10.5 billion.
The results for all the companies were for the parent company only, meaning they excluded subsidiaries like Toyota's manufacturing operation in Kentucky and Nissan's in Tennessee. Nissan officials said the company had also returned to the black on a consolidated basis.
There are now signs the currency windfall will shrink. On Thursday the dollar tumbled more than 2 yen, to 111.6 yen, amid speculation that the United States and Japanese Governments would relax their support for a strong dollar. Toyota said it expected a further decline, with an average currency rate of 105 yen to the dollar in the second half.
Even without the currency tail wind, Toyota looks to be in a strong position. It has recently introduced several fast-selling vehicles in Japan. It revised upward its forecast results for the full year.
Nissan and Mitsubishi, however, revised some projections downward, saying it was difficult to sell in the fiercely competitive Japanese market. The two companies are losing out to Toyota and Honda, which is rapidly expanding its market share on the strength of its popular new sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and station wagons.
